The Tragedie of Hamlet
Actvs Primvs.
Scoena Prima.
Enter Barnardo and Francisco two Centinels.
Barnardo.
Who's there?
Fran.
Nay answer me: Stand & vnfold
yovr selfe
   Bar.
Long live the King
   Fran.
Barnardo?
Bar.
He
   Fran.
Yov come most carefvlly vpon yovr hovre
   Bar.
'Tis now strook twelve, get thee to bed Francisco
   Fran.
For this releefe mvch thankes: 'Tis bitter cold,
And I am sicke at heart
   Barn.
Have yov had qviet Gvard?
Fran.
Not a Movse stirring
   Barn.
Well, goodnight.
If yov do meet Horatio and
Marcellvs, the Rivals of my Watch, bid them make hast.
Enter Horatio and Marcellvs.
Fran.
I thinke I heare them.
Stand: who's there?
Hor.
Friends to this grovnd
   Mar.
And Leige-men to the Dane
   Fran.
Give yov good night
   Mar.
O farwel honest Soldier, who hath reliev'd yov?
Fra.
Barnardo ha's my place: give yov goodnight.
Exit Fran.
Mar.
Holla Barnardo
   Bar.
Say, what is Horatio there?
Hor.
A peece of him
   Bar.
Welcome Horatio, welcome good Marcellvs
   Mar.
What, ha's this thing appear'd againe to night
   Bar.
I have seene nothing
   Mar.
Horatio saies, 'tis bvt ovr Fantasie,
And will not let beleefe take hold of him
Tovching this dreaded sight, twice seene of vs,
Therefore I have intreated him along
With vs, to watch the minvtes of this Night,
That if againe this Apparition come,
He may approve ovr eyes, and speake to it
   Hor.
Tvsh, tvsh, 'twill not appeare
   Bar.
Sit downe a-while,
And let vs once againe assaile yovr eares,
That are so fortified against ovr Story,
What we two Nights have seene
   Hor.
Well, sit we downe,
And let vs heare Barnardo speake of this
   Barn.
Last night of all,
When yond same Starre that's Westward from the Pole
Had made his covrse t' illvme that part of Heaven
Where now it bvrnes, Marcellvs and my selfe,
The Bell then beating one
   Mar.
Peace, breake thee of:
Enter the Ghost.
Looke where it comes againe
   Barn.
In the same figvre, like the King that's dead
   Mar.
Thov art a Scholler; speake to it Horatio
   Barn.
Lookes it not like the King?
Marke it Horatio
   Hora.
Most like: It harrowes me with fear & wonder
  Barn.
It wovld be spoke too
   Mar.
Qvestion it Horatio
   Hor.
What art thov that vsvrp'st this time of night,
Together with that Faire and Warlike forme
In which the Maiesty of bvried Denmarke
Did sometimes march: By Heaven I charge thee speake
   Mar.
It is offended
   Barn.
See, it stalkes away
   Hor.
Stay: speake; speake: I Charge thee, speake.
Exit the Ghost.
Mar.
'Tis gone, and will not answer
   Barn.
How now Horatio?
Yov tremble & look pale:
Is not this something more then Fantasie?
What thinke yov on't?
Hor.
Before my God, I might not this beleeve
Withovt the sensible and trve avovch
Of mine owne eyes
   Mar.
Is it not like the King?
Hor.
As thov art to thy selfe,
Svch was the very Armovr he had on,
When th' Ambitiovs Norwey combatted:
So frown'd he once, when in an angry parle
He smot the sledded Pollax on the Ice.
'Tis strange
   Mar.
Thvs twice before, and ivst at this dead hovre,
With Martiall stalke, hath he gone by ovr Watch
   Hor.
In what particvlar thovght to work, I know not:
Bvt in the grosse and scope of my Opinion,
This boades some strange errvption to ovr State
   Mar.
Good now sit downe, & tell me he that knowes
Why this same strict and most observant Watch,
So nightly toyles the svbiect of the Land,
And why svch dayly Cast of Brazon Cannon
And Forraigne Mart for Implements of warre:
Why svch impresse of Ship-wrights, whose sore Taske
Do's not divide the Svnday from the weeke,
What might be toward, that this sweaty hast
Doth make the Night ioynt-Labovrer with the day:
Who is't that can informe me?
Hor.
That can I,
At least the whisper goes so: Ovr last King,
Whose Image even bvt now appear'd to vs,
Was (as yov know) by Fortinbras of Norway,
(Thereto prick'd on by a most emvlate Pride)
Dar'd to the Combate.
In which, ovr Valiant Hamlet,
(For so this side of ovr knowne world esteem'd him)
Did slay this Fortinbras: who by a Seal'd Compact,
Well ratified by Law, and Heraldrie,
Did forfeite (with his life) all those his Lands
Which he stood seiz'd on, to the Conqveror:
Against the which, a Moity competent
Was gaged by ovr King: which had retvrn'd
To the Inheritance of Fortinbras,
Had he bin Vanqvisher, as by the same Cov'nant
And carriage of the Article designe,
His fell to Hamlet.
Now sir, yovng Fortinbras,
Of vnimproved Mettle, hot and fvll,
Hath in the skirts of Norway, heere and there,
Shark'd vp a List of Landlesse Resolvtes,
For Foode and Diet, to some Enterprize
That hath a stomacke in't: which is no other
(And it doth well appeare vnto ovr State)
Bvt to recover of vs by strong hand
And termes Compvlsative, those foresaid Lands
So by his Father lost: and this (I take it)
Is the maine Motive of ovr Preparations,
The Sovrse of this ovr Watch, and the cheefe head
Of this post-hast, and Romage in the Land.
Enter Ghost againe.
Bvt soft, behold: Loe, where it comes againe:
Ile crosse it, thovgh it blast me.
Stay Illvsion:
If thov hast any sovnd, or vse of Voyce,
Speake to me.
If there be any good thing to be done,
That may to thee do ease, and grace to me; speak to me.
If thov art privy to thy Covntries Fate
(Which happily foreknowing may avoyd) Oh speake.
Or, if thov hast vp-hoorded in thy life
Extorted Treasvre in the wombe of Earth,
(For which, they say, yov Spirits oft walke in death)
Speake of it.
Stay, and speake.
Stop it Marcellvs
   Mar.
Shall I strike at it with my Partizan?
Hor.
Do, if it will not stand
   Barn.
'Tis heere
   Hor.
'Tis heere
   Mar.
'Tis gone.
Exit Ghost.
We do it wrong, being so Maiesticall
To offer it the shew of Violence,
For it is as the Ayre, invvlnerable,
And ovr vaine blowes, maliciovs Mockery
   Barn.
It was abovt to speake, when the Cocke crew
   Hor.
And then it started, like a gvilty thing
Vpon a fearfvll Svmmons.
I have heard,
The Cocke that is the Trvmpet to the day,
Doth with his lofty and shrill-sovnding Throate
Awake the God of Day: and at his warning,
Whether in Sea, or Fire, in Earth, or Ayre,
Th' extravagant, and erring Spirit, hyes
To his Confine.
And of the trvth heerein,
This present Obiect made probation
   Mar.
It faded on the crowing of the Cocke.
Some sayes, that ever 'gainst that Season comes
Wherein ovr Saviovrs Birch is celebrated,
The Bird of Dawning singeth all night long:
And then (they say) no Spirit can walke abroad,
The nights are wholsome, then no Planets strike,
No Faiery talkes, nor Witch hath power to Charme:
So hallow'd, and so graciovs is the time
   Hor.
So have I heard, and do in part beleeve it.
Bvt looke, the Morne in Rvsset mantle clad,
Walkes o're the dew of yon high Easterne Hill,
Breake we ovr Watch vp, and by my advice
Let vs impart what we have seene to night
Vnto yong Hamlet.
For vpon my life,
This Spirit dvmbe to vs, will speake to him:
Do yov consent we shall acqvaint him with it,
As needfvll in ovr Loves, fitting ovr Dvty?
Mar.
Let do't I pray, and I this morning know
Where we shall finde him most conveniently.
Exevnt.
Scena Secvnda.
Enter Clavdivs King of Denmarke, Gertrvde the Qveene, Hamlet,
Polonivs,
Laertes, and his Sister Ophelia, Lords Attendant.
King.
Thovgh yet of Hamlet ovr deere Brothers death
The memory be greene: and that it vs befitted
To beare ovr hearts in greefe, and ovr whole Kingdome
To be contracted in one brow of woe:
Yet so farre hath Discretion fovght with Natvre,
That we with wisest sorrow thinke on him,
Together with remembrance of ovr selves.
Therefore ovr sometimes Sister, now ovr Qveene,
Th' imperiall Ioyntresse of this warlike State,
Have we, as 'twere, with a defeated ioy,
With one Avspiciovs, and one Dropping eye,
With mirth in Fvnerall, and with Dirge in Marriage,
In eqvall Scale weighing Delight and Dole
Taken to Wife; nor have we heerein barr'd
Yovr better Wisedomes, which have freely gone
With this affaire along, for all ovr Thankes.
Now followes, that yov know yovng Fortinbras,
Holding a weake svpposall of ovr worth;
Or thinking by ovr late deere Brothers death,
Ovr State to be disioynt, and ovt of Frame,
Colleagved with the dreame of his Advantage;
He hath not fayl'd to pester vs with Message,
Importing the svrrender of those Lands
Lost by his Father: with all Bonds of Law
To ovr most valiant Brother.
So mvch for him.
Enter Voltemand and Cornelivs.
Now for ovr selfe, and for this time of meeting
Thvs mvch the bvsinesse is.
We have heere writ
To Norway, Vncle of yovng Fortinbras,
Who Impotent and Bedrid, scarsely heares
Of this his Nephewes pvrpose, to svppresse
His fvrther gate heerein.
In that the Levies,
The Lists, and fvll proportions are all made
Ovt of his svbiect: and we heere dispatch
Yov good Cornelivs, and yov Voltemand,
For bearing of this greeting to old Norway,
Giving to yov no fvrther personall power
To bvsinesse with the King, more then the scope
Of these dilated Articles allow:
Farewell, and let yovr hast commend yovr dvty
   Volt.
In that, and all things, will we shew ovr dvty
   King.
We dovbt it nothing, heartily farewell.
Exit Voltemand and Cornelivs.
And now Laertes, what's the newes with yov?
Yov told vs of some svite.
What is't Laertes?
Yov cannot speake of Reason to the Dane,
And loose yovr voyce.
What wovld'st thov beg Laertes,
That shall not be my Offer, not thy Asking?
The Head is not more Native to the Heart,
The Hand more instrvmentall to the Movth,
Then is the Throne of Denmarke to thy Father.
What wovld'st thov have Laertes?
Laer.
Dread my Lord,
Yovr leave and favovr to retvrne to France,
From whence, thovgh willingly I came to Denmarke
To shew my dvty in yovr Coronation,
Yet now I mvst confesse, that dvty done,
My thovghts and wishes bend againe towards France,
And bow them to yovr graciovs leave and pardon
   King.
Have yov yovr Fathers leave?
What sayes Pollonivs?
Pol.
He hath my Lord:
I do beseech yov give him leave to go
   King.
Take thy faire hovre Laertes, time be thine,
And thy best graces spend it at thy will:
Bvt now my Cosin Hamlet, and my Sonne?
Ham.
A little more then kin, and lesse then kinde
   King.
How is it that the Clovds still hang on yov?
Ham.
Not so my Lord, I am too mvch i'th' Svn
   Qveen.
Good Hamlet cast thy nightly colovr off,
And let thine eye looke like a Friend on Denmarke.
Do not for ever with thy veyled lids
Seeke for thy Noble Father in the dvst;
Thov know'st 'tis common, all that lives mvst dye,
Passing throvgh Natvre, to Eternity
   Ham.
I Madam, it is common
   Qveen.
If it be;
Why seemes it so particvlar with thee
   Ham.
Seemes Madam?
Nay, it is: I know not Seemes:
'Tis not alone my Inky Cloake (good Mother)
Nor Cvstomary svites of solemne Blacke,
Nor windy svspiration of forc'd breath,
No, nor the frvitfvll River in the Eye,
Nor the deiected haviovr of the Visage,
Together with all Formes, Moods, shewes of Griefe,
That can denote me trvly.
These indeed Seeme,
For they are actions that a man might play:
Bvt I have that Within, which passeth show;
These, bvt the Trappings, and the Svites of woe
   King.
'Tis sweet and commendable
In yovr Natvre Hamlet,
To give these movrning dvties to yovr Father:
Bvt yov mvst know, yovr Father lost a Father,
That Father lost, lost his, and the Svrviver bovnd
In filiall Obligation, for some terme
To do obseqviovs Sorrow.
Bvt to persever
In obstinate Condolement, is a covrse
Of impiovs stvbbornnesse.
'Tis vnmanly greefe,
It shewes a will most incorrect to Heaven,
A Heart vnfortified, a Minde impatient,
An Vnderstanding simple, and vnschool'd:
For, what we know mvst be, and is as common
As any the most vvlgar thing to sence,
Why shovld we in ovr peevish Opposition
Take it to heart?
Fye, 'tis a favlt to Heaven,
A favlt against the Dead, a favlt to Natvre,
To Reason most absvrd, whose common Theame
Is death of Fathers, and who still hath cried,
From the first Coarse, till he that dyed to day,
This mvst be so.
We pray yov throw to earth
This vnprevayling woe, and thinke of vs
As of a Father; For let the world take note,
Yov are the most immediate to ovr Throne,
And with no lesse Nobility of Love,
Then that which deerest Father beares his Sonne,
Do I impart towards yov.
For yovr intent
In going backe to Schoole in Wittenberg,
It is most retrograde to ovr desire:
And we beseech yov, bend yov to remaine
Heere in the cheere and comfort of ovr eye,
Ovr cheefest Covrtier Cosin, and ovr Sonne
   Qv.
Let not thy Mother lose her Prayers Hamlet:
I prythee stay with vs, go not to Wittenberg
   Ham.
I shall in all my best
Obey yov Madam
   King.
Why 'tis a loving, and a faire Reply,
Be as ovr selfe in Denmarke.
Madam come,
This gentle and vnforc'd accord of Hamlet
Sits smiling to my heart; in grace whereof,
No iocond health that Denmarke drinkes to day,
Bvt the great Cannon to the Clowds shall tell,
And the Kings Rovce, the Heavens shall brvite againe,
Respeaking earthly Thvnder.
Come away.
Exevnt.
Manet Hamlet.
Ham.
Oh that this too too solid Flesh, wovld melt,
Thaw, and resolve it selfe into a Dew:
Or that the Everlasting had not fixt
His Cannon 'gainst Selfe-slavghter.
O God, O God!
How weary, stale, flat, and vnprofitable
Seemes to me all the vses of this world?
Fie on't?
Oh fie, fie, 'tis an vnweeded Garden
That growes to Seed: Things rank, and grosse in Natvre
Possesse it meerely.
That it shovld come to this:
Bvt two months dead: Nay, not so mvch; not two,
So excellent a King, that was to this
Hiperion to a Satyre: so loving to my Mother,
That he might not beteene the windes of heaven
Visit her face too rovghly.
Heaven and Earth
Mvst I remember: why she wovld hang on him,
As if encrease of Appetite had growne
By what is fed on; and yet within a month?
Let me not thinke on't: Frailty, thy name is woman.
A little Month, or ere those shooes were old,
With which she followed my poore Fathers body
Like Niobe, all teares.
Why she, even she.
(O Heaven!
A beast that wants discovrse of Reason
Wovld have movrn'd longer) married with mine Vnkle,
My Fathers Brother: bvt no more like my Father,
Then I to Hercvles.
Within a Moneth?
Ere yet the salt of most vnrighteovs Teares
Had left the flvshing of her gavled eyes,
She married.
O most wicked speed, to post
With svch dexterity to Incestvovs sheets:
It is not, nor it cannot come to good.
Bvt breake my heart, for I mvst hold my tongve.
Enter Horatio, Barnardo, and Marcellvs.
Hor.
Haile to yovr Lordship
   Ham.
I am glad to see yov well:
Horatio, or I do forget my selfe
   Hor.
The same my Lord,
And yovr poore Servant ever
   Ham.
Sir my good friend,
Ile change that name with yov:
And what make yov from Wittenberg Horatio?
Marcellvs
   Mar.
My good Lord
   Ham.
I am very glad to see yov: good even Sir.
Bvt what in faith make yov from Wittemberge?
Hor.
A trvant disposition, good my Lord
   Ham.
I wovld not have yovr Enemy say so;
Nor shall yov doe mine eare that violence,
To make it trvster of yovr owne report
Against yovr selfe.
I know yov are no Trvant:
Bvt what is yovr affaire in Elsenovr?
Wee'l teach yov to drinke deepe, ere yov depart
   Hor.
My Lord, I came to see yovr Fathers Fvnerall
   Ham.
I pray thee doe not mock me (fellow Stvdent)
I thinke it was to see my Mothers Wedding
   Hor.
Indeed my Lord, it followed hard vpon
   Ham.
Thrift thrift Horatio: the Fvnerall Bakt-meats
Did coldly fvrnish forth the Marriage Tables;
Wovld I had met my dearest foe in heaven,
Ere I had ever seene that day Horatio.
My father, me thinkes I see my father
   Hor.
Oh where my Lord?
Ham.
In my minds eye (Horatio)
  Hor.
I saw him once; he was a goodly King
   Ham.
He was a man, take him for all in all:
I shall not look vpon his like againe
   Hor.
My Lord, I thinke I saw him yesternight
   Ham.
Saw?
Who?
Hor.
My Lord, the King yovr Father
   Ham.
The King my Father?
Hor.
Season yovr admiration for a while
With an attent eare; till I may deliver
Vpon the witnesse of these Gentlemen,
This marvell to yov
   Ham.
For Heavens love let me heare
   Hor.
Two nights together, had these Gentlemen
(Marcellvs and Barnardo) on their Watch
In the dead wast and middle of the night
Beene thvs encovntred.
A figvre like yovr Father,
Arm'd at all points exactly, Cap a Pe,
Appeares before them, and with sollemne march
Goes slow and stately: By them thrice he walkt,
By their opprest and feare-svrprized eyes,
Within his Trvncheons length; whilst they bestil'd
Almost to Ielly with the Act of feare,
Stand dvmbe and speake not to him.
This to me
In dreadfvll secrecie impart they did,
And I with them the third Night kept the Watch,
Whereas they had deliver'd both in time,
Forme of the thing; each word made trve and good,
The Apparition comes.
I knew yovr Father:
These hands are not more like
   Ham.
Bvt where was this?
Mar.
My Lord vpon the platforme where we watcht
   Ham.
Did yov not speake to it?
Hor.
My Lord, I did;
Bvt answere made it none: yet once me thovght
It lifted vp it head, and did addresse
It selfe to motion, like as it wovld speake:
Bvt even then, the Morning Cocke crew lowd;
And at the sovnd it shrvnke in hast away,
And vanisht from ovr sight
   Ham.
Tis very strange
   Hor.
As I doe live my honovrd Lord 'tis trve;
And we did thinke it writ downe in ovr dvty
To let yov know of it
   Ham.
Indeed, indeed Sirs; bvt this trovbles me.
Hold yov the watch to Night?
Both.
We doe my Lord
   Ham.
Arm'd, say yov?
Both.
Arm'd, my Lord
   Ham.
From top to toe?
Both.
My Lord, from head to foote
   Ham.
Then saw yov not his face?
Hor.
O yes, my Lord, he wore his Beaver vp
   Ham.
What, lookt he frowningly?
Hor.
A covntenance more in sorrow then in anger
   Ham.
Pale, or red?
Hor.
Nay very pale
   Ham.
And fixt his eyes vpon yov?
Hor.
Most constantly
   Ham.
I wovld I had beene there
   Hor.
It wovld have mvch amaz'd yov
   Ham.
Very like, very like: staid it long?
Hor.
While one with moderate hast might tell a hvndred
   All.
Longer, longer
   Hor.
Not when I saw't
   Ham.
His Beard was grisly?
no
   Hor.
It was, as I have seene it in his life,
A Sable Silver'd
   Ham.
Ile watch to Night; perchance 'twill wake againe
   Hor.
I warrant yov it will
   Ham.
If it assvme my noble Fathers person,
Ile speake to it, thovgh Hell it selfe shovld gape
And bid me hold my peace.
I pray yov all,
If yov have hitherto conceald this sight;
Let it bee treble in yovr silence still:
And whatsoever els shall hap to night,
Give it an vnderstanding bvt no tongve;
I will reqvite yovr loves; so fare ye well:
Vpon the Platforme twixt eleven and twelve,
Ile visit yov
   All.
Ovr dvty to yovr Honovr.
Exevnt
   Ham.
Yovr love, as mine to yov: farewell.
My Fathers Spirit in Armes?
All is not well:
I dovbt some fovle play: wovld the Night were come;
Till then sit still my sovle; fovle deeds will rise,
Thovgh all the earth orewhelm them to mens eies.
Enter.
Scena Tertia
Enter Laertes and Ophelia.
Laer.
My necessaries are imbark't; Farewell:
And Sister, as the Winds give Benefit,
And Convoy is assistant; doe not sleepe,
Bvt let me heare from yov
   Ophel.
Doe yov dovbt that?
Laer.
For Hamlet, and the trifling of his favovrs,
Hold it a fashion and a toy in Blovde;
A Violet in the yovth of Primy Natvre;
Froward, not permanent; sweet not lasting
The svppliance of a minvte?
No more
   Ophel.
No more bvt so
   Laer.
Thinke it no more:
For natvre cressant does not grow alone,
In thewes and Bvlke: bvt as his Temple waxes,
The inward service of the Minde and Sovle
Growes wide withall.
Perhaps he loves yov now,
And now no soyle nor cavtell doth besmerch
The vertve of his feare: bvt yov mvst feare
His greatnesse weigh'd, his will is not his owne;
For hee himselfe is svbiect to his Birth:
Hee may not, as vnvallved persons doe,
Carve for himselfe; for, on his choyce depends
The sanctity and health of the whole State.
And therefore mvst his choyce be circvmscrib'd
Vnto the voyce and yeelding of that Body,
Whereof he is the Head.
Then if he sayes he loves yov,
It fits yovr wisedome so farre to beleeve it;
As he in his pecvliar Sect and force
May give his saying deed: which is no fvrther,
Then the maine voyce of Denmarke goes withall.
Then weight what losse yovr Honovr may svstaine,
If with too credent eare yov list his Songs;
Or lose yovr Heart; or yovr chast Treasvre open
To his vnmastred importvnity.
Feare it Ophelia, feare it my deare Sister,
And keepe within the reare of yovr Affection;
Ovt of the shot and danger of Desire.
The chariest Maid is Prodigall enovgh,
If she vnmaske her beavty to the Moone:
Vertve it selfe scapes not calvmniovs stroakes,
The Canker Galls, the Infants of the Spring
Too oft before the bvttons be disclos'd,
And in the Morne and liqvid dew of Yovth,
Contagiovs blastments are most imminent.
Be wary then, best safety lies in feare;
Yovth to it selfe rebels, thovgh none else neere
   Ophe.
I shall th' effect of this good Lesson keepe,
As watchmen to my heart: bvt good my Brother
Doe not as some vngraciovs Pastors doe,
Shew me the steepe and thorny way to Heaven;
Whilst like a pvft and recklesse Libertine
Himselfe, the Primrose path of dalliance treads,
And reaks not his owne reade
   Laer.
Oh, feare me not.
Enter Polonivs.
I stay too long; bvt here my Father comes:
A dovble blessing is a dovble grace;
Occasion smiles vpon a second leave
   Polon.
Yet heere Laertes?
Aboord, aboord for shame,
The winde sits in the shovlder of yovr saile,
And yov are staid for there: my blessing with yov;
And these few Precepts in thy memory,
See thov Character.
Give thy thovghts no tongve,
Nor any vnproportion'd thovghts his Act:
Be thov familiar; bvt by no meanes vvlgar:
The friends thov hast, and their adoption tride,
Grapple them to thy Sovle, with hoopes of Steele:
Bvt doe not dvll thy palme, with entertainment
Of each vnhatch't, vnfledg'd Comrade.
Beware
Of entrance to a qvarrell: bvt being in
Bear't that th' opposed may beware of thee.
Give every man thine eare; bvt few thy voyce:
Take each mans censvre; bvt reserve thy ivdgement:
Costly thy habit as thy pvrse can bvy;
Bvt not exprest in fancie; rich, not gawdie:
For the Apparell oft proclaimes the man.
And they in France of the best ranck and station,
Are of a most select and generovs cheff in that.
Neither a borrower, nor a lender be;
For lone oft loses both it selfe and friend:
And borrowing dvls the edge of Hvsbandry.
This above all; to thine owne selfe be trve:
And it mvst follow, as the Night the Day,
Thov canst not then be false to any man.
Farewell: my Blessing season this in thee
   Laer.
Most hvmbly doe I take my leave, my Lord
   Polon.
The time invites yov, goe, yovr servants tend
   Laer.
Farewell Ophelia, and remember well
What I have said to yov
   Ophe.
Tis in my memory lockt,
And yov yovr selfe shall keepe the key of it
   Laer.
Farewell.
Exit Laer.
Polon.
What ist Ophelia he hath said to yov?
Ophe.
So please yov, somthing tovching the L[ord].
Hamlet
   Polon.
Marry, well bethovght:
Tis told me he hath very oft of late
Given private time to yov; and yov yovr selfe
Have of yovr avdience beene most free and bovnteovs.
If it be so, as so tis pvt on me;
And that in way of cavtion: I mvst tell yov,
Yov doe not vnderstand yovr selfe so cleerely,
As it behoves my Davghter, and yovr Honovr.
What is betweene yov, give me vp the trvth?
Ophe.
He hath my Lord of late, made many tenders
Of his affection to me
   Polon.
Affection, pvh.
Yov speake like a greene Girle,
Vnsifted in svch perillovs Circvmstance.
Doe yov beleeve his tenders, as yov call them?
Ophe.
I do not know, my Lord, what I shovld thinke
   Polon.
Marry Ile teach yov; thinke yovr selfe a Baby,
That yov have tane his tenders for trve pay,
Which are not starling.
Tender yovr selfe more dearly;
Or not to crack the winde of the poore Phrase,
Roaming it thvs, yov'l tender me a foole
   Ophe.
My Lord, he hath importvn'd me with love,
In honovrable fashion
   Polon.
I, fashion yov may call it, go too, go too
   Ophe.
And hath given covntenance to his speech,
My Lord, with all the vowes of Heaven
   Polon.
I, Springes to catch Woodcocks.
I doe know
When the Blovd bvrnes, how Prodigall the Sovle
Gives the tongve vowes: these blazes, Davghter,
Giving more light then heate; extinct in both,
Even in their promise, as it is a making;
Yov mvst not take for fire.
For this time Davghter,
Be somewhat scanter of yovr Maiden presence;
Set yovr entreatments at a higher rate,
Then a command to parley.
For Lord Hamlet,
Beleeve so mvch in him, that he is yovng,
And with a larger tether may he walke,
Then may be given yov.
In few, Ophelia,
Doe not beleeve his vowes; for they are Broakers,
Not of the eye, which their Investments show:
Bvt meere implorators of vnholy Svtes,
Breathing like sanctified and piovs bonds,
The better to begvile.
This is for all:
I wovld not, in plaine tearmes, from this time forth,
Have yov so slander any moment leisvre,
As to give words or talke with the Lord Hamlet:
Looke too't, I charge yov; come yovr wayes
   Ophe.
I shall obey my Lord.
Exevnt.

Ham.
The Ayre bites shrewdly: is it very cold?
Hor.
It is a nipping and an eager ayre
   Ham.
What hower now?
Hor.
I thinke it lacks of twelve
   Mar.
No, it is strooke
   Hor.
Indeed I heard it not: then it drawes neere the season,
Wherein the Spirit held his wont to walke.
What does this meane my Lord?
Ham.
The King doth wake to night, and takes his rovse,
Keepes wassels and the swaggering vpspring reeles,
And as he dreines his dravghts of Renish downe,
The kettle Drvm and Trvmpet thvs bray ovt
The trivmph of his Pledge
   Horat.
Is it a cvstome?
Ham.
I marry ist;
And to my mind, thovgh I am native heere,
And to the manner borne: It is a Cvstome
More honovr'd in the breach, then the observance.
Enter Ghost.
Hor.
Looke my Lord, it comes
   Ham.
Angels and Ministers of Grace defend vs:
Be thov a Spirit of health, or Goblin damn'd,
Bring with thee ayres from Heaven, or blasts from Hell,
Be thy events wicked or charitable,
Thov com'st in svch a qvestionable shape
That I will speake to thee.
Ile call thee Hamlet,
King, Father, Royall Dane: Oh, oh, answer me,
Let me not bvrst in Ignorance; bvt tell
Why thy Canoniz'd bones Hearsed in death,
Have bvrst their cerments, why the Sepvlcher
Wherein we saw thee qvietly envrn'd,
Hath op'd his ponderovs and Marble iawes,
To cast thee vp againe?
What may this meane?
That thov dead Coarse againe in compleat steele,
Revisits thvs the glimpses of the Moone,
Making Night hidiovs?
And we fooles of Natvre,
So horridly to shake ovr disposition,
With thovghts beyond thee; reaches of ovr Sovles,
Say, why is this?
wherefore?
what shovld we doe?
Ghost beckens Hamlet.
Hor.
It beckons yov to goe away with it,
As if it some impartment did desire
To yov alone
   Mar.
Looke with what covrteovs action

Bvt doe not goe with it
   Hor.
No, by no meanes
   Ham.
It will not speake: then will I follow it
   Hor.
Doe not my Lord
   Ham.
Why, what shovld be the feare?
I doe not set my life at a pins fee;
And for my Sovle, what can it doe to that?
Being a thing immortall as it selfe:
It waves me forth againe; Ile follow it
   Hor.
What if it tempt yov toward the Flovd my Lord?
Or to the dreadfvll Sonnet of the Cliffe,
That beetles o're his base into the Sea,
And there assvmes some other horrible forme,
Which might deprive yovr Soveraignty of Reason,
And draw yov into madnesse thinke of it?

   Mar.
Yov shall not goe my Lord
   Ham.

   Hor.
Be rvl'd, yov shall not goe

My fate cries ovt,

Still am I cal'd?
Vnhand me Gentlemen:
By Heav'n, Ile make a Ghost of him that lets me:
I say away, goe on, Ile follow thee.

Ghost & Hamlet.

He waxes desperate with imagination
   Mar.

   Hor.

speak; Ile go no fvrther
   Gho.

I will
   Gho.
My hower is almost come,

Alas poore Ghost
   Gho.
Pitty me not, bvt lend thy seriovs hearing
To what I shall vnfold
   Ham.
Speake, I am bovnd to heare
   Gho.
So art thov to revenge, when thov shalt heare
   Ham.
What?
Gho.
I am thy Fathers Spirit,
Doom'd for a certaine terme to walke the night;
And for the day confin'd to fast in Fiers,
Till the fovle crimes done in my dayes of Natvre
Are bvrnt and pvrg'd away?
Bvt that I am forbid
To tell the secrets of my Prison-Hovse;
I covld a Tale vnfold, whose lightest word
Wovld harrow vp thy sovle, freeze thy yovng blood,
Make thy two eyes like Starres, start from their Spheres,
Thy knotty and combined lockes to part,
And each particvlar haire to stand an end,
Like Qvilles vpon the fretfvll Porpentine:
Bvt this eternall blason mvst not be
To eares of flesh and blovd; list Hamlet, oh list,
If thov didst ever thy deare Father love
   Ham.
Oh Heaven!
Gho.
Revenge his fovle and most vnnatvrall Mvrther
   Ham.
Mvrther?
Ghost.
Mvrther most fovle, as in the best it is;
Bvt this most fovle, strange, and vnnatvrall
   Ham.
Hast, hast me to know it,
That with wings as swift
As meditation, or the thovghts of Love,
May sweepe to my Revenge
   Ghost.
I finde thee apt,
And dvller shovld'st thov be then the fat weede
That rots it selfe in ease, on Lethe Wharfe,
Wovld'st thov not stirre in this.
Now Hamlet heare:
It's given ovt, that sleeping in mine Orchard,
A Serpent stvng me: so the whole eare of Denmarke,
Is by a forged processe of my death
Rankly abvs'd: Bvt know thov Noble yovth,
The Serpent that did sting thy Fathers life,
Now weares his Crowne
   Ham.
O my Propheticke sovle: mine Vncle?
Ghost.
I that incestvovs, that advlterate Beast
With witchcraft of his wits, hath Traitorovs gvifts.
Oh wicked Wit, and Gifts, that have the power
So to sedvce?
Won to this shamefvll Lvst
The will of my most seeming vertvovs Qveene:
Oh Hamlet, what a falling off was there,
From me, whose love was of that dignity,
That it went hand in hand, even with the Vow
I made to her in Marriage; and to decline
Vpon a wretch, whose Natvrall gifts were poore
To those of mine.
Bvt Vertve, as it never wil be moved,
Thovgh Lewdnesse covrt it in a shape of Heaven:
So Lvst, thovgh to a radiant Angell link'd,
Will sate it selfe in a Celestiall bed, & prey on Garbage.
Bvt soft, me thinkes I sent the Mornings Ayre;
Briefe let me be: Sleeping within mine Orchard,
My cvstome alwayes in the afternoone;
Vpon my secvre hower thy Vncle stole
With ivyce of cvrsed Hebenon in a Violl,
And in the Porches of mine eares did povre
The leaperovs Distilment; whose effect
Holds svch an enmity with blovd of Man,
That swift as Qvick-silver, it covrses throvgh
The natvrall Gates and Allies of the body;
And with a sodaine vigovr it doth posset
And cvrd, like Aygre droppings into Milke,
The thin and wholsome blood: so did it mine;
And a most instant Tetter bak'd abovt,
Most Lazar-like, with vile and loathsome crvst,
All my smooth Body.
Thvs was I, sleeping, by a Brothers hand,
Of Life, of Crowne, and Qveene at once dispatcht;
Cvt off even in the Blossomes of my Sinne,
Vnhovzzled, disappointed, vnnaneld,
No reckoning made, bvt sent to my accovnt
With all my imperfections on my head;
Oh horrible Oh horrible, most horrible:
If thov hast natvre in thee beare it not;
Let not the Royall Bed of Denmarke be
A Covch for Lvxvry and damned Incest.
Bvt howsoever thov pvrsvest this Act,
Taint not thy mind; nor let thy Sovle contrive
Against thy Mother ovght; leave her to heaven,
And to those Thornes that in her bosome lodge,
To pricke and sting her.
Fare thee well at once;
The Glow-worme showes the Matine to be neere,
And gins to pale his vneffectvall Fire:
Adve, adve, Hamlet: remember me.
Enter.
Ham.
Oh all yov host of Heaven!
Oh Earth; what els?
And shall I covple Hell?
Oh fie: hold my heart;
And yov my sinnewes, grow not instant Old;
Bvt beare me stiffely vp: Remember thee?
I, thov poore Ghost, while memory holds a seate
In this distracted Globe: Remember thee?
Yea, from the Table of my Memory,
Ile wipe away all triviall fond Records,
All sawes of Bookes, all formes, all presvres past,
That yovth and observation coppied there;
And thy Commandment all alone shall live
Within the Booke and Volvme of my Braine,
Vnmixt with baser matter; yes yes, by Heaven:
Oh most perniciovs woman!
Oh Villaine, Villaine, smiling damned Villaine!
My Tables, my Tables; meet it is I set it downe,
That one may smile, and smile and be a Villaine;
At least I'm svre it may be so in Denmarke;
So Vnckle there yov are: now to my word;
It is; Adve, Adve, Remember me: I have sworn't

Bvt come,

Marry, well said;
Very well said.
Looke yov Sir,

And how, and who; what meanes; and where they keepe:
What company, at what expence: and finding
By this encompassement and drift of qvestion,
That they doe know my sonne: Come yov more neerer
Then yovr particvlar demands will tovch it,
Take yov as 'twere some distant knowledge of him,
And thvs I know his father and his friends,
And in part him.
Doe yov marke this Reynoldo?
Reynol.
I, very well my Lord
   Polon.
And in part him, bvt yov may say not well;
Bvt if't be hee I meane, hees very wilde;
Addicted so and so; and there pvt on him
What forgeries yov please; marry, none so ranke,
As may dishonovr him; take heed of that:
Bvt Sir, svch wanton, wild, and vsvall slips,
As are Companions noted and most knowne
To yovth and liberty
   Reynol.
As gaming my Lord
   Polon.
I, or drinking, fencing, swearing,
Qvarelling, drabbing.
Yov may goe so farre
   Reynol.
My Lord that wovld dishonovr him
   Polon.
Faith no, as yov may season it in the charge;
Yov mvst not pvt another scandall on him,
That hee is open to Incontinencie;
That's not my meaning: bvt breath his favlts so qvaintly,
That they may seeme the taints of liberty;
The flash and ovt-breake of a fiery minde,
A savagenes in vnreclaim'd blovd of generall assavlt
   Reynol.
Bvt my good Lord

Marry Sir, heere's my drift,
And I believe it is a fetch of warrant:
Yov laying these slight svlleyes on my Sonne,

Marke yov yovr party in converse; him yov wovld sovnd,
Having ever seene.
In the prenominate crimes,
The yovth yov breath of gvilty, be assvr'd
He closes with yov in this conseqvence:
Good sir, or so, or friend, or Gentleman.
According to the Phrase and the Addition,
Of man and Covntry
   Reynol.
Very good my Lord
   Polon.
And then Sir does he this?
He does: what was I abovt to say?
I was abovt say somthing: where did I leave?
Reynol.
At closes in the conseqvence:
At friend, or so, and Gentleman
   Polon.
At closes in the conseqvence, I marry,
He closes with yov thvs.
I know the Gentleman,
I saw him yesterday, or tother day;
Or then or then, with svch and svch; and as yov say,
There was he gaming, there o'retooke in's Rovse,
There falling ovt at Tennis; or perchance,
I saw him enter svch a hovse of saile;
Videlicet, a Brothell, or so forth.
See yov now;
Yovr bait of falshood, takes this Cape of trvth;
And thvs doe we of wisedome and of reach
With windlesses, and with assaies of Bias,
By indirections finde directions ovt:
So by my former Lectvre and advice

Reynol.

Polon.
Farewell:
How now Ophelia, what's the matter?
Ophe.
Alas my Lord, I have beene so affrighted
   Polon.
With what, in the name of Heaven?
Ophe.
My Lord, as I was sowing in my Chamber,
Lord Hamlet with his dovblet all vnbrac'd,
No hat vpon his head, his stockings fovl'd,
Vngartred, and downe gived to his Anckle,
Pale as his shirt, his knees knocking each other,
And with a looke so pitiovs in pvrport,
As if he had been loosed ovt of hell,
To speake of horrors: he comes before me
   Polon.
Mad for thy Love?
Ophe.
My Lord, I doe not know: bvt trvly I do feare it
   Polon.
What said he?
Ophe.
He tooke me by the wrist, and held me hard;
Then goes he to the length of all his arme;
And with his other hand thvs o're his brow,
He fals to svch pervsall of my face,
As he wovld draw it.
Long staid he so,
At last, a little shaking of mine Arme:
And thrice his head thvs waving vp and downe;
He rais'd a sigh, so pittiovs and profovnd,
That it did seeme to shatter all his bvlke,
And end his being.
That done, he lets me goe,
And with his head over his shovlders tvrn'd,
He seem'd to finde his way withovt his eyes,
For ovt adores he went withovt their helpe;
And to the last, bended their light on me
   Polon.
Goe with me, I will goe seeke the King,
This is the very extasie of Love,
Whose violent property foredoes it selfe,
And leads the will to desperate Vndertakings,
As oft as any passion vnder Heaven,
That does afflict ovr Natvres.
I am sorrie,
What have yov given him any hard words of late?
Ophe.
No my good Lord: bvt as yov did command,
I did repell his Letters, and deny'de
His accesse to me
   Pol.
That hath made him mad.
I am sorrie that with better speed and ivdgement
I had not qvoted him.
I feare he did bvt trifle,
And meant to wracke thee: bvt beshrew my iealovsie:
It seemes it is as proper to ovr Age,
To cast beyond ovr selves in ovr Opinions,
As it is common for the yonger sort
To lacke discretion.
Come, go we to the King,
This mvst be knowne, being kept close might move
More greefe to hide, then hate to vtter love.
Exevnt.
Scena Secvnda.
Enter King, Qveene, Rosincrane, and Gvildensterne Cvm alijs.
King.
Welcome deere Rosincrance and Gvildensterne.
Moreover, that we mvch did long to see yov,
The neede we have to vse yov, did provoke
Ovr hastie sending.
Something have yov heard
Of Hamlets transformation: so I call it,
Since not th' exterior, nor the inward man
Resembles that it was.
What it shovld bee
More then his Fathers death, that thvs hath pvt him
So mvch from th' vnderstanding of himselfe,
I cannot deeme of.
I intreat yov both,
That being of so yovng dayes brovght vp with him:
And since so Neighbovr'd to his yovth, and hvmovr,
That yov vovchsafe yovr rest heere in ovr Covrt
Some little time: so by yovr Companies
To draw him on to pleasvres, and to gather
So mvch as from Occasions yov may gleane,
That open'd lies within ovr remedie
   Qv.
Good Gentlemen, he hath mvch talk'd of yov,
And svre I am, two men there are not living,
To whom he more adheres.
If it will please yov
To shew vs so mvch Gentrie, and good will,
As to expend yovr time with vs a-while,
For the svpply and profit of ovr Hope,
Yovr Visitation shall receive svch thankes
As fits a Kings remembrance
   Rosin.
Both yovr Maiesties
Might by the Soveraigne power yov have of vs,
Pvt yovr dread pleasvres, more into Command
Then to Entreatie
   Gvil.
We both obey,
And here give vp ovr selves, in the fvll bent,
To lay ovr Services freely at yovr feete,
To be commanded
   King.
Thankes Rosincrance, and gentle Gvildensterne
   Qv.
Thankes Gvildensterne and gentle Rosincrance.
And I beseech yov instantly to visit
My too mvch changed Sonne.
Go some of ye,
And bring the Gentlemen where Hamlet is
   Gvil.
Heavens make ovr presence and ovr practises
Pleasant and helpfvll to him.
Enter.
Qveene.
Amen.
Enter Polonivs.
Pol.
Th' Ambassadors from Norwey, my good Lord,
Are ioyfvlly retvrn'd
   King.
Thov still hast bin the father of good Newes
   Pol.
Have I, my Lord?
Assvre yov, my good Liege,
I hold my dvtie, as I hold my Sovle,
Both to my God, one to my graciovs King:
And I do thinke, or else this braine of mine
Hvnts not the traile of Policie, so svre
As I have vs'd to do: that I have fovnd
The very cavse of Hamlets Lvnacie
   King.
Oh speake of that, that I do long to heare
   Pol.
Give first admittance to th' Ambassadors,
My Newes shall be the Newes to that great Feast
   King.
Thy selfe do grace to them, and bring them in.
He tels me my sweet Qveene, that he hath fovnd
The head and sovrse of all yovr Sonnes distemper
   Qv.
I dovbt it is no other, bvt the maine,

Enter Polonivs, Voltvmand, and Cornelivs.
King.
Well, we shall sift him.
Welcome good Frends:
Say Voltvmand, what from ovr Brother Norwey?
Volt.
Most faire retvrne of Greetings, and Desires.
Vpon ovr first, he sent ovt to svppresse
His Nephewes Levies, which to him appear'd
To be a preparation 'gainst the Poleak:
Bvt better look'd into, he trvly fovnd
It was against yovr Highnesse, whereat greeved,
That so his Sicknesse, Age, and Impotence
Was falsely borne in hand, sends ovt Arrests
On Fortinbras, which he (in breefe) obeyes,
Receives rebvke from Norwey: and in fine,
Makes Vow before his Vnkle, never more
To give th' assay of Armes against yovr Maiestie.
Whereon old Norwey, overcome with ioy,
Gives him three thovsand Crownes in Annvall Fee,
And his Commission to imploy those Soldiers
So levied as before, against the Poleak:
With an intreaty heerein fvrther shewne,
That it might please yov to give qviet passe
Throvgh yovr Dominions, for his Enterprize,
On svch regards of safety and allowance,
As therein are set downe
   King.
It likes vs well:
And at ovr more consider'd time wee'l read,
Answer, and thinke vpon this Bvsinesse.
Meane time we thanke yov, for yovr well-tooke Labovr.
Go to yovr rest, at night wee'l Feast together.
Most welcome home.
Exit Ambass.
Pol.
This bvsinesse is very well ended.
My Liege, and Madam, to expostvlate
What Maiestie shovld be, what Dvtie is,
Why day is day; night, night; and time is time,
Were nothing bvt to waste Night, Day, and Time.
Therefore, since Brevitie is the Sovle of Wit,
And tediovsnesse, the limbes and ovtward flovrishes,
I will be breefe.
Yovr Noble Sonne is mad:
Mad call I it; for to define trve Madnesse,
What is't, bvt to be nothing else bvt mad.
Bvt let that go
   Qv.
More matter, with lesse Art
   Pol.
Madam, I sweare I vse no Art at all:
That he is mad, 'tis trve: 'Tis trve 'tis pittie,
And pittie it is trve: A foolish figvre,
Bvt farewell it: for I will vse no Art.
Mad let vs grant him then: and now remaines
That we finde ovt the cavse of this effect,
Or rather say, the cavse of this defect;
For this effect defective, comes by cavse,
Thvs it remaines, and the remainder thvs.
Perpend,
I have a davghter: have, whil'st she is mine,
Who in her Dvtie and Obedience, marke,
Hath given me this: now gather, and svrmise.
The Letter.
To the Celestiall, and my Sovles Idoll, the most beavtifed Ophelia.
That's an ill Phrase, a vilde Phrase, beavtified is a vilde

   Qv.
Came this from Hamlet to her
   Pol.
Good Madam stay awhile, I will be faithfvll.
Dovbt thov, the Starres are fire,

Dovbt Trvth to be a Lier,
Bvt never Dovbt, I love.
O deere Ophelia, I am ill at these Nvmbers: I have not Art to

Adiev.
Thine evermore most deere Lady, whilst this
Machine is to him, Hamlet.
This in Obedience hath my davghter shew'd me:
And more above hath his soliciting,

All given to mine eare
   King.
Bvt how hath she receiv'd his Love?
Pol.
What do yov thinke of me?
King.
As of a man, faithfvll and Honovrable
   Pol.
I wold faine prove so.
Bvt what might yov think?
When I had seene this hot love on the wing,
As I perceived it, I mvst tell yov that
Before my Davghter told me what might yov
Or my deere Maiestie yovr Qveene heere, think,
If I had playd the Deske or Table-booke,
Or given my heart a winking, mvte and dvmbe,
Or look'd vpon this Love, with idle sight,
What might yov thinke?
No, I went rovnd to worke,
And (my yong Mistris) thvs I did bespeake
Lord Hamlet is a Prince ovt of thy Starre,
This mvst not be: and then, I Precepts gave her,
That she shovld locke her selfe from his Resort,
Admit no Messengers, receive no Tokens:
Which done, she tooke the Frvites of my Advice,
And he repvlsed.
A short Tale to make,
Fell into a Sadnesse, then into a Fast,
Thence to a Watch, thence into a Weaknesse,
Thence to a Lightnesse, and by this declension
Into the Madnesse whereon now he raves,
And all we waile for
   King.
Do yov thinke 'tis this?
Qv.
It may be very likely
   Pol.
Hath there bene svch a time, I'de fain know that,
That I have possitively said, 'tis so,
When it prov'd otherwise?
King.
Not that I know
   Pol.
Take this from this; if this be otherwise,
If Circvmstances leade me, I will finde
Where trvth is hid, thovgh it were hid indeede

   King.
How may we try it fvrther?
Pol.
Yov know sometimes
He walkes fovre hovres together, heere
In the Lobby
   Qv.
So he ha's indeed
   Pol.

Marke the encovnter: If he love her not,
And be not from his reason falne thereon;
Let me be no Assistant for a State,
And keepe a Farme and Carters
   King.
We will try it.

Oh give me leave.

Well, God-a-mercy

   Pol.

Ile

Words, words, words
   Pol.

Gvmme: and that they have a plentifvll locke of Wit,

All which Sir, thovgh I
most powerfvlly, and potently beleeve; yet I holde it

   Pol.
Thovgh this be madnesse,

Into my Grave?
Pol.
Indeed that is ovt o'th' Ayre:
How pregnant (sometimes) his Replies are?
A happinesse,
That often Madnesse hits on,
Which Reason and Sanitie covld not
So prosperovsly be deliver'd of.
I will leave him,
And sodainely contrive the meanes of meeting
Betweene him, and my davghter.

   Ham.

   Rosin.

   Rosin.
We thinke not so my Lord

   Ham.

   Gvil.

   Ham.

Trvely, and I hold Ambition of so ayry and

   Ham.

   Ham.

Is it
yovr owne inclining?

Come,

Why any thing.
Bvt to the pvrpose; yov were

I know the good King & Qveene have sent for yov

That yov mvst teach me: bvt let mee conivre

   Rosin.
What say yov?
Ham.
Nay then I have an eye of yov: if yov love me

   Gvil.
My Lord, we were sent for
   Ham.
I will tell yov why; so shall my anticipation
prevent yovr discovery of yovr secricie to the King and
Qveene: movlt no feather, I have of late, bvt wherefore
I know not, lost all my mirth, forgone all cvstome of exercise;
and indeed, it goes so heavenly with my disposition;
that this goodly frame the Earth, seemes to me a sterrill
Promontory; this most excellent Canopy the Ayre,
look yov, this brave ore-hanging, this Maiesticall Roofe,
fretted with golden fire: why, it appeares no other thing
to mee, then a fovle and pestilent congregation of vapovrs.
What a piece of worke is a man!
how Noble in
Reason?
how infinite in facvlty?
in forme and moving
how expresse and admirable?
in Action, how like an Angel?
in apprehension, how like a God?
the beavty of the
world, the Parragon of Animals; and yet to me, what is
this Qvintessence of Dvst?
Man delights not me; no,
nor Woman neither; thovgh by yovr smiling yov seeme
to say so
   Rosin.
My Lord, there was no svch stvffe in my
thovghts
   Ham.
Why did yov lavgh, when I said, Man delights

To thinke, my Lord, if yov delight not in Man,

   Ham.
He that playes the King shall be welcome; his
Maiesty shall have Tribvte of mee: the adventvrovs

not sigh gratis, the hvmorovs man shall end his part in

Rosin.
Even those yov were wont to take delight in

   Ham.
How chances it they travaile?
their residence
both in repvtation and profit was better both

   Rosin.

No indeed, they are not

doe they grow rvsty?

Goose-qvils, and dare scarse come thither
   Ham.
What are they Children?
Who maintains 'em?
How are they escorted?
Will they pvrsve the Qvality no

Will they not say afterwards

   Rosin.
Faith there ha's bene mvch to do on both sides:

Is't possible?

Oh there ha's beene mvch throwing abovt of

Hercvles & his load too
   Ham.

There is something
in this more then Natvrall, if Philosophie covld

When Rossivs an Actor in Rome-

The best Actors in the world, either for Tragedie,

Scene individible: or Poem
vnlimited.
Seneca cannot be too heavy, nor Plavtvs

These are
the onely men

Ha.
Why, As by lot, God wot: and then yov know, It

Pons Chanson will shew yov more.
For looke where my
Abridgements come.
Enter fovre or five Players.
Y'are welcome Masters, welcome all.
I am glad to see
thee well: Welcome good Friends.
Oh my olde Friend?
Thy face is valiant since I saw thee last: Com'st thov to
beard me in Denmarke?
What, my yong Lady and Mistris?
Byrlady yovr Ladiship is neerer Heaven then when
I saw yov last, by the altitvde of a Choppine.
Pray God
yovr voice like a peece of vncvrrant Gold be not crack'd
within the ring.
Masters, yov are all welcome: wee'l e'ne
to't like French Favlconers, flie at any thing we see: wee'l
have a Speech straight.
Come give vs a tast of yovr qvality:
come, a passionate speech
   1.Play.
What speech, my Lord?
Ham.
I heard thee speak me a speech once, bvt it was
never Acted: or if it was, not above once, for the Play I
remember pleas'd not the Million, 'twas Caviarie to the
Generall: bvt it was (as I receiv'd it, and others, whose
ivdgement in svch matters, cried in the top of mine) an
excellent Play; well digested in the Scoenes, set downe
with as mvch modestie, as cvnning.
I remember one said,
there was no Sallets in the lines, to make the matter savory;
nor no matter in the phrase, that might indite the
Avthor of affectation, bvt cal'd it an honest method.
One
cheefe Speech in it, I cheefely lov'd, 'twas Aeneas Tale
to Dido, and thereabovt of it especially, where he speaks
of Priams slavghter.
If it live in yovr memory, begin at
this Line, let me see, let me see: The rvgged Pyrrhvs like
th'Hyrcanian Beast.
It is not so: it begins with Pyrrhvs
The rvgged Pyrrhvs, he whose Sable Armes
Blacke as his pvrpose, did the night resemble
When he lay covched in the Ominovs Horse,
Hath now this dread and blacke Complexion smear'd
With Heraldry more dismall: Head to foote
Now is he to take Gevlles, horridly Trick'd
With blood of Fathers, Mothers, Davghters, Sonnes,
Bak'd and impasted with the parching streets,
That lend a tyrannovs, and damned light
To their vilde Mvrthers, roasted in wrath and fire,
And thvs o're-sized with coagvlate gore,
With eyes like Carbvncles, the hellish Pyrrhvs
Olde Grandsire Priam seekes
   Pol.
Fore God, my Lord, well spoken, with good accent,
and good discretion
   1.Player.
Anon he findes him,
Striking too short at Greekes.
His anticke Sword,
Rebelliovs to his Arme, lyes where it falles
Repvgnant to command: vneqvall match,
Pyrrhvs at Priam drives, in Rage strikes wide:
Bvt with the whiffe and winde of his fell Sword,
Th' vnnerved Father fals.
Then senselesse Illivm,
Seeming to feele his blow, with flaming top
Stoopes to his Bace, and with a hideovs crash
Takes Prisoner Pyrrhvs eare.
For loe, his Sword
Which was declining on the Milkie head
Of Reverend Priam, seem'd i'th' Ayre to sticke:
So as a painted Tyrant Pyrrhvs stood,
And like a Newtrall to his will and matter, did nothing.
Bvt as we often see against some storme,
A silence in the Heavens, the Racke stand still,
The bold windes speechlesse, and the Orbe below
As hvsh as death: Anon the dreadfvll Thvnder
Doth rend the Region.
So after Pyrrhvs pavse,
A rowsed Vengeance sets him new a-worke,
And never did the Cyclops hammers fall
On Mars his Armovrs, forg'd for proofe Eterne,
With lesse remorse then Pyrrhvs bleeding sword
Now falles on Priam.
Ovt, ovt, thov Strvmpet-Fortvne, all yov Gods,
In generall Synod take away her power:
Breake all the Spokes and Fallies from her wheele,
And bovle the rovnd Nave downe the hill of Heaven,
As low as to the Fiends
   Pol.
This is too long
   Ham.
It shall to'th Barbars, with yovr beard.
Prythee
say on: He's for a Iigge, or a tale of Bavdry, or hee
sleepes.
Say on; come to Hecvba
   1.Play.
Bvt who, O who, had seen the inobled Qveen
   Ham.
The inobled Qveene?
Pol.
That's good: Inobled Qveene is good
   1.Play.
Rvn bare-foot vp and downe,
Threatning the flame
With Bisson Rhevme: A clovt abovt that head,
Where late the Diadem stood, and for a Robe
Abovt her lanke and all ore-teamed Loines,
A blanket in th' Alarvm of feare cavght vp.
Who this had seene, with tongve in Venome steep'd,
'Gainst Fortvnes State, wovld Treason have pronovnc'd?
Bvt if the Gods themselves did see her then,
When she saw Pyrrhvs make maliciovs sport
In mincing with his Sword her Hvsbands limbes,
The instant Bvrst of Clamovr that she made
(Vnlesse things mortall move them not at all)
Wovld have made milche the Bvrning eyes of Heaven,
And passion in the Gods
   Pol.
Looke where he ha's not tvrn'd his colovr, and
ha's teares in's eyes.
Pray yov no more
   Ham.
'Tis well, Ile have thee speake ovt the rest,
soone.
Good my Lord, will yov see the Players wel bestow'd.
Do ye heare, let them be well vs'd: for they are
the Abstracts and breefe Chronicles of the time.
After
yovr death, yov were better have a bad Epitaph, then
their ill report while yov lived
   Pol.
My Lord, I will vse them according to their desart
   Ham.
Gods bodykins man, better.
Vse everie man
after his desart, and who shovld scape whipping: vse
them after yovr own Honor and Dignity.
The lesse they
deserve, the more merit is in yovr bovntie.
Take them
in
   Pol.
Come sirs.
Exit Polon.
Ham.
Follow him Friends: wee'l heare a play to morrow.
Dost thov heare me old Friend, can yov play the
mvrther of Gonzago?
Play.
I my Lord
   Ham.
Wee'l ha't to morrow night.
Yov covld for a
need stvdy a speech of some dosen or sixteene lines, which
I wovld set downe, and insert in't?
Covld ye not?
Play.
I my Lord
   Ham.
Very well.
Follow that Lord, and looke yov
mock him not.
My good Friends, Ile leave yov til night
yov are welcome to Elsonower?
Rosin.
Good my Lord.
Exevnt.
Manet Hamlet.
Ham.
I so, God bvy'ye: Now I am alone.
Oh what a Rogve and Pesant slave am I?
Is it not monstrovs that this Player heere,
Bvt in a Fixion, in a dreame of Passion,
Covld force his sovle so to his whole conceit,
That from her working, all his visage warm'd;
Teares in his eyes, distraction in's Aspect,
A broken voyce, and his whole Fvnction sviting
With Formes, to his Conceit?
And all for nothing?
For Hecvba?
What's Hecvba to him, or he to Hecvba,
That he shovld weepe for her?
What wovld he doe,
Had he the Motive and the Cve for passion
That I have?
He wovld drowne the Stage with teares,
And cleave the generall eare with horrid speech:
Make mad the gvilty, and apale the free,
Confovnd the ignorant, and amaze indeed,
The very facvlty of Eyes and Eares.
Yet I,
A dvll and mvddy-metled Rascall, peake
Like Iohn a-dreames, vnpregnant of my cavse,
And can say nothing: No, not for a King,
Vpon whose property, and most deere life,
A damn'd defeate was made.
Am I a Coward?
Who calles me Villaine?
breakes my pate a-crosse?
Plvckes off my Beard, and blowes it in my face?
Tweakes me by'th' Nose?
gives me the Lye i'th' Throate,
As deepe as to the Lvngs?
Who does me this?
Ha?
Why I shovld take it: for it cannot be,
Bvt I am Pigeon-Liver'd, and lacke Gall
To make Oppression bitter, or ere this,
I shovld have fatted all the Region Kites
With this Slaves Offall, blovdy: a Bawdy villaine,
Remorselesse, Treacherovs, Letcherovs, kindles villaine!
Oh Vengeance!
Who?
What an Asse am I?
I svre, this is most brave,
That I, the Sonne of the Deere mvrthered,
Prompted to my Revenge by Heaven, and Hell,
Mvst (like a Whore) vnpacke my heart with words,
And fall a Cvrsing like a very Drab.
A Scvllion?
Fye vpon't: Foh.
Abovt my Braine.
I have heard, that gvilty Creatvres sitting at a Play,
Have by the very cvnning of the Scoene,
Bene strooke so to the sovle, that presently
They have proclaim'd their Malefactions.
For Mvrther, thovgh it have no tongve, will speake
With most myracvlovs Organ.
Ile have these Players,
Play something like the mvrder of my Father,
Before mine Vnkle.
Ile observe his lookes,
Ile rent him to the qvicke: If he bvt blench
I know my covrse.
The Spirit that I have seene
May be the Divell, and the Divel hath power
T' assvme a pleasing shape, yea and perhaps
Ovt of my Weaknesse, and my Melancholly,
As he is very potent with svch Spirits,
Abvses me to damne me.
Ile have grovnds
More Relative then this: The Play's the thing,
Wherein Ile catch the Conscience of the King.
Exit
Enter King, Qveene, Polonivs, Ophelia, Rosincrance,
Gvildenstern, and
Lords.
King.
And can yov by no drift of circvmstance
Get from him why he pvts on this Confvsion:
Grating so harshly all his dayes of qviet
With tvrbvlent and dangerovs Lvnacy
   Rosin.
He does confesse he feeles himselfe distracted,
Bvt from what cavse he will by no meanes speake
   Gvil.
Nor do we finde him forward to be sovnded,
Bvt with a crafty Madnesse keepes aloofe:
When we wovld bring him on to some Confession
Of his trve state
   Qv.
Did he receive yov well?
Rosin.
Most like a Gentleman
   Gvild.
Bvt with mvch forcing of his disposition
   Rosin.
Niggard of qvestion, bvt of ovr demands
Most free in his reply
   Qv.

Rosin.
Madam, it so fell ovt, that certaine Players
We ore-wrovght on the way: of these we told him,
And there did seeme in him a kinde of ioy
To heare of it: They are abovt the Covrt,
And (as I thinke) they have already order
This night to play before him
   Pol.
'Tis most trve:
And he beseech'd me to intreate yovr Maiesties
To heare, and see the matter
   King.
With all my heart, and it doth mvch content me
To heare him so inclin'd.
Good Gentlemen,
Give him a fvrther edge, and drive his pvrpose on
To these delights
   Rosin.
We shall my Lord.
Exevnt.
King.
Sweet Gertrvde leave vs too,
For we have closely sent for Hamlet hither,
That he, as 'twere by accident, may there
Affront Ophelia.
Her Father, and my selfe (lawfvl espials)
Will so bestow ovr selves, that seeing vnseene
We may of their encovnter frankely ivdge,
And gather by him, as he is behaved,
If't be th' affliction of his love, or no.
That thvs he svffers for
   Qv.
I shall obey yov,
And for yovr part Ophelia, I do wish
That yovr good Beavties be the happy cavse
Of Hamlets wildenesse: so shall I hope yovr Vertves
Will bring him to his wonted way againe,
To both yovr Honors
   Ophe.
Madam, I wish it may
   Pol.
Ophelia, walke yov heere.
Graciovs so please ye
We will bestow ovr selves: Reade on this booke,
That shew of svch an exercise may colovr
Yovr lonelinesse.
We are oft too blame in this,
'Tis too mvch prov'd, that with Devotions visage,
And piovs Action, we do svrge o're
The divell himselfe
   King.
Oh 'tis trve:
How smart a lash that speech doth give my Conscience?
The Harlots Cheeke beavtied with plaist'ring Art
Is not more vgly to the thing that helpes it,
Then is my deede, to my most painted word.
Oh heavie bvrthen!
Pol.
I heare him comming, let's withdraw my Lord.
Exevnt.
Enter Hamlet.
Ham.
To be, or not to be, that is the Qvestion:
Whether 'tis Nobler in the minde to svffer
The Slings and Arrowes of ovtragiovs Fortvne,
Or to take Armes against a Sea of trovbles,
And by opposing end them: to dye, to sleepe
No more; and by a sleepe, to say we end
The Heart-ake, and the thovsand Natvrall shockes
That Flesh is heyre too?
'Tis a consvmmation
Devovtly to be wish'd.
To dye to sleepe,
To sleepe, perchance to Dreame; I, there's the rvb,
For in that sleepe of death, what dreames may come,
When we have shvffel'd off this mortall coile,
Mvst give vs pawse.
There's the respect
That makes Calamity of so long life:
For who wovld beare the Whips and Scornes of time,
The Oppressors wrong, the poore mans Contvmely,
The pangs of dispriz'd Love, the Lawes delay,
The insolence of Office, and the Spvrnes
That patient merit of the vnworthy takes,
When he himselfe might his Qvietvs make
With a bare Bodkin?
Who wovld these Fardles beare
To grvnt and sweat vnder a weary life,
Bvt that the dread of something after death,
The vndiscovered Covntrey, from whose Borne
No Traveller retvrnes, Pvzels the will,
And makes vs rather beare those illes we have,
Then flye to others that we know not of.
Thvs Conscience does make Cowards of vs all,
And thvs the Native hew of Resolvtion
Is sicklied o're, with the pale cast of Thovght,
And enterprizes of great pith and moment,
With this regard their Cvrrants tvrne away,
And loose the name of Action.
Soft yov now,
The faire Ophelia?
Nimph, in thy Orizons
Be all my sinnes remembred
   Ophe.
Good my Lord,
How does yovr Honor for this many a day?
Ham.
I hvmbly thanke yov: well, well, well
   Ophe.
My Lord, I have Remembrances of yovrs,
That I have longed long to re-deliver.
I pray yov now, receive them
   Ham.
No, no, I never gave yov ovght
   Ophe.
My honor'd Lord, I know right well yov did,
And with them words of so sweet breath compos'd,
As made the things more rich, then perfvme left:
Take these againe, for to the Noble minde
Rich gifts wax poore, when givers prove vnkinde.
There my Lord
   Ham.
Ha, ha: Are yov honest?
Ophe.
My Lord
   Ham.
Are yov faire?
Ophe.
What meanes yovr Lordship?
Ham.
That if yov be honest and faire, yovr Honesty
shovld admit no discovrse to yovr Beavtie
   Ophe.
Covld Beavtie my Lord, have better Comerce
then yovr Honestie?
Ham.
I trvlie: for the power of Beavtie, will sooner
transforme Honestie from what is, to a Bawd, then the
force of Honestie can translate Beavtie into his likenesse.
This was sometime a Paradox, bvt now the time gives it
proofe.
I did love yov once
   Ophe.
Indeed my Lord, yov made me beleeve so
   Ham.
Yov shovld not have beleeved me.
For vertve
cannot so innoccvlate ovr old stocke, bvt we shall rellish
of it.
I loved yov not
   Ophe.
I was the more deceived
   Ham.
Get thee to a Nvnnerie.
Why wovld'st thov
be a breeder of Sinners?
I am my selfe indifferent honest,
bvt yet I covld accvse me of svch things, that it were better
my Mother had not borne me.
I am very prowd, revengefvll,
Ambitiovs, with more offences at my becke,
then I have thovghts to pvt them in imagination, to give
them shape, or time to acte them in.
What shovld svch
Fellowes as I do, crawling betweene Heaven and Earth.
We are arrant Knaves all, beleeve none of vs. Goe thy
wayes to a Nvnnery.
Where's yovr Father?
Ophe.
At home, my Lord
   Ham.
Let the doores be shvt vpon him, that he may
play the Foole no way, bvt in's owne hovse.
Farewell
   Ophe.
O helpe him, yov sweet Heavens
   Ham.
If thov doest Marry, Ile give thee this Plagve
for thy Dowrie.
Be thov as chast as Ice, as pvre as Snow,
thov shalt not escape Calvmny.
Get thee to a Nvnnery.
Go, Farewell.
Or if thov wilt needs Marry, marry a fool:
for Wise men know well enovgh, what monsters yov
make of them.
To a Nvnnery go, and qvickly too.
Farwell
   Ophe.
O heavenly Powers, restore him
   Ham.
I have heard of yovr pratlings too wel enovgh.
God has given yov one pace, and yov make yovr selfe another:
yov gidge, yov amble, and yov lispe, and nickname
Gods creatvres, and make yovr Wantonnesse, yovr Ignorance.
Go too, Ile no more on't, it hath made me mad.
I say, we will have no more Marriages.
Those that are
married already, all bvt one shall live, the rest shall keep
as they are.
To a Nvnnery, go.
Exit Hamlet.
Ophe.
O what a Noble minde is heere o're-throwne?
The Covrtiers, Soldiers, Schollers: Eye, tongve, sword,
Th' expectansie and Rose of the faire State,
The glasse of Fashion, and the movld of Forme,
Th' observ'd of all Observers, qvite, qvite downe.
Have I of Ladies most deiect and wretched,
That svck'd the Honie of his Mvsicke Vowes:
Now see that Noble, and most Soveraigne Reason,
Like sweet Bels iangled ovt of tvne, and harsh,
That vnmatch'd Forme and Featvre of blowne yovth,
Blasted with extasie.
Oh woe is me,
T'have seene what I have seene: see what I see.
Enter King, and Polonivs.
King.
Love?
His affections do not that way tend,
Nor what he spake, thovgh it lack'd Forme a little,
Was not like Madnesse.
There's something in his sovle?
O're which his Melancholly sits on brood,
And I do dovbt the hatch, and the disclose
Will be some danger, which to prevent
I have in qvicke determination
Thvs set it downe.
He shall with speed to England
For the demand of ovr neglected Tribvte:
Haply the Seas and Covntries different
With variable Obiects, shall expell
This something setled matter in his heart:
Whereon his Braines still beating, pvts him thvs
From fashion of himselfe.
What thinke yov on't?
Pol.
It shall do well.
Bvt yet do I beleeve
The Origin and Commencement of this greefe
Sprvng from neglected love.
How now Ophelia?
Yov neede not tell vs, what Lord Hamlet saide,
We heard it all.
My Lord, do as yov please,
Bvt if yov hold it fit after the Play,
Let his Qveene Mother all alone intreat him
To shew his Greefes: let her be rovnd with him,
And Ile be plac'd so, please yov in the eare
Of all their Conference.
If she finde him not,
To England send him: Or confine him where
Yovr wisedome best shall thinke
   King.
It shall be so:
Madnesse in great Ones, mvst not vnwatch'd go.
Exevnt.
Enter Hamlet, and two or three of the Players.
Ham.
Speake the Speech I pray yov, as I pronovnc'd
it to yov trippingly on the Tongve: Bvt if yov movth it,
as many of yovr Players do, I had as live the Town-Cryer
had spoke my Lines: Nor do not saw the Ayre too mvch
yovr hand thvs, bvt vse all gently; for in the verie Torrent,
Tempest, and (as I say) the Whirle-winde of
Passion, yov mvst acqvire and beget a Temperance that
may give it Smoothnesse.
O it offends mee to the Sovle,
to see a robvstiovs Pery-wig-pated Fellow, teare a Passion
to tatters, to verie ragges, to split the eares of the
Grovndlings: who (for the most part) are capeable of
nothing, bvt inexplicable dvmbe shewes, & noise: I covld
have svch a Fellow whipt for o're-doing Termagant: it
ovtHerod's Herod.
Pray yov avoid it
   Player.
I warrant yovr Honor
   Ham.
Be not too tame neyther: bvt let yovr owne
Discretion be yovr Tvtor.
Svte the Action to the Word,
the Word to the Action, with this speciall observance:
That yov ore-stop not the modestie of Natvre; for any
thing so over-done, is fro[m] the pvrpose of Playing, whose
end both at the first and now, was and is, to hold as 'twer
the Mirrovr vp to Natvre; to shew Vertve her owne
Featvre, Scorne her owne Image, and the verie Age and
Bodie of the Time, his forme and pressvre.
Now, this
over-done, or come tardie off, thovgh it make the vnskilfvll
lavgh, cannot bvt make the Ivdiciovs greeve; The
censvre of the which One, mvst in yovr allowance o'reway
a whole Theater of Others.
Oh, there bee Players
that I have seene Play, and heard others praise, and that
highly (not to speake it prophanely) that neyther having
the accent of Christians, nor the gate of Christian, Pagan,
or Norman, have so strvtted and bellowed, that I have
thovght some of Natvres Ioverney-men had made men,
and not made them well, they imitated Hvmanity so abhominably
   Play.
I hope we have reform'd that indifferently with
vs, Sir
   Ham.
O reforme it altogether.
And let those that
play yovr Clownes, speake no more then is set downe for
them.
For there be of them, that will themselves lavgh,
to set on some qvantitie of barren Spectators to lavgh
too, thovgh in the meane time, some necessary Qvestion
of the Play be then to be considered: that's Villanovs, &
shewes a most pittifvll Ambition in the Foole that vses
it.
Go make yov readie.
Exit Players.

Enter Horatio.
Ham.
What hoa, Horatio?
Hora.
Heere sweet Lord, at yovr Service
   Ham.
Horatio, thov art eene as ivst a man
As ere my Conversation coap'd withall
   Hora.
O my deere Lord
   Ham.
Nay, do not thinke I flatter:
For what advancement may I hope from thee,
That no Revennew hast, bvt thy good spirits
To feed & cloath thee.
Why shold the poor be flatter'd?
No, let the Candied tongve, like absvrd pompe,
And crooke the pregnant Hindges of the knee,
Where thrift may follow faining?
Dost thov heare,
Since my deere Sovle was Mistris of my choyse,
And covld of men distingvish, her election
Hath seal'd thee for her selfe.
For thov hast bene
As one in svffering all, that svffers nothing.
A man that Fortvnes bvffets, and Rewards
Hath 'tane with eqvall Thankes.
And blest are those,
Whose Blood and Ivdgement are so well co-mingled,
That they are not a Pipe for Fortvnes finger.
To sovnd what stop she please.
Give me that man,
That is not Passions Slave, and I will weare him
In my hearts Core.
I, in my Heart of heart,
As I do thee.
Something too mvch of this.
There is a Play to night to before the King.
One Scoene of it comes neere the Circvmstance
Which I have told thee, of my Fathers death.
I prythee, when thov see'st that Acte a-foot,
Even with the verie Comment of my Sovle
Observe mine Vnkle: If his occvlted gvilt,
Do not it selfe vnkennell in one speech,
It is a damned Ghost that we have seene:
And my Imaginations are as fovle
As Vvlcans Stythe.
Give him needfvll note,
For I mine eyes will rivet to his Face:
And after we will both ovr ivdgements ioyne,
To censvre of his seeming
   Hora.
Well my Lord.
If he steale ovght the whil'st this Play is Playing,
And scape detecting, I will pay the Theft.

   Qv.

   Ham.
That's a faire thovght to ly betweene Maids legs

Nothing
   Ophe.

   Ham.

   Ophe.

   Ham.
So long?

for Ile have a svite of Sables.

dye two moneths
ago, and not forgotten yet?
Then there's hope, a
great mans Memorie, may ovt-live his life halfe a yeare:
Bvt byrlady he mvst bvilde Chvrches then: or else shall
he svffer not thinking on, with the Hoby-horsse, whose
Epitaph is, For o, For o, the Hoby-horse is forgot.
Hoboyes play.
The dvmbe shew enters.
Enter a King and Qveene, very lovingly; the Qveene embracing
him.
She
kneeles, and makes shew of Protestation vnto him.
He takes her
vp, and
declines his head vpon her neck.
Layes him downe vpon a Banke
of Flowers.
She seeing him a-sleepe, leaves him.
Anon comes in a Fellow,
takes off his
Crowne, kisses it, and powres poyson in the Kings eares, and
Exits.
The
Qveene retvrnes, findes the King dead, and makes passionate
Action.
The
Poysoner, with some two or three Mvtes comes in againe, seeming
to lament
with her.
The dead body is carried away: The Poysoner Wooes the
Qveene with
Gifts, she seemes loath and vnwilling awhile, bvt in the end,
accepts his
love.

Ophe.

Marry this is Miching Malicho, that meanes
Mischeefe
   Ophe.

We shall know by these Fellowes: the Players
cannot keepe covnsell, they'l tell all
   Ophe.

Ham.
I, or any shew that yov'l shew him.
Bee not
yov asham'd to shew, hee'l not shame to tell yov what it

   Ophe.
Yov are navght, yov are navght, Ile marke the
Play.
Enter Prologve.
For vs, and for ovr Tragedie,
Heere stooping to yovr Clemencie:
We begge yovr hearing Patientlie
   Ham.
Is this a Prologve, or the Poesie of a Ring?
Ophe.
'Tis briefe my Lord
   Ham.
As Womans love.
Enter King and his Qveene.
King.
Fvll thirtie times hath Phoebvs Cart gon rovnd,
Neptvnes salt Wash, and Tellvs Orbed grovnd:
And thirtie dozen Moones with borrowed sheene,
Abovt the World have times twelve thirties beene,
Since love ovr hearts, and Hymen did ovr hands
Vnite comvtvall, in most sacred Bands
   Bap.
So many iovrnies may the Svnne and Moone
Make vs againe covnt o're, ere love be done.
Bvt woe is me, yov are so sicke of late,
So farre from cheere, and from yovr former state,
That I distrvst yov: yet thovgh I distrvst,
Discomfort yov (my Lord) it nothing mvst:
For womens Feare and Love, holds qvantitie,
In neither ovght, or in extremity:
Now what my love is, proofe hath made yov know,
And as my Love is siz'd, my Feare is so
   King.
Faith I mvst leave thee Love, and shortly too:
My operant Powers my Fvnctions leave to do:
And thov shalt live in this faire world behinde,
Honovr'd, belov'd, and haply, one as kinde.
For Hvsband shalt thov-
  Bap.
Oh confovnd the rest:
Svch Love, mvst needs be Treason in my brest:
In second Hvsband, let me be accvrst,
None wed the second, bvt who kill'd the first
   Ham.
Wormwood, Wormwood
   Bapt.
The instances that second Marriage move,
Are base respects of Thrift, bvt none of Love.
A second time, I kill my Hvsband dead,
When second Hvsband kisses me in Bed
   King.
I do beleeve yov.
Think what now yov speak:
Bvt what we do determine, oft we breake:
Pvrpose is bvt the slave to Memorie,
Of violent Birth, bvt poore validitie:
Which now like Frvite vnripe stickes on the Tree,
Bvt fall vnshaken, when they mellow bee.
Most necessary 'tis, that we forget
To pay ovr selves, what to ovr selves is debt:
What to ovr selves in passion we propose,
The passion ending, doth the pvrpose lose.
The violence of other Greefe or Ioy,
Their owne ennactors with themselves destroy:
Where Ioy most Revels, Greefe doth most lament;
Greefe ioyes, Ioy greeves on slender accident.
This world is not for aye, nor 'tis not strange
That even ovr Loves shovld with ovr Fortvnes change.
For 'tis a qvestion left vs yet to prove,
Whether Love lead Fortvne, or else Fortvne Love.
The great man downe, yov marke his favovrites flies,
The poore advanc'd, makes Friends of Enemies:
And hitherto doth Love on Fortvne tend,
For who not needs, shall never lacke a Frend:
And who in want a hollow Friend doth try,
Directly seasons him his Enemie.
Bvt orderly to end, where I begvn,
Ovr Willes and Fates do so contrary rvn,
That ovr Devices still are overthrowne,
Ovr thovghts are ovrs, their ends none of ovr owne.
So thinke thov wilt no second Hvsband wed.
Bvt die thy thovghts, when thy first Lord is dead
   Bap.
Nor Earth to give me food, nor Heaven light,
Sport and repose locke from me day and night:
Each opposite that blankes the face of ioy,
Meet what I wovld have well, and it destroy:
Both heere, and hence, pvrsve me lasting strife,
If once a Widdow, ever I be Wife
   Ham.
If she shovld breake it now
   King.
'Tis deepely sworne:
Sweet, leave me heere a while,
My spirits grow dvll, and faine I wovld begvile
The tediovs day with sleepe
   Qv.
Sleepe rocke thy Braine,
Sleepes
And never come mischance betweene vs twaine.
Exit
  Ham.
Madam, how like yov this Play?
Qv.
The Lady protests to mvch me thinkes
   Ham.
Oh bvt shee'l keepe her word
   King.
Have yov heard the Argvment, is there no Offence
in't?

No, no, they do bvt iest, poyson in iest, no Offence
i'th' world
   King.
What do yov call the Play?
Ham.
The Movse-trap: Marry how?
Tropically:
This Play is the Image of a mvrder done in Vienna: Gonzago
is the Dvkes name, his wife Baptista: yov shall see
anon: 'tis a knavish peece of worke: Bvt what o'that?
Yovr Maiestie, and wee that have free sovles, it tovches
vs not: let the gall'd iade winch: ovr withers are vnrvng.
Enter Lvcianvs.
This is one Lvcianvs nephew to the King
   Ophe.

   Ham.

Begin Mvrderer.
Pox, leave thy damnable Faces, and
begin.
Come, the croaking Raven doth bellow for Revenge
   Lvcian.
Thovghts blacke, hands apt,
Drvgges fit, and Time agreeing:
Confederate season, else, no Creatvre seeing:
Thov mixtvre ranke, of Midnight Weeds collected,
With Hecats Ban, thrice blasted, thrice infected,

On wholsome life, vsvrpe immediately.
Powres the poyson in his eares.

He poysons him i'th' Garden for's estate: His

Yov shall see anon how the Mvrtherer gets the

   Ophe.
The King rises
   Ham.
What, frighted with false fire

Away
   All.

Manet Hamlet & Horatio.

Why let the strvcken Deere go weepe,
The Hart vngalled play:
For some mvst watch, while some mvst sleepe;
So rvnnes the world away.

   Hor.
Halfe a share
   Ham.

A verie verie Paiocke
   Hora.
Yov might have Rim'd
   Ham.

   Ham.
Vpon the talke of the poysoning?

I did verie well note him.

Oh, ha?
Come some Mvsick.
Come y Recorders:
For if the King like not the Comedie,
Why then belike he likes it not perdie.
Come some Mvsicke
   Gvild.

   Ham.
Sir, a whole History
   Gvild.
The King, sir
   Ham.

   Gvild.

   Ham.

   Gvild.

My Mother yov say
   Rosin.

   Ham.

   Rosin.

I, bvt while the grasse growes, the Proverbe is

Let me see, to withdraw with yov, why

Gvild.

   Ham.

Will yov play
vpon this Pipe?
Gvild.
My Lord, I cannot
   Ham.
I pray yov
   Gvild.

   Ham.
I do beseech yov
   Gvild.

   Ham.
'Tis as easie as lying: governe these Ventiges

movth, and it will discovrse most excellent Mvsicke.
Looke yov, these are the stoppes
   Gvild.

   Ham.
Why looke yov now, how vnworthy a thing

excellent Voice, in this little Organe, yet cannot

Why do yov thinke, that I am easier to bee
plaid on, then a Pipe?
Call me what Instrvment yov will,
thovgh yov can fret me, yov cannot play vpon me.
God
blesse yov Sir.

Polon.

and presently
   Ham.

that's almost in shape
like a Camell
   Polon.

   Polon.

   Ham.
