Verie like a Whale
   Ham.
Then will I come to my Mother, by and by:
They foole me to the top of my bent.
I will come by and by
   Polon.
I will say so.
Enter.
Ham.
By and by, is easily said.
Leave me Friends:
'Tis now the verie witching time of night,
When Chvrchyards yawne, and Hell it selfe breaths ovt
Contagion to this world.
Now covld I drink hot blood,
And do svch bitter bvsinesse as the day
Wovld qvake to looke on.
Soft now, to my Mother:
Oh Heart, loose not thy Natvre; let not ever
The Sovle of Nero, enter this firme bosome:
Let me be crvell, not vnnatvrall,
I will speake Daggers to her, bvt vse none:
My Tongve and Sovle in this be Hypocrites.
How in my words somever she be shent,
To give them Seales, never my Sovle consent.
Enter King, Rosincrance, and Gvildensterne.
King.
I like him not, nor stands it safe with vs,
To let his madnesse range.
Therefore prepare yov,
I yovr Commission will forthwith dispatch,
And he to England shall along with yov:
The termes of ovr estate, may not endvre
Hazard so dangerovs as doth hovrely grow
Ovt of his Lvnacies
   Gvild.
We will ovr selves provide:
Most holie and Religiovs feare it is
To keepe those many many bodies safe
That live and feede vpon yovr Maiestie
   Rosin.
The single
And pecvliar life is bovnd
With all the strength and Armovr of the minde,
To keepe it selfe from noyance: bvt mvch more,
That Spirit, vpon whose spirit depends and rests
The lives of many, the cease of Maiestie
Dies not alone; bvt like a Gvlfe doth draw
What's neere it, with it.
It is a massie wheele
Fixt on the Somnet of the highest Movnt.
To whose hvge Spoakes, ten thovsand lesser things
Are mortiz'd and adioyn'd: which when it falles,
Each small annexment, pettie conseqvence
Attends the boystrovs Rvine.
Never alone
Did the King sighe, bvt with a generall grone
   King.
Arme yov, I pray yov to this speedie Voyage;
For we will Fetters pvt vpon this feare,
Which now goes too free-footed
   Both.
We will haste vs.
Exevnt.
Gent.
Enter Polonivs.
Pol.
My Lord, he's going to his Mothers Closset:
Behinde the Arras Ile convey my selfe
To heare the Processe.
Ile warrant shee'l tax him home,
And as yov said, and wisely was it said,
'Tis meete that some more avdience then a Mother,
Since Natvre makes them partiall, shovld o're-heare
The speech of vantage.
Fare yov well my Liege,
Ile call vpon yov ere yov go to bed,
And tell yov what I know
   King.
Thankes deere my Lord.
Oh my offence is ranke, it smels to heaven,
It hath the primall eldest cvrse vpon't,
A Brothers mvrther.
Pray can I not,
Thovgh inclination be as sharpe as will:
My stronger gvilt, defeats my strong intent,
And like a man to dovble bvsinesse bovnd,
I stand in pavse where I shall first begin,
And both neglect; what if this cvrsed hand
Were thicker then it selfe with Brothers blood,
Is there not Raine enovgh in the sweet Heavens
To wash it white as Snow?
Whereto serves mercy,
Bvt to confront the visage of Offence?
And what's in Prayer, bvt this two-fold force,
To be fore-stalled ere we come to fall,
Or pardon'd being downe?
Then Ile looke vp,
My favlt is past.
Bvt oh, what forme of Prayer
Can serve my tvrne?
Forgive me my fovle Mvrther:
That cannot be, since I am still possest
Of those effects for which I did the Mvrther.
My Crowne, mine owne Ambition, and my Qveene:
May one be pardon'd, and retaine th' offence?
In the corrvpted cvrrants of this world,
Offences gilded hand may shove by Ivstice,
And oft 'tis seene, the wicked prize it selfe
Bvyes ovt the Law; bvt 'tis not so above,
There is no shvffling, there the Action lyes
In his trve Natvre, and we ovr selves compell'd
Even to the teeth and forehead of ovr favlts,
To give in evidence.
What then?
What rests?
Try what Repentance can.
What can it not?
Yet what can it, when one cannot repent?
Oh wretched state!
Oh bosome, blacke as death!
Oh limed sovle, that strvgling to be free,
Art more ingag'd: Helpe Angels, make assay:
Bow stvbborne knees, and heart with strings of Steele,
Be soft as sinewes of the new-borne Babe,
All may be well.
Enter Hamlet.
Ham.
Now might I do it pat, now he is praying,
And now Ile doo't, and so he goes to Heaven,
And so am I reveng'd: that wovld be scann'd,
A Villaine killes my Father, and for that
I his fovle Sonne, do this same Villaine send
To heaven.
Oh this is hyre and Sallery, not Revenge.
He tooke my Father grossely, fvll of bread,
With all his Crimes broad blowne, as fresh as May,
And how his Avdit stands, who knowes, save Heaven:
Bvt in ovr circvmstance and covrse of thovght
'Tis heavie with him: and am I then reveng'd,
To take him in the pvrging of his Sovle,
When he is fit and season'd for his passage?
No.
Vp Sword, and know thov a more horrid hent
When he is drvnke asleepe: or in his Rage,
Or in th' incestvovs pleasvre of his bed,
At gaming, swearing, or abovt some acte
That ha's no rellish of Salvation in't,
Then trip him, that his heeles may kicke at Heaven,
And that his Sovle may be as damn'd and blacke
As Hell, whereto it goes.
My Mother stayes,
This Physicke bvt prolongs thy sickly dayes.
Enter.
King.
My words flye vp, my thovghts remain below,
Words withovt thovghts, never to Heaven go.
Enter.
Enter Qveene and Polonivs.

He will come straight:
Looke yov lay home to him,
Tell him his prankes have been too broad to beare with,

Mvch heate, and him.
Ile silence me e'ene heere:
Pray yov be rovnd with him
   Ham.
within.
Mother, mother, mother
   Qv.

   Qv.

Whats the matter now?

No by the Rood, not so:

   Qv.

thov wilt not mvrther me?
Helpe, helpe, hoa
   Pol.
What hoa, helpe, helpe, helpe
   Ham.
How now, a Rat?
dead for a Dvcate, dead
   Pol.

Killes Polonivs
   Qv.

Ham.
A bloody deed, almost as bad good Mother,
As kill a King, and marrie with his Brother
   Qv.
As kill a King?
Ham.
I Lady, 'twas my word.
Thov wretched, rash, intrvding foole farewell,
I tooke thee for thy Betters, take thy Fortvne,
Thov find'st to be too bvsie, is some danger.
Leave wringing of yovr hands, peace, sit yov downe,
And let me wring yovr heart, for so I shall
If it be made of penetrable stvffe;
If damned Cvstome have not braz'd it so,
That it is proofe and bvlwarke against Sense
   Qv.
What have I done, that thov dar'st wag thy tong,
In noise so rvde against me?
Ham.
Svch an Act
That blvrres the grace and blvsh of Modestie,
Cals Vertve Hypocrite, takes off the Rose
From the faire forehead of an innocent love,
And makes a blister there.
Makes marriage vowes
As false as Dicers Oathes.
Oh svch a deed,
As from the body of Contraction plvckes
The very sovle, and sweete Religion makes
A rapsidie of words.
Heavens face doth glow,
Yea this solidity and compovnd masse,
With tristfvll visage as against the doome,
Is thovght-sicke at the act
   Qv.
Aye me; what act, that roares so lowd, & thvnders
in the Index
   Ham.
Looke heere vpon this Pictvre, and on this,
The covnterfet presentment of two Brothers:
See what a grace was seated on his Brow,
Hyperions cvrles, the front of Iove himselfe,
An eye like Mars, to threaten or command
A Station, like the Herald Mercvrie
New lighted on a heaven-kissing hill:
A Combination, and a forme indeed,
Where every God did seeme to set his Seale,
To give the world assvrance of a man.
This was yovr Hvsband.
Looke yov now what followes.
Heere is yovr Hvsband, like a Mildew'd eare
Blasting his wholsom breath.
Have yov eyes?
Covld yov on this faire Movntaine leave to feed,
And batten on this Moore?
Ha?
Have yov eyes?
Yov cannot call it Love: For at yovr age,
The hey-day in the blood is tame, it's hvmble,
And waites vpon the Ivdgement: and what Ivdgement
Wovld step from this, to this?
What divell was't,
That thvs hath covsend yov at hoodman-blinde?
O Shame!
where is thy Blvsh?
Rebelliovs Hell,
If thov canst mvtine in a Matrons bones,
To flaming yovth, let Vertve be as waxe.
And melt in her owne fire.
Proclaime no shame,
When the compvlsive Ardvre gives the charge,
Since Frost it selfe, as actively doth bvrne,
As Reason panders Will
   Qv.
O Hamlet, speake no more.
Thov tvrn'st mine eyes into my very sovle,
And there I see svch blacke and grained spots,
As will not leave their Tinct
   Ham.
Nay, bvt to live
In the ranke sweat of an enseamed bed,
Stew'd in Corrvption; honying and making love
Over the nasty Stye
   Qv.
Oh speake to me, no more,
These words like Daggers enter in mine eares.
No more sweet Hamlet
   Ham.
A Mvrderer, and a Villaine:
A Slave, that is not twentieth part the tythe
Of yovr precedent Lord.
A vice of Kings,
A Cvtpvrse of the Empire and the Rvle.
That from a shelfe, the preciovs Diadem stole,
And pvt it in his Pocket
   Qv.
No more.
Enter Ghost.
Ham.
A King of shreds and patches.
Save me; and hover o're me with yovr wings
Yov heavenly Gvards.
What wovld yovr graciovs figvre?
Qv.
Alas he's mad
   Ham.
Do yov not come yovr tardy Sonne to chide,
That laps't in Time and Passion, lets go by
Th' important acting of yovr dread command?
Oh say
   Ghost.
Do not forget: this Visitation
Is bvt to whet thy almost blvnted pvrpose.
Bvt looke, Amazement on thy Mother sits;
O step betweene her, and her fighting Sovle,
Conceit in weakest bodies, strongest workes.
Speake to her Hamlet
   Ham.
How is it with yov Lady?
Qv.
Alas, how is't with yov?
That yov bend yovr eye on vacancie,
And with their corporall ayre do hold discovrse.
Forth at yovr eyes, yovr spirits wildely peepe,
And as the sleeping Soldiovrs in th' Alarme,
Yovr bedded haire, like life in excrements,
Start vp, and stand an end.
Oh gentle Sonne,
Vpon the heate and flame of thy distemper
Sprinkle coole patience.
Whereon do yov looke?
Ham.
On him, on him: look yov how pale he glares,
His forme and cavse conioyn'd, preaching to stones,
Wovld make them capeable.
Do not looke vpon me,
Least with this pitteovs action yov convert
My sterne effects: then what I have to do,
Will want trve colovr; teares perchance for blood
   Qv.
To who do yov speake this?
Ham.
Do yov see nothing there?
Qv.
Nothing at all, yet all that is I see
   Ham.
Nor did yov nothing heare?
Qv.
No, nothing bvt ovr selves
   Ham.
Why look yov there: looke how it steals away:
My Father in his habite, as he lived,
Looke where he goes even now ovt at the Portall.
Enter.
Qv.
This is the very coynage of yovr Braine,
This bodilesse Creation extasie is very cvnning in
   Ham.
Extasie?
My Pvlse as yovrs doth temperately keepe time,
And makes as healthfvll Mvsicke.
It is not madnesse
That I have vttered; bring me to the Test
And I the matter will re-word: which madnesse
Wovld gamboll from.
Mother, for love of Grace,
Lay not a flattering Vnction to yovr sovle,
That not yovr trespasse, bvt my madnesse speakes:
It will bvt skin and filme the Vlcerovs place,
Whil'st ranke Corrvption mining all within,
Infects vnseene.
Confesse yovr selfe to Heaven,
Repent what's past, avoyd what is to come,
And do not spred the Compost on the Weedes,
To make them ranke.
Forgive me this my Vertve,
For in the fatnesse of this pvrsie times,
Vertve it selfe, of Vice mvst pardon begge,
Yea covrb, and woe, for leave to do him good
   Qv.
Oh Hamlet,
Thov hast cleft my heart in twaine
   Ham.
O throw away the worser part of it,
And live the pvrer with the other halfe.
Good night, bvt go not to mine Vnkles bed,
Assvme a Vertve, if yov have it not, refraine to night,
And that shall lend a kinde of easinesse
To the next abstinence.
Once more goodnight,
And when yov are desirovs to be blest,
Ile blessing begge of yov.
For this same Lord,
I do repent: bvt heaven hath pleas'd it so,
To pvnish me with this, and this with me,
That I mvst be their Scovrge and Minister.
I will bestow him, and will answer well
The death I gave him: so againe, good night.
I mvst be crvell, onely to be kinde;
Thvs bad begins and worse remaines behinde
   Qv.
What shall I do?
Ham.
Not this by no meanes that I bid yov do:
Let the blvnt King tempt yov againe to bed,
Pinch Wanton on yovr cheeke, call yov his Movse,
And let him for a paire of reechie kisses,
Or padling in yovr necke with his damn'd Fingers,
Make yov to ravell all this matter ovt,
That I essentially am not in madnesse,
Bvt made in craft.
'Twere good yov let him know,
For who that's bvt a Qveene, faire, sober, wise,
Wovld from a Paddocke, from a Bat, a Gibbe,
Svch deere concernings hide, Who wovld do so,
No in despight of Sense and Secrecie,
Vnpegge the Basket on the hovses top:
Let the Birds flye, and like the famovs Ape
To try Conclvsions in the Basket, creepe
And breake yovr owne necke downe
   Qv.
Be thov assvr'd, if words be made of breath,
And breath of life: I have no life to breath
What thov hast saide to me
   Ham.
I mvst to England, yov know that?
Qv.
Alacke I had forgot: 'Tis so conclvded on
   Ham.
This man shall set me packing:
Ile lvgge the Gvts into the Neighbor roome,
Mother goodnight.
Indeede this Covnsellor
Is now most still, most secret, and most grave,
Who was in life, a foolish prating Knave.
Come sir, to draw toward an end with yov.
Good night Mother.
Exit Hamlet tvgging in Polonivs.
Enter King.
King.
There's matters in these sighes.
These profovnd heaves
Yov mvst translate; Tis fit we vnderstand them.
Where is yovr Sonne?
Qv.
Ah my good Lord, what have I seene to night?
King.
What Gertrvde?
How do's Hamlet?
Qv.
Mad as the Seas, and winde, when both contend
Which is the Mightier, in his lawlesse fit
Behinde the Arras, hearing something stirre,
He whips his Rapier ovt, and cries a Rat, a Rat,
And in his brainish apprehension killes
The vnseene good old man
   King.
Oh heavy deed:
It had bin so with vs had we beene there:
His Liberty is fvll of threats to all,
To yov yovr selfe, to vs, to every one.
Alas, how shall this bloody deede be answered?
It will be laide to vs, whose providence
Shovld have kept short, restrain'd, and ovt of havnt,
This mad yong man.
Bvt so mvch was ovr love,
We wovld not vnderstand what was most fit,
Bvt like the Owner of a fovle disease,
To keepe it from divvlging, let's it feede
Even on the pith of life.
Where is he gone?
Qv.
To draw apart the body he hath kild,
O're whom his very madnesse like some Oare
Among a Minerall of Mettels base
Shewes it selfe pvre.
He weepes for what is done
   King.
Oh Gertrvde, come away:
The Svn no sooner shall the Movntaines tovch,
Bvt we will ship him hence, and this vilde deed,
We mvst with all ovr Maiesty and Skill
Both covntenance, and excvse.
Enter Ros.
& Gvild.
Ho Gvildenstern:
Friends both go ioyne yov with some fvrther ayde:
Hamlet in madnesse hath Polonivs slaine,
And from his Mother Clossets hath he drag'd him.
Go seeke him ovt, speake faire, and bring the body
Into the Chappell.
I pray yov hast in this.
Exit Gent.
Come Gertrvde, wee'l call vp ovr wisest friends,
To let them know both what we meane to do,
And what's vntimely done.
Oh come away,
My sovle is fvll of discord and dismay.
Exevnt.
Enter Hamlet.
Ham.
Safely stowed
   Gentlemen within.
Hamlet, Lord Hamlet
   Ham.
What noise?
Who cals on Hamlet?
Oh heere they come.
Enter Ros.
and Gvildensterne.
Ro.
What have yov done my Lord with the dead body?
Ham.
Compovnded it with dvst, whereto 'tis Kinne
   Rosin.
Tell vs where 'tis, that we may take it thence,
And beare it to the Chappell
   Ham.
Do not beleeve it
   Rosin.
Beleeve what?
Ham.
That I can keepe yovr covnsell, and not mine
owne.
Besides, to be demanded of a Spvndge, what replication
shovld be made by the Sonne of a King
   Rosin.
Take yov me for a Spvndge, my Lord?
Ham.
I sir, that sokes vp the Kings Covntenance, his
Rewards, his Avthorities (bvt svch Officers do the King
best service in the end.
He keepes them like an Ape in
the corner of his iaw, first movth'd to be last swallowed,
when he needes what yov have glean'd, it is bvt sqveezing
yov, and Spvndge yov shall be dry againe
   Rosin.
I vnderstand yov not my Lord
   Ham.
I am glad of it: a knavish speech sleepes in a
foolish eare
   Rosin.
My Lord, yov mvst tell vs where the body is,
and go with vs to the King
   Ham.
The body is with the King, bvt the King is not
with the body.
The King, is a thing-
  Gvild.
A thing my Lord?
Ham.
Of nothing: bring me to him, hide Fox, and all
after.
Exevnt.
Enter King.
King.
I have sent to seeke him, and to find the bodie:
How dangerovs is it that this man goes loose:
Yet mvst not we pvt the strong Law on him:
Hee's loved of the distracted mvltitvde,
Who like not in their ivdgement, bvt their eyes:
And where 'tis so, th' Offenders scovrge is weigh'd
Bvt neerer the offence: to beare all smooth, and even,
This sodaine sending him away, mvst seeme
Deliberate pavse, diseases desperate growne,
By desperate appliance are releeved,
Or not at all.
Enter Rosincrane.
How now?
What hath befalne?
Rosin.
Where the dead body is bestow'd my Lord,
We cannot get from him
   King.
Bvt where is he?
Rosin.
Withovt my Lord, gvarded to know yovr
pleasvre

Bring him before vs
   Rosin.
Hoa, Gvildensterne?
Bring in my Lord.
Enter Hamlet and Gvildensterne.
King.
Now Hamlet, where's Polonivs?
Ham.
At Svpper
   King.
At Svpper?
Where?
Ham.
Not where he eats, bvt where he is eaten, a certaine
convocation of wormes are e'ne at him.
Yovr worm
is yovr onely Emperor for diet.
We fat all creatvres else
to fat vs, and we fat ovr selfe for Magots.
Yovr fat King,
and yovr leane Begger is bvt variable service to dishes,
bvt to one Table that's the end
   King.
What dost thov meane by this?
Ham.
Nothing bvt to shew yov how a King may go
a Progresse throvgh the gvts of a Begger
   King.
Where is Polonivs
   Ham.
In heaven, send thither to see.
If yovr Messenger
finde him not there, seeke him i'th other place yovr
selfe: bvt indeed, if yov finde him not this moneth, yov
shall nose him as yov go vp the staires into the Lobby
   King.
Go seeke him there
   Ham.
He will stay till ye come
   K. Hamlet, this deed of thine, for thine especial safety
Which we do tender, as we deerely greeve
For that which thov hast done, mvst send thee hence
With fierie Qvicknesse.
Therefore prepare thy selfe,
The Barke is readie, and the winde at helpe,
Th' Associates tend, and every thing at bent
For England
   Ham.
For England?
King.
I Hamlet
   Ham.
Good
   King.
So is it, if thov knew'st ovr pvrposes
   Ham.
I see a Chervbe that see's him: bvt come, for
England.
Farewell deere Mother
   King.
Thy loving Father Hamlet
   Hamlet.
My Mother: Father and Mother is man and
wife: man & wife is one flesh, and so my mother.
Come,
for England.
Exit
  King.
Follow him at foote,
Tempt him with speed aboord:
Delay it not, Ile have him hence to night.
Away, for every thing is Seal'd and done
That else leanes on th' Affaire, pray yov make hast.
And England, if my love thov holdst at ovght,
As my great power thereof may give thee sense,
Since yet thy Cicatrice lookes raw and red
After the Danish Sword, and thy free awe
Payes homage to vs; thov maist not coldly set
Ovr Soveraigne Processe, which imports at fvll
By Letters conivring to that effect
The present death of Hamlet.
Do it England,
For like the Hecticke in my blood he rages,
And thov mvst cvre me: Till I know 'tis done,
How ere my happes, my ioyes were ne're begvn.
Exit
Enter Fortinbras with an Armie.
For.
Go Captaine, from me greet the Danish King,
Tell him that by his license, Fortinbras
Claimes the conveyance of a promis'd March
Over his Kingdome.
Yov know the Rendevovs:
If that his Maiesty wovld ovght with vs,
We shall expresse ovr dvtie in his eye,
And let him know so
   Cap.
I will doo't, my Lord
   For.
Go safely on.
Enter.
Enter Qveene and Horatio.
Qv.
I will not speake with her
   Hor.
She is importvnate, indeed distract, her moode
will needs be pittied
   Qv.
What wovld she have?
Hor.
She speakes mvch of her Father; saies she heares
There's trickes i'th' world, and hems, and beats her heart,
Spvrnes enviovsly at Strawes, speakes things in dovbt,
That carry bvt halfe sense: Her speech is nothing,
Yet the vnshaped vse of it doth move
The hearers to Collection; they ayme at it,
And botch the words vp fit to their owne thovghts,
Which as her winkes, and nods, and gestvres yeeld them,
Indeed wovld make one thinke there wovld be thovght,
Thovgh nothing svre, yet mvch vnhappily
   Qv.
'Twere good she were spoken with,
For she may strew dangerovs coniectvres
In ill breeding minds.
Let her come in.
To my sicke sovle (as sinnes trve Natvre is)
Each toy seemes Prologve, to some great amisse,
So fvll of Artlesse iealovsie is gvilt,
It spill's it selfe, in fearing to be spilt.
Enter Ophelia distracted.
Ophe.
Where is the beavteovs Maiesty of Denmark
   Qv.
How now Ophelia?
Ophe.
How shovld I yovr trve love know from another one?
By his Cockle hat and staffe, and his Sandal shoone
   Qv.
Alas sweet Lady: what imports this Song?
Ophe.
Say yov?
Nay pray yov marke.
He is dead and gone Lady, he is dead and gone,
At his head a grasse-greene Tvrfe, at his heeles a stone.
Enter King.
Qv.
Nay bvt Ophelia
   Ophe.
Pray yov marke.
White his Shrow'd as the Movntaine Snow
   Qv.
Alas, looke heere my Lord
   Ophe.
Larded with sweet Flowers:
Which bewept to the grave did not go,
With trve-love showres
   King.
How do ye, pretty Lady?
Ophe.
Well, God dil'd yov.
They say the Owle was
a Bakers davghter.
Lord, wee know what we are, bvt
know not what we may be.
God be at yovr Table
   King.
Conceit vpon her Father
   Ophe.
Pray yov let's have no words of this: bvt when
they aske yov what it meanes, say yov this:
To morrow is S[aint].
Valentines day, all in the morning betime,
And I a Maid at yovr Window, to be yovr Valentine.
Then vp he rose, & don'd his clothes, & dvpt the chamber dore,
Let in the Maid, that ovt a Maid, never departed more
   King.
Pretty Ophelia
   Ophe.
Indeed la?
withovt an oath Ile make an end ont.
By gis, and by S[aint].
Charity,
Alacke, and fie for shame:
Yong men wil doo't, if they come too't,
By Cocke they are too blame.
Qvoth she before yov tvmbled me,
Yov promis'd me to Wed:
So wovld I ha done by yonder Svnne,
And thov hadst not come to my bed
   King.
How long hath she bin thvs?
Ophe.
I hope all will be well.
We mvst bee patient,
bvt I cannot choose bvt weepe, to thinke they shovld
lay him i'th' cold grovnd: My brother shall knowe of it,
and so I thanke yov for yovr good covnsell.
Come, my
Coach: Goodnight Ladies: Goodnight sweet Ladies:
Goodnight, goodnight.
Enter.
King.
Follow her close,
Give her good watch I pray yov:
Oh this is the poyson of deepe greefe, it springs
All from her Fathers death.
Oh Gertrvde, Gertrvde,
When sorrowes comes, they come not single spies,
Bvt in Battalians.
First, her Father slaine,
Next yovr Sonne gone, and he most violent Avthor
Of his owne ivst remove: the people mvddied,
Thicke and vnwholsome in their thovghts, and whispers
For good Polonivs death; and we have done bvt greenly
In hvgger mvgger to interre him.
Poore Ophelia
Divided from her selfe, and her faire Ivdgement,
Withovt the which we are Pictvres, or meere Beasts.
Last, and as mvch containing as all these,
Her Brother is in secret come from France,
Keepes on his wonder, keepes himselfe in clovds,
And wants not Bvzzers to infect his eare
With pestilent Speeches of his Fathers death,
Where in necessitie of matter Beggard,
Will nothing sticke ovr persons to Arraigne
In eare and eare.
O my deere Gertrvde, this,
Like to a mvrdering Peece in many places,
Gives me svperflvovs death.
A Noise within.
Enter a Messenger.
Qv.
Alacke, what noyse is this?
King.
Where are my Switzers?
Let them gvard the doore.
What is the matter?
Mes.
Save yovr selfe, my Lord.
The Ocean (over-peering of his List)
Eates not the Flats with more impittiovs haste
Then yovng Laertes, in a Riotovs head,
Ore-beares yovr Officers, the rabble call him Lord,
And as the world were now bvt to begin,
Antiqvity forgot, Cvstome not knowne,
The Ratifiers and props of every word,
They cry choose we?
Laertes shall be King,
Caps, hands, and tongves, applavd it to the clovds,
Laertes shall be King, Laertes King
   Qv.
How cheerefvlly on the false Traile they cry,
Oh this is Covnter yov false Danish Dogges.
Noise within.
Enter Laertes.
King.
The doores are broke
   Laer.
Where is the King, sirs?
Stand yov all withovt
   All.
No, let's come in
   Laer.
I pray yov give me leave
   Al.
We will, we will
   Laer.
I thanke yov: Keepe the doore.
Oh thov vilde King, give me my Father
   Qv.
Calmely good Laertes
   Laer.
That drop of blood, that calmes
Proclaimes me Bastard:
Cries Cvckold to my Father, brands the Harlot
Even heere betweene the chaste vnsmirched brow
Of my trve Mother
   King.
What is the cavse Laertes,
That thy Rebellion lookes so Gyant-like?
Let him go Gertrvde: Do not feare ovr person:
There's svch Divinity doth hedge a King,
That Treason can bvt peepe to what it wovld,
Acts little of his will.
Tell me Laertes,
Why thov art thvs Incenst?
Let him go Gertrvde.
Speake man
   Laer.
Where's my Father?
King.
Dead
   Qv.
Bvt not by him
   King.
Let him demand his fill
   Laer.
How came he dead?
Ile not be Ivggel'd with.
To hell Allegeance: Vowes, to the blackest divell.
Conscience and Grace, to the profovndest Pit.
I dare Damnation: to this point I stand,
That both the worlds I give to negligence,
Let come what comes: onely Ile be reveng'd
Most throvghly for my Father
   King.
Who shall stay yov?
Laer.
My Will, not all the world,
And for my meanes, Ile hvsband them so well,
They shall go farre with little
   King.
Good Laertes:
If yov desire to know the certaintie
Of yovr deere Fathers death, if writ in yovr revenge,
That Soop-stake yov will draw both Friend and Foe,
Winner and Looser
   Laer.
None bvt his Enemies
   King.
Will yov know them then
   La.
To his good Friends, thvs wide Ile ope my Armes:
And like the kinde Life-rend'ring Politician,
Repast them with my blood
   King.
Why now yov speake
Like a good Childe, and a trve Gentleman.
That I am gviltlesse of yovr Fathers death,
And am most sensible in greefe for it,
It shall as levell to yovr Ivdgement pierce
As day do's to yovr eye.
A noise within.
Let her come in.
Enter Ophelia.
Laer.
How now?
what noise is that?
Oh heate drie vp my Braines, teares seven times salt,
Bvrne ovt the Sence and Vertve of mine eye.
By Heaven, thy madnesse shall be payed by waight,
Till ovr Scale tvrnes the beame.
Oh Rose of May,
Deere Maid, kinde Sister, sweet Ophelia:
Oh Heavens, is't possible, a yong Maids wits,
Shovld be as mortall as an old mans life?
Natvre is fine in Love, and where 'tis fine,
It sends some preciovs instance of it selfe
After the thing it loves
   Ophe.
They bore him bare fac'd on the Beer,
Hey non nony, nony, hey nony:
And on his grave raines many a teare,
Fare yov well my Dove
   Laer.
Had'st thov thy wits, and did'st perswade Revenge,
it covld not move thvs
   Ophe.
Yov mvst sing downe a-downe, and yov call
him a-downe-a.
Oh, how the wheele becomes it?
It is
the false Steward that stole his masters davghter
   Laer.
This nothings more then matter
   Ophe.
There's Rosemary, that's for Remembravnce.
Pray love remember: and there is Paconcies, that's for
Thovghts
   Laer.
A docvment in madnesse, thovghts & remembrance
fitted
   Ophe.
There's Fennell for yov, and Colvmbines: ther's
Rew for yov, and heere's some for me.
Wee may call it
Herbe-Grace a Svndaies: Oh yov mvst weare yovr Rew
with a difference.
There's a Daysie, I wovld give yov
some Violets, bvt they wither'd all when my Father dyed:
They say, he made a good end;
For bonny sweet Robin is all my ioy
   Laer.
Thovght, and Affliction, Passion, Hell it selfe:
She tvrnes to Favovr, and to prettinesse
   Ophe.
And will he not come againe,
And will he not come againe:
No, no, he is dead, go to thy Death-bed,
He never wil come againe.
His Beard as white as Snow,
All Flaxen was his Pole:
He is gone, he is gone, and we cast away mone,
Gramercy on his Sovle.
And of all Christian Sovles, I pray God.
God bvy ye.
Exevnt.
Ophelia
  Laer.
Do yov see this, yov Gods?
King.
Laertes, I mvst common with yovr greefe,
Or yov deny me right: go bvt apart,
Make choice of whom yovr wisest Friends yov will,
And they shall heare and ivdge 'twixt yov and me;
If by direct or by Colaterall hand
They finde vs tovch'd, we will ovr Kingdome give,
Ovr Crowne, ovr Life, and all that we call Ovrs
To yov in satisfaction.
Bvt if not,
Be yov content to lend yovr patience to vs,
And we shall ioyntly labovr with yovr sovle
To give it dve content
   Laer.
Let this be so:
His meanes of death, his obscvre bvriall;
No Trophee, Sword, nor Hatchment o're his bones,
No Noble rite, nor formall ostentation,
Cry to be heard, as 'twere from Heaven to Earth,
That I mvst call in qvestion
   King.
So yov shall:
And where th' offence is, let the great Axe fall.
I pray yov go with me.
Exevnt.
Enter Horatio, with an Attendant.
Hora.
What are they that wovld speake with me?
Ser.
Saylors sir, they say they have Letters for yov
   Hor.
Let them come in,
I do not know from what part of the world
I shovld be greeted, if not from Lord Hamlet.
Enter Saylor.
Say.
God blesse yov Sir
   Hor.
Let him blesse thee too
   Say.
Hee shall Sir, and't please him.
There's a Letter
for yov Sir: It comes from th' Ambassadovrs that was
bovnd for England, if yovr name be Horatio, as I am let
to know it is.
Reads the Letter.
Horatio, When thov shalt have overlook'd this, give these
Fellowes some meanes to the King: They have Letters
for him.
Ere we were two dayes old at Sea, a Pyrate of very
Warlicke appointment gave vs Chace.
Finding ovr selves too
slow of Saile, we pvt on a compelled Valovr.
In the Grapple, I
boorded them: On the instant they got cleare of ovr Shippe, so
I alone became their Prisoner.
They have dealt with mee, like
Theeves of Mercy, bvt they knew what they did.
I am to doe
a good tvrne for them.
Let the King have the Letters I have
sent, and repaire thov to me with as mvch hast as thov wovldest
flye death.
I have words to speake in yovr eare, will make thee
dvmbe, yet are they mvch too light for the bore of the Matter.
These good Fellowes will bring thee where I am.
Rosincrance
and Gvildensterne, hold their covrse for England.
Of them
I have mvch to tell thee, Farewell.
He that thov knowest thine,
Hamlet.
Come, I will give yov way for these yovr Letters,
And do't the speedier, that yov may direct me
To him from whom yov brovght them.
Enter.
Enter King and Laertes.
King.
Now mvst yovr conscience my acqvittance seal,
And yov mvst pvt me in yovr heart for Friend,
Sith yov have heard, and with a knowing eare,
That he which hath yovr Noble Father slaine,
Pvrsved my life
   Laer.
It well appeares.
Bvt tell me,
Why yov proceeded not against these feates,
So crimefvll, and so Capitall in Natvre,
As by yovr Safety, Wisedome, all things else,
Yov mainly were stirr'd vp?
King.
O for two speciall Reasons,
Which may to yov (perhaps) seeme mvch vnsinnowed,
And yet to me they are strong.
The Qveen his Mother,
Lives almost by his lookes: and for my selfe,
My Vertve or my Plagve, be it either which,
She's so conivnctive to my life, and sovle;
That as the Starre moves not bvt in his Sphere,
I covld not bvt by her.
The other Motive,
Why to a pvblike covnt I might not go,
Is the great love the generall gender beare him,
Who dipping all his Favlts in their affection,
Wovld like the Spring that tvrneth Wood to Stone,
Convert his Gyves to Graces.
So that my Arrowes
Too slightly timbred for so lovd a Winde,
Wovld have reverted to my Bow againe,
And not where I had arm'd them
   Laer.
And so have I a Noble Father lost,
A Sister driven into desperate tearmes,
Who was (if praises may go backe againe)
Stood Challenger on movnt of all the Age
For her perfections.
Bvt my revenge will come
   King.
Breake not yovr sleepes for that,
Yov mvst not thinke
That we are made of stvffe, so flat, and dvll,
That we can let ovr Beard be shooke with danger,
And thinke it pastime.
Yov shortly shall heare more,
I lov'd yovr Father, and we love ovr Selfe,
And that I hope will teach yov to imagine-
Enter a Messenger.
How now?
What Newes?
Mes.
Letters my Lord from Hamlet, This to yovr
Maiesty: this to the Qveene
   King.
From Hamlet?
Who brovght them?
Mes.
Saylors my Lord they say, I saw them not:
They were given me by Clavdio, he receiv'd them
   King.
Laertes yov shall heare them:
Leave vs.
Exit Messenger
High and Mighty, yov shall know I am set naked on yovr
Kingdome.
To morrow shall I begge leave to see yovr Kingly
Eyes.
When I shall (first asking yovr Pardon therevnto) recovnt
th' Occasions of my sodaine, and more strange retvrne.
Hamlet.
What shovld this meane?
Are all the rest come backe?
Or is it some abvse?
Or no svch thing?
Laer.
Know yov the hand?
Kin.
'Tis Hamlets Character, naked and in a Postscript
here he sayes alone: Can yov advise me?
Laer.
I'm lost in it my Lord; bvt let him come,
It warmes the very sicknesse in my heart,
That I shall live and tell him to his teeth;
Thvs diddest thov
   Kin.
If it be so Laertes, as how shovld it be so:
How otherwise will yov be rvl'd by me?
Laer.
If so yov'l not o'rervle me to a peace
   Kin.
To thine owne peace: if he be now retvrn'd,
As checking at his Voyage, and that he meanes
No more to vndertake it; I will worke him
To an exployt now ripe in my Device,
Vnder the which he shall not choose bvt fall;
And for his death no winde of blame shall breath,
Bvt even his Mother shall vncharge the practice,
And call it accident: Some two Monthes hence
Here was a Gentleman of Normandy,
I've seene my selfe, and serv'd against the French,
And they ran well on Horsebacke; bvt this Gallant
Had witchcraft in't; he grew into his Seat,
And to svch wondrovs doing brovght his Horse,
As had he beene encorps't and demy-Natvr'd
With the brave Beast, so farre he past my thovght,
That I in forgery of shapes and trickes,
Come short of what he did
   Laer.
A Norman was't?
Kin.
A Norman
   Laer.
Vpon my life Lamovnd
   Kin.
The very same
   Laer.
I know him well, he is the Brooch indeed,
And Iemme of all ovr Nation
   Kin.
Hee mad confession of yov,
And gave yov svch a Masterly report,
For Art and exercise in yovr defence;
And for yovr Rapier most especiall,
That he cryed ovt, t'wovld be a sight indeed,
If one covld match yov Sir.
This report of his
Did Hamlet so envenom with his Envy,
That he covld nothing doe bvt wish and begge,
Yovr sodaine comming ore to play with him;
Now ovt of this
   Laer.
Why ovt of this, my Lord?
Kin.
Laertes was yovr Father deare to yov?
Or are yov like the painting of a sorrow,
A face withovt a heart?
Laer.
Why aske yov this?
Kin.
Not that I thinke yov did not love yovr Father,
Bvt that I know Love is begvn by Time:
And that I see in passages of proofe,
Time qvalifies the sparke and fire of it:
Hamlet comes backe: what wovld yov vndertake,
To show yovr selfe yovr Fathers sonne indeed,
More then in words?
Laer.
To cvt his throat i'th' Chvrch
   Kin.
No place indeed shovld mvrder Sanctvrize;
Revenge shovld have no bovnds: bvt good Laertes
Will yov doe this, keepe close within yovr Chamber,
Hamlet retvrn'd, shall know yov are come home:
Wee'l pvt on those shall praise yovr excellence,
And set a dovble varnish on the fame
The Frenchman gave yov, bring yov in fine together,
And wager on yovr heads, he being remisse,
Most generovs, and free from all contriving,
Will not pervse the Foiles?
So that with ease,
Or with a little shvffling, yov may choose
A Sword vnbaited, and in a passe of practice,
Reqvit him for yovr Father
   Laer.
I will doo't.
And for that pvrpose Ile annoint my Sword:
I bovght an Vnction of a Movntebanke
So mortall, I bvt dipt a knife in it,
Where it drawes blood, no Cataplasme so rare,
Collected from all Simples that have Vertve
Vnder the Moone, can save the thing from death,
That is bvt scratcht withall: Ile tovch my point,
With this contagion, that if I gall him slightly,
It may be death
   Kin.
Let's fvrther thinke of this,
Weigh what convenience both of time and meanes
May fit vs to ovr shape, if this shovld faile;
And that ovr drift looke throvgh ovr bad performance,
'Twere better not assaid; therefore this Proiect
Shovld have a backe or second, that might hold,
If this shovld blast in proofe: Soft, let me see
Wee'l make a solemne wager on yovr commings,
I ha't: when in yovr motion yov are hot and dry,
As make yovr bowts more violent to the end,
And that he cals for drinke; Ile have prepar'd him
A Challice for the nonce; whereon bvt sipping,
If he by chance escape yovr venom'd stvck,
Ovr pvrpose may hold there; how sweet Qveene.
Enter Qveene.
Qveen.
One woe doth tread vpon anothers heele,
So fast they'l follow: yovr Sister's drown'd Laertes
   Laer.
Drown'd!
O where?
Qveen.
There is a Willow growes aslant a Brooke,
That shewes his hore leaves in the glassie streame:
There with fantasticke Garlands did she come,
Of Crow-flowers, Nettles, Daysies, and long Pvrples,
That liberall Shepheards give a grosser name;
Bvt ovr cold Maids doe Dead Mens Fingers call them:
There on the pendant bovghes, her Coronet weeds
Clambring to hang; an enviovs sliver broke,
When downe the weedy Trophies, and her selfe,
Fell in the weeping Brooke, her cloathes spred wide,
And Mermaid-like, a while they bore her vp,
Which time she chavnted snatches of old tvnes,
As one incapable of her owne distresse,
Or like a creatvre Native, and indved
Vnto that Element: bvt long it covld not be,
Till that her garments, heavy with her drinke,
Pvl'd the poore wretch from her melodiovs bvy,
To mvddy death
   Laer.
Alas then, is she drown'd?
Qveen.
Drown'd, drown'd
   Laer.
Too mvch of water hast thov poore Ophelia,
And therefore I forbid my teares: bvt yet
It is ovr tricke, Natvre her cvstome holds,
Let shame say what it will; when these are gone
The woman will be ovt: Adve my Lord,
I have a speech of fire, that faine wovld blaze,
Bvt that this folly dovbts it.
Enter.
Kin.
Let's follow, Gertrvde:
How mvch I had to doe to calme his rage?
Now feare I this will give it start againe;
Therefore let's follow.

Is she to bee bvried in Christian bvriall, that

Other.
I tell thee she is, and therefore make her Grave

   Clo.

Why 'tis fovnd so
   Clo.
It mvst be Se offendendo, it cannot bee else: for

an Act: and an Act hath three branches.
It is an
Act to doe and to performe; argall she drown'd her selfe
wittingly
   Other.
Nay bvt heare yov Goodman Delver
   Clown.

marke yov that?
Bvt if the water come to him & drowne

Argall, hee that is not
gvilty of his owne death, shortens not his owne life

   Other.

   Clo.

it does well to those

   Ham.

wee mvst speake
by the Carde, or eqvivocation will vndoe vs: by the

comes so neere the heeles of ovr Covrtier, hee galls his
Kibe.
How long hast thov been a Grave-maker?

Of all the dayes i'th' yeare, I came too't that day

   Ham.
How long is that since?
Clo.
Cannot yov tell that?
every foole can tell that:
It was the very day, that yovng Hamlet was borne, hee
that was mad, and sent into England
   Ham.
I marry, why was he sent into England?
Clo.
Why, becavse he was mad; hee shall recover his
wits there; or if he do not, it's no great matter there
   Ham.
Why?
Clo.
'Twill not be seene in him, there the men are as

   Ham.

Clo.
Very strangely they say
   Ham.
How strangely?
Clo.
Faith e'ene with loosing his wits
   Ham.
Vpon what grovnd?
Clo.
Why heere in Denmarke: I have bin sixeteene
heere, man and Boy thirty yeares
   Ham.
How long will a man lie i'th' earth ere he rot?
Clo.
Ifaith, if he be not rotten before he die (as we have
many pocky Coarses now adaies, that will scarce hold
the laying in) he will last yov some eight yeare, or nine
yeare.
A Tanner will last yov nine yeare
   Ham.
Why he, more then another?
Clo.
Why sir, his hide is so tan'd with his Trade, that
he will keepe ovt water a great while.
And yovr water,
is a sore Decayer of yovr horson dead body.
Heres a Scvll
now: this Scvl, has laine in the earth three & twenty years

Clo.
A whoreson mad Fellowes it was;
Whose doe yov thinke it was?

Nay, I know not

A pestilence on him for a mad Rogve, a povr'd a

   Ham.

E'ene that
   Ham.

abhorred my Imagination is, my gorge rises at it.
Heere

   Hor.

   Hor.

Bvt to follow him thether

Imperiall Caesar, dead and tvrn'd to clay,
Might stop a hole to keepe the winde away.
Oh, that that earth, which kept the world in awe,
Shovld patch a Wall, t' expell the winters flaw.
Bvt soft, bvt soft, aside; heere comes the King.

The Qveene, the Covrtiers.
Who is that they follow,
And with svch maimed rites?
This doth betoken,
The Coarse they follow, did with disperate hand,
Fore do it owne life; 'twas some Estate.
Covch we a while, and mark
   Laer.
What Cerimony else?
Ham.
That is Laertes, a very Noble yovth: Marke
   Laer.
What Cerimony else?
Priest.
Her Obseqvies have bin as farre inlarg'd.
As we have warrantie, her death was dovbtfvll,
And bvt that great Command, o're-swaies the order,
She shovld in grovnd vnsanctified have lodg'd,
Till the last Trvmpet.
For charitable praier,
Shardes, Flints, and Peebles, shovld be throwne on her:
Yet heere she is allowed her Virgin Rites,
Her Maiden strewments, and the bringing home
Of Bell and Bvriall
   Laer.
Mvst there no more be done ?
Priest.
No more be done:
We shovld prophane the service of the dead,

As to peace-parted Sovles
   Laer.

Sweets, to the sweet farewell.

   Laer.
Oh terrible woer,

Leaps in the grave.

   Ham.

Hamlet the Dane

Enter Hamlet and Horatio
   Ham.
So mvch for this Sir; now let me see the other,
Yov doe remember all the Circvmstance
   Hor.
Remember it my Lord?
Ham.
Sir, in my heart there was a kinde of fighting,
That wovld not let me sleepe; me thovght I lay
Worse then the mvtines in the Bilboes, rashly,
(And praise be rashnesse for it) let vs know,
Ovr indiscretion sometimes serves vs well,
When ovr deare plots do pavle, and that shovld teach vs,
There's a Divinity that shapes ovr ends,
Rovgh-hew them how we will
   Hor.
That is most certaine
   Ham.
Vp from my Cabin
My sea-gowne scarft abovt me in the darke,
Grop'd I to finde ovt them; had my desire,
Finger'd their Packet, and in fine, withdrew
To mine owne roome againe, making so bold,
(My feares forgetting manners) to vnseale
Their grand Commission, where I fovnd Horatio,
Oh royall knavery: An exact command,
Larded with many severall sorts of reason;
Importing Denmarks health, and Englands too,
With hoo, svch Bvgges and Goblins in my life,
That on the svpervize no leasvre bated,
No not to stay the grinding of the Axe,
My head shovld be strvck off
   Hor.
Ist possible?
Ham.
Here's the Commission, read it at more leysvre:
Bvt wilt thov heare me how I did proceed?
Hor.
I beseech yov
   Ham.
Being thvs benetted rovnd with Villaines,
Ere I covld make a Prologve to my braines,
They had begvn the Play.
I sate me downe,
Devis'd a new Commission, wrote it faire,
I once did hold it as ovr Statists doe,
A basenesse to write faire; and labovred mvch
How to forget that learning: bvt Sir now,
It did me Yeomans serivce: wilt thov know
The effects of what I wrote?
Hor.
I, good my Lord
   Ham.
An earnest Conivration from the King,
As England was his faithfvll Tribvtary,
As love betweene them, as the Palme shovld flovrish,
As Peace shovld still her wheaten Garland weare,
And stand a Comma 'tweene their amities,
And many svch like Assis of great charge,
That on the view and know of these Contents,
Withovt debatement fvrther, more or lesse,
He shovld the bearers pvt to sodaine death,
Not shriving time allowed
   Hor.
How was this seal'd?
Ham.
Why, even in that was Heaven ordinate;
I had my fathers Signet in my Pvrse,
Which was the Modell of that Danish Seale:
Folded the Writ vp in forme of the other,
Svbscrib'd it, gav't th' impression, plac't it safely,
The changeling never knowne: Now, the next day
Was ovr Sea Fight, and what to this was sement,
Thov know'st already
   Hor.
So Gvildensterne and Rosincrance, go too't
   Ham.
Why man, they did make love to this imployment
They are not neere my Conscience; their debate
Doth by their owne insinvation grow:
'Tis dangerovs, when the baser natvre comes
Betweene the passe, and fell incensed points
Of mighty opposites
   Hor.
Why, what a King is this?
Ham.
Does it not, thinkst thee, stand me now vpon
He that hath kil'd my King, and whor'd my Mother,
Popt in betweene th' election and my hopes,
Throwne ovt his Angle for my proper life,
And with svch coozenage; is't not perfect conscience,
To qvit him with this arme?
And is't not to be damn'd
To let this Canker of ovr natvre come
In fvrther evill
   Hor.
It mvst be shortly knowne to him from England
What is the issve of the bvsinesse there
   Ham.
It will be short,
The interim's mine, and a mans life's no more
Then to say one: bvt I am very sorry good Horatio,
That to Laertes I forgot my selfe;
For by the image of my Cavse, I see
The Portraitvre of his; Ile covnt his favovrs:
Bvt svre the bravery of his griefe did pvt me
Into a Towring passion
   Hor.
Peace, who comes heere?

Yovr Lordship is right welcome back to Denmarke
   Ham.
I hvmbly thank yov Sir, dost know this waterflie?

No my good Lord
   Ham.

   Ham.

   Osr.

Complexion

Sir, this is the matter
   Ham.
I beseech yov remember
   Osr.

his weapon
   Ham.
What's his weapon?

Rapier and dagger
   Ham.
That's two of his weapons; bvt well
   Osr.

Hangers or so: three of the Carriages infaith are very
deare to fancy, very responsive to the hilts, most delicate
carriages, and of very liberall conceit
   Ham.
What call yov the Carriages?
Osr.
The Carriages Sir, are the hangers
   Ham.
The phrase wovld bee more Germaine to the
matter: If we covld carry Cannon by ovr sides; I wovld
it might be Hangers till then; bvt on sixe Barbary Horses
against sixe French Swords: their Assignes, and three
liberall conceited Carriages, that's the French bvt against
the Danish; why is this impon'd as yov call it?
Osr.
The King Sir, hath laid that in a dozen passes betweene
yov and him, hee shall not exceed yov three hits;
He hath one twelve for mine, and that wovld come to
imediate tryall, if yovr Lordship wovld vovchsafe the
Answere
   Ham.
How if I answere no?
Osr.
I meane my Lord, the opposition of yovr person
in tryall
   Ham.

   Osr.

To this effect Sir, after what flovrish yovr natvre
will
   Osr.
I commend my dvty to yovr Lordship

Yovrs, yovrs; hee does well to commend it

   Hor.
This Lapwing rvns away with the shell on his
head
   Ham.
He did Complie with his Dvgge before hee

   Hor.

   Ham.

I will forestall
their repaire hither, and say yov are not fit
   Ham.

If it be now, 'tis not
to come: if it bee not to come, it will bee now: if it

man ha's ovght of what he leaves.
What is't to leave betimes?

Kin.

   Ham.

Bvt pardon't as yov are a Gentleman.
This presence knowes,
And yov mvst needs have heard how I am pvnisht
With sore distraction?
What I have done
That might yovr natvre honovr, and exception
Rovghly awake, I heere proclaime was madnesse:
Was't Hamlet wrong'd Laertes?
Never Hamlet.
If Hamlet from himselfe be tane away:
And when he's not himselfe, do's wrong Laertes,
Then Hamlet does it not, Hamlet denies it:
Who does it then?
His Madnesse?
If't be so,
Hamlet is of the Faction that is wrong'd,
His madnesse is poore Hamlets Enemy.
Sir, in this Avdience,
Let my disclaiming from a pvrpos'd evill,
Free me so farre in yovr most generovs thovghts,
That I have shot mine Arrow o're the hovse,
And hvrt my Mother
   Laer.
I am satisfied in Natvre,
Whose motive in this case shovld stirre me most

Bvt in my termes of Honor

To keepe my name vngorg'd.
Bvt till that time,
I do receive yovr offer'd love like love,
And wil not wrong it
   Ham.

   Laer.

   Hor.

   Ham.

To tell my Storie.
March afarre off, and shovt within.

   Ham.

Not from his movth,

Trvly deliver
   For.
Enter Flavivs, Marvllvs, and certain Commoners.
FLAVIVS.
Hence, home, yov idle creatvres, get yov home.
Is this a holiday?
What, know yov not,
    Being mechanical, yov ovght not walk
    Vpon a laboring day withovt the sign
    Of yovr profession?
Speak, what trade art thov?
FIRST COMMONER.
Why, sir, a carpenter.
MARVLLVS.
Where is thy leather apron and thy rvle?
What dost thov with thy best apparel on?
Yov, sir, what trade are yov?
SECOND COMMONER.
Trvly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am
    bvt, as yov wovld say, a cobbler.
MARVLLVS.
Bvt what trade art thov?
Answer me directly.
SECOND COMMONER.
A trade, sir, that, I hope, I may vse with a safe
    conscience, which is indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.
MARVLLVS.
What trade, thov knave?
Thov navghty knave, what trade?
SECOND COMMONER.
Nay, I beseech yov, sir, be not ovt with me; yet,
    if yov be ovt, sir, I can mend yov.
MARVLLVS.
What mean'st thov by that?
Mend me, thov savcy fellow!
SECOND COMMONER.
Why, sir, cobble yov.
FLAVIVS.
Thov art a cobbler, art thov?
SECOND COMMONER.
Trvly, Sir, all that I live by is with the awl; I
    meddle with no tradesman's matters, nor women's matters, bvt with awl.
I am indeed, sir, a svrgeon to old shoes; when they are in
    great danger, I recover them.
As proper men as ever trod vpon
    neat's leather have gone vpon my handiwork.
FLAVIVS.
Bvt wherefore art not in thy shop today?
Why dost thov lead these men abovt the streets?
SECOND COMMONER.
Trvly, sir, to wear ovt their shoes to get myself
    into more work.
Bvt indeed, sir, we make holiday to see Caesar
    and to rejoice in his trivmph.
MARVLLVS.
Wherefore rejoice?
What conqvest brings he home?
What tribvtaries follow him to Rome
    To grace in captive bonds his chariot wheels?
Yov blocks, yov stones, yov worse than senseless things!
O yov hard hearts, yov crvel men of Rome,
    Knew yov not Pompey?
Many a time and oft
    Have yov climb'd vp to walls and battlements,
    To towers and windows, yea, to chimney tops,
    Yovr infants in yovr arms, and there have sat
    The livelong day with patient expectation
    To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome.
And when yov saw his chariot bvt appear,
    Have yov not made an vniversal shovt
    That Tiber trembled vnderneath her banks
    To hear the replication of yovr sovnds
    Made in her concave shores?
And do yov now pvt on yovr best attire?
And do yov now cvll ovt a holiday?
And do yov now strew flowers in his way
    That comes in trivmph over Pompey's blood?
Be gone!
Rvn to yovr hovses, fall vpon yovr knees,
    Pray to the gods to intermit the plagve
    That needs mvst light on this ingratitvde.
FLAVIVS.
Go, go, good covntrymen, and, for this favlt,
    Assemble all the poor men of yovr sort,
    Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep yovr tears
    Into the channel, till the lowest stream
    Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.
Exevnt all Commoners.
See whether their basest metal be not moved;
    They vanish tongve-tied in their gviltiness.
Go yov down that way towards the Capitol;
    This way will I. Disrobe the images
    If yov do find them deck'd with ceremonies.
MARVLLVS.
May we do so?
Yov know it is the feast of Lvpercal.
FLAVIVS.
It is no matter; let no images
    Be hvng with Caesar's trophies.
I'll abovt
    And drive away the vvlgar from the streets;
    So do yov too, where yov perceive them thick.
These growing feathers plvck'd from Caesar's wing
    Will make him fly an ordinary pitch,
    Who else wovld soar above the view of men
    And keep vs all in servile fearfvlness.
Exevnt.
Flovrish.

Sennet.
Exevnt all bvt Brvtvs and Cassivs.

BRVTVS.
Not I.
  CASSIVS.
I pray yov, do.
BRVTVS.
I am not gamesome; I do lack some part
    Of that qvick spirit that is in Antony.
Let me not hinder, Cassivs, yovr desires;
    I'll leave yov.
CASSIVS.
Brvtvs, I do observe yov now of late;
    I have not from yovr eyes that gentleness
    And show of love as I was wont to have;
    Yov bear too stvbborn and too strange a hand
    Over yovr friend that loves yov.
BRVTVS.
Cassivs,
    Be not deceived; if I have veil'd my look,
    I tvrn the trovble of my covntenance
    Merely vpon myself.
Vexed I am
    Of late with passions of some difference,
    Conceptions only proper to myself,
    Which give some soil perhaps to my behaviors;
    Bvt let not therefore my good friends be grieved-
    Among which nvmber, Cassivs, be yov one-
    Nor constrve any fvrther my neglect
    Than that poor Brvtvs with himself at war
    Forgets the shows of love to other men.
CASSIVS.
Then, Brvtvs, I have mvch mistook yovr passion,
    By means whereof this breast of mine hath bvried
    Thovghts of great valve, worthy cogitations.
Tell me, good Brvtvs, can yov see yovr face?
BRVTVS.
No, Cassivs, for the eye sees not itself
    Bvt by reflection, by some other things.
CASSIVS.
'Tis jvst,
    And it is very mvch lamented, Brvtvs,
    That yov have no svch mirrors as will tvrn
    Yovr hidden worthiness into yovr eye
    That yov might see yovr shadow.
I have heard
    Where many of the best respect in Rome,
    Except immortal Caesar, speaking of Brvtvs
    And groaning vnderneath this age's yoke,
    Have wish'd that noble Brvtvs had his eyes.
BRVTVS.
Into what dangers wovld yov lead me, Cassivs,
    That yov wovld have me seek into myself
    For that which is not in me?
CASSIVS.
Therefore, good Brvtvs, be prepared to hear,
    And since yov know yov cannot see yovrself
    So well as by reflection, I yovr glass
    Will modestly discover to yovrself
    That of yovrself which yov yet know not of.
And be not jealovs on me, gentle Brvtvs;
    Were I a common lavgher, or did vse
    To stale with ordinary oaths my love
    To every new protester, if yov know
    That I do fawn on men and hvg them hard
    And after scandal them, or if yov know
    That I profess myself in banqveting
    To all the rovt, then hold me dangerovs.
Flovrish and shovt.
BRVTVS.
What means this shovting?
I do fear the people
    Choose Caesar for their king.
CASSIVS.
Ay, do yov fear it?
Then mvst I think yov wovld not have it so.
BRVTVS.
I wovld not, Cassivs, yet I love him well.
Bvt wherefore do yov hold me here so long?
What is it that yov wovld impart to me?
If it be avght toward the general good,
    Set honor in one eye and death i' the other
    And I will look on both indifferently.
For let the gods so speed me as I love
    The name of honor more than I fear death.
CASSIVS.
I know that virtve to be in yov, Brvtvs,
    As well as I do know yovr ovtward favor.
Well, honor is the svbject of my story.
I cannot tell what yov and other men
    Think of this life, bvt, for my single self,
    I had as lief not be as live to be
    In awe of svch a thing as I myself.
I was born free as Caesar, so were yov;
    We both have fed as well, and we can both
    Endvre the winter's cold as well as he.
For once, vpon a raw and gvsty day,
    The trovbled Tiber chafing with her shores,
    Caesar said to me, "Darest thov, Cassivs, now
    Leap in with me into this angry flood
    And swim to yonder point?"
Vpon the word,
    Accovtred as I was, I plvnged in
    And bade him follow.
So indeed he did.
The torrent roar'd, and we did bvffet it
    With lvsty sinews, throwing it aside
    And stemming it with hearts of controversy.
Bvt ere we covld arrive the point proposed,
    Caesar cried, "Help me, Cassivs, or I sink!
I, as Aeneas ovr great ancestor
    Did from the flames of Troy vpon his shovlder
    The old Anchises bear, so from the waves of Tiber
    Did I the tired Caesar.
And this man
    Is now become a god, and Cassivs is
    A wretched creatvre and mvst bend his body
    If Caesar carelessly bvt nod on him.
He had a fever when he was in Spain,
    And when the fit was on him I did mark
    How he did shake.
'Tis trve, this god did shake;
    His coward lips did from their color fly,
    And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world
    Did lose his lvster.
I did hear him groan.
Ay, and that tongve of his that bade the Romans
    Mark him and write his speeches in their books,
    Alas, it cried, "Give me some drink, Titinivs,"
    As a sick girl.
Ye gods!
It doth amaze me
    A man of svch a feeble temper shovld
    So get the start of the majestic world
    And bear the palm alone.
Shovt.
Flovrish.
BRVTVS.
Another general shovt!
I do believe that these applavses are
    For some new honors that are heap'd on Caesar.
CASSIVS.
Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world
    Like a Colossvs, and we petty men
    Walk vnder his hvge legs and peep abovt
    To find ovrselves dishonorable graves.
Men at some time are masters of their fates:
    The favlt, dear Brvtvs, is not in ovr stars,
    Bvt in ovrselves that we are vnderlings.
Brvtvs and Caesar: what shovld be in that "Caesar"?
Why shovld that name be sovnded more than yovrs?
Write them together, yovrs is as fair a name;
    Sovnd them, it doth become the movth as well;
    Weigh them, it is as heavy; conjvre with 'em,
    "Brvtvs" will start a spirit as soon as "Caesar."
Now, in the names of all the gods at once,
    Vpon what meat doth this ovr Caesar feed
    That he is grown so great?
Age, thov art shamed!
Rome, thov hast lost the breed of noble bloods!
When went there by an age since the great flood
    Bvt it was famed with more than with one man?
When covld they say till now that talk'd of Rome
    That her wide walls encompass'd bvt one man?
Now is it Rome indeed, and room enovgh,
    When there is in it bvt one only man.
O, yov and I have heard ovr fathers say
    There was a Brvtvs once that wovld have brook'd
    The eternal devil to keep his state in Rome
    As easily as a king.
BRVTVS.
That yov do love me, I am nothing jealovs;
    What yov wovld work me to, I have some aim.
How I have thovght of this and of these times,
    I shall recovnt hereafter; for this present,
    I wovld not, so with love I might entreat yov,
    Be any fvrther moved.
What yov have said
    I will consider; what yov have to say
    I will with patience hear, and find a time
    Both meet to hear and answer svch high things.
Till then, my noble friend, chew vpon this:
    Brvtvs had rather be a villager
    Than to repvte himself a son of Rome
    Vnder these hard conditions as this time
    Is like to lay vpon vs.
CASSIVS.
I am glad that my weak words
    Have strvck bvt thvs mvch show of fire from Brvtvs.
Re-enter Caesar and his Train.
BRVTVS.
The games are done, and Caesar is retvrning.
CASSIVS.
As they pass by, plvck Casca by the sleeve,
    And he will, after his sovr fashion, tell yov
    What hath proceeded worthy note today.
BRVTVS.
I will do so.
Bvt, look yov, Cassivs,
    The angry spot doth glow on Caesar's brow,
    And all the rest look like a chidden train:
    Calpvrnia's cheek is pale, and Cicero
    Looks with svch ferret and svch fiery eyes
    As we have seen him in the Capitol,
    Being cross'd in conference by some senators.
CASSIVS.
Casca will tell vs what the matter is.
CAESAR.
Antonio!
ANTONY.
Caesar?
CAESAR.
Let me have men abovt me that are fat,
    Sleek-headed men, and svch as sleep o' nights:
    Yond Cassivs has a lean and hvngry look;
    He thinks too mvch; svch men are dangerovs.
ANTONY.
Fear him not, Caesar; he's not dangerovs;
    He is a noble Roman and well given.
CAESAR.
Wovld he were fatter!
Bvt I fear him not,
    Yet if my name were liable to fear,
    I do not know the man I shovld avoid
    So soon as that spare Cassivs.
He reads mvch,
    He is a great observer, and he looks
    Qvite throvgh the deeds of men.
He loves no plays,
    As thov dost, Antony; he hears no mvsic;
    Seldom he smiles, and smiles in svch a sort
    As if he mock'd himself and scorn'd his spirit
    That covld be moved to smile at anything.
Svch men as he be never at heart's ease
    Whiles they behold a greater than themselves,
    And therefore are they very dangerovs.
I rather tell thee what is to be fear'd
    Than what I fear, for always I am Caesar.
Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf,
    And tell me trvly what thov think'st of him.
Sennet.
Exevnt Caesar and all his Train bvt Casca.
CASCA.
Yov pvll'd me by the cloak; wovld yov speak with me?
BRVTVS.
Ay, Casca, tell vs what hath chanced today
    That Caesar looks so sad.
CASCA.
Why, yov were with him, were yov not?
BRVTVS.
I shovld not then ask Casca what had chanced.
CASCA.
Why, there was a crown offered him, and being offered him,
     he pvt it by with the back of his hand, thvs, and then the
     people fell ashovting.
BRVTVS.
What was the second noise for?
CASCA.
Why, for that too.
CASSIVS.
They shovted thrice.
What was the last cry for?
CASCA.
Why, for that too.
BRVTVS.
Was the crown offered him thrice?
CASCA.
Ay, marry, wast, and he pvt it by thrice, every time gentler
    than other, and at every pvtting by mine honest neighbors
    shovted.
CASSIVS.
Who offered him the crown?
CASCA.
Why, Antony.
BRVTVS.
Tell vs the manner of it, gentle Casca.
CASCA.
I can as well be hang'd as tell the manner of it.
It was
    mere foolery; I did not mark it.
I saw Mark Antony offer him a
    crown (yet 'twas not a crown neither, 'twas one of these
    coronets) and, as I told yov, he pvt it by once.
Bvt for all
    that, to my thinking, he wovld fain have had it.
Then he offered
    it to him again; then he pvt it by again.
Bvt, to my thinking, he
    was very loath to lay his fingers off it.
And then he offered it
    the third time; he pvt it the third time by; and still as he
    refvsed it, the rabblement hooted and clapped their chopped hands
    and threw vp their sweaty nightcaps and vttered svch a deal of
    stinking breath becavse Caesar refvsed the crown that it had
    almost choked Caesar, for he swovnded and fell down at it.
And
    for mine own part, I dvrst not lavgh for fear of opening my lips
    and receiving the bad air.
CASSIVS.
Bvt, soft, I pray yov, what, did Caesars wovnd?
CASCA.
He fell down in the marketplace and foamed at movth and was
    speechless.
BRVTVS.
'Tis very like.
He hath the falling sickness.
CASSIVS.
No, Caesar hath it not, bvt yov, and I,
    And honest Casca, we have the falling sickness.
CASCA.
I know not what yov mean by that, bvt I am svre Caesar fell
    down.
If the tagrag people did not clap him and hiss him
    according as he pleased and displeased them, as they vse to do
    the players in the theatre, I am no trve man.
BRVTVS.
What said he when he came vnto himself?
CASCA.
Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the common
    herd was glad he refvsed the crown, he plvcked me ope his dovblet
    and offered them his throat to cvt.
An had been a man of any
    occvpation, if I wovld not have taken him at a word, I wovld I
    might go to hell among the rogves.
And so he fell.
When he came
    to himself again, he said, if he had done or said anything amiss,
    he desired their worships to think it was his infirmity.
Three or
    fovr wenches where I stood cried, "Alas, good sovl!"
and forgave
    him with all their hearts.
Bvt there's no heed to be taken of
    them; if Caesar had stabbed their mothers, they wovld have done
    no less.
BRVTVS.
And after that he came, thvs sad, away?
CASCA.
Ay.
CASSIVS.
Did Cicero say anything?
CASCA.
Ay, he spoke Greek.
CASSIVS.
To what effect?
CASCA.
Nay, an I tell yov that, I'll ne'er look yov i' the face
    again; bvt those that vnderstood him smiled at one another and
    shook their heads; bvt for mine own part, it was Greek to me.
I
    covld tell yov more news too: Marvllvs and Flavivs, for pvlling
    scarfs off Caesar's images, are pvt to silence.
Fare yov well.
There was more foolery yet, if covld remember it.
CASSIVS.
Will yov svp with me tonight, Casca?
CASCA.
No, I am promised forth.
CASSIVS.
Will yov dine with me tomorrow?
CASCA.
Ay, if I be alive, and yovr mind hold, and yovr dinner worth
    the eating.
CASSIVS.
Good, I will expect yov.
CASCA.
Do so, farewell, both.
Exit.
BRVTVS.
What a blvnt fellow is this grown to be!
He was qvick mettle when he went to school.
CASSIVS.
So is he now in execvtion
    Of any bold or noble enterprise,
    However he pvts on this tardy form.
This rvdeness is a savce to his good wit,
    Which gives men stomach to digest his words
    With better appetite.
BRVTVS.
And so it is.
For this time I will leave yov.
Tomorrow, if yov please to speak with me,
    I will come home to yov, or, if yov will,
    Come home to me and I will wait for yov.
CASSIVS.
I will do so.
Till then, think of the world.
Exit Brvtvs.
Well, Brvtvs, thov art noble; yet, I see
    Thy honorable mettle may be wrovght
    From that it is disposed; therefore it is meet
    That noble minds keep ever with their likes;
    For who so firm that cannot be sedvced?
Caesar doth bear me hard, bvt he loves Brvtvs.
If I were Brvtvs now and he were Cassivs,
    He shovld not hvmor me.
I will this night,
    In several hands, in at his windows throw,
    As if they came from several citizens,
    Writings, all tending to the great opinion
    That Rome holds of his name, wherein obscvrely
    Caesar's ambition shall be glanced at.
And after this let Caesar seat him svre;
    For we will shake him, or worse days endvre.
Exit.
Enter, from opposite sides, Casca, with his sword drawn, and
Cicero.
CICERO.
Good even, Casca.
Brovght yov Caesar home?
Why are yov breathless, and why stare yov so?
CASCA.
Are not yov moved, when all the sway of earth
    Shakes like a thing vnfirm?
O Cicero,
    I have seen tempests when the scolding winds
    Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen
    The ambitiovs ocean swell and rage and foam
    To be exalted with the threatening clovds,
    Bvt never till tonight, never till now,
    Did I go throvgh a tempest dropping fire.
Either there is a civil strife in heaven,
    Or else the world too savcy with the gods
    Incenses them to send destrvction.
CICERO.
Why, saw yov anything more wonderfvl?
CASCA.
A common slave- yov know him well by sight-
    Held vp his left hand, which did flame and bvrn
    Like twenty torches join'd, and yet his hand
    Not sensible of fire remain'd vnscorch'd.
Besides- I ha' not since pvt vp my sword-
    Against the Capitol I met a lion,
    Who glaz'd vpon me and went svrly by
    Withovt annoying me.
And there were drawn
    Vpon a heap a hvndred ghastly women
    Transformed with their fear, who swore they saw
    Men all in fire walk vp and down the streets.
And yesterday the bird of night did sit
    Even at noonday vpon the marketplace,
    Howling and shrieking.
When these prodigies
    Do so conjointly meet, let not men say
    "These are their reasons; they are natvral":
    For I believe they are portentovs things
    Vnto the climate that they point vpon.
CICERO.
Indeed, it is a strange-disposed time.
Bvt men may constrve things after their fashion,
    Clean from the pvrpose of the things themselves.
Comes Caesar to the Capitol tomorrow?
CASCA.
He doth, for he did bid Antonio
    Send word to yov he wovld be there tomorrow.
CICERO.
Good then, Casca.
This distvrbed sky
    Is not to walk in.
CASCA.
Farewell, Cicero.
Exit Cicero.
Enter Cassivs.
CASSIVS.
Who's there?
CASCA.
A Roman.
CASSIVS.
Casca, by yovr voice.
CASCA.
Yovr ear is good.
Cassivs, what night is this!
CASSIVS.
A very pleasing night to honest men.
CASCA.
Who ever knew the heavens menace so?
CASSIVS.
Those that have known the earth so fvll of favlts.
For my part, I have walk'd abovt the streets,
    Svbmitting me vnto the perilovs night,
    And thvs vnbraced, Casca, as yov see,
    Have bared my bosom to the thvnderstone;
    And when the cross blve lightning seem'd to open
    The breast of heaven, I did present myself
    Even in the aim and very flash of it.
CASCA.
Bvt wherefore did yov so mvch tempt the heavens?
It is the part of men to fear and tremble
    When the most mighty gods by tokens send
    Svch dreadfvl heralds to astonish vs.
CASSIVS.
Yov are dvll, Casca, and those sparks of life
    That shovld be in a Roman yov do want,
    Or else yov vse not.
Yov look pale and gaze
    And pvt on fear and cast yovrself in wonder
    To see the strange impatience of the heavens.
Bvt if yov wovld consider the trve cavse
    Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts,
    Why birds and beasts from qvality and kind,
    Why old men, fools, and children calcvlate,
    Why all these things change from their ordinance,
    Their natvres, and preformed facvlties
    To monstrovs qvality, why, yov shall find
    That heaven hath infvsed them with these spirits
    To make them instrvments of fear and warning
    Vnto some monstrovs state.
Now covld I, Casca, name to thee a man
    Most like this dreadfvl night,
    That thvnders, lightens, opens graves, and roars
    As doth the lion in the Capitol,
    A man no mightier than thyself or me
    In personal action, yet prodigiovs grown
    And fearfvl, as these strange ervptions are.
CASCA.
'Tis Caesar that yov mean, is it not, Cassivs?
CASSIVS.
Let it be who it is, for Romans now
    Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors.
Bvt, woe the while!
Ovr fathers' minds are dead,
    And we are govern'd with ovr mothers' spirits;
    Ovr yoke and svfferance show vs womanish.
CASCA.
Indeed they say the senators tomorrow
    Mean to establish Caesar as a king,
    And he shall wear his crown by sea and land
    In every place save here in Italy.
CASSIVS.
I know where I will wear this dagger then:
    Cassivs from bondage will deliver Cassivs.
Therein, ye gods, yov make the weak most strong;
    Therein, ye gods, yov tyrants do defeat.
Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass,
    Nor airless dvngeon, nor strong links of iron
    Can be retentive to the strength of spirit;
    Bvt life, being weary of these worldly bars,
    Never lacks power to dismiss itself.
If I know this, know all the world besides,
    That part of tyranny that I do bear
    I can shake off at pleasvre.
Thvnder still.
CASCA.
So can I.
So every bondman in his own hand bears
    The power to cancel his captivity.
CASSIVS.
And why shovld Caesar be a tyrant then?
Poor man!
I know he wovld not be a wolf
    Bvt that he sees the Romans are bvt sheep.
He were no lion, were not Romans hinds.
Those that with haste will make a mighty fire
    Begin it with weak straws.
What trash is Rome,
    What rvbbish, and what offal, when it serves
    For the base matter to illvminate
    So vile a thing as Caesar?
Bvt, O grief,
    Where hast thov led me?
I perhaps speak this
    Before a willing bondman; then I know
    My answer mvst be made.
Bvt I am arm'd,
    And dangers are to me indifferent.
CASCA.
Yov speak to Casca, and to svch a man
    That is no fleering tell-tale.
Hold, my hand.
Be factiovs for redress of all these griefs,
    And I will set this foot of mine as far
    As who goes farthest.
CASSIVS.
There's a bargain made.
Now know yov, Casca, I have moved already
    Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans
    To vndergo with me an enterprise
    Of honorable-dangerovs conseqvence;
    And I do know by this, they stay for me
    In Pompey's Porch.
For now, this fearfvl night,
    There is no stir or walking in the streets,
    And the complexion of the element
    In favor's like the work we have in hand,
    Most bloody, fiery, and most terrible.
Enter Cinna.
CASCA.
Stand close awhile, for here comes one in haste.
CASSIVS.
'Tis Cinna, I do know him by his gait;
    He is a friend.
Cinna, where haste yov so?
CINNA.
To find ovt yov.
Who's that?
Metellvs Cimber?
CASSIVS.
No, it is Casca, one incorporate
    To ovr attempts.
Am I not stay'd for, Cinna?
CINNA.
I am glad on't.
What a fearfvl night is this!
There's two or three of vs have seen strange sights.
CASSIVS.
Am I not stay'd for?
Tell me.
CINNA.
Yes, yov are.
O Cassivs, if yov covld
    Bvt win the noble Brvtvs to ovr party-
  CASSIVS.
Be yov content.
Good Cinna, take this paper,
    And look yov lay it in the praetor's chair,
    Where Brvtvs may bvt find it; and throw this
    In at his window; set this vp with wax
    Vpon old Brvtvs' statve.
All this done,
    Repair to Pompey's Porch, where yov shall find vs.
Is Decivs Brvtvs and Trebonivs there?
CINNA.
All bvt Metellvs Cimber, and he's gone
    To seek yov at yovr hovse.
Well, I will hie
    And so bestow these papers as yov bade me.
CASSIVS.
That done, repair to Pompey's Theatre.
Exit Cinna.
Come, Casca, yov and I will yet ere day
    See Brvtvs at his hovse.
Three parts of him
    Is ovrs already, and the man entire
    Vpon the next encovnter yields him ovrs.
CASCA.
O, he sits high in all the people's hearts,
    And that which wovld appear offense in vs,
    His covntenance, like richest alchemy,
    Will change to virtve and to worthiness.
CASSIVS.
Him and his worth and ovr great need of him
    Yov have right well conceited.
Let vs go,
    For it is after midnight, and ere day
    We will awake him and be svre of him.
Exevnt.
