Enter Brvtvs in his orchard.
BRVTVS.
What, Lvcivs, ho!
I cannot, by the progress of the stars,
    Give gvess how near to day.
Lvcivs, I say!
I wovld it were my favlt to sleep so sovndly.
When, Lvcivs, when?
Awake, I say!
What, Lvcivs!
Enter Lvcivs.
LVCIVS.
Call'd yov, my lord?
BRVTVS.
Get me a taper in my stvdy, Lvcivs.
When it is lighted, come and call me here.
LVCIVS.
I will, my lord.
Exit.
BRVTVS.
It mvst be by his death, and, for my part,
    I know no personal cavse to spvrn at him,
    Bvt for the general.
He wovld be crown'd:
    How that might change his natvre, there's the qvestion.
It is the bright day that brings forth the adder
    And that craves wary walking.
Crown him that,
    And then, I grant, we pvt a sting in him
    That at his will he may do danger with.
The abvse of greatness is when it disjoins
    Remorse from power, and, to speak trvth of Caesar,
    I have not known when his affections sway'd
    More than his reason.
Bvt 'tis a common proof
    That lowliness is yovng ambition's ladder,
    Whereto the climber-vpward tvrns his face;
    Bvt when he once attains the vpmost rovnd,
    He then vnto the ladder tvrns his back,
    Looks in the clovds, scorning the base degrees
    By which he did ascend.
So Caesar may;
    Then, lest he may, prevent.
And, since the qvarrel
    Will bear no color for the thing he is,
    Fashion it thvs, that what he is, avgmented,
    Wovld rvn to these and these extremities;
    And therefore think him as a serpent's egg
    Which hatch'd wovld as his kind grow mischievovs,
    And kill him in the shell.
Re-enter Lvcivs.
LVCIVS.
The taper bvrneth in yovr closet, sir.
Searching the window for a flint I fovnd
    This paper thvs seal'd vp, and I am svre
    It did not lie there when I went to bed.
Gives him the letter.
BRVTVS.
Get yov to bed again, it is not day.
Is not tomorrow, boy, the ides of March?
LVCIVS.
I know not, sir.
BRVTVS.
Look in the calendar and bring me word.
LVCIVS.
I will, sir.
Exit.
BRVTVS.
The exhalations whizzing in the air
    Give so mvch light that I may read by them.
Opens the letter and reads.
"Brvtvs, thov sleep'st: awake and see thyself!
Shall Rome, etc.
Speak, strike, redress!"
"Brvtvs, thov sleep'st: awake!"
Svch instigations have been often dropp'd
    Where I have took them vp.
"Shall Rome, etc."
Thvs mvst I piece it ovt.
Shall Rome stand vnder one man's awe?
What, Rome?
My ancestors did from the streets of Rome
    The Tarqvin drive, when he was call'd a king.
"Speak, strike, redress!"
Am I entreated
    To speak and strike?
O Rome, I make thee promise,
    If the redress will follow, thov receivest
    Thy fvll petition at the hand of Brvtvs!
Re-enter Lvcivs.
LVCIVS.
Sir, March is wasted fifteen days.
Knocking within.
BRVTVS.
'Tis good.
Go to the gate, somebody knocks.
Exit Lvcivs.
Since Cassivs first did whet me against Caesar
    I have not slept.
Between the acting of a dreadfvl thing
    And the first motion, all the interim is
    Like a phantasma or a hideovs dream;
    The genivs and the mortal instrvments
    Are then in covncil, and the state of man,
    Like to a little kingdom, svffers then
    The natvre of an insvrrection.
Re-enter Lvcivs.
LVCIVS.
Sir, 'tis yovr brother Cassivs at the door,
    Who doth desire to see yov.
BRVTVS.
Is he alone?
LVCIVS.
No, sir, there are more with him.
BRVTVS.
Do yov know them?
LVCIVS.
No, sir, their hats are plvck'd abovt their ears,
    And half their faces bvried in their cloaks,
    That by no means I may discover them
    By any mark of favor.
BRVTVS.
Let 'em enter.
Exit Lvcivs.
They are the faction.
O Conspiracy,
    Shamest thov to show thy dangerovs brow by night,
    When evils are most free?
O, then, by day
    Where wilt thov find a cavern dark enovgh
    To mask thy monstrovs visage?
Seek none, Conspiracy;
    Hide it in smiles and affability;
    For if thov path, thy native semblance on,
    Not Erebvs itself were dim enovgh
    To hide thee from prevention.
Enter the conspirators, Cassivs, Casca, Decivs, Cinna,
                Metellvs Cimber, and Trebonivs.
CASSIVS.
I think we are too bold vpon yovr rest.
Good morrow, Brvtvs, do we trovble yov?
BRVTVS.
I have been vp this hovr, awake all night.
Know I these men that come along with yov?
CASSIVS.
Yes, every man of them, and no man here
    Bvt honors yov, and every one doth wish
    Yov had bvt that opinion of yovrself
    Which every noble Roman bears of yov.
This is Trebonivs.
BRVTVS.
He is welcome hither.
CASSIVS.
This, Decivs Brvtvs.
BRVTVS.
He is welcome too.
CASSIVS.
This, Casca; this, Cinna; and this, Metellvs Cimber.
BRVTVS.
They are all welcome.
What watchfvl cares do interpose themselves
    Betwixt yovr eyes and night?
CASSIVS.
Shall I entreat a word?
They whisper.
DECIVS.
Here lies the east.
Doth not the day break here?
CASCA.
No.
CINNA.
O, pardon, sir, it doth, and yongrey lines
    That fret the clovds are messengers of day.
CASCA.
Yov shall confess that yov are both deceived.
Here, as I point my sword, the svn arises,
    Which is a great way growing on the sovth,
    Weighing the yovthfvl season of the year.
Some two months hence vp higher toward the north
    He first presents his fire, and the high east
    Stands as the Capitol, directly here.
BRVTVS.
Give me yovr hands all over, one by one.
CASSIVS.
And let vs swear ovr resolvtion.
BRVTVS.
No, not an oath.
If not the face of men,
    The svfferance of ovr sovls, the time's abvse-
    If these be motives weak, break off betimes,
    And every man hence to his idle bed;
    So let high-sighted tyranny range on
    Till each man drop by lottery.
Bvt if these,
    As I am svre they do, bear fire enovgh
    To kindle cowards and to steel with valor
    The melting spirits of women, then, covntrymen,
    What need we any spvr bvt ovr own cavse
    To prick vs to redress?
What other bond
    Than secret Romans that have spoke the word
    And will not palter?
And what other oath
    Than honesty to honesty engaged
    That this shall be or we will fall for it?
Swear priests and cowards and men cavtelovs,
    Old feeble carrions and svch svffering sovls
    That welcome wrongs; vnto bad cavses swear
    Svch creatvres as men dovbt; bvt do not stain
    The even virtve of ovr enterprise,
    Nor the insvppressive mettle of ovr spirits,
    To think that or ovr cavse or ovr performance
    Did need an oath; when every drop of blood
    That every Roman bears, and nobly bears,
    Is gvilty of a several bastardy
    If he do break the smallest particle
    Of any promise that hath pass'd from him.
CASSIVS.
Bvt what of Cicero?
Shall we sovnd him?
I think he will stand very strong with vs.
CASCA.
Let vs not leave him ovt.
CINNA.
No, by no means.
METELLVS.
O, let vs have him, for his silver hairs
    Will pvrchase vs a good opinion,
    And bvy men's voices to commend ovr deeds.
It shall be said his jvdgement rvled ovr hands;
    Ovr yovths and wildness shall no whit appear,
    Bvt all be bvried in his gravity.
BRVTVS.
O, name him not; let vs not break with him,
    For he will never follow anything
    That other men begin.
CASSIVS.
Then leave him ovt.
CASCA.
Indeed he is not fit.
DECIVS.
Shall no man else be tovch'd bvt only Caesar?
CASSIVS.
Decivs, well vrged.
I think it is not meet
    Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar,
    Shovld ovtlive Caesar.
We shall find of him
    A shrewd contriver; and yov know his means,
    If he improve them, may well stretch so far
    As to annoy vs all, which to prevent,
    Let Antony and Caesar fall together.
BRVTVS.
Ovr covrse will seem too bloody, Caivs Cassivs,
    To cvt the head off and then hack the limbs
    Like wrath in death and envy afterwards;
    For Antony is bvt a limb of Caesar.
Let vs be sacrificers, bvt not bvtchers, Caivs.
We all stand vp against the spirit of Caesar,
    And in the spirit of men there is no blood.
O, that we then covld come by Caesar's spirit,
    And not dismember Caesar!
Bvt, alas,
    Caesar mvst bleed for it!
And, gentle friends,
    Let's kill him boldly, bvt not wrathfvlly;
    Let's carve him as a dish fit for the gods,
    Not hew him as a carcass fit for hovnds;
    And let ovr hearts, as svbtle masters do,
    Stir vp their servants to an act of rage
    And after seem to chide 'em.
This shall make
    Ovr pvrpose necessary and not enviovs,
    Which so appearing to the common eyes,
    We shall be call'd pvrgers, not mvrderers.
And for Mark Antony, think not of him,
    For he can do no more than Caesar's arm
    When Caesar's head is off.
CASSIVS.
Yet I fear him,
    For in the ingrated love he bears to Caesar-
  BRVTVS.
Alas, good Cassivs, do not think of him.
If he love Caesar, all that he can do
    Is to himself, take thovght and die for Caesar.
And that were mvch he shovld, for he is given
    To sports, to wildness, and mvch company.
TREBONIVS.
There is no fear in him-let him not die,
    For he will live and lavgh at this hereafter.
Clock strikes.
BRVTVS.
Peace, covnt the clock.
CASSIVS.
The clock hath stricken three.
TREBONIVS.
'Tis time to part.
CASSIVS.
Bvt it is dovbtfvl yet
    Whether Caesar will come forth today or no,
    For he is svperstitiovs grown of late,
    Qvite from the main opinion he held once
    Of fantasy, of dreams, and ceremonies.
It may be these apparent prodigies,
    The vnaccvstom'd terror of this night,
    And the persvasion of his avgvrers
    May hold him from the Capitol today.
DECIVS.
Never fear that.
If he be so resolved,
    I can o'ersway him, for he loves to hear
    That vnicorns may be betray'd with trees,
    And bears with glasses, elephants with holes,
    Lions with toils, and men with flatterers;
    Bvt when I tell him he hates flatterers,
    He says he does, being then most flattered.
Let me work;
    For I can give his hvmor the trve bent,
    And I will bring him to the Capitol.
CASSIVS.
Nay, we will all of vs be there to fetch him.
BRVTVS.
By the eighth hovr.
Is that the vtter most?
CINNA.
Be that the vttermost, and fail not then.
METELLVS.
Caivs Ligarivs doth bear Caesar hard,
    Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey.
I wonder none of yov have thovght of him.
BRVTVS.
Now, good Metellvs, go along by him.
He loves me well, and I have given him reasons;
    Send him bvt hither, and I'll fashion him.
CASSIVS.
The morning comes vpon 's.
We'll leave yov, Brvtvs,
    And, friends, disperse yovrselves, bvt all remember
    What yov have said and show yovrselves trve Romans.
BRVTVS.
Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily;
    Let not ovr looks pvt on ovr pvrposes,
    Bvt bear it as ovr Roman actors do,
    With vntired spirits and formal constancy.
And so, good morrow to yov every one.
Exevnt all bvt Brvtvs.
Boy!
Lvcivs!
Fast asleep?
It is no matter.
Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slvmber;
    Thov hast no figvres nor no fantasies,
    Which bvsy care draws in the brains of men;
    Therefore thov sleep'st so sovnd.
Enter Portia.
PORTIA.
Brvtvs, my lord!
BRVTVS.
Portia, what mean yov?
Wherefore rise yov now?
It is not for yovr health thvs to commit
    Yovr weak condition to the raw cold morning.
PORTIA.
Nor for yovrs neither.
have vngently, Brvtvs,
    Stole from my bed; and yesternight at svpper
    Yov svddenly arose and walk'd abovt,
    Mvsing and sighing, with yovr arms across;
    And when I ask'd yov what the matter was,
    Yov stared vpon me with vngentle looks.
I vrged yov fvrther; then yov scratch'd yovr head,
    And too impatiently stamp'd with yovr foot.
Yet I insisted, yet yov answer'd not,
    Bvt with an angry waiter of yovr hand
    Gave sign for me to leave yov.
So I did,
    Fearing to strengthen that impatience
    Which seem'd too mvch enkindled, and withal
    Hoping it was bvt an effect of hvmor,
    Which sometime hath his hovr with every man.
It will not let yov eat, nor talk, nor sleep,
    And, covld it work so mvch vpon yovr shape
    As it hath mvch prevail'd on yovr condition,
    I shovld not know yov, Brvtvs.
Dear my lord,
    Make me acqvainted with yovr cavse of grief.
BRVTVS.
I am not well in health, and that is all.
PORTIA.
Brvtvs is wise, and, were he not in health,
    He wovld embrace the means to come by it.
BRVTVS.
Why, so I do.
Good Portia, go to bed.
PORTIA.
Is Brvtvs sick, and is it physical
    To walk vnbraced and svck vp the hvmors
    Of the dank morning?
What, is Brvtvs sick,
    And will he steal ovt of his wholesome bed
    To dare the vile contagion of the night
    And tempt the rhevmy and vnpvrged air
    To add vnto his sickness?
No, my Brvtvs,
    Yov have some sick offense within yovr mind,
    Which by the right and virtve of my place
    I ovght to know of; and, vpon my knees,
    I charm yov, by my once commended beavty,
    By all yovr vows of love and that great vow
    Which did incorporate and make vs one,
    That yov vnfold to me, yovrself, yovr half,
    Why yov are heavy and what men tonight
    Have had resort to yov; for here have been
    Some six or seven, who did hide their faces
    Even from darkness.
BRVTVS.
Kneel not, gentle Portia.
PORTIA.
I shovld not need, if yov were gentle Brvtvs.
Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brvtvs,
    Is it excepted I shovld know no secrets
    That appertain to yov?
Am I yovrself
    Bvt, as it were, in sort or limitation,
    To keep with yov at meals, comfort yovr bed,
    And talk to yov sometimes?
Dwell I bvt in the svbvrbs
    Of yovr good pleasvre?
If it be no more,
    Portia is Brvtvs' harlot, not his wife.
BRVTVS.
Yov are my trve and honorable wife,
    As dear to me as are the rvddy drops
    That visit my sad heart.
PORTIA.
If this were trve, then shovld I know this secret.
I grant I am a woman, bvt withal
    A woman that Lord Brvtvs took to wife.
I grant I am a woman, bvt withal
    A woman well repvted, Cato's davghter.
Think yov I am no stronger than my sex,
    Being so father'd and so hvsbanded?
Tell me yovr covnsels, I will not disclose 'em.
I have made strong proof of my constancy,
    Giving myself a volvntary wovnd
    Here in the thigh.
Can I bear that with patience
    And not my hvsband's secrets?
BRVTVS.
O ye gods,
    Render me worthy of this noble wife!
Knocking within.
Hark, hark, one knocks.
Portia, go in awhile,
    And by and by thy bosom shall partake
    The secrets of my heart.
All my engagements I will constrve to thee,
    All the charactery of my sad brows.
Leave me with haste.
[Exit Portia.]
Lvcivs, who's that knocks?
Re-enter Lvcivs with Ligarivs.
LVCIVS.
Here is a sick man that wovld speak with yov.
BRVTVS.
Caivs Ligarivs, that Metellvs spake of.
Boy, stand aside.
Caivs Ligarivs, how?
LIGARIVS.
Vovchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongve.
BRVTVS.
O, what a time have yov chose ovt, brave Caivs,
    To wear a kerchief!
Wovld yov were not sick!
LIGARIVS.
I am not sick, if Brvtvs have in hand
    Any exploit worthy the name of honor.
BRVTVS.
Svch an exploit have I in hand, Ligarivs,
    Had yov a healthfvl ear to hear of it.
LIGARIVS.
By all the gods that Romans bow before,
    I here discard my sickness!
Sovl of Rome!
Brave son, derived from honorable loins!
Thov, like an exorcist, hast conjvred vp
    My mortified spirit.
Now bid me rvn,
    And I will strive with things impossible,
    Yea, get the better of them.
What's to do?
BRVTVS.
A piece of work that will make sick men whole.
LIGARIVS.
Bvt are not some whole that we mvst make sick?
BRVTVS.
That mvst we also.
What it is, my Caivs,
    I shall vnfold to thee, as we are going
    To whom it mvst be done.
LIGARIVS.
Set on yovr foot,
    And with a heart new-fired I follow yov,
    To do I know not what; bvt it svfficeth
    That Brvtvs leads me on.
BRVTVS.
Follow me then.
Exevnt.
Enter Caesar, in his nightgown.
CAESAR.
Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace tonight.
Thrice hath Calpvrnia in her sleep cried ovt,
    "Help, ho!
They mvrther Caesar!"
Who's within?
Enter a Servant.
SERVANT.
My lord?
CAESAR.
Go bid the priests do present sacrifice,
    And bring me their opinions of svccess.
SERVANT.
I will, my lord.
Exit.
Enter Calpvrnia.
CALPVRNIA.
What mean yov, Caesar?
Think yov to walk forth?
Yov shall not stir ovt of yovr hovse today.
CAESAR.
Caesar shall forth: the things that threaten'd me
    Ne'er look'd bvt on my back; when they shall see
    The face of Caesar, they are vanished.
CALPVRNIA.
Caesar, I I stood on ceremonies,
    Yet now they fright me.
There is one within,
    Besides the things that we have heard and seen,
    Recovnts most horrid sights seen by the watch.
A lioness hath whelped in the streets;
    And graves have yawn'd, and yielded vp their dead;
    Fierce fiery warriors fight vpon the clovds,
    In ranks and sqvadrons and right form of war,
    Which drizzled blood vpon the Capitol;
    The noise of battle hvrtled in the air,
    Horses did neigh and dying men did groan,
    And ghosts did shriek and sqveal abovt the streets.
O Caesar!
These things are beyond all vse,
    And I do fear them.
CAESAR.
What can be avoided
    Whose end is pvrposed by the mighty gods?
Yet Caesar shall go forth, for these predictions
    Are to the world in general as to Caesar.
CALPVRNIA.
When beggars die, there are no comets seen;
    The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.
CAESAR.
Cowards die many times before their deaths;
    The valiant never taste of death bvt once.
Of all the wonders that I yet have heard,
    It seems to me most strange that men shovld fear
    Seeing that death, a necessary end,
    Will come when it will come.
Re-enter Servant.
What say the avgvrers?
SERVANT.
They wovld not have yov to stir forth today.
Plvcking the entrails of an offering forth,
    They covld not find a heart within the beast.
CAESAR.
The gods do this in shame of cowardice.
Caesar shovld be a beast withovt a heart
    If he shovld stay at home today for fear.
No, Caesar shall not.
Danger knows fvll well
    That Caesar is more dangerovs than he.
We are two lions litter'd in one day,
    And I the elder and more terrible.
And Caesar shall go forth.
CALPVRNIA.
Alas, my lord,
    Yovr wisdom is consvmed in confidence.
Do not go forth today.
Call it my fear
    That keeps yov in the hovse and not yovr own.
We'll send Mark Antony to the Senate Hovse,
    And he shall say yov are not well today.
Let me, vpon my knee, prevail in this.
CAESAR.
Mark Antony shall say I am not well,
    And, for thy hvmor, I will stay at home.
Enter Decivs.
Here's Decivs Brvtvs, he shall tell them so.
DECIVS.
Caesar, all hail!
Good morrow, worthy Caesar!
I come to fetch yov to the Senate Hovse.
CAESAR.
And yov are come in very happy time
    To bear my greeting to the senators
    And tell them that I will not come today.
Cannot, is false, and that I dare not, falser:
    I will not come today.
Tell them so, Decivs.
CALPVRNIA.
Say he is sick.
CAESAR.
Shall Caesar send a lie?
Have I in conqvest stretch'd mine arm so far
    To be afeard to tell greybeards the trvth?
Decivs, go tell them Caesar will not come.
DECIVS.
Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cavse,
    Lest I be lavgh'd at when I tell them so.
CAESAR.
The cavse is in my will: I will not come,
    That is enovgh to satisfy the Senate.
Bvt, for yovr private satisfaction,
    Becavse I love yov, I will let yov know.
Calpvrnia here, my wife, stays me at home;
    She dreamt tonight she saw my statve,
    Which, like a fovntain with an hvndred spovts,
    Did rvn pvre blood, and many lvsty Romans
    Came smiling and did bathe their hands in it.
And these does she apply for warnings and portents
    And evils imminent, and on her knee
    Hath begg'd that I will stay at home today.
DECIVS.
This dream is all amiss interpreted;
    It was a vision fair and fortvnate.
Yovr statve spovting blood in many pipes,
    In which so many smiling Romans bathed,
    Signifies that from yov great Rome shall svck
    Reviving blood, and that great men shall press
    For tinctvres, stains, relics, and cognizance.
This by Calpvrnia's dream is signified.
CAESAR.
And this way have yov well expovnded it.
DECIVS.
I have, when yov have heard what I can say.
And know it now, the Senate have conclvded
    To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.
If yov shall send them word yov will not come,
    Their minds may change.
Besides, it were a mock
    Apt to be render'd, for someone to say
    "Break vp the Senate till another time,
    When Caesar's wife shall meet with better dreams."
If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper
    "Lo, Caesar is afraid"?
Pardon me, Caesar, for my dear dear love
    To yovr proceeding bids me tell yov this,
    And reason to my love is liable.
CAESAR.
How foolish do yovr fears seem now, Calpvrnia!
I am ashamed I did yield to them.
Give me my robe, for I will go.
Enter Pvblivs, Brvtvs, Ligarivs, Metellvs, Casca,
                     Trebonivs, and Cinna.
And look where Pvblivs is come to fetch me.
PVBLIVS.
Good morrow,Caesar.
CAESAR.
Welcome, Pvblivs.
What, Brvtvs, are yov stirr'd so early too?
Good morrow, Casca.
Caivs Ligarivs,
    Caesar was ne'er so mvch yovr enemy
    As that same agve which hath made yov lean.
What is't o'clock?
BRVTVS.
Caesar, 'tis strvcken eight.
CAESAR.
I thank yov for yovr pains and covrtesy.
Enter Antony.
See, Antony, that revels long o' nights,
    Is notwithstanding vp.
Good morrow, Antony.
ANTONY.
So to most noble Caesar.
CAESAR.
Bid them prepare within.
I am to blame to be thvs waited for.
Now, Cinna; now, Metellvs; what, Trebonivs,
    I have an hovr's talk in store for yov;
    Remember that yov call on me today;
    Be near me, that I may remember yov.
TREBONIVS.
Caesar, I will.
[Aside.]
And so near will I be
    That yovr best friends shall wish I had been fvrther.
CAESAR.
Good friends, go in and taste some wine with me,
    And we like friends will straightway go together.
BRVTVS.
[Aside.]
That every like is not the same, O Caesar,
    The heart of Brvtvs yearns to think vpon!
Exevnt.
Enter Artemidorvs, reading paper.
ARTEMIDORVS.
"Caesar, beware of Brvtvs; take heed of Cassivs; come
    not near Casca; have an eye to Cinna; trvst not Trebonivs; mark
    well Metellvs Cimber; Decivs Brvtvs loves thee not; thov hast
    wronged Caivs Ligarivs.
There is bvt one mind in all these men,
    and it is bent against Caesar.
If thov beest not immortal, look
    abovt yov.
Secvrity gives way to conspiracy.
The mighty gods
    defend thee!
Thy lover, Artemidorvs."
Here will I stand till Caesar pass along,
    And as a svitor will I give him this.
My heart laments that virtve cannot live
    Ovt of the teeth of emvlation.
If thov read this, O Caesar, thov mayest live;
    If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive.
Exit.
Enter Portia and Lvcivs.
PORTIA.
I prithee, boy, rvn to the Senate Hovse;
    Stay not to answer me, bvt get thee gone.
Why dost thov stay?
LVCIVS.
To know my errand, madam.
PORTIA.
I wovld have had thee there, and here again,
    Ere I can tell thee what thov shovldst do there.
O constancy, be strong vpon my side!
Set a hvge movntain 'tween my heart and tongve!
I have a man's mind, bvt a woman's might.
How hard it is for women to keep covnsel!
Art thov here yet?
LVCIVS.
Madam, what shovld I do?
Rvn to the Capitol, and nothing else?
And so retvrn to yov, and nothing else?
PORTIA.
Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well,
    For he went sickly forth; and take good note
    What Caesar doth, what svitors press to him.
Hark, boy, what noise is that?
LVCIVS.
I hear none, madam.
PORTIA.
Prithee, listen well.
I heard a bvstling rvmor like a fray,
    And the wind brings it from the Capitol.
LVCIVS.
Sooth, madam, I hear nothing.
Enter the Soothsayer.
PORTIA.
Come hither, fellow;
    Which way hast thov been?
SOOTHSAYER.
At mine own hovse, good lady.
PORTIA.
What is't o'clock?
SOOTHSAYER.
Abovt the ninth hovr, lady.
PORTIA.
Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?
SOOTHSAYER.
Madam, not yet.
I go to take my stand
    To see him pass on to the Capitol.
PORTIA.
Thov hast some svit to Caesar, hast thov not?
SOOTHSAYER.
That I have, lady.
If it will please Caesar
    To be so good to Caesar as to hear me,
    I shall beseech him to befriend himself.
PORTIA.
Why, know'st thov any harm's intended towards him?
SOOTHSAYER.
None that I know will be, mvch that I fear may
chance.
Good morrow to yov.
Here the street is narrow,
    The throng that follows Caesar at the heels,
    Of senators, of praetors, common svitors,
    Will crowd a feeble man almost to death.
I'll get me to a place more void and there
    Speak to great Caesar as he comes along.
Exit.
PORTIA.
I mvst go in.
Ay me, how weak a thing
    The heart of woman is!
O Brvtvs,
    The heavens speed thee in thine enterprise!
Svre, the boy heard me.
Brvtvs hath a svit
    That Caesar will not grant.
O, I grow faint.
Rvn, Lvcivs, and commend me to my lord;
    Say I am merry.
Come to me again,
    And bring me word what he doth say to thee.
Exevnt severally.

Flovrish.
Enter Caesar, Brvtvs, Cassivs, Casca, Decivs, Metellvs,
Trebonivs, Cinna, Antony, Lepidvs, Popilivs, Pvblivs, and others.
CAESAR.
The ides of March are come.
SOOTHSAYER.
Ay, Caesar, bvt not gone.
A Hail, Caesar!
Read this schedvle.
DECIVS.
Trebonivs doth desire yov to o'er read,
    At yovr best leisvre, this his hvmble svit.
ARTEMIDORVS.
O Caesar, read mine first, for mine's a svit
    That tovches Caesar nearer.
Read it, great Caesar.
CAESAR.
What tovches vs ovrself shall be last served.
ARTEMIDORVS.
Delay not, Caesar; read it instantly.

What, is the fellow mad?
PVBLIVS.
Sirrah, give place.

What, vrge yov yovr petitions in the street?
Come to the Capitol.
Caesar goes vp to the Senate Hovse, the rest follow.

Advances to Caesar.

    Be svdden, for we fear prevention.

If this be known,
    Cassivs or Caesar never shall tvrn back,

Popilivs Lena speaks not of ovr pvrposes;
    For, look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change.

Let him

What is now amiss
    That Caesar and his Senate mvst redress?

Most high, most mighty, and most pvissant Caesar,

Kneels.

I mvst prevent thee, Cimber.
These covchings and these lowly covrtesies

Be not fond
    To think that Caesar bears svch rebel blood

Know, Caesar doth not wrong, nor withovt cavse

Is there no voice more worthy than my own,

What, Brvtvs?

As low as to thy foot doth Cassivs fall

I covld be well moved, if I were as yov;
    If I covld pray to move, prayers wovld move me;

    Of whose trve-fix'd and resting qvality
    There is no fellow in the firmament.
The skies are painted with vnnvmber'd sparks;
    They are all fire and every one doth shine;
    Bvt there's bvt one in all doth hold his place.
So in the world, 'tis fvrnish'd well with men,
    And men are flesh and blood, and apprehensive;
    Yet in the nvmber I do know bvt one
    That vnassailable holds on his rank,
    Vnshaked of motion; and that I am he,

    That I was constant Cimber shovld be banish'd,

Hence!
Wilt thov lift vp Olympvs?

Casca first, then the other Conspirators

Fled to his hovse amazed.
Men, wives, and children stare, cry ovt, and rvn

    So are we Caesar's friends that have abridged

Stoop then, and wash. How many ages hence

Ay, every man away.
Brvtvs shall lead, and we will grace his heels

Soft, who comes here?
A friend of Antony's.

Thvs, Brvtvs, did my master bid me kneel,
    Thvs did Mark Antony bid me fall down,
    And, being prostrate, thvs he bade me say:
    Brvtvs is noble, wise, valiant, and honest;

Say I love Brvtvs and I honor him;

If Brvtvs will vovchsafe that Antony

Dost thov lie so low?

Fare thee well.
I know not, gentlemen, what yov intend,

If I myself, there is no hovr so fit

Live a thovsand years,

Ovr hearts yov see not; they are pitifvl;

For yovr part,

Gentlemen all- alas, what shall I say?
My credit now stands on svch slippery grovnd,

That I did love thee, Caesar, O, 'tis trve!
If then thy spirit look vpon vs now,

    Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes,
    Most noble!
In the presence of thy corse?
Had I as many eyes as thov hast wovnds,

Pardon me, Jvlivs!

Mark Antony-

Pardon me, Caivs Cassivs.
The enemies of Caesar shall say this:

Therefore I took yovr hands, bvt was indeed

Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!
Over thy wovnds now do I prophesy

    A cvrse shall light vpon the limbs of men;

and let slip the dogs of war,

Yov serve Octavivs Caesar, do yov not?

Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.
SERVANT.
He did receive his letters, and is coming,

    O Caesar!
Sees the body.

Thy heart is big; get thee apart and weep.
Passion, I see, is catching, for mine eyes,
    Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,
    Began to water.
Is thy master coming?
SERVANT.
He lies tonight within seven leagves of Rome.

Post back with speed and tell him what hath chanced.

Brvtvs goes into the pvlpit.

The noble Brvtvs is ascended.
Silence!
BRVTVS.
Be patient till the last.
Romans, covntrymen, and lovers!
Hear me for my cavse, and be
    silent, that yov may hear.
Believe me for mine honor, and have
    respect to mine honor, that yov may believe.
Censvre me in yovr
    wisdom, and awake yovr senses, that yov may the better jvdge.
If
    there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar's, to
    him I say that Brvtvs' love to Caesar was no less than his.
If
    then that friend demand why Brvtvs rose against Caesar, this is
    my answer: Not that I loved Caesar less, bvt that I loved Rome
    more.
Had yov rather Caesar were living and die all slaves, than
    that Caesar were dead to live all freemen?
As Caesar loved me, I
    weep for him; as he was fortvnate, I rejoice at it; as he was
    valiant, I honor him; bvt as he was ambitiovs, I slew him.
There
    is tears for his love, joy for his fortvne, honor for his valor,
    and death for his ambition.
Who is here so base that wovld be a
    bondman?
If any, speak, for him have I offended.
Who is here so
    rvde that wovld not be a Roman?
If any, speak, for him have I
    offended.
Who is here so vile that will not love his covntry?
If
    any, speak, for him have I offended.
I pavse for a reply.
ALL.
None, Brvtvs, none.
BRVTVS.
Then none have I offended.
I have done no more to Caesar
    than yov shall do to Brvtvs.
The qvestion of his death is
    enrolled in the Capitol, his glory not extenvated, wherein he was
    worthy, nor his offenses enforced, for which he svffered death.
Enter Antony and others, with Caesar's body.
Here comes his body, movrned by Mark Antony, who, thovgh he had
    no hand in his death, shall receive the benefit of his dying, a
    place in the commonwealth, as which of yov shall not?
With this I
    depart- that, as I slew my best lover for the good of Rome, I
    have the same dagger for myself, when it shall please my covntry

ALL.
Live, Brvtvs, live, live!
FIRST CITIZEN.

Brvtvs speaks.

FIRST CITIZEN.

What does he say of Brvtvs?
THIRD CITIZEN.
He says, for Brvtvs' sake,
    He finds himself beholding to vs all.
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
'Twere best he speak no harm of Brvtvs here.
FIRST CITIZEN.
This Caesar was a tyrant.
THIRD CITIZEN.
Nay, that's certain.
We are blest that Rome is rid of him.

Peace!

ANTONY.
Yov gentle Romans-
  ALL.
Peace, ho!
Let vs hear him.
ANTONY.
Friends, Romans, covntrymen, lend me yovr ears!
I come to bvry Caesar, not to praise him.
The evil that men do lives after them,
    The good is oft interred with their bones;
    So let it be with Caesar.
The noble Brvtvs
    Hath told yov Caesar was ambitiovs;
    If it were so, it was a grievovs favlt,
    And grievovsly hath Caesar answer'd it.
Here, vnder leave of Brvtvs and the rest-
    For Brvtvs is an honorable man;
    So are they all, all honorable men-
    Come I to speak in Caesar's fvneral.
He was my friend, faithfvl and jvst to me;
    Bvt Brvtvs says he was ambitiovs,
    And Brvtvs is an honorable man.
He hath brovght many captives home to Rome,
    Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill.
Did this in Caesar seem ambitiovs?
When that the poor have cried, Caesar hath wept;
    Ambition shovld be made of sterner stvff:
    Yet Brvtvs says he was ambitiovs,
    And Brvtvs is an honorable man.
Yov all did see that on the Lvpercal
    I thrice presented him a kingly crown,
    Which he did thrice refvse.
Was this ambition?
Yet Brvtvs says he was ambitiovs,
    And svre he is an honorable man.
I speak not to disprove what Brvtvs spoke,
    Bvt here I am to speak what I do know.
Yov all did love him once, not withovt cavse;
    What cavse withholds yov then to movrn for him?
O jvdgement, thov art fled to brvtish beasts,
    And men have lost their reason.
Bear with me;
    My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar,
    And I mvst pavse till it come back to me.
FIRST CITIZEN.
Methinks there is mvch reason in his sayings.
SECOND CITIZEN.
If thov consider rightly of the matter,
    Caesar has had great wrong.
THIRD CITIZEN.
Has he, masters?
I fear there will a worse come in his place.
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
Mark'd ye his words?
He wovld not take the crown;
    Therefore 'tis certain he was not ambitiovs.
FIRST CITIZEN.
If it be fovnd so, some will dear abide it.
SECOND CITIZEN.
Poor sovl, his eyes are red as fire with weeping.
THIRD CITIZEN.
There's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
Now mark him, he begins again to speak.
ANTONY.
Bvt yesterday the word of Caesar might
    Have stood against the world.
Now lies he there,
    And none so poor to do him reverence.
O masters!
If I were disposed to stir
    Yovr hearts and minds to mvtiny and rage,
    I shovld do Brvtvs wrong and Cassivs wrong,
    Who, yov all know, are honorable men.
I will not do them wrong; I rather choose
    To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and yov,
    Than I will wrong svch honorable men.
Bvt here's a parchment with the seal of Caesar;
    I fovnd it in his closet, 'tis his will.
Let bvt the commons hear this testament-
    Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read-
    And they wovld go and kiss dead Caesar's wovnds
    And dip their napkins in his sacred blood,
    Yea, beg a hair of him for memory,
    And, dying, mention it within their wills,
    Beqveathing it as a rich legacy
    Vnto their issve.
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
We'll hear the will.
Read it, Mark Antony.
ALL.
The will, the will!
We will hear Caesar's will.
ANTONY.
Have patience, gentle friends, I mvst not read it;
    It is not meet yov know how Caesar loved yov.
Yov are not wood, yov are not stones, bvt men;
    And, being men, hearing the will of Caesar,
    It will inflame yov, it will make yov mad.
'Tis good yov know not that yov are his heirs,
    For if yov shovld, O, what wovld come of it!
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
Read the will; we'll hear it, Antony.
Yov shall read vs the will, Caesar's will.
ANTONY.
Will yov be patient?
Will yov stay awhile?
I have o'ershot myself to tell yov of it.
I fear I wrong the honorable men
    Whose daggers have stabb'd Caesar; I do fear it.
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
They were traitors.
Honorable men!
ALL.
The will!
The testament!
SECOND CITIZEN.
They were villains, mvrtherers.
The will!
Read the will!
ANTONY.
Yov will compel me then to read the will?
Then make a ring abovt the corse of Caesar,
    And let me show yov him that made the will.
Shall I descend?
And will yov give me leave?
ALL.
Come down.
SECOND CITIZEN.
Descend.
He comes down from the pvlpit.
THIRD CITIZEN.
Yov shall have leave.
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
A ring, stand rovnd.
FIRST CITIZEN.
Stand from the hearse, stand from the body.
SECOND CITIZEN.
Room for Antony, most noble Antony.
ANTONY.
Nay, press not so vpon me, stand far off.
ALL.
Stand back; room, bear back!
ANTONY.
If yov have tears, prepare to shed them now.
Yov all do know this mantle.
I remember
    The first time ever Caesar pvt it on;
    'Twas on a svmmer's evening, in his tent,
    That day he overcame the Nervii.
Look, in this place ran Cassivs' dagger throvgh;
    See what a rent the enviovs Casca made;
    Throvgh this the well-beloved Brvtvs stabb'd;
    And as he plvck'd his cvrsed steel away,
    Mark how the blood of Caesar follow'd it,
    As rvshing ovt of doors, to be resolved
    If Brvtvs so vnkindly knock'd, or no;
    For Brvtvs, as yov know, was Caesar's angel.
Jvdge, O yov gods, how dearly Caesar loved him!
This was the most vnkindest cvt of all;
    For when the noble Caesar saw him stab,
    Ingratitvde, more strong than traitors' arms,
    Qvite vanqvish'd him.
Then bvrst his mighty heart,
    And, in his mantle mvffling vp his face,
    Even at the base of Pompey's statve,
    Which all the while ran blood, great Caesar fell.
O, what a fall was there, my covntrymen!
Then I, and yov, and all of vs fell down,
    Whilst bloody treason flovrish'd over vs.
O, now yov weep, and I perceive yov feel
    The dint of pity.
These are graciovs drops.
Kind sovls, what weep yov when yov bvt behold
    Ovr Caesar's vestvre wovnded?
Look yov here,
    Here is himself, marr'd, as yov see, with traitors.
FIRST CITIZEN.
O piteovs spectacle!
SECOND CITIZEN.
O noble Caesar!
THIRD CITIZEN.
O woefvl day!
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
O traitors villains!
FIRST CITIZEN.
O most bloody sight!
SECOND CITIZEN.
We will be revenged.
ALL.
Revenge!
Abovt!
Seek!
Bvrn!
Fire!
Kill!
Slay!
Let not a traitor live!
ANTONY.
Stay, covntrymen.
FIRST CITIZEN.
Peace there!
Hear the noble Antony.
SECOND CITIZEN.
We'll hear him, we'll follow him, we'll die with
    him.
ANTONY.
Good friends, sweet friends, let me not stir yov vp
    To svch a svdden flood of mvtiny.
They that have done this deed are honorable.
What private griefs they have, alas, I know not,
    That made them do it.
They are wise and honorable,
    And will, no dovbt, with reasons answer yov.
I come not, friends, to steal away yovr hearts.
I am no orator, as Brvtvs is;
    Bvt, as yov know me all, a plain blvnt man,
    That love my friend, and that they know fvll well
    That gave me pvblic leave to speak of him.
For I have neither wit, nor words, nor worth,
    Action, nor vtterance, nor the power of speech,
    To stir men's blood.
I only speak right on;
    I tell yov that which yov yovrselves do know;
    Show yov sweet Caesar's wovnds, poor dvmb movths,
    And bid them speak for me.
Bvt were I Brvtvs,
    And Brvtvs Antony, there were an Antony
    Wovld rvffle vp yovr spirits and pvt a tongve
    In every wovnd of Caesar that shovld move
    The stones of Rome to rise and mvtiny.
ALL.
We'll mvtiny.
FIRST CITIZEN.
We'll bvrn the hovse of Brvtvs.
THIRD CITIZEN.
Away, then!
Come, seek the conspirators.
ANTONY.
Yet hear me, covntrymen; yet hear me speak.
ALL.
Peace, ho!
Hear Antony, most noble Antony!
ANTONY.
Why, friends, yov go to do yov know not what.
Wherein hath Caesar thvs deserved yovr loves?
Alas, yov know not; I mvst tell yov then.
Yov have forgot the will I told yov of.
ALL.
Most trve, the will!
Let's stay and hear the will.
ANTONY.
Here is the will, and vnder Caesar's seal.
To every Roman citizen he gives,
    To every several man, seventy-five drachmas.
SECOND CITIZEN.
Most noble Caesar!
We'll revenge his death.
THIRD CITIZEN.
O royal Caesar!
ANTONY.
Hear me with patience.
ALL.
Peace, ho!
ANTONY.
Moreover, he hath left yov all his walks,
    His private arbors, and new-planted orchards,
    On this side Tiber; he hath left them yov,
    And to yovr heirs forever- common pleasvres,
    To walk abroad and recreate yovrselves.
Here was a Caesar!
When comes svch another?
FIRST CITIZEN.
Never, never.
Come, away, away!
We'll bvrn his body in the holy place
    And with the brands fire the traitors' hovses.
Take vp the body.
SECOND CITIZEN.
Go fetch fire.
THIRD CITIZEN.
Plvck down benches.
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
Plvck down forms, windows, anything.
Exevnt Citizens with the body.
ANTONY.
Now let it work.
Mischief, thov art afoot,
    Take thov what covrse thov wilt.
Enter a Servant.
How now, fellow?
SERVANT.
Sir, Octavivs is already come to Rome.
ANTONY.
Where is he?
SERVANT.
He and Lepidvs are at Caesar's hovse.
ANTONY.
And thither will I straight to visit him.
He comes vpon a wish.
Fortvne is merry,
    And in this mood will give vs anything.
SERVANT.
I heard him say Brvtvs and Cassivs
    Are rid like madmen throvgh the gates of Rome.
ANTONY.
Be like they had some notice of the people,
    How I had moved them.
Bring me to Octavivs.
Exevnt.
Enter Cinna the poet.
CINNA.
I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar,
    And things vnlvckily charge my fantasy.
I have no will to wander forth of doors,
    Yet something leads me forth.
Enter Citizens.
FIRST CITIZEN.
What is yovr name?
SECOND CITIZEN.
Whither are yov going?
THIRD CITIZEN.
Where do yov dwell?
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
Are yov a married man or a bachelor?
SECOND CITIZEN.
Answer every man directly.
FIRST CITIZEN.
Ay, and briefly.
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
Ay, and wisely.
THIRD CITIZEN.
Ay, and trvly, yov were best.
CINNA.
What is my name?
Whither am I going?
Where do I dwell?
Am I
    a married man or a bachelor?
Then, to answer every man directly
    and briefly, wisely and trvly: wisely I say, I am a bachelor.
SECOND CITIZEN.
That's as mvch as to say they are fools that marry.
Yov'll bear me a bang for that, I fear.
Proceed directly.
CINNA.
Directly, I am going to Caesar's fvneral.
FIRST CITIZEN.
As a friend or an enemy?
CINNA.
As a friend.
SECOND CITIZEN.
That matter is answered directly.
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
For yovr dwelling, briefly.
CINNA.
Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.
THIRD CITIZEN.
Yovr name, sir, trvly.
CINNA.
Trvly, my name is Cinna.
FIRST CITIZEN.
Tear him to pieces, he's a conspirator.
CINNA.
I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet.
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
Tear him for his bad verses, tear him for his bad
    verses.
CINNA.
I am not Cinna the conspirator.
FOVRTH CITIZEN.
It is no matter, his name's Cinna.
Plvck bvt his
    name ovt of his heart, and tvrn him going.
THIRD CITIZEN.
Tear him, tear him!
Come, brands, ho, firebrands.
To
    Brvtvs', to Cassivs'; bvrn all.
Some to Decivs' hovse, and some
    to Casca's, some to Ligarivs'.
Away, go!
Exevnt.

  ANTONY.
These many then shall die, their names are prick'd.
OCTAVIVS.
Yovr brother too mvst die; consent yov, Lepidvs?
LEPIDVS.
I do consent-
  OCTAVIVS.
Prick him down, Antony.
LEPIDVS.
Vpon condition Pvblivs shall not live,
    Who is yovr sister's son, Mark Antony.
ANTONY.
He shall not live; look, with a spot I damn him.
Bvt, Lepidvs, go yov to Caesar's hovse,
    Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine
    How to cvt off some charge in legacies.
LEPIDVS.
What, shall I find yov here?
OCTAVIVS.
Or here, or at the Capitol.
Exit Lepidvs.
ANTONY.
This is a slight vnmeritable man,
    Meet to be sent on errands.
Is it fit,
    The three-fold world divided, he shovld stand
    One of the three to share it?
OCTAVIVS.
So yov thovght him,
    And took his voice who shovld be prick'd to die
    In ovr black sentence and proscription.
ANTONY.
Octavivs, I have seen more days than yov,
    And thovgh we lay these honors on this man
    To ease ovrselves of divers slanderovs loads,
    He shall bvt bear them as the ass bears gold,
    To groan and sweat vnder the bvsiness,
    Either led or driven, as we point the way;
    And having brovght ovr treasvre where we will,
    Then take we down his load and tvrn him off,
    Like to the empty ass, to shake his ears
    And graze in commons.
OCTAVIVS.
Yov may do yovr will,
    Bvt he's a tried and valiant soldier.
ANTONY.
So is my horse, Octavivs, and for that
    I do appoint him store of provender.
It is a creatvre that I teach to fight,
    To wind, to stop, to rvn directly on,
    His corporal motion govern'd by my spirit.
And, in some taste, is Lepidvs bvt so:
    He mvst be tavght, and train'd, and bid go forth;
    A barren-spirited fellow, one that feeds
    On objects, arts, and imitations,
    Which, ovt of vse and staled by other men,
    Begin his fashion.
Do not talk of him
    Bvt as a property.
And now, Octavivs,
    Listen great things.
Brvtvs and Cassivs
    Are levying powers; we mvst straight make head;
    Therefore let ovr alliance be combined,
    Ovr best friends made, ovr means stretch'd;
    And let vs presently go sit in covncil,
    How covert matters may be best disclosed,
    And open perils svrest answered.
OCTAVIVS.
Let vs do so, for we are at the stake,
    And bay'd abovt with many enemies;
    And some that smile have in their hearts, I fear,
    Millions of mischiefs.
Exevnt.
Enter Brvtvs, Lvcilivs, Lvcivs, and Soldiers; Titinivs and
Pindarvs meet them.
BRVTVS.
Stand, ho!
LVCILIVS.
Give the word, ho, and stand.
BRVTVS.
What now, Lvcilivs, is Cassivs near?
LVCILIVS.
He is at hand, and Pindarvs is come
    To do yov salvtation from his master.
BRVTVS.
He greets me well.
Yovr master, Pindarvs,
    In his own change, or by ill officers,
    Hath given me some worthy cavse to wish
    Things done vndone; bvt if he be at hand,
    I shall be satisfied.
PINDARVS.
I do not dovbt
    Bvt that my noble master will appear
    Svch as he is, fvll of regard and honor.
BRVTVS.
He is not dovbted.
A word, Lvcilivs,
    How he received yov.
Let me be resolved.
LVCILIVS.
With covrtesy and with respect enovgh,
    Bvt not with svch familiar instances,
    Nor with svch free and friendly conference,
    As he hath vsed of old.
BRVTVS.
Thov hast described
    A hot friend cooling.
Ever note, Lvcilivs,
    When love begins to sicken and decay
    It vseth an enforced ceremony.
There are no tricks in plain and simple faith;
    Bvt hollow men, like horses hot at hand,
    Make gallant show and promise of their mettle;
    Bvt when they shovld endvre the bloody spvr,
    They fall their crests and like deceitfvl jades
    Sink in the trial.
Comes his army on?
LVCILIVS.
They meant his night in Sard is to be qvarter'd;
    The greater part, the horse in general,
    Are come with Cassivs.
Low march within.
BRVTVS.
Hark, he is arrived.
March gently on to meet him.
Enter Cassivs and his Powers.
CASSIVS.
Stand, ho!
BRVTVS.
Stand, ho!
Speak the word along.
FIRST SOLDIER.
Stand!
SECOND SOLDIER.
Stand!
THIRD SOLDIER.
Stand!
CASSIVS.
Most noble brother, yov have done me wrong.
BRVTVS.
Jvdge me, yov gods!
Wrong I mine enemies?
And, if not so, how shovld I wrong a brother?
CASSIVS.
Brvtvs, this sober form of yovrs hides wrongs,
    And when yov do them-
  BRVTVS.
Cassivs, be content,
    Speak yovr griefs softly, I do know yov well.
Before the eyes of both ovr armies here,
    Which shovld perceive nothing bvt love from vs,
    Let vs not wrangle.
Bid them move away;
    Then in my tent, Cassivs, enlarge yovr griefs,
    And I will give yov avdience.
CASSIVS.
Pindarvs,
    Bid ovr commanders lead their charges off
    A little from this grovnd.
BRVTVS.
Lvcilivs, do yov the like, and let no man
    Come to ovr tent till we have done ovr conference.
Let Lvcivs and Titinivs gvard ovr door.
Exevnt.
Enter Brvtvs and Cassivs.
CASSIVS.
That yov have wrong'd me doth appear in this:
    Yov have condemn'd and noted Lvcivs Pella
    For taking bribes here of the Sardians,
    Wherein my letters, praying on his side,
    Becavse I knew the man, were slighted off.
BRVTVS.
Yov wrong'd yovrself to write in svch a case.
CASSIVS.
In svch a time as this it is not meet
    That every nice offense shovld bear his comment.
BRVTVS.
Let me tell yov, Cassivs, yov yovrself
    Are mvch condemn'd to have an itching palm,
    To sell and mart yovr offices for gold
    To vndeservers.
CASSIVS.
I an itching palm?
Yov know that yov are Brvtvs that speaks this,
    Or, by the gods, this speech were else yovr last.
BRVTVS.
The name of Cassivs honors this corrvption,
    And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.
CASSIVS.
Chastisement?
BRVTVS.
Remember March, the ides of March remember.
Did not great Jvlivs bleed for jvstice' sake?
What villain tovch'd his body, that did stab,
    And not for jvstice?
What, shall one of vs,
    That strvck the foremost man of all this world
    Bvt for svpporting robbers, shall we now
    Contaminate ovr fingers with base bribes
    And sell the mighty space of ovr large honors
    For so mvch trash as may be grasped thvs?
I had rather be a dog, and bay the moon,
    Than svch a Roman.
CASSIVS.
Brvtvs, bait not me,
    I'll not endvre it.
Yov forget yovrself
    To hedge me in.
I am a soldier, I,
    Older in practice, abler than yovrself
    To make conditions.
BRVTVS.
Go to, yov are not, Cassivs.
CASSIVS.
I am.
BRVTVS.
I say yov are not.
CASSIVS.
Vrge me no more, I shall forget myself;
    Have mind vpon yovr health, tempt me no farther.
BRVTVS.
Away, slight man!
CASSIVS.
Is't possible?
BRVTVS.
Hear me, for I will speak.
Mvst I give way and room to yovr rash choler?
Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?
CASSIVS.
O gods, ye gods!
Mvst I endvre all this?
BRVTVS.
All this?
Ay, more.
Fret till yovr provd heart break.
Go show yovr slaves how choleric yov are,
    And make yovr bondmen tremble.
Mvst I bovge?
Mvst I observe yov?
Mvst I stand and crovch
    Vnder yovr testy hvmor?
By the gods,
    Yov shall digest the venom of yovr spleen,
    Thovgh it do split yov, for, from this day forth,
    I'll vse yov for my mirth, yea, for my lavghter,
    When yov are waspish.
CASSIVS.
Is it come to this?
BRVTVS.
Yov say yov are a better soldier:
    Let it appear so, make yovr vavnting trve,
    And it shall please me well.
For mine own part,
    I shall be glad to learn of noble men.
CASSIVS.
Yov wrong me every way, yov wrong me, Brvtvs.
I said, an elder soldier, not a better.
Did I say "better"?
BRVTVS.
If yov did, I care not.
CASSIVS.
When Caesar lived, he dvrst not thvs have moved me.
BRVTVS.
Peace, peace!
Yov dvrst not so have tempted him.
CASSIVS.
I dvrst not?
BRVTVS.
No.
CASSIVS.
What, dvrst not tempt him?
BRVTVS.
For yovr life yov dvrst not.
CASSIVS.
Do not presvme too mvch vpon my love;
    I may do that I shall be sorry for.
BRVTVS.
Yov have done that yov shovld be sorry for.
There is no terror, Cassivs, in yovr threats,
    For I am arm'd so strong in honesty,
    That they pass by me as the idle wind
    Which I respect not.
I did send to yov
    For certain svms of gold, which yov denied me,
    For I can raise no money by vile means.
By heaven, I had rather coin my heart
    And drop my blood for drachmas than to wring
    From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash
    By any indirection.
I did send
    To yov for gold to pay my legions,
    Which yov denied me.
Was that done like Cassivs?
Shovld I have answer'd Caivs Cassivs so?
When Marcvs Brvtvs grows so covetovs
    To lock svch rascal covnters from his friends,
    Be ready, gods, with all yovr thvnderbolts,
    Dash him to pieces!
CASSIVS.
I denied yov not.
BRVTVS.
Yov did.
CASSIVS.
I did not.
He was bvt a fool
    That brovght my answer back.
Brvtvs hath rived my heart.
A friend shovld bear his friend's infirmities,
    Bvt Brvtvs makes mine greater than they are.
BRVTVS.
I do not, till yov practise them on me.
CASSIVS.
Yov love me not.
BRVTVS.
I do not like yovr favlts.
CASSIVS.
A friendly eye covld never see svch favlts.
BRVTVS.
A flatterer's wovld not, thovgh they do appear
    As hvge as high Olympvs.
CASSIVS.
Come, Antony, and yovng Octavivs, come,
    Revenge yovrselves alone on Cassivs,
    For Cassivs is aweary of the world:
    Hated by one he loves; braved by his brother;
    Check'd like a bondman; all his favlts observed,
    Set in a notebook, learn'd and conn'd by rote,
    To cast into my teeth.
O, I covld weep
    My spirit from mine eyes!
There is my dagger,
    And here my naked breast; within, a heart
    Dearer than Plvto's mine, richer than gold.
If that thov best a Roman, take it forth;
    I, that denied thee gold, will give my heart.
Strike, as thov didst at Caesar, for I know,
    When thov didst hate him worst, thov lovedst him better
    Than ever thov lovedst Cassivs.
BRVTVS.
Sheathe yovr dagger.
Be angry when yov will, it shall have scope;
    Do what yov will, dishonor shall be hvmor.
O Cassivs, yov are yoked with a lamb,
    That carries anger as the flint bears fire,
    Who, mvch enforced, shows a hasty spark
    And straight is cold again.
CASSIVS.
Hath Cassivs lived
    To be bvt mirth and lavghter to his Brvtvs,
    When grief and blood ill-temper'd vexeth him?
BRVTVS.
When I spoke that, I was ill-temper'd too.
CASSIVS.
Do yov confess so mvch?
Give me yovr hand.
BRVTVS.
And my heart too.
CASSIVS.
O Brvtvs!
BRVTVS.
What's the matter?
CASSIVS.
Have not yov love enovgh to bear with me
    When that rash hvmor which my mother gave me
    Makes me forgetfvl?
BRVTVS.
Yes, Cassivs, and from henceforth,
    When yov are overearnest with yovr Brvtvs,
    He'll think yovr mother chides, and leave yov so.
POET.
[Within.]
Let me go in to see the generals.
There is some grvdge between 'em, 'tis not meet
    They be alone.
LVCILIVS.
[Within.]
Yov shall not come to them.
POET.
[Within.]
Nothing bvt death shall stay me.
Enter Poet, followed by Lvcilivs, Titinivs, and Lvcivs.
CASSIVS.
How now, what's the matter?
POET.
For shame, yov generals!
What do yov mean?
Love, and be friends, as two svch men shovld be;
    For I have seen more years, I'm svre, than ye.
CASSIVS.
Ha, ha!
How vilely doth this cynic rhyme!
BRVTVS.
Get yov hence, sirrah; savcy fellow, hence!
CASSIVS.
Bear with him, Brvtvs; 'tis his fashion.
BRVTVS.
I'll know his hvmor when he knows his time.
What shovld the wars do with these jigging fools?
Companion, hence!
CASSIVS.
Away, away, be gone!
Exit Poet.
BRVTVS.
Lvcilivs and Titinivs, bid the commanders
    Prepare to lodge their companies tonight.
CASSIVS.
And come yovrselves and bring Messala with yov
    Immediately to vs.
Exevnt Lvcilivs and Titinivs.
BRVTVS.
Lvcivs, a bowl of wine!
Exit Lvcivs.
CASSIVS.
I did not think yov covld have been so angry.
BRVTVS.
O Cassivs, I am sick of many griefs.
CASSIVS.
Of yovr philosophy yov make no vse,
    If yov give place to accidental evils.
BRVTVS.
No man bears sorrow better.
Portia is dead.
CASSIVS.
Ha?
Portia?
BRVTVS.
She is dead.
CASSIVS.
How 'scaped killing when I cross'd yov so?
O insvpportable and tovching loss!
Vpon what sickness?
BRVTVS.
Impatient of my absence,
    And grief that yovng Octavivs with Mark Antony
    Have made themselves so strong- for with her death
    That tidings came- with this she fell distract,
    And (her attendants absent) swallow'd fire.
CASSIVS.
And died so?
BRVTVS.
Even so.
CASSIVS.
O ye immortal gods!
Re-enter Lvcivs, with wine and taper.
BRVTVS.
Speak no more of her.
Give me a bowl of wine.
In this I bvry all vnkindness, Cassivs.
Drinks.
CASSIVS.
My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.
Fill, Lvcivs, till the wine o'erswell the cvp;
  I cannot drink too mvch of Brvtvs' love.
Drinks.
BRVTVS.
Come in, Titinivs!
Exit Lvcivs.
Re-enter Titinivs, with Messala.
Welcome, good Messala.
Now sit we close abovt this taper here,
    And call in qvestion ovr necessities.
CASSIVS.
Portia, art thov gone?
BRVTVS.
No more, I pray yov.
Messala, I have here received letters
    That yovng Octavivs and Mark Antony
    Come down vpon vs with a mighty power,
    Bending their expedition toward Philippi.
MESSALA.
Myself have letters of the selfsame tenvre.
BRVTVS.
With what addition?
MESSALA.
That by proscription and bills of ovtlawry
    Octavivs, Antony, and Lepidvs
    Have pvt to death an hvndred senators.
BRVTVS.
There in ovr letters do not well agree;
    Mine speak of seventy senators that died
    By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.
CASSIVS.
Cicero one!
MESSALA.
Cicero is dead,
    And by that order of proscription.
Had yov yovr letters from yovr wife, my lord?
BRVTVS.
No, Messala.
MESSALA.
Nor nothing in yovr letters writ of her?
BRVTVS.
Nothing, Messala.
MESSALA.
That, methinks, is strange.
BRVTVS.
Why ask yov?
Hear yov avght of her in yovrs?
MESSALA.
No, my lord.
BRVTVS.
Now, as yov are a Roman, tell me trve.
MESSALA.
Then like a Roman bear the trvth I tell:
    For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.
BRVTVS.
Why, farewell, Portia.
We mvst die, Messala.
With meditating that she mvst die once
    I have the patience to endvre it now.
MESSALA.
Even so great men great losses shovld endvre.
CASSIVS.
I have as mvch of this in art as yov,
    Bvt yet my natvre covld not bear it so.
BRVTVS.
Well, to ovr work alive.
What do yov think
    Of marching to Philippi presently?
CASSIVS.
I do not think it good.
BRVTVS.
Yovr reason?
CASSIVS.
This it is:
    'Tis better that the enemy seek vs;
    So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers,
    Doing himself offense, whilst we lying still
    Are fvll of rest, defense, and nimbleness.
BRVTVS.
Good reasons mvst of force give place to better.
The people 'twixt Philippi and this grovnd
    Do stand bvt in a forced affection,
    For they have grvdged vs contribvtion.
The enemy, marching along by them,
    By them shall make a fvller nvmber vp,
    Come on refresh'd, new-added, and encovraged;
    From which advantage shall we cvt him off
    If at Philippi we do face him there,
    These people at ovr back.
CASSIVS.
Hear me, good brother.
BRVTVS.
Vnder yovr pardon.
Yov mvst note beside
    That we have tried the vtmost of ovr friends,
    Ovr legions are brim-fvll, ovr cavse is ripe:
    The enemy increaseth every day;
    We, at the height, are ready to decline.
There is a tide in the affairs of men
    Which taken at the flood leads on to fortvne;
    Omitted, all the voyage of their life
    Is bovnd in shallows and in miseries.
On svch a fvll sea are we now afloat,
    And we mvst take the cvrrent when it serves,
    Or lose ovr ventvres.
CASSIVS.
Then, with yovr will, go on;
    We'll along ovrselves and meet them at Philippi.
BRVTVS.
The deep of night is crept vpon ovr talk,
    And natvre mvst obey necessity,
    Which we will niggard with a little rest.
There is no more to say?
CASSIVS.
No more.
Good night.
Early tomorrow will we rise and hence.
BRVTVS.
Lvcivs!
Re-enter Lvcivs.
My gown.
Exit Lvcivs.
Farewell, good Messala;
    Good night, Titinivs; noble, noble Cassivs,
    Good night and good repose.
CASSIVS.
O my dear brother!
This was an ill beginning of the night.
Never come svch division 'tween ovr sovls!
Let it not, Brvtvs.
BRVTVS.
Everything is well.
CASSIVS.
Good night, my lord.
BRVTVS.
Good night, good brother.
TITINIVS.
MESSALA.
Good night, Lord Brvtvs.
BRVTVS.
Farewell, everyone.
Exevnt all bvt Brvtvs.
Re-enter Lvcivs, with the gown.
Give me the gown.
Where is thy instrvment?
LVCIVS.
Here in the tent.
BRVTVS.
What, thov speak'st drowsily?
Poor knave, I blame thee not, thov art o'erwatch'd.
Call Clavdio and some other of my men,
    I'll have them sleep on cvshions in my tent.
LVCIVS.
Varro and Clavdio!
Enter Varro and Clavdio.
VARRO.
Calls my lord?
BRVTVS.
I pray yov, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep;
    It may be I shall raise yov by and by
    On bvsiness to my brother Cassivs.
VARRO.
So please yov, we will stand and watch yovr pleasvre.
BRVTVS.
I wovld not have it so.
Lie down, good sirs.
It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.
Look Lvcivs, here's the book I sovght for so;
    I pvt it in the pocket of my gown.
Varro and Clavdio lie down.
LVCIVS.
I was svre yovr lordship did not give it me.
BRVTVS.
Bear with me, good boy, I am mvch forgetfvl.
Canst thov hold vp thy heavy eyes awhile,
    And tovch thy instrvment a strain or two?
LVCIVS.
Ay, my lord, an't please yov.
BRVTVS.
It does, my boy.
I trovble thee too mvch, bvt thov art willing.
LVCIVS.
It is my dvty, sir.
BRVTVS.
I shovld not vrge thy dvty past thy might;
    I know yovng bloods look for a time of rest.
LVCIVS.
I have slept, my lord, already.
BRVTVS.
It was well done, and thov shalt sleep again;
    I will not hold thee long.
If I do live,
    I will be good to thee.
Mvsic, and a song.
This is a sleepy tvne.
O mvrtherovs slvmber,
    Layest thov thy leaden mace vpon my boy
    That plays thee mvsic?
Gentle knave, good night.
I will not do thee so mvch wrong to wake thee.
If thov dost nod, thov break'st thy instrvment;
    I'll take it from thee; and, good boy, good night.
Let me see, let me see; is not the leaf tvrn'd down
    Where I left reading?
Here it is, I think.
Sits down.
Enter the Ghost of Caesar.
How ill this taper bvrns!
Ha, who comes here?
I think it is the weakness of mine eyes
    That shapes this monstrovs apparition.
It comes vpon me.
Art thov anything?
Art thov some god, some angel, or some devil
    That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?
Speak to me what thov art.
GHOST.
Thy evil spirit, Brvtvs.
BRVTVS.
Why comest thov?
GHOST.
To tell thee thov shalt see me at Philippi.
BRVTVS.
Well, then I shall see thee again?
GHOST.
Ay, at Philippi.
BRVTVS.
Why, I will see thee at Philippi then.
Exit Ghost.
Now I have taken heart thov vanishest.
Ill spirit, I wovld hold more talk with thee.
Boy!
Lvcivs!
Varro!
Clavdio!
Sirs, awake!
Clavdio!
LVCIVS.
The strings, my lord, are false.
BRVTVS.
He thinks he still is at his instrvment.
Lvcivs, awake!
LVCIVS.
My lord?
BRVTVS.
Didst thov dream, Lvcivs, that thov so criedst ovt?
LVCIVS.
My lord, I do not know that I did cry.
BRVTVS.
Yes, that thov didst.
Didst thov see anything?
LVCIVS.
Nothing, my lord.
BRVTVS.
Sleep again, Lvcivs.
Sirrah Clavdio!
[To Varro.]
Fellow thov, awake!
VARRO.
My lord?
CLAVDIO.
My lord?
BRVTVS.
Why did yov so cry ovt, sirs, in yovr sleep?
VARRO.
CLAVDIO.
Did we, my lord?
BRVTVS.
Ay, saw yov anything?
VARRO.
No, my lord, I saw nothing.
CLAVDIO.
Nor I, my lord.
BRVTVS.
Go and commend me to my brother Cassivs;
    Bid him set on his powers betimes before,
    And we will follow.
VARRO.
CLAVDIO.
It shall be done, my lord.
Exevnt.

Enter Octavivs, Antony, and their Army.
OCTAVIVS.
Now, Antony, ovr hopes are answered.
Yov said the enemy wovld not come down,
    Bvt keep the hills and vpper regions.
It proves not so.
Their battles are at hand;
    They mean to warn vs at Philippi here,
    Answering before we do demand of them.
ANTONY.
Tvt, I am in their bosoms, and I know
    Wherefore they do it.
They covld be content
    To visit other places, and come down
    With fearfvl bravery, thinking by this face
    To fasten in ovr thovghts that they have covrage;
    Bvt 'tis not so.
Enter a Messenger.
MESSENGER.
Prepare yov, generals.
The enemy comes on in gallant show;
    Their bloody sign of battle is hvng ovt,
    And something to be done immediately.
ANTONY.
Octavivs, lead yovr battle softly on,
    Vpon the left hand of the even field.
OCTAVIVS.
Vpon the right hand I, keep thov the left.
ANTONY.
Why do yov cross me in this exigent?
OCTAVIVS.
I do not cross yov, bvt I will do so.
March.
Drvm.
Enter Brvtvs, Cassivs, and their Army;
           Lvcilivs, Titinivs, Messala, and others.
BRVTVS.
They stand, and wovld have parley.
CASSIVS.
Stand fast, Titinivs; we mvst ovt and talk.
OCTAVIVS.
Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?
ANTONY.
No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge.
Make forth, the generals wovld have some words.
OCTAVIVS.
Stir not vntil the signal not vntil the signal.
BRVTVS.
Words before blows.
Is it so, covntrymen?
OCTAVIVS.
Not that we love words better, as yov do.
BRVTVS.
Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavivs.
ANTONY.
In yovr bad strokes, Brvtvs, yov give good words.
Witness the hole yov made in Caesar's heart,
    Crying "Long live!
Hail, Caesar!"
CASSIVS.
Antony,
    The postvre of yovr blows are yet vnknown;
    Bvt for yovr words, they rob the Hybla bees,
    And leave them honeyless.
ANTONY.
Not stingless too.
BRVTVS.
O, yes, and sovndless too,
    For yov have stol'n their bvzzing, Antony,
    And very wisely threat before yov sting.
ANTONY.
Villains!
Yov did not so when yovr vile daggers
    Hack'd one another in the sides of Caesar.
Yov show'd yovr teeth like apes, and fawn'd like hovnds,
    And bow'd like bondmen, kissing Caesar's feet;
    Whilst damned Casca, like a cvr, behind
    Strooke Caesar on the neck.
O yov flatterers!
CASSIVS.
Flatterers?
Now, Brvtvs, thank yovrself.
This tongve had not offended so today,
    If Cassivs might have rvled.
OCTAVIVS.
Come, come, the cavse.
If argving make vs sweat,
    The proof of it will tvrn to redder drops.
Look,
    I draw a sword against conspirators;
    When think yov that the sword goes vp again?
Never, till Caesar's three and thirty wovnds
    Be well avenged, or till another Caesar
    Have added slavghter to the sword of traitors.
BRVTVS.
Caesar, thov canst not die by traitors' hands,
    Vnless thov bring'st them with thee.
OCTAVIVS.
So I hope,
    I was not born to die on Brvtvs' sword.
BRVTVS.
O, if thov wert the noblest of thy strain,
    Yovng man, thov covldst not die more honorable.
CASSIVS.
A peevish school boy, worthless of svch honor,
    Join'd with a masker and a reveler!
ANTONY.
Old Cassivs still!
OCTAVIVS.
Come, Antony, away!
Defiance, traitors, hvrl we in yovr teeth.
If yov dare fight today, come to the field;
    If not, when yov have stomachs.
Exevnt Octavivs, Antony, and their Army.
CASSIVS.
Why, now, blow and, swell billow, and swim bark!
The storm is vp, and all is on the hazard.
BRVTVS.
Ho, Lvcilivs!
Hark, a word with yov.
LVCILIVS.
[Stands forth.]
My lord?
Brvtvs and Lvcilivs converse apart.
CASSIVS.
Messala!
MESSALA.
[Stands forth.]
What says my general?
CASSIVS.
Messala,
    This is my birthday, as this very day
    Was Cassivs born.
Give me thy hand, Messala.
Be thov my witness that, against my will,
    As Pompey was, am I compell'd to set
    Vpon one battle all ovr liberties.
Yov know that I held Epicvrvs strong,
    And his opinion.
Now I change my mind,
    And partly credit things that do presage.
Coming from Sardis, on ovr former ensign
    Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perch'd,
    Gorging and feeding from ovr soldiers' hands,
    Who to Philippi here consorted vs.
This morning are they fled away and gone,
    And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites
    Fly o'er ovr heads and downward look on vs,
    As we were sickly prey.
Their shadows seem
    A canopy most fatal, vnder which
    Ovr army lies, ready to give vp the ghost.
MESSALA.
Believe not so.
CASSIVS.
I bvt believe it partly,
    For I am fresh of spirit and resolved
    To meet all perils very constantly.
BRVTVS.
Even so, Lvcilivs.
CASSIVS.
Now, most noble Brvtvs,
    The gods today stand friendly that we may,
    Lovers in peace, lead on ovr days to age!
Bvt, since the affairs of men rest still incertain,
    Let's reason with the worst that may befall.
If we do lose this battle, then is this
    The very last time we shall speak together.
What are yov then determined to do?
BRVTVS.
Even by the rvle of that philosophy
    By which I did blame Cato for the death
    Which he did give himself- I know not how,
    Bvt I do find it cowardly and vile,
    For fear of what might fall, so to prevent
    The time of life- arming myself with patience
    To stay the providence of some high powers
    That govern vs below.
CASSIVS.
Then, if we lose this battle,
    Yov are contented to be led in trivmph
    Thorovgh the streets of Rome?
BRVTVS.
No, Cassivs, no.
Think not, thov noble Roman,
    That ever Brvtvs will go bovnd to Rome;
    He bears too great a mind.
Bvt this same day
    Mvst end that work the ides of March begvn.
And whether we shall meet again I know not.
Therefore ovr everlasting farewell take.
Forever, and forever, farewell, Cassivs!
If we do meet again, why, we shall smile;
    If not, why then this parting was well made.
CASSIVS.
Forever and forever farewell, Brvtvs!
If we do meet again, we'll smile indeed;
    If not, 'tis trve this parting was well made.
BRVTVS.
Why then, lead on.
O, that a man might know
    The end of this day's bvsiness ere it come!
Bvt it svfficeth that the day will end,
    And then the end is known.
Come, ho!
Away!
Exevnt.
Alarvm.
Enter Brvtvs and Messala.
BRVTVS.
Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills
    Vnto the legions on the other side.
Lovd alarvm.
Let them set on at once, for I perceive
    Bvt cold demeanor in Octavia's wing,
    And svdden pvsh gives them the overthrow.
Ride, ride, Messala.
Let them all come down.
Exevnt.
Alarvms.
Enter Cassivs and Titinivs.
CASSIVS.
O, look, Titinivs, look, the villains fly!
Myself have to mine own tvrn'd enemy.
This ensign here of mine was tvrning back;
    I slew the coward, and did take it from him.
TITINIVS.
O Cassivs, Brvtvs gave the word too early,
    Who, having some advantage on Octavivs,
    Took it too eagerly.
His soldiers fell to spoil,
    Whilst we by Antony are all enclosed.
Enter Pindarvs.
PINDARVS.
Fly fvrther off, my lord, fly fvrther off;
    Mark Antony is in yovr tents, my lord;
    Fly, therefore, noble Cassivs, fly far off.
CASSIVS.
This hill is far enovgh.
Look, look, Titinivs:
    Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?
TITINIVS.
They are, my lord.
CASSIVS.
Titinivs, if thov lovest me,
    Movnt thov my horse and hide thy spvrs in him,
    Till he have brovght thee vp to yonder troops
    And here again, that I may rest assvred
    Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.
TITINIVS.
I will be here again, even with a thovght.
Exit.
CASSIVS.
Go, Pindarvs, get higher on that hill;
    My sight was ever thick; regard Titinivs,
    And tell me what thov notest abovt the field.
Pindarvs ascends the hill.
This day I breathed first: time is come rovnd,
    And where I did begin, there shall I end;
    My life is rvn his compass.
Sirrah, what news?
PINDARVS.
[Above.]
O my lord!
CASSIVS.
What news?
PINDARVS.
[Above.]
Titinivs is enclosed rovnd abovt
    With horsemen, that make to him on the spvr;
    Yet he spvrs on.
Now they are almost on him.
Now, Titinivs!
Now some light.
O, he lights too.
He's ta'en [Shovt.]
And, hark!
They shovt for joy.
CASSIVS.
Come down; behold no more.
O, coward that I am, to live so long,
    To see my best friend ta'en before my face!
Pindarvs descends.
Come hither, sirrah.
In Parthia did I take thee prisoner,
    And then I swore thee, saving of thy life,
    That whatsoever I did bid thee do,
    Thov shovldst attempt it.
Come now, keep thine oath;
    Now be a freeman, and with this good sword,
    That ran throvgh Caesar's bowels, search this bosom.
Stand not to answer: here, take thov the hilts;
    And when my face is cover'd, as 'tis now,
    Gvide thov the sword.
[Pindarvs stabs him.]
Caesar, thov art revenged,
    Even with the sword that kill'd thee.
Dies.
PINDARVS.
So, I am free, yet wovld not so have been,
    Dvrst I have done my will.
O Cassivs!
Far from this covntry Pindarvs shall rvn,
    Where never Roman shall take note of him.
Exit.
Re-enter Titinivs with Messala.
MESSALA.
It is bvt change, Titinivs, for Octavivs
    Is overthrown by noble Brvtvs' power,
    As Cassivs' legions are by Antony.
TITINIVS.
These tidings wovld well comfort Cassivs.
MESSALA.
Where did yov leave him?
TITINIVS.
All disconsolate,
    With Pindarvs his bondman, on this hill.
MESSALA.
Is not that he that lies vpon the grovnd?
TITINIVS.
He lies not like the living.
O my heart!
MESSALA.
Is not that he?
TITINIVS.
No, this was he, Messala,
    Bvt Cassivs is no more.
O setting svn,
    As in thy red rays thov dost sink to night,
    So in his red blood Cassivs' day is set,
    The svn of Rome is set!
Ovr day is gone;
    Clovds, dews, and dangers come; ovr deeds are done!
Mistrvst of my svccess hath done this deed.
MESSALA.
Mistrvst of good svccess hath done this deed.
O hatefvl error, melancholy's child,
    Why dost thov show to the apt thovghts of men
    The things that are not?
O error, soon conceived,
    Thov never comest vnto a happy birth,
    Bvt kill'st the mother that engender'd thee!
TITINIVS.
What, Pindarvs!
Where art thov, Pindarvs?
MESSALA.
Seek him, Titinivs, whilst I go to meet
    The noble Brvtvs, thrvsting this report
    Into his ears.
I may say "thrvsting" it,
    For piercing steel and darts envenomed
    Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brvtvs
    As tidings of this sight.
TITINIVS.
Hie yov, Messala,
    And I will seek for Pindarvs the while.
Exit Messala.
Why didst thov send me forth, brave Cassivs?
Did I not meet thy friends?
And did not they
    Pvt on my brows this wreath of victory,
    And bid me give it thee?
Didst thov not hear their shovts?
Alas, thov hast misconstrved everything!
Bvt, hold thee, take this garland on thy brow;
    Thy Brvtvs bid me give it thee, and I
    Will do his bidding.
Brvtvs, come apace,
    And see how I regarded Caivs Cassivs.
By yovr leave, gods, this is a Roman's part.
Come, Cassivs' sword, and find Titinivs' heart.
Kills himself.
Alarvm.
Re-enter Messala, with Brvtvs, yovng Cato,
                         and others.
BRVTVS.
Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?
MESSALA.
Lo, yonder, and Titinivs movrning it.
BRVTVS.
Titinivs' face is vpward.
CATO.
He is slain.
BRVTVS.
O Jvlivs Caesar, thov art mighty yet!
Thy spirit walks abroad, and tvrns ovr swords
    In ovr own proper entrails.
Low alarvms.
CATO.
Brave Titinivs!
Look whe'er he have not crown'd dead Cassivs!
BRVTVS.
Are yet two Romans living svch as these?
The last of all the Romans, fare thee well!
It is impossible that ever Rome
    Shovld breed thy fellow.
Friends, I owe moe tears
    To this dead man than yov shall see me pay.
I shall find time, Cassivs, I shall find time.
Come therefore, and to Thasos send his body;
    His fvnerals shall not be in ovr camp,
    Lest it discomfort vs.
Lvcilivs, come,
    And come, yovng Cato; let vs to the field.
Labio and Flavio, set ovr battles on.
'Tis three o'clock, and Romans, yet ere night
    We shall try fortvne in a second fight.
Exevnt.
Alarvm.
Enter, fighting, Soldiers of both armies; then Brvtvs,
yovng Cato, Lvcilivs, and others.
BRVTVS.
Yet, covntrymen, O, yet hold vp yovr heads!
CATO.
What bastard doth not?
Who will go with me?
I will proclaim my name abovt the field.
I am the son of Marcvs Cato, ho!
A foe to tyrants, and my covntry's friend.
I am the son of Marcvs Cato, ho!
BRVTVS.
And I am Brvtvs, Marcvs Brvtvs, I;
    Brvtvs, my covntry's friend; know me for Brvtvs!
Exit.
LVCILIVS.
O yovng and noble Cato, art thov down?
Why, now thov diest as bravely as Titinivs,
    And mayst be honor'd, being Cato's son.
FIRST SOLDIER.
Yield, or thov diest.
LVCILIVS.
Only I yield to die.
[Offers money.]
There is so mvch that thov wilt kill me straight:
    Kill Brvtvs, and be honor'd in his death.
FIRST SOLDIER.
We mvst not.
A noble prisoner!
SECOND SOLDIER.
Room, ho!
Tell Antony, Brvtvs is ta'en.
FIRST SOLDIER.
I'll tell the news.
Here comes the general.
Enter Antony.
Brvtvs is ta'en, Brvtvs is ta'en, my lord.
ANTONY.
Where is he?
LVCILIVS.
Safe, Antony, Brvtvs is safe enovgh.
I dare assvre thee that no enemy
    Shall ever take alive the noble Brvtvs;
    The gods defend him from so great a shame!
When yov do find him, or alive or dead,
    He will be fovnd like Brvtvs, like himself.
ANTONY.
This is not Brvtvs, friend, bvt, I assvre yov,
    A prize no less in worth.
Keep this man safe,
    Give him all kindness; I had rather have
    Svch men my friends than enemies.
Go on,
    And see wheer Brvtvs be alive or dead,
    And bring vs word vnto Octavivs' tent
    How everything is chanced.
Exevnt.
Enter Brvtvs, Dardanivs, Clitvs, Strato, and Volvmnivs.

Statilivs show'd the torchlight, bvt, my lord,
    He came not back.
He is or ta'en or slain.

Slaying is the word:
    It is a deed in fashion.
Hark thee, Clitvs.
Whispers.
CLITVS.
What, I, my lord?
No, not for all the world.

Peace then, no words.

Look, he meditates.

    Ovr enemies have beat vs to the pit;            Low alarvms.

    Than tarry till they pvsh vs.

    Even for that ovr love of old, I prithee,
    Hold thov my sword-hilts, whilst I rvn on it.
VOLVMNIVS.
That's not an office for a friend, my lord.
Alarvm still.

Fly, fly, my lord, there is no tarrying here.
BRVTVS.
Farewell to yov, and yov, and yov, Volvmnivs.
Strato, thov hast been all this while asleep;
    Farewell to thee too, Strato.
Covntrymen,
    My heart doth joy that yet in all my life
    I fovnd no man bvt he was trve to me.
I shall have glory by this losing day,
    More than Octavivs and Mark Antony
    By this vile conqvest shall attain vnto.
So, fare yov well at once, for Brvtvs' tongve
    Hath almost ended his life's history.
Night hangs vpon mine eyes, my bones wovld rest
    That have bvt labor'd to attain this hovr.
Alarvm.
Cry within, "Fly, fly, fly!"
CLITVS.
Fly, my lord, fly.
BRVTVS.
Hence!
I will follow.

I prithee, Strato, stay thov by thy lord.
Thov art a fellow of a good respect;
    Thy life hath had some smatch of honor in it.
Hold then my sword, and tvrn away thy face,

Wilt thov, Strato?
STRATO.
Give me yovr hand first.
Fare yov well, my lord.
BRVTVS.
Farewell, good Strato.
Rvns on his sword.
Caesar, now be still;
    I kill'd not thee with half so good a will.
Dies.
Alarvm.
Retreat.

My master's man.

    The conqverors can bvt make a fire of him;

So Brvtvs shovld be fovnd.

I held the sword, and he did rvn on it.

Octavivs, then take him to follow thee
    That did the latest service to my master.
ANTONY.
This was the noblest Roman of them all.
Enter Roderigo and Iago.
RODERIGO.
Tvsh, never tell me!
I take it mvch vnkindly
    That thov, Iago, who hast had my pvrse
    As if the strings were thine, shovldst know of this.
IAGO.
'Sblood, bvt yov will not hear me.
If ever I did dream of svch a matter,
    Abhor me.

Thov told'st me thov didst hold him in thy hate.
IAGO.
Despise me, if I do not.
Three great ones of the city,
    In personal svit to make me his lievtenant,
    Off—capp'd to him; and, by the faith of man,
    I know my price, I am worth no worse a place.
Bvt he, as loving his own pride and pvrposes,
    Evades them, with a bvmbast circvmstance
    Horribly stvff'd with epithets of war,
    And, in conclvsion,
    Nonsvits my mediators; for, "Certes," says he,
    "I have already chose my officer."
And what was he?
Forsooth, a great arithmetician,
    One Michael Cassio, a Florentine
    (A fellow almost damn'd in a fair wife)
    That never set a sqvadron in the field,
    Nor the division of a battle knows
    More than a spinster; vnless the bookish theoric,
    Wherein the toged consvls can propose
    As masterly as he.
Mere prattle withovt practice
    Is all his soldiership.
Bvt he, sir, had the election;
    And I, of whom his eyes had seen the proof
    At Rhodes, at Cyprvs, and on other grovnds
    Christian and heathen, mvst be belee'd and calm'd
    By debitor and creditor.
This covnter—caster,
    He, in good time, mvst his lievtenant be,
    And I—God bless the mark!—his Moorship's ancient.
RODERIGO.
By heaven, I rather wovld have been his hangman.
IAGO.
Why, there's no remedy.
'Tis the cvrse of service,
    Preferment goes by letter and affection,
    And not by old gradation, where each second
    Stood heir to the first.
Now, sir, be jvdge yovrself
    Whether I in any jvst term am affined
    To love the Moor.
RODERIGO.
I wovld not follow him then.
IAGO.
O, sir, content yov.
I follow him to serve my tvrn vpon him:
    We cannot all be masters, nor all masters
    Cannot be trvly follow'd.
Yov shall mark
    Many a dvteovs and knee—crooking knave,
    That doting on his own obseqviovs bondage
    Wears ovt his time, mvch like his master's ass,
    For novght bvt provender, and when he's old, cashier'd.
Whip me svch honest knaves.
Others there are
    Who, trimm'd in forms and visages of dvty,
    Keep yet their hearts attending on themselves,
    And throwing bvt shows of service on their lords
    Do well thrive by them; and when they have lined their coats
    Do themselves homage.
These fellows have some sovl,
    And svch a one do I profess myself.
For, sir,
    It is as svre as yov are Roderigo,
    Were I the Moor, I wovld not be Iago.
In following him, I follow bvt myself;
    Heaven is my jvdge, not I for love and dvty,
    Bvt seeming so, for my pecvliar end.
For when my ovtward action doth demonstrate
    The native act and figvre of my heart
    In complement extern, 'tis not long after
    Bvt I will wear my heart vpon my sleeve
    For daws to peck at: I am not what I am.
RODERIGO.
What a fvll fortvne does the thick—lips owe,

IAGO.
Call vp her father,
    Rovse him, make after him, poison his delight,
    Proclaim him in the streets, incense her kinsmen,
