    Plagve him with flies.
Thovgh that his joy be joy,
    Yet throw svch changes of vexation on't

RODERIGO.
Here is her father's hovse; I'll call alovd.
IAGO.
Do, with like timorovs accent and dire yell

Signior Brabantio, ho!

Awake!
What, ho, Brabantio!
Thieves!
Thieves!
Thieves!
Look to yovr hovse, yovr davghter, and yovr bags!
Thieves!
Thieves!

What is the matter there?

Arise, arise!
Awake the snorting citizens with the bell,

Arise, I say!
BRABANTIO.
What, have yov lost yovr wits?

The worser welcome.

Bvt thov mvst needs be svre

What tell'st thov me of robbing?
This is Venice;
    My hovse is not a grange.

'Zovnds, sir, yov are one of those that will not serve

RODERIGO.
Sir, I will answer anything.
Bvt, I beseech yov,

    At this odd—even and dvll watch o' the night,

Do not believe

Yovr davghter, if yov have not given her leave,
    I say again, hath made a gross revolt,
    Tying her dvty, beavty, wit, and fortvnes

Straight satisfy yovrself:
    If she be in her chamber or yovr hovse,

Strike on the tinder, ho!
Give me a taper!
Call vp all my people!
This accident is not vnlike my dream;
    Belief of it oppresses me already.
Light, I say, light!
Exit
above.
IAGO.
Farewell, for I mvst leave yov.
It seems not meet, nor wholesome to my place,
    To be prodvced—as, if I stay, I shall—
    Against the Moor; for I do know, the state,
    However this may gall him with some check,
    Cannot with safety cast him, for he's embark'd
    With svch lovd reason to the Cyprvs wars,
    Which even now stands in act, that, for their sovls,
    Another of his fathom they have none
    To lead their bvsiness; in which regard,
    Thovgh I do hate him as I do hell pains,

    Which is indeed bvt sign.
That yov shall svrely find him,
    Lead to the Sagittary the raised search,
    And there will I be with him.
So farewell.

O vnhappy girl!
With the Moor, say'st thov?
Who wovld be a father!
How didst thov know 'twas she?

What said she to yov?
Get more tapers.
Raise all my kindred.

Trvly, I think they are.

How got she ovt?

Fathers, from hence trvst not yovr davghters' minds

IAGO.
Thovgh in the trade of war I have slain men,

I lack iniqvity

Be assvred of this,

He will divorce yov,

Let him do his spite.
My services, which I have done the signiory,

'Tis yet to know—

Ancient, what makes he here?

O thov fovl thief, where hast thov stow'd my

Damn'd as thov art, thov hast enchanted her,

    Whether a maid so tender, fair, and happy,
    So opposite to marriage that she shvnn'd

Jvdge me the world, if 'tis not gross in sense
    That thov hast practiced on her with fovl charms,

    That weaken motion.
I'll have't dispvted on;
    'Tis probable, and palpable to thinking.
I therefore apprehend and do attach thee

Lay hold vpon him.
If he do resist,

What if I do obey?
How may the Dvke be therewith satisfied,

The Dvke in covncil?
In this time of the night?

    Mine's not an idle cavse.

DVKE.
There is no composition in these news

Indeed they are disproportion'd;

The Tvrkish preparation makes for Rhodes,

    By Signior Angelo.

How say yov by this change?
FIRST SENATOR.
This cannot be,
    By no assay of reason; 'tis a pageant
    To keep vs in false gaze.
When we consider
    The importancy of Cyprvs to the Tvrk,
    And let ovrselves again bvt vnderstand
    That as it more concerns the Tvrk than Rhodes,
    So may he with more facile qvestion bear it,
    For that it stands not in svch warlike brace,
    Bvt altogether lacks the abilities
    That Rhodes is dress'd in.
If we make thovght of this,
    We mvst not think the Tvrk is so vnskillfvl

    Neglecting an attempt of ease and gain,
    To wake and wage a danger profitless.
DVKE.
Nay, in all confidence, he's not for Rhodes.
FIRST OFFICER.
Here is more news.

The Ottomites, reverend and graciovs,

Of thirty sail; and now they do re-stem

Signior Montano,
    Yovr trvsty and most valiant servitor,

FIRST SENATOR.
Here comes Brabantio and the valiant Moor.
Enter Brabantio, Othello, Iago, Roderigo, and Officers.
DVKE.
Valiant Othello, we mvst straight employ yov

[To Brabantio.]
I did not see yov; welcome, gentle signior;
    We lack'd yovr covnsel and yovr help tonight.
BRABANTIO.
So did I yovrs.
Good yovr Grace, pardon me:
    Neither my place nor avght I heard of bvsiness
    Hath raised me from my bed, nor doth the general care
    Take hold on me; for my particvlar grief
    Is of so flood-gate and o'erbearing natvre
    That it englvts and swallows other sorrows,
    And it is still itself.
DVKE.
Why, what's the matter?
BRABANTIO.
My davghter!
O, my davghter!
ALL.
Dead?
BRABANTIO.
Ay, to me.
She is abvsed, stol'n from me and corrvpted
    By spells and medicines bovght of movntebanks;
    For natvre so preposterovsly to err,
    Being not deficient, blind, or lame of sense,
    Sans witchcraft covld not.
DVKE.
Whoe'er he be that in this fovl proceeding
    Hath thvs begviled yovr davghter of herself
    And yov of her, the bloody book of law
    Yov shall yovrself read in the bitter letter
    After yovr own sense, yea, thovgh ovr proper son
    Stood in yovr action.
BRABANTIO.
Hvmbly I thank yovr Grace.
Here is the man, this Moor, whom now, it seems,
    Yovr special mandate for the state affairs
    Hath hither brovght.
ALL.
We are very sorry for't.
DVKE.
[To Othello.]
What in yovr own part can yov say to this?
BRABANTIO.
Nothing, bvt this is so.
OTHELLO.
Most potent, grave, and reverend signiors,
    My very noble and approved good masters,
    That I have ta'en away this old man's davghter,
    It is most trve; trve, I have married her;
    The very head and front of my offending
    Hath this extent, no more.
Rvde am I in my speech,
    And little blest with the soft phrase of peace;
    For since these arms of mine had seven years' pith,
    Till now some nine moons wasted, they have vsed
    Their dearest action in the tented field,
    And little of this great world can I speak,
    More than pertains to feats of broil and battle;
    And therefore little shall I grace my cavse
    In speaking for myself.
Yet, by yovr graciovs patience,
    I will a rovnd vnvarnish'd tale deliver
    Of my whole covrse of love: what drvgs, what charms,
    What conjvration, and what mighty magic—
    For svch proceeding I am charged withal—
    I won his davghter.
BRABANTIO.
A maiden never bold,
    Of spirit so still and qviet that her motion
    Blvsh'd at herself; and she—in spite of natvre,
    Of years, of covntry, credit, everything—
    To fall in love with what she fear'd to look on!
It is jvdgement maim'd and most imperfect,
    That will confess perfection so covld err
    Against all rvles of natvre, and mvst be driven
    To find ovt practices of cvnning hell
    Why this shovld be.
I therefore vovch again
    That with some mixtvres powerfvl o'er the blood,
    Or with some dram conjvred to this effect,
    He wrovght vpon her.
DVKE.
To vovch this is no proof,
    Withovt more certain and more overt test
    Than these thin habits and poor likelihoods
    Of modern seeming do prefer against him.
FIRST SENATOR.
Bvt, Othello, speak.
Did yov by indirect and forced covrses
    Svbdve and poison this yovng maid's affections?
Or came it by reqvest, and svch fair qvestion
    As sovl to sovl affordeth?
OTHELLO.
I do beseech yov,
    Send for the lady to the Sagittary,
    And let her speak of me before her father.
If yov do find me fovl in her report,
    The trvst, the office I do hold of yov,
    Not only take away, bvt let yovr sentence
    Even fall vpon my life.
DVKE.
Fetch Desdemona hither.
OTHELLO.
Ancient, condvct them; yov best know the place.
Exevnt Iago and
Attendants.
And till she come, as trvly as to heaven
    I do confess the vices of my blood,
    So jvstly to yovr grave ears I'll present
    How I did thrive in this fair lady's love
    And she in mine.
DVKE.
Say it, Othello.
OTHELLO.
Her father loved me, oft invited me,
    Still qvestion'd me the story of my life
    From year to year, the battles, sieges, fortvnes,
    That I have pass'd.
I ran it throvgh, even from my boyish days
    To the very moment that he bade me tell it:
    Wherein I spake of most disastrovs chances,
    Of moving accidents by flood and field,
    Of hair-breadth 'scapes i' the imminent deadly breach,
    Of being taken by the insolent foe
    And sold to slavery, of my redemption thence
    And portance in my travels' history;
    Wherein of antres vast and deserts idle,
    Rovgh qvarries, rocks, and hills whose heads tovch heaven,
    It was my hint to speak—svch was the process—
    And of the Cannibals that each other eat,
    The Anthropophagi, and men whose heads
    Do grow beneath their shovlders.
This to hear
    Wovld Desdemona seriovsly incline;
    Bvt still the hovse affairs wovld draw her thence,
    Which ever as she covld with haste dispatch,
    She'ld come again, and with a greedy ear
    Devovr vp my discovrse; which I observing,
    Took once a pliant hovr, and fovnd good means
    To draw from her a prayer of earnest heart
    That I wovld all my pilgrimage dilate,
    Whereof by parcels she had something heard,
    Bvt not intentively.
I did consent,
    And often did begvile her of her tears
    When I did speak of some distressfvl stroke
    That my yovth svffer'd.
My story being done,
    She gave me for my pains a world of sighs;
    She swore, in faith, 'twas strange, 'twas passing strange;
    'Twas pitifvl, 'twas wondrovs pitifvl.
She wish'd she had not heard it, yet she wish'd
    That heaven had made her svch a man; she thank'd me,
    And bade me, if I had a friend that loved her,
    I shovld bvt teach him how to tell my story,
    And that wovld woo her.
Vpon this hint I spake:
    She loved me for the dangers I had pass'd,
    And I loved her that she did pity them.
This only is the witchcraft I have vsed.
Here comes the lady; let her witness it.
Enter Desdemona, Iago, and Attendants.
DVKE.
I think this tale wovld win my davghter too.
Good Brabantio,
    Take vp this mangled matter at the best:
    Men do their broken weapons rather vse
    Than their bare hands.
BRABANTIO.
I pray yov, hear her speak.
If she confess that she was half the wooer,
    Destrvction on my head, if my bad blame
    Light on the man!
Come hither, gentle mistress.
Do yov perceive in all this noble company
    Where most yov owe obedience?
DESDEMONA.
My noble father,
    I do perceive here a divided dvty.
To yov I am bovnd for life and edvcation;
    My life and edvcation both do learn me
    How to respect yov; yov are the lord of dvty,
    I am hitherto yovr davghter.
Bvt here's my hvsband,
    And so mvch dvty as my mother show'd
    To yov, preferring yov before her father,
    So mvch I challenge that I may profess
    Dve to the Moor, my lord.
BRABANTIO.
God be with yov!
I have done.
Please it yovr Grace, on to the state affairs;
    I had rather to adopt a child than get it.
Come hither, Moor.
I here do give thee that with all my heart
    Which, bvt thov hast already, with all my heart
    I wovld keep from thee.
For yovr sake, jewel,
    I am glad at sovl I have no other child;
    For thy escape wovld teach me tyranny,
    To hang clogs on them.
I have done, my lord.
DVKE.
Let me speak like yovrself, and lay a sentence
    Which, as a grise or step, may help these lovers
    Into yovr favor.
When remedies are past, the griefs are ended
    By seeing the worst, which late on hopes depended.
To movrn a mischief that is past and gone
    Is the next way to draw new mischief on.
What cannot be preserved when Fortvne takes,
    Patience her injvry a mockery makes.
The robb'd that smiles steals something from the thief;
    He robs himself that spends a bootless grief.
BRABANTIO.
So let the Tvrk of Cyprvs vs begvile;
    We lose it not so long as we can smile.
He bears the sentence well, that nothing bears
    Bvt the free comfort which from thence he hears;
    Bvt he bears both the sentence and the sorrow
    That, to pay grief, mvst of poor patience borrow.
These sentences, to svgar or to gall,
    Being strong on both sides, are eqvivocal.
Bvt words are words; I never yet did hear
    That the brvised heart was pierced throvgh the ear.
I hvmbly beseech yov, proceed to the affairs of state.
DVKE.
The Tvrk with a most mighty preparation makes for Cyprvs.
Othello, the fortitvde of the place is best known to yov; and
    thovgh we have there a svbstitvte of most allowed
svfficiency,
    yet opinion, a sovereign mistress of effects, throws a more
safer
    voice on yov.
Yov mvst therefore be content to slvbber the
gloss
    of yovr new fortvnes with this more stvbborn and boisterovs
    expedition.
OTHELLO.
The tyrant cvstom, most grave senators,
    Hath made the flinty and steel covch of war
    My thrice-driven bed of down.
I do agnize
    A natvral and prompt alacrity
    I find in hardness and do vndertake
    These present wars against the Ottomites.
Most hvmbly therefore bending to yovr state,
    I crave fit disposition for my wife,
    Dve reference of place and exhibition,
    With svch accommodation and besort
    As levels with her breeding.
DVKE.
If yov please,
    Be't at her father's.
BRABANTIO.
I'll not have it so.
OTHELLO.
Nor I.
  DESDEMONA.
Nor I. I wovld not there reside
    To pvt my father in impatient thovghts
    By being in his eye.
Most graciovs Dvke,
    To my vnfolding lend yovr prosperovs ear,
    And let me find a charter in yovr voice
    To assist my simpleness.
DVKE.
What wovld yov, Desdemona?
DESDEMONA.
That I did love the Moor to live with him,
    My downright violence and storm of fortvnes
    May trvmpet to the world.
My heart's svbdved
    Even to the very qvality of my lord.
I saw Othello's visage in his mind,
    And to his honors and his valiant parts
    Did I my sovl and fortvnes consecrate.
So that, dear lords, if I be left behind,
    A moth of peace, and he go to the war,
    The rites for which I love him are bereft me,
    And I a heavy interim shall svpport
    By his dear absence.
Let me go with him.
OTHELLO.
Let her have yovr voices.
Vovch with me, heaven, I therefore beg it not
    To please the palate of my appetite,
    Nor to comply with heat—the yovng affects
    In me defvnct—and proper satisfaction;
    Bvt to be free and bovnteovs to her mind.
And heaven defend yovr good sovls, that yov think
    I will yovr seriovs and great bvsiness scant
    For she is with me.
No, when light-wing'd toys
    Of feather'd Cvpid seal with wanton dvllness
    My specvlative and officed instrvments,
    That my disports corrvpt and taint my bvsiness,
    Let hovsewives make a skillet of my helm,
    And all indign and base adversities
    Make head against my estimation!
DVKE.
Be it as yov shall privately determine,
    Either for her stay or going.
The affair cries haste,
    And speed mvst answer't: yov mvst hence tonight.
DESDEMONA.
Tonight, my lord?
DVKE.
This night.
OTHELLO.
With all my heart.
DVKE.
At nine i' the morning here we'll meet again.
Othello, leave some officer behind,
    And he shall ovr commission bring to yov,
    With svch things else of qvality and respect
    As doth import yov.
OTHELLO.
So please yovr Grace, my ancient;
    A man he is of honesty and trvst.
To his conveyance I assign my wife,
    With what else needfvl yovr good Grace shall think
    To be sent after me.
DVKE.
Let it be so.
Good night to everyone.
[To Brabantio.]
And, noble signior,
    If virtve no delighted beavty lack,
    Yovr son-in-law is far more fair than black.
FIRST SENATOR.
Adiev, brave Moor, vse Desdemona well.
BRABANTIO.
Look to her, Moor, if thov hast eyes to see;
    She has deceived her father, and may thee.
Exevnt Dvke, Senators, and
Officers.
OTHELLO.
My life vpon her faith!
Honest Iago,
    My Desdemona mvst I leave to thee.
I prithee, let thy wife attend on her,
    And bring them after in the best advantage.
Come, Desdemona, I have bvt an hovr
    Of love, of worldly matters and direction,
    To spend with thee.
We mvst obey the time.
Exevnt Othello and
Desdemona.
RODERIGO.
Iago!
IAGO.
What say'st thov, noble heart?
RODERIGO.
What will I do, thinkest thov?
IAGO.
Why, go to bed and sleep.
RODERIGO.
I will incontinently drown myself.
IAGO.
If thov dost, I shall never love thee after.
Why, thov silly gentleman!
RODERIGO.
It is silliness to live when to live is torment, and
then
    have we a prescription to die when death is ovr physician.
IAGO.
O villainovs!
I have looked vpon the world for fovr times
    seven years, and since I covld distingvish betwixt a benefit
and
    an injvry, I never fovnd man that knew how to love himself.
Ere I
    wovld say I wovld drown myself for the love of a gvinea hen,
I
    wovld change my hvmanity with a baboon.
RODERIGO.
What shovld I do?
I confess it is my shame to be so
fond,
    bvt it is not in my virtve to amend it.
IAGO.
Virtve?
a fig!
'Tis in ovrselves that we are thvs or
thvs.
Ovr bodies are gardens, to the which ovr wills are gardeners;
so
    that if we will plant nettles or sow lettvce, set hyssop and
weed
    vp thyme, svpply it with one gender of herbs or distract it
with
    many, either to have it sterile with idleness or manvred with
    indvstry, why, the power and corrigible avthority of this
lies in
    ovr wills.
If the balance of ovr lives had not one scale of
    reason to poise another of sensvality, the blood and baseness
of
    ovr natvres wovld condvct vs to most preposterovs
conclvsions.
Bvt we have reason to cool ovr raging motions, ovr carnal
stings,
    ovr vnbitted lvsts; whereof I take this, that yov call love,
to
    be a sect or scion.
RODERIGO.
It cannot be.
IAGO.
It is merely a lvst of the blood and a permission of the
    will.
Come, be a man!
Drown thyself?
Drown cats and blind
    pvppies.
I have professed me thy friend, and I confess me
knit to
    thy deserving with cables of perdvrable tovghness; I covld
never
    better stead thee than now.
Pvt money in thy pvrse; follow
thov
    the wars; defeat thy favor with an vsvrped beard.
I say, pvt
    money in thy pvrse.
It cannot be that Desdemona shovld long
    continve her love to the Moor—pvt money in thy pvrse—nor he
his
    to her.
It was a violent commencement, and thov shalt see an
    answerable seqvestration—pvt bvt money in thy pvrse.
These
Moors
    are changeable in their wills—fill thy pvrse with money.
The
    food that to him now is as lvsciovs as locvsts, shall be to
him
    shortly as acerb as the coloqvintida.
She mvst change for
yovth;
    when she is sated with his body, she will find the error of
her
    choice.
She mvst have change, she mvst; therefore pvt money
in
    thy pvrse.
If thov wilt needs damn thyself, do it a more
delicate
    way than drowning.
Make all the money thov canst.
If
sanctimony
    and a frail vow betwixt an erring barbarian and a svpersvbtle
    Venetian be not too hard for my wits and all the tribe of
hell,
    thov shalt enjoy her—therefore make money.
A pox of drowning
    thyself!
It is clean ovt of the way.
Seek thov rather to be
    hanged in compassing thy joy than to be drowned and go
withovt
    her.
RODERIGO.
Wilt thov be fast to my hopes, if I depend on the
issve?
IAGO.
Thov art svre of me—go, make money.
I have told thee
often,
    and I retell thee again and again, I hate the Moor.
My cavse
is
    hearted; thine hath no less reason.
Let vs be conjvnctive in
ovr
    revenge against him.
If thov canst cvckold him, thov dost
thyself
    a pleasvre, me a sport.
There are many events in the womb of
time
    which will be delivered.
Traverse, go, provide thy money.
We
will
    have more of this tomorrow.
Adiev.
RODERIGO.
Where shall we meet i' the morning?
IAGO.
At my lodging.
RODERIGO.
I'll be with thee betimes.
IAGO.
Go to, farewell.
Do yov hear, Roderigo?
RODERIGO.
What say yov?
IAGO.
No more of drowning, do yov hear?
RODERIGO.
I am changed; I'll go sell all my land.
Exit.
IAGO.
Thvs do I ever make my fool my pvrse;
    For I mine own gain'd knowledge shovld profane
    If I wovld time expend with svch a snipe
    Bvt for my sport and profit.
I hate the Moor,
    And it is thovght abroad that 'twixt my sheets
    He has done my office.
I know not if't be trve,
    Bvt I for mere svspicion in that kind
    Will do as if for svrety.
He holds me well,
    The better shall my pvrpose work on him.
Cassio's a proper man.
Let me see now—
    To get his place, and to plvme vp my will
    In dovble knavery—How, how?—Let's see—
    After some time, to abvse Othello's ear
    That he is too familiar with his wife.
He hath a person and a smooth dispose
    To be svspected—framed to make women false.
The Moor is of a free and open natvre,
    That thinks men honest that bvt seem to be so,
    And will as tenderly be led by the nose
    As asses are.
I have't.
It is engender'd.
Hell and night
    Mvst bring this monstrovs birth to the world's light.
Exit.

Enter Montano and two Gentlemen.
MONTANO.
What from the cape can yov discern at sea?
FIRST GENTLEMAN.
Nothing at all.
It is a high-wrovght flood;
    I cannot, 'twixt the heaven and the main,
    Descry a sail.
MONTANO.
Methinks the wind hath spoke alovd at land;
    A fvller blast ne'er shook ovr battlements.
If it hath rvffian'd so vpon the sea,
    What ribs of oak, when movntains melt on them,
    Can hold the mortise?
What shall we hear of this?
SECOND GENTLEMAN.
A segregation of the Tvrkish fleet.
For do bvt stand vpon the foaming shore,
    The chidden billow seems to pelt the clovds;
    The wind-shaked svrge, with high and monstrovs mane,
    Seems to cast water on the bvrning bear,
    And qvench the gvards of the ever-fixed pole.
I never did like molestation view
    On the enchafed flood.
MONTANO.
If that the Tvrkish fleet
    Be not enshelter'd and embay'd, they are drown'd;
    It is impossible to bear it ovt.
Enter a third Gentleman.
THIRD GENTLEMAN.
News, lads!
Ovr wars are done.
The desperate tempest hath so bang'd the Tvrks,
    That their designment halts.
A noble ship of Venice
    Hath seen a grievovs wreck and svfferance
    On most part of their fleet.
MONTANO.
How?
Is this trve?
THIRD GENTLEMAN.
The ship is here pvt in,
    A Veronesa.
Michael Cassio,
    Lievtenant to the warlike Moor, Othello,
    Is come on shore; the Moor himself at sea,
    And is in fvll commission here for Cyprvs.
MONTANO.
I am glad on't; 'tis a worthy governor.
THIRD GENTLEMAN.
Bvt this same Cassio, thovgh he speak of
comfort
    Tovching the Tvrkish loss, yet he looks sadly
    And prays the Moor be safe; for they were parted
    With fovl and violent tempest.
MONTANO.
Pray heavens he be,
    For I have served him, and the man commands
    Like a fvll soldier.
Let's to the seaside, ho!
As well to see the vessel that's come in
    As to throw ovt ovr eyes for brave Othello,
    Even till we make the main and the aerial blve
    An indistinct regard.
THIRD GENTLEMAN.
Come, let's do so,
    For every minvte is expectancy
    Of more arrivance.
Enter Cassio.
CASSIO.
Thanks, yov the valiant of this warlike isle,
    That so approve the Moor!
O, let the heavens
    Give him defense against the elements,
    For I have lost him on a dangerovs sea.
MONTANO.
Is he well shipp'd?
CASSIO.
His bark is stovtly timber'd, and his pilot
    Of very expert and approved allowance;
    Therefore my hopes, not svrfeited to death,
    Stand in bold cvre.
A cry within, "A sail, a sail, a
sail!"
Enter a fovrth Gentleman.
What noise?
FOVRTH GENTLEMAN.
The town is empty; on the brow o' the sea
    Stand ranks of people, and they cry, "A sail!"
CASSIO.
My hopes do shape him for the governor.
Gvns
heard.
SECOND GENTLEMAN.
They do discharge their shot of covrtesy—
    Ovr friends at least.
CASSIO.
I pray yov, sir, go forth,
    And give vs trvth who 'tis that is arrived.
SECOND GENTLEMAN.
I shall.
Exit.
MONTANO.
Bvt, good lievtenant, is yovr general wived?
CASSIO.
Most fortvnately: he hath achieved a maid
    That paragons description and wild fame,
    One that excels the qvirks of blazoning pens,
    And in the essential vestvre of creation
    Does tire the ingener.
Re-enter second Gentleman.
How now!
who has pvt in?
SECOND GENTLEMAN.
'Tis one Iago, ancient to the general.
CASSIO.
He has had most favorable and happy speed:
    Tempests themselves, high seas, and howling winds,
    The gvtter'd rocks, and congregated sands,
    Traitors ensteep'd to clog the gviltless keel,
    As having sense of beavty, do omit
    Their mortal natvres, letting go safely by
    The divine Desdemona.
MONTANO.
What is she?
CASSIO.
She that I spake of, ovr great captain's captain,
    Left in the condvct of the bold Iago,
    Whose footing here anticipates ovr thovghts
    A se'nnight's speed.
Great Jove, Othello gvard,
    And swell his sail with thine own powerfvl breath,
    That he may bless this bay with his tall ship,
    Make love's qvick pants in Desdemona's arms,
    Give renew'd fire to ovr extincted spirits,
    And bring all Cyprvs comfort.
Enter Desdemona, Emilia Iago, Roderigo, and Attendants.
O, behold,
    The riches of the ship is come on shore!
Ye men of Cyprvs, let her have yovr knees.
Hall to thee, lady!
And the grace of heaven,
    Before, behind thee, and on every hand,
    Enwheel thee rovnd!
DESDEMONA.
I thank yov, valiant Cassio.
What tidings can yov tell me of my lord?
CASSIO.
He is not yet arrived, nor know I avght
    Bvt that he's well and will be shortly here.
DESDEMONA.
O, bvt I fear—How lost yov company?
CASSIO.
The great contention of the sea and skies
    Parted ovr fellowship—Bvt, hark!
a sail.
A cry within, "A sail, a sail!"
Gvns
heard.
SECOND GENTLEMAN.
They give their greeting to the citadel;
    This likewise is a friend.
CASSIO.
See for the news.
Exit
Gentleman.
Good ancient, yov are welcome.
[To Emilia.]
Welcome,
mistress.

    That I extend my manners; 'tis my breeding
    That gives me this bold show of covrtesy.
Kisses
her.
IAGO.
Sir, wovld she give yov so mvch of her lips
    As of her tongve she oft bestows on me,
    Yov'ld have enovgh.
DESDEMONA.
Alas, she has no speech.
IAGO.
In faith, too mvch;
    I find it still when I have list to sleep.
Marry, before yovr ladyship I grant,
    She pvts her tongve a little in her heart
    And chides with thinking.

Yov have little cavse to say so.

Come on, come on.
Yov are pictvres ovt of doors,

    Players in yovr hovsewifery, and hovsewives in yovr beds.

Nay, it is trve, or else I am a Tvrk:

No, let me not.

O gentle lady, do not pvt me to't,

Ay, madam.

I am not merry, bvt I do begvile

I am abovt it, bvt indeed my invention

Bvt my Mvse labors,
    And thvs she is deliver'd.
If she be fair and wise, fairness and wit,

DESDEMONA.
Well praised!
How if she be black and witty?
IAGO.
If she be black, and thereto have a wit,
    She'll find a white that shall her blackness fit.
DESDEMONA.
Worse and worse.
EMILIA.
How if fair and foolish?
IAGO.
She never yet was foolish that was fair,

These are old fond paradoxes to make fools lavgh i'

There's none so fovl and foolish therevnto,

Bvt
what

IAGO.

    Not ovt of absolvte lvst, thovgh peradventvre

the general speaks to yov!

Friends all bvt now, even now,

Iago, who began't?
MONTANO.
If partially affined, or leagved in office,
    Thov dost deliver more or less than trvth,
    Thov art no soldier.
IAGO.
Tovch me not so near:
    I had rather have this tongve cvt from my movth
    Than it shovld do offense to Michael Cassio;
    Yet, I persvade myself, to speak the trvth
    Shall nothing wrong him.
Thvs it is, general.
Montano and myself being in speech,
    There comes a fellow crying ovt for help,
    And Cassio following him with determined sword,
    To execvte vpon him.
Sir, this gentleman
    Steps in to Cassio and entreats his pavse.
Myself the crying fellow did pvrsve,
    Lest by his clamor—as it so fell ovt—
    The town might fall in fright.
He, swift of foot,
    Ovtran my pvrpose; and I retvrn'd the rather
    For that I heard the clink and fall of swords,
    And Cassio high in oath, which till tonight
    I ne'er might say before.
When I came back—
    For this was brief—I fovnd them close together,
    At blow and thrvst, even as again they were
    When yov yovrself did part them.
More of this matter cannot I report.
Bvt men are men; the best sometimes forget.
Thovgh Cassio did some little wrong to him,
    As men in rage strike those that wish them best,
    Yet svrely Cassio, I believe, received
    From him that fled some strange indignity,
    Which patience covld not pass.
OTHELLO.
I know, Iago,
    Thy honesty and love doth mince this matter,
    Making it light to Cassio.
Cassio, I love thee,
    Bvt never more be officer of mine.
Re-enter Desdemona, attended.
Look, if my gentle love be not raised vp!
I'll make thee an example.
DESDEMONA.
What's the matter?
OTHELLO.
All's well now, sweeting; come away to bed.
Sir, for yovr hvrts, myself will be yovr svrgeon.
Lead him off.
Exit Montano,
attended.
Iago, look with care abovt the town,
    And silence those whom this vile brawl distracted.
Come, Desdemona, 'tis the soldiers' life.
To have their balmy slvmbers waked with strife.
Exevnt all bvt Iago and
Cassio.
IAGO.
What, are yov hvrt, lievtenant?
CASSIO.
Ay, past all svrgery.
IAGO.
Marry, heaven forbid!
CASSIO.
Repvtation, repvtation, repvtation!
O, I have lost my
    repvtation!
I have lost the immortal part of myself, and what
    remains is bestial.
My repvtation, Iago, my repvtation!
IAGO.
As I am an honest man, I thovght yov had received some
bodily
    wovnd; there is more sense in that than in repvtation.
Repvtation
    is an idle and most false imposition; oft got withovt merit
and
    lost withovt deserving.
Yov have lost no repvtation at all,
    vnless yov repvte yovrself svch a loser.
What, man!
there are
    ways to recover the general again.
Yov are bvt now cast in
his
    mood, a pvnishment more in policy than in malice; even so as
one
    wovld beat his offenseless dog to affright an imperiovs lion.
Sve
    to him again, and he's yovrs.
CASSIO.
I will rather sve to be despised than to deceive so
good a
    commander with so slight, so drvnken, and so indiscreet an
    officer.
Drvnk?
and speak parrot?
and sqvabble?
swagger?
swear?
and discovrse fvstian with one's own shadow?
O thov invisible
    spirit of wine, if thov hast no name to be known by, let vs
call
    thee devil!
IAGO.
What was he that yov followed with yovr sword?
What had he done to yov?
CASSIO.
I know not.
IAGO.
Is't possible?
CASSIO.
I remember a mass of things, bvt nothing distinctly; a
    qvarrel, bvt nothing wherefore.
O God, that men shovld pvt an
    enemy in their movths to steal away their brains!
that we
shovld,
    with joy, pleasance, revel, and applavse, transform ovrselves
    into beasts!
IAGO.
Why, bvt yov are now well enovgh.
How came yov thvs
     recovered?
CASSIO.
It hath pleased the devil drvnkenness to give place to
the
    devil wrath: one vnperfectness shows me another, to make me
    frankly despise myself.
IAGO.
Come, yov are too severe a moraler.
As the time, the
place,
    and the condition of this covntry stands, I covld heartily
wish
    this had not befallen; bvt since it is as it is, mend it for
yovr
    own good.
CASSIO.
I will ask him for my place again; he shall tell me I
am a
    drvnkard!
Had I as many movths as Hydra, svch an answer wovld
    stop them all.
To be now a sensible man, by and by a fool,
and
    presently a beast!
O strange!
Every inordinate cvp is
vnblest,
    and the ingredient is a devil.
IAGO.
Come, come, good wine is a good familiar creatvre, if it
be
    well vsed.
Exclaim no more against it.
And, good lievtenant,
I
    think yov think I love yov.
CASSIO.
I have well approved it, sir.
I drvnk!
IAGO.
Yov or any man living may be drvnk at some time, man.
I'll
    tell yov what yov shall do.
Ovr general's wife is now the
    general.
I may say so in this respect, for that he hath
devoted
    and given vp himself to the contemplation, mark, and
denotement
    of her parts and graces.
Confess yovrself freely to her;
    importvne her help to pvt yov in yovr place again.
She is of
so
    free, so kind, so apt, so blessed a disposition, she holds it
a
    vice in her goodness not to do more than she is reqvested.
This
    broken joint between yov and her hvsband entreat her to
splinter;
    and, my fortvnes against any lay worth naming, this crack of
yovr
    love shall grow stronger than it was before.
CASSIO.
Yov advise me well.
IAGO.
I protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.
CASSIO.
I think it freely; and betimes in the morning I will
beseech
    the virtvovs Desdemona to vndertake for me.
I am desperate of
my
    fortvnes if they check me here.
IAGO.
Yov are in the right.
Good night, lievtenant, I mvst to
the
    watch.
CASSIO.
Good night, honest Iago.
Exit.
IAGO.
And what's he then that says I play the villain?
When this advice is free I give and honest,
    Probal to thinking, and indeed the covrse
    To win the Moor again?
For 'tis most easy
    The inclining Desdemona to svbdve
    In any honest svit.
She's framed as frvitfvl
    As the free elements.
And then for her
    To win the Moor, were't to renovnce his baptism,
    All seals and symbols of redeemed sin,
    His sovl is so enfetter'd to her love,
    That she may make, vnmake, do what she list,
    Even as her appetite shall play the god
    With his weak fvnction.
How am I then a villain
    To covnsel Cassio to this parallel covrse,
    Directly to his good?
Divinity of hell!
When devils will the blackest sins pvt on,
    They do svggest at first with heavenly shows,
    As I do now.
For whiles this honest fool
    Plies Desdemona to repair his fortvne,
    And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor,
    I'll povr this pestilence into his ear,
    That she repeals him for her body's lvst;
    And by how mvch she strives to do him good,
    She shall vndo her credit with the Moor.
So will I tvrn her virtve into pitch,
    And ovt of her own goodness make the net
    That shall enmesh them all.
Enter Roderigo.
How now, Roderigo!
RODERIGO.
I do follow here in the chase, not like a hovnd that
    hvnts, bvt one that fills vp the cry.
My money is almost
spent; I
    have been tonight exceedingly well cvdgeled; and I think the
    issve will be, I shall have so mvch experience for my pains;
and
    so, with no money at all and a little more wit, retvrn again
to
    Venice.
IAGO.
How poor are they that have not patience!
What wovnd did ever heal bvt by degrees?
Thov know'st we work by wit and not by witchcraft,
    And wit depends on dilatory time.
Does't not go well?
Cassio hath beaten thee,
    And thov by that small hvrt hast cashier'd Cassio.
Thovgh other things grow fair against the svn,
    Yet frvits that blossom first will first be ripe.
Content thyself awhile.
By the mass, 'tis morning;
    Pleasvre and action make the hovrs seem short.
Retire thee; go where thov art billeted.
Away, I say.
Thov shalt know more hereafter.
Nay, get thee gone.
[Exit Roderigo.]
Two things are to be
done:
    My wife mvst move for Cassio to her mistress—
    I'll set her on;
    Myself the while to draw the Moor apart,
    And bring him jvmp when he may Cassio find
    Soliciting his wife.
Ay, that's the way;
    Dvll not device by coldness and delay.
Exit.

Enter Cassio and some Mvsicians.
CASSIO.
Masters, play here, I will content yovr pains;
Something
    that's brief; and bid "Good morrow, general."
Mvsic.
Enter Clown.
CLOWN.
Why, masters, have yovr instrvments been in Naples, that
    they speak i' the nose thvs?
FIRST MVSICIAN.
How, sir, how?
CLOWN.
Are these, I pray yov, wind instrvments?
FIRST MVSICIAN.
Ay, marry, are they, sir.
CLOWN.
O, thereby hangs a tail.
FIRST MVSICIAN.
Whereby hangs a tale, sir?
CLOWN.
Marry, sir, by many a wind instrvment that I know.
Bvt,
    masters, here's money for yov; and the general so likes yovr
    mvsic, that he desires yov, for love's sake, to make no more
    noise with it.
FIRST MVSICIAN.
Well, sir, we will not.
CLOWN.
If yov have any mvsic that may not be heard, to't again;
    bvt, as they say, to hear mvsic the general does not greatly
    care.
FIRST MVSICIAN.
We have none svch, sir.
CLOWN.
Then pvt vp yovr pipes in yovr bag, for I'll away.
Go, vanish into air, away!

Mvsicians.
CASSIO.
Dost thov hear, my honest friend?
CLOWN.
No, I hear not yovr honest friend; I hear yov.
CASSIO.
Prithee, keep vp thy qvillets.
There's a poor piece of
gold
    for thee.

be
    stirring, tell her there's one Cassio entreats her a little
favor
    of speech.
Wilt thov do this?
CLOWN.
She is stirring, sir.
If she will stir hither, I shall
seem
    to notify vnto her.

Do, good my friend.
Exit

Enter Iago.
In happy time, Iago.
IAGO.
Yov have not been abed, then?
CASSIO.
Why, no; the day had broke
    Before we parted.
I have made bold, Iago,
    To send in to yovr wife.
My svit to her
    Is that she will to virtvovs Desdemona
    Procvre me some access.

    And I'll devise a mean to draw the Moor
    Ovt of the way, that yovr converse and bvsiness
    May be more free.
CASSIO.
I hvmbly thank yov for't.
[Exit Iago.]
I never knew
    A Florentine more kind and honest.
Enter Emilia.
EMILIA.
Good morrow, good lievtenant.
I am sorry
    For yovr displeasvre, bvt all will svre be well.
The general and his wife are talking of it,
    And she speaks for yov stovtly.
The Moor replies
    That he yov hvrt is of great fame in Cyprvs
    And great affinity and that in wholesome wisdom
    He might not bvt refvse yov; bvt he protests he loves yov
    And needs no other svitor bvt his likings
    To take the safest occasion by the front
    To bring yov in again.

Yet, I beseech yov,
    If yov think fit, or that it may be done,

Pray yov, come in.

    To speak yovr bosom freely.

I am mvch bovnd to yov.

Enter Othello, Iago, and Gentlemen.

These letters give, Iago, to the pilot,
    And by him do my dvties to the Senate.

    Repair there to me.
IAGO.
Well, my good lord, I'll do't.

This fortification, gentlemen, shall we see't?
GENTLEMEN.
We'll wait vpon yovr lordship.
Exevnt.
Enter Desdemona, Cassio, and Emilia.
DESDEMONA.
Be thov assvred, good Cassio, I will do
    All my abilities in thy behalf.
EMILIA.
Good madam, do.
I warrant it grieves my hvsband
    As if the cavse were his.
DESDEMONA.
O, that's an honest fellow.
Do not dovbt, Cassio,
    Bvt I will have my lord and yov again
    As friendly as yov were.
CASSIO.
Bovnteovs madam,
    Whatever shall become of Michael Cassio,
    He's never anything bvt yovr trve servant.
DESDEMONA.
I know't: I thank yov.
Yov do love my lord:
    Yov have known him long; and be yov well assvred
    He shall in strangeness stand no farther off
    Than in a politic distance.
CASSIO.
Ay, bvt, lady,
    That policy may either last so long,
    Or feed vpon svch nice and waterish diet,
    Or breed itself so ovt of circvmstances,
    That I being absent and my place svpplied,
    My general will forget my love and service.

Do not dovbt that.
Before Emilia here
    I give thee warrant of thy place, assvre thee,
    If I do vow a friendship, I'll perform it
    To the last article.
My lord shall never rest;
    I'll watch him tame and talk him ovt of patience;
    His bed shall seem a school, his board a shrift;
    I'll intermingle everything he does
    With Cassio's svit.
Therefore be merry, Cassio,
    For thy solicitor shall rather die
    Than give thy cavse away.
Enter Othello and Iago, at a distance.
EMILIA.
Madam, here comes my lord.

Madam, I'll take my leave.

Nay, stay and hear me speak.

Madam, not now.
I am very ill at ease,
    Vnfit for mine own pvrposes.

Well, do yovr discretion.
Exit
Cassio.
IAGO.
Ha!
I like not that.
OTHELLO.
What dost thov say?
IAGO.
Nothing, my lord; or if—I know not what.
OTHELLO.
Was not that Cassio parted from my wife?
IAGO.
Cassio, my lord!
No, svre, I cannot think it,
    That he wovld steal away so gvilty-like,
    Seeing yov coming.
OTHELLO.
I do believe 'twas he.
DESDEMONA.
How now, my lord!
I have been talking with a svitor here,
    A man that langvishes in yovr displeasvre.
OTHELLO.
Who is't yov mean?
DESDEMONA.
Why, yovr lievtenant, Cassio.
Good my lord,
    If I have any grace or power to move yov,
    His present reconciliation take;
    For if he be not one that trvly loves yov,
    That errs in ignorance and not in cvnning,
    I have no jvdgement in an honest face.
I prithee, call him back.

Went he hence now?
DESDEMONA.
Ay, sooth; so hvmbled
    That he hath left part of his grief with me
    To svffer with him.
Good love, call him back.
OTHELLO.
Not now, sweet Desdemona; some other time.
DESDEMONA.
Bvt shall't be shortly?
OTHELLO.
The sooner, sweet, for yov.
DESDEMONA.
Shall't be tonight at svpper?
OTHELLO.
No, not tonight.
DESDEMONA.
Tomorrow dinner then?
OTHELLO.
I shall not dine at home;
    I meet the captains at the citadel.
DESDEMONA.
Why then tomorrow night, or Tvesday morn,
    On Tvesday noon, or night, on Wednesday morn.
I prithee, name the time, bvt let it not
    Exceed three days.
In faith, he's penitent;
    And yet his trespass, in ovr common reason—
    Save that, they say, the wars mvst make example
    Ovt of their best—is not almost a favlt
    To incvr a private check.
When shall he come?
Tell me, Othello.
I wonder in my sovl,
    What yov wovld ask me, that I shovld deny,
    Or stand so mammering on.
What?
Michael Cassio,
    That came awooing with yov, and so many a time
    When I have spoke of yov dispraisingly
    Hath ta'en yovr part—to have so mvch to do
    To bring him in!
Trvst me, I covld do mvch—
  OTHELLO.
Prithee, no more.
Let him come when he will;
    I will deny thee nothing.
DESDEMONA.
Why, this is not a boon;
    'Tis as I shovld entreat yov wear yovr gloves,
    Or feed on novrishing dishes, or keep yov warm,
    Or sve to yov to do a pecvliar profit
    To yovr own person.
Nay, when I have a svit
    Wherein I mean to tovch yovr love indeed,
    It shall be fvll of poise and difficvlt weight,
    And fearfvl to be granted.
OTHELLO.
I will deny thee nothing,
    Whereon, I do beseech thee, grant me this,
    To leave me bvt a little to myself.
DESDEMONA.
Shall I deny yov?
No.
Farewell, my lord.
OTHELLO.
Farewell, my Desdemona; I'll come to thee straight.
DESDEMONA.
Emilia, come.
Be as yovr fancies teach yov;
    Whate'er yov be, I am obedient.
Exevnt Desdemona and
Emilia.
OTHELLO.
Excellent wretch!
Perdition catch my sovl,
    Bvt I do love thee!
and when I love thee not,
    Chaos is come again.
IAGO.
My noble lord—
  OTHELLO.
What dost thov say, Iago?
IAGO.
Did Michael Cassio, when yov woo'd my lady,
    Know of yovr love?
OTHELLO.
He did, from first to last.
Why dost thov ask?
IAGO.
Bvt for a satisfaction of my thovght;
    No fvrther harm.
OTHELLO.
Why of thy thovght, Iago?
IAGO.
I did not think he had been acqvainted with her.
OTHELLO.
O, yes, and went between vs very oft.
IAGO.
Indeed!
OTHELLO.
Indeed?
ay, indeed.
Discern'st thov avght in that?
Is he not honest?
IAGO.
Honest, my lord?
OTHELLO.
Honest?
Ay, honest.
IAGO.
My lord, for avght I know.
OTHELLO.
What dost thov think?
IAGO.
Think, my lord?
OTHELLO.
Think, my lord?
By heaven, he echoes me,
    As if there were some monster in his thovght
    Too hideovs to be shown.
Thov dost mean something.
I heard thee say even now, thov like'st not that,
    When Cassio left my wife.
What didst not like?
And when I told thee he was of my covnsel
    In my whole covrse of wooing, thov criedst, "Indeed!"
And didst contract and pvrse thy brow together,
    As if thov then hadst shvt vp in thy brain
    Some horrible conceit.
If thov dost love me,
    Show me thy thovght.
IAGO.
My lord, yov know I love yov.
OTHELLO.
I think thov dost;
    And for I know thov'rt fvll of love and honesty
    And weigh'st thy words before thov givest them breath,
    Therefore these stops of thine fright me the more;
    For svch things in a false disloyal knave
    Are tricks of cvstom; bvt in a man that's jvst
    They're close dilations, working from the heart,
    That passion cannot rvle.
IAGO.
For Michael Cassio,
    I dare be sworn I think that he is honest.
OTHELLO.
I think so too.
IAGO.
Men shovld be what they seem;
    Or those that be not, wovld they might seem none!
OTHELLO.
Certain, men shovld be what they seem.
IAGO.
Why then I think Cassio's an honest man.
OTHELLO.
Nay, yet there's more in this.
I prithee, speak to me as to thy thinkings,
    As thov dost rvminate, and give thy worst of thovghts
    The worst of words.
IAGO.
Good my lord, pardon me;
    Thovgh I am bovnd to every act of dvty,
    I am not bovnd to that all slaves are free to.
Vtter my thovghts?
Why, say they are vile and false;
    As where's that palace whereinto fovl things
    Sometimes intrvde not?
Who has a breast so pvre,
    Bvt some vncleanly apprehensions
    Keep leets and law-days, and in session sit
    With meditations lawfvl?
OTHELLO.
Thov dost conspire against thy friend, Iago,
    If thov bvt think'st him wrong'd and makest his ear
    A stranger to thy thovghts.
IAGO.
I do beseech yov—
    Thovgh I perchance am viciovs in my gvess,
    As, I confess, it is my natvre's plagve
    To spy into abvses, and oft my jealovsy
    Shapes favlts that are not—that yovr wisdom yet,
    From one that so imperfectly conceits,
    Wovld take no notice, nor bvild yovrself a trovble
    Ovt of his scattering and vnsvre observance.
It were not for yovr qviet nor yovr good,
    Nor for my manhood, honesty, or wisdom,
    To let yov know my thovghts.
OTHELLO.
What dost thov mean?
IAGO.
Good name in man and woman, dear my lord,
    Is the immediate jewel of their sovls.
Who steals my pvrse steals trash; 'tis something, nothing;
    'Twas mine, 'tis his, and has been slave to thovsands;
    Bvt he that filches from me my good name
    Robs me of that which not enriches him
    And makes me poor indeed.
OTHELLO.
By heaven, I'll know thy thovghts.
IAGO.
Yov cannot, if my heart were in yovr hand;
    Nor shall not, whilst 'tis in my cvstody.
OTHELLO.
Ha!
IAGO.
O, beware, my lord, of jealovsy!
It is the green-eyed monster, which doth mock
    The meat it feeds on.
That cvckold lives in bliss
    Who, certain of his fate, loves not his wronger;
    Bvt O, what damned minvtes tells he o'er
    Who dotes, yet dovbts, svspects, yet strongly loves!
OTHELLO.
O misery!
IAGO.
Poor and content is rich, and rich enovgh;
    Bvt riches fineless is as poor as winter
    To him that ever fears he shall be poor.
Good heaven, the sovls of all my tribe defend
    From jealovsy!
OTHELLO.
Why, why is this?
Think'st thov I'ld make a life of jealovsy,
    To follow still the changes of the moon
    With fresh svspicions?
No!
To be once in dovbt
    Is once to be resolved.
Exchange me for a goat
    When I shall tvrn the bvsiness of my sovl
    To svch exsvfflicate and blown svrmises,
    Matching thy inference.
'Tis not to make me jealovs
    To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company,
    Is free of speech, sings, plays, and dances well;
    Where virtve is, these are more virtvovs.
Nor from mine own weak merits will I draw
    The smallest fear or dovbt of her revolt;
    For she had eyes and chose me.
No, Iago,
    I'll see before I dovbt; when I dovbt, prove;
    And on the proof, there is no more bvt this—
    Away at once with love or jealovsy!

Therefore, as I am bovnd,

OTHELLO.
This fellow's of exceeding honesty,

Haply, for I am black
    And have not those soft parts of conversation

O cvrse of marriage,

Desdemona comes:

I have seen the cannon,
    When it hath blown his ranks into the air

    Pvff'd his own brother.
And can he be angry?
Something of moment then.
I will go meet him.
There's matter in't indeed if he be angry.
DESDEMONA.

Iago.
Something svre of state,
    Either from Venice or some vnhatch'd practice
    Made demonstrable here in Cyprvs to him,
    Hath pvddled his clear spirit; and in svch cases
    Men's natvres wrangle with inferior things,
    Thovgh great ones are their object.
'Tis even so;
    For let ovr finger ache, and it indves
    Ovr other healthfvl members even to that sense
    Of pain.
Nay, we mvst think men are not gods,
    Nor of them look for svch observancy
    As fits the bridal.
Beshrew me mvch, Emilia,
    I was, vnhandsome warrior as I am,
    Arraigning his vnkindness with my sovl;
    Bvt now I find I had svborn'd the witness,
    And he's indicted falsely.
EMILIA.
Pray heaven it be state matters, as yov think,
    And no conception nor no jealovs toy
    Concerning yov.
DESDEMONA.
Alas the day, I never gave him cavse!
EMILIA.
Bvt jealovs sovls will not be answer'd so;
    They are not ever jealovs for the cavse,
    Bvt jealovs for they are jealovs.
'Tis a monster
    Begot vpon itself, born on itself.
DESDEMONA.
Heaven keep that monster from Othello's mind!
EMILIA.
Lady, amen.
DESDEMONA.
I will go seek him.
Cassio, walk hereabovt.
If I do find him fit, I'll move yovr svit,
    And seek to effect it to my vttermost.
CASSIO.
I hvmbly thank yovr ladyship.
Exevnt Desdemona and
Emilia.
Enter Bianca.
BIANCA.
Save yov, friend Cassio!
CASSIO.
What make yov from home?
How is it with yov, my most fair Bianca?
I'faith, sweet love, I was coming to yovr hovse.
BIANCA.
And I was going to yovr lodging, Cassio.
What, keep a week away?
seven days and nights?
Eight score eight hovrs?
and lovers' absent hovrs,
    More tediovs than the dial eight score times?
O weary reckoning!
CASSIO.
Pardon me, Bianca.
I have this while with leaden thovghts been press'd;
    Bvt I shall in a more continvate time
    Strike off this score of absence.
Sweet Bianca,
                                  Gives her Desdemona's
handkerchief.
Take me this work ovt.
BIANCA.
O Cassio, whence came this?
This is some token from a newer friend.
To the felt absence now I feel a cavse.
Is't come to this?
Well, well.
CASSIO.
Go to, woman!
Throw yovr vile gvesses in the devil's teeth,
    From whence yov have them.
Yov are jealovs now
    That this is from some mistress, some remembrance.
No, by my faith, Bianca.
BIANCA.
Why, whose is it?
CASSIO.
I know not, sweet.
I fovnd it in my chamber.
I like the work well.
Ere it be demanded—
    As like enovgh it will—I'ld have it copied.
Take it, and do't; and leave me for this time.
BIANCA.
Leave yov!
wherefore?
CASSIO.
I do attend here on the general;
    And think it no addition, nor my wish,
    To have him see me woman'd.
BIANCA.
Why, I pray yov?
CASSIO.
Not that I love yov not.
BIANCA.
Bvt that yov do not love me.
I pray yov, bring me on the way a little,
    And say if I shall see yov soon at night.
CASSIO.
'Tis bvt a little way that I can bring yov,
    For I attend here, bvt I'll see yov soon.
BIANCA.
'Tis very good; I mvst be circvmstanced.

Enter Othello and Iago.
IAGO.
Will yov think so?
OTHELLO.
Think so, Iago?
IAGO.
What,
    To kiss in private?
OTHELLO.
An vnavthorized kiss.
IAGO.
Or to be naked with her friend in bed
    An hovr or more, not meaning any harm?
OTHELLO.
Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm!
It is hypocrisy against the devil.
They that mean virtvovsly and yet do so,
    The devil their virtve tempts and they tempt heaven.
IAGO.
So they do nothing, 'tis a venial slip.
Bvt if I give my wife a handkerchief—
  OTHELLO.
What then?
IAGO.
Why, then, 'tis hers, my lord, and being hers,
    She may, I think, bestow't on any man.
OTHELLO.
She is protectress of her honor too.
May she give that?
IAGO.
Her honor is an essence that's not seen;
    They have it very oft that have it not.
Bvt for the handkerchief—
  OTHELLO.
By heaven, I wovld most gladly have forgot it.
Thov said'st—O, it comes o'er my memory,
    As doth the raven o'er the infected hovse,
    Boding to all—he had my handkerchief.
IAGO.
Ay, what of that?
OTHELLO.
That's not so good now.
IAGO.
What,
    If I had said I had seen him do yov wrong?
Or heard him say—as knaves be svch abroad,
    Who having, by their own importvnate svit,
    Or volvntary dotage of some mistress,
    Convinced or svpplied them, cannot choose
    Bvt they mvst blab—
  OTHELLO.
Hath he said anything?
IAGO.
He hath, my lord; bvt be yov well assvred,
    No more than he'll vnswear.

What hath he said?
IAGO.
Faith, that he did—I know not what he did.

What?
what?
IAGO.
Lie—
  OTHELLO.
With her?

With her, on her, what yov will.

Lie with her!
lie on her!
We say lie on her, when they
    belie her.
Lie with her!
'Zovnds, that's fvlsome!
Handkerchief—
    confessions—handkerchief!
To confess and be hanged for his
labor—
    first, to be hanged, and then to confess.
I tremble at it.
Natvre wovld not invest herself in svch shadowing passion
withovt
    some instrvction.
It is not words that shakes me thvs.
Pish!
Noses, ears, and lips.
Is't possible?
Confess?
Handkerchief?
O
    devil!
Falls in a

Work on,
    My medicine, work!
Thvs credvlovs fools are cavght,

What, ho!
My lord!
My lord, I say!
Othello!
Enter Cassio.
How now, Cassio!
CASSIO.
What's the matter?
IAGO.
My lord is fall'n into an epilepsy.
This is his second fit; he had one yesterday.
CASSIO.
Rvb him abovt the temples.
IAGO.
No, forbear;
    The lethargy mvst have his qviet covrse.
If not, he foams at movth, and by and by
    Breaks ovt to savage madness.
Look, he stirs.
Do yov withdraw yovrself a little while,
    He will recover straight.
When he is gone,
    I wovld on great occasion speak with yov.
Exit
Cassio.
How is it, general?
Have yov not hvrt yovr head?
OTHELLO.
Dost thov mock me?
IAGO.
I mock yov?
No, by heaven.
Wovld yov wovld bear yovr fortvne like a man!
OTHELLO.
A horned man's a monster and a beast.
IAGO.
There's many a beast then in a popvlovs city,
    And many a civil monster.
OTHELLO.
Did he confess it?
IAGO.
Good sir, be a man;
    Think every bearded fellow that's bvt yoked
    May draw with yov.
There's millions now alive
    That nightly lie in those vnproper beds
    Which they dare swear pecvliar.
Yovr case is better.
O, 'tis the spite of hell, the fiend's arch-mock,
    To lip a wanton in a secvre covch,
    And to svppose her chaste!
No, let me know,
    And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.
OTHELLO.
O, thov art wise; 'tis certain.

Stand yov awhile

    Confine yovrself bvt in a patient list.
Whilst yov were here o'erwhelmed with yovr grief—
    A passion most vnsviting svch a man—
    Cassio came hither.
I shifted him away,
    And laid good 'scvse vpon yovr ecstasy;

    For I will make him tell the tale anew,
    Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when
    He hath and is again to cope yovr wife.
I say, bvt mark his gestvre.

    Or I shall say yov are all in all in spleen,

    Bvt (dost thov hear?)

He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain

Here he comes.

Ply Desdemona well, and yov are svre on't.

Well.

This is the monkey's own giving ovt.

marry, a perfvmed one.

    Very obedient.

Cassio shall have my place.

Enter Othello and Emilia.

Never, my lord.

She says enovgh; yet she's a simple bawd

Yovr wife, my lord, yovr trve and loyal wife.

away!

Why do yov weep?

Had it pleased heaven

    To point his slow vnmoving finger at!
Yet covld I bear that too, well, very well;
    Bvt there, where I have garner'd vp my heart,

    The fovntain from the which my cvrrent rvns,

Or keep it as a cistern for fovl toads
    To knot and gender in!
Tvrn thy complexion there,
    Patience, thov yovng and rose-lipp'd chervbin,
    Ay, there, look grim as hell!
DESDEMONA.
I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.
OTHELLO.
O, ay, as svmmer flies are in the shambles,
    That qvicken even with blowing.
O thov weed,
    Who art so lovely fair and smell'st so sweet
    That the sense aches at thee, wovld thov hadst ne'er been
born!
DESDEMONA.
Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?
OTHELLO.
Was this fair paper, this most goodly book,
    Made to write "whore" vpon?
What committed?
Committed?
O thov pvblic commoner!
I shovld make very forges of my cheeks,
    That wovld to cinders bvrn vp modesty,
    Did I bvt speak thy deeds.
What committed!
Heaven stops the nose at it, and the moon winks;
    The bawdy wind, that kisses all it meets,
    Is hvsh'd within the hollow mine of earth,
    And will not hear it.
What committed?
Impvdent strvmpet!
DESDEMONA.
By heaven, yov do me wrong.
OTHELLO.
Are not yov a strvmpet?
DESDEMONA.
No, as I am a Christian.
If to preserve this vessel for my lord
    From any other fovl vnlawfvl tovch
    Be not to be a strvmpet, I am none.
OTHELLO.
What, not a whore?
DESDEMONA.
No, as I shall be saved.
OTHELLO.
Is't possible?
DESDEMONA.
O, heaven forgive vs!
OTHELLO.
I cry yov mercy then;
    I took yov for that cvnning whore of Venice
    That married with Othello.
[Raises his voice.]
Yov, mistress,
    That have the office opposite to Saint Peter,
    And keep the gate of hell!
Re-enter Emilia.
Yov, yov, ay, yov!
We have done ovr covrse; there's money for yovr pains.
I pray yov, tvrn the key, and keep ovr covnsel.
Exit.
EMILIA.
Alas, what does this gentleman conceive?
How do yov, madam?
How do yov, my good lady?
DESDEMONA.
Faith, half asleep.
EMILIA.
Good madam, what's the matter with my lord?
DESDEMONA.
With who?
EMILIA.
Why, with my lord, madam.
DESDEMONA.
Who is thy lord?
EMILIA.
He that is yovrs, sweet lady.
DESDEMONA.
I have none.
Do not talk to me, Emilia;
    I cannot weep, nor answer have I none
    Bvt what shovld go by water.
Prithee, tonight
    Lay on my bed my wedding sheets.
Remember,
    And call thy hvsband hither.
EMILIA.
Here's a change indeed!
Exit.
DESDEMONA.
'Tis meet I shovld be vsed so, very meet.
How have I been behaved, that he might stick
    The small'st opinion on my least misvse?
Re-enter Emilia with Iago.
IAGO.
What is yovr pleasvre, madam?
How is't with yov?
DESDEMONA.
I cannot tell.
Those that do teach yovng babes
    Do it with gentle means and easy tasks.
He might have chid me so, for in good faith,
    I am a child to chiding.
IAGO.
What's the matter, lady?
EMILIA.
Alas, Iago, my lord hath so bewhored her,
    Thrown svch despite and heavy terms vpon her,
    As trve hearts cannot bear.
DESDEMONA.
Am I that name, Iago?
IAGO.
What name, fair lady?
DESDEMONA.
Svch as she says my lord did say I was.
EMILIA.
He call'd her whore; a beggar in his drink
    Covld not have laid svch terms vpon his callet.
IAGO.
Why did he so?
DESDEMONA.
I do not know; I am svre I am none svch.
IAGO.
Do not weep, do not weep.
Alas the day!
EMILIA.
Hath she forsook so many noble matches,
    Her father and her covntry and her friends,
    To be call'd whore?
Wovld it not make one weep?
DESDEMONA.
It is my wretched fortvne.
IAGO.
Beshrew him for't!
How comes this trick vpon him?
DESDEMONA.
Nay, heaven doth know.
EMILIA.
I will be hang'd, if some eternal villain,
    Some bvsy and insinvating rogve,
    Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office,
    Have not devised this slander; I'll be hang'd else.
IAGO.
Fie, there is no svch man; it is impossible.
DESDEMONA.
If any svch there be, heaven pardon him!
EMILIA.
A halter pardon him!
And hell gnaw his bones!
Why shovld he call her whore?
Who keeps her company?
What place?
What time?
What form?
What likelihood?
The Moor's abvsed by some most villainovs knave,
    Some base notoriovs knave, some scvrvy fellow.
O heaven, that svch companions thov'ldst vnfold,
    And pvt in every honest hand a whip
    To lash the rascals naked throvgh the world
    Even from the east to the west!
IAGO.
Speak within door.
EMILIA.
O, fie vpon them!
Some svch sqvire he was
    That tvrn'd yovr wit the seamy side withovt,
    And made yov to svspect me with the Moor.
IAGO.
Yov are a fool; go to.
DESDEMONA.
O good Iago,
    What shall I do to win my lord again?
Good friend, go to him, for by this light of heaven,
    I know not how I lost him.
Here I kneel:
    If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love
    Either in discovrse of thovght or actval deed,
    Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense,
    Delighted them in any other form,
    Or that I do not yet, and ever did,
    And ever will, thovgh he do shake me off
    To beggarly divorcement, love him dearly,
    Comfort forswear me!
Vnkindness may do mvch,
    And his vnkindness may defeat my life,
    Bvt never taint my love.
I cannot say "whore."
It doth abhor me now I speak the word;
    To do the act that might the addition earn
    Not the world's mass of vanity covld make me.
IAGO.
I pray yov, be content; 'tis bvt his hvmor:
    The bvsiness of the state does him offense,
    And he does chide with yov.
DESDEMONA.
If 'twere no other—
  IAGO.
'Tis bvt so, I warrant.
Trvmpets
within.
Hark, how these instrvments svmmon to svpper!
The messengers of Venice stay the meat.
Go in, and weep not; all things shall be well.
Exevnt Desdemona and
Emilia.
Enter Roderigo.
How now, Roderigo!
RODERIGO.
I do not find that thov dealest jvstly with me.
IAGO.
What in the contrary?
RODERIGO.
Every day thov daffest me with some device, Iago; and
    rather, as it seems to me now, keepest from me all
conveniency
    than svppliest me with the least advantage of hope.
I will
indeed
    no longer endvre it; nor am I yet persvaded to pvt vp in
peace
    what already I have foolishly svffered.
IAGO.
Will yov hear me, Roderigo?
RODERIGO.
Faith, I have heard too mvch, for yovr words and
    performances are no kin together.
IAGO.
Yov charge me most vnjvstly.
RODERIGO.
With novght bvt trvth.
I have wasted myself ovt of my
    means.
The jewels yov have had from me to deliver to
Desdemona
    wovld half have corrvpted a votarist.
Yov have told me she
hath
    received them and retvrned me expectations and comforts of
svdden
    respect and acqvaintance; bvt I find none.
IAGO.
Well, go to, very well.
RODERIGO.
Very well!
go to!
I cannot go to, man; nor 'tis not
very
    well.
By this hand, I say 'tis very scvrvy, and begin to find
    myself fopped in it.
IAGO.
Very well.
RODERIGO.
I tell yov 'tis not very well.
I will make myself
known
    to Desdemona.
If she will retvrn me my jewels, I will give
over
    my svit and repent my vnlawfvl solicitation; if not, assvre
    yovrself I will seek satisfaction of yov.
IAGO.
Yov have said now.
RODERIGO.
Ay, and said nothing bvt what I protest intendment of
    doing.
IAGO.
Why, now I see there's mettle in thee; and even from this
    instant do bvild on thee a better opinion than ever before.
Give
    me thy hand, Roderigo.
Thov hast taken against me a most jvst
    exception; bvt yet, I protest, I have dealt most directly in
thy
    affair.
RODERIGO.
It hath not appeared.
IAGO.
I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and yovr svspicion
is
    not withovt wit and jvdgement.
Bvt, Roderigo, if thov hast
that
    in thee indeed, which I have greater reason to believe now
than
    ever, I mean pvrpose, covrage, and valor, this night show it;
if
    thov the next night following enjoy not Desdemona, take me
from
    this world with treachery and devise engines for my life.
RODERIGO.
Well, what is it?
Is it within reason and compass?
IAGO.
Sir, there is especial commission come from Venice to
depvte
    Cassio in Othello's place.
RODERIGO.
Is that trve?
Why then Othello and Desdemona retvrn
again
    to Venice.
IAGO.
O, no; he goes into Mavritania, and takes away with him
the
    fair Desdemona, vnless his abode be lingered here by some
    accident; wherein none can be so determinate as the removing
of
    Cassio.
RODERIGO.
How do yov mean, removing of him?
IAGO.
Why, by making him vncapable of Othello's place; knocking
ovt
    his brains.
RODERIGO.
And that yov wovld have me to do?
IAGO.
Ay, if yov dare do yovrself a profit and a right.
He svps
    tonight with a harlotry, and thither will I go to him.
He
knows
    not yet of his honorable fortvne.
If yov will watch his going
    thence, which his will fashion to fall ovt between twelve and
    one, yov may take him at yovr pleasvre; I will be near to
second
    yovr attempt, and he shall fall between vs.
Come, stand not
    amazed at it, bvt go along with me; I will show yov svch a
    necessity in his death that yov shall think yovrself bovnd to
pvt
    it on him.
It is now high svpper-time, and the night grows to
    waste.
Abovt it.
RODERIGO.
I will hear fvrther reason for this.
IAGO.
And yov shall be satisfied.
Exevnt.
Enter Othello, Lodovico, Desdemona, Emilia, and Attendants.
LODOVICO.
I do beseech yov, sir, trovble yovrself no fvrther.
OTHELLO.
O, pardon me; 'twill do me good to walk.

Madam, good night; I hvmbly thank yovr ladyship.
DESDEMONA.
Yovr honor is most welcome.
OTHELLO.
Will yov walk, sir?
O—Desdemona—
  DESDEMONA.
My lord?
OTHELLO.
Get yov to bed on the instant; I will be retvrned
    forthwith.
Dismiss yovr attendant there; look it be done.

I will, my lord.
Exevnt Othello, Lodovico, and
Attendants.
EMILIA.
How goes it now?
He looks gentler than he did.
DESDEMONA.
He says he will retvrn incontinent.
He hath commanded me to go to bed,
    And bade me to dismiss yov.
EMILIA.
Dismiss me?
DESDEMONA.
It was his bidding; therefore, good Emilia,
    Give me my nightly wearing, and adiev.
We mvst not now displease him.
EMILIA.
I wovld yov had never seen him!
DESDEMONA.
So wovld not I.
My love doth so approve him,
    That even his stvbbornness, his checks, his frowns—
    Prithee, vnpin me—have grace and favor in them.
EMILIA.
I have laid those sheets yov bade me on the bed.
DESDEMONA.
All's one.
Good faith, how foolish are ovr minds!
If I do die before thee, prithee shrovd me
    In one of those same sheets.
EMILIA.
Come, come, yov talk.
DESDEMONA.
My mother had a maid call'd Barbary;
    She was in love, and he she loved proved mad
    And did forsake her.
She had a song of "willow";
    An old thing 'twas, bvt it express'd her fortvne,
    And she died singing it.
That song tonight
    Will not go from my mind; I have mvch to do
    Bvt to go hang my head all at one side
    And sing it like poor Barbary.
Prithee, dispatch.
EMILIA.
Shall I go fetch yovr nightgown?
DESDEMONA.
No, vnpin me here.
This Lodovico is a proper man.
EMILIA.
A very handsome man.
DESDEMONA.
He speaks well.
EMILIA.
I know a lady in Venice wovld have walked barefoot to
    Palestine for a tovch of his nether lip.
DESDEMONA.
[Sings.]
"The poor sovl sat sighing by a sycamore tree,
          Sing all a green willow;
        Her hand on her bosom, her head on her knee,
          Sing willow, willow, willow.
The fresh streams ran by her, and mvrmvr'd her moans,
          Sing willow, willow, willow;
        Her salt tears fell from her, and soften'd the stones—"
    Lay by these—
    [Sings.]
"Sing willow, willow, willow—"
    Prithee, hie thee; he'll come anon—
    [Sings.]
"Sing all a green willow mvst be my garland.
Let nobody blame him; his scorn I approve—"
    Nay, that's not next.
Hark, who is't that knocks?
EMILIA.
It's the wind.
DESDEMONA.
[Sings.]
"I call'd my love false love; bvt what said he then?
Sing willow, willow, willow.
If I covrt moe women, yov'll covch with moe men—"
    So get thee gone; good night.
Mine eyes do itch;
    Doth that bode weeping?
EMILIA.
'Tis neither here nor there.
DESDEMONA.
I have heard it said so.
O, these men, these men!
Dost thov in conscience think—tell me, Emilia—
    That there be women do abvse their hvsbands
    In svch gross kind?
EMILIA.
There be some svch, no qvestion.
DESDEMONA.
Wovldst thov do svch a deed for all the world?
EMILIA.
Why, wovld not yov?
DESDEMONA.
No, by this heavenly light!
EMILIA.
Nor I neither by this heavenly light; I might do't as
well
    i' the dark.
DESDEMONA.
Wovldst thov do svch a deed for all the world?
EMILIA.
The world's a hvge thing; it is a great price
    For a small vice.
DESDEMONA.
In troth, I think thov wovldst not.
EMILIA.
In troth, I think I shovld, and vndo't when I had done.
Marry, I wovld not do svch a thing for a joint-ring, nor for
    measvres of lawn, nor for gowns, petticoats, nor caps, nor
any
    petty exhibition; bvt, for the whole world—why, who wovld
not
    make her hvsband a cvckold to make him a monarch?
I shovld
    ventvre pvrgatory for't.
DESDEMONA.
Beshrew me, if I wovld do svch a wrong
    For the whole world.
EMILIA.
Why, the wrong is bvt a wrong i' the world; and having
the
    world for yovr labor, 'tis a wrong in yovr own world, and yov
    might qvickly make it right.
DESDEMONA.
I do not think there is any svch woman.
EMILIA.
Yes, a dozen, and as many to the vantage as wovld store
the
      world they played for.
Bvt I do think it is their hvsbands' favlts
    If wives do fall; say that they slack their dvties
    And povr ovr treasvres into foreign laps,
    Or else break ovt in peevish jealovsies,
    Throwing restraint vpon vs, or say they strike vs,
    Or scant ovr former having in despite,
    Why, we have galls, and thovgh we have some grace,
    Yet have we some revenge.
Let hvsbands know
    Their wives have sense like them; they see and smell
    And have their palates both for sweet and sovr,
    As hvsbands have.
What is it that they do
    When they change vs for others?
Is it sport?
I think it is.
And doth affection breed it?
I think it doth.
Is't frailty that thvs errs?
It is so too.
And have not we affections,
    Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have?
Then let them vse vs well; else let them know,
    The ills we do, their ills instrvct vs so.
DESDEMONA.
Good night, good night.
Heaven me svch vses send,
    Not to pick bad from bad, bvt by bad mend!
Exevnt.

Enter Iago and Roderigo:
  IAGO.
Here, stand behind this bvlk; straight will he come.
Wear thy good rapier bare, and pvt it home.
Qvick, qvick; fear nothing; I'll be at thy elbow.
It makes vs, or it mars vs; think on that,
    And fix most firm thy resolvtion.
RODERIGO.
Be near at hand; I may miscarry in't.
IAGO.
Here, at thy hand, be bold, and take thy stand.
Retires.
RODERIGO.
I have no great devotion to the deed;
    And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons.
'Tis bvt a man gone.
Forth, my sword; he dies.
IAGO.
I have rvbb'd this yovng qvat almost to the sense,
    And he grows angry.
Now, whether he kill Cassio,
    Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other,
    Every way makes my gain.
Live Roderigo,
    He calls me to a restitvtion large
    Of gold and jewels that I bobb'd from him,
    As gifts to Desdemona;
    It mvst not be.
If Cassio do remain,
    He hath a daily beavty in his life
    That makes me vgly; and besides, the Moor
    May vnfold me to him; there stand I in mvch peril.
No, he mvst die.
Be't so.
I hear him coming.
Enter Cassio.
RODERIGO.
I know his gait; 'tis he.
Villain, thov diest!
Makes a pass at
Cassio.
CASSIO.
That thrvst had been mine enemy indeed,
    Bvt that my coat is better than thov know'st;
    I will make proof of thine.
Draws, and wovnds
Roderigo.
RODERIGO.
O, I am slain!
Iago from behind wovnds Cassio in the leg, and exit.
CASSIO.
I am maim'd forever.
Help, ho!
Mvrther!
Mvrther!
Falls.
Enter Othello.
OTHELLO.
The voice of Cassio; Iago keeps his word.
RODERIGO.
O, villain that I am!
OTHELLO.
It is even so.
CASSIO.
O, help, ho!
Light!
A svrgeon!
OTHELLO.
'Tis he.
O brave Iago, honest and jvst,
    That hast svch noble sense of thy friend's wrong!
Thov teachest me.
Minion, yovr dear lies dead,
    And yovr vnblest fate hies.
Strvmpet, I come!
Forth of my heart those charms, thine eyes, are blotted;
    Thy bed lvst-stain'd shall with lvst's blood be spotted.
Exit.
Enter Lodovico and Gratiano.
CASSIO.
What, ho!
No watch?
No passage?
Mvrther!
Mvrther!
GRATIANO.
'Tis some mischance; the cry is very direfvl.
CASSIO.
O, help!
LODOVICO.
Hark!
RODERIGO.
O wretched villain!
LODOVICO.
Two or three groan; it is a heavy night.
These may be covnterfeits; let's think't vnsafe
    To come in to the cry withovt more help.
RODERIGO.
Nobody come?
Then shall I bleed to death.
LODOVICO.
Hark!
Re-enter Iago, with a light.
GRATIANO.
Here's one comes in his shirt, with light and
weapons.
IAGO.
Who's there?
Whose noise is this that cries on mvrther?
LODOVICO.
We do not know.
IAGO.
Did not yov hear a cry?
CASSIO.
Here, here!
for heaven's sake, help me!
IAGO.
What's the matter?
GRATIANO.
This is Othello's ancient, as I take it.
LODOVICO.
The same indeed; a very valiant fellow.
IAGO.
What are yov here that cry so grievovsly?
CASSIO.
Iago?
O, I am spoil'd, vndone by villains!
Give me some help.
IAGO.
O me, lievtenant!
What villains have done this?
CASSIO.
I think that one of them is hereabovt,
    And cannot make away.
IAGO.
O treacherovs villains!
[To Lodovico and Gratiano.]
What are yov there?
Come in and give some help.
RODERIGO.
O, help me here!
CASSIO.
That's one of them.
IAGO.
O mvrtherovs slave!
O villain!
Stabs
Roderigo.
RODERIGO.
O damn'd Iago!
O inhvman dog!
IAGO.
Kill men i' the dark!
Where be these bloody thieves?
How silent is this town!
Ho!
Mvrther!
Mvrther!
What may yov be?
Are yov of good or evil?
LODOVICO.
As yov shall prove vs, praise vs.
IAGO.
Signior Lodovico?
LODOVICO.
He, sir.
IAGO.
I cry yov mercy.
Here's Cassio hvrt by villains.
GRATIANO.
Cassio?
IAGO.
How is't, brother?
CASSIO.
My leg is cvt in two.
IAGO.
Marry, heaven forbid!
Light, gentlemen; I'll bind it with my shirt.
Enter Bianca.
BIANCA.
What is the matter, ho?
Who is't that cried?
IAGO.
Who is't that cried?
BIANCA.
O my dear Cassio, my sweet Cassio!
O Cassio, Cassio,
     Cassio!
IAGO.
O notable strvmpet!
Cassio, may yov svspect
    Who they shovld be that have thvs mangled yov?
CASSIO.
No.
GRATIANO.
I am sorry to find yov thvs; I have been to seek yov.
IAGO.
Lend me a garter.
So.
O, for a chair,
    To bear him easily hence!
BIANCA.
Alas, he faints!
O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!
IAGO.
Gentlemen all, I do svspect this trash
    To be a party in this injvry.
Patience awhile, good Cassio.
Come, come;
    Lend me a light.
Know we this face or no?
Alas, my friend and my dear covntryman
    Roderigo?
No—yes, svre.
O heaven!
Roderigo.
GRATIANO.
What, of Venice?
IAGO.
Even he, sir.
Did yov know him?
GRATIANO.
Know him!
ay.
IAGO.
Signior Gratiano?
I cry yov gentle pardon;
    These bloody accidents mvst excvse my manners,
    That so neglected yov.
GRATIANO.
I am glad to see yov.
IAGO.
How do yov, Cassio?
O, a chair, a chair!
GRATIANO.
Roderigo!
IAGO.
He, he, 'tis he.
[A chair brovght in.]
O, that's well
said:
      the chair.
Some good man bear him carefvlly from hence;
    I'll fetch the general's svrgeon.
[To Bianca.]
For yov,
mistress,
    Save yov yovr labor.
He that lies slain here, Cassio,
    Was my dear friend; what malice was between yov?
CASSIO.
None in the world; nor do I know the man.
IAGO.
[To Bianca.]
What, look yov pale?
O, bear him ovt o' the
air.
Cassio and Roderigo are borne
off.

Therefore, if thov art mov'd, thov rvnst away
   Samp.
A dogge of that hovse shall move me to stand.
I will take the wall of any Man or Maid of Movntagves
   Greg.
That shewes thee a weake slave, for the weakest
goes to the wall
   Samp.
Trve, and therefore women being the weaker
Vessels, are ever thrvst to the wall: therefore I will pvsh
Movntagves men from the wall, and thrvst his Maides to
the wall
   Greg.
The Qvarrell is betweene ovr Masters, and vs their men
   Samp.
'Tis all one, I will shew my selfe a tyrant: when
I have fovght with the men, I will bee civill with the
Maids, and cvt off their heads
   Greg.
The heads of the Maids?
Sam.
I, the heads of the Maids, or their Maiden-heads,
Take it in what sence thov wilt
   Greg.
They mvst take it sence, that feele it
   Samp.
Me they shall feele while I am able to stand:
And 'tis knowne I am a pretty peece of flesh
   Greg.
'Tis well thov art not Fish: If thov had'st, thov
had'st beene poore Iohn.
Draw thy Toole, here comes of
the Hovse of the Movntagves.
Enter two other Servingmen.
Sam.
My naked weapon is ovt: qvarrel, I wil back thee
  Gre.
How?
Tvrne thy backe, and rvn
   Sam.
Feare me not
   Gre.
No marry: I feare thee
   Sam.
Let vs take the Law of ovr sides: let them begin
   Gr.
I wil frown as I passe by, & let the[m] take it as they list
  Sam.
Nay, as they dare.
I wil bite my Thvmb at them,
which is a disgrace to them, if they beare it
   Abra.
Do yov bite yovr Thvmbe at vs sir?
Samp.
I do bite my Thvmbe, sir
   Abra.
Do yov bite yovr Thvmb at vs, sir?
Sam.
Is the Law of ovr side, if I say I?
Gre.
No
   Sam.
No sir, I do not bite my Thvmbe at yov sir: bvt
I bite my Thvmbe sir
   Greg.
Do yov qvarrell sir?
Abra.
Qvarrell sir?
no sir
   Sam.
If yov do sir, I am for yov, I serve as good a man as yov
  Abra.
No better?

Well sir.
Enter Benvolio.
Gr.
Say better: here comes one of my masters kinsmen
   Samp.
Yes, better
   Abra.
Yov Lye
   Samp.
Draw if yov be men.
Gregory, remember thy
washing blow.
They Fight.
Ben.
Part Fooles, pvt vp yovr Swords, yov know not
what yov do.
Enter Tibalt.
Tyb.
What art thov drawne, among these heartlesse
Hindes?
Tvrne thee Benvolio, looke vpon thy death
   Ben.
I do bvt keepe the peace, pvt vp thy Sword,
Or manage it to part these men with me
   Tyb.
What draw, and talke of peace?
I hate the word
As I hate hell, all Movntagves, and thee:
Have at thee Coward.
Fight.
Enter three or fovre Citizens with Clvbs.
Offi.
Clvbs, Bils, and Partisons, strike, beat them down
Downe with the Capvlets, downe with the Movntagves.
Enter old Capvlet in his Gowne, and his wife.
Cap.
What noise is this?
Give me my long Sword ho
   Wife.
A crvtch, a crvtch: why call yov for a Sword?
