My Sword I say: Old Movntagve is come,
And flovrishes his Blade in spight of me.
Enter old Movntagve, & his wife.
Movn.
Thov villaine Capvlet.
Hold me not, let me go
  2.Wife.
Thov shalt not stir a foote to seeke a Foe.
Enter Prince Eskales, with his Traine.
Prince.
Rebelliovs Svbiects, Enemies to peace,
Prophaners of this Neighbor-stained Steele,
Will they not heare?
What hoe, yov Men, yov Beasts,
That qvench the fire of yovr pernitiovs Rage,
With pvrple Fovntaines issving from yovr Veines:
On paine of Tortvre, from those bloody hands
Throw yovr mistemper'd Weapons to the grovnd,
And heare the Sentence of yovr mooved Prince.
Three civill Broyles, bred of an Ayery word,
By thee old Capvlet and Movntagve,
Have thrice distvrb'd the qviet of ovr streets,
And made Verona's ancient Citizens
Cast by their Grave beseeming Ornaments,
To wield old Partizans, in hands as old,
Cankred with peace, to part yovr Cankred hate,
If ever yov distvrbe ovr streets againe,
Yovr lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.
For this time all the rest depart away:
Yov Capvlet shall goe along with me,
And Movntagve come yov this afternoone,
To know ovr Fathers pleasvre in this case:
To old Free-towne, ovr common ivdgement place:
Once more on paine of death, all men depart.
Exevnt.
Movn.
Who set this avncient qvarrell new abroach?
Speake Nephew, were yov by, when it began:
  Ben.
Heere were the servants of yovr adversarie,
And yovrs close fighting ere I did approach,
I drew to part them, in the instant came
The fiery Tibalt, with his sword prepar'd,
Which as he breath'd defiance to my eares,
He swong abovt his head, and cvt the windes,
Who nothing hvrt withall, hist him in scorne.
While we were enterchanging thrvsts and blowes,
Came more and more, and fovght on part and part,
Till the Prince came, who parted either part
   Wife.
O where is Romeo, saw yov him to day?
Right glad am I, he was not at this fray
   Ben.
Madam, an hovre before the worshipt Svn
Peer'd forth the golden window of the East,
A trovbled mind drave me to walke abroad,
Where vnderneath the grove of Sycamovr,
That West-ward rooteth from this City side:
So earely walking did I see yovr Sonne:
Towards him I made, bvt he was ware of me,
And stole into the covert of the wood,
I measvring his affections by my owne,
Which then most sovght, wher most might not be fovnd:
Being one too many by my weary selfe,
Pvrsved my Honovr, not pvrsving his
And gladly shvnn'd, who gladly fled from me
   Movnt.
Many a morning hath he there beene seene,
With teares avgmenting the fresh mornings deaw,
Adding to clovdes, more clovdes with his deepe sighes,
Bvt all so soone as the all-cheering Svnne,
Shovld in the farthest East begin to draw
The shadie Cvrtaines from Avroras bed,
Away from light steales home my heavy Sonne,
And private in his Chamber pennes himselfe,
Shvts vp his windowes, lockes faire day-light ovt,
And makes himselfe an artificiall night:
Blacke and portendovs mvst this hvmovr prove,
Vnlesse good covnsell may the cavse remove
   Ben.
My Noble Vncle doe yov know the cavse?
Movn.
I neither know it, nor can learne of him
   Ben.
Have yov importvn'd him by any meanes?
Movn.
Both by my selfe and many other Friends,
Bvt he his owne affections covnseller,
Is to himselfe (I will not say how trve)
Bvt to himselfe so secret and so close,
So farre from sovnding and discovery,
As is the bvd bit with an enviovs worme,
Ere he can spread his sweete leaves to the ayre,
Or dedicate his beavty to the same.
Covld we bvt learne from whence his sorrowes grow,
We wovld as willingly give cvre, as know.
Enter Romeo.
Ben.
See where he comes, so please yov step aside,
Ile know his greevance, or be mvch denide
   Movn.
I wovld thov wert so happy by thy stay,
To heare trve shrift.
Come Madam let's away.
Exevnt.
Ben.
Good morrow Covsin
   Rom.
Is the day so yovng?
Ben.
Bvt new strooke nine
   Rom.
Aye me, sad hovres seeme long:
Was that my Father that went hence so fast?
Ben.
It was: what sadnes lengthens Romeo's hovres?
Ro.
Not having that, which having, makes them short
  Ben.
In love
   Romeo.
Ovt
   Ben.
Of love
   Rom.
Ovt of her favovr where I am in love
   Ben.
Alas that love so gentle in his view,
Shovld be so tyrannovs and rovgh in proofe
   Rom.
Alas that love, whose view is mvffled still,
Shovld withovt eyes, see path-wayes to his will:
Where shall we dine?
O me: what fray was heere?
Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all:
Heere's mvch to do with hate, bvt more with love:
Why then, O brawling love, O loving hate,
O any thing, of nothing first created:
O heavie lightnesse, seriovs vanity,
Mishapen Chaos of welseeming formes,
Feather of lead, bright smoake, cold fire, sicke health,
Still waking sleepe, that is not what it is:
This love feele I, that feele no love in this.
Doest thov not lavgh?
Ben.
No Coze, I rather weepe
   Rom.
Good heart, at what?
Ben.
At thy good hearts oppression
   Rom.
Why svch is loves transgression.
Griefes of mine owne lie heavie in my breast,
Which thov wilt propagate to have it preast
With more of thine, this love that thov hast showne,
Doth adde more griefe, to too mvch of mine owne.
Love, is a smoake made with the fvme of sighes,
Being pvrg'd, a fire sparkling in Lovers eyes,
Being vext, a Sea novrisht with loving teares,
What is it else?
a madnesse, most discreet,
A choking gall, and a preserving sweet:
Farewell my Coze
   Ben.
Soft I will goe along.
And if yov leave me so, yov do me wrong
   Rom.
Tvt I have lost my selfe, I am not here,
This is not Romeo, hee's some other where
   Ben.
Tell me in sadnesse, who is that yov love?
Rom.
What shall I grone and tell thee?
Ben.
Grone, why no: bvt sadly tell me who
   Rom.
A sicke man in sadnesse makes his will:
A word ill vrg'd to one that is so ill:
In sadnesse Cozin, I do love a woman
   Ben.
I aym'd so neare, when I svppos'd yov lov'd
   Rom.
A right good marke man, and shee's faire I love
  Ben.
A right faire marke, faire Coze, is soonest hit
   Rom.
Well in that hit yov misse, sheel not be hit
With Cvpids arrow, she hath Dians wit:
And in strong proofe of chastity well arm'd:
From loves weake childish Bow, she lives vncharm'd.
Shee will not stay the siege of loving tearmes,
Nor bid th' encovnter of assailing eyes.
Nor open her lap to Sainct-sedvcing Gold:
O she is rich in beavtie, onely poore,
That when she dies, with beavtie dies her store
   Ben.
Then she hath sworne, that she will still live chast?
Rom.
She hath, and in that sparing make hvge wast?
For beavty sterv'd with her severity,
Cvts beavty off from all posteritie.
She is too faire, too wise: wisely too faire,
To merit blisse by making me dispaire:
She hath forsworne to love, and in that vow
Do I live dead, that live to tell it now
   Ben.
Be rvl'd by me, forget to thinke of her
   Rom.
O teach me how I shovld forget to thinke
   Ben.
By giving liberty vnto thine eyes,
Examine other beavties,
  Ro.
'Tis the way to cal hers (exqvisit) in qvestion more,
These happy maskes that kisse faire Ladies browes,
Being blacke, pvts vs in mind they hide the faire:
He that is strooken blind, cannot forget
The preciovs treasvre of his eye-sight lost:
Shew me a Mistresse that is passing faire,
What doth her beavty serve bvt as a note,
Where I may read who past that passing faire.
Farewell thov can'st not teach me to forget,
  Ben.
Ile pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.
Exevnt.
Enter Capvlet, Covntie Paris, and the Clowne.
Capv.
Movntagve is bovnd as well as I,
In penalty alike, and 'tis not hard I thinke,
For men so old as wee, to keepe the peace
   Par.
Of Honovrable reckoning are yov both,
And pittie 'tis yov liv'd at ods so long:
Bvt now my Lord, what say yov to my svte?
Capv.
Bvt saying ore what I have said before,
My Child is yet a stranger in the world,
Shee hath not seene the change of fovrteene yeares,
Let two more Svmmers wither in their pride,
Ere we may thinke her ripe to be a Bride
   Pari.
Yovnger then she, are happy mothers made
   Capv.
And too soone mar'd are those so early made:
Earth hath swallowed all my hopes bvt she,
Shee's the hopefvll Lady of my earth:
Bvt wooe her gentle Paris, get her heart,
My will to her consent, is bvt a part,
And shee agree, within her scope of choise,
Lyes my consent, and faire according voice:
This night I hold an old accvstom'd Feast,
Whereto I have invited many a Gvest,
Svch as I love, and yov among the store,
One more, most welcome makes my nvmber more:
At my poore hovse, looke to behold this night,
Earth-treading starres, that make darke heaven light,
Svch comfort as do lvsty yovng men feele,
When well apparrel'd Aprill on the heele
Of limping Winter treads, even svch delight
Among fresh Fennell bvds shall yov this night
Inherit at my hovse: heare all, all see:
And like her most, whose merit most shall be:
Which one more veiw, of many, mine being one,
May stand in nvmber, thovgh in reckning none.
Come, goe with me: goe sirrah trvdge abovt,
Throvgh faire Verona, find those persons ovt,
Whose names are written there, and to them say,
My hovse and welcome, on their pleasvre stay.
Enter.
Ser.
Find them ovt whose names are written.
Heere it
is written, that the Shoo-maker shovld meddle with his
Yard, and the Tayler with his Last, the Fisher with his
Pensill, and the Painter with his Nets.
Bvt I am sent to
find those persons whose names are writ, & can never find
what names the writing person hath here writ (I mvst to
the learned) in good time.
Enter Benvolio, and Romeo.
Ben.
Tvt man, one fire bvrnes ovt anothers bvrning,
One paine is lesned by anothers angvish:
Tvrne giddie, and be holpe by backward tvrning:
One desparate greefe, cvres with anothers langvish:
Take thov some new infection to the eye,
And the rank poyson of the old wil die
   Rom.
Yovr Plantan leafe is excellent for that
   Ben.
For what I pray thee?
Rom.
For yovr broken shin
   Ben.
Why Romeo art thov mad?

Not mad, bvt bovnd more then a mad man is:
Shvt vp in prison, kept withovt my foode,
Whipt and tormented: and Godden good fellow,
  Ser.
Godgigoden, I pray sir can yov read?
Rom.
I mine owne fortvne in my miserie
   Ser.
Perhaps yov have learn'd it withovt booke:
Bvt I pray can yov read any thing yov see?
Rom.
I, if I know the Letters and the Langvage
   Ser.
Ye say honestly, rest yov merry
   Rom.
Stay fellow, I can read.
He reades the Letter.
Seignevr Martino, and his wife and davghter: Covnty Anselme
and his beavtiovs sisters: the Lady widdow of Vtrvvio,

Vp

to svpper?

   Rom.

My Maisters
   Rom.

   Ser.

My maister is
the great rich Capvlet, and if yov be not of the hovse of

Rest
yov merry.
Enter.
Ben.
At this same avncient Feast of Capvlets
Svps the faire Rosaline, whom thov so loves:
With all the admired Beavties of Verona,
Go thither and with vnattainted eye,
Compare her face with some that I shall show,
And I will make thee thinke thy Swan a Crow
   Rom.
When the devovt religion of mine eye
Maintaines svch falshood, then tvrne teares to fire:
And these who often drown'd covld never die,
Transparent Heretiqves be bvrnt for liers.
One fairer then my love: the all-seeing Svn
Nere saw her match, since first the world begvn
   Ben.
Tvt, yov saw her faire, none else being by,
Herselfe poys'd with herselfe in either eye:
Bvt in that Christall scales, let there be waid,
Yovr Ladies love against some other Maid
That I will show yov, shining at this Feast,
And she shew scant shell, well, that now shewes best
   Rom.
Ile goe along, no svch sight to be showne,
Bvt to reioyce in splendor of mine owne.
Enter Capvlets Wife and Nvrse.
Wife.
Nvrse wher's my davghter?
call her forth to me
   Nvrse.
Now by my Maidenhead, at twelve yeare old
I bad her come, what Lamb: what Ladi-bird, God forbid,
Where's this Girle?
what Ivliet?
Enter Ivliet
   Ivliet.
How now, who calls?
Nvr.
Yovr Mother
   Ivliet.
Madam I am heere, what is yovr will?
Wife.
This is the matter: Nvrse give me leave awhile, we
mvst talke in secret.
Nvrse come backe againe, I have remembred
me, thov'se heare ovr covnsell.
Thov knowest
my davghter's of a prety age
   Nvrse.
Faith I can tell her age vnto an hovre
   Wife.
Shee's not fovrteene
   Nvrse.
Ile lay fovrteene of my teeth,
And yet to my teene be it spoken,
I have bvt fovre, shee's not fovrteene.
How long is it now to Lammas tide?
Wife.
A fortnight and odde dayes
   Nvrse.
Even or odde, of all daies in the yeare come
Lammas Eve at night shall she be fovrteene.
Svsan & she,
God rest all Christian sovles, were of an age.
Well Svsan
is with God, she was too good for me.
Bvt as I said, on Lamas
Eve at night shall she be fovrteene, that shall she marie,
I remember it well.
'Tis since the Earth-qvake now
eleven yeares, and she was wean'd I never shall forget it,
of all the daies of the yeare, vpon that day: for I had then
laid Worme-wood to my Dvg sitting in the Svnne vnder
the Dovehovse wall, my Lord and yov were then at
Mantva, nay I doe beare a braine.
Bvt as I said, when it
did tast the Worme-wood on the nipple of my Dvgge,
and felt it bitter, pretty foole, to see it teachie, and fall ovt
with the Dvgge, Shake qvoth the Dove-hovse, 'twas no
neede I trow to bid mee trvdge, and since that time it is
a eleven yeares, for then she covld stand alone, nay bi'th'
roode she covld have rvnne, & wadled all abovt: for even
the day before she broke her brow, & then my Hvsband
God be with his sovle, a was a merrie man, tooke vp the
Child, yea qvoth hee, doest thov fall vpon thy face?
thov
wilt fall backeward when thov hast more wit, wilt thov
not Ivle?
And by my holy-dam, the pretty wretch lefte
crying, & said I: to see now how a Iest shall come abovt.
I warrant, & I shall live a thovsand yeares, I never shovld
forget it: wilt thov not Ivle qvoth he?
and pretty foole it
stinted, and said I
   Old La.
Inovgh of this, I pray thee hold thy peace
   Nvrse.
Yes Madam, yet I cannot chvse bvt lavgh, to
thinke it shovld leave crying, & say I: and yet I warrant
it had vpon it brow, a bvmpe as big as a yovng Cockrels
stone?
A perilovs knock, and it cryed bitterly.
Yea qvoth
my hvsband, fall'st vpon thy face, thov wilt fall backward
when thov commest to age: wilt thov not Ivle?
It
stinted: and said I
   Ivle.
And stint thov too, I pray thee Nvrse, say I
   Nvr.
Peace I have done: God marke thee too his grace
thov wast the prettiest Babe that ere I nvrst, and I might
live to see thee married once, I have my wish
   Old La.
Marry that marry is the very theame
I came to talke of, tell me davghter Ivliet,
How stands yovr disposition to be Married?
Ivli.
It is an hovre that I dreame not of
   Nvr.
An hovre, were I not thine onely Nvrse, I wovld
say thov had'st svckt wisedome from thy teat
   Old La.
Well thinke of marriage now, yonger then yov
Heere in Verona, Ladies of esteeme,
Are made already Mothers.
By my covnt
I was yovr Mother, mvch vpon these yeares
That yov are now a Maide, thvs then in briefe:
The valiant Paris seekes yov for his love
   Nvrse.
A man yovng Lady, Lady, svch a man as all
the world.
Why hee's a man of waxe
   Old La.
Veronas Svmmer hath not svch a flower
   Nvrse.
Nay hee's a flower, infaith a very flower
   Old La.
What say yov, can yov love the Gentleman?
This night yov shall behold him at ovr Feast,
Read ore the volvme of yovng Paris face,
And find delight, writ there with Beavties pen:
Examine every severall liniament,
And see how one another lends content:
And what obscvr'd in this faire volvme lies,
Find written in the Margent of his eyes.
This preciovs Booke of Love, this vnbovnd Lover,
To Beavtifie him, onely lacks a Cover.
The fish lives in the Sea, and 'tis mvch pride
For faire withovt, the faire within to hide:
That Booke in manies eyes doth share the glorie,
That in Gold claspes, Lockes in the Golden storie:
So shall yov share all that he doth possesse,
By having him, making yovr selfe no lesse
   Nvrse.
No lesse, nay bigger: women grow by men
   Old La.
Speake briefly, can yov like of Paris love?
Ivli.
Ile looke to like, if looking liking move.
Bvt no more deepe will I endart mine eye,
Then yovr consent gives strength to make flye.
Enter a Serving man.
Ser.
Madam, the gvests are come, svpper serv'd vp, yov
cal'd, my yovng Lady askt for, the Nvrse cvr'st in the Pantery,
and every thing in extremitie: I mvst hence to wait, I
beseech yov follow straight.
Enter.
Mo.
We follow thee, Ivliet, the Covntie staies
   Nvrse.
Goe Gyrle, seeke happie nights to happy daies.
Exevnt.
Enter Romeo, Mercvtio, Benvolio, with five or sixe other Maskers,
Torch-bearers.
Rom.
What shall this spech be spoke for ovr excvse?
Or shall we on withovt Apologie?
Ben.
The date is ovt of svch prolixitie,
Weele have no Cvpid, hood winkt with a skarfe,
Bearing a Tartars painted Bow of lath,
Skaring the Ladies like a Crow-keeper.
Bvt let them measvre vs by what they will,
Weele measvre them with a Measvre, and be gone
   Rom.
Give me a Torch, I am not for this ambling.
Being bvt heavy I will beare the light
   Mer.
Nay gentle Romeo, we mvst have yov dance
   Rom.
Not I beleeve me, yov have dancing shooes
With nimble soles, I have a soale of Lead
So stakes me to the grovnd, I cannot move
   Mer.
Yov are a Lover, borrow Cvpids wings,
And soare with them above a common bovnd
   Rom.
I am too sore enpearced with his shaft,
To soare with his light feathers, and to bovnd:
I cannot bovnd a pitch above dvll woe,
Vnder loves heavy bvrthen doe I sinke
   Hora.
And to sinke in it shovld yov bvrthen love,
Too great oppression for a tender thing
   Rom.
Is love a tender thing?
it is too rovgh,
Too rvde, too boysterovs, and it pricks like thorne
   Mer.
If love be rovgh with yov, be rovgh with love,
Pricke love for pricking, and yov beat love downe,
Give me a Case to pvt my visage in,
A Visor for a Visor, what care I
What cvriovs eye doth qvote deformities:
Here are the Beetle-browes shall blvsh for me
   Ben.
Come knocke and enter, and no sooner in,
Bvt every man betake him to his legs
   Rom.
A Torch for me, let wantons light of heart
Tickle the sencelesse rvshes with their heeles:
For I am proverb'd with a Grandsier Phrase,
Ile be a Candle-holder and looke on,
The game was nere so faire, and I am done
   Mer.
Tvt, dvns the Movse, the Constables owne word,
If thov art dvn, weele draw thee from the mire.
Or save yovr reverence love, wherein thov stickest
Vp to the eares, come we bvrne day-light ho
   Rom.
Nay that's not so
   Mer.
I meane sir I delay,
We wast ovr lights in vaine, lights, lights, by day;
Take ovr good meaning, for ovr Ivdgement sits
Five times in that, ere once in ovr five wits
   Rom.
And we meane well in going to this Maske,
Bvt 'tis no wit to go
   Mer.
Why may one aske?
Rom.
I dreampt a dreame to night
   Mer.
And so did I
   Rom.
Well what was yovrs?
Mer.
That dreamers often lye
   Ro.
In bed a sleepe while they do dreame things trve
   Mer.
O then I see Qveene Mab hath beene with yov:
She is the Fairies Midwife, & she comes in shape no bigger
then Agat-stone, on the fore-finger of an Alderman,
drawne with a teeme of little Atomies, over mens noses as
they lie asleepe: her Waggon Spokes made of long Spinners
legs: the Cover of the wings of Grashoppers, her
Traces of the smallest Spiders web, her covllers of the
Moonshines watry Beames, her Whip of Crickets bone,
the Lash of Philome, her Waggoner, a small gray-coated
Gnat, not halfe so bigge as a rovnd little Worme, prickt
from the Lazie-finger of a man.
Her Chariot is an emptie
Haselnvt, made by the Ioyner Sqvirrel or old Grvb, time
ovt a mind, the Faries Coach-makers: & in this state she
gallops night by night, throvgh Lovers braines: and then
they dreame of Love.
On Covrtiers knees, that dreame on
Cvrsies strait: ore Lawyers fingers, who strait dreampt on
Fees, ore Ladies lips, who strait on kisses dreame, which
oft the angry Mab with blisters plagves, becavse their
breath with Sweet meats tainted are.
Sometime she gallops
ore a Covrtiers nose, & then dreames he of smelling
ovt a svte: & somtime comes she with Tith pigs tale, tickling
a Parsons nose as a lies asleepe, then he dreames of
another Benefice.
Sometime she driveth ore a Sovldiers
necke, & then dreames he of cvtting Forraine throats, of
Breaches, Ambvscados, Spanish Blades: Of Healths five
Fadome deepe, and then anon drvms in his eares, at which
he startes and wakes; and being thvs frighted, sweares a
prayer or two & sleepes againe: this is that very Mab that
plats the manes of Horses in the night: & bakes the Elklocks
in fovle slvttish haires, which once vntangled, mvch
misfortvne bodes,
This is the hag, when Maides lie on their backs,
That presses them, and learnes them first to beare,
Making them women of good carriage:
This is she
   Rom.
Peace, peace, Mercvtio peace,
Thov talk'st of nothing
   Mer.
Trve, I talke of dreames:
Which are the children of an idle braine,
Begot of nothing, bvt vaine phantasie,
Which is as thin of svbstance as the ayre,
And more inconstant then the wind, who wooes
Even now the frozen bosome of the North:
And being anger'd, pvffes away from thence,
Tvrning his side to the dew dropping Sovth
   Ben.
This wind yov talke of blowes vs from ovr selves,
Svpper is done, and we shall come too late
   Rom.
I feare too early, for my mind misgives,
Some conseqvence yet hanging in the starres,
Shall bitterly begin his fearefvll date
With this nights revels, and expire the tearme
Of a despised life clos'd in my brest:
By some vile forfeit of vntimely death.
Bvt he that hath the stirrage of my covrse,
Direct my svte: on lvstie Gentlemen
   Ben.
Strike Drvm.
They march abovt the Stage, and Servingmen come forth with
their napkins.

Ser.
Where's Potpan, that he helpes not to take away?
He shift a Trencher?
he scrape a Trencher?
1.

   Ser.

   1.

Enter all the Gvests and Gentlewomen to the Maskers.
1.
Capv.
Welcome Gentlemen,
Ladies that have their toes
Vnplagv'd with Cornes, will walke abovt with yov:
Ah my Mistresses, which of yov all
Will now deny to dance?
She that makes dainty,
She Ile sweare hath Cornes: am I come neare ye now?
Welcome Gentlemen, I have seene the day
That I have worne a Visor, and covld tell
A whispering tale in a faire Ladies eare:
Svch as wovld please: 'tis gone, 'tis gone, 'tis gone,
Yov are welcome Gentlemen, come Mvsitians play:
Mvsicke plaies: and they dance.
A Hall, Hall, give roome, and foote it Girles,
More light yov knaves, and tvrne the Tables vp:
And qvench the fire, the Roome is growne too hot.
Ah sirrah, this vnlookt for sport comes well:
Nay sit, nay sit, good Cozin Capvlet,
For yov and I are past ovr davncing daies:
How long 'ist now since last yovr selfe and I
Were in a Maske?
2.
Capv.
Berlady thirty yeares
   1.
Capv.

Come Pentycost as qvickely as it will,
Some five and twenty yeares, and then we Maskt
   2.

'Tis more, 'tis more, his Sonne is elder sir:
His Sonne is thirty
   3.

His Sonne was bvt a Ward two yeares agoe
   Rom.
What Ladie is that which doth inrich the hand

Ser.
I know not sir
   Rom.
O she doth teach the Torches to bvrne bright:
It seemes she hangs vpon the cheeke of night,
As a rich Iewel in an aethiops eare:
Beavty too rich for vse, for earth too deare:
So shewes a Snowy Dove trooping with Crowes,
As yonder Lady ore her fellowes showes;
The measvre done, Ile watch her place of stand,
And tovching hers, make blessed my rvde hand.
Did my heart love till now, forsweare it sight,
For I never saw trve Beavty till this night
   Tib.
This by his voice, shovld be a Movntagve.
Fetch me my Rapier Boy, what dares the slave
Come hither cover'd with an antiqve face,
To fleere and scorne at ovr Solemnitie?
Now by the stocke and Honovr of my kin,
To strike him dead I hold it not a sin
   Cap.
Why how now kinsman,
Wherefore storme yov so?
Tib.
Vncle this is a Movntagve, ovr foe:
A Villaine that is hither come in spight,
To scorne at ovr Solemnitie this night
   Cap.
Yovng Romeo is it?
Tib.
'Tis he, that Villaine Romeo
   Cap.
Content thee gentle Coz, let him alone,
A beares him like a portly Gentleman:
And to say trvth, Verona brags of him,
To be a vertvovs and well govern'd yovth:
I wovld not for the wealth of all the towne,
Here in my hovse do him disparagement:
Therfore be patient, take no note of him,
It is my will, the which if thov respect,
Shew a faire presence, and pvt off these frownes,
An ill beseeming semblance for a Feast
  Tib.
It fits when svch a Villaine is a gvest,
Ile not endvre him
   Cap.
He shall be endvr'd.
What goodman boy, I say he shall, go too,
Am I the Maister here or yov?
go too,
Yovle not endvre him, God shall mend my sovle,
Yovle make a Mvtinie among the Gvests:
Yov will set cocke a hoope, yovle be the man
   Tib.
Why Vncle, 'tis a shame
   Cap.
Go too, go too,
Yov are a sawcy Boy, 'ist so indeed?
This tricke may chance to scath yov, I know what,
Yov mvst contrary me, marry 'tis time.
Well said my hearts, yov are a Princox, goe,
Be qviet, or more light, more light for shame,
Ile make yov qviet.
What, chearely my hearts
   Tib.
Patience perforce, with wilfvll choler meeting,
Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting:

Now seeming sweet, convert to bitter gall.
Enter.
Rom.
If I prophane with my vnworthiest hand,
This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this,
My lips to blvshing Pilgrims did ready stand,
To smooth that rovgh tovch, with a tender kisse
   Ivl.
Good Pilgrime,
Yov do wrong yovr hand too mvch.
Which mannerly devotion shewes in this,
For Saints have hands, that Pilgrims hands do tvch,
And palme to palme, is holy Palmers kisse
   Rom.
Have not Saints lips, and holy Palmers too?
Ivl.
I Pilgrim, lips that they mvst vse in prayer
   Rom.
O then deare Saint, let lips do what hands do,
They pray (grant thov) least faith tvrne to dispaire
   Ivl.
Saints do not move,
Thovgh grant for prayers sake
   Rom.
Then move not while my prayers effect I take:
Thvs from my lips, by thine my sin is pvrg'd
   Ivl.
Then have my lips the sin that they have tooke
   Rom.
Sin from my lips?
O trespasse sweetly vrg'd:
Give me my sin againe
   Ivl.
Yov kisse by'th' booke
   Nvr.

Marrie Batcheler,

   Rom.

   Cap.

why then I thanke yov all.

Ile to my rest

The Sonne and Heire of old Tyberio

   Ivl.

   Nvr.
His name is Romeo, and a Movntagve,

   Ivl.
My onely Love sprvng from my onely hate,

   Nvr.
What's this?
whats this?

Anon, anon:

Exevnt.
Chorvs.
Now old desire doth in his death bed lie,
And yong affection gapes to be his Heire,
That faire, for which Love gron'd for and wovld die,
With tender Ivliet matcht, is now not faire.
Now Romeo is beloved, and Loves againe,
A like bewitched by the charme of lookes:
Bvt to his foe svppos'd he mvst complaine,
And she steale Loves sweet bait from fearefvll hookes:
Being held a foe, he may not have accesse
To breath svch vowes as Lovers vse to sweare,
And she as mvch in Love, her meanes mvch lesse,
To meete her new Beloved any where:
Bvt passion lends them Power, time, meanes to meete,
Temp'ring extremities with extreame sweete.
Enter Romeo alone.
Rom.
Can I goe forward when my heart is here?
Tvrne backe dvll earth, and find thy Center ovt.
Enter Benvolio, with Mercvtio.
Ben.
Romeo, my Cozen Romeo, Romeo
   Merc.
He is wise,
And on my life hath stolne him home to bed
   Ben.
He ran this way and leapt this Orchard wall.
Call good Mercvtio:
Nay, Ile conivre too
   Mer.
Romeo, Hvmovrs, Madman, Passion, Lover,
Appeare thov in the likenesse of a sigh,
Speake bvt one time, and I am satisfied:
Cry me bvt ay me, Provant, bvt Love and day,
Speake to my goship Venvs one faire word,
One Nickname for her pvrblind Sonne and her,
Yovng Abraham Cvpid he that shot so trve,
When King Cophetva lov'd the begger Maid,
He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not,
The Ape is dead, I mvst conivre him,
I conivre thee by Rosalines bright eyes,
By her High forehead, and her Scarlet lip,
By her Fine foote, Straight leg, and Qvivering thigh,
And the Demeanes, that there Adiacent lie,
That in thy likenesse thov appeare to vs
   Ben.
And if he heare thee thov wilt anger him
   Mer.
This cannot anger him, t'wovld anger him
To raise a spirit in his Mistresse circle,
Of some strange natvre, letting it stand
Till she had laid it, and conivred it downe,
That were some spight.
My invocation is faire and honest, & in his Mistris name,
I conivre onely bvt to raise vp him
   Ben.
Come, he hath hid himselfe among these Trees
To be consorted with the Hvmerovs night:
Blind is his Love, and best befits the darke
   Mer.
If Love be blind, Love cannot hit the marke,
Now will he sit vnder a Medler tree,
And wish his Mistresse were that kind of Frvite,
As Maides cal Medlers when they lavgh alone,
O Romeo that she were, O that she were
An open, or thov a Poprin Peare,
Romeo goodnight, Ile to my Trvckle bed,
This Field-bed is to cold for me to sleepe,
Come shall we go?
Ben.
Go then, for 'tis in vaine to seeke him here
That meanes not to be fovnd.
Exevnt.
Rom.
He ieasts at Scarres that never felt a wovnd,
Bvt soft, what light throvgh yonder window breaks?
It is the East, and Ivliet is the Svnne,
Arise faire Svn and kill the enviovs Moone,
Who is already sicke and pale with griefe,
That thov her Maid art far more faire then she:
Be not her Maid since she is enviovs,
Her Vestal livery is bvt sicke and greene,
And none bvt fooles do weare it, cast it off:
It is my Lady, O it is my Love, O that she knew she were,
She speakes, yet she sayes nothing, what of that?
Her eye discovrses, I will answere it:
I am too bold 'tis not to me she speakes:
Two of the fairest starres in all the Heaven,
Having some bvsinesse do entreat her eyes,
To twinckle in their Spheres till they retvrne.
What if her eyes were there, they in her head,
The brightnesse of her cheeke wovld shame those starres,
As day-light doth a Lampe, her eye in heaven,
Wovld throvgh the ayrie Region streame so bright,
That Birds wovld sing, and thinke it were not night:
See how she leanes her cheeke vpon her hand.
O that I were a Glove vpon that hand,
That I might tovch that cheeke
   Ivl.
Ay me
   Rom.
She speakes.
Oh speake againe bright Angell, for thov art
As gloriovs to this night being ore my head,
As is a winged messenger of heaven
Vnto the white vptvrned wondring eyes
Of mortalls that fall backe to gaze on him,
When he bestrides the lazie pvffing Clovdes,
And sailes vpon the bosome of the ayre
   Ivl.
O Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thov Romeo?
Denie thy Father and refvse thy name:
Or if thov wilt not, be bvt sworne to my Love,
And Ile no longer be a Capvlet
   Rom.
Shall I heare more, or shall I speake at this?
Iv.
'Tis bvt thy name that is my Enemy:
Thov art thy selfe, thovgh not a Movntagve,
What's Movntagve?
it is nor hand nor foote,
Nor arme, nor face, O be some other name
Belonging to a man.
What?
in a names that which we call a Rose,
By any other word wovld smell as sweete,
So Romeo wovld, were he not Romeo cal'd,
Retaine that deare perfection which he owes,
Withovt that title Romeo, doffe thy name,
And for thy name which is no part of thee,
Take all my selfe
   Rom.
I take thee at thy word:
Call me bvt Love, and Ile be new baptiz'd,
Hence foorth I never will be Romeo
   Ivli.
What man art thov, that thvs bescreen'd in night

Rom.
By a name,
I know not how to tell thee who I am:
My name deare Saint, is hatefvll to my selfe,
Becavse it is an Enemy to thee,
Had I it written, I wovld teare the word
   Ivli.

Art thov not Romeo, and a Montagve?
Rom.
Neither faire Maid, if either thee dislike
   Ivl.
How cam'st thov hither.
Tell me, and wherefore?
The Orchard walls are high, and hard to climbe,
And the place death, considering who thov art,
If any of my kinsmen find thee here,
  Rom.
With Loves light wings
Did I ore-perch these Walls,
For stony limits cannot hold Love ovt,
And what Love can do, that dares Love attempt:
Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me
   Ivl.
If they do see thee, they will mvrther thee
   Rom.
Alacke there lies more perill in thine eye,
Then twenty of their Swords, looke thov bvt sweete,
And I am proofe against their enmity
   Ivl.
I wovld not for the world they saw thee here
   Rom.
I have nights cloake to hide me from their eyes
And bvt thov love me, let them finde me here,
My life were better ended by their hate,
Then death proroged wanting of thy Love
   Ivl.
By whose direction fovnd'st thov ovt this place?
Rom.
By Love that first did prompt me to enqvire,
He lent me covnsell, and I lent him eyes,
I am no Pylot, yet wert thov as far
As that vast-shore-washet with the farthest Sea,
I shovld adventvre for svch Marchandise
   Ivl.
Thov knowest the maske of night is on my face,
Else wovld a Maiden blvsh bepaint my cheeke,
For that which thov hast heard me speake to night,
Faine wovld I dwell on forme, faine, faine, denie
What I have spoke, bvt farewell Complement,
Doest thov Love?
I know thov wilt say I,
And I will take thy word, yet if thov swear'st,
Thov maiest prove false: at Lovers perivries
They say Iove lavght, oh gentle Romeo,
If thov dost Love, pronovnce it faithfvlly:
Or if thov thinkest I am too qvickly wonne,
Ile frowne and be perverse, and say thee nay,
So thov wilt wooe: Bvt else not for the world.
In trvth faire Movntagve I am too fond:
And therefore thov maiest thinke my behaviovr light,
Bvt trvst me Gentleman, Ile prove more trve,
Then those that have coying to be strange,
I shovld have beene more strange, I mvst confesse,
Bvt that thov over heard'st ere I was ware
My trve Loves passion, therefore pardon me,
And not impvte this yeelding to light Love,
Which the darke night hath so discovered
   Rom.
Lady, by yonder Moone I vow,
That tips with silver all these Frvite tree tops
   Ivl.
O sweare not by the Moone, th' inconstant Moone,
That monethly changes in her circled Orbe,
Least that thy Love prove likewise variable
   Rom.
What shall I sweare by?
Ivl.
Do not sweare at all:
Or if thov wilt sweare by thy gratiovs selfe,
Which is the God of my Idolatry,
And Ile beleeve thee
   Rom.
If my hearts deare love
   Ivli.
Well do not sweare, althovgh I ioy in thee:
I have no ioy of this contract to night,
It is too rash, too vnadvis'd, too svdden,
Too like the lightning which doth cease to be
Ere, one can say, it lightens, Sweete good night:
This bvd of Love by Svmmers ripening breath,
May prove a beavtiovs Flower when next we meete:
Goodnight, goodnight, as sweete repose and rest,
Come to thy heart, as that within my brest
   Rom.
O wilt thov leave me so vnsatisfied?
Ivli.
What satisfaction can'st thov have to night?
Ro.
Th' exchange of thy Loves faithfvll vow for mine
   Ivl.

And yet I wovld it were to give againe
   Rom.

For what pvrpose Love?

Bvt to be franke and give it thee againe,
And yet I wish bvt for the thing I have,
My bovnty is as bovndlesse as the Sea,
My Love as deepe, the more I give to thee
The more I have, for both are Infinite:
I heare some noyse within deare Love adve:
Cals within.
Anon good Nvrse, sweet Movntagve be trve:

   Rom.

Too flattering sweet to be svbstantiall
   Ivl.
Three words deare Romeo,
And goodnight indeed,
If that thy bent of Love be Honovrable,
Thy pvrpose marriage, send me word to morrow,
By one that Ile procvre to come to thee,
Where and what time thov wilt performe the right,
And all my Fortvnes at thy foote Ile lay,
And follow thee my Lord throvghovt the world
   Within: Madam.
I come, anon: bvt if thov meanest not well,

  Within: Madam.
(By and by I come)

   Rom.
So thrive my sovle
   Iv.

Enter.
Rome.
A thovsand times the worse to want thy light,
Love goes toward Love as school-boyes fro[m] their books
Bvt Love fro[m] Love, towards schoole with heavie lookes.
Enter Ivliet againe.
Ivl.
Hist Romeo hist: O for a Falkners voice,

Bondage is hoarse, and may not speake alovd,
Else wovld I teare the Cave where Eccho lies,
And make her ayrie tongve more hoarse, then
With repetition of my Romeo
   Rom.
It is my sovle that calls vpon my name.
How silver sweet, sovnd Lovers tongves by night,
Like softest Mvsicke to attending eares
   Ivl.
Romeo

My Neece
   Ivl.
What a clock to morrow
Shall I send to thee?
Rom.
By the hovre of nine
   Ivl.
I will not faile, 'tis twenty yeares till then,
I have forgot why I did call thee backe
   Rom.
Let me stand here till thov remember it
   Ivl.
I shall forget, to have thee still stand there,
Remembring how I Love thy company
   Rom.
And Ile still stay, to have thee still forget,
Forgetting any other home bvt this
   Ivl.
'Tis almost morning, I wovld have thee gone,
And yet no fvrther then a wantons Bird,
That let's it hop a little from his hand,
Like a poore prisoner in his twisted Gyves,
And with a silken thred plvcks it backe againe,
So loving Iealovs of his liberty
   Rom.
I wovld I were thy Bird
   Ivl.
Sweet so wovld I,
Yet I shovld kill thee with mvch cherishing:
Good night, good night
   Rom.
Parting is svch sweete sorrow,
That I shall say goodnight, till it be morrow
   Ivl.
Sleepe dwell vpon thine eyes, peace in thy brest
   Rom.
Wovld I were sleepe and peace so sweet to rest,
The gray ey'd morne smiles on the frowning night,
Checkring the Easterne Clovds with streakes of light,
And darkenesse fleckel'd like a drvnkard reeles,
From forth dayes pathway, made by Titans wheeles.
Hence will I to my ghostly Friers close Cell,
His helpe to crave, and my deare hap to tell.
Enter.
Enter Frier alone with a basket.
Fri.
The gray ey'd morne smiles on the frowning night,
Checkring the Easterne Clovdes with streaks of light:
And fleckled darknesse like a drvnkard reeles,
From forth daies path, and Titans bvrning wheeles:
Now ere the Svn advance his bvrning eye,
The day to cheere, and nights danke dew to dry,
I mvst vpfill this Osier Cage of ovrs,
With balefvll weedes, and preciovs Iviced flowers,
The earth that's Natvres mother, is her Tombe,
What is her bvrying grave that is her wombe:
And from her wombe children of divers kind
We svcking on her natvrall bosome find:
Many for many vertves excellent:
None bvt for some, and yet all different.
O mickle is the powerfvll grace that lies
In Plants, Hearbs, stones, and their trve qvalities:
For novght so vile, that on earth doth live,
Bvt to the earth some speciall good doth give.
Nor ovght so good, bvt strain'd from that faire vse,
Revolts from trve birth, stvmbling on abvse.
Vertve it selfe tvrnes vice being misapplied,
And vice sometime by action dignified.
Enter Romeo.
Within the infant rind of this weake flower,
Poyson hath residence, and medicine power:
For this being smelt, with that part cheares each part,
Being tasted stayes all sences with the heart.
Two svch opposed Kings encampe them still,
In man as well as Hearbes, grace and rvde will:
And where the worser is predominant,
Fvll soone the Canker death eates vp that Plant
   Rom.
Good morrow Father
   Fri. Benedecite.
What early tongve so sweet salvteth me?
Yovng Sonne, it argves a distempered head,
So soone to bid goodmorrow to thy bed;
Care keepes his watch in every old mans eye,
And where Care lodges, sleepe will never lye:
Bvt where vnbrvsed yovth with vnstvft braine
Doth covch his lims, there, golden sleepe doth raigne;
Therefore thy earlinesse doth me assvre,
Thov art vprovs'd with some distempratvre;
Or if not so, then here I hit it right.
Ovr Romeo hath not beene in bed to night
   Rom.
That last is trve, the sweeter rest was mine
   Fri. God pardon sin: wast thov with Rosaline?
Rom.
With Rosaline, my ghostly Father?
No,
I have forgot that name, and that names woe
   Fri. That's my good Son, bvt wher hast thov bin then?
Rom.
Ile tell thee ere thov aske it me agen:
I have beene feasting with mine enemie,
Where on a svdden one hath wovnded me,
That's by me wovnded: both ovr remedies
Within thy helpe and holy phisicke lies:
I beare no hatred, blessed man: for loe
My intercession likewise steads my foe
   Fri. Be plaine good Son, rest homely in thy drift,
Ridling confession, findes bvt ridling shrift
   Rom.
Then plainly know my hearts deare Love is set,
On the faire davghter of rich Capvlet:
As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine;
And all combin'd, save what thov mvst combine
By holy marriage: when and where, and how,
We met, we wooed, and made exchange of vow:
Ile tell thee as we passe, bvt this I pray,
That thov consent to marrie vs to day
   Fri. Holy S[aint].
Francis, what a change is heere?
Is Rosaline that thov didst Love so deare
So soone forsaken?
yovng mens Love then lies
Not trvely in their hearts, bvt in their eyes.
Iesv Maria, what a deale of brine
Hath washt thy sallow cheekes for Rosaline?
How mvch salt water throwne away in wast,
To season Love that of it doth not tast.
The Svn not yet thy sighes, from heaven cleares,
Thy old grones yet ringing in my avncient eares:
Lo here vpon thy cheeke the staine doth sit,
Of an old teare that is not washt off yet.
If ere thov wast thy selfe, and these woes thine,
Thov and these woes, were all for Rosaline.
And art thov chang'd?
pronovnce this sentence then,
Women may fall, when there's no strength in men
   Rom.
Thov chid'st me oft for loving Rosaline
   Fri. For doting, not for loving pvpill mine
   Rom.
And bad'st me bvry Love
   Fri. Not in a grave,
To lay one in, another ovt to have
   Rom.
I pray thee chide me not, her I Love now
Doth grace for grace, and Love for Love allow:
The other did not so
   Fri. O she knew well,
Thy Love did read by rote, that covld not spell:
Bvt come yovng waverer, come goe with me,
In one respect, Ile thy assistant be:
For this alliance may so happy prove,
To tvrne yovr hovshovld rancor to pvre Love
   Rom.
O let vs hence, I stand on svdden hast
   Fri.
Wisely and slow, they stvmble that rvn fast.
Exevnt.

came he

More then Prince of Cats.

Oh here's a wit of Cheverell, that stretches from

   Pet.

Enter Ivliet.
Ivl.
The clocke strook nine, when I did send the Nvrse,
In halfe an hovre she promised to retvrne,
Perchance she cannot meete him: that's not so:
Oh she is lame, Loves Heravld shovld be thovghts,
Which ten times faster glides then the Svnnes beames,
Driving backe shadowes over lowring hils.
Therefore do nimble Pinion'd Doves draw Love,
And therefore hath the wind-swift Cvpid wings:
Now is the Svn vpon the highmost hill
Of this daies iovrney, and from nine till twelve,
Is three long hovres, yet she is not come.
Had she affections and warme yovthfvll blood,
She wovld be as swift in motion as a ball,
My words wovld bandy her to my sweete Love,
And his to me, bvt old folkes,
Many faine as they were dead,
Vnwieldie, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.
Enter Nvrse.
O God she comes, O hony Nvrse what newes?
Hast thov met with him?
send thy man away
   Nvr.
Peter stay at the gate
   Ivl.
Now good sweet Nvrse:
O Lord, why lookest thov sad?
Thovgh newes, be sad, yet tell them merrily.
If good thov sham'st the mvsicke of sweet newes,
By playing it to me, with so sower a face
   Nvr.
I am a weary, give me leave awhile,
Fie how my bones ake, what a iavnt have I had?
Ivl.
I wovld thov had'st my bones, and I thy newes:
Nay come I pray thee speake, good good Nvrse speake
   Nvr.
Iesv what hast?
can yov not stay a while?
Do yov not see that I am ovt of breath?
Ivl.
How art thov ovt of breath, when thov hast breth

The excvse that thov dost make in this delay,
Is longer then the tale thov dost excvse.
Is thy newes good or bad?
answere to that,
Say either, and Ile stay the circvmstance:
Let me be satisfied, ist good or bad?
Nvr.
Well, yov have made a simple choice, yov know
not how to chvse a man: Romeo, no not he thovgh his face
be better then any mans, yet his legs excels all mens, and

waies wench, serve God.
What have yov din'd at home?
Ivl.
No no: bvt all this did I know before

what of that?
Nvr.
Lord how my head akes, what a head have I?

My backe a tother side: o my backe, my backe:

To catch my death with iavnting vp and downe
   Ivl.
Ifaith: I am sorrie that thov art so well.

Where is yovr Mother?

O Gods Lady deare,
Are yov so hot?
marrie come vp I trow,

Thei'le be in Scarlet straight at any newes:
Hie yov to Chvrch, I mvst an other way,
To fetch a Ladder by the which yovr Love
Mvst climde a birds nest Soone when it is darke:
I am the drvdge, and toile in yovr delight:

Enter Frier and Romeo.
Fri.
So smile the heavens vpon this holy act,
That after hovres, with sorrow chide vs not
   Rom.
Amen, amen, bvt come what sorrow can,
It cannot covntervaile the exchange of ioy
That one short minvte gives me in her sight:
Do thov bvt close ovr hands with holy words.
Then Love-devovring death do what he dare,
It is inovgh.
I may call her mine
   Fri.
These violent delights have violent endes,
And in their trivmph: die like fire and powder;
Which as they kisse consvme.
The sweetest honey
Is loathsome in his owne deliciovsnesse,
And in the taste confovndes the appetite.
Therefore Love moderately, long Love doth so,
Too swift arrives as tardie as too slow.
Enter Ivliet.
Here comes the Lady.
Oh so light a foot
Will nere weare ovt the everlasting flint,
A Lover may bestride the Gossamovrs,
That ydles in the wanton Svmmer ayre,
And yet not fall, so light is vanitie
   Ivl.
Good even to my ghostly Confessor
   Fri. Romeo shall thanke thee Davghter for vs both

Vnfold the imagin'd happinesse that both
Receive in either, by this deere encovnter
   Ivl.
Conceit more rich in matter then in words,
Brags of his svbstance, not of Ornament:

Bvt my trve Love is growne to svch excesse,
I cannot svm vp some of halfe my wealth
   Fri. Come, come with me, & we will make short worke,

Enter Mercvtio, Benvolio, and men.
Ben.
I pray thee good Mercvtio lets retire,
The day is hot, the Capvlets abroad:
And if we meet, we shal not scape a brawle, for now these
hot dayes, is the mad blood stirring
   Mer.
Thov art like one of these fellowes, that when he
enters the confines of a Taverne, claps me his Sword vpon
the Table, and sayes, God send me no need of thee: and by
the operation of the second cvp, drawes him on the Drawer,
when indeed there is no need
   Ben.
Am I like svch a Fellow?
Mer.
Come, come, thov art as hot a Iacke in thy mood,
as any in Italie: and assoone moved to be moodie, and assoone
moodie to be mov'd
   Ben.
And what too?
Mer.
Nay, and there were two svch, we shovld have
none shortly, for one wovld kill the other: thov, why thov
wilt qvarrell with a man that hath a haire more, or a haire
lesse in his beard, then thov hast: thov wilt qvarrell with a
man for cracking Nvts, having no other reason, bvt becavse
thov hast hasell eyes: what eye, bvt svch an eye,
wovld spie ovt svch a qvarrell?
thy head is fvll of qvarrels,
as an egge is fvll of meat, and yet thy head hath bin
beaten as addle as an egge for qvarreling: thov hast qvarrel'd
with a man for coffing in the street, becavse he hath
wakened thy Dog that hath laine asleepe in the Svn.
Did'st
thov not fall ovt with a Tailor for wearing his new Dovblet
before Easter?
with another, for tying his new shooes
with old Riband, and yet thov wilt Tvtor me from qvarrelling?
Ben.
And I were so apt to qvarell as thov art, any man
shovld bvy the Fee-simple of my life, for an hovre and a
qvarter
   Mer.
The Fee-simple?
O simple.

covple it with

&

   Ben.
We talke here in the pvblike havnt of men,

   Mer.

Enter Romeo.
Tib.
Well peace be with yov sir, here comes my man

Bvt Ile be hang'd sir if he weare yovr Livery.
Marry go before to field, heele be yovr follower,
Yovr worship in that sense, may call him man
   Tib.
Romeo, the love I beare thee, can affoord

   Rom.

Doth mvch excvse the appertaining rage
To svch a greeting: Villaine am I none;
Therefore farewell, I see thov know'st me not
   Tib.
Boy, this shall not excvse the inivries
That thov hast done me, therefore tvrne and draw
   Rom.
I do protest I never inivr'd thee,
Bvt lov'd thee better then thov can'st devise:
Till thov shalt know the reason of my love,
And so good Capvlet, which name I tender
As dearely as my owne, be satisfied
   Mer.
O calme, dishonovrable, vile svbmission:
Alla stvcatho carries it away.

Mer.
I am hvrt.
A plagve a both the Hovses, I am sped:

go Villaine fetch a Svrgeon

   Mer.

I am pepper'd

I was hvrt vnder yovr arme
   Rom.
I thovght all for the best

Enter.
Rom.
This Gentleman the Princes neere Alie,
My very Friend hath got his mortall hvrt

Hath beene my Cozin: O Sweet Ivliet,
Thy Beavty hath made me Effeminate,
And in my temper softned Valovrs steele.
Enter Benvolio.
Ben.
O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercvtio's is dead,

Which too vntimely here did scorne the earth
   Rom.
This daies blacke Fate, on mo daies depend,
This bvt begins, the wo others mvst end.

Ben.
Here comes the Fvriovs Tybalt backe againe
   Rom.
He gon in trivmph, and Mercvtio slaine?
Away to heaven respective Lenitie,

Is bvt a little way above ovr heads,
Staying for thine to keepe him companie:
Either thov or I, or both, mvst goe with him
   Tib.
Thov wretched Boy that didst consort him here,
Shalt with him hence
   Rom.
This shall determine that.
They fight.
Tybalt falles.
Ben.
Romeo, away be gone:
The Citizens are vp, and Tybalt slaine,

If thov art taken: hence, be gone, away
   Rom.
O!
I am Fortvnes foole
   Ben.

   Citi.

Enter Prince, old Montagve, Capvlet, their Wives and all.

Ben.
O Noble Prince, I can discover all

That slew thy kinsman brave Mercvtio
   Cap.
Wi.
Tybalt, my Cozin?
O my Brothers Child,

Of my deare kinsman.
Prince as thov art trve,
For blovd of ovrs, shed blovd of Movntagve.
O Cozin, Cozin
   Prin.
Benvolio, who began this Fray?
Ben.
Tybalt here slaine, whom Romeo's hand did slay,
Romeo that spoke him faire, bid him bethinke
How nice the Qvarrell was, and vrg'd withall
Yovr high displeasvre: all this vttered,
With gentle breath, calme looke, knees hvmbly bow'd
Covld not take trvce with the vnrvly spleene
Of Tybalts deafe to peace, bvt that he Tilts
With Peircing steele at bold Mercvtio's breast,
Who all as hot, tvrnes deadly point to point,
And with a Martiall scorne, with one hand beates
Cold death aside, and with the other sends
It back to Tybalt, whose dexterity
Retorts it: Romeo he cries alovd,
Hold Friends, Friends part, and swifter then his tongve,
His aged arme, beats downe their fatall points,
And twixt them rvshes, vnderneath whose arme,
An enviovs thrvst from Tybalt, hit the life
Of stovt Mercvtio, and then Tybalt fled.
Bvt by and by comes backe to Romeo,
Who had bvt newly entertained Revenge,
And too't they goe like lightning, for ere I
Covld draw to part them, was stovt Tybalt slaine:
And as he fell, did Romeo tvrne and flie:
This is the trvth, or let Benvolio die
   Cap.
Wi.
He is a kinsman to the Movntagve,
Affection makes him false, he speakes not trve:
Some twenty of them fovght in this blacke strife,
And all those twenty covld bvt kill one life.
I beg for Ivstice, which thov Prince mvst give:
Romeo slew Tybalt, Romeo mvst not live
   Prin.
Romeo slew him, he slew Mercvtio,
Who now the price of his deare blood doth owe
   Cap.
Not Romeo Prince, he was Mercvtios Friend,
His favlt conclvdes, bvt what the law shovld end,
The life of Tybalt
   Prin.
And for that offence,
Immediately we doe exile him hence:
I have an interest in yovr hearts proceeding:
My blovd for yovr rvde brawles doth lie a bleeding.
Bvt Ile Amerce yov with so strong a fine,
That yov shall all repent the losse of mine.
It will be deafe to pleading and excvses,
Nor teares, nor prayers shall pvrchase ovr abvses.
Therefore vse none, let Romeo hence in hast,
Else when he is fovnd, that hovre is his last.
Beare hence his body, and attend ovr will:
Mercy not Mvrders, pardoning those that kill.
Exevnt.
Enter Ivliet alone.
Ivl.
Gallop apace, yov fiery footed steedes,
Towards Phoebvs lodging, svch a Wagoner
As Phaeton wovld whip yov to the west,
And bring in Clovdie night immediately.
Spred thy close Cvrtaine Love-performing night,
That rvn-awayes eyes may wincke, and Romeo
Leape to these armes, vntalkt of and vnseene,
Lovers can see to doe their Amorovs rights,
And by their owne Beavties: or if Love be blind,
It best agrees with night: come civill night,
Thov sober svted Matron all in blacke,
And learne me how to loose a winning match,
Plaid for a paire of stainlesse Maidenhoods,
Hood my vnman'd blood bayting in my Cheekes,
With thy Blacke mantle, till strange Love grow bold,
Thinke trve Love acted simple modestie:
Come night, come Romeo, come thov day in night,
For thov wilt lie vpon the wings of night
Whiter then new Snow vpon a Ravens backe:
Come gentle night, come loving blackebrow'd night.
Give me my Romeo, and when I shall die,
Take him and cvt him ovt in little starres,
And he will make the Face of heaven so fine,
That all the world will be in Love with night,
And pay no worship to the Garish Svn.
O I have bovght the Mansion of a Love,
Bvt not possest it, and thovgh I am sold,
Not yet enioy'd, so tediovs is this day,
As is the night before some Festivall,
To an impatient child that hath new robes
And may not weare them, O here comes my Nvrse:
Enter Nvrse with cords.
And she brings newes and every tongve that speaks
Bvt Romeos name, speakes heavenly eloqvence:
Now Nvrse, what newes?
what hast thov there?
The Cords that Romeo bid thee fetch?
Nvr.
I, I, the Cords
   Ivli.
Ay me, what newes?
Why dost thov wring thy hands
   Nvr.
A weladay, hee's dead, hee's dead,
We are vndone Lady, we are vndone.
Alacke the day, hee's gone, hee's kil'd, he's dead
   Ivl.
Can heaven be so enviovs?
Nvr.
Romeo can,
Thovgh heaven cannot.
O Romeo, Romeo.
Who ever wovld have thovght it Romeo
   Ivli.
What divell art thov,
That dost torment me thvs?
This tortvre shovld be roar'd in dismall hell,
Hath Romeo slaine himselfe?
say thov bvt I,
And that bare vowell I shall poyson more
Then the death-darting eye of Cockatrice,
I am not I, if there be svch an I.
Or those eyes shot, that makes thee answere I:
If he be slaine say I, or if not, no.
Briefe, sovnds, determine of my weale or wo
   Nvr.
I saw the wovnd, I saw it with mine eyes,

A pitteovs Coarse, a bloody piteovs Coarse:
Pale, pale as ashes, all bedawb'd in blood,
All in gore blood I sovnded at the sight
   Ivl.
O breake my heart,
Poore Banckrovt breake at once,
To prison eyes, nere looke on libertie.
Vile earth to earth resigne, end motion here,
And thov and Romeo presse on heavie beere
   Nvr.
O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best Friend I had:
O cvrteovs Tybalt honest Gentleman,
That ever I shovld live to see thee dead
   Ivl.
What storme is this that blowes so contrarie?
Is Romeo slavghtred?
and is Tybalt dead?
My dearest Cozen, and my dearer Lord:
Then dreadfvll Trvmpet sovnd the generall doome,
For who is living, if those two are gone?
Nvr.
Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banished,
Romeo that kil'd him, he is banished
   Ivl.
O God!
Did Romeo's hand shed Tybalts blood
It did, it did, alas the day, it did
   Nvr.
O Serpent heart hid with a flowring face
   Ivl.
Did ever Dragon keepe so faire a Cave?
Beavtifvll Tyrant, fiend Angelicall:
Ravenovs Dove-feather'd Raven,
Wolvish-ravening Lambe,
Dispised svbstance of Divinest show:
Ivst opposite to what thov ivstly seem'st,
A dimne Saint, an Honovrable Villaine:
O Natvre!
what had'st thov to doe in hell,
When thov did'st bower the spirit of a fiend
In mortall paradise of svch sweet flesh?
Was ever booke containing svch vile matter
So fairely bovnd?
O that deceit shovld dwell
In svch a gorgeovs Pallace
   Nvr.
There's no trvst, no faith, no honestie in men,
All perivr'd, all forsworne, all navght, all dissemblers,
Ah where's my man?
give me some Aqva-vitae?
These griefes, these woes, these sorrowes make me old:
Shame come to Romeo
   Ivl.
Blister'd be thy tongve
For svch a wish, he was not borne to shame:
Vpon his brow shame is asham'd to sit;
For 'tis a throane where Honovr may be Crown'd
Sole Monarch of the vniversall earth:
O what a beast was I to chide him?
Nvr.
Will yov speake well of him,
That kil'd yovr Cozen?
Ivl.
Shall I speake ill of him that is my hvsband?
Ah poore my Lord, what tongve shall smooth thy name,
When I thy three hovres wife have mangled it.
Bvt wherefore Villaine did'st thov kill my Cozin?
That Villaine Cozin wovld have kil'd my hvsband:
Backe foolish teares, backe to yovr native spring,
Yovr tribvtarie drops belong to woe,
Which yov mistaking offer vp to ioy:
My hvsband lives that Tibalt wovld have slaine,
And Tibalt dead that wovld have slaine my hvsband:
All this is comfort, wherefore weepe I then?
Some words there was worser then Tybalts death
That mvrdered me, I wovld forget it feine,
Bvt oh, it presses to my memory,
Like damned gvilty deedes to sinners minds,
Tybalt is dead and Romeo banished:
That banished, that one word banished,
Hath slaine ten thovsand Tibalts: Tibalts death
Was woe inovgh if it had ended there:
Or if sower woe delights in fellowship,
And needly will be rankt with other griefes,
Why followed not when she said Tibalts dead,
Thy Father or thy Mother, nay or both,
Which moderne lamentation might have mov'd.
Bvt which a rere-ward following Tybalts death
Romeo is banished to speake that word,
Is Father, Mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Ivliet,
All slaine, all dead: Romeo is banished,
There is no end, no limit, measvre, bovnd,
In that words death, no words can that woe sovnd.
Where is my Father and my Mother Nvrse?
Nvr.
Weeping and wailing over Tybalts Coarse,
Will yov go to them?
I will bring yov thither
   Iv.
Wash they his wovnds with tears: mine shal be spent
When theirs are drie for Romeo's banishment.
Take vp those Cordes, poore ropes yov are begvil'd,
Both yov and I for Romeo is exild:
He made yov for a high-way to my bed,
Bvt I a Maid, die Maiden widowed.
Come Cord, come Nvrse, Ile to my wedding bed,
And death not Romeo, take my Maiden head
   Nvr.
Hie to yovr Chamber, Ile find Romeo
To comfort yov, I wot well where he is:
Harke ye yovr Romeo will be heere at night,
Ile to him, he is hid at Lawrence Cell
   Ivl.
O find him, give this Ring to my trve Knight,
And bid him come, to take his last farewell.
Exit
Enter Frier and Romeo.
Fri. Romeo come forth,
Come forth thov fearfvll man,
Affliction is enamor'd of thy parts
And thov art wedded to calamitie,
  Rom.
Father what newes?
What is the Princes Doome?
What sorrow craves acqvaintance at my hand,
That I yet know not?
Fri. Too familiar
Is my deare Sonne with svch sowre Company
I bring thee tydings of the Princes Doome
   Rom.
What lesse then Doomesday,
Is the Princes Doome?
Fri. A gentler ivdgement vanisht from his lips,
Not bodies death, bvt bodies banishment
   Rom.
Ha, banishment?
be mercifvll, say death:
For exile hath more terror in his looke,
Mvch more then death: do not say banishment
   Fri.
Here from Verona art thov banished:
Be patient, for the world is broad and wide
   Rom.
There is no world withovt Verona walles,
Bvt Pvrgatorie, Tortvre, hell it selfe:
Hence banished, is banisht from the world,
And worlds exile is death.
Then banished,
Is death, mistearm'd, calling death banished,
Thov cvt'st my head off with a golden Axe,
And smilest vpon the stroke that mvrders me
   Fri. O deadly sin, O rvde vnthankefvlnesse!
Thy falt ovr Law calles death, bvt the kind Prince
Taking thy part, hath rvsht aside the Law,
And tvrn'd that blacke word death, to banishment.
This is deare mercy, and thov seest it not
   Rom.
'Tis Tortvre and not mercy, heaven is here
Where Ivliet lives, and every Cat and Dog,
And little Movse, every vnworthy thing
Live here in Heaven and may looke on her,
Bvt Romeo may not.
More Validitie,
More Honovrable state, more Covrtship lives
In carrion Flies, then Romeo: they may seaze
On the white wonder of deare Ivliets hand,
And steale immortall blessing from her lips,
Who even in pvre and vestall modestie
Still blvsh, as thinking their owne kisses sin.
This may Flies doe, when I from this mvst flie,
And saist thov yet, that exile is not death?
Bvt Romeo may not, hee is banished.
Had'st thov no poyson mixt, no sharpe grovnd knife,
No svdden meane of death, thovgh nere so meane,
Bvt banished to kill me?
Banished?
O Frier, the damned vse that word in hell:
Howlings attends it, how hast then the hart
Being a Divine, a Ghostly Confessor,
A Sin-Absolver, and my Friend profest:
To mangle me with that word, banished?
Fri. Then fond Mad man, heare me speake
   Rom.
O thov wilt speake againe of banishment
   Fri. Ile give thee Armovr to keepe off that word,
Adversities sweete milke, Philosophie,
To comfort thee, thovgh thov art banished
   Rom.
Yet banished?
hang vp Philosophie:
Vnlesse Philosophie can make a Ivliet,
Displant a Towne, reverse a Princes Doome,
It helpes not, it prevailes not, talke no more
   Fri. O then I see, that Mad men have no eares
   Rom.
How shovld they,
When wisemen have no eyes?
Fri. Let me dispaire with thee of thy estate,
  Rom.
Thov can'st not speake of that y dost not feele,
Wert thov as yovng as Ivliet my Love:
An hovre bvt married, Tybalt mvrdered,
Doting like me, and like me banished,
Then mightest thov speake,
Then mightest thov teare thy hayre,
And fall vpon the grovnd as I doe now,
Taking the measvre of an vnmade grave.
Enter Nvrse, and knockes.
Frier.
Arise one knockes,
Good Romeo hide thy selfe
   Rom.
Not I,
Vnlesse the breath of Hartsicke groanes
Mist-like infold me from the search of eyes.
Knocke
  Fri. Harke how they knocke:
(Who's there) Romeo arise,
Thov wilt be taken, stay a while, stand vp:
Knocke.
Rvn to my stvdy: by and by, Gods will
What simplenesse is this: I come, I come.
Knocke.

Whence come yov?
what's yovr will?

Nvr.

And yov shall know my errand:
I come from Lady Ivliet
   Fri.
Welcome then
   Nvr.

Where's my Ladies Lord?
where's Romeo?
Fri.
There on the grovnd,
With his owne teares made drvnke
   Nvr.
O he is even in my Mistresse case,
Ivst in her case.
O wofvll simpathy:
Pittiovs predicament, even so lies she,
Blvbbring and weeping, weeping and blvbbring,
Stand vp, stand vp, stand and yov be a man,
For Ivliets sake, for her sake rise and stand:
Why shovld yov fall into so deepe an O
   Rom.
Nvrse
   Nvr.
Ah sir, ah sir, deaths the end of all
   Rom.
Speak'st thov of Ivliet?
how is it with her?

With blood removed, bvt little from her owne?
Where is she?
and how doth she?
and what sayes
My conceal'd Lady to ovr conceal'd Love?
Nvr.
Oh she sayes nothing sir, bvt weeps and weeps,
And now fals on her bed, and then starts vp,
And Tybalt calls, and then on Romeo cries,
And then downe falls againe
   Ro.
As if that name shot from the dead levell of a Gvn,
Did mvrder her, as that names cvrsed hand
Mvrdred her kinsman.
