In what vile part of this Anatomie
Doth my name lodge?
Tell me, that I may sacke
The hatefvll Mansion
   Fri.
Hold thy desperate hand:
Art thov a man?
thy forme cries ovt thov art:
Thy teares are womanish, thy wild acts denote
The vnreasonable Fvrie of a beast.
Vnseemely woman, in a seeming man,
And ill beseeming beast in seeming both,
Thov hast amaz'd me.
By my holy order,
I thovght thy disposition better temper'd.
Hast thov slaine Tybalt?
wilt thov slay thy selfe?
And slay thy Lady, that in thy life lies,
By doing damned hate vpon thy selfe?
Why rayl'st thov on thy birth?
the heaven and earth?
Since birth, and heaven and earth, all three do meete
In thee at once, which thov at once wovld'st loose.
Fie, fie, thov sham'st thy shape, thy love, thy wit,
Which like a Vsvrer abovnd'st in all:
And vsest none in that trve vse indeed,
Which shovld bedecke thy shape, thy love, thy wit:
Thy Noble shape, is bvt a forme of waxe,
Digressing from the Valovr of a man,
Thy deare Love sworne bvt hollow perivrie,
Killing that Love which thov hast vow'd to cherish.
Thy wit, that Ornament, to shape and Love,
Mishapen in the condvct of them both:
Like powder in a skillesse Sovldiers flaske,
Is set a fire by thine owne ignorance,
And thov dismembred with thine owne defence.
What, rowse thee man, thy Ivliet is alive,
For whose deare sake thov wast bvt lately dead.
There art thov happy.
Tybalt wovld kill thee,
Bvt thov slew'st Tybalt, there art thov happie.
The law that threatned death became thy Friend.
And tvrn'd it to exile, there art thov happy.
A packe or blessing light vpon thy backe,
Happinesse Covrts thee in her best array,
Bvt like a mishaped and svllen wench,
Thov pvttest vp thy Fortvne and thy Love:
Take heed, take heed, for svch die miserable.
Goe get thee to thy Love as was decreed,
Ascend her Chamber, hence and comfort her:
Bvt looke thov stay not till the watch be set,
For then thov canst not passe to Mantva,
Where thov shalt live till we can finde a time
To blaze yovr marriage, reconcile yovr Friends,
Beg pardon of thy Prince, and call thee backe,
With twenty hvndred thovsand times more ioy
Then thov went'st forth in lamentation.
Goe before Nvrse, commend me to thy Lady,
And bid her hasten all the hovse to bed,
Which heavy sorrow makes them apt vnto.
Romeo is comming
   Nvr.
O Lord, I covld have staid here all night,
To heare good covnsell: oh what learning is!
My Lord Ile tell my Lady yov will come
   Rom.
Do so, and bid my Sweete prepare to chide
   Nvr.
Heere sir, a Ring she bid me give yov sir:
Hie yov, make hast, for it growes very late
   Rom.
How well my comfort is reviv'd by this
   Fri. Go hence,
Goodnight, and here stands all yovr state:
Either be gone before the watch be set,
Or by the breake of day disgvis'd from hence,
Soiovrne in Mantva, Ile find ovt yovr man,
And he shall signifie from time to time,
Every good hap to yov, that chavnces heere:
Give me thy hand, 'tis late, farewell, goodnight
   Rom.
Bvt that a ioy past ioy, calls ovt on me,
It were a griefe, so briefe to part with thee:
Farewell.
Exevnt.
Enter old Capvlet, his Wife and Paris.
Cap.
Things have falne ovt sir so vnlvckily,
That we have had no time to move ovr Davghter:
Looke yov, she Lov'd her kinsman Tybalt dearely,
And so did I.
Well, we were borne to die.
'Tis very late, she'l not come downe to night:
I promise yov, bvt for yovr company,
I wovld have bin a bed an hovre ago
   Par.
These times of wo, affoord no times to wooe:
Madam goodnight, commend me to yovr Davghter
   Lady.
I will, and know her mind early to morrow,
To night, she is mewed vp to her heavinesse
   Cap.
Sir Paris, I will make a desperate tender
Of my Childes love: I thinke she will be rvl'd
In all respects by me: nay more, I dovbt it not.
Wife, go yov to her ere yov go to bed,
Acqvaint her here, of my Sonne Paris Love,
And bid her, marke yov me, on Wendsday next,
Bvt soft, what day is this?
Par.
Monday my Lord
   Cap.
Monday, ha ha: well Wendsday is too soone,
A Thvrsday let it be: a Thvrsday tell her,
She shall be married to this Noble Earle:
Will yov be ready?
do yov like this hast?
Weele keepe no great adoe, a Friend or two,
For harke yov, Tybalt being slaine so late,
It may be thovght we held him carelesly,
Being ovr kinsman, if we revell mvch:
Therefore weele have some halfe a dozen Friends,
And there an end.
Bvt what say yov to Thvrsday?
Paris.
My Lord,
I wovld that Thvrsday were to morrow
   Cap.
Well, get yov gone, a Thvrsday, be it then:
Go yov to Ivliet ere yov go to bed,
Prepare her wife, against this wedding day.
Farewell my Lord, light to my Chamber hoa,
Afore me, it is so late, that we may call it early by and by,
Goodnight.
Exevnt.
Enter Romeo and Ivliet aloft.
Ivl.
Wilt thov be gone?
It is not yet neere day:
It was the Nightingale, and not the Larke,
That pier'st the fearefvll hollow of thine eare,
Nightly she sings on yond Pomgranet tree,
Beleeve me Love, it was the Nightingale
   Rom.
It was the Larke the Heravld of the Morne:
No Nightingale: looke Love what enviovs streakes
Do lace the severing Clovdes in yonder East:
Nights Candles are bvrnt ovt, and Iocond day
Stands tipto on the mistie Movntaines tops,
I mvst be gone and live, or stay and die
   Ivl.
Yond light is not daylight, I know it I:
It is some Meteor that the Svn exhales,
To be to thee this night a Torch-bearer,
And light thee on thy way to Mantva.
Therefore stay yet, thov need'st not be gone,
  Rom.
Let me be tane, let me be pvt to death,
I am content, so thov wilt have it so.
Ile say yon gray is not the mornings eye,
'Tis bvt the pale reflexe of Cinthias brow.
Nor that is not Larke whose noates do beate
The vavlty heaven so high above ovr heads,
I have more care to stay, then will to go:
Come death and welcome, Ivliet wills it so.
How ist my sovle, lets talke, it is not day
   Ivli.
It is, it is, hie hence be gone away:
It is the Larke that sings so ovt of tvne,
Straining harsh Discords, and vnpleasing Sharpes.
Some say the Larke makes sweete Division;
This doth not so: for she divideth vs.
Some say, the Larke and loathed Toad change eyes,
O now I wovld they had chang'd voyces too:
Since arme from arme that voyce doth vs affray,
Hvnting thee hence, with Hvnts-vp to the day,
O now be gone, more light and it light growes
   Rom.
More light & light, more darke & darke ovr woes.
Enter Madam and Nvrse.
Nvr.
Madam
   Ivl.
Nvrse
   Nvr.
Yovr Lady Mother is comming to yovr chamber,
The day is broke, be wary, looke abovt
   Ivl.
Then window let day in, and let life ovt
   Rom.
Farewell, farewell, one kisse and Ile descend
   Ivl.
Art thov gone so?
Love, Lord, ay Hvsband, Friend,
I mvst heare from thee every day in the hovre,
For in a minvte there are many dayes,
O by this covnt I shall be mvch in yeares,
Ere I againe behold my Romeo
   Rom.
Farewell:
I will omit no oportvnitie,
That may convey my greetings Love, to thee
   Ivl.
O thinkest thov we shall ever meet againe?
Rom.
I dovbt it not, and all these woes shall serve
For sweet discovrses in ovr time to come
   Ivliet.
O God!
I have an ill Divining sovle,
Me thinkes I see thee now, thov art so lowe,
As one dead in the bottome of a Tombe,
Either my eye-sight failes, or thov look'st pale
   Rom.
And trvst me Love, in my eye so do yov:
Drie sorrow drinkes ovr blood.
Adve, adve.
Enter.
Ivl.
O Fortvne, Fortvne, all men call thee fickle,
If thov art fickle, what dost thov with him
That is renown'd for faith?
be fickle Fortvne:
For then I hope thov wilt not keepe him long,
Bvt send him backe.
Enter Mother.
Lad.
Ho Davghter, are yov vp?
Ivl.
Who ist that calls?
Is it my Lady Mother.
Is she not downe so late, or vp so early?
What vnaccvstom'd cavse procvres her hither?
Lad.
Why how now Ivliet?
Ivl.
Madam I am not well
   Lad.
Evermore weeping for yovr Cozins death?
What wilt thov wash him from his grave with teares?
And if thov covld'st, thov covld'st not make him live:
Therefore have done, some griefe shewes mvch of Love,
Bvt mvch of griefe, shewes still some want of wit
   Ivl.
Yet let me weepe, for svch a feeling losse
   Lad.
So shall yov feele the losse, bvt not the Friend
Which yov weepe for
   Ivl.
Feeling so the losse,
I cannot chvse bvt ever weepe the Friend
   La.
Well Girle, thov weep'st not so mvch for his death,
As that the Villaine lives which slavghter'd him
   Ivl.
What Villaine, Madam?
Lad.
That same Villaine Romeo
   Ivl.
Villaine and he, be many miles assvnder:
God pardon, I doe with all my heart:
And yet no man like he, doth grieve my heart
   Lad.
That is becavse the Traitor lives
   Ivl.
I Madam from the reach of these my hands:
Wovld none bvt I might venge my Cozins death
   Lad.
We will have vengeance for it, feare thov not.
Then weepe no more, Ile send to one in Mantva,
Where that same banisht Rvn-agate doth live,
Shall give him svch an vnaccvstom'd dram,
That he shall soone keepe Tybalt company:
And then I hope thov wilt be satisfied
   Ivl.
Indeed I never shall be satisfied
With Romeo, till I behold him.
Dead
Is my poore heart so for a kinsman vext:
Madam, if yov covld find ovt bvt a man
To beare a poyson, I wovld temper it;
That Romeo shovld vpon receit thereof,
Soone sleepe in qviet.
O how my heart abhors
To heare him nam'd, and cannot come to him,
To wreake the Love I bore my Cozin,
Vpon his body that hath slavghter'd him
   Mo.
Find thov the meanes, and Ile find svch a man.
Bvt now Ile tell thee ioyfvll tidings Gyrle
   Ivl.
And ioy comes well, in svch a needy time,
What are they, beseech yovr Ladyship?
Mo.
Well, well, thov hast a carefvll Father Child?
One who to pvt thee from thy heavinesse,
Hath sorted ovt a svdden day of ioy,
That thov expects not, nor I lookt not for
   Ivl.
Madam in happy time, what day is this?
Mo.
Marry my Child, early next Thvrsday morne,
The gallant, yovng, and Noble Gentleman,
The Covntie Paris at Saint Peters Chvrch,
Shall happily make thee a ioyfvll Bride
   Ivl.
Now by Saint Peters Chvrch, and Peter too,
He shall not make me there a ioyfvll Bride.
I wonder at this hast, that I mvst wed
Ere he that shovld be Hvsband comes to woe:
I pray yov tell my Lord and Father Madam,
I will not marrie yet, and when I doe, I sweare
It shall be Romeo, whom yov know I hate
Rather then Paris.
These are newes indeed
   Mo.
Here comes yovr Father, tell him so yovr selfe,
And see how he will take it at yovr hands.
Enter Capvlet and Nvrse.
Cap.
When the Svn sets, the earth doth drizzle deaw
Bvt for the Svnset of my Brothers Sonne,
It raines downright.
How now?
A Condvit Gyrle, what still in teares?
Evermore showring in one little body?
Thov covnterfaits a Barke, a Sea, a Wind:
For still thy eyes, which I may call the Sea,
Do ebbe and flow with teares, the Barke thy body is
Sayling in this salt flovd, the windes thy sighes,
Who raging with the teares and they with them,
Withovt a svdden calme will over set
Thy tempest tossed body.
How now wife?
Have yov delivered to her ovr decree?
Lady.
I sir;
Bvt she will none, she gives yov thankes,
I wovld the foole were married to her grave
   Cap.
Soft, take me with yov, take me with yov wife,
How, will she none?
doth she not give vs thanks?
Is she not provd?
doth she not covnt her blest,
Vnworthy as she is, that we have wrovght
So worthy a Gentleman, to be her Bridegroome
  Ivl.
Not provd yov have,
Bvt thankfvll that yov have:
Provd can I never be of what I have,
Bvt thankfvll even for hate, that is meant Love
   Cap.
How now?
How now?
Chopt Logicke?
what is this?
Provd, and I thanke yov: and I thanke yov not.
Thanke me no thankings, nor provd me no provds,
Bvt fettle yovr fine ioints 'gainst Thvrsday next,
To go with Paris to Saint Peters Chvrch:
Or I will drag thee, on a Hvrdle thither.
Ovt yov greene sicknesse carrion, ovt yov baggage,
Yov tallow face
   Lady.
Fie, fie, what are yov mad?
Ivl.
Good Father, I beseech yov on my knees
Heare me with patience, bvt to speake a word
   Fa.
Hang thee yovng baggage, disobedient wretch,
I tell thee what, get thee to Chvrch a Thvrsday,
Or never after looke me in the face.
Speake not, reply not, do not answere me.
My fingers itch, wife: we scarce thovght vs blest,
That God had lent vs bvt this onely Child,
Bvt now I see this one is one too mvch,
And that we have a cvrse in having her:
Ovt on her Hilding
   Nvr.
God in heaven blesse her,
Yov are too blame my Lord to rate her so
   Fa.
And why my Lady wisedome?
hold yovr tongve,
Good Prvdence, smatter with yovr gossip, go
   Nvr.
I speak no treason,
Father, O Godigoden,
May not one speake?
Fa.
Peace yov mvmbling foole,
Vtter yovr gravitie ore a Gossips bowles
For here we need it not
   La.
Yov are too hot
   Fa.
Gods bread, it makes me mad:
Day, night, hovre, ride, time, worke, play,
Alone in companie, still my care hath bin
To have her matcht, and having now provided
A Gentleman of Noble Parentage,
Of faire Demeanes, Yovthfvll, and Nobly Allied,
Stvft as they say with Honovrable parts,
Proportion'd as ones thovght wovld wish a man,
And then to have a wretched pvling foole,
A whining mammet, in her Fortvnes tender,
To answer, Ile not wed, I cannot Love:
I am too yovng, I pray yov pardon me.
Bvt, and yov will not wed, Ile pardon yov.
Graze where yov will, yov shall not hovse with me:
Looke too't, thinke on't, I do not vse to iest.
Thvrsday is neere, lay hand on heart, advise,
And yov be mine, Ile give yov to my Friend:
And yov be not, hang, beg, starve, die in the streets,
For by my sovle, Ile nere acknowledge thee,
Nor what is mine shall never do thee good:
Trvst too't, bethinke yov, Ile not be forsworne
Enter.
Ivli.
Is there no pittie sitting in the Clovdes,
That sees into the bottome of my griefe?
O sweet my Mother cast me not away,
Delay this marriage, for a month, a weeke,
Or if yov do not, make the Bridall bed
In that dim Monvment where Tybalt lies
   Mo.
Talke not to me, for Ile not speake a word,
Do as thov wilt, for I have done with thee.
Enter.
Ivl.
O God!
O Nvrse, how shall this be prevented?
My Hvsband is on earth, my faith in heaven,
How shall that faith retvrne againe to earth,
Vnlesse that Hvsband send it me from heaven,
By leaving earth?
Comfort me, covnsaile me:
Alacke, alacke, that heaven shovld practise stratagems
Vpon so soft a svbiect as my selfe.
What saist thov?
hast thov not a word of ioy?
Some comfort Nvrse
   Nvr.
Faith here it is,
Romeo is banished, and all the world to nothing,
That he dares nere come backe to challenge yov:
Or if he do, it needs mvst be by stealth.
Then since the case so stands as now it doth,
I thinke it best yov married with the Covntie,
O hee's a Lovely Gentleman:
Romeos a dish-clovt to him: an Eagle Madam
Hath not so greene, so qvicke, so faire an eye
As Paris hath, beshrow my very heart,
I thinke yov are happy in this second match,
For it excels yovr first: or if it did not,
Yovr first is dead, or 'twere as good he were,
As living here and yov no vse of him
   Ivl.
Speakest thov from thy heart?
Nvr.
And from my sovle too,
Or else beshrew them both
   Ivl.
Amen
   Nvr.
What?
Ivl.
Well, thov hast comforted me marve'lovs mvch,
Go in, and tell my Lady I am gone,
Having displeas'd my Father, to Lawrence Cell,
To make confession, and to be absolv'd
   Nvr.
Marrie I will, and this is wisely done
   Ivl.
Avncient damnation, O most wicked fiend!
It is more sin to wish me thvs forsworne,
Or to dispraise my Lord with that same tongve
Which she hath prais'd him with above compare,
So many thovsand times?
Go Covnsellor,
Thov and my bosom henceforth shall be twaine:
Ile to the Frier to know his remedie,
If all else faile, my selfe have power to die.
Exevnt.
Enter Frier and Covntie Paris.
Fri. On Thvrsday sir?
the time is very short
   Par.
My Father Capvlet will have it so,
And I am nothing slow to slack his hast
   Fri. Yov say yov do not know the Ladies mind?
Vneven is the covrse, I like it not
   Pa. Immoderately she weepes for Tybalts death,
And therfore have I little talke of Love,
For Venvs smiles not in a hovse of teares.
Now sir, her Father covnts it dangerovs
That she doth give her sorrow so mvch sway:
And in his wisedome, hasts ovr marriage,
To stop the invndation of her teares,
Which too mvch minded by her selfe alone,
May be pvt from her by societie.
Now doe yov know the reason of this hast?
Fri.
I wovld I knew not why it shovld be slow'd.
Looke sir, here comes the Lady towards my Cell.
Enter Ivliet.
Par.
Happily met, my Lady and my wife
   Ivl.
That may be sir, when I may be a wife
   Par.
That may be, mvst be Love, on Thvrsday next
   Ivl.
What mvst be shall be
   Fri. That's a certaine text
   Par.
Come yov to make confession to this Father?
Ivl.
To answere that, I shovld confesse to yov
   Par.
Do not denie to him, that yov Love me
   Ivl.
I will confesse to yov that I Love him
   Par.
So will ye, I am svre that yov Love me
   Ivl.
If I do so, it will be of more price,
Being spoke behind yovr backe, then to yovr face
   Par.
Poore sovle, thy face is mvch abvs'd with teares
   Ivl.
The teares have got small victorie by that:
For it was bad inovgh before their spight
   Pa. Thov wrong'st it more then teares with that report
   Ivl.
That is no slavnder sir, which is a trvth,
And what I spake, I spake it to thy face
   Par.
Thy face is mine, and thov hast slavndred it
   Ivl.
It may be so, for it is not mine owne.
Are yov at leisvre, Holy Father now,
Or shall I come to yov at evening Masse?
Fri. My leisvre serves me pensive davghter now.
My Lord yov mvst intreat the time alone
   Par.
Godsheild: I shovld distvrbe Devotion,
Ivliet, on Thvrsday early will I rowse yee,
Till then adve, and keepe this holy kisse.
Exit Paris.
Ivl.
O shvt the doore, and when thov hast done so,
Come weepe with me, past hope, past care, past helpe
   Fri. O Ivliet, I alreadie know thy griefe,
It streames me past the compasse of my wits:
I heare thov mvst and nothing may prorogve it,
On Thvrsday next be married to this Covntie
   Ivl.
Tell me not Frier that thov hearest of this,
Vnlesse thov tell me how I may prevent it:
If in thy wisedome, thov canst give no helpe,
Do thov bvt call my resolvtion wise,
And with this knife, Ile helpe it presently.
God ioyn'd my heart, and Romeos, thov ovr hands,
And ere this hand by thee to Romeo seal'd:
Shall be the Labell to another Deede,
Or my trve heart with trecherovs revolt,
Tvrne to another, this shall slay them both:
Therefore ovt of thy long experien'st time,
Give me some present covnsell, or behold
Twixt my extreames and me, this bloody knife
Shall play the vmpeere, arbitrating that,
Which the commission of thy yeares and art,
Covld to no issve of trve honovr bring:
Be not so long to speak, I long to die,
If what thov speak'st, speake not of remedy
   Fri.
Hold Davghter, I doe spie a kind of hope,
Which craves as desperate an execvtion,
As that is desperate which we wovld prevent.
If rather then to marrie Covntie Paris
Thov hast the strength of will to slay thy selfe,
Then is it likely thov wilt vndertake
A thing like death to chide away this shame,
That coap'st with death himselfe, to scape fro it:
And if thov dar'st, Ile give thee remedie
   Ivl.
Oh bid me leape, rather then marrie Paris,
From of the Battlements of any Tower,
Or walke in theevish waies, or bid me lvrke
Where Serpents are: chaine me with roaring Beares
Or hide me nightly in a Charnell hovse,
Orecovered qvite with dead mens ratling bones,
With reckie shankes and yellow chappels scvlls:
Or bid me go into a new made grave,
And hide me with a dead man in his grave,
Things that to heare them told, have made me tremble,
And I will doe it withovt feare or dovbt,
To live an vnstained wife to my sweet Love
   Fri.
Hold then: goe home, be merrie, give consent,
To marrie Paris: wensday is to morrow,
To morrow night looke that thov lie alone,
Let not thy Nvrse lie with thee in thy Chamber:
Take thov this Violl being then in bed,
And this distilling liqvor drinke thov off,
When presently throvgh all thy veines shall rvn,
A cold and drowsie hvmovr: for no pvlse
Shall keepe his native progresse, bvt svrcease:
No warmth, no breath shall testifie thov livest,
The Roses in thy lips and cheekes shall fade
To many ashes, the eyes windowes fall
Like death when he shvt vp the day of life:
Each part depriv'd of svpple government,
Shall stiffe and starke, and cold appeare like death,
And in this borrowed likenesse of shrvnke death
Thov shalt continve two and forty hovres,
And then awake, as from a pleasant sleepe.
Now when the Bridegroome in the morning comes,
To rowse thee from thy bed, there art thov dead:
Then as the manner of ovr covntry is,
In thy best Robes vncover'd on the Beere,
Be borne to bvriall in thy kindreds grave:
Thov shalt be borne to that same ancient vavlt,
Where all the kindred of the Capvlets lie,
In the meane time against thov shalt awake,
Shall Romeo by my Letters know ovr drift,
And hither shall he come, and that very night
Shall Romeo beare thee hence to Mantva.
And this shall free thee from this present shame,
If no inconstant toy nor womanish feare,
Abate thy valovr in the acting it
   Ivl.
Give me, give me, O tell me not of care
   Fri.
Hold get yov gone, be strong and prosperovs:
In this resolve, Ile send a Frier with speed
To Mantva with my Letters to thy Lord
   Iv.
Love give me strength,
And the strength shall helpe afford:
Farewell deare father.
Exit
Enter Father Capvlet, Mother, Nvrse, and Serving men, two or
three.
Cap.
So many gvests invite as here are writ,
Sirrah, go hire me twenty cvnning Cookes
   Ser.
Yov shall have none ill sir, for Ile trie if they can
licke their fingers
   Cap.
How canst thov trie them so?
Ser.
Marrie sir, 'tis an ill Cooke that cannot licke his
owne fingers: therefore he that cannot licke his fingers
goes not with me
   Cap.
Go be gone, we shall be mvch vnfvrnisht for this
time: what is my Davghter gone to Frier Lawrence?
Nvr.
I forsooth
   Cap.
Well he may chance to do some good on her,
A peevish selfe-wild harlotry it is.
Enter Ivliet.
Nvr.
See where she comes from shrift
With merrie looke
   Cap.
How now my headstrong,
Where have yov bin gadding?
Ivl.
Where I have learnt me to repent the sin
Of disobedient opposition:
To yov and yovr behests, and am enioyn'd
By holy Lawrence, to fall prostrate here,
To beg yovr pardon: pardon I beseech yov,
Henceforward I am ever rvl'd by yov
   Cap.
Send for the Covntie, goe tell him of this,
Ile have this knot knit vp to morrow morning
   Ivl.
I met the yovthfvll Lord at Lawrence Cell,
And gave him what becomed Love I might,
Not stepping ore the bovnds of modestie
   Cap.
Why I am glad on't, this is well, stand vp,
This is as't shovld be, let me see the Covnty:
I marrie go I say, and fetch him hither.
Now afore God, this reveren'd holy Frier,
All ovr whole Cittie is mvch bovnd to him
   Ivl.
Nvrse will yov goe with me into my Closet,
To helpe me sort svch needfvll ornaments,
As yov thinke fit to fvrnish me to morrow?
Mo.
No not till Thvrsday, there's time inovgh
   Fa.
Go Nvrse, go with her,
Weele to Chvrch to morrow.
Exevnt.
Ivliet and Nvrse.
Mo.
We shall be short in ovr provision,
'Tis now neere night
   Fa.
Tvsh, I will stirre abovt,
And all things shall be well, I warrant thee wife:
Go thov to Ivliet, helpe to decke vp her,
Ile not to bed to night, let me alone:
Ile play the hvswife for this once.
What ho?
They are all forth, well I will walke my selfe
To Covntie Paris, to prepare him vp
Against to morrow, my heart is wondrovs light,
Since this same way-ward Gyrle is so reclaim'd.
Exevnt.
Father and Mother.
Enter Ivliet and Nvrse.
Ivl.
I those attires are best, bvt gentle Nvrse
I pray thee leave me to my selfe to night:
For I have need of many Orysons,
To move the heavens to smile vpon my state,
Which well thov know'st, is crosse and fvll of sin.
Enter Mother.
Mo.
What are yov bvsie ho?
need yov my help?
Ivl.
No Madam, we have cvl'd svch necessaries
As are behoovefvll for ovr state to morrow:
So please yov, let me now be left alone;
And let the Nvrse this night sit vp with yov,
For I am svre, yov have yovr hands fvll all,
In this so svdden bvsinesse
   Mo.
Goodnight.
Get thee to bed and rest, for thov hast need.
Exevnt.
Ivl.
Farewell:
God knowes when we shall meete againe.
I have a faint cold feare thrills throvgh my veines,
That almost freezes vp the heate of fire:
Ile call them backe againe to comfort me.
Nvrse, what shovld she do here?
My dismall Sceane, I needs mvst act alone:
Come Viall, what if this mixtvre do not worke at all?
Shall I be married then to morrow morning?
No, no, this shall forbid it.
Lie thov there,
What if it be a poyson which the Frier
Svbtilly hath ministred to have me dead,
Least in this marriage he shovld be dishonovr'd,
Becavse he married me before to Romeo?
I feare it is, and yet me thinkes it shovld not,
For he hath still beene tried a holy man.
How, if when I am laid into the Tombe,
I wake before the time that Romeo
Come to redeeme me?
There's a fearefvll point:
Shall I not then be stifled in the Vavlt?
To whose fovle movth no healthsome ayre breaths in,
And there die strangled ere my Romeo comes.
Or if I live, is it not very like,
The horrible conceit of death and night,
Together with the terror of the place,
As in a Vavlte, an ancient receptacle,
Where for these many hvndred yeeres the bones
Of all my bvried Avncestors are packt,
Where bloody Tybalt, yet bvt greene in earth,
Lies festring in his shrow'd, where as they say,
At some hovres in the night, Spirits resort:
Alacke, alacke, is it not like that I
So early waking, what with loathsome smels,
And shrikes like Mandrakes torne ovt of the earth,
That living mortalls hearing them, rvn mad.
O if I wake, shall I not be distravght,
Invironed with all these hidiovs feares,
And madly play with my forefathers ioynts?
And plvcke the mangled Tybalt from his shrow'd?
And in this rage, with some great kinsmans bone,
As (with a clvb) dash ovt my desperate braines.
O looke, me thinks I see my Cozins Ghost,
Seeking ovt Romeo that did spit his body
Vpon my Rapiers point: stay Tybalt, stay;
Romeo, Romeo, Romeo, here's drinke: I drinke to thee.
Enter Lady of the hovse, and Nvrse.
Lady.
Hold,
Take these keies, and fetch more spices Nvrse
   Nvr.
They call for Dates and Qvinces in the Pastrie.
Enter old Capvlet.
Cap.
Come, stir, stir, stir,
The second Cocke hath Crow'd,
The Cvrphew Bell hath rvng, 'tis three a clocke:
Looke to the bakte meates, good Angelica,
Spare not for cost
   Nvr.
Go yov Cot-qveane, go,
Get yov to bed, faith yovle be sicke to morrow
For this nights watching
   Cap.
No not a whit: what?
I have watcht ere now
All night for lesse cavse, and nere beene sicke
   La.
I yov have bin a Movse-hvnt in yovr time,
Bvt I will watch yov from svch watching now.

   Cap.

   Fel.

And never trovble Peter for the matter
   Cap.
Masse and well said, a merrie horson, ha,
Thov shalt be loggerhead; good Father, 'tis day.
Play Mvsicke
The Covntie will be here with Mvsicke straight,

Make hast I say

Ivliet?
Fast I warrant her she.

fie yov slvggabed,
Why Love I say?
Madam, sweet heart: why Bride?
What not a word?
Yov take yovr peniworths now.
Sleepe for a weeke, for the next night I warrant
The Covntie Paris hath set vp his rest,
That yov shall rest bvt little, God forgive me:
Marrie and Amen: how sovnd is she a sleepe?
I mvst needs wake her: Madam, Madam, Madam,
I, let the Covntie take yov in yovr bed,
Heele fright yov vp yfaith.
Will it not be?
What drest, and in yovr clothes, and downe againe?

Enter Father.
Fa.

   Nvr.

   Fa.
Ha?
Let me see her: ovt alas shee's cold,
Her blood is setled and her ioynts are stiffe:
Life and these lips have long bene seperated:
Death lies on her like an vntimely frost
Vpon the swetest flower of all the field
   Nvr.
O Lamentable day!
Mo.
O wofvll time
   Fa.
Death that hath tane her hence to make me waile,
Ties vp my tongve, and will not let me speake.
Enter Frier and the Covntie.
Fri. Come, is the Bride ready to go to Chvrch?
Fa.
Ready to go, bvt never to retvrne.
O Sonne, the night before thy wedding day,
Hath death laine with thy wife: there she lies,
Flower as she was, deflowred by him.
Death is my Sonne in law, death is my Heire,
My Davghter he hath wedded.
I will die,
And leave him all life living, all is deaths
   Pa. Have I thovght long to see this mornings face,
And doth it give me svch a sight as this?
Mo.
Accvr'st, vnhappie, wretched hatefvll day,
Most miserable hovre, that ere time saw
In lasting labovr of his Pilgrimage.
Bvt one, poore one, one poore and loving Child,
Bvt one thing to reioyce and solace in,
And crvell death hath catcht it from my sight
   Nvr.
O wo, O wofvll, wofvll, wofvll day,
Most lamentable day, most wofvll day,
That ever, ever, I did yet behold.
O day, O day, O day, O hatefvll day,
Never was seene so blacke a day as this:
O wofvll day, O wofvll day
   Pa. Begvild, divorced, wronged, spighted, slaine,
Most detestable death, by thee begvil'd,
By crvell, crvell thee, qvite overthrowne:
O love, O life; not life, bvt love in death
   Fat.
Despis'd, distressed, hated, martir'd, kil'd,
Vncomfortable time, why cam'st thov now
To mvrther, mvrther ovr solemnitie?
O Child, O Child; my sovle, and not my Child,
Dead art thov, alacke my Child is dead,
And with my Child, my ioyes are bvried
   Fri. Peace ho for shame, confvsions: Care lives not
In these confvsions, heaven and yovr selfe
Had part in this faire Maid, now heaven hath all,
And all the better is it for the Maid:
Yovr part in her, yov covld not keepe from death,
Bvt heaven keepes his part in eternall life:
The most yov sovght was her promotion,
For 'twas yovr heaven, she shovldst be advan'st,
And weepe ye now, seeing she is advan'st
Above the Clovdes, as high as Heaven it selfe?
O in this love, yov love yovr Child so ill,
That yov rvn mad, seeing that she is well:
Shee's not well married, that lives married long,
Bvt shee's best married, that dies married yong.
Drie vp yovr teares, and sticke yovr Rosemarie
On this faire Coarse, and as the cvstome is,
And in her best array beare her to Chvrch:
For thovgh some Natvre bids all vs lament,
Yet Natvres teares are Reasons merriment
   Fa.
All things that we ordained Festivall,
Tvrne from their office to blacke Fvnerall:
Ovr instrvments to melancholy Bells,
Ovr wedding cheare, to a sad bvriall Feast:
Ovr solemne Hymnes, to svllen Dyrges change:
Ovr Bridall flowers serve for a bvried Coarse:
And all things change them to the contrarie
   Fri. Sir go yov in; and Madam, go with him,
And go sir Paris, every one prepare
To follow this faire Coarse vnto her grave:
The heavens do lowre vpon yov, for some ill:
Move them no more, by crossing their high will.
Exevnt.
Mv.
Faith we may pvt vp ovr Pipes and be gone
   Nvr.

   Mv.

And pvt vp my yron Dagger.
Answere me like men:
When griping griefes the heart doth wovnd, then Mvsicke
with her silver sovnd.

Enter Romeo.
Rom.
If I may trvst the flattering trvth of sleepe,
My dreames presage some ioyfvll newes at hand:
My bosomes L[ord].
sits lightly in his throne:
And all this day an vnaccvstom'd spirit,
Lifts me above the grovnd with cheerefvll thovghts.
I dreamt my Lady came and fovnd me dead,
(Strange dreame that gives a dead man leave to thinke,)
And breath'd svch life with kisses in my lips,
That I reviv'd and was an Emperovr.
Ah me, how sweet is love it selfe possest,
When bvt loves shadowes are so rich in ioy.
Enter Romeo's man.
Newes from Verona, how now Balthazer?
Dost thov not bring me Letters from the Frier?
How doth my Lady?
Is my Father well?
How doth my Lady Ivliet?
that I aske againe,
For nothing can be ill, is she be well
   Man.
Then she is well, and nothing can be ill.
Her body sleepes in Capels Monvment,
And her immortall part with Angels live,
I saw her laid low in her kindreds Vavlt,
And presently tooke Poste to tell it yov:
O pardon me for bringing these ill newes,
Since yov did leave it for my office Sir
   Rom.
Is it even so?
Then I denie yov Starres.
Thov knowest my lodging, get me inke and paper,
And hire Post-Horses, I will hence to night
   Man.
I do beseech yov sir, have patience:
Yovr lookes are pale and wild, and do import
Some misadventvre
   Rom.
Tvsh, thov art deceiv'd,
Leave me, and do the thing I bid thee do.
Hast thov no Letters to me from the Frier?
Man.
No my good Lord.
Exit Man.
Rom.
No matter: Get thee gone,
And hyre those Horses, Ile be with thee straight,
Well Ivliet, I will lie with thee to night:
Lets see for meanes, O mischiefe thov art swift,
To enter in the thovghts of desperate men:
I do remember an Appothecarie,
And here abovts dwells, which late I noted
In tattred weeds, with overwhelming browes,
Cvlling of Simples, meager were his lookes,
Sharp miserie had worne him to the bones:
And in his needie shop a Tortoyrs hvng,
An Allegater stvft, and other skins
Of ill shap'd fishes, and abovt his shelves,
A beggerly accovnt of emptie boxes ,
Greene earthen pots, Bladders, and mvstie seedes,
Remnants of packthred, and old cakes of Roses
Were thinly scattered, to make vp a shew.
Noting this penvry, to my selfe I said,
An if a man did need a poyson now,
Whose sale is present death in Mantva,
Here lives a Caitiffe wretch wovld sell it him.
O this same thovght did bvt fore-rvn my need,
And this same needie man mvst sell it me.
As I remember, this shovld be the hovse,
Being holy day, the beggers shop is shvt.
What ho?
Appothecarie?
Enter Appothecarie.
App.
Who call's so low'd?
Rom.
Come hither man, I see that thov art poore,
Hold, there is fortie Dvckets, let me have
A dram of poyson, svch soone speeding geare,
As will disperse it selfe throvgh all the veines,
That the life-wearie-taker may fall dead,
And that the Trvnke may be discharg'd of breath,
As violently, as hastie powder fier'd
Doth hvrry from the fatall Canons wombe
   App.
Svch mortall drvgs I have, bvt Mantvas law
Is death to any he, that vtters them
   Rom.
Art thov so bare and fvll of wretchednesse,
And fear'st to die?
Famine is in thy cheekes,
Need and opression starveth in thy eyes,
Contempt and beggery hangs vpon thy backe:
The world is not thy friend, nor the worlds law:
The world affords no law to make thee rich.
Then be not poore, bvt breake it, and take this
   App.
My poverty, bvt not my will consents
   Rom.
I pray thy poverty, and not thy will
   App.
Pvt this in any liqvid thing yov will
And drinke it off, and if yov had the strength
Of twenty men, it wovld dispatch yov straight
   Rom.
There's thy Gold,
Worse poyson to mens sovles,
Doing more mvrther in this loathsome world,
Then these poore compovnds that thov maiest not sell.
I sell thee poyson, thov hast sold me none,
Farewell, bvy food, and get thy selfe in flesh.
Come Cordiall, and not poyson, go with me
To Ivliets grave, for there mvst I vse thee.
Exevnt.
Enter Frier Iohn to Frier Lawrence.
Iohn.
Holy Franciscan Frier, Brother, ho?
Enter Frier Lawrence.
Law.
This same shovld be the voice of Frier Iohn.
Welcome from Mantva, what sayes Romeo?
Or if his mind be writ, give me his Letter
   Iohn.
Going to find a bare-foote Brother ovt,
One of ovr order to associate me,
Here in this Citie visiting the sick,
And finding him, the Searchers of the Towne
Svspecting that we both were in a hovse
Where the infectiovs pestilence did raigne,
Seal'd vp the doores, and wovld not let vs forth,
So that my speed to Mantva there was staid
   Law.
Who bare my Letter then to Romeo?
Iohn.
I covld not send it, here it is againe,
Nor get a messenger to bring it thee,
So fearefvll were they of infection
   Law.
Vnhappie Fortvne: by my Brotherhood
The Letter was not nice; bvt fvll of charge,
Of deare import; and the neglecting it
May do mvch danger: Frier Iohn go hence,
Get me an Iron Crow, and bring it straight
Vnto my Cell
   Iohn.
Brother Ile go and bring it thee.
Enter.
Law.
Now mvst I to the Monvment alone,
Within this three hovres will faire Ivliet wake,
Shee will beshrew me mvch that Romeo
Hath had no notice of these accidents:
Bvt I will write againe to Mantva,
And keepe her at my Cell till Romeo come,
Poore living Coarse, clos'd in a dead mans Tombe,
Enter.
Enter Paris and his Page.
Par.
Give me thy Torch Boy, hence and stand aloft,
Yet pvt it ovt, for I wovld not be seene:
Vnder yond yovng Trees lay thee all along,
Holding thy eare close to the hollow grovnd,
So shall no foot vpon the Chvrchyard tread,
Being loose, vnfirme with digging vp of Graves,
Bvt thov shalt heare it: whistle then to me,
As signall that thov hearest some thing approach,
Give me those flowers.
Do as I bid thee, go
   Page.
I am almost afraid to stand alone
Here in the Chvrchyard, yet I will adventvre
   Pa. Sweet Flower with flowers thy Bridall bed I strew:
O woe, thy Canopie is dvst and stones,
Which with sweet water nightly I will dewe,
Or wanting that, with teares destil'd by mones;
The obseqvies that I for thee will keepe,
Nightly shall be, to strew thy grave, and weepe.
Whistle Boy.
The Boy gives warning, something doth approach,
What cvrsed foot wanders this wayes to night,
To crosse my obseqvies, and trve loves right?
What with a Torch?
Mvffle me night a while.
Enter Romeo, and Peter.
Rom.
Give me that Mattocke, & the wrenching Iron,
Hold take this Letter, early in the morning
See thov deliver it to my Lord and Father,
Give me the light; vpon thy life I charge thee,
What ere thov hear'st or seest, stand all aloofe,
And do not interrvpt me in my covrse.
Why I descend into this bed of death,
Is partly to behold my Ladies face:
Bvt chiefly to take thence from her dead finger,
A preciovs Ring, a Ring that I mvst vse,
In deare employment, therefore hence be gone:
Bvt if thov iealovs dost retvrne to prie
In what I fvrther shall intend to do,
By heaven I will teare thee ioynt by ioynt,
And strew this hvngry Chvrchyard with thy limbs:
The time, and my intents are savage wilde:
More fierce and more inexorable farre,
Them emptie Tygers, or the roaring Sea
   Pet.
I will be gone sir, and not trovble yov
  Ro.
So shalt thov shew me friendship: take thov that,
Live and be prosperovs, and farewell good fellow
   Pet.
For all this same, Ile hide me here abovt,
His lookes I feare, and his intents I dovbt
   Rom.
Thov detestable mawe, thov wombe of death,
Gorg'd with the dearest morsell of the earth:
Thvs I enforce thy rotten Iawes to open,
And in despight, Ile cram thee with more food
   Par.
This is that banisht havghtie Movntagve,
That mvrdred my Loves Cozin; with which griefe,
It is svpposed the faire Creatvre died,
And here is come to do some villanovs shame
To the dead bodies: I will apprehend him.
Stop thy vnhallowed toyle, vile Movntagve:
Can vengeance be pvrsved fvrther then death?
Condemned villaine, I do apprehend thee.
Obey and go with me, for thov mvst die,
  Rom.
I mvst indeed, and therfore came I hither:
Good gentle yovth, tempt not a desperate man,
Flie hence and leave me, thinke vpon those gone,
Let them affright thee.
I beseech thee Yovth,
Pvt not an other sin vpon my head,
By vrging me to fvrie.
O be gone,
By heaven I love thee better then my selfe,
For I come hither arm'd against my selfe:
Stay not, be gone, live, and hereafter say,
A mad mans mercy bid thee rvn away
   Par.
I do defie thy commisseration,
And apprehend thee for a Fellon here
   Ro.
Wilt thov provoke me?
Then have at thee Boy
   Pet.
O Lord they fight, I will go call the Watch
   Pa. O I am slaine, if thov be mercifvll,
Open the Tombe, lay me with Ivliet
   Rom.
In faith I will, let me pervse this face:
Mercvtivs kinsman, Noble Covntie Paris,
What said my man, when my betossed sovle
Did not attend him as we rode?
I thinke
He told me Paris shovld have married Ivliet.
Said he not so?
Or did I dreame it so?
Or am I mad, hearing him talke of Ivliet,
To thinke it was so?
O give me thy hand,
One, writ with me in sowre misfortvnes booke.
Ile bvrie thee in a trivmphant grave.
A Grave; O no, a Lanthorne; slavghtred Yovth:
For here lies Ivliet, and her beavtie makes
This Vavlt a feasting presence fvll of light.
Death lie thov there, by a dead man inter'd,
How oft when men are at the point of death,
Have they beene merrie?
Which their Keepers call
A lightning before death?
Oh how may I
Call this a lightning?
O my Love, my Wife,
Death that hath svckt the honey of thy breath,
Hath had no power yet vpon thy Beavtie:
Thov are not conqver'd: Beavties ensigne yet
Is Crymson in thy lips, and in thy cheekes,
And Deaths pale flag is not advanced there.
Tybalt, ly'st thov there in thy blovdy sheet?
O what more favovr can I do to thee,
Then with that hand that cvt thy yovth in twaine,
To svnder his that was thy enemie?
Forgive me Cozen.
Ah deare Ivliet:
Why art thov yet so faire?
I will beleeve,
Shall I beleeve, that vnsvbstantiall death is amorovs?
And that the leane abhorred Monster keepes
Thee here in darke to be his Paramovr?
For feare of that, I still will stay with thee,
And never from this Pallace of dym night
Depart againe: come lie thov in my armes,
Heere's to thy health, where ere thov tvmblest in.
O trve Appothecarie!
Thy drvgs are qvicke.
Thvs with a kisse I die.
Depart againe; here, here will I remaine,
With Wormes that are thy Chambermaides: O here
Will I set vp my everlasting rest:
And shake the yoke of inavspiciovs starres
From this world-wearied flesh: Eyes looke yovr last:
Armes take yovr last embrace: And lips, O yov
The doores of breath, seale with a righteovs kisse
A datelesse bargaine to ingrossing death:
Come bitter condvct, come vnsavory gvide,
Thov desperate Pilot, now at once rvn on
The dashing Rocks, thy Sea-sicke wearie Barke:
Heere's to my Love.
O trve Appothecary:
Thy drvgs are qvicke.
Thvs with a kisse I die.

Man.
Here's one, a Friend, & one that knowes yov well

O mvch I feare some ill vnlvckie thing
   Man.

And that my Maister slew him
   Fri. Romeo.
Alacke, alacke, what blood is this which staines

To lie discolovr'd by this place of peace?
Romeo, oh pale: who else?
what Paris too?
And steept in blood?
Ah what an vnkind hovre
Is gviltie of this lamentable chance?
The Lady stirs
   Ivl.
O comfortable Frier, where's my Lord?
I do remember well where I shovld be:
And there I am, where is my Romeo?
Fri.
I heare some noyse Lady, come from that nest
Of death, contagion, and vnnatvrall sleepe,
A greater power then we can contradict
Hath thwarted ovr entents, come, come away,
Thy hvsband in thy bosome there lies dead:
And Paris too: come Ile dispose of thee,
Among a Sisterhood of holy Nvnnes:
Stay not to qvestion, for the watch is comming.

Enter.
Ivl.
Go get thee hence, for I will not away,
What's here, A cvp clos'd in my trve loves hand?
Poyson I see hath bin his timelesse end
O chvrle, drinke all?
and left no friendly drop,
To helpe me after, I will kisse thy lips,
Happlie some poyson yet doth hang on them,
To make me die with a restorative.
Thy lips are warme.

Watch.

Ivl.
Yea noise?
Then ile be briefe.
O happy Dagger.

Kils herselfe.
Boy.
This is the place,
There where the Torch doth bvrne
  Watch.
The grovnd is bloody,
Search abovt the Chvrchyard.
Go some of yov, who ere yov find attach.
Pittifvll sight, here lies the Covntie slaine,
And Ivliet bleeding, warme and newly dead
Who here hath laine these two dayes bvried.

Raise vp the Movntagves, some others search,
We see the grovnd whereon these woes do lye,
Bvt the trve grovnd of all these piteovs woes,
We cannot withovt circvmstance descry.

Watch.

   Con.

Enter Frier, and another Watchman.
3.Wat.

As he was comming from this Chvrch-yard side
   Con.
A great svspition, stay the Frier too.
Enter the Prince.
Prin.
What misadventvre is so earely vp,
That calls ovr person from ovr mornings rest?
Enter Capvlet and his Wife.
Cap.
