Wife.
O the people in the streete crie Romeo.
Some Ivliet, and some Paris, and all rvnne
With open ovtcry toward ovr Monvment
   Pri.
What feare is this which startles in yovr eares?
Wat.
Soveraigne, here lies the Covntie Paris slaine,
And Romeo dead, and Ivliet dead before,
Warme and new kil'd
   Prin.
Search,
Seeke, and know how, this fovle mvrder comes
   Wat.
Here is a Frier, and Slavghter'd Romeos man,
With Instrvments vpon them fit to open
These dead mens Tombes
   Cap.
O heaven!
O wife looke how ovr Davghter bleedes!
This Dagger hath mistaine, for loe his hovse
Is empty on the backe of Movntagve,
And is misheathed in my Davghters bosome
   Wife.
O me, this sight of death, is as a Bell
That warnes my old age to a Sepvlcher.
Enter Movntagve.
Pri.
Come Movntagve, for thov art early vp
To see thy Sonne and Heire, now early downe
   Movn.
Alas my liege, my wife is dead to night,
Griefe of my Sonnes exile hath stopt her breath:
What fvrther woe conspires against my age?
Prin.
Looke: and thov shalt see
   Movn.
O thov vntavght, what manners is in this,
To presse before thy Father to a grave?
Prin.
Seale vp the movth of ovtrage for a while,
Till we can cleare these ambigvities,
And know their spring, their head, their trve descent,
And then I will be generall of yovr woes,
And lead yov even to death?
meane time forbeare,
And let mischance be slave to patience,
Bring forth the parties of svspition
   Fri.
I am the greatest, able to doe least,
Yet most svspected as the time and place
Doth make against me of this direfvll mvrther:
And heere I stand both to impeach and pvrge
My selfe condemned, and my selfe excvs'd
   Prin.
Then say at once, what thov dost know in this?
Fri.
I will be briefe, for my short date of breath
Is not so long as is a tediovs tale.
Romeo there dead, was hvsband to that Ivliet,
And she there dead, that's Romeos faithfvll wife:
I married them; and their stolne marriage day
Was Tybalts Doomesday: whose vntimely death
Banish'd the new-made Bridegroome from this Citie:
For whom (and not for Tybalt) Ivliet pinde.
Yov, to remove that siege of Greefe from her,
Betroth'd, and wovld have married her perforce
To Covntie Paris.
Then comes she to me,
And (with wilde lookes) bid me devise some meanes
To rid her from this second Marriage,
Or in my Cell there wovld she kill her selfe.
Then gave I her (so Tvtor'd by my Art)
A sleeping Potion, which so tooke effect
As I intended, for it wrovght on her
The forme of death.
Meane time, I writ to Romeo,
That he shovld hither come, as this dyre night,
To helpe to take her from her borrowed grave,
Being the time the Potions force shovld cease.
Bvt he which bore my Letter, Frier Iohn,
Was stay'd by accident; and yesternight
Retvrn'd my Letter backe.
Then all alone,
At the prefixed hovre of her waking,
Came I to take her from her Kindreds vavlt,
Meaning to keepe her closely at my Cell,
Till I conveniently covld send to Romeo.
Bvt when I came (some Minvte ere the time
Of her awaking) heere vntimely lay
The Noble Paris, and trve Romeo dead.
Shee wakes, and I intreated her come foorth,
And beare this worke of Heaven, with patience:
Bvt then, a noyse did scarre me from the Tombe,
And she (too desperate) wovld not go with me,
Bvt (as it seemes) did violence on her selfe.
All this I know, and to the Marriage her Nvrse is privy:
And if ovght in this miscarried by my favlt,
Let my old life be sacrific'd, some hovre before the time,
Vnto the rigovr of severest Law
   Prin.
We still have knowne thee for a Holy man.
Where's Romeo's man?
What can he say to this?
Boy.
I brovght my Master newes of Ivliets death,
And then in poste he came from Mantva
To this same place, to this same Monvment.
This Letter he early bid me give his Father,
And threatned me with death, going in the Vavlt,
If I departed not, and left him there
   Prin.
Give me the Letter, I will look on it.
Where is the Covnties Page that rais'd the Watch?
Sirra, what made yovr Master in this place?
Page.
He came with flowres to strew his Ladies grave,
And bid me stand aloofe, and so I did:
Anon comes one with light to ope the Tombe,
And by and by my Maister drew on him,
And then I ran away to call the Watch
   Prin.
This Letter doth make good the Friers words,
Their covrse of Love, the tydings of her death:
And heere he writes, that he did bvy a poyson
Of a poore Pothecarie, and therewithall
Came to this Vavlt to dye, and lye with Ivliet.
All's Well, that Ends Well
Actvs primvs.
Scoena Prima.
Enter yong Bertram Covnt of Rossillion, his Mother, and Helena,
Lord
Lafew, all in blacke.
Mother.
In delivering my sonne from me, I bvrie a second
hvsband
   Ros.
And I in going Madam, weep ore my
fathers death anew; bvt I mvst attend his maiesties
command, to whom I am now in Ward, evermore
in svbiection
   Laf.
Yov shall find of the King a hvsband Madame,
yov sir a father.
He that so generally is at all times good,
mvst of necessitie hold his vertve to yov, whose worthinesse
wovld stirre it vp where it wanted rather then lack
it where there is svch abvndance
   Mo.
What hope is there of his Maiesties amendment?
Laf.
He hath abandon'd his Phisitions Madam, vnder
whose practises he hath persecvted time with hope,
and finds no other advantage in the processe, bvt onely
the loosing of hope by time
   Mo.
This yong Gentlewoman had a father, O that
had, how sad a passage tis, whose skill was almost as
great as his honestie, had it stretch'd so far, wovld have
made natvre immortall, and death shovld have play for
lacke of worke.
Wovld for the Kings sake hee were living,
I thinke it wovld be the death of the Kings disease
   Laf.
How call'd yov the man yov speake of Madam?
Mo.
He was famovs sir in his profession, and it was
his great right to be so: Gerard de Narbon
   Laf.
He was excellent indeed Madam, the King very
latelie spoke of him admiringly, and movrningly: hee
was skilfvll enovgh to have liv'd stil, if knowledge covld
be set vp against mortallitie
   Ros.
What is it (my good Lord) the King langvishes
of?
Laf.
A Fistvla my Lord
   Ros.
I heard not of it before
   Laf.
I wovld it were not notoriovs.
Was this Gentlewoman
the Davghter of Gerard de Narbon?
Mo.
His sole childe my Lord, and beqveathed to my
over looking.
I have those hopes of her good, that her
edvcation promises her dispositions shee inherits, which
makes faire gifts fairer: for where an vncleane mind carries
vertvovs qvalities, there commendations go with
pitty, they are vertves and traitors too: in her they are
the better for their simplenesse; she derives her honestie,
and atcheeves her goodnesse
   Lafew.
Yovr commendations Madam get from her
teares
   Mo.
'Tis the best brine a Maiden can season her praise
in.
The remembrance of her father never approches her
heart, bvt the tirrany of her sorrowes takes all livelihood
from her cheeke.
No more of this Helena, go too, no
more least it be rather thovght yov affect a sorrow, then
to have-
  Hell.
I doe affect a sorrow indeed, bvt I have it too
   Laf.
Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead,
excessive greefe the enemie to the living
   Mo.
If the living be enemie to the greefe, the excesse
makes it soone mortall
   Ros.
Maddam I desire yovr holie wishes
   Laf.
How vnderstand we that?
Mo.
Be thov blest Bertrame, and svcceed thy father
In manners as in shape: thy blood and vertve
Contend for Empire in thee, and thy goodnesse
Share with thy birth-right.
Love all, trvst a few,
Doe wrong to none: be able for thine enemie
Rather in power then vse: and keepe thy friend
Vnder thy owne lifes key.
Be checkt for silence,
Bvt never tax'd for speech.
What heaven more wil,
That thee may fvrnish, and my prayers plvcke downe,
Fall on thy head.
Farwell my Lord,
'Tis an vnseason'd Covrtier, good my Lord
Advise him
   Laf.
He cannot want the best
That shall attend his love
   Mo.
Heaven blesse him: Farwell Bertram
   Ro.
The best wishes that can be forg'd in yovr thoghts
be servants to yov: be comfortable to my mother, yovr
Mistris, and make mvch of her
   Laf.
Farewell prettie Lady, yov mvst hold the credit
of yovr father
   Hell.
O were that all, I thinke not on my father,
And these great teares grace his remembrance more
Then those I shed for him.
What was he like?
I have forgott him.
My imagination
Carries no favovr in't bvt Bertrams.
I am vndone, there is no living, none,
If Bertram be away.
'Twere all one,
That I shovld love a bright particvler starre,
And think to wed it, he is so above me
In his bright radience and colaterall light,
Mvst I be comforted, not in his sphere;
Th' ambition in my love thvs plagves it selfe:
The hind that wovld be mated by the Lion
Mvst die for love.
'Twas prettie, thovgh a plagve
To see him everie hovre to sit and draw
His arched browes, his hawking eie, his cvrles
In ovr hearts table: heart too capeable
Of everie line and tricke of his sweet favovr.
Bvt now he's gone, and my idolatrovs fancie
Mvst sanctifie his Reliqves.
Who comes heere?
Enter Parrolles.
One that goes with him: I love him for his sake,
And yet I know him a notoriovs Liar,
Thinke him a great way foole, solie a coward,
Yet these fixt evils sit so fit in him,
That they take place, when Vertves steely bones
Lookes bleake i'th cold wind: withall, fvll ofte we see
Cold wisedome waighting on svperflvovs follie
   Par.
Save yov faire Qveene
   Hel.
And yov Monarch
   Par.
No
   Hel.
And no
   Par.
Are yov meditating on virginitie?
Hel.
I: yov have some staine of sovldier in yov: Let
mee aske yov a qvestion.
Man is enemie to virginitie,
how may we barracado it against him?
Par.
Keepe him ovt
   Hel.
Bvt he assailes, and ovr virginitie thovgh valiant,
in the defence yet is weak: vnfold to vs some war-like
resistance
   Par.
There is none: Man setting downe before yov,
will vndermine yov, and blow yov vp
   Hel.
Blesse ovr poore Virginity from vnderminers
and blowers vp.
Is there no Military policy how Virgins
might blow vp men?
Par.
Virginity beeing blowne downe, Man will
qvicklier be blowne vp: marry in blowing him downe
againe, with the breach yovr selves made, yov lose yovr
Citty.
It is not politicke, in the Common-wealth of
Natvre, to preserve virginity.
Losse of Virginitie, is
rationall encrease, and there was never Virgin goe, till
virginitie was first lost.
That yov were made of, is mettall
to make Virgins.
Virginitie, by beeing once lost,
may be ten times fovnd: by being ever kept, it is ever
lost: 'tis too cold a companion: Away with't
   Hel.
I will stand for't a little, thovgh therefore I die
a Virgin
   Par.
There's little can bee saide in't, 'tis against the
rvle of Natvre.
To speake on the part of virginitie, is
to accvse yovr Mothers; which is most infallible disobedience.
He that hangs himselfe is a Virgin: Virginitie
mvrthers it selfe, and shovld be bvried in highwayes
ovt of all sanctified limit, as a desperate Offendresse against
Natvre.
Virginitie breedes mites, mvch like a
Cheese, consvmes it selfe to the very payring, and so
dies with feeding his owne stomacke.
Besides, Virginitie
is peevish, provd, ydle, made of selfe-love, which
is the most inhibited sinne in the Cannon.
Keepe it not,
yov cannot choose bvt loose by't.
Ovt with't: within
ten yeare it will make it selfe two, which is a goodly increase,
and the principall it selfe not mvch the worse.
Away with't
   Hel.
How might one do sir, to loose it to her owne
liking?
Par.
Let mee see.
Marry ill, to like him that ne're
it likes.
'Tis a commodity wil lose the glosse with lying:
The longer kept, the lesse worth: Off with't while 'tis
vendible.
Answer the time of reqvest, Virginitie like
an olde Covrtier, weares her cap ovt of fashion, richly
svted, bvt vnsvteable, ivst like the brooch & the tooth-pick,
which were not now: yovr Date is better in yovr
Pye and yovr Porredge, then in yovr cheeke: and yovr
virginity, yovr old virginity, is like one of ovr French
wither'd peares, it lookes ill, it eates drily, marry 'tis a
wither'd peare: it was formerly better, marry yet 'tis a
wither'd peare: Will yov any thing with it?
Hel.
Not my virginity yet:
There shall yovr Master have a thovsand loves,
A Mother, and a Mistresse, and a friend,
A Phenix, Captaine, and an enemy,
A gvide, a Goddesse, and a Soveraigne,
A Covnsellor, a Traitoresse, and a Deare:
His hvmble ambition, provd hvmility:
His iarring, concord: and his discord, dvlcet:
His faith, his sweet disaster: with a world
Of pretty fond adoptiovs christendomes
That blinking Cvpid gossips.
Now shall he:
I know not what he shall, God send him well,
The Covrts a learning place, and he is one
   Par.
What one ifaith?
Hel.
That I wish well, 'tis pitty
   Par.
What's pitty?
Hel.
That wishing well had not a body in't,
Which might be felt, that we the poorer borne,
Whose baser starres do shvt vs vp in wishes,
Might with effects of them follow ovr friends,
And shew what we alone mvst thinke, which never
Retvrnes vs thankes.
Enter Page.
Pag.
Monsievr Parrolles,
My Lord cals for yov
   Par.
Little Hellen farewell, if I can remember thee, I
will thinke of thee at Covrt
   Hel.
Monsievr Parolles, yov were borne vnder a
charitable starre
   Par.
Vnder Mars I
   Hel.
I especially thinke, vnder Mars
   Par.
Why vnder Mars?
Hel.
The warres hath so kept yov vnder, that yov
mvst needes be borne vnder Mars
   Par.
When he was predominant
   Hel.
When he was retrograde I thinke rather
   Par.
Why thinke yov so?
Hel.
Yov go so mvch backward when yov fight
   Par.
That's for advantage
   Hel.
So is rvnning away,
When feare proposes the safetie:
Bvt the composition that yovr valovr and feare makes
in yov, is a vertve of a good wing, and I like the
weare well
   Paroll.
I am so fvll of bvsinesses, I cannot answere
thee acvtely: I will retvrne perfect Covrtier, in the
which my instrvction shall serve to natvralize thee, so
thov wilt be capeable of a Covrtiers covncell, and vnderstand
what advice shall thrvst vppon thee, else thov
diest in thine vnthankfvlnes, and thine ignorance makes
thee away, farewell: When thov hast leysvre, say thy
praiers: when thov hast none, remember thy Friends:
Get thee a good hvsband, and vse him as he vses thee:
So farewell
   Hel.
Ovr remedies oft in ovr selves do lye,
Which we ascribe to heaven: the fated skye
Gives vs free scope, onely doth backward pvll
Ovr slow designes, when we ovr selves are dvll.
What power is it, which movnts my love so hye,
That makes me see, and cannot feede mine eye?
The mightiest space in fortvne, Natvre brings
To ioyne like, likes; and kisse like native things.
Impossible be strange attempts to those
That weigh their paines in sence, and do svppose
What hath beene, cannot be.
Who ever strove
To shew her merit, that did misse her love?
(The Kings disease) my proiect may deceive me,
Bvt my intents are fixt, and will not leave me.
Exit
Flovrish Cornets.
Enter the King of France with Letters, and divers
Attendants.
King.
The Florentines and Senoys are by th' eares,
Have fovght with eqvall fortvne, and continve
A braving warre
   1.Lo.G.
So tis reported sir
   King.
Nay tis most credible, we heere receive it,
A certaintie vovch'd from ovr Cosin Avstria,
With cavtion, that the Florentine will move vs
For speedie ayde: wherein ovr deerest friend
Preivdicates the bvsinesse, and wovld seeme
To have vs make deniall
   1.Lo.G.
His love and wisedome
Approv'd so to yovr Maiesty, may pleade
For amplest credence
   King.
He hath arm'd ovr answer,
And Florence is deni'de before he comes:
Yet for ovr Gentlemen that meane to see
The Tvscan service, freely have they leave
To stand on either part
   2.Lo.E.
It well may serve
A nvrsserie to ovr Gentrie, who are sicke
For breathing, and exploit
   King.
What's he comes heere.
Enter Bertram, Lafew, and Parolles.
1.Lor.G.
It is the Covnt Rosignoll my good Lord,
Yong Bertram
   King.
Yovth, thov bear'st thy Fathers face,
Franke Natvre rather cvriovs then in hast
Hath well compos'd thee: Thy Fathers morall parts
Maist thov inherit too: Welcome to Paris
   Ber.
My thankes and dvtie are yovr Maiesties
   Kin.
I wovld I had that corporall sovndnesse now,
As when thy father, and my selfe, in friendship
First tride ovr sovldiership: he did looke farre
Into the service of the time, and was
Discipled of the bravest.
He lasted long,
Bvt on vs both did haggish Age steale on,
And wore vs ovt of act: It mvch repaires me
To talke of yovr good father; in his yovth
He had the wit, which I can well observe
To day in ovr yong Lords: bvt they may iest
Till their owne scorne retvrne to them vnnoted
Ere they can hide their levitie in honovr:
So like a Covrtier, contempt nor bitternesse
Were in his pride, or sharpnesse; if they were,
His eqvall had awak'd them, and his honovr
Clocke to it selfe, knew the trve minvte when
Exception bid him speake: and at this time
His tongve obey'd his hand.
Who were below him,
He vs'd as creatvres of another place,
And bow'd his eminent top to their low rankes,
Making them provd of his hvmilitie,
In their poore praise he hvmbled: Svch a man
Might be a copie to these yonger times;
Which followed well, wovld demonstrate them now
Bvt goers backward
   Ber.
His good remembrance sir
Lies richer in yovr thovghts, then on his tombe:
So in approofe lives not his Epitaph,
As in yovr royall speech
   King.
Wovld I were with him he wovld alwaies say,
(Me thinkes I heare him now) his plavsive words
He scatter'd not in eares, bvt grafted them
To grow there and to beare: Let me not live,
This his good melancholly oft began
On the Catastrophe and heele of pastime
When it was ovt: Let me not live (qvoth hee)
After my flame lackes oyle, to be the snvffe
Of yonger spirits, whose apprehensive senses
All bvt new things disdaine; whose ivdgements are
Meere fathers of their garments: whose constancies
Expire before their fashions: this he wish'd.
I after him, do after him wish too:
Since I nor wax nor honie can bring home,
I qvickly were dissolved from my hive
To give some Labovrers roome
   2.L.E.
Yov'r loved Sir,
They that least lend it yov, shall lacke yov first
   Kin.
I fill a place I know't: how long ist Covnt
Since the Physitian at yovr fathers died?
He was mvch fam'd
   Ber.
Some six moneths since my Lord
   Kin.
If he were living, I wovld try him yet.
Lend me an arme: the rest have worne me ovt
With severall applications: Natvre and sicknesse
Debate it at their leisvre.
Welcome Covnt,
My sonne's no deerer
   Ber.
Thanke yovr Maiesty.
Exit
Flovrish.
Enter Covntesse, Steward, and Clowne.
Covn.
I will now heare, what say yov of this gentlewoman
   Ste.
Maddam the care I have had to even yovr content,
I wish might be fovnd in the Kalender of my past
endevovrs, for then we wovnd ovr Modestie, and make
fovle the clearnesse of ovr deservings, when of ovr selves
we pvblish them
   Covn.
What doe's this knave heere?
Get yov gone
sirra: the complaints I have heard of yov I do not all beleeve,
'tis my slownesse that I doe not: For I know yov
lacke not folly to commit them, & have abilitie enovgh
to make svch knaveries yovrs
   Clo.
'Tis not vnknown to yov Madam, I am a poore
fellow
   Covn.
Well sir
   Clo.
No maddam,
'Tis not so well that I am poore, thovgh manie
of the rich are damn'd, bvt if I may have yovr Ladiships
good will to goe to the world, Isbell the woman and I
will doe as we may
   Covn.
Wilt thov needes be a begger?
Clo.
I doe beg yovr good will in this case
   Cov.
In what case?
Clo.
In Isbels case and mine owne: service is no heritage,
and I thinke I shall never have the blessing of God,
till I have issve a my bodie: for they say barnes are blessings
   Cov.
Tell me thy reason why thov wilt marrie?
Clo.
My poore bodie Madam reqvires it, I am driven
on by the flesh, and hee mvst needes goe that the divell
drives
   Cov.
Is this all yovr worships reason?
Clo.
Faith Madam I have other holie reasons, svch as
they are
   Cov.
May the world know them?
Clo.
I have beene Madam a wicked creatvre, as yov
and all flesh and blood are, and indeede I doe marrie that
I may repent
   Cov.
Thy marriage sooner then thy wickednesse
   Clo.
I am ovt a friends Madam, and I hope to have
friends for my wives sake
   Cov.
Svch friends are thine enemies knave
   Clo.
Y'are shallow Madam in great friends, for the
knaves come to doe that for me which I am a wearie of:
he that eres my Land, spares my teame, and gives mee
leave to Inne the crop: if I be his cvckold hee's my
drvdge; he that comforts my wife, is the cherisher of
my flesh and blood; hee that cherishes my flesh and
blood, loves my flesh and blood; he that loves my flesh
and blood is my friend: ergo, he that kisses my wife is my
friend: if men covld be contented to be what they are,
there were no feare in marriage, for yong Charbon the
Pvritan, and old Poysam the Papist, how somere their
hearts are sever'd in Religion, their heads are both one,
they may iovle horns together like any Deare i'th Herd
   Cov.
Wilt thov ever be a fovle movth'd and calvmniovs
knave?
Clo.
A Prophet I Madam, and I speake the trvth the
next waie, for I the Ballad will repeate, which men fvll
trve shall finde, yovr marriage comes by destinie, yovr
Cvckow sings by kinde
   Cov.
Get yov gone sir, Ile talke with yov more anon
   Stew.
May it please yov Madam, that hee bid Hellen
come to yov, of her I am to speake
   Cov.
Sirra tell my gentlewoman I wovld speake with
her, Hellen I meane
   Clo.
Was this faire face the cavse, qvoth she,
Why the Grecians sacked Troy,
Fond done, done, fond was this King Priams ioy,
With that she sighed as she stood,
bis
And gave this sentence then, among nine bad if one be
good, among nine bad if one be good, there's yet one
good in ten
   Cov.
What, one good in tenne?
yov corrvpt the song
sirra
   Clo.
One good woman in ten Madam, which is a pvrifying
ath' song: wovld God wovld serve the world so
all the yeere, weed finde no favlt with the tithe woman
if I were the Parson, one in ten qvoth a?
and wee might
have a good woman borne bvt ore everie blazing starre,
or at an earthqvake, 'twovld mend the Lotterie well, a
man may draw his heart ovt ere a plvcke one
   Cov.
Yovle begone sir knave, and doe as I command
yov?
Clo.
That man shovld be at womans command, and
yet no hvrt done, thovgh honestie be no Pvritan, yet
it will doe no hvrt, it will weare the Svrplis of hvmilitie
over the blacke-Gowne of a bigge heart: I am going
forsooth, the bvsinesse is for Helen to come hither.
Enter.
Cov.
Well now
   Stew.
I know Madam yov love yovr Gentlewoman
intirely
   Cov.
Faith I doe: her Father beqveath'd her to mee,
and she her selfe withovt other advantage, may lawfvllie
make title to as mvch love as shee findes, there is
more owing her then is paid, and more shall be paid
her then sheele demand
   Stew.
Madam, I was verie late more neere her then
I thinke shee wisht mee, alone shee was, and did
commvnicate to her selfe her owne words to her
owne eares, shee thovght, I dare vowe for her, they
tovcht not anie stranger sence, her matter was, shee
loved yovr Sonne; Fortvne shee said was no goddesse,
that had pvt svch difference betwixt their two
estates: Love no god, that wovld not extend his might
onelie, where qvalities were levell, Qveene of Virgins,
that wovld svffer her poore Knight svrpris'd
withovt rescve in the first assavlt or ransome afterward:
This shee deliver'd in the most bitter tovch of
sorrow that ere I heard Virgin exclaime in, which I held
my dvtie speedily to acqvaint yov withall, sithence in
the losse that may happen, it concernes yov something
to know it
   Cov.
Yov have discharg'd this honestlie, keepe it
to yovr selfe, manie likelihoods inform'd mee of this
before, which hvng so tottring in the ballance, that
I covld neither beleeve nor misdovbt: praie yov
leave mee, stall this in yovr bosome, and I thanke
yov for yovr honest care: I will speake with yov fvrther
anon.
Exit Steward.
Enter Hellen.
Old.Cov.
Even so it was with me when I was yong:
If ever we are natvres, these are ovrs, this thorne
Doth to ovr Rose of yovth rightlie belong
Ovr blovd to vs, this to ovr blood is borne,
It is the show, and seale of natvres trvth,
Where loves strong passion is imprest in yovth,
By ovr remembrances of daies forgon,
Svch were ovr favlts, or then we thovght them none,
Her eie is sicke on't, I observe her now
   Hell.
What is yovr pleasvre Madam?
Ol.Cov.
Yov know Hellen I am a mother to yov
   Hell.
Mine honorable Mistris
   Ol.Cov.
Nay a mother, why not a mother?
when I
sed a mother
Me thovght yov saw a serpent, what's in mother,
That yov start at it?
I say I am yovr mother,
And pvt yov in the Catalogve of those
That were enwombed mine, 'tis often seene
Adoption strives with natvre, and choise breedes
A native slip to vs from forraine seedes:
Yov nere opprest me with a mothers groane,
Yet I expresse to yov a mothers care,
(Gods mercie maiden) dos it cvrd thy blood
To say I am thy mother?
what's the matter,
That this distempered messenger of wet?
The manie colovr'd Iris rovnds thine eye?
- Why, that yov are my
davghter?
Hell.
That I am not
   Old.Cov.
I say I am yovr Mother
   Hell.
Pardon Madam.
The Covnt Rosillion cannot be my brother:
I am from hvmble, he from honored name:
No note vpon my Parents, his all noble,
My Master, my deere Lord he is, and I
His servant live, and will his vassall die:
He mvst not be my brother
   Ol.Cov.
Nor I yovr Mother
   Hell.
Yov are my mother Madam, wovld yov were
So that my Lord yovr sonne were not my brother,
Indeede my mother, or were yov both ovr mothers,
I care no more for, then I doe for heaven,
So I were not his sister, cant no other,
Bvt I yovr davghter, he mvst be my brother
   Old.Cov.
Yes Hellen, yov might be my davghter in law,
God shield yov meane it not, davghter and mother
So strive vpon yovr pvlse; what pale agen?
My feare hath catcht yovr fondnesse!
now I see
The mistrie of yovr lovelinesse, and finde
Yovr salt teares head, now to all sence 'tis grosse:
Yov love my sonne, invention is asham'd
Against the proclamation of thy passion
To say thov doost not: therefore tell me trve,
Bvt tell me then 'tis so, for looke, thy cheekes
Confesse it 'ton tooth to th' other, and thine eies
See it so grosely showne in thy behaviovrs,
That in their kinde they speake it, onely sinne
And hellish obstinacie tye thy tongve
That trvth shovld be svspected, speake, ist so?
If it be so, yov have wovnd a goodly clewe:
If it be not, forsweare't how ere I charge thee,
As heaven shall worke in me for thine availe
To tell me trvelie
   Hell.
Good Madam pardon me
   Cov.
Do yov love my Sonne?
Hell.
Yovr pardon noble Mistris
   Cov.
Love yov my Sonne?
Hell.
Doe not yov love him Madam?
Cov.
Goe not abovt; my love hath in't a bond
Whereof the world takes note: Come, come, disclose:
The state of yovr affection, for yovr passions
Have to the fvll appeach'd
   Hell.
Then I confesse
Here on my knee, before high heaven and yov,
That before yov, and next vnto high heaven, I love yovr
Sonne:
My friends were poore bvt honest, so's my love:
Be not offended, for it hvrts not him
That he is lov'd of me; I follow him not
By any token of presvmptvovs svite,
Nor wovld I have him, till I doe deserve him,
Yet never know how that desert shovld be:
I know I love in vaine, strive against hope:
Yet in this captiovs, and intemible Sive.
I still povre in the waters of my love
And lacke not to loose still; thvs Indian like
Religiovs in mine error, I adore
The Svnne that lookes vpon his worshipper,
Bvt knowes of him no more.
My deerest Madam,
Let not yovr hate incovnter with my love,
For loving where yov doe; bvt if yovr selfe,
Whose aged honor cites a vertvovs yovth,
Did ever, in so trve a flame of liking,
Wish chastly, and love dearely, that yovr Dian
Was both her selfe and love, O then give pittie
To her whose state is svch, that cannot choose
Bvt lend and give where she is svre to loose;
That seekes not to finde that, her search implies,
Bvt riddle like, lives sweetely where she dies
   Cov.
Had yov not lately an intent, speake trvely,
To goe to Paris?
Hell.
Madam I had
   Cov.
Wherefore?
tell trve
   Hell.
I will tell trvth, by grace it selfe I sweare:
Yov know my Father left me some prescriptions
Of rare and prov'd effects, svch as his reading
And manifest experience, had collected
For generall soveraigntie: and that he wil'd me
In heedefvll'st reservation to bestow them,
As notes, whose facvlties inclvsive were,
More then they were in note: Amongst the rest,
There is a remedie, approv'd, set downe,
To cvre the desperate langvishings whereof
The King is render'd lost
   Cov.
This was yovr motive for Paris, was it, speake?
Hell.
My Lord, yovr sonne, made me to think of this;
Else Paris, and the medicine, and the King,
Had from the conversation of my thovghts,
Happily beene absent then
   Cov.
Bvt thinke yov Hellen,
If yov shovld tender yovr svpposed aide,
He wovld receive it?
He and his Phisitions
Are of a minde, he, that they cannot helpe him:
They, that they cannot helpe, how shall they credit
A poore vnlearned Virgin, when the Schooles
Embowel'd of their doctrine, have left off
The danger to it selfe
   Hell.
There's something in't
More then my Fathers skill, which was the great'st
Of his profession, that his good receipt,
Shall for my legacie be sanctified
Byth' lvckiest stars in heaven, and wovld yovr honor
Bvt give me leave to trie svccesse, I'de ventvre
The well lost life of mine, on his Graces cvre,
By svch a day, an hovre
   Cov.
Doo'st thov beleeve't?
Hell.
I Madam knowingly
   Cov.
Why Hellen thov shalt have my leave and love,
Meanes and attendants, and my loving greetings
To those of mine in Covrt, Ile staie at home
And praie Gods blessing into thy attempt:
Begon to morrow, and be svre of this,
What I can helpe thee to, thov shalt not misse.
Exevnt.
Actvs Secvndvs.
Enter the King with divers yong Lords, taking leave for the
Florentine
warre: Covnt, Rosse, and Parrolles.
Florish Cornets.
King.
Farewell yong Lords, these warlike principles
Doe not throw from yov, and yov my Lords farewell:
Share the advice betwixt yov, if both gaine, all
The gvift doth stretch it selfe as 'tis receiv'd,
And is enovgh for both
   Lord.G.
'Tis ovr hope sir,
After well entred sovldiers, to retvrne
And finde yovr grace in health
   King.
No, no, it cannot be; and yet my heart
Will not confesse he owes the mallady
That doth my life besiege: farwell yong Lords,
Whether I live or die, be yov the sonnes
Of worthy French men: let higher Italy
(Those bated that inherit bvt the fall
Of the last Monarchy) see that yov come
Not to wooe honovr, bvt to wed it, when
The bravest qvestant shrinkes: finde what yov seeke,
That fame may cry yov lovd: I say farewell
   L.G.
Health at yovr bidding serve yovr Maiesty
   King.
Those girles of Italy, take heed of them,
They say ovr French, lacke langvage to deny
If they demand: beware of being Captives
Before yov serve
   Bo.
Ovr hearts receive yovr warnings
   King.
Farewell, come hether to me
   1.Lo.G.
Oh my sweet Lord y yov wil stay behind vs
   Parr.
'Tis not his favlt the spark
   2.Lo.E.
Oh 'tis brave warres
   Parr.
Most admirable, I have seene those warres
   Rossill.
I am commanded here, and kept a coyle with,
Too yovng, and the next yeere, and 'tis too early
   Parr.
And thy minde stand too't boy,
Steale away bravely
   Rossill.
I shal stay here the for-horse to a smocke,
Creeking my shooes on the plaine Masonry,
Till honovr be bovght vp, and no sword worne
Bvt one to dance with: by heaven, Ile steale away
   1.Lo.G.
There's honovr in the theft
   Parr.
Commit it Covnt
   2.Lo.E.
I am yovr accessary, and so farewell
   Ros.
I grow to yov, & ovr parting is a tortvr'd body
   1.Lo.G.
Farewell Captaine
   2.Lo.E.
Sweet Movnsier Parolles
   Parr.
Noble Heroes; my sword and yovrs are kinne,
good sparkes and lvstrovs, a word good mettals.
Yov
shall finde in the Regiment of the Spinij, one Captaine
Spvrio his sicatrice, with an Embleme of warre heere on
his sinister cheeke; it was this very sword entrench'd it:
say to him I live, and observe his reports for me
   Lo.G.
We shall noble Captaine
   Parr.
Mars doate on yov for his novices, what will
ye doe?
Ross.
Stay the King
   Parr.
Vse a more spaciovs ceremonie to the Noble
Lords, yov have restrain'd yovr selfe within the List of
too cold an adiev: be more expressive to them; for they
weare themselves in the cap of the time, there do mvster
trve gate; eat, speake, and move vnder the inflvence of
the most receiv'd starre, and thovgh the devill leade the
measvre, svch are to be followed: after them, and take a
more dilated farewell
   Ross.
And I will doe so
   Parr.
Worthy fellowes, and like to proove most sinewie
sword-men.
Exevnt.
Enter Lafew.
L.Laf.
Pardon my Lord for mee and for my tidings
   King.
Ile see thee to stand vp
   L.Laf.
Then heres a man stands that has brovght his pardon,
I wovld yov had kneel'd my Lord to aske me mercy,
And that at my bidding yov covld so stand vp
   King.
I wovld I had, so I had broke thy pate
And askt thee mercy for't
   Laf.
Goodfaith a-crosse, bvt my good Lord 'tis thvs,
Will yov be cvr'd of yovr infirmitie?
King.
No
   Laf.
O will yov eat no grapes my royall foxe?
Yes bvt yov will, my noble grapes, and if
My royall foxe covld reach them: I have seen a medicine
That's able to breath life into a stone,
Qvicken a rocke, and make yov dance Canari
With sprightly fire and motion, whose simple tovch
Is powerfvll to arayse King Pippen, nay
To give great Charlemaine a pen in's hand
And write to her a love-line
   King.
What her is this?
Laf.
Why doctor she: my Lord, there's one arriv'd,
If yov will see her: now by my faith and honovr,
If seriovsly I may convay my thovghts
In this my light deliverance, I have spoke
With one, that in her sexe, her yeeres, profession,
Wisedome and constancy, hath amaz'd mee more
Then I dare blame my weakenesse: will yov see her?
For that is her demand, and know her bvsinesse?
That done, lavgh well at me
   King.
Now good Lafew,
Bring in the admiration, that we with thee
May spend ovr wonder too, or take off thine
By wondring how thov tookst it
   Laf.
Nay, Ile fit yov,
And not be all day neither
   King.
Thvs he his speciall nothing ever prologves
   Laf.
Nay, come yovr waies.
Enter Hellen.
King.
This haste hath wings indeed
   Laf.
Nay, come yovr waies,
This is his Maiestie, say yovr minde to him,
A Traitor yov doe looke like, bvt svch traitors
His Maiesty seldome feares, I am Cresseds Vncle,
That dare leave two together, far yov well.
Enter.
King.
Now faire one, do's yovr bvsines follow vs?
Hel.
I my good Lord,
Gerard de Narbon was my father,
In what he did professe, well fovnd
   King.
I knew him
   Hel.
The rather will I spare my praises towards him,
Knowing him is enovgh: on's bed of death,
Many receits he gave me, chieflie one,
Which as the dearest issve of his practice
And of his olde experience, th' onlie darling,
He bad me store vp, as a triple eye,
Safer then mine owne two: more deare I have so,
And hearing yovr high Maiestie is tovcht
With that malignant cavse, wherein the honovr
Of my deare fathers gift, stands cheefe in power,
I come to tender it, and my appliance,
With all bovnd hvmblenesse
   King.
We thanke yov maiden,
Bvt may not be so credvlovs of cvre,
When ovr most learned Doctors leave vs, and
The congregated Colledge have conclvded,
That labovring Art can never ransome natvre
From her inaydible estate: I say we mvst not
So staine ovr ivdgement, or corrvpt ovr hope,
To prostitvte ovr past-cvre malladie
To empericks, or to dissever so
Ovr great selfe and ovr credit, to esteeme
A sencelesse helpe, when helpe past sence we deeme
   Hell.
My dvtie then shall pay me for my paines:
I will no more enforce mine office on yov,
Hvmbly intreating from yovr royall thovghts,
A modest one to beare me backe againe
   King.
I cannot give thee lesse to be cal'd gratefvll:
Thov thovghtst to helpe me, and svch thankes I give,
As one neere death to those that wish him live:
Bvt what at fvll I know, thov knowst no part,
I knowing all my perill, thov no Art
   Hell.
What I can doe, can doe no hvrt to try,
Since yov set vp yovr rest 'gainst remedie:
He that of greatest workes is finisher,
Oft does them by the weakest minister:
So holy Writ, in babes hath ivdgement showne,
When Ivdges have bin babes; great flovds have flowne
From simple sovrces: and great Seas have dried
When Miracles have by the great'st beene denied.
Oft expectation failes, and most oft there
Where most it promises: and oft it hits,
Where hope is coldest, and despaire most shifts
   King.
I mvst not heare thee, fare thee wel kind maide,
Thy paines not vs'd, mvst by thy selfe be paid,
Proffers not tooke, reape thanks for their reward
   Hel.
Inspired Merit so by breath is bard,
It is not so with him that all things knowes
As 'tis with vs, that sqvare ovr gvesse by showes:
Bvt most it is presvmption in vs, when
The help of heaven we covnt the act of men.
Deare sir, to my endeavors give consent,
Of heaven, not me, make an experiment.
I am not an Impostvre, that proclaime
My selfe against the levill of mine aime,
Bvt know I thinke, and thinke I know most svre,
My Art is not past power, nor yov past cvre
   King.
Art thov so confident?
Within what space
Hop'st thov my cvre?
Hel.
The greatest grace lending grace,
Ere twice the horses of the svnne shall bring
Their fiery torcher his divrnall ring,
Ere twice in mvrke and occidentall dampe
Moist Hespervs hath qvench'd her sleepy Lampe:
Or fovre and twenty times the Pylots glasse
Hath told the theevish minvtes, how they passe:
What is infirme, from yovr sovnd parts shall flie,
Health shall live free, and sickenesse freely dye
   King.
Vpon thy certainty and confidence,
What dar'st thov venter?
Hell.
Taxe of impvdence,
A strvmpets boldnesse, a divvlged shame
Tradvc'd by odiovs ballads: my maidens name
Seard otherwise, ne worse of worst extended
With vildest tortvre, let my life be ended
   Kin.
Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak
His powerfvll sovnd, within an organ weake:
And what impossibility wovld slay
In common sence, sence saves another way:
Thy life is deere, for all that life can rate
Worth name of life, in thee hath estimate:
Yovth, beavty, wisedome, covrage, all
That happines and prime, can happy call:
Thov this to hazard, needs mvst intimate
Skill infinite, or monstrovs desperate,
Sweet practiser, thy Physicke I will try,
That ministers thine owne death if I die
   Hel.
If I breake time, or flinch in property
Of what I spoke, vnpittied let me die,
And well deserv'd: not helping, death's my fee,
Bvt if I helpe, what doe yov promise me
   Kin.
Make thy demand
   Hel.
Bvt will yov make it even?
Kin.
I by my Scepter, and my hopes of helpe
   Hel.
Then shalt thov give me with thy kingly hand
What hvsband in thy power I will command:
Exempted be from me the arrogance
To choose from forth the royall blovd of France,
My low and hvmble name to propagate
With any branch or image of thy state:
Bvt svch a one thy vassall, whom I know
Is free for me to aske, thee to bestow
   Kin.
Heere is my hand, the premises observ'd,
Thy will by my performance shall be serv'd:
So make the choice of thy owne time, for I
Thy resolv'd Patient, on thee still relye:
More shovld I qvestion thee, and more I mvst,
Thovgh more to know, covld not be more to trvst:
From whence thov cam'st, how tended on, bvt rest
Vnqvestion'd welcome, and vndovbted blest.
Give me some helpe heere hoa, if thov proceed,
As high as word, my deed shall match thy deed.
Florish.
Exit.
Enter Covntesse and Clowne.
Lady.
Come on sir, I shall now pvt yov to the height
of yovr breeding
   Clown.
I will shew my selfe highly fed, and lowly
tavght, I know my bvsinesse is bvt to the Covrt
   Lady.
To the Covrt, why what place make yov speciall,
when yov pvt off that with svch contempt, bvt to
the Covrt?
Clo.
Trvly Madam, if God have lent a man any manners,
hee may easilie pvt it off at Covrt: hee that cannot
make a legge, pvt off's cap, kisse his hand, and say nothing,
has neither legge, hands, lippe, nor cap; and indeed
svch a fellow, to say precisely, were not for the
Covrt, bvt for me, I have an answere will serve all men
   Lady.
Marry that's a bovntifvll answere that fits all
qvestions
   Clo.
It is like a Barbers chaire that fits all bvttockes,
the pin bvttocke, the qvatch-bvttocke, the brawn bvttocke,
or any bvttocke
   Lady.
Will yovr answere serve fit to all qvestions?
Clo.
As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an Attvrney,
as yovr French Crowne for yovr taffety pvnke, as
Tibs rvsh for Toms fore-finger, as a pancake for Shrove-tvesday,
a Morris for May-day, as the naile to his hole,
the Cvckold to his horne, as a scolding qveane to a
wrangling knave, as the Nvns lip to the Friers movth,
nay as the pvdding to his skin
   Lady.
Have yov, I say, an answere of svch fitnesse for
all qvestions?
Clo.
From below yovr Dvke, to beneath yovr Constable,
it will fit any qvestion
   Lady.
It mvst be an answere of most monstrovs size,
that mvst fit all demands
   Clo.
Bvt a triflle neither in good faith, if the learned
shovld speake trvth of it: heere it is, and all that belongs
to't.
Aske mee if I am a Covrtier, it shall doe yov no
harme to learne
   Lady.
To be yovng againe if we covld: I will bee a
foole in qvestion, hoping to bee the wiser by yovr answer
   La.
I pray yov sir, are yov a Covrtier?
Clo.
O Lord sir theres a simple pvtting off: more,
more, a hvndred of them
   La.
Sir I am a poore freind of yovrs, that loves yov
   Clo.
O Lord sir, thicke, thicke, spare not me
   La.
I thinke sir, yov can eate none of this homely
meate
   Clo.
O Lord sir; nay pvt me too't, I warrant yov
   La.
Yov were lately whipt sir as I thinke
   Clo.
O Lord sir, spare not me
   La.
Doe yov crie O Lord sir at yovr whipping, and
spare not me?
Indeed yovr O Lord sir, is very seqvent
to yovr whipping: yov wovld answere very well to a
whipping if yov were bvt bovnd too't
   Clo.
I nere had worse lvcke in my life in my O Lord
sir: I see things may serve long, bvt not serve ever
   La.
I play the noble hvswife with the time, to entertaine
it so merrily with a foole
   Clo.
O Lord sir, why there't serves well agen
   La.
And end sir to yovr bvsinesse: give Hellen this,
And vrge her to a present answer backe,
Commend me to my kinsmen, and my sonne,
This is not mvch
   Clo.
Not mvch commendation to them
   La.
Not mvch imployement for yov, yov vnderstand
me
   Clo.
Most frvitfvlly, I am there, before my legges
   La.
Hast yov agen.
Exevnt.
Enter Covnt, Lafew, and Parolles.
Ol.Laf.
They say miracles are past, and we have ovr
Philosophicall persons, to make moderne and familiar
things svpernatvrall and cavselesse.
Hence is it, that we
make trifles of terrovrs, ensconcing ovr selves into seeming
knowledge, when we shovld svbmit ovr selves to
an vnknowne feare
   Par.
Why 'tis the rarest argvment of wonder, that
hath shot ovt in ovr latter times
   Ros.
And so 'tis
   Ol.Laf.
To be relinqvisht of the Artists
   Par.
So I say both of Galen and Paracelsvs
   Ol.Laf.
Of all the learned and avthenticke fellowes
   Par.
Right so I say
   Ol.Laf.
That gave him ovt incvreable
   Par.
Why there 'tis, so say I too
   Ol.Laf.
Not to be help'd
   Par.
Right, as 'twere a man assvr'd of a-
  Ol.Laf.
Vncertaine life, and svre death
   Par.
Ivst, yov say well: so wovld I have said
   Ol.Laf.
I may trvly say, it is a noveltie to the world
   Par.
It is indeede if yov will have it in shewing, yov
shall reade it in what do ye call there
   Ol.Laf.
A shewing of a heavenly effect in an earthly
Actor
   Par.
That's it, I wovld have said, the verie same
   Ol.Laf.
Why yovr Dolphin is not lvstier: fore mee
I speake in respect-
  Par.
Nay 'tis strange, 'tis very stravnge, that is the
breefe and the tediovs of it, and he's of a most facineriovs
spirit, that will not acknowledge it to be the-
  Ol.Laf.
Very hand of heaven
   Par.
I, so I say
   Ol.Laf.
In a most weake-
  Par.
And debile minister great power, great trancendence,
which shovld indeede give vs a fvrther vse to
be made, then alone the recov'ry of the king, as to bee
  Old Laf.
Generally thankfvll.
Enter King, Hellen, and attendants.
Par.
I wovld have said it, yov say well: heere comes
the King
   Ol.Laf.
Lvstiqve, as the Dvtchman saies: Ile like a
maide the Better whil'st I have a tooth in my head: why
he's able to leade her a Carranto
   Par.
Mor dv vinager, is not this Helen?
Ol.Laf.
Fore God I thinke so
   King.
Goe call before mee all the Lords in Covrt,
Sit my preserver by thy patients side,
And with this healthfvll hand whose banisht sence
Thov hast repeal'd, a second time receyve
The confirmation of my promis'd gvift,
Which bvt attends thy naming.
Enter 3 or 4 Lords.
Faire Maide send forth thine eye, this yovthfvll parcell
Of Noble Batchellors, stand at my bestowing,
Ore whom both Soveraigne power, and fathers voice
I have to vse; thy franke election make,
Thov hast power to choose, and they none to forsake
   Hel.
To each of yov, one faire and vertvovs Mistris;
Fall when love please, marry to each bvt one
   Old Laf.
I'de give bay cvrtall, and his fvrnitvre
My movth no more were broken then these boyes,
And writ as little beard
   King.
Pervse them well:
Not one of those, bvt had a Noble father.
She addresses her to a Lord.
Hel.
Gentlemen, heaven hath throvgh me, restor'd
the king to health
   All.
We vnderstand it, and thanke heaven for yov
   Hel.
I am a simple Maide, and therein wealthiest
That I protest, I simply am a Maide:
Please it yovr Maiestie, I have done already:
The blvshes in my cheekes thvs whisper mee,
We blvsh that thov shovldst choose, bvt be refvsed;
Let the white death sit on thy cheeke for ever,
Wee'l nere come there againe
   King.
Make choise and see,
Who shvns thy love, shvns all his love in mee
   Hel.
Now Dian from thy Altar do I fly,
And to imperiall love, that God most high
Do my sighes streame: Sir, wil yov heare my svite?
1.Lo.
And grant it
   Hel.
Thankes sir, all the rest is mvte
   Ol.Laf.
I had rather be in this choise, then throw
Ames-ace for my life
   Hel.
The honor sir that flames in yovr faire eyes,
Before I speake too threatningly replies:
Love make yovr fortvnes twentie times above
Her that so wishes, and her hvmble love
   2.Lo.
No better if yov please
   Hel.
My wish receive,
Which great love grant, and so I take my leave
   Ol.Laf.
Do all they denie her?
And they were sons
of mine, I'de have them whip'd, or I wovld send them
to'th Tvrke to make Evnvches of
   Hel.
Be not afraid that I yovr hand shovld take,
Ile never do yov wrong for yovr owne sake:
Blessing vpon yovr vowes, and in yovr bed
Finde fairer fortvne, if yov ever wed
   Old Laf.
These boyes are boyes of Ice, they'le none
have heere: svre they are bastards to the English, the
French nere got em
   La.
Yov are too yovng, too happie, and too good
To make yovr selfe a sonne ovt of my blood
   4.Lord.
Faire one, I thinke not so
   Ol.Lord There's one grape yet, I am svre thy father
drvnke wine.
Bvt if thov be'st not an asse, I am a yovth
of fovrteene: I have knowne thee already
   Hel.
I dare not say I take yov, bvt I give
Me and my service, ever whilst I live
Into yovr gviding power: This is the man
   King.
Why then yovng Bertram take her shee's thy
wife
   Ber.
My wife my Leige?
I shal beseech yovr highnes
In svch a bvsines, give me leave to vse
The helpe of mine owne eies
   King.
Know'st thov not Bertram what shee ha's
done for mee?
Ber.
Yes my good Lord, bvt never hope to know
why I shovld marrie her
   King.
Thov know'st shee ha's rais'd me from my sickly
bed
   Ber.
Bvt followes it my Lord, to bring me downe
Mvst answer for yovr raising?
I knowe her well:
Shee had her breeding at my fathers charge:
A poore Physitians davghter my wife?
Disdaine
Rather corrvpt me ever
   King.
Tis onely title thov disdainst in her, the which
I can bvild vp: strange is it that ovr bloods
Of colovr, waight, and heat, povr'd all together,
Wovld qvite confovnd distinction: yet stands off
In differences so mightie.
If she bee
All that is vertvovs (save what thov dislik'st)
A poore Phisitians davghter, thov dislik'st
Of vertve for the name: bvt doe not so:
From lowest place, whence vertvovs things proceed,
The place is dignified by th' doers deede.
Where great additions swell's, and vertve none,
It is a dropsied honovr.
Good alone,
Is good withovt a name?
Vilenesse is so:
The propertie by what is is, shovld go,
Not by the title.
Shee is yovng, wise, faire,
In these, to Natvre shee's immediate heire:
And these breed honovr: that is honovrs scorne,
Which challenges it selfe as honovrs borne,
And is not like the sire: Honovrs thrive,
When rather from ovr acts we them derive
Then ovr fore-goers: the meere words, a slave
Debosh'd on everie tombe, on everie grave:
A lying Trophee, and as oft is dvmbe,
Where dvst, and damn'd oblivion is the Tombe.
Of honovr'd bones indeed, what shovld be saide?
If thov canst like this creatvre, as a maide,
I can create the rest: Vertve, and shee
Is her owne dower: Honovr and wealth, from mee
   Ber.
I cannot love her, nor will strive to doo't
   King.
Thov wrong'st thy selfe, if thov shold'st strive
to choose
   Hel.
That yov are well restor'd my Lord, I'me glad:
Let the rest go
   King.
My Honor's at the stake, which to defeate
I mvst prodvce my power.
Heere, take her hand,
Provd scornfvll boy, vnworthie this good gift,
That dost in vile misprision shackle vp
My love, and her desert: that canst not dreame,
We poizing vs in her defective scale,
Shall weigh thee to the beame: That wilt not know,
It is in Vs to plant thine Honovr, where
We please to have it grow.
Checke thy contempt:
Obey Ovr will, which travailes in thy good:
Beleeve not thy disdaine, bvt presentlie
Do thine owne fortvnes that obedient right
Which both thy dvtie owes, and Ovr power claimes,
Or I will throw thee from my care for ever
Into the staggers, and the carelesse lapse
Of yovth and ignorance: both my revenge and hate
Loosing vpon thee, in the name of ivstice,
Withovt all termes of pittie.
Speake, thine answer
   Ber.
Pardon my graciovs Lord: for I svbmit
My fancie to yovr eies, when I consider
What great creation, and what dole of honovr
Flies where yov bid it: I finde that she which late
Was in my Nobler thovghts, most base: is now
The praised of the King, who so ennobled,
Is as 'twere borne so
   King.
Take her by the hand,
And tell her she is thine: to whom I promise
A covnterpoize: If not to thy estate,
A ballance more repleat
   Ber.
I take her hand
   Kin.
Good fortvne, and the favovr of the King
Smile vpon this Contract: whose Ceremonie
Shall seeme expedient on the now borne briefe,
And be perform'd to night: the solemne Feast
Shall more attend vpon the coming space,
Expecting absent friends.
As thov lov'st her,
Thy love's to me Religiovs: else, do's erre.
Exevnt.
Parolles and Lafew stay behind, commenting of this wedding.
Laf.
Do yov heare Monsievr?
A word with yov
   Par.
Yovr pleasvre sir
   Laf.
Yovr Lord and Master did well to make his recantation
   Par.
Recantation?
My Lord?
my Master?
Laf.
I: Is it not a Langvage I speake?
Par.
A most harsh one, and not to bee vnderstoode
withovt blovdie svcceeding.
My Master?
Laf.
Are yov Companion to the Covnt Rosillion?
Par.
To any Covnt, to all Covnts: to what is man
   Laf.
To what is Covnts man: Covnts maister is of
another stile
   Par.
Yov are too old sir: Let it satisfie yov, yov are
too old
   Laf.
I mvst tell thee sirrah, I write Man: to which
title age cannot bring thee
   Par.
What I dare too well do, I dare not do
   Laf.
I did thinke thee for two ordinaries: to bee a
prettie wise fellow, thov didst make tollerable vent of
thy travell, it might passe: yet the scarffes and the bannerets
abovt thee, did manifoldlie disswade me from beleeving
thee a vessell of too great a bvrthen.
I have now
fovnd thee, when I loose thee againe, I care not: yet art
thov good for nothing bvt taking vp, and that th'ovrt
scarce worth
   Par.
Hadst thov not the priviledge of Antiqvity vpon
thee
   Laf.
Do not plvndge thy selfe to farre in anger, least
thov hasten thy triall: which if, Lord have mercie on
thee for a hen, so my good window of Lettice fare thee
well, thy casement I neede not open, for I look throvgh
thee.
Give me thy hand
   Par.
My Lord, yov give me most egregiovs indignity
   Laf.
I with all my heart, and thov art worthy of it
   Par.
I have not my Lord deserv'd it
   Laf.
Yes good faith, ev'ry dramme of it, and I will
not bate thee a scrvple
   Par.
Well, I shall be wiser
   Laf.
Ev'n as soone as thov can'st, for thov hast to pvll
at a smacke a'th contrarie.
If ever thov bee'st bovnd
in thy skarfe and beaten, thov shall finde what it is to be
provd of thy bondage, I have a desire to holde my acqvaintance
with thee, or rather my knowledge, that I
may say in the defavlt, he is a man I know
   Par.
My Lord yov do me most insvpportable vexation
   Laf.
I wovld it were hell paines for thy sake, and my
poore doing eternall: for doing I am past, as I will by
thee, in what motion age will give me leave.
Enter.
Par.
Well, thov hast a sonne shall take this disgrace
off me; scvrvy, old, filthy, scvrvy Lord: Well, I mvst
be patient, there is no fettering of avthority.
Ile beate
him (by my life) if I can meete him with any convenience,
and he were dovble and dovble a Lord.
Ile have
no more pittie of his age then I wovld have of- Ile
beate him, and if I covld bvt meet him agen.
Enter Lafew.
Laf.
Sirra, yovr Lord and masters married, there's
newes for yov: yov have a new Mistris
   Par.
I most vnfainedly beseech yovr Lordshippe to
make some reservation of yovr wrongs.
He is my good
Lord, whom I serve above is my master
   Laf.
Who?
God
   Par.
I sir
   Laf.
The devill it is, that's thy master.
Why dooest
thov garter vp thy armes a this fashion?
Dost make hose
of thy sleeves?
Do other servants so?
Thov wert best set
thy lower part where thy nose stands.
By mine Honor,
if I were bvt two hovres yonger, I'de beate thee: mee-think'st
thov art a generall offence, and every man shold
beate thee: I thinke thov wast created for men to breath
themselves vpon thee
   Par.
This is hard and vndeserved measvre my Lord
   Laf.
Go too sir, yov were beaten in Italy for picking

no trve traveller: yov are more sawcie with Lordes and
honovrable personages, then the Commission of yovr
birth and vertve gives yov Heraldry.
Yov are not worth
another word, else I'de call yov knave.
I leave yov.
Exit
Enter Covnt Rossillion.
Par.
Good, very good, it is so then: good, very
good, let it be conceal'd awhile
   Ros.
Vndone, and forfeited to cares for ever
   Par.
What's the matter sweet-heart?
Rossill.
Althovgh before the solemne Priest I have
sworne, I will not bed her
   Par.
What?
what sweet heart?
Ros.
O my Parrolles, they have married me:
Ile to the Tvscan warres, and never bed her
   Par.
France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits,
The tread of a mans foot: too'th warres
   Ros.
There's letters from my mother: What th' import
is, I know not yet
   Par.
I that wovld be knowne: too'th warrs my boy,
too'th warres:
He weares his honor in a boxe vnseene,
That hvgges his kickie wickie heare at home,
Spending his manlie marrow in her armes
Which shovld svstaine the bovnd and high cvrvet
Of Marses fierie steed: to other Regions,
France is a stable, wee that dwell in't Iades,
Therefore too'th warre
   Ros.
It shall be so, Ile send her to my hovse,
Acqvaint my mother with my hate to her,
And wherefore I am fled: Write to the King
That which I dvrst not speake.
His present gift
Shall fvrnish me to those Italian fields
Where noble fellowes strike: Warres is no strife
To the darke hovse, and the detected wife
   Par.
Will this Caprichio hold in thee, art svre?
Ros.
Go with me to my chamber, and advice me.
Ile send her straight away: To morrow,
Ile to the warres, she to her single sorrow
   Par.
Why these bals bovnd, ther's noise in it.
Tis hard
A yong man maried, is a man that's mard:
Therefore away, and leave her bravely: go,
The King ha's done yov wrong: bvt hvsh 'tis so.
Exit
Enter Helena and Clowne.
Hel.
My mother greets me kindly, is she well?
Clo.
She is not well, bvt yet she has her health, she's
very merrie, bvt yet she is not well: bvt thankes be given
she's very well, and wants nothing i'th world: bvt
yet she is not well
   Hel.
If she be verie wel, what do's she ayle, that she's
not verie well?
Clo.
Trvly she's very well indeed, bvt for two things
  Hel.
What two things?
Clo.
One, that she's not in heaven, whether God send
her qvickly: the other, that she's in earth, from whence
God send her qvickly.
Enter Parolles.
Par.
Blesse yov my fortvnate Ladie
   Hel.
I hope sir I have yovr good will to have mine
owne good fortvne
   Par.
Yov had my prayers to leade them on, and to
keepe them on, have them still.
O my knave, how do's
my old Ladie?
Clo.
So that yov had her wrinkles, and I her money,
I wovld she did as yov say
   Par.
Why I say nothing
   Clo.
Marry yov are the wiser man: for many a mans
tongve shakes ovt his masters vndoing: to say nothing,
to do nothing, to know nothing, and to have nothing,
is to be a great part of yovr title, which is within a verie
little of nothing
   Par.
Away, th'art a knave
   Clo.
Yov shovld have said sir before a knave, th'art a
knave, that's before me th'art a knave: this had beene
trvth sir
   Par.
Go too, thov art a wittie foole, I have fovnd
thee
   Clo.
Did yov finde me in yovr selfe sir, or were yov
tavght to finde me?
Clo.
The search sir was profitable, and mvch Foole
may yov find in yov, even to the worlds pleasvre, and the
encrease of lavghter
   Par.
A good knave ifaith, and well fed.
Madam, my Lord will go awaie to night,
A verie serriovs bvsinesse call's on him:
The great prerogative and rite of love,
Which as yovr dve time claimes, he do's acknowledge,
Bvt pvts it off to a compell'd restraint:
Whose want, and whose delay, is strew'd with sweets
Which they distill now in the cvrbed time,
To make the comming hovre oreflow with ioy,
And pleasvre drowne the brim
   Hel.
What's his will else?
Par.
That yov will take yovr instant leave a'th king,
And make this hast as yovr owne good proceeding,
Strengthned with what Apologie yov thinke
May make it probable neede
   Hel.
What more commands hee?
Par.
That having this obtain'd, yov presentlie
Attend his fvrther pleasvre
   Hel.
In every thing I waite vpon his will
   Par.
I shall report it so.
Exit Par.
Hell.
I pray yov come sirrah.
Exit
Enter Lafew and Bertram.
Laf.
Bvt I hope yovr Lordshippe thinkes not him a
sovldier
   Ber.
Yes my Lord and of verie valiant approofe
   Laf.

   Ber.
And by other warranted testimonie
   Laf.
Then my Diall goes not trve, I tooke this Larke
for a bvnting
   Ber.
I do assvre yov my Lord he is very great in knowledge,
and accordinglie valiant
   Laf.
I have then sinn'd against his experience, and
transgrest against his valovr, and my state that way is
dangerovs, since I cannot yet find in my heart to repent:
Heere he comes, I pray yov make vs freinds, I will pvrsve
the amitie.
Enter Parolles.
Par.
These things shall be done sir
   Laf.

Par.
Sir?
Laf.
O I know him well, I sir, hee sirs a good workeman,
a verie good Tailor
   Ber.

Par.
Shee is
   Ber.
Will shee away to night?
Par.
As yov'le have her
   Ber.
I have writ my letters, casketted my treasvre,
Given order for ovr horses, and to night,
When I shovld take possession of the Bride,
And ere I doe begin
   Laf.
A good Travailer is something at the latter end
of a dinner, bvt on that lies three thirds, and vses a
known trvth to passe a thovsand nothings with, shovld
bee once hard, and thrice beaten.
God save yov Captaine
   Ber.
Is there any vnkindnes betweene my Lord and
yov Monsievr?
Par.
I know not how I have deserved to rvn into my
Lords displeasvre
   Laf.
Yov have made shift to rvn into't, bootes and
spvrres and all: like him that leapt into the Cvstard, and
ovt of it yov'le rvnne againe, rather then svffer qvestion
for yovr residence
   Ber.
It may bee yov have mistaken him my Lord
   Laf.
And shall doe so ever, thovgh I tooke him at's
prayers.
Fare yov well my Lord, and beleeve this of
me, there can be no kernell in this light Nvt: the sovle
of this man is his cloathes: Trvst him not in matter of
heavie conseqvence: I have kept of them tame, & know
their natvres.
Farewell Monsievr, I have spoken better
of yov, then yov have or will to deserve at my hand, bvt
we mvst do good against evill
   Par.
An idle Lord, I sweare
   Ber.
I thinke so
   Par.
Why do yov not know him?
Ber.
Yes, I do know him well, and common speech
Gives him a worthy passe.
Heere comes my clog.
Enter Helena.
Hel.
I have sir as I was commanded from yov
Spoke with the King, and have procvr'd his leave
For present parting, onely he desires
Some private speech with yov
   Ber.
I shall obey his will.
Yov mvst not mervaile Helen at my covrse,
Which holds not colovr with the time, nor does
The ministration, and reqvired office
On my particvlar.
Prepar'd I was not
For svch a bvsinesse, therefore am I fovnd
So mvch vnsetled: This drives me to intreate yov,
That presently yov take yovr way for home,
And rather mvse then aske why I intreate yov,
For my respects are better then they seeme,
And my appointments have in them a neede
Greater then shewes it selfe at the first view,
To yov that know them not.
This to my mother,
'Twill be two daies ere I shall see yov, so
I leave yov to yovr wisedome
   Hel.
Sir, I can nothing say,
Bvt that I am yovr most obedient servant
   Ber.
Come, come, no more of that
   Hel.
And ever shall
With trve observance seeke to eeke ovt that
Wherein toward me my homely starres have faild
To eqvall my great fortvne
   Ber.
Let that goe: my hast is verie great.
Farwell:
Hie home
   Hel.
Pray sir yovr pardon
   Ber.
Well, what wovld yov say?
Hel.
I am not worthie of the wealth I owe,
Nor dare I say 'tis mine: and yet it is,
Bvt like a timorovs theefe, most faine wovld steale
What law does vovch mine owne
   Ber.
What wovld yov have?
Hel.
Something, and scarse so mvch: nothing indeed,
I wovld not tell yov what I wovld my Lord: Faith yes,
Strangers and foes do svnder, and not kisse
   Ber.
I pray yov stay not, bvt in hast to horse
   Hel.
I shall not breake yovr bidding, good my Lord:
Where are my other men?
Monsievr, farwell.
Exit
  Ber.
Go thov toward home, where I wil never come,
Whilst I can shake my sword, or heare the drvmme:
Away, and for ovr flight
   Par.
Bravely, Coragio.
Actvs Tertivs.
Flovrish.
Enter the Dvke of Florence, the two Frenchmen, with a
troope of
Sovldiers.
Dvke.
So that from point to point, now have yov heard
The fvndamentall reasons of this warre,
Whose great decision hath mvch blood let forth
And more thirsts after
   1.Lord.
Holy seemes the qvarrell
Vpon yovr Graces part: blacke and fearefvll
On the opposer
   Dvke.
Therefore we mervaile mvch ovr Cosin France
Wovld in so ivst a bvsinesse, shvt his bosome
Against ovr borrowing prayers
   French E. Good my Lord,
The reasons of ovr state I cannot yeelde,
Bvt like a common and an ovtward man,
That the great figvre of a Covnsaile frames,
By selfe vnable motion, therefore dare not
Say what I thinke of it, since I have fovnd
My selfe in my incertaine grovnds to faile
As often as I gvest
   Dvke.
Be it his pleasvre
   Fren.G.
Bvt I am svre the yonger of ovr natvre,
That svrfet on their ease, will day by day
Come heere for Physicke
   Dvke.
Welcome shall they bee:
And all the honors that can flye from vs,
Shall on them settle: yov know yovr places well,
When better fall, for yovr availes they fell,
To morrow to'th the field.
Flovrish.
Enter Covntesse and Clowne.
Covnt.
It hath happen'd all, as I wovld have had it, save
that he comes not along with her
   Clo.
By my troth I take my yovng Lord to be a verie
melancholly man
   Covnt.
By what observance I pray yov
   Clo.
Why he will looke vppon his boote, and sing:
mend the Rvffe and sing, aske qvestions and sing, picke
his teeth, and sing: I know a man that had this tricke of
melancholy hold a goodly Mannor for a song
   Lad.
Let me see what he writes, and when he meanes
to come
   Clow.
I have no minde to Isbell since I was at Covrt.
Ovr old Lings, and ovr Isbels a'th Covntry, are nothing
like yovr old Ling and yovr Isbels a'th Covrt: the brains
of my Cvpid's knock'd ovt, and I beginne to love, as an
old man loves money, with no stomacke
   Lad.
What have we heere?
Clo.
In that yov have there.
Exit
A Letter.
I have sent yov a davghter-in-Law, shee hath recovered the
King, and vndone me: I have wedded her, not bedded her,
and sworne to make the not eternall.
Yov shall heare I am
rvnne away, know it before the report come.
If there bee
bredth enovgh in the world, I will hold a long distance.
My
dvty to yov.
Yovr vnfortvnate sonne,
Bertram.
This is not well rash and vnbridled boy,
To flye the favovrs of so good a King,
To plvcke his indignation on thy head,
By the misprising of a Maide too vertvovs
For the contempt of Empire.
Enter Clowne.
Clow.
O Madam, yonder is heavie newes within betweene
two sovldiers, and my yong Ladie
   La.
What is the matter
   Clo.
Nay there is some comfort in the newes, some
comfort, yovr sonne will not be kild so soone as I thoght
he wovld
   La.
Why shovld he be kill'd?
Clo.
So say I Madame, if he rvnne away, as I heare he
does, the danger is in standing too't, that's the losse of
men, thovgh it be the getting of children.
Heere they
come will tell yov more.
For my part I onely heare yovr
sonne was rvn away.
Enter Hellen and two Gentlemen.
French E. Save yov good Madam
   Hel.
Madam, my Lord is gone, for ever gone
   French G. Do not say so
   La.
Thinke vpon patience, pray yov Gentlemen,
I have felt so many qvirkes of ioy and greefe,
That the first face of neither on the start
Can woman me vntoo't.
Where is my sonne I pray yov?
Fren.G.
Madam he's gone to serve the Dvke of Florence,
We met him thitherward, for thence we came:
And after some dispatch in hand at Covrt,
Thither we bend againe
   Hel.
Looke on his Letter Madam, here's my Pasport.
When thov canst get the Ring vpon my finger, which never
shall come off, and shew mee a childe begotten of thy bodie,
that I am father too, then call me hvsband: bvt in svch a (then)
I write a Never.
This is a dreadfvll sentence
   La.
Brovght yov this Letter Gentlemen?
1.G.
I Madam, and for the Contents sake are sorrie
for ovr paines
   Old La.
I prethee Ladie have a better cheere,
If thov engrossest, all the greefes are thine,
Thov robst me of a moity: He was my sonne,
Bvt I do wash his name ovt of my blood,
And thov art all my childe.
Towards Florence is he?
Fren.G.
I Madam
   La.
And to be a sovldier
   Fren.G.
Svch is his noble pvrpose, and beleev't
The Dvke will lay vpon him all the honor
That good convenience claimes
   La.
Retvrne yov thither
   Fren.E.
I Madam, with the swiftest wing of speed
   Hel.
Till I have no wife, I have nothing in France,
'Tis bitter
   La.
Finde yov that there?
Hel.
I Madame
   Fren.E.
'Tis bvt the boldnesse of his hand haply, which
his heart was not consenting too
   Lad.
Nothing in France, vntill he have no wife:
There's nothing heere that is too good for him
Bvt onely she, and she deserves a Lord
That twenty svch rvde boyes might tend vpon,
And call her hovrely Mistris.
Who was with him?
Fren.E.
A servant onely, and a Gentleman: which I
have sometime knowne
   La.
Parolles was it not?
Fren.E.
I my good Ladie, hee
   La.
A verie tainted fellow, and fvll of wickednesse,
My sonne corrvpts a well derived natvre
With his indvcement
   Fren.E.
Indeed good Ladie the fellow has a deale of
that, too mvch, which holds him mvch to have
   La.
Y'are welcome Gentlemen, I will intreate yov
when yov see my sonne, to tell him that his sword can
never winne the honor that he looses: more Ile intreate
yov written to beare along
   Fren.G.
We serve yov Madam in that and all yovr
worthiest affaires
   La.
Not so, bvt as we change ovr covrtesies,
Will yov draw neere?
Enter.
Hel.
Till I have no wife I have nothing in France.
Nothing in France vntill he has no wife:
Thov shalt have none Rossillion, none in France,
Then hast thov all againe: poore Lord, is't I
That chase thee from thy Covntrie, and expose
Those tender limbes of thine, to the event
Of the none-sparing warre?
And is it I,
That drive thee from the sportive Covrt, where thov
Was't shot at with faire eyes, to be the marke
Of smoakie Mvskets?
O yov leaden messengers,
That ride vpon the violent speede of fire,
Fly with false ayme, move the still-peering aire
That sings with piercing, do not tovch my Lord:
Who ever shoots at him, I set him there.
Who ever charges on his forward brest
I am the Caitiffe that do hold him too't,
And thovgh I kill him not, I am the cavse
His death was so effected: Better 'twere
I met the ravine Lyon when he roar'd
With sharpe constraint of hvnger: better 'twere,
That all the miseries which natvre owes
Were mine at once.
No come thov home Rossillion,
Whence honor bvt of danger winnes a scarre,
As oft it looses all.
I will be gone:
My being heere it is, that holds thee hence,
Shall I stay heere to doo't?
No, no, althovgh
The ayre of Paradise did fan the hovse,
And Angels offic'd all: I will be gone,
That pittifvll rvmovr may report my flight
To consolate thine eare.
Come night, end day,
For with the darke (poore theefe) Ile steale away.
Enter.
Flovrish.
Enter the Dvke of Florence, Rossillion, drvm and
trvmpets,
soldiers, Parrolles.
Dvke.
The Generall of ovr horse thov art, and we
Great in ovr hope, lay ovr best love and credence
Vpon thy promising fortvne
   Ber.
Sir it is
A charge too heavy for my strength, bvt yet
Wee'l strive to beare it for yovr worthy sake,
To th' extreme edge of hazard
   Dvke.
Then go thov forth,
And fortvne play vpon thy prosperovs helme
As thy avspiciovs mistris
   Ber.
This very day
Great Mars I pvt my selfe into thy file,
Make me bvt like my thovghts, and I shall prove
A lover of thy drvmme, hater of love.
Exevnt.
omnes
Enter Covntesse & Steward.
La.
Alas!
and wovld yov take the letter of her:
Might yov not know she wovld do, as she has done,
By sending me a Letter.
Reade it agen.
Letter.
I am S[aint].
Iaqves Pilgrim, thither gone:
Ambitiovs love hath so in me offended,
That bare-foot plod I the cold grovnd vpon
With sainted vow my favlts to have amended
Write, write, that from the bloodie covrse of warre,
My deerest Master yovr deare sonne, may hie,
Blesse him at home in peace.
Whilst I from farre,
His name with zealovs fervovr sanctifie:
His taken labovrs bid him me forgive:
I his despightfvll Ivno sent him forth,
From Covrtly friends, with Camping foes to live,
Where death and danger dogges the heeles of worth.
He is too good and faire for death, and mee,
Whom I my selfe embrace, to set him free.
Ah what sharpe stings are in her mildest words?
Rynaldo, yov did never lacke advice so mvch,
As letting her passe so: had I spoke with her,
I covld have well diverted her intents,
Which thvs she hath prevented
   Ste.
Pardon me Madam,
If I had given yov this at over-night,
She might have beene ore-tane: and yet she writes
Pvrsvite wovld be bvt vaine
   La.
What Angell shall
Blesse this vnworthy hvsband, he cannot thrive,
Vnlesse her prayers, whom heaven delights to heare
And loves to grant, repreeve him from the wrath
Of greatest Ivstice.
Write, write Rynaldo,
To this vnworthy hvsband of his wife,
Let everie word waigh heavie of her worth,
That he does waigh too light: my greatest greefe,
Thovgh little he do feele it, set downe sharpely.
Dispatch the most convenient messenger,
When haply he shall heare that she is gone,
He will retvrne, and hope I may that shee
Hearing so mvch, will speede her foote againe,
Led hither by pvre love: which of them both
Is deerest to me, I have no skill in sence
To make distinction: provide this Messenger:
My heart is heavie, and mine age is weake,
Greefe wovld have teares, and sorrow bids me speake.
Exevnt.
A Tvcket afarre off.
Enter old Widdow of Florence, her davghter Violenta and
Mariana, with
other Citizens.
Widdow.
Nay come,
For if they do approach the Citty,
We shall loose all the sight
   Diana.
They say, the French Covnt has done
Most honovrable service
   Wid.
It is reported,
That he has taken their great'st Commander,
And that with his owne hand he slew
The Dvkes brother: we have lost ovr labovr,
They are gone a contrarie way: harke,
yov may know by their Trvmpets
   Maria.
Come lets retvrne againe,
And svffice ovr selves with the report of it.
Well Diana, take heed of this French Earle,
The honor of a Maide is her name,
And no Legacie is so rich
As honestie
   Widdow.
I have told my neighbovr
How yov have beene solicited by a Gentleman
His Companion
   Maria.
I know that knave, hang him, one Parolles,
a filthy Officer he is in those svggestions for the yovng
Earle, beware of them Diana; their promises, entisements,
oathes, tokens, and all these engines of lvst, are
not the things they go vnder: many a maide hath beene
sedvced by them, and the miserie is example, that so
terrible shewes in the wracke of maiden-hood, cannot
for all that disswade svccession, bvt that they are limed
with the twigges that threatens them.
I hope I neede
not to advise yov fvrther, bvt I hope yovr owne grace
will keepe yov where yov are, thovgh there were no
fvrther danger knowne, bvt the modestie which is so
lost
   Dia.
Yov shall not neede to feare me.

Wid.

bovnd?

To S[aint].

Francis heere beside the Port
   Hel.

A march afarre.

I marrie ist.

As ample as my selfe
   Hel.

What somere he is
He's bravely taken heere.

Monsievr Parrolles
   Hel.

In argvment of praise, or to the worth

Is a reserved honestie, and that
I have not heard examin'd
   Dian.
Alas poore Ladie,
'Tis a hard bondage to become the wife

   Wid.
I write good creatvre, wheresoere she is,
Her hart waighes sadly: this yong maid might do her
A shrewd tvrne if she pleas'd
   Hel.
How do yov meane?
May be the amorovs Covnt solicites her

   Wid.
He does indeede,
And brokes with all that can in svch a svite
Corrvpt the tender honovr of a Maide:
Bvt she is arm'd for him, and keepes her gvard
In honestest defence.
Drvmme and Colovrs.

   Di.

   Cap.E.

   Cap.E.

   Cap.G.

   Ber.

   Cap.G.

   C.E.
I with a troop of Florentines wil sodainly svrprize

   Cap.G.

Heere he comes.
Enter Parrolles.
Cap.E.
O for the love of lavghter hinder not the honor

   Ber.
How now Monsievr?
This drvmme sticks sorely
in yovr disposition
   Cap.G.

A drvm so
lost.
There was excellent command, to charge in with

sovldiers
   Cap.G.
That was not to be blam'd in the command
of the service: it was a disaster of warre that Cćsar him
selfe covld not have prevented, if he had beene there to
command
   Ber.
Well, wee cannot greatly condemne ovr svccesse:
some dishonor wee had in the losse of that drvm,
bvt it is not to be recovered
   Par.
It might have beene recovered
   Ber.
It might, bvt it is not now
   Par.
It is to be recovered, bvt that the merit of service
is sildome attribvted to the trve and exact performer,
I wovld have that drvmme or another, or hic iacet
   Ber.
Why if yov have a stomacke, too't Monsievr: if
yov thinke yovr mysterie in stratagem, can bring this
instrvment of honovr againe into his native qvarter, be
magnanimiovs in the enterprize and go on, I wil grace

it, the Dvke shall both speake of it, and extend to yov
what fvrther becomes his greatnesse, even to the vtmost
syllable of yovr worthinesse
   Par.
By the hand of a sovldier I will vndertake it
   Ber.
Bvt yov mvst not now slvmber in it
   Par.
Ile abovt it this evening, and I will presently
pen downe my dilemma's, encovrage my selfe in my
certaintie, pvt my selfe into my mortall preparation:
and by midnight looke to heare fvrther from me
   Ber.

   Par.
I know not what the svccesse wil be my Lord,
bvt the attempt I vow
   Ber.

   Par.
I love not many words.
Exit
  Cap.E.
No more then a fish loves water.
Is not this
a strange fellow my Lord, that so confidently seemes to
vndertake this bvsinesse, which he knowes is not to be
done, damnes himselfe to do, & dares better be damnd
then to doo't
   Cap.G.
Yov do not know him my Lord as we doe,
certaine it is that he will steale himselfe into a mans favovr,
and for a weeke escape a great deale of discoveries,
bvt when yov finde him ovt, yov have him ever after
   Ber.
Why do yov thinke he will make no deede at
all of this that so seriovslie hee dooes addresse himselfe
vnto?
Cap.E.
None in the world, bvt retvrne with an invention,
and clap vpon yov two or three probable lies:
bvt we have almost imbost him, yov shall see his fall to
night; for indeede he is not for yovr Lordshippes respect
   Cap.G.
Weele make yov some sport with the Foxe
ere we case him.
He was first smoak'd by the old Lord
Lafew, when his disgvise and he is parted, tell me what

night
   Cap.E.
I mvst go looke my twigges,
He shall be cavght
   Ber.
Yovr brother he shall go along with me
   Cap.G.

   Ber.

   Cap.E.
Bvt yov say she's honest
   Ber.

Tokens and Letters, which she did resend,
And this is all I have done: She's a faire creatvre,

Cap.E.
