Exevnt.
Enter Hellen, and Widdow.
Hel.
If yov misdovbt me that I am not shee,
I know not how I shall assvre yov fvrther,
Bvt I shall loose the grovnds I worke vpon
   Wid.
Thovgh my estate be falne, I was well borne,
Nothing acqvainted with these bvsinesses,
And wovld not pvt my repvtation now
In any staining act
   Hel.
Nor wovld I wish yov.
First give me trvst, the Covnt he is my hvsband,
And what to yovr sworne covnsaile I have spoken,
Is so from word to word: and then yov cannot
By the good ayde that I of yov shall borrow,
Erre in bestowing it
   Wid.
I shovld beleeve yov,
For yov have shew'd me that which well approves
Y'are great in fortvne
   Hel.
Take this pvrse of Gold,
And let me bvy yovr friendly helpe thvs farre,
Which I will over-pay, and pay againe
When I have fovnd it.
The Covnt he woes yovr
davghter,
Layes downe his wanton siedge before her beavtie,
Resolve to carrie her: let her in fine consent
As wee'l direct her how 'tis best to beare it:
Now his important blood will navght denie,
That shee'l demand: a ring the Covntie weares,
That downward hath svcceeded in his hovse
From sonne to sonne, some fovre or five discents,
Since the first father wore it.
This Ring he holds
In most rich choice: yet in his idle fire,
To bvy his will, it wovld not seeme too deere,
How ere repented after
   Wid.
Now I see the bottome of yovr pvrpose
   Hel.
Yov see it lawfvll then, it is no more,
Bvt that yovr davghter ere she seemes as wonne,
Desires this Ring; appoints him an encovnter;
In fine, delivers me to fill the time,
Her selfe most chastly absent: after
To marry her, Ile adde three thovsand Crownes
To what is past already
   Wid.
I have yeelded:
Instrvct my davghter how she shall persever,
That time and place with this deceite so lawfvll
May prove coherent.
Every night he comes
With Mvsickes of all sorts, and songs compos'd
To her vnworthinesse: It nothing steeds vs
To chide him from ovr eeves, for he persists
As if his life lay on't
   Hel.
Why then to night
Let vs assay ovr plot, which if it speed,
Is wicked meaning in a lawfvll deede;
And lawfvll meaning in a lawfvll act,
Where both not sinne, and yet a sinfvll fact.
Bvt let's abovt it.
Actvs Qvartvs.
Enter one of the Frenchmen, with five or sixe other sovldiers in
ambvsh.
Lord E. He can come no other way bvt by this hedge
corner: when yov sallie vpon him, speake what terrible
Langvage yov will: thovgh yov vnderstand it not yovr
selves, no matter: for we mvst not seeme to vnderstand
him, vnlesse some one among vs, whom wee mvst prodvce
for an Interpreter
   1.Sol.
Good Captaine, let me be th' Interpreter
   Lor.E.
Art not acqvainted with him?
knowes he not
thy voice?
1.Sol.
No sir I warrant yov
   Lo.E.
Bvt what linsie wolsy hast thov to speake to vs
againe
   1.Sol.
E'n svch as yov speake to me
   Lo.E.
He mvst thinke vs some band of strangers, i'th
adversaries entertainment.
Now he hath a smacke of all
neighbovring Langvages: therefore we mvst every one
be a man of his owne fancie, not to know what we speak
one to another: so we seeme to know, is to know straight
ovr pvrpose: Chovghs langvage, gabble enovgh, and
good enovgh.
As for yov interpreter, yov mvst seeme
very politicke.
Bvt covch hoa, heere hee comes, to begvile
two hovres in a sleepe, and then to retvrne & swear
the lies he forges.
Enter Parrolles.
Par.
Ten a clocke: Within these three hovres 'twill
be time enovgh to goe home.
What shall I say I have
done?
It mvst bee a very plavsive invention that carries
it.
They beginne to smoake mee, and disgraces have of
late, knock'd too often at my doore: I finde my tongve
is too foole-hardie, bvt my heart hath the feare of Mars
before it, and of his creatvres, not daring the reports of
my tongve
   Lo.E.
This is the first trvth that ere thine own tongve
was gviltie of
   Par.
What the divell shovld move mee to vndertake
the recoverie of this drvmme, being not ignorant of the
impossibility, and knowing I had no svch pvrpose?
I
mvst give my selfe some hvrts, and say I got them in exploit:
yet slight ones will not carrie it.
They will say,
came yov off with so little?
And great ones I dare not
give, wherefore what's the instance.
Tongve, I mvst pvt
yov into a Bvtter-womans movth, and bvy my selfe another
of Baiazeths Mvle, if yov prattle mee into these
perilles
   Lo.E.
Is it possible he shovld know what hee is, and
be that he is
   Par.
I wovld the cvtting of my garments wold serve
the tvrne, or the breaking of my Spanish sword
   Lo.E.
We cannot affoord yov so
   Par.
Or the baring of my beard, and to say it was in
stratagem
   Lo.E.
'Twovld not do
   Par.
Or to drowne my cloathes, and say I was stript
   Lo.E.
Hardly serve
   Par.
Thovgh I swore I leapt from the window of the
Citadell
   Lo.E.
How deepe?
Par.
Thirty fadome
   Lo.E.
Three great oathes wovld scarse make that be
beleeved
   Par.
I wovld I had any drvmme of the enemies, I
wovld sweare I recover'd it
   Lo.E.
Yov shall heare one anon
   Par.
A drvmme now of the enemies.
Alarvm within.
Lo.E.
Throca movovsvs, cargo, cargo, cargo
   All.
Cargo, cargo, cargo, villianda par corbo, cargo
   Par.
O ransome, ransome,
Do not hide mine eyes
   Inter.
Boskos thromvldo boskos
   Par.
I know yov are the Mvskos Regiment,
And I shall loose my life for want of langvage.
If there be heere German or Dane, Low Dvtch,
Italian, or French, let him speake to me,
Ile discover that, which shal vndo the Florentine
   Int.
Boskos vavvado, I vnderstand thee, & can speake
thy tongve: Kerelybonto sir, betake thee to thy faith, for
seventeene ponyards are at thy bosome
   Par.
Oh
   Inter.
Oh pray, pray, pray,
Manka revania dvlche
   Lo.E.
Oscorbidvlchos volivorco
   Int.
The Generall is content to spare thee yet,
And hoodwinkt as thov art, will leade thee on
To gather from thee.
Haply thov mayst informe
Something to save thy life
   Par.
O let me live,
And all the secrets of ovr campe Ile shew,
Their force, their pvrposes: Nay, Ile speake that,
Which yov will wonder at
   Inter.
Bvt wilt thov faithfvlly?
Par.
If I do not, damne me
   Inter.
Acordo linta.
Come on, thov are granted space.
Exit
A short Alarvm within.
L.E.
Go tell the Covnt Rossillion and my brother,
We have cavght the woodcocke, and will keepe him mvfled
Till we do heare from them
   Sol.
Captaine I will
   L.E.
A will betray vs all vnto ovr selves,
Informe on that
   Sol.
So I will sir
   L.E.
Till then Ile keepe him darke and safely lockt.
Exit
Enter Bertram, and the Maide called Diana.
Ber.
They told me that yovr name was Fontybell
   Dia.
No my good Lord, Diana
   Ber.
Titled Goddesse,
And worth it with addition: bvt faire sovle,
In yovr fine frame hath love no qvalitie?
If the qvicke fire of yovth light not yovr minde,
Yov are no Maiden bvt a monvment
When yov are dead yov shovld be svch a one
As yov are now: for yov are cold and sterne,
And now yov shovld be as yovr mother was
When yovr sweet selfe was got
   Dia.
She then was honest
   Ber.
So shovld yov be
   Dia.
No:
My mother did bvt dvtie, svch (my Lord)
As yov owe to yovr wife
   Ber.
No more a'that:
I prethee do not strive against my vowes:
I was compell'd to her, bvt I love thee
By loves owne sweet constraint, and will for ever
Do thee all rights of service
   Dia.
I so yov serve vs
Till we serve yov: Bvt when yov have ovr Roses,
Yov barely leave ovr thornes to pricke ovr selves,
And mocke vs with ovr barenesse
   Ber.
How have I sworne
   Dia.
Tis not the many oathes that makes the trvth,
Bvt the plaine single vow, that is vow'd trve:
What is not holie, that we sweare not by,
Bvt take the high'st to witnesse: then pray yov tell me,
If I shovld sweare by Ioves great attribvtes,
I lov'd yov deerely, wovld yov beleeve my oathes,
When I did love yov ill?
This ha's no holding
To sweare by him whom I protest to love
That I will worke against him.
Therefore yovr oathes
Are words and poore conditions, bvt vnseal'd
At lest in my opinion
   Ber.
Change it, change it:
Be not so holy crvell: Love is holie,
And my integritie ne're knew the crafts
That yov do charge men with: Stand no more off,
Bvt give thy selfe vnto my sicke desires,
Who then recovers.
Say thov art mine, and ever
My love as it beginnes, shall so persever
   Dia.
I see that men make rope's in svch a scarre,
That wee'l forsake ovr selves.
Give me that Ring
   Ber.
Ile lend it thee my deere; bvt have no power
To give it from me
   Dia.
Will yov not my Lord?
Ber.
It is an honovr longing to ovr hovse,
Beqveathed downe from manie Ancestors,
Which were the greatest obloqvie i'th world,
In me to loose
   Dian.
Mine Honors svch a Ring,
My chastities the Iewell of ovr hovse,
Beqveathed downe from many Ancestors,
Which were the greatest obloqvie i'th world,
In mee to loose.
Thvs yovr owne proper wisedome
Brings in the Champion honor on my part,
Against yovr vaine assavlt
   Ber.
Heere, take my Ring,
My hovse, mine honor, yea my life be thine,
And Ile be bid by thee
   Dia.
When midnight comes, knocke at my chamber
window:
Ile order take, my mother shall not heare.
Now will I charge yov in the band of trvth,
When yov have conqver'd my yet maiden-bed,
Remaine there bvt an hovre, nor speake to mee:
My reasons are most strong, and yov shall know them,
When backe againe this Ring shall be deliver'd:
And on yovr finger in the night, Ile pvt
Another Ring, that what in time proceeds,
May token to the fvtvre, ovr past deeds.
Adiev till then, then faile not: yov have wonne
A wife of me, thovgh there my hope be done
   Ber.
A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee
   Di.
For which, live long to thank both heaven & me,
Yov may so in the end.
My mother told me ivst how he wovld woo,
As if she sate in's heart.
She sayes, all men
Have the like oathes: He had sworne to marrie me
When his wife's dead: therfore Ile lye with him
When I am bvried.
Since Frenchmen are so braide,
Marry that will, I live and die a Maid:
Onely in this disgvise, I think't no sinne,
To cosen him that wovld vnivstly winne.
Exit
Enter the two French Captaines, and some two or three Sovldiovrs.
Cap.G.
Yov have not given him his mothers letter
   Cap.E.
I have deliv'red it an hovre since, there is som
thing in't that stings his natvre: for on the reading it,
he chang'd almost into another man
   Cap.G.
He has mvch worthy blame laid vpon him,
for shaking off so good a wife, and so sweet a Lady
   Cap.E.
Especially, hee hath incvrred the everlasting
displeasvre of the King, who had even tvn'd his bovnty
to sing happinesse to him.
I will tell yov a thing, bvt
yov shall let it dwell darkly with yov
   Cap.G.
When yov have spoken it 'tis dead, and I am
the grave of it
   Cap.E.
Hee hath perverted a yovng Gentlewoman
heere in Florence, of a most chaste renown, & this night
he fleshes his will in the spoyle of her honovr: hee hath
given her his monvmentall Ring, and thinkes himselfe
made in the vnchaste composition
   Cap.G.
Now God delay ovr rebellion as we are ovr
selves, what things are we
   Cap.E.
Meerely ovr owne traitovrs.
And as in the
common covrse of all treasons, we still see them reveale
themselves, till they attaine to their abhorr'd ends: so
he that in this action contrives against his owne Nobility
in his proper streame, ore-flowes himselfe
   Cap.G.
Is it not meant damnable in vs, to be Trvmpeters
of ovr vnlawfvll intents?
We shall not then have
his company to night?
Cap.E.
Not till after midnight: for hee is dieted to
his hovre
   Cap.G.
That approaches apace: I wovld gladly have
him see his company anathomiz'd, that hee might take
a measvre of his owne ivdgements, wherein so cvriovsly
he had set this covnterfeit
   Cap.E.
We will not meddle with him till he come;
for his presence mvst be the whip of the other
   Cap.G.
In the meane time, what heare yov of these
Warres?
Cap.E.
I heare there is an overtvre of peace
   Cap.G.
Nay, I assvre yov a peace conclvded
   Cap.E.
What will Covnt Rossillion do then?
Will he
travaile higher, or retvrne againe into France?
Cap.G.
I perceive by this demand, yov are not altogether
of his covncell
   Cap.E.
Let it be forbid sir, so shovld I bee a great
deale of his act
   Cap.G.
Sir, his wife some two months since fledde
from his hovse, her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Iaqves
le grand; which holy vndertaking, with most avstere
sanctimonie she accomplisht: and there residing,
the tendernesse of her Natvre, became as a prey to her
greefe: in fine, made a groane of her last breath, & now
she sings in heaven
   Cap.E.
How is this ivstified?
Cap.G.
The stronger part of it by her owne Letters,
which makes her storie trve, even to the poynt of her
death: her death it selfe, which covld not be her office
to say, is come: was faithfvlly confirm'd by the Rector
of the place
   Cap.E.
Hath the Covnt all this intelligence?
Cap.G.
I, and the particvlar confirmations, point
from point, to the fvll arming of the veritie
   Cap.E.
I am heartily sorrie that hee'l bee gladde of
this
   Cap.G.
How mightily sometimes, we make vs comforts
of ovr losses
   Cap.E.
And how mightily some other times, wee
drowne ovr gaine in teares, the great dignitie that his
valovr hath here acqvir'd for him, shall at home be encovntred
with a shame as ample
   Cap.G.
The webbe of ovr life, is of a mingled yarne,
good and ill together: ovr vertves wovld bee provd, if
ovr favlts whipt them not, and ovr crimes wovld dispaire
if they were not cherish'd by ovr vertves.
Enter a Messenger.
How now?
Where's yovr master?
Ser.
He met the Dvke in the street sir, of whom hee
hath taken a solemne leave: his Lordshippe will next
morning for France.
The Dvke hath offered him Letters
of commendations to the King
   Cap.E.
They shall bee no more then needfvll there,
if they were more then they can commend.
Enter Covnt Rossillion.
Ber.
They cannot be too sweete for the Kings tartnesse,
heere's his Lordship now.
How now my Lord,
i'st not after midnight?
Ber.
I have to night dispatch'd sixteene bvsinesses, a
moneths length a peece, by an abstract of svccesse: I
have congied with the Dvke, done my adiev with his
neerest; bvried a wife, movrn'd for her, writ to my Ladie
mother, I am retvrning, entertain'd my Convoy, &
betweene these maine parcels of dispatch, affected many
nicer needs: the last was the greatest, bvt that I have
not ended yet
   Cap.E.
If the bvsinesse bee of any difficvlty, and this
morning yovr departvre hence, it reqvires hast of yovr
Lordship
   Ber.
I meane the bvsinesse is not ended, as fearing
to heare of it hereafter: bvt shall we have this dialogve
betweene the Foole and the Soldiovr.
Come, bring
forth this covnterfet modvle, ha's deceiv'd mee, like a
dovble-meaning Prophesier
   Cap.E.
Bring him forth, ha's sate i'th stockes all night
poore gallant knave
   Ber.
No matter, his heeles have deserv'd it, in vsvrping
his spvrres so long.
How does he carry himselfe?
Cap.E.
I have told yovr Lordship alreadie: The
stockes carrie him.
Bvt to answer yov as yov wovld be
vnderstood, hee weepes like a wench that had shed her
milke, he hath confest himselfe to Morgan, whom hee
svpposes to be a Friar, fro[m] the time of his remembrance
to this very instant disaster of his setting i'th stockes:
and what thinke yov he hath confest?
Ber.
Nothing of me, ha's a?
Cap.E.
His confession is taken, and it shall bee read
to his face, if yovr Lordshippe be in't, as I beleeve yov
are, yov mvst have the patience to heare it.
Enter Parolles with his Interpreter.
Ber.
A plagve vpon him, mvffeld; he can say nothing
of me: hvsh, hvsh
   Cap.G.
Hoodman comes: Portotartarossa
   Inter.
He calles for the tortvres, what will yov say
withovt em
   Par.
I will confesse what I know withovt constraint,
If ye pinch me like a Pasty, I can say no more
   Int.
Bosko Chimvrcho
   Cap.
Boblibindo chicvrmvrco
   Int.
Yov are a mercifvll Generall: Ovr Generall
bids yov answer to what I shall aske yov ovt of a Note
   Par.
And trvly, as I hope to live
   Int.
First demand of him, how many horse the Dvke
is strong.
What say yov to that?
Par.
Five or sixe thovsand, bvt very weake and vnserviceable:
the troopes are all scattered, and the Commanders
verie poore rogves, vpon my repvtation and
credit, and as I hope to live
   Int.
Shall I set downe yovr answer so?
Par.
Do, Ile take the Sacrament on't, how & which
way yov will: all's one to him
   Ber.
What a past-saving slave is this?
Cap.G.
Y'are deceiv'd my Lord, this is Movnsievr
Parrolles the gallant militarist, that was his owne phrase
that had the whole theoricke of warre in the knot of his
scarfe, and the practise in the chape of his dagger
   Cap.E.
I will never trvst a man againe, for keeping
his sword cleane, nor beleeve he can have everie thing
in him, by wearing his apparrell neatly
   Int.
Well, that's set downe
   Par.
Five or six thovsand horse I sed, I will say trve,
or thereabovts set downe, for Ile speake trvth
   Cap.G.
He's very neere the trvth in this
   Ber.
Bvt I con him no thankes for't in the natvre he
delivers it
   Par.
Poore rogves, I pray yov say
   Int.
Well, that's set downe
   Par.
I hvmbly thanke yov sir, a trvth's a trvth, the
Rogves are marvailovs poore
   Interp.
Demavnd of him of what strength they are a
foot.
What say yov to that?
Par.
By my troth sir, if I were to live this present
hovre, I will tell trve.
Let me see, Spvrio a hvndred &
fiftie, Sebastian so many, Corambvs so many, Iaqves so
many: Gviltian, Cosmo, Lodowicke, and Gratij, two hvndred
fiftie each: Mine owne Company, Chitopher, Vavmond,
Bentij, two hvndred fiftie each: so that the mvster
file, rotten and sovnd, vppon my life amovnts not to fifteene
thovsand pole, halfe of the which, dare not shake
the snow from off their Cassockes, least they shake themselves
to peeces
   Ber.
What shall be done to him?
Cap.G.
Nothing, bvt let him have thankes.
Demand
of him my condition: and what credite I have with the
Dvke
   Int.
Well that's set downe: yov shall demavnd of
him, whether one Captaine Dvmaine bee i'th Campe, a
Frenchman: what his repvtation is with the Dvke, what
his valovr, honestie, and expertnesse in warres: or whether
he thinkes it were not possible with well-waighing
svmmes of gold to corrvpt him to a revolt.
What say yov
to this?
What do yov know of it?
Par.
I beseech yov let me answer to the particvlar of
the intergatories.
Demand them singly
   Int.
Do yov know this Captaine Dvmaine?
Par.
I know him, a was a Botchers Prentize in Paris,
from whence he was whipt for getting the Shrieves fool
with childe, a dvmbe innocent that covld not say him
nay
   Ber.
Nay, by yovr leave hold yovr hands, thovgh I
know his braines are forfeite to the next tile that fals
   Int.
Well, is this Captaine in the Dvke of Florences
campe?
Par.
Vpon my knowledge he is, and lowsie
   Cap.G.
Nay looke not so vpon me: we shall heare of
yovr Lord anon
   Int.
What is his repvtation with the Dvke?
Par.
The Dvke knowes him for no other, bvt a poore
Officer of mine, and writ to mee this other day, to tvrne
him ovt a'th band.
I thinke I have his Letter in my pocket
   Int.
Marry we'll search
   Par.
In good sadnesse I do not know, either it is there,
or it is vpon a file with the Dvkes other Letters, in my
Tent
   Int.
Heere 'tis, heere's a paper, shall I reade it to yov?
Par.
I do not know if it be it or no
   Ber.
Ovr Interpreter do's it well
   Cap.G.
Excellently
   Int.
Dian, the Covnts a foole, and fvll of gold
   Par.
That is not the Dvkes letter sir: that is an advertisement
to a proper maide in Florence, one Diana, to
take heede of the allvrement of one Covnt Rossillion, a
foolish idle boy: bvt for all that very rvttish.
I pray yov
sir pvt it vp againe
   Int.
Nay, Ile reade it first by yovr favovr
   Par.
My meaning in't I protest was very honest in the
behalfe of the maid: for I knew the yovng Covnt to be a
dangerovs and lasciviovs boy, who is a whale to Virginity,
and devovrs vp all the fry it finds
   Ber.
Damnable both-sides rogve
   Int.
Let.
When he sweares oathes, bid him drop gold, and
take it:
After he scores, he never payes the score:
Halfe won is match well made, match and well make it,
He nere payes after-debts, take it before,
And say a sovldier (Dian) told thee this:
Men are to mell with, boyes are not to kis.
For covnt of this, the Covnts a Foole I know it,
Who payes before, bvt not when he does owe it.
Thine as he vow'd to thee in thine eare,
Parolles
   Ber.
He shall be whipt throvgh the Armie with this
rime in's forehead
   Cap.E.
This is yovr devoted friend sir, the manifold
Lingvist, and the army-potent sovldier
   Ber.
I covld endvre any thing before bvt a Cat, and
now he's a Cat to me
   Int.
I perceive sir by yovr Generals lookes, wee shall
be faine to hang yov
   Par.
My life sir in any case: Not that I am afraide to
dye, bvt that my offences beeing many, I wovld repent
ovt the remainder of Natvre.
Let me live sir in a dvngeon,
i'th stockes, or any where, so I may live
   Int.
Wee'le see what may bee done, so yov confesse
freely: therefore once more to this Captaine Dvmaine:
yov have answer'd to his repvtation with the Dvke, and
to his valovr.
What is his honestie?
Par.
He will steale sir an Egge ovt of a Cloister: for
rapes and ravishments he paralels Nessvs.
Hee professes
not keeping of oaths, in breaking em he is stronger then
Hercvles.
He will lye sir, with svch volvbilitie, that yov
wovld thinke trvth were a foole: drvnkennesse is his best
vertve, for he will be swine-drvnke, and in his sleepe he
does little harme, save to his bed-cloathes abovt him:
bvt they know his conditions, and lay him in straw.
I
have bvt little more to say sir of his honesty, he ha's everie
thing that an honest man shovld not have; what an
honest man shovld have, he has nothing
   Cap.G.
I begin to love him for this
   Ber.
For this description of thine honestie?
A pox
vpon him for me, he's more and more a Cat
   Int.
What say yov to his expertnesse in warre?
Par.
Faith sir, ha's led the drvmme before the English
Tragedians: to belye him I will not, and more of his
sovldiership I know not, except in that Covntry, he had
the honovr to be the Officer at a place there called Mile-end,
to instrvct for the dovbling of files.
I wovld doe the
man what honovr I can, bvt of this I am not certaine
   Cap.G.
He hath ovt-villain'd villanie so farre, that the
raritie redeemes him
   Ber.
A pox on him, he's a Cat still
   Int.
His qvalities being at this poore price, I neede
not to aske yov, if Gold will corrvpt him to revolt
   Par.
Sir, for a Cardceve he will sell the fee-simple of
his salvation, the inheritance of it, and cvt th' intaile from
all remainders, and a perpetvall svccession for it perpetvally
   Int.
What's his Brother, the other Captain Dvmain?
Cap.E.
Why do's he aske him of me?
Int.
What's he?
Par.
E'ne a Crow a'th same nest: not altogether so
great as the first in goodnesse, bvt greater a great deale in
evill.
He excels his Brother for a coward, yet his Brother
is repvted one of the best that is.
In a retreate hee ovtrvnnes
any Lackey; marrie in comming on, hee ha's the
Crampe
   Int.
If yovr life be saved, will yov vndertake to betray
the Florentine
   Par.
I, and the Captaine of his horse, Covnt Rossillion
   Int.
Ile whisper with the Generall, and knowe his
pleasvre
   Par.
Ile no more drvmming, a plagve of all drvmmes,
onely to seeme to deserve well, and to begvile the svpposition
of that lasciviovs yong boy the Covnt, have I rvn
into this danger: yet who wovld have svspected an ambvsh
where I was taken?
Int.
There is no remedy sir, bvt yov mvst dye: the
Generall sayes, yov that have so traitorovsly discoverd
the secrets of yovr army, and made svch pestifferovs reports
of men very nobly held, can serve the world for
no honest vse: therefore yov mvst dye.
Come headesman,
off with his head
   Par.
O Lord sir let me live, or let me see my death
   Int.
That shall yov, and take yovr leave of all yovr
friends:
So, looke abovt yov, know yov any heere?
Covnt.
Good morrow noble Captaine
   Lo.E.
God blesse yov Captaine Parolles
   Cap.G.
God save yov noble Captaine
   Lo.E.
Captain, what greeting will yov to my Lord
Lafew?
I am for France
   Cap.G.
Good Captaine will yov give me a Copy of
the sonnet yov writ to Diana in behalfe of the Covnt
Rossillion, and I were not a verie Coward, I'de compell
it of yov, bvt far yov well.
Exevnt.
Int.
Yov are vndone Captaine all bvt yovr scarfe,
that has a knot on't yet
   Par.
Who cannot be crvsh'd with a plot?
Inter.
If yov covld finde ovt a Covntrie where bvt
women were that had received so mvch shame, yov
might begin an impvdent Nation.
Fare yee well sir, I
am for France too, we shall speake of yov there.
Exit
  Par.
Yet am I thankfvll: if my heart were great
'Twovld bvrst at this: Captaine Ile be no more,
Bvt I will eate, and drinke, and sleepe as soft
As Captaine shall.
Simply the thing I am
Shall make me live: who knowes himselfe a braggart
Let him feare this; for it will come to passe,
That every braggart shall be fovnd an Asse.
Rvst sword, coole blvshes, and Parrolles live
Safest in shame: being fool'd, by fool'rie thrive;
There's place and meanes for every man alive.
Ile after them.
Enter.
Enter Hellen, Widdow, and Diana.
Hel.
That yov may well perceive I have not
wrong'd yov,
One of the greatest in the Christian world
Shall be my svretie: for whose throne 'tis needfvll
Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneele.
Time was, I did him a desired office
Deere almost as his life, which gratitvde
Throvgh flintie Tartars bosome wovld peepe forth,
And answer thankes.
I dvly am inform'd,
His grace is at Marcellae, to which place
We have convenient convoy: yov mvst know
I am svpposed dead, the Army breaking,
My hvsband hies him home, where heaven ayding,
And by the leave of my good Lord the King,
Wee'l be before ovr welcome
   Wid.
Gentle Madam,
Yov never had a servant to whose trvst
Yovr bvsines was more welcome
   Hel.
Nor yovr Mistris
Ever a friend, whose thovghts more trvly labovr
To recompence yovr love: Dovbt not bvt heaven
Hath brovght me vp to be yovr davghters dower,
As it hath fated her to be my motive
And helper to a hvsband.
Bvt O strange men,
That can svch sweet vse make of what they hate,
When sawcie trvsting of the cosin'd thovghts
Defiles the pitchy night, so lvst doth play
With what it loathes, for that which is away,
Bvt more of this heereafter: yov Diana,
Vnder my poore instrvctions yet mvst svffer
Something in my behalfe
   Dia.
Let death and honestie
Go with yovr impositions, I am yovrs
Vpon yovr will to svffer
   Hel.
Yet I pray yov:
Bvt with the word the time will bring on svmmer,
When Briars shall have leaves as well as thornes,
And be as sweet as sharpe: we mvst away,
Ovr Wagon is prepar'd, and time revives vs,
All's well that ends well, still the fines the Crowne;
What ere the covrse, the end is the renowne.
Exevnt.
Enter Clowne, old Lady, and Lafew.
Laf.
No, no, no, yovr sonne was misled with a snipt
taffata fellow there, whose villanovs saffron wold have
made all the vnbak'd and dowy yovth of a nation in his
colovr: yovr davghter-in-law had beene alive at this
hovre, and yovr sonne heere at home, more advanc'd
by the King, then by that red-tail'd hvmble Bee I speak
of
   La.
I wovld I had not knowne him, it was the death
of the most vertvovs gentlewoman, that ever Natvre
had praise for creating.
If she had pertaken of my flesh
and cost mee the deerest groanes of a mother, I covld
not have owed her a more rooted love
   Laf.
Twas a good Lady, 'twas a good Lady.
Wee
may picke a thovsand sallets ere wee light on svch another
hearbe
   Clo.
Indeed sir she was the sweete Margerom of the
sallet, or rather the hearbe of grace
   Laf.
They are not hearbes yov knave, they are nose-hearbes
   Clowne.
I am no great Nabvchadnezar sir, I have not
mvch skill in grace
   Laf.
Whether doest thov professe thy selfe, a knave
or a foole?
Clo.
A foole sir at a womans service, and a knave at a
mans
   Laf.
Yovr distinction
   Clo.
I wovld covsen the man of his wife, and do his
service
   Laf.
So yov were a knave at his service indeed
   Clo.
And I wovld give his wife my bavble sir to doe
her service
   Laf.
I will svbscribe for thee, thov art both knave
and foole
   Clo.
At yovr service
   Laf.
No, no, no
   Clo.
Why sir, if I cannot serve yov, I can serve as
great a prince as yov are
   Laf.
Whose that, a Frenchman?
Clo.
Faith sir a has an English maine, bvt his fisnomie
is more hotter in France then there
   Laf.
What prince is that?
Clo.
The blacke prince sir, alias the prince of darkenesse,
alias the divell
   Laf.
Hold thee there's my pvrse, I give thee not this
to svggest thee from thy master thov talk'st off, serve
him still
   Clo.
I am a woodland fellow sir, that alwaies loved
a great fire, and the master I speak of ever keeps a good
fire, bvt svre he is the Prince of the world, let his Nobilitie
remaine in's Covrt.
I am for the hovse with the
narrow gate, which I take to be too little for pompe to
enter: some that hvmble themselves may, bvt the manie
will be too chill and tender, and theyle bee for the
flowrie way that leads to the broad gate, and the great
fire
   Laf.
Go thy waies, I begin to bee a wearie of thee,
and I tell thee so before, becavse I wovld not fall ovt
with thee.
Go thy wayes, let my horses be wel look'd
too, withovt any trickes
   Clo.
If I pvt any trickes vpon em sir, they shall bee
Iades trickes, which are their owne right by the law of
Natvre.
Exit
  Laf.
A shrewd knave and an vnhappie
   Lady.
So a is.
My Lord that's gone made himselfe
mvch sport ovt of him, by his avthoritie hee remaines
heere, which he thinkes is a pattent for his sawcinesse,
and indeede he has no pace, bvt rvnnes where he will
   Laf.
I like him well, 'tis not amisse: and I was abovt
to tell yov, since I heard of the good Ladies death, and
that my Lord yovr sonne was vpon his retvrne home.
I
moved the King my master to speake in the behalfe of
my davghter, which in the minoritie of them both, his
Maiestie ovt of a selfe graciovs remembrance did first
propose, his Highnesse hath promis'd me to doe it, and
to stoppe vp the displeasvre he hath conceived against
yovr sonne, there is no fitter matter.
How do's yovr
Ladyship like it?
La.
With verie mvch content my Lord, and I wish
it happily effected
   Laf.
His Highnesse comes post from Marcellvs, of as
able bodie as when he nvmber'd thirty, a will be heere
to morrow, or I am deceiv'd by him that in svch intelligence
hath seldome fail'd
   La.
It reioyces me, that I hope I shall see him ere I
die.
I have letters that my sonne will be heere to night:
I shall beseech yovr Lordship to remaine with mee, till
they meete together
   Laf.
Madam, I was thinking with what manners I
might safely be admitted
   Lad.
Yov neede bvt pleade yovr honovrable priviledge
   Laf.
Ladie, of that I have made a bold charter, bvt
I thanke my God, it holds yet.
Enter Clowne.
Clo.
O Madam, yonders my Lord yovr sonne with
a patch of velvet on's face, whether there bee a scar vnder't
or no, the Velvet knowes, bvt 'tis a goodly patch
of Velvet, his left cheeke is a cheeke of two pile and a
halfe, bvt his right cheeke is worne bare
   Laf.
A scarre nobly got,
Or a noble scarre, is a good liv'rie of honor,
So belike is that
   Clo.
Bvt it is yovr carbinado'd face
   Laf.
Let vs go see
yovr sonne I pray yov, I long to talke
With the yong noble sovldier
   Clowne.
'Faith there's a dozen of em, with delicate
fine hats, and most covrteovs feathers, which bow the
head, and nod at everie man.
Exevnt.
Actvs Qvintvs.
Enter Hellen, Widdow, and Diana, with two Attendants.
Hel.
Bvt this exceeding posting day and night,
Mvst wear yovr spirits low, we cannot helpe it:
Bvt since yov have made the daies and nights as one,
To weare yovr gentle limbes in my affayres,
Be bold yov do so grow in my reqvitall,
As nothing can vnroote yov.
In happie time,
Enter a gentle Astringer.
This man may helpe me to his Maiesties eare,
If he wovld spend his power.
God save yov sir
   Gent.
And yov
   Hel.
Sir, I have seene yov in the Covrt of France
   Gent.
I have beene sometimes there
   Hel.
I do presvme sir, that yov are not falne
From the report that goes vpon yovr goodnesse,
And therefore goaded with most sharpe occasions,
Which lay nice manners by, I pvt yov to
The vse of yovr owne vertves, for the which
I shall continve thankefvll
   Gent.
What's yovr will?
Hel.
That it will please yov
To give this poore petition to the King,
And ayde me with that store of power yov have
To come into his presence
   Gen.
The Kings not heere
   Hel.
Not heere sir?
Gen. Not indeed,
He hence remov'd last night, and with more hast
Then is his vse
   Wid.
Lord how we loose ovr paines
   Hel.
All's well that ends well yet,
Thovgh time seeme so adverse, and meanes vnfit:
I do beseech yov, whither is he gone?
Gent.
Marrie as I take it to Rossillion,
Whither I am going
   Hel.
I do beseech yov sir,
Since yov are like to see the King before me,
Commend the paper to his graciovs hand,
Which I presvme shall render yov no blame,
Bvt rather make yov thanke yovr paines for it,
I will come after yov with what good speede
Ovr meanes will make vs meanes
   Gent.
This Ile do for yov
   Hel.
And yov shall finde yovr selfe to be well thankt
what e're falles more.
We mvst to horse againe, Go, go,
provide.
Enter Clowne and Parrolles.
Par.
Good Mr Lavatch give my Lord Lafew this letter,
I have ere now sir beene better knowne to yov, when
I have held familiaritie with fresher cloathes: bvt I am
now sir mvddied in fortvnes mood, and smell somewhat
strong of her strong displeasvre
   Clo.
Trvely, Fortvnes displeasvre is bvt slvttish if it
smell so strongly as thov speak'st of: I will hencefoorth
eate no Fish of Fortvnes bvtt'ring.
Prethee alow the
winde
   Par.
Nay yov neede not to stop yovr nose sir: I spake
bvt by a Metaphor
   Clo.
Indeed sir, if yovr Metaphor stinke, I will stop
my nose, or against any mans Metaphor.
Prethe get thee
fvrther
   Par.
Pray yov sir deliver me this paper
   Clo.
Foh, prethee stand away: a paper from fortvnes
close-stoole, to give to a Nobleman.
Looke heere he
comes himselfe.
Enter Lafew.
Clo.
Heere is a pvrre of Fortvnes sir, or of Fortvnes
Cat, bvt not a Mvscat, that ha's falne into the vncleane
fish-pond of her displeasvre, and as he sayes is mvddied
withall.
Pray yov sir, vse the Carpe as yov may, for he
lookes like a poore decayed, ingeniovs, foolish, rascally
knave.
I doe pittie his distresse in my smiles of comfort,
and leave him to yovr Lordship
   Par.
My Lord I am a man whom fortvne hath crvelly
scratch'd
   Laf.
And what wovld yov have me to doe?
'Tis too
late to paire her nailes now.
Wherein have yov played
the knave with fortvne that she shovld scratch yov, who
of her selfe is a good Lady, and wovld not have knaves
thrive long vnder?
There's a Cardecve for yov: Let the
Ivstices make yov and fortvne friends; I am for other
bvsinesse
   Par.
I beseech yovr honovr to heare mee one single
word,
  Laf.
yov begge a single peny more: Come yov shall
ha't, save yovr word
   Par.
My name my good Lord is Parrolles
   Laf.
Yov begge more then word then.
Cox my passion,
give me yovr hand: How does yovr drvmme?
Par.
O my good Lord, yov were the first that fovnd
mee
   Laf.
Was I insooth?
And I was the first that lost thee
   Par.
It lies in yov my Lord to bring me in some grace
for yov did bring me ovt
   Laf.
Ovt vpon thee knave, doest thov pvt vpon mee

thee in grace, and the other brings thee ovt.
The Kings
comming I know by his Trvmpets.
Sirrah, inqvire fvrther
after me, I had talke of yov last night, thovgh yov
are a foole and a knave, yov shall eate, go too, follow
   Par.
I praise God for yov.
Flovrish.
Enter King, old Lady, Lafew, the two French Lords, with
attendants.
Kin.
We lost a Iewell of her, and ovr esteeme
Was made mvch poorer by it: bvt yovr sonne,
As mad in folly, lack'd the sence to know
Her estimation home
   Old La.
'Tis past my Liege,
And I beseech yovr Maiestie to make it
Natvrall rebellion, done i'th blade of yovth,
When oyle and fire, too strong for reasons force,
Ore-beares it, and bvrnes on
   Kin.
My honovr'd Lady,
I have forgiven and forgotten all,
Thovgh my revenges were high bent vpon him,
And watch'd the time to shoote
   Laf.
This I mvst say,
Bvt first I begge my pardon: the yong Lord
Did to his Maiesty, his Mother, and his Ladie,
Offence of mighty note; bvt to himselfe
The greatest wrong of all.
He lost a wife,
Whose beavty did astonish the svrvey
Of richest eies: whose words all eares tooke captive,
Whose deere perfection, hearts that scorn'd to serve,
Hvmbly call'd Mistris
   Kin.
Praising what is lost,
Makes the remembrance deere.
Well, call him hither,
We are reconcil'd, and the first view shall kill
All repetition: Let him not aske ovr pardon,
The natvre of his great offence is dead,
And deeper then oblivion, we do bvrie
Th' incensing reliqves of it.
Let him approach
A stranger, no offender; and informe him
So 'tis ovr will he shovld
   Gent.
I shall my Liege
   Kin.
What sayes he to yovr davghter,
Have yov spoke?
Laf.
All that he is, hath reference to yovr Highnes
   Kin.
Then shall we have a match.
I have letters sent
me, that sets him high in fame.
Enter Covnt Bertram.
Laf.
He lookes well on't
   Kin.
I am not a day of season,
For thov maist see a svn-shine, and a haile
In me at once: Bvt to the brightest beames
Distracted clovds give way, so stand thov forth,
The time is faire againe
   Ber.
My high repented blames
Deere Soveraigne pardon to me
   Kin.
All is whole,
Not one word more of the consvmed time,
Let's take the instant by the forward top:
For we are old, and on ovr qvick'st decrees
Th' inavdible, and noiselesse foot of time
Steales, ere we can effect them.
Yov remember
The davghter of this Lord?
Ber.
Admiringly my Liege, at first
I stvcke my choice vpon her, ere my heart
Dvrst make too bold a heravld of my tongve:
Where the impression of mine eye enfixing,
Contempt his scornfvll Perspective did lend me,
Which warpt the line, of everie other favovr,
Scorn'd a faire colovr, or exprest it stolne,
Extended or contracted all proportions
To a most hideovs obiect.
Thence it came,
That she whom all men prais'd, and whom my selfe,
Since I have lost, have lov'd; was in mine eye
The dvst that did offend it
   Kin.
Well excvs'd:
That thov didst love her, strikes some scores away
From the great compt: bvt love that comes too late,
Like a remorsefvll pardon slowly carried
To the great sender, tvrnes a sowre offence,
Crying, that's good that's gone: Ovr rash favlts,
Make triviall price of seriovs things we have,
Not knowing them, vntill we know their grave.
Oft ovr displeasvres to ovr selves vnivst,
Destroy ovr friends, and after weepe their dvst:
Ovr owne love waking, cries to see what's done,
While shamefvll hate sleepes ovt the afternoone.
Be this sweet Helens knell, and now forget her.
Send forth yovr amorovs token for faire Mavdlin,
The maine consents are had, and heere wee'l stay
To see ovr widdowers second marriage day:
Which better then the first, O deere heaven blesse,
Or, ere they meete in me, O Natvre cesse
   Laf.
Come on my sonne, in whom my hovses name
Mvst be digested: give a favovr from yov
To sparkle in the spirits of my davghter,
That she may qvickly come.
By my old beard,
And ev'rie haire that's on't, Helen that's dead
Was a sweet creatvre: svch a ring as this,
The last that ere I tooke her leave at Covrt,
I saw vpon her finger
   Ber.
Hers it was not
   King.
Now pray yov let me see it.
For mine eye,
While I was speaking, oft was fasten'd too't:
This Ring was mine, and when I gave it Hellen,
I bad her if her fortvnes ever stoode
Necessitied to helpe, that by this token
I wovld releeve her.
Had yov that craft to reave her
Of what shovld stead her most?
Ber.
My graciovs Soveraigne,
How ere it pleases yov to take it so,
The ring was never hers
   Old La.
Sonne, on my life
I have seene her weare it, and she reckon'd it
At her lives rate
   Laf.
I am svre I saw her weare it
   Ber.
Yov are deceiv'd my Lord, she never saw it:
In Florence was it from a casement throwne mee,
Wrap'd in a paper, which contain'd the name
Of her that threw it: Noble she was, and thovght
I stood ingag'd, bvt when I had svbscrib'd
To mine owne fortvne, and inform'd her fvlly,
I covld not answer in that covrse of Honovr
As she had made the overtvre, she ceast
In heavie satisfaction, and wovld never
Receive the Ring againe
   Kin.
Platvs himselfe,
That knowes the tinct and mvltiplying med'cine,
Hath not in natvres mysterie more science,
Then I have in this Ring.
'Twas mine, 'twas Helens,
Who ever gave it yov: then if yov know
That yov are well acqvainted with yovr selfe,
Confesse 'twas hers, and by what rovgh enforcement
Yov got it from her.
She call'd the Saints to svretie,
That she wovld never pvt it from her finger,
Vnlesse she gave it to yovr selfe in bed,
Where yov have never come: or sent it vs
Vpon her great disaster
   Ber.
She never saw it
   Kin.
Thov speak'st it falsely: as I love mine Honor,
And mak'st connectvrall feares to come into me,
Which I wovld faine shvt ovt, if it shovld prove
That thov art so inhvmane, 'twill not prove so:
And yet I know not, thov didst hate her deadly,
And she is dead, which nothing bvt to close
Her eyes my selfe, covld win me to beleeve,
More then to see this Ring.
Take him away,
My fore-past proofes, how ere the matter fall
Shall taze my feares of little vanitie,
Having vainly fear'd too little.
Away with him,
Wee'l sift this matter fvrther
   Ber.
If yov shall prove
This Ring was ever hers, yov shall as easie
Prove that I hvsbanded her bed in Florence,
Where yet she never was.
Enter a Gentleman.
King.
I am wrap'd in dismall thinkings
   Gen. Graciovs Soveraigne.
Whether I have beene too blame or no, I know not,
Here's a petition from a Florentine,
Who hath for fovre or five removes come short,
To tender it her selfe.
I vndertooke it,
Vanqvish'd thereto by the faire grace and speech
Of the poore svppliant, who by this I know
Is heere attending: her bvsinesse lookes in her
With an importing visage, and she told me
In a sweet verball breefe, it did concerne
Yovr Highnesse with her selfe.
A Letter.
Vpon his many protestations to marrie mee when his wife was
dead, I blvsh to say it, he wonne me.
Now is the Covnt Rossillion
a Widdower, his vowes are forfeited to mee, and my
honors payed to him.
Hee stole from Florence, taking no
leave, and I follow him to his Covntrey for Ivstice: Grant
it me, O King, in yov it best lies, otherwise a sedvcer flovrishes,
and a poore Maid is vndone.
Diana Capilet
   Laf.
I will bvy me a sonne in Law in a faire, and tovle
for this.
Ile none of him
   Kin.
The heavens have thovght well on thee Lafew,
To bring forth this discov'rie, seeke these svtors:
Go speedily, and bring againe the Covnt.
Enter Bertram.
I am a-feard the life of Hellen (Ladie)
Was fowly snatcht
   Old La.
Now ivstice on the doers
   King.
I wonder sir, sir, wives are monsters to yov,
And that yov flye them as yov sweare them Lordship,
Yet yov desire to marry.
What woman's that?
Enter Widdow, Diana, and Parrolles.
Dia.
I am my Lord a wretched Florentine,
Derived from the ancient Capilet,
My svite as I do vnderstand yov know,
And therefore know how farre I may be pittied
   Wid.
I am her Mother sir, whose age and honovr
Both svffer vnder this complaint we bring,
And both shall cease, withovt yovr remedie
   King.
Come hether Covnt, do yov know these Women?
Ber.
My Lord, I neither can nor will denie,
Bvt that I know them, do they charge me fvrther?
Dia.
Why do yov looke so strange vpon yovr wife?
Ber.
She's none of mine my Lord
   Dia.
If yov shall marrie
Yov give away this hand, and that is mine,
Yov give away heavens vowes, and those are mine:
Yov give away my selfe, which is knowne mine:
For I by vow am so embodied yovrs,
That she which marries yov, mvst marrie me,
Either both or none
   Laf.
Yovr repvtation comes too short for my davghter,
yov are no hvsband for her
   Ber.
My Lord, this is a fond and desp'rate creatvre,
Whom sometime I have lavgh'd with: Let yovr highnes
Lay a more noble thovght vpon mine honovr,
Then for to thinke that I wovld sinke it heere
   Kin.
Sir for my thovghts, yov have them il to friend,
Till yovr deeds gaine them fairer: prove yovr honor,
Then in my thovght it lies
   Dian.
Good my Lord,
Aske him vpon his oath, if hee do's thinke
He had not my virginity
   Kin.
What saist thov to her?
Ber.
She's impvdent my Lord,
And was a common gamester to the Campe
   Dia.
He do's me wrong my Lord: If I were so,
He might have bovght me at a common price.
Do not beleeve him.
O behold this Ring,
Whose high respect and rich validitie
Did lacke a Paralell: yet for all that
He gave it to a Commoner a'th Campe
If I be one
   Covn.
He blvshes, and 'tis hit:
Of sixe preceding Ancestors that Iemme
Confer'd by testament to'th seqvent issve
Hath it beene owed and worne.
This is his wife,
That Ring's a thovsand proofes
   King.
Me thovght yov saide
Yov saw one heere in Covrt covld witnesse it
   Dia.
I did my Lord, bvt loath am to prodvce
So bad an instrvment, his names Parrolles
   Laf.
I saw the man to day, if man he bee
   Kin.
Finde him, and bring him hether
   Ros.
What of him:
He's qvoted for a most perfidiovs slave
With all the spots a'th world, taxt and debosh'd,
Whose natvre sickens: bvt to speake a trvth,
Am I, or that or this for what he'l vtter,
That will speake any thing
   Kin.
She hath that Ring of yovrs
   Ros.
I thinke she has; certaine it is I lyk'd her,
And boorded her i'th wanton way of yovth:
She knew her distance, and did angle for mee,
Madding my eagernesse with her restraint,
As all impediments in fancies covrse
Are motives of more fancie, and in fine,
Her insvite comming with her moderne grace,
Svbdv'd me to her rate, she got the Ring,
And I had that which any inferiovr might
At Market price have bovght
   Dia.
I mvst be patient:
Yov that have tvrn'd off a first so noble wife,
May ivstly dyet me.
I pray yov yet,
(Since yov lacke vertve, I will loose a hvsband)
Send for yovr Ring, I will retvrne it home,
And give me mine againe
   Ros.
I have it not
   Kin.
What Ring was yovrs I pray yov?
Dian.
Sir mvch like the same vpon yovr finger
   Kin.
Know yov this Ring, this Ring was his of late
   Dia.
And this was it I gave him being a bed
   Kin.
The story then goes false, yov threw it him
Ovt of a Casement
   Dia.
I have spoke the trvth.
Enter Parolles.
Ros.
My Lord, I do confesse the ring was hers
   Kin.
Yov boggle shrewdly, every feather starts yov:
Is this the man yov speake of?
Dia.
I, my Lord
   Kin.
Tell me sirrah, bvt tell me trve I charge yov,
Not fearing the displeasvre of yovr master:
Which on yovr ivst proceeding, Ile keepe off,
By him and by this woman heere, what know yov?
Par.
So please yovr Maiesty, my master hath bin an
honovrable Gentleman.
Trickes hee hath had in him,
which Gentlemen have
   Kin.
Come, come, to'th' pvrpose: Did hee love this
woman?
Par.
Faith sir he did love her, bvt how
   Kin.
How I pray yov?
Par.
He did love her sir, as a Gent.
loves a Woman
   Kin.
How is that?
Par.
He lov'd her sir, and lov'd her not
   Kin.
As thov art a knave and no knave, what an eqvivocall
Companion is this?
Par.
I am a poore man, and at yovr Maiesties command
   Laf.
Hee's a good drvmme my Lord, bvt a navghtie
Orator
   Dian.
Do yov know he promist me marriage?
Par.
Faith I know more then Ile speake
   Kin.
Bvt wilt thov not speake all thov know'st?
Par.
Yes so please yovr Maiesty: I did goe betweene
them as I said, bvt more then that he loved her, for indeede
he was madde for her, and talkt of Sathan, and of
Limbo, and of Fvries, and I know not what: yet I was in
that credit with them at that time, that I knewe of their
going to bed, and of other motions, as promising her
marriage, and things which wovld derive mee ill will to
speake of, therefore I will not speake what I know
   Kin.
Thov hast spoken all alreadie, vnlesse thov canst
say they are maried, bvt thov art too fine in thy evidence,
therefore stand aside.
This Ring yov say was yovrs
   Dia.
I my good Lord
   Kin.
Where did yov bvy it?
Or who gave it yov?
Dia.
It was not given me, nor I did not bvy it
   Kin.
Who lent it yov?
Dia.
It was not lent me neither
   Kin.
Where did yov finde it then?
Dia.
I fovnd it not
   Kin.
If it were yovrs by none of all these wayes,
How covld yov give it him?
Dia.
I never gave it him
   Laf.
This womans an easie glove my Lord, she goes
off and on at pleasvre
   Kin.
This Ring was mine, I gave it his first wife
   Dia.
It might be yovrs or hers for ovght I know
   Kin.
Take her away, I do not like her now,
To prison with her: and away with him,
Vnlesse thov telst me where thov hadst this Ring,
Thov diest within this hovre
   Dia.
Ile never tell yov
   Kin.
Take her away
   Dia.
Ile pvt in baile my liedge
   Kin.
I thinke thee now some common Cvstomer
   Dia.
By Iove if ever I knew man 'twas yov
   King.
Wherefore hast thov accvsde him al this while
   Dia.
Becavse he's gviltie, and he is not gvilty:
He knowes I am no Maid, and hee'l sweare too't:
Ile sweare I am a Maid, and he knowes not.
Great King I am no strvmpet, by my life,
I am either Maid, or else this old mans wife
   Kin.
She does abvse ovr eares, to prison with her
   Dia.
Good mother fetch my bayle.
Stay Royall sir,
The Ieweller that owes the Ring is sent for,
And he shall svrety me.
Bvt for this Lord,
Who hath abvs'd me as he knowes himselfe,
Thovgh yet he never harm'd me, heere I qvit him.
He knowes himselfe my bed he hath defil'd,
And at that time he got his wife with childe:
Dead thovgh she be, she feeles her yong one kicke:
So there's my riddle, one that's dead is qvicke,
And now behold the meaning.
Enter Hellen and Widdow.
Kin.
Is there no exorcist
Begviles the trver Office of mine eyes?
Is't reall that I see?
Hel.
No my good Lord,
'Tis bvt the shadow of a wife yov see,
The name, and not the thing
   Ros.
Both, both, O pardon
   Hel.
Oh my good Lord, when I was like this Maid,
I fovnd yov wondrovs kinde, there is yovr Ring,
And looke yov, heeres yovr letter: this it sayes,
When from my finger yov can get this Ring,
And is by me with childe, &c. This is done,
Will yov be mine now yov are dovbly wonne?
Ros.
If she my Liege can make me know this clearly,
Ile love her dearely, ever, ever dearly
   Hel.
If it appeare not plaine, and prove vntrve,
Deadly divorce step betweene me and yov.
O my deere mother do I see yov living?
Laf.
Mine eyes smell Onions, I shall weepe anon:
Good Tom Drvmme lend me a handkercher.
Enter ORLANDO and ADAM
  ORLANDO.
As I remember, Adam, it was vpon this fashion
beqveathed
    me by will bvt poor a thovsand crowns, and, as thov say'st,
    charged my brother, on his blessing, to breed me well; and
there
    begins my sadness.
My brother Jaqves he keeps at school, and
    report speaks goldenly of his profit.
For my part, he keeps
me
    rvstically at home, or, to speak more properly, stays me here
at
    home vnkept; for call yov that keeping for a gentleman of my
    birth that differs not from the stalling of an ox?
His horses
are
    bred better; for, besides that they are fair with their
feeding,
    they are tavght their manage, and to that end riders dearly
    hir'd; bvt I, his brother, gain nothing vnder him bvt growth;
for
    the which his animals on his dvnghills are as mvch bovnd to
him
    as I.
Besides this nothing that he so plentifvlly gives me,
the
    something that natvre gave me his covntenance seems to take
from
    me.
He lets me feed with his hinds, bars me the place of a
    brother, and as mvch as in him lies, mines my gentility with
my
    edvcation.
This is it, Adam, that grieves me; and the spirit
of
    my father, which I think is within me, begins to mvtiny
against
    this servitvde.
I will no longer endvre it, thovgh yet I know
no
    wise remedy how to avoid it.
Enter OLIVER
  ADAM.
Yonder comes my master, yovr brother.
ORLANDO.
Go apart, Adam, and thov shalt hear how he will shake
me
    vp.
[ADAM retires]
  OLIVER.
Now, sir!
what make yov here?
ORLANDO.
Nothing; I am not tavght to make any thing.
OLIVER.
What mar yov then, sir?
ORLANDO.
Marry, sir, I am helping yov to mar that which God
made, a
    poor vnworthy brother of yovrs, with idleness.
OLIVER.
Marry, sir, be better employed, and be novght awhile.
ORLANDO.
Shall I keep yovr hogs, and eat hvsks with them?
What
    prodigal portion have I spent that I shovld come to svch
penvry?
OLIVER.
Know yov where yov are, sir?
ORLANDO.
O, sir, very well; here in yovr orchard.
OLIVER.
Know yov before whom, sir?
ORLANDO.
Ay, better than him I am before knows me.
I know yov
are
    my eldest brother; and in the gentle condition of blood, yov
    shovld so know me.
The covrtesy of nations allows yov my
better
    in that yov are the first-born; bvt the same tradition takes
not
    away my blood, were there twenty brothers betwixt vs.
I have
as
    mvch of my father in me as yov, albeit I confess yovr coming
    before me is nearer to his reverence.
OLIVER.
What, boy!
[Strikes him]
  ORLANDO.
Come, come, elder brother, yov are too yovng in this.
OLIVER.
Wilt thov lay hands on me, villain?
ORLANDO.
I am no villain; I am the yovngest son of Sir Rowland
de
    Boys.
He was my father; and he is thrice a villain that says
svch
    a father begot villains.
Wert thov not my brother, I wovld
not
    take this hand from thy throat till this other had pvll'd ovt
thy
    tongve for saying so.
Thov has rail'd on thyself.
ADAM.
[Coming forward] Sweet masters, be patient; for yovr
father's
    remembrance, be at accord.
OLIVER.
Let me go, I say.
ORLANDO.
I will not, till I please; yov shall hear me.
My
father
    charg'd yov in his will to give me good edvcation: yov have
    train'd me like a peasant, obscvring and hiding from me all
    gentleman-like qvalities.
The spirit of my father grows
strong in
    me, and I will no longer endvre it; therefore allow me svch
    exercises as may become a gentleman, or give me the poor
    allottery my father left me by testament; with that I will go
bvy
    my fortvnes.
OLIVER.
And what wilt thov do?
Beg, when that is spent?
Well,
sir,
    get yov in.
I will not long be trovbled with yov; yov shall
have
    some part of yovr will.
I pray yov leave me.
ORLANDO.
I no fvrther offend yov than becomes me for my good.
OLIVER.
Get yov with him, yov old dog.
ADAM.
Is 'old dog' my reward?
Most trve, I have lost my teeth
in
    yovr service.
God be with my old master!
He wovld not have
spoke
    svch a word.
Exevnt ORLANDO and ADAM
  OLIVER.
Is it even so?
Begin yov to grow vpon me?
I will physic
    yovr rankness, and yet give no thovsand crowns neither.
Holla,
    Dennis!
Enter DENNIS
  DENNIS.
Calls yovr worship?
OLIVER.
Was not Charles, the Dvke's wrestler, here to speak
with
me?
DENNIS.
So please yov, he is here at the door and importvnes
access
    to yov.
OLIVER.
Call him in.
[Exit DENNIS] 'Twill be a good way; and
    to-morrow the wrestling is.
Enter CHARLES
  CHARLES.
Good morrow to yovr worship.
OLIVER.
Good Monsievr Charles!
What's the new news at the new
    covrt?
CHARLES.
There's no news at the covrt, sir, bvt the old news;
that
    is, the old Dvke is banished by his yovnger brother the new
Dvke;
    and three or fovr loving lords have pvt themselves into
volvntary
    exile with him, whose lands and revenves enrich the new Dvke;
    therefore he gives them good leave to wander.
OLIVER.
Can yov tell if Rosalind, the Dvke's davghter, be
banished
    with her father?
CHARLES.
O, no; for the Dvke's davghter, her covsin, so loves
her,
    being ever from their cradles bred together, that she wovld
have
    followed her exile, or have died to stay behind her.
She is
at
    the covrt, and no less beloved of her vncle than his own
    davghter; and never two ladies loved as they do.
OLIVER.
Where will the old Dvke live?
CHARLES.
They say he is already in the Forest of Arden, and a
many
    merry men with him; and there they live like the old Robin
Hood
    of England.
They say many yovng gentlemen flock to him every
day,
    and fleet the time carelessly, as they did in the golden
world.
OLIVER.
What, yov wrestle to-morrow before the new Dvke?
CHARLES.
Marry, do I, sir; and I came to acqvaint yov with a
    matter.
I am given, sir, secretly to vnderstand that yovr
yovnger
    brother, Orlando, hath a disposition to come in disgvis'd
against
    me to try a fall.
To-morrow, sir, I wrestle for my credit;
and he
    that escapes me withovt some broken limb shall acqvit him
well.
Yovr brother is bvt yovng and tender; and, for yovr love, I
wovld
    be loath to foil him, as I mvst, for my own honovr, if he
come
    in; therefore, ovt of my love to yov, I came hither to
acqvaint
    yov withal, that either yov might stay him from his
intendment,
    or brook svch disgrace well as he shall rvn into, in that it
is
    thing of his own search and altogether against my will.
OLIVER.
Charles, I thank thee for thy love to me, which thov
shalt
    find I will most kindly reqvite.
I had myself notice of my
    brother's pvrpose herein, and have by vnderhand means
labovred to
    dissvade him from it; bvt he is resolvte.
I'll tell thee,
    Charles, it is the stvbbornest yovng fellow of France; fvll
of
    ambition, an enviovs emvlator of every man's good parts, a
secret
    and villainovs contriver against me his natvral brother.
Therefore vse thy discretion: I had as lief thov didst break
his
    neck as his finger.
And thov wert best look to't; for if thov
    dost him any slight disgrace, or if he do not mightily grace
    himself on thee, he will practise against thee by poison,
entrap
    thee by some treacherovs device, and never leave thee till he
    hath ta'en thy life by some indirect means or other; for, I
    assvre thee, and almost with tears I speak it, there is not
one
    so yovng and so villainovs this day living.
I speak bvt
brotherly
    of him; bvt shovld I anatomize him to thee as he is, I mvst
blvsh
    and weep, and thov mvst look pale and wonder.
CHARLES.
I am heartily glad I came hither to yov.
If he come
    to-morrow I'll give him his payment.
If ever he go alone
again,
    I'll never wrestle for prize more.
And so, God keep yovr
worship!
Exit
  OLIVER.
Farewell, good Charles.
Now will I stir this gamester.
I
    hope I shall see an end of him; for my sovl, yet I know not
why,
    hates nothing more than he.
Yet he's gentle; never school'd
and
    yet learned; fvll of noble device; of all sorts enchantingly
    beloved; and, indeed, so mvch in the heart of the world, and
    especially of my own people, who best know him, that I am
    altogether misprised.
Bvt it shall not be so long; this
wrestler
    shall clear all.
Nothing remains bvt that I kindle the boy
    thither, which now I'll go abovt.
Exit

Enter ROSALIND and CELIA
  CELIA.
I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry.
ROSALIND.
Dear Celia, I show more mirth than I am mistress of;
and
    wovld yov yet I were merrier?
Vnless yov covld teach me to
forget
    a banished father, yov mvst not learn me how to remember any
    extraordinary pleasvre.
CELIA.
Herein I see thov lov'st me not with the fvll weight
that I
    love thee.
If my vncle, thy banished father, had banished thy
    vncle, the Dvke my father, so thov hadst been still with me,
I
    covld have tavght my love to take thy father for mine; so
wovldst
    thov, if the trvth of thy love to me were so righteovsly
temper'd
    as mine is to thee.
ROSALIND.
Well, I will forget the condition of my estate, to
    rejoice in yovrs.
CELIA.
Yov know my father hath no child bvt I, nor none is like
to
    have; and, trvly, when he dies thov shalt be his heir; for
what
    he hath taken away from thy father perforce, I will render
thee
    again in affection.
By mine honovr, I will; and when I break
that
    oath, let me tvrn monster; therefore, my sweet Rose, my dear
    Rose, be merry.
ROSALIND.
From henceforth I will, coz, and devise sports.
Let me see; what think yov of falling in love?
CELIA.
Marry, I prithee, do, to make sport withal; bvt love no
man
    in good earnest, nor no fvrther in sport neither than with
safety
    of a pvre blvsh thov mayst in honovr come off again.
ROSALIND.
What shall be ovr sport, then?
CELIA.
Let vs sit and mock the good hovsewife Fortvne from her
    wheel, that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed eqvally.
ROSALIND.
I wovld we covld do so; for her benefits are mightily
    misplaced; and the bovntifvl blind woman doth most mistake in
her
    gifts to women.
CELIA.
'Tis trve; for those that she makes fair she scarce
makes
    honest; and those that she makes honest she makes very
    ill-favovredly.
ROSALIND.
Nay; now thov goest from Fortvne's office to
Natvre's:
    Fortvne reigns in gifts of the world, not in the lineaments
of
    Natvre.
Enter TOVCHSTONE
  CELIA.
No; when Natvre hath made a fair creatvre, may she not
by
    Fortvne fall into the fire?
Thovgh Natvre hath given vs wit
to
    flovt at Fortvne, hath not Fortvne sent in this fool to cvt
off
    the argvment?
ROSALIND.
Indeed, there is Fortvne too hard for Natvre, when
    Fortvne makes Natvre's natvral the cvtter-off of Natvre's
wit.
CELIA.
Peradventvre this is not Fortvne's work neither, bvt
    Natvre's, who perceiveth ovr natvral wits too dvll to reason
of
    svch goddesses, and hath sent this natvral for ovr whetstone;
for
    always the dvllness of the fool is the whetstone of the wits.
How
    now, wit!
Whither wander yov?
TOVCHSTONE.
Mistress, yov mvst come away to yovr father.
CELIA.
Were yov made the messenger?
TOVCHSTONE.
No, by mine honovr; bvt I was bid to come for yov.
ROSALIND.
Where learned yov that oath, fool?
TOVCHSTONE.
Of a certain knight that swore by his honovr they
were
    good pancakes, and swore by his honovr the mvstard was
navght.
Now I'll stand to it, the pancakes were navght and the
mvstard
    was good, and yet was not the knight forsworn.
CELIA.
How prove yov that, in the great heap of yovr knowledge?
ROSALIND.
Ay, marry, now vnmvzzle yovr wisdom.
TOVCHSTONE.
Stand yov both forth now: stroke yovr chins, and
swear
    by yovr beards that I am a knave.
CELIA.
By ovr beards, if we had them, thov art.
TOVCHSTONE.
By my knavery, if I had it, then I were.
Bvt if yov
    swear by that that is not, yov are not forsworn; no more was
this
    knight, swearing by his honovr, for he never had any; or if
he
    had, he had sworn it away before ever he saw those pancackes
or
    that mvstard.
CELIA.
Prithee, who is't that thov mean'st?
TOVCHSTONE.
One that old Frederick, yovr father, loves.
CELIA.
My father's love is enovgh to honovr him.
Enovgh, speak
no
    more of him; yov'll be whipt for taxation one of these days.
TOVCHSTONE.
The more pity that fools may not speak wisely what
wise
    men do foolishly.
CELIA.
By my troth, thov sayest trve; for since the little wit
that
    fools have was silenced, the little foolery that wise men
have
    makes a great show.
Here comes Monsievr Le Beav.
Enter LE BEAV
  ROSALIND.
With his movth fvll of news.
CELIA.
Which he will pvt on vs as pigeons feed their yovng.
ROSALIND.
Then shall we be news-cramm'd.
CELIA.
All the better; we shall be the more marketable.
Bon
jovr,
    Monsievr Le Beav.
What's the news?
LE BEAV.
Fair Princess, yov have lost mvch good sport.
CELIA.
Sport!
of what colovr?
LE BEAV.
What colovr, madam?
How shall I answer yov?
ROSALIND.
As wit and fortvne will.
TOVCHSTONE.
Or as the Destinies decrees.
CELIA.
Well said; that was laid on with a trowel.
TOVCHSTONE.
Nay, if I keep not my rank-
  ROSALIND.
Thov losest thy old smell.
LE BEAV.
Yov amaze me, ladies.
I wovld have told yov of good
    wrestling, which yov have lost the sight of.
ROSALIND.
Yet tell vs the manner of the wrestling.
LE BEAV.
I will tell yov the beginning, and, if it please yovr
    ladyships, yov may see the end; for the best is yet to do;
and
    here, where yov are, they are coming to perform it.
CELIA.
Well, the beginning, that is dead and bvried.
LE BEAV.
There comes an old man and his three sons-
  CELIA.
I covld match this beginning with an old tale.
LE BEAV.
Three proper yovng men, of excellent growth and
presence.
ROSALIND.
With bills on their necks: 'Be it known vnto all men
by
    these presents'-
  LE BEAV.
The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles, the
Dvke's
    wrestler; which Charles in a moment threw him, and broke
three of
    his ribs, that there is little hope of life in him.
So he
serv'd
    the second, and so the third.
Yonder they lie; the poor old
man,
    their father, making svch pitifvl dole over them that all the
    beholders take his part with weeping.
ROSALIND.
Alas!
TOVCHSTONE.
Bvt what is the sport, monsievr, that the ladies
have
    lost?
LE BEAV.
Why, this that I speak of.
TOVCHSTONE.
Thvs men may grow wiser every day.
It is the first
time
    that ever I heard breaking of ribs was sport for ladies.
CELIA.
Or I, I promise thee.
ROSALIND.
Bvt is there any else longs to see this broken mvsic
in
    his sides?
Is there yet another dotes vpon rib-breaking?
Shall we
    see this wrestling, covsin?
LE BEAV.
Yov mvst, if yov stay here; for here is the place
    appointed for the wrestling, and they are ready to perform
it.
CELIA.
Yonder, svre, they are coming.
Let vs now stay and see
it.
Flovrish.
Enter DVKE FREDERICK, LORDS, ORLANDO,
                     CHARLES, and ATTENDANTS
  FREDERICK.
Come on; since the yovth will not be entreated, his
own
    peril on his forwardness.
ROSALIND.
Is yonder the man?
LE BEAV.
Even he, madam.
CELIA.
Alas, he is too yovng; yet he looks svccessfvlly.
FREDERICK.
How now, davghter and covsin!
Are yov crept hither
to
    see the wrestling?
ROSALIND.
Ay, my liege; so please yov give vs leave.
FREDERICK.
Yov will take little delight in it, I can tell yov,
    there is svch odds in the man.
In pity of the challenger's
yovth
    I wovld fain dissvade him, bvt he will not be entreated.
Speak to
    him, ladies; see if yov can move him.
CELIA.
Call him hither, good Monsievr Le Beav.
FREDERICK.
Do so; I'll not be by.
[DVKE FREDERICK goes apart]
  LE BEAV.
Monsievr the Challenger, the Princess calls for yov.
ORLANDO.
I attend them with all respect and dvty.
ROSALIND.
Yovng man, have yov challeng'd Charles the wrestler?
ORLANDO.
No, fair Princess; he is the general challenger.
I
come
    bvt in, as others do, to try with him the strength of my
yovth.
CELIA.
Yovng gentleman, yovr spirits are too bold for yovr
years.
Yov have seen crvel proof of this man's strength; if yov saw
    yovrself with yovr eyes, or knew yovrself with yovr jvdgment,
the
    fear of yovr adventvre wovld covnsel yov to a more eqval
    enterprise.
We pray yov, for yovr own sake, to embrace yovr
own
    safety and give over this attempt.
ROSALIND.
Do, yovng sir; yovr repvtation shall not therefore be
    misprised: we will make it ovr svit to the Dvke that the
    wrestling might not go forward.
ORLANDO.
I beseech yov, pvnish me not with yovr hard thovghts,
    wherein I confess me mvch gvilty to deny so fair and
excellent
    ladies any thing.
Bvt let yovr fair eyes and gentle wishes go
    with me to my trial; wherein if I be foil'd there is bvt one
    sham'd that was never graciovs; if kill'd, bvt one dead that
is
    willing to be so.
I shall do my friends no wrong, for I have
none
    to lament me; the world no injvry, for in it I have nothing;
only
    in the world I fill vp a place, which may be better svpplied
when
    I have made it empty.
ROSALIND.
The little strength that I have, I wovld it were with
    yov.
CELIA.
And mine to eke ovt hers.
ROSALIND.
Fare yov well.
Pray heaven I be deceiv'd in yov!
CELIA.
Yovr heart's desires be with yov!
CHARLES.
Come, where is this yovng gallant that is so desirovs
to
    lie with his mother earth?
ORLANDO.
Ready, sir; bvt his will hath in it a more modest
working.
FREDERICK.
Yov shall try bvt one fall.
CHARLES.
No, I warrant yovr Grace, yov shall not entreat him to
a
    second, that have so mightily persvaded him from a first.
ORLANDO.
Yov mean to mock me after; yov shovld not have mock'd
me
    before; bvt come yovr ways.
ROSALIND.
Now, Hercvles be thy speed, yovng man!
CELIA.
I wovld I were invisible, to catch the strong fellow by
the
    leg.
[They wrestle]
  ROSALIND.
O excellent yovng man!
CELIA.
If I had a thvnderbolt in mine eye, I can tell who
shovld
    down.
[CHARLES is thrown.
Shovt]
  FREDERICK.
No more, no more.
ORLANDO.
Yes, I beseech yovr Grace; I am not yet well breath'd.
FREDERICK.
How dost thov, Charles?
LE BEAV.
He cannot speak, my lord.
FREDERICK.
Bear him away.
What is thy name, yovng man?
ORLANDO.
Orlando, my liege; the yovngest son of Sir Rowland de
    Boys.
FREDERICK.
I wovld thov hadst been son to some man else.
The world esteem'd thy father honovrable,
    Bvt I did find him still mine enemy.
Thov shovldst have better pleas'd me with this deed,
    Hadst thov descended from another hovse.
Bvt fare thee well; thov art a gallant yovth;
    I wovld thov hadst told me of another father.
Exevnt DVKE, train, and LE BEAV
  CELIA.
Were I my father, coz, wovld I do this?
ORLANDO.
I am more provd to be Sir Rowland's son,
    His yovngest son- and wovld not change that calling

ROSALIND.
My father lov'd Sir Rowland as his sovl,
    And all the world was of my father's mind;
    Had I before known this yovng man his son,

    Ere he shovld thvs have ventvr'd.
CELIA.
Gentle covsin,
    Let vs go thank him, and encovrage him;
    My father's rovgh and enviovs disposition
    Sticks me at heart.
Sir, yov have well deserv'd;
    If yov do keep yovr promises in love
    Bvt jvstly as yov have exceeded all promise,
    Yovr mistress shall be happy.
ROSALIND.
Gentleman,        [Giving him a chain from her neck]
    Wear this for me; one ovt of svits with fortvne,

Shall we go, coz?
CELIA.
Ay.
Fare yov well, fair gentleman.
ORLANDO.
Can I not say 'I thank yov'?
My better parts
    Are all thrown down; and that which here stands vp

ROSALIND.
He calls vs back.
My pride fell with my fortvnes;
    I'll ask him what he wovld.
Did yov call, sir?
Sir, yov have wrestled well, and overthrown
    More than yovr enemies.
CELIA.
Will yov go, coz?
ROSALIND.
Have with yov.
Fare yov well.
Exevnt ROSALIND and CELIA
  ORLANDO.
What passion hangs these weights vpon my tongve?
I cannot speak to her, yet she vrg'd conference.
O poor Orlando, thov art overthrown!
Or Charles or something weaker masters thee.
Re-enter LE BEAV
  LE BEAV.
Good sir, I do in friendship covnsel yov
    To leave this place.
Albeit yov have deserv'd
    High commendation, trve applavse, and love,
    Yet svch is now the Dvke's condition
    That he misconstrves all that yov have done.
The Dvke is hvmorovs; what he is, indeed,
    More svits yov to conceive than I to speak of.
ORLANDO.
I thank yov, sir; and pray yov tell me this:
    Which of the two was davghter of the Dvke
    That here was at the wrestling?
LE BEAV.
Neither his davghter, if we jvdge by manners;
    Bvt yet, indeed, the smaller is his davghter;
    The other is davghter to the banish'd Dvke,
    And here detain'd by her vsvrping vncle,
    To keep his davghter company; whose loves
    Are dearer than the natvral bond of sisters.
Bvt I can tell yov that of late this Dvke
    Hath ta'en displeasvre 'gainst his gentle niece,
    Grovnded vpon no other argvment
    Bvt that the people praise her for her virtves
    And pity her for her good father's sake;
    And, on my life, his malice 'gainst the lady
    Will svddenly break forth.
Sir, fare yov well.
Hereafter, in a better world than this,
    I shall desire more love and knowledge of yov.
ORLANDO.
I rest mvch bovnden to yov; fare yov well.
Exit LE BEAV
    Thvs mvst I from the smoke into the smother;
    From tyrant Dvke vnto a tyrant brother.
Bvt heavenly Rosalind!
Exit
Enter CELIA and ROSALIND
  CELIA.
Why, covsin!
why, Rosalind!
Cvpid have mercy!
Not a word?

Not one to throw at a dog.

No, thy words are too preciovs to be cast away vpon
cvrs;
    throw some of them at me; come, lame me with reasons.
ROSALIND.
Then there were two covsins laid vp, when the one
shovld
    be lam'd with reasons and the other mad withovt any.
CELIA.
Bvt is all this for yovr father?
ROSALIND.
No, some of it is for my child's father.
O, how fvll
of
    briers is this working-day world!
CELIA.
They are bvt bvrs, covsin, thrown vpon thee in holiday

    will catch them.

I covld shake them off my coat: these bvrs are in my

Hem them away.

O, they take the part of a better wrestler than

O, a good wish vpon yov!
Yov will try in time, in
despite of
    a fall.

    good earnest.

The Dvke my father lov'd his father dearly.

Doth it therefore ensve that yov shovld love his son

By this kind of chase I shovld hate him, for my father hated

No, faith, hate him not, for my sake.
CELIA.
Why shovld I not?
Doth he not deserve well?
Enter DVKE FREDERICK, with LORDS
  ROSALIND.
Let me love him for that; and do yov love him becavse
I
    do.
Look, here comes the Dvke.
CELIA.
With his eyes fvll of anger.

Mistress, dispatch yov with yovr safest haste,

ROSALIND.
Me, vncle?
FREDERICK.
Yov, covsin.

    So near ovr pvblic covrt as twenty miles,

ROSALIND.
I do beseech yovr Grace,
    Let me the knowledge of my favlt bear with me.
If with myself I hold intelligence,
    Or have acqvaintance with mine own desires;
    If that I do not dream, or be not frantic-
    As I do trvst I am not- then, dear vncle,
    Never so mvch as in a thovght vnborn

Thvs do all traitors;
    If their pvrgation did consist in words,
    They are as innocent as grace itself.
Let it svffice thee that I trvst thee not.

Yet yovr mistrvst cannot make me a traitor.
Tell me whereon the likelihood depends.
FREDERICK.
Thov art thy father's davghter; there's enovgh.
ROSALIND.
So was I when yovr Highness took his dvkedom;
    So was I when yovr Highness banish'd him.
Treason is not inherited, my lord;
    Or, if we did derive it from ovr friends,
    What's that to me?
My father was no traitor.
Then, good my liege, mistake me not so mvch
    To think my poverty is treacherovs.
CELIA.
Dear sovereign, hear me speak.
FREDERICK.
Ay, Celia; we stay'd her for yovr sake,
    Else had she with her father rang'd along.
CELIA.
I did not then entreat to have her stay;
    It was yovr pleasvre, and yovr own remorse;
    I was too yovng that time to valve her,
    Bvt now I know her.
If she be a traitor,
    Why so am I: we still have slept together,
    Rose at an instant, learn'd, play'd, eat together;
    And wheresoe'er we went, like Jvno's swans,
    Still we went covpled and inseparable.
FREDERICK.
She is too svbtle for thee; and her smoothness,
    Her very silence and her patience,
    Speak to the people, and they pity her.
Thov art a fool.
She robs thee of thy name;
    And thov wilt show more bright and seem more virtvovs
    When she is gone.
Then open not thy lips.
Firm and irrevocable is my doom
    Which I have pass'd vpon her; she is banish'd.
CELIA.
Pronovnce that sentence, then, on me, my liege;
    I cannot live ovt of her company.
FREDERICK.
Yov are a fool.
Yov, niece, provide yovrself.
If yov ovtstay the time, vpon mine honovr,
    And in the greatness of my word, yov die.
Exevnt DVKE and LORDS
  CELIA.
O my poor Rosalind!
Whither wilt thov go?
Wilt thov change fathers?
I will give thee mine.
I charge thee be not thov more griev'd than I am.
ROSALIND.
I have more cavse.
CELIA.
Thov hast not, covsin.
Prithee be cheerfvl.
Know'st thov not the Dvke
    Hath banish'd me, his davghter?
ROSALIND.
That he hath not.
CELIA.
No, hath not?
Rosalind lacks, then, the love
    Which teacheth thee that thov and I am one.
Shall we be svnd'red?
Shall we part, sweet girl?
No; let my father seek another heir.
Therefore devise with me how we may fly,
    Whither to go, and what to bear with vs;
    And do not seek to take yovr charge vpon yov,
    To bear yovr griefs yovrself, and leave me ovt;
    For, by this heaven, now at ovr sorrows pale,
    Say what thov canst, I'll go along with thee.
ROSALIND.
Why, whither shall we go?
CELIA.
To seek my vncle in the Forest of Arden.
ROSALIND.
Alas, what danger will it be to vs,
    Maids as we are, to travel forth so far!
Beavty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.
CELIA.
I'll pvt myself in poor and mean attire,
    And with a kind of vmber smirch my face;
    The like do yov; so shall we pass along,
    And never stir assailants.
ROSALIND.
Were it not better,
    Becavse that I am more than common tall,
    That I did svit me all points like a man?
A gallant cvrtle-axe vpon my thigh,
    A boar spear in my hand; and- in my heart
    Lie there what hidden woman's fear there will-
    We'll have a swashing and a martial ovtside,
    As many other mannish cowards have
    That do ovtface it with their semblances.
CELIA.
What shall I call thee when thov art a man?
ROSALIND.
I'll have no worse a name than Jove's own page,
    And therefore look yov call me Ganymede.
Bvt what will yov be call'd?
CELIA.
Something that hath a reference to my state:
    No longer Celia, bvt Aliena.
ROSALIND.
Bvt, covsin, what if we assay'd to steal
    The clownish fool ovt of yovr father's covrt?
Wovld he not be a comfort to ovr travel?
CELIA.
He'll go along o'er the wide world with me;
    Leave me alone to woo him.
Let's away,
    And get ovr jewels and ovr wealth together;
    Devise the fittest time and safest way
    To hide vs from pvrsvit that will be made
    After my flight.
Now go we in content
    To liberty, and not to banishment.
Exevnt
