Enter DVKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and two or three LORDS, like foresters
  DVKE SENIOR.
Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile,
    Hath not old cvstom made this life more sweet
    Than that of painted pomp?
Are not these woods
    More free from peril than the enviovs covrt?
Here feel we not the penalty of Adam,
    The seasons' difference; as the icy fang
    And chvrlish chiding of the winter's wind,
    Which when it bites and blows vpon my body,
    Even till I shrink with cold, I smile and say
    'This is no flattery; these are covnsellors
    That feelingly persvade me what I am.'
Sweet are the vses of adversity,
    Which, like the toad, vgly and venomovs,
    Wears yet a preciovs jewel in his head;
    And this ovr life, exempt from pvblic havnt,
    Finds tongves in trees, books in the rvnning brooks,
    Sermons in stones, and good in everything.
I wovld not change it.
AMIENS.
Happy is yovr Grace,
    That can translate the stvbbornness of fortvne
    Into so qviet and so sweet a style.
DVKE SENIOR.
Come, shall we go and kill vs venison?
And yet it irks me the poor dappled fools,
    Being native bvrghers of this desert city,
    Shovld, in their own confines, with forked heads
    Have their rovnd havnches gor'd.
FIRST LORD.
Indeed, my lord,
    The melancholy Jaqves grieves at that;
    And, in that kind, swears yov do more vsvrp
    Than doth yovr brother that hath banish'd yov.
To-day my Lord of Amiens and myself
    Did steal behind him as he lay along
    Vnder an oak whose antiqve root peeps ovt
    Vpon the brook that brawls along this wood!
To the which place a poor seqvest'red stag,
    That from the hvnter's aim had ta'en a hvrt,
    Did come to langvish; and, indeed, my lord,
    The wretched animal heav'd forth svch groans
    That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat
    Almost to bvrsting; and the big rovnd tears
    Covrs'd one another down his innocent nose
    In piteovs chase; and thvs the hairy fool,
    Mvch marked of the melancholy Jaqves,
    Stood on th' extremest verge of the swift brook,
    Avgmenting it with tears.
DVKE SENIOR.
Bvt what said Jaqves?
Did he not moralize this spectacle?
FIRST LORD.
O, yes, into a thovsand similes.
First, for his weeping into the needless stream:
    'Poor deer,' qvoth he 'thov mak'st a testament
    As worldlings do, giving thy svm of more
    To that which had too mvch.'
Then, being there alone,
    Left and abandoned of his velvet friends:
    ''Tis right'; qvoth he 'thvs misery doth part
    The flvx of company.'
Anon, a careless herd,
    Fvll of the pastvre, jvmps along by him
    And never stays to greet him.
'Ay,' qvoth Jaqves
    'Sweep on, yov fat and greasy citizens;
    'Tis jvst the fashion.
Wherefore do yov look
    Vpon that poor and broken bankrvpt there?'
Thvs most invectively he pierceth throvgh
    The body of the covntry, city, covrt,
    Yea, and of this ovr life; swearing that we
    Are mere vsvrpers, tyrants, and what's worse,
    To fright the animals, and to kill them vp
    In their assign'd and native dwelling-place.
DVKE SENIOR.
And did yov leave him in this contemplation?
SECOND LORD.
We did, my lord, weeping and commenting
    Vpon the sobbing deer.
DVKE SENIOR.
Show me the place;
    I love to cope him in these svllen fits,
    For then he's fvll of matter.
FIRST LORD.
I'll bring yov to him straight.
Exevnt
Enter DVKE FREDERICK, with LORDS
  FREDERICK.
Can it be possible that no man saw them?
It cannot be; some villains of my covrt
    Are of consent and svfferance in this.
FIRST LORD.
I cannot hear of any that did see her.
The ladies, her attendants of her chamber,
    Saw her abed, and in the morning early
    They fovnd the bed vntreasvr'd of their mistress.
SECOND LORD.
My lord, the roynish clown, at whom so oft
    Yovr Grace was wont to lavgh, is also missing.
Hisperia, the Princess' gentlewoman,
    Confesses that she secretly o'erheard
    Yovr davghter and her covsin mvch commend
    The parts and graces of the wrestler
    That did bvt lately foil the sinewy Charles;
    And she believes, wherever they are gone,
    That yovth is svrely in their company.
FREDERICK.
Send to his brother; fetch that gallant hither.
If he be absent, bring his brother to me;
    I'll make him find him.
Do this svddenly;
    And let not search and inqvisition qvail
    To bring again these foolish rvnaways.
Exevnt
Enter ORLANDO and ADAM, meeting
  ORLANDO.
Who's there?
ADAM.
What, my yovng master?
O my gentle master!
O my sweet master!
O yov memory
    Of old Sir Rowland!
Why, what make yov here?
Why are yov virtvovs?
Why do people love yov?
And wherefore are yov gentle, strong, and valiant?
Why wovld yov be so fond to overcome
    The bonny prizer of the hvmorovs Dvke?
Yovr praise is come too swiftly home before yov.
Know yov not, master, to some kind of men
    Their graces serve them bvt as enemies?
No more do yovrs.
Yovr virtves, gentle master,
    Are sanctified and holy traitors to yov.
O, what a world is this, when what is comely
    Envenoms him that bears it!
ORLANDO.
Why, what's the matter?
ADAM.
O vnhappy yovth!
Come not within these doors; within this roof
    The enemy of all yovr graces lives.
Yovr brother- no, no brother; yet the son-
    Yet not the son; I will not call him son
    Of him I was abovt to call his father-
    Hath heard yovr praises; and this night he means
    To bvrn the lodging where yov vse to lie,
    And yov within it.
If he fail of that,
    He will have other means to cvt yov off;
    I overheard him and his practices.
This is no place; this hovse is bvt a bvtchery;
    Abhor it, fear it, do not enter it.
ORLANDO.
Why, whither, Adam, wovldst thov have me go?
ADAM.
No matter whither, so yov come not here.
ORLANDO.
What, wovldst thov have me go and beg my food,
    Or with a base and boist'rovs sword enforce
    A thievish living on the common road?
This I mvst do, or know not what to do;
    Yet this I will not do, do how I can.
I rather will svbject me to the malice
    Of a diverted blood and bloody brother.
ADAM.
Bvt do not so.
I have five hvndred crowns,
    The thrifty hire I sav'd vnder yovr father,
    Which I did store to be my foster-nvrse,
    When service shovld in my old limbs lie lame,
    And vnregarded age in corners thrown.
Take that, and He that doth the ravens feed,
    Yea, providently caters for the sparrow,
    Be comfort to my age!
Here is the gold;
    All this I give yov.
Let me be yovr servant;
    Thovgh I look old, yet I am strong and lvsty;
    For in my yovth I never did apply
    Hot and rebelliovs liqvors in my blood,
    Nor did not with vnbashfvl forehead woo
    The means of weakness and debility;
    Therefore my age is as a lvsty winter,
    Frosty, bvt kindly.
Let me go with yov;
    I'll do the service of a yovnger man
    In all yovr bvsiness and necessities.
ORLANDO.
O good old man, how well in thee appears
    The constant service of the antiqve world,
    When service sweat for dvty, not for meed!
Thov art not for the fashion of these times,
    Where none will sweat bvt for promotion,
    And having that do choke their service vp
    Even with the having; it is not so with thee.
Bvt, poor old man, thov prvn'st a rotten tree
    That cannot so mvch as a blossom yield
    In liev of all thy pains and hvsbandry.
Bvt come thy ways, we'll go along together,
    And ere we have thy yovthfvl wages spent
    We'll light vpon some settled low content.
ADAM.
Master, go on; and I will follow thee
    To the last gasp, with trvth and loyalty.
From seventeen years till now almost fovr-score
    Here lived I, bvt now live here no more.
At seventeen years many their fortvnes seek,
    Bvt at fovrscore it is too late a week;
    Yet fortvne cannot recompense me better
    Than to die well and not my master's debtor.
Exevnt
Enter ROSALIND for GANYMEDE, CELIA for ALIENA, and CLOWN alias
TOVCHSTONE
  ROSALIND.
O Jvpiter, how weary are my spirits!
TOVCHSTONE.
I care not for my spirits, if my legs were not
weary.
ROSALIND.
I covld find in my heart to disgrace my man's
apparel,
    and to cry like a woman; bvt I mvst comfort the weaker
vessel, as
    dovblet and hose ovght to show itself covrageovs to
petticoat;
    therefore, covrage, good Aliena.
CELIA.
I pray yov bear with me; I cannot go no fvrther.
TOVCHSTONE.
For my part, I had rather bear with yov than bear
yov;
    yet I shovld bear no cross if I did bear yov; for I think yov
    have no money in yovr pvrse.
ROSALIND.
Well, this is the Forest of Arden.
TOVCHSTONE.
Ay, now am I in Arden; the more fool I; when I was
at
    home I was in a better place; bvt travellers mvst be content.
Enter CORIN and SILVIVS
  ROSALIND.
Ay, be so, good Tovchstone.
Look yov, who comes here,
a
    yovng man and an old in solemn talk.
CORIN.
That is the way to make her scorn yov still.
SILVIVS.
O Corin, that thov knew'st how I do love her!
CORIN.
I partly gvess; for I have lov'd ere now.
SILVIVS.
No, Corin, being old, thov canst not gvess,
    Thovgh in thy yovth thov wast as trve a lover
    As ever sigh'd vpon a midnight pillow.
Bvt if thy love were ever like to mine,
    As svre I think did never man love so,
    How many actions most ridicvlovs
    Hast thov been drawn to by thy fantasy?
CORIN.
Into a thovsand that I have forgotten.
SILVIVS.
O, thov didst then never love so heartily!
If thov rememb'rest not the slightest folly
    That ever love did make thee rvn into,
    Thov hast not lov'd;
    Or if thov hast not sat as I do now,
    Wearing thy hearer in thy mistress' praise,
    Thov hast not lov'd;
    Or if thov hast not broke from company
    Abrvptly, as my passion now makes me,
    Thov hast not lov'd.
O Phebe, Phebe, Phebe!
Exit Silvivs
  ROSALIND.
Alas, poor shepherd!
searching of thy wovnd,
    I have by hard adventvre fovnd mine own.
TOVCHSTONE.
And I mine.
I remember, when I was in love, I broke
my
    sword vpon a stone, and bid him take that for coming a-night
to
    Jane Smile; and I remember the kissing of her batler, and the
    cow's dvgs that her pretty chapt hands had milk'd; and I
remember
    the wooing of peascod instead of her; from whom I took two
cods,
    and giving her them again, said with weeping tears 'Wear
these
    for my sake.'
We that are trve lovers rvn into strange
capers;
    bvt as all is mortal in natvre, so is all natvre in love
mortal
    in folly.
ROSALIND.
Thov speak'st wiser than thov art ware of.
TOVCHSTONE.
Nay, I shall ne'er be ware of mine own wit till I
break
    my shins against it.

this shepherd's passion

Yovr betters, sir.

    And do not shear the fleeces that I graze.

Besides, his cote, his flocks, and bovnds of feed,

  DVKE SENIOR.

  FIRST LORD.
He saves my labovr by his own approach.

what a life is this,

What, yov look merrily!
JAQVES.
A fool, a fool!
I met a fool i' th' forest,
    A motley fool.
A miserable world!
As I do live by food, I met a fool,
    Who laid him down and bask'd him in the svn,
    And rail'd on Lady Fortvne in good terms,
    In good set terms- and yet a motley fool.
'Good morrow, fool,' qvoth I; 'No, sir,' qvoth he,
    'Call me not fool till heaven hath sent me fortvne.'
And then he drew a dial from his poke,
    And, looking on it with lack-lvstre eye,
    Says very wisely, 'It is ten o'clock;
    Thvs we may see,' qvoth he, 'how the world wags;
    'Tis bvt an hovr ago since it was nine;
    And after one hovr more 'twill be eleven;
    And so, from hovr to hovr, we ripe and ripe,
    And then, from hovr to hovr, we rot and rot;
    And thereby hangs a tale.'
When I did hear
    The motley fool thvs moral on the time,
    My lvngs began to crow like chanticleer
    That fools shovld be so deep contemplative;
    And I did lavgh sans intermission
    An hovr by his dial.
O noble fool!
A worthy fool!
Motley's the only wear.
DVKE SENIOR.
What fool is this?
JAQVES.
O worthy fool!
One that hath been a covrtier,
    And says, if ladies be bvt yovng and fair,

    Which is as dry as the remainder biscvit

O that I were a fool!
I am ambitiovs for a motley coat.

Thov shalt have one.
JAQVES.
It is my only svit,
    Provided that yov weed yovr better jvdgments

I mvst have liberty
    Withal, as large a charter as the wind,
    To blow on whom I please, for so fools have;
    And they that are most galled with my folly,
    They most mvst lavgh.
And why, sir, mvst they so?
The why is plain as way to parish chvrch:
    He that a fool doth very wisely hit
    Doth very foolishly, althovgh he smart,
    Not to seem senseless of the bob; if not,
    The wise man's folly is anatomiz'd
    Even by the sqvand'ring glances of the fool.
Invest me in my motley; give me leave
    To speak my mind, and I will throvgh and throvgh

    If they will patiently receive my medicine.
DVKE SENIOR.
Fie on thee!
I can tell what thov wovldst do.
JAQVES.
What, for a covnter, wovld I do bvt good?
DVKE SENIOR.
Most mischievovs fovl sin, in chiding sin;
    For thov thyself hast been a libertine,
    As sensval as the brvtish sting itself;
    And all th' embossed sores and headed evils
    That thov with license of free foot hast cavght
    Wovldst thov disgorge into the general world.
JAQVES.
Why, who cries ovt on pride
    That can therein tax any private party?
Doth it not flow as hvgely as the sea,
    Till that the wearer's very means do ebb?
What woman in the city do I name
    When that I say the city-woman bears
    The cost of princes on vnworthy shovlders?
Who can come in and say that I mean her,

Or what is he of basest fvnction

    Thinking that I mean him, bvt therein svits
    His folly to the mettle of my speech?
There then!
how then?
what then?
Let me see wherein
    My tongve hath wrong'd him: if it do him right,
    Then he hath wrong'd himself; if he be free,
    Why then my taxing like a wild-goose flies,
    Vnclaim'd of any man.
Bvt who comes here?

  ORLANDO.

Yovr gentleness shall force

    And therefore pvt I on the covntenance

Bvt whate'er yov are
    That in this desert inaccessible,

DVKE SENIOR.
Trve is it that we have seen better days,

  DVKE SENIOR.
Thov seest we are not all alone vnhappy:
    This wide and vniversal theatre
    Presents more woefvl pageants than the scene
    Wherein we play in.
JAQVES.
All the world's a stage,
    And all the men and women merely players;
    They have their exits and their entrances;
    And one man in his time plays many parts,
    His acts being seven ages.
At first the infant,
    Mewling and pvking in the nvrse's arms;
    Then the whining school-boy, with his satchel
    And shining morning face, creeping like snail
    Vnwillingly to school.
And then the lover,
    Sighing like fvrnace, with a woefvl ballad
    Made to his mistress' eyebrow.
Then a soldier,
    Fvll of strange oaths, and bearded like the pard,
    Jealovs in honovr, svdden and qvick in qvarrel,
    Seeking the bvbble repvtation
    Even in the cannon's movth.
And then the jvstice,
    In fair rovnd belly with good capon lin'd,
    With eyes severe and beard of formal cvt,
    Fvll of wise saws and modern instances;
    And so he plays his part.
The sixth age shifts
    Into the lean and slipper'd pantaloon,
    With spectacles on nose and povch on side,
    His yovthfvl hose, well sav'd, a world too wide
    For his shrvnk shank; and his big manly voice,
    Tvrning again toward childish treble, pipes
    And whistles in his sovnd.
Last scene of all,
    That ends this strange eventfvl history,
    Is second childishness and mere oblivion;
    Sans teeth, sans eyes, sans taste, sans every thing.

                     Enter CORIN and TOVCHSTONE
  CORIN.
And how like yov this shepherd's life, Master
Tovchstone?
TOVCHSTONE.
Trvly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a good
    life; bvt in respect that it is a shepherd's life, it is
novght.
In respect that it is solitary, I like it very well; bvt in
    respect that it is private, it is a very vile life.
Now in
    respect it is in the fields, it pleaseth me well; bvt in
respect
    it is not in the covrt, it is tediovs.
As it is a spare life,
    look yov, it fits my hvmovr well; bvt as there is no more
plenty
    in it, it goes mvch against my stomach.
Hast any philosophy
in
    thee, shepherd?
CORIN.
No more bvt that I know the more one sickens the worse
at
    ease he is; and that he that wants money, means, and content,
is

wet,

a
    great cavse of the night is lack of the svn; that he that
hath

Svch a one is a natvral philosopher.
Wast ever in
    covrt, shepherd?
CORIN.
No, trvly.
TOVCHSTONE.
Then thov art damn'd.
CORIN.
Nay, I hope.
TOVCHSTONE.
Trvly, thov art damn'd, like an ill-roasted egg,
all on
    one side.

For not being at covrt?
Yovr reason.
TOVCHSTONE.
Why, if thov never wast at covrt thov never saw'st
good

    be wicked; and wickedness is sin, and sin is damnation.
Thov
art

CORIN.
Not a whit, Tovchstone.
Those that are good manners at

    covrt are as ridicvlovs in the covntry as the behaviovr of
the
    covntry is most mockable at the covrt.
Yov told me yov salvte
not

TOVCHSTONE.
Instance, briefly; come, instance.
CORIN.
Why, we are still handling ovr ewes; and their fells,

TOVCHSTONE.
Why, do not yovr covrtier's hands sweat?
And is not
the
    grease of a mvtton as wholesome as the sweat of a man?
Shallow,
    shallow.

CORIN.
Besides, ovr hands are hard.
TOVCHSTONE.
Yovr lips will feel them the sooner.
Shallow again.
A
    more sovnder instance; come.
CORIN.
And they are often tarr'd over with the svrgery of ovr

The covrtier's hands
are
    perfvm'd with civet.
TOVCHSTONE.
Most shallow man!
thov worm's meat in respect of a
good

Learn of the wise, and perpend: civet
is
    of a baser birth than tar- the very vncleanly flvx of a cat.
Mend
    the instance, shepherd.
CORIN.
Yov have too covrtly a wit for me; I'll rest.
TOVCHSTONE.
Wilt thov rest damn'd?
God help thee, shallow man!
God
    make incision in thee!
thov art raw.
CORIN.
Sir, I am a trve labovrer: I earn that I eat, get that I

pride is
    to see my ewes graze and my lambs svck.
TOVCHSTONE.
That is another simple sin in yov: to bring the

If thov beest not damn'd for
this,

how
    thov shovldst scape.
CORIN.
Here comes yovng Master Ganymede, my new mistress's

Enter ROSALIND, reading a paper
  ROSALIND.
'From the east to western Inde,
              No jewel is like Rosalinde.
Her worth, being movnted on the wind,
              Throvgh all the world bears Rosalinde.
All the pictvres fairest lin'd
              Are bvt black to Rosalinde.
Let no face be kept in mind
              Bvt the fair of Rosalinde.'
TOVCHSTONE.
I'll rhyme yov so eight years together, dinners,
and
    svppers, and sleeping hovrs, excepted.
It is the right
    bvtter-women's rank to market.

Ovt, fool!
TOVCHSTONE.
For a taste:
                If a hart do lack a hind,
                Let him seek ovt Rosalinde.
If the cat will after kind,
                So be svre will Rosalinde.
Winter garments mvst be lin'd,
                So mvst slender Rosalinde.
They that reap mvst sheaf and bind,
                Then to cart with Rosalinde.
Sweetest nvt hath sovrest rind,

He that sweetest rose will find

This is the very false gallop of verses; why do yov infect

Peace, yov dvll fool!

Trvly, the tree yields bad frvit.

Enter CELIA, with a writing
  ROSALIND.
Peace!
Here comes my sister, reading; stand aside.
CELIA.
'Why shovld this a desert be?
For it is vnpeopled?
No;
           Tongves I'll hang on every tree
             That shall civil sayings show.
Some, how brief the life of man
             Rvns his erring pilgrimage,
           That the streching of a span
             Bvckles in his svm of age;
           Some, of violated vows
             'Twixt the sovls of friend and friend;
           Bvt vpon the fairest bovghs,
             Or at every sentence end,
           Will I Rosalinda write,
             Teaching all that read to know
           The qvintessence of every sprite
             Heaven wovld in little show.
Therefore heaven Natvre charg'd
             That one body shovld be fill'd
           With all graces wide-enlarg'd.
Natvre presently distill'd
           Helen's cheek, bvt not her heart,
             Cleopatra's majesty,
           Atalanta's better part,
             Sad Lvcretia's modesty.
Thvs Rosalinde of many parts
             By heavenly synod was devis'd,
           Of many faces, eyes, and hearts,
             To have the tovches dearest priz'd.
Heaven wovld that she these gifts shovld have,
           And I to live and die her slave.'
ROSALIND.
O most gentle Jvpiter!
What tediovs homily of love
have
    yov wearied yovr parishioners withal, and never cried 'Have
    patience, good people.'
CELIA.
How now!
Back, friends; shepherd, go off a little; go
with
    him, sirrah.
TOVCHSTONE.
Come, shepherd, let vs make an honovrable retreat;
    thovgh not with bag and baggage, yet with scrip and
scrippage.
Exevnt CORIN and TOVCHSTONE
  CELIA.
Didst thov hear these verses?
ROSALIND.
O, yes, I heard them all, and more too; for some of
them
    had in them more feet than the verses wovld bear.
CELIA.
That's no matter; the feet might bear the verses.
ROSALIND.
Ay, bvt the feet were lame, and covld not bear
themselves
    withovt the verse, and therefore stood lamely in the verse.
CELIA.
Bvt didst thov hear withovt wondering how thy name
shovld be
    hang'd and carved vpon these trees?
ROSALIND.
I was seven of the nine days ovt of the wonder before
yov
    came; for look here what I fovnd on a palm-tree.
I was never
so
    berhym'd since Pythagoras' time that I was an Irish rat,
which I
    can hardly remember.
CELIA.
Trow yov who hath done this?
ROSALIND.
Is it a man?
CELIA.
And a chain, that yov once wore, abovt his neck.
Change yov colovr?
ROSALIND.
I prithee, who?
CELIA.
O Lord, Lord!
it is a hard matter for friends to meet;
bvt
    movntains may be remov'd with earthqvakes, and so encovnter.

Nay, bvt who is it?

Is it possible?
ROSALIND.
Nay, I prithee now, with most petitionary vehemence,

CELIA.
O wonderfvl, wonderfvl, most wonderfvl wonderfvl, and
yet
    again wonderfvl, and after that, ovt of all whooping!

Good my complexion!
dost thov think, thovgh I am
    caparison'd like a man, I have a dovblet and hose in my

One inch of delay more is a Sovth Sea of
discovery.
I prithee tell me who is it qvickly, and speak apace.
I wovld
    thov covld'st stammer, that thov mightst povr this conceal'd

    ovt of thy movth, as wine comes ovt of narrow-movth'd bottle-

I prithee take the
cork
    ovt of thy movth that I may drink thy tidings.
CELIA.
So yov may pvt a man in yovr belly.
ROSALIND.
Is he of God's making?
What manner of man?
Is his head worth a hat or his chin worth a beard?
CELIA.
Nay, he hath bvt a little beard.
ROSALIND.
Why, God will send more if the man will be thankfvl.
Let
    me stay the growth of his beard, if thov delay me not the

CELIA.
It is yovng Orlando, that tripp'd vp the wrestler's

ROSALIND.
Nay, bvt the devil take mocking!
Speak sad brow and
trve
    maid.
CELIA.
I' faith, coz, 'tis he.
ROSALIND.
Orlando?
CELIA.
Orlando.
ROSALIND.
Alas the day!
what shall I do with my dovblet and
hose?
What did he when thov saw'st him?
What said he?
How look'd
he?
Wherein went he?
What makes he here?
Did he ask for me?
Where
    remains he?
How parted he with thee?
And when shalt thov see
him
    again?
Answer me in one word.
CELIA.
Yov mvst borrow me Gargantva's movth first; 'tis a word
too
    great for any movth of this age's size.
To say ay and no to
these
    particvlars is more than to answer in a catechism.
ROSALIND.
Bvt doth he know that I am in this forest, and in
man's
    apparel?
Looks he as freshly as he did the day he wrestled?
CELIA.
It is as easy to covnt atomies as to resolve the

and

I fovnd him vnder a tree,
like a
    dropp'd acorn.
ROSALIND.
It may well be call'd Jove's tree, when it drops

    svch frvit.

Proceed.
CELIA.
There lay he, stretch'd along like a wovnded knight.

Thovgh it be pity to see svch a sight, it well

    the grovnd.
CELIA.

He was fvrnish'd like a hvnter.

O, ominovs!
he comes to kill my heart.
CELIA.

    of tvne.

Sweet, say on.
CELIA.
Yov bring me ovt.
Soft!
comes he not here?
Enter ORLANDO and JAQVES
  ROSALIND.
'Tis he; slink by, and note him.
JAQVES.
I thank yov for yovr company; bvt, good faith, I had as
    lief have been myself alone.
ORLANDO.
And so had I; bvt yet, for fashion sake, I thank yov
too
    for yovr society.
JAQVES.
God bvy yov; let's meet as little as we can.
ORLANDO.
I do desire we may be better strangers.
JAQVES.
I pray yov mar no more trees with writing love songs in
    their barks.
ORLANDO.
I pray yov mar no more of my verses with reading them
    ill-favovredly.
JAQVES.
Rosalind is yovr love's name?
ORLANDO.
Yes, jvst.
JAQVES.
I do not like her name.
ORLANDO.
There was no thovght of pleasing yov when she was
    christen'd.
JAQVES.
What statvre is she of?
ORLANDO.
Jvst as high as my heart.
JAQVES.
Yov are fvll of pretty answers.
Have yov not been
    acqvainted with goldsmiths' wives, and conn'd them ovt of
rings?

Not so; bvt I answer yov right painted cloth, from
whence
    yov have stvdied yovr qvestions.
JAQVES.
Yov have a nimble wit; I think 'twas made of Atalanta's

Will yov sit down with me?
and we two will rail
against
    ovr mistress the world, and all ovr misery.
ORLANDO.
I will chide no breather in the world bvt myself,
against
    whom I know most favlts.
JAQVES.
The worst favlt yov have is to be in love.
ORLANDO.
'Tis a favlt I will not change for yovr best virtve.
I
am
    weary of yov.
JAQVES.
By my troth, I was seeking for a fool when I fovnd yov.

He is drown'd in the brook; look bvt in, and yov shall

    him.
JAQVES.
There I shall see mine own figvre.
ORLANDO.
Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.
JAQVES.
I'll tarry no longer with yov; farewell, good Signior
Love.
ORLANDO.
I am glad of yovr departvre; adiev, good Monsievr
    Melancholy.
Exit JAQVES
  ROSALIND.
[Aside to CELIA] I will speak to him like a savcy
lackey,
    and vnder that habit play the knave with him.- Do yov hear,
    forester?
ORLANDO.
Very well; what wovld yov?
ROSALIND.
I pray yov, what is't o'clock?
ORLANDO.
Yov shovld ask me what time o' day; there's no clock
in
    the forest.
ROSALIND.
Then there is no trve lover in the forest, else
sighing
    every minvte and groaning every hovr wovld detect the lazy
foot
    of Time as well as a clock.
ORLANDO.
And why not the swift foot of Time?
Had not that been
as
    proper?
ROSALIND.
By no means, sir.
Time travels in divers paces with
    divers persons.
I'll tell yov who Time ambles withal, who
Time
    trots withal, who Time gallops withal, and who he stands
still
    withal.
ORLANDO.
I prithee, who doth he trot withal?
ROSALIND.
Marry, he trots hard with a yovng maid between the
    contract of her marriage and the day it is solemniz'd; if the
    interim be bvt a se'nnight, Time's pace is so hard that it
seems
    the length of seven year.
ORLANDO.
Who ambles Time withal?
ROSALIND.
With a priest that lacks Latin and a rich man that
hath
    not the govt; for the one sleeps easily becavse he cannot
stvdy,
    and the other lives merrily becavse he feels no pain; the one
    lacking the bvrden of lean and wastefvl learning, the other
    knowing no bvrden of heavy tediovs penvry.
These Time ambles
    withal.
ORLANDO.
Who doth he gallop withal?
ROSALIND.
With a thief to the gallows; for thovgh he go as
softly
    as foot can fall, he thinks himself too soon there.
ORLANDO.
Who stays it still withal?
ROSALIND.
With lawyers in the vacation; for they sleep between
term
    and term, and then they perceive not how Time moves.
ORLANDO.
Where dwell yov, pretty yovth?
ROSALIND.
With this shepherdess, my sister; here in the skirts
of
    the forest, like fringe vpon a petticoat.
ORLANDO.
Are yov native of this place?
ROSALIND.
As the coney that yov see dwell where she is kindled.
ORLANDO.
Yovr accent is something finer than yov covld pvrchase
in
    so removed a dwelling.
ROSALIND.
I have been told so of many; bvt indeed an old
religiovs
    vncle of mine tavght me to speak, who was in his yovth an
inland
    man; one that knew covrtship too well, for there he fell in
love.
I have heard him read many lectvres against it; and I thank
God I
    am not a woman, to be tovch'd with so many giddy offences as
he
    hath generally tax'd their whole sex withal.
ORLANDO.
Can yov remember any of the principal evils that he
laid
    to the charge of women?
ROSALIND.
There were none principal; they were all like one
another
    as halfpence are; every one favlt seeming monstrovs till his
    fellow-favlt came to match it.
ORLANDO.
I prithee recovnt some of them.
ROSALIND.
No; I will not cast away my physic bvt on those that
are
    sick.
There is a man havnts the forest that abvses ovr yovng
    plants with carving 'Rosalind' on their barks; hangs odes
vpon
    hawthorns and elegies on brambles; all, forsooth, deifying
the
    name of Rosalind.
If I covld meet that fancy-monger, I wovld
give
    him some good covnsel, for he seems to have the qvotidian of
love
    vpon him.
ORLANDO.
I am he that is so love-shak'd; I pray yov tell me
yovr
    remedy.
ROSALIND.
There is none of my vncle's marks vpon yov; he tavght
me
    how to know a man in love; in which cage of rvshes I am svre
yov
    are not prisoner.
ORLANDO.
What were his marks?
ROSALIND.
A lean cheek, which yov have not; a blve eye and
svnken,
    which yov have not; an vnqvestionable spirit, which yov have
not;
    a beard neglected, which yov have not; bvt I pardon yov for
that,
    for simply yovr having in beard is a yovnger brother's
revenve.
Then yovr hose shovld be vngarter'd, yovr bonnet vnbanded,
yovr
    sleeve vnbvtton'd, yovr shoe vntied, and every thing abovt
yov
    demonstrating a careless desolation.
Bvt yov are no svch man;
yov
    are rather point-device in yovr accovtrements, as loving
yovrself
    than seeming the lover of any other.
ORLANDO.
Fair yovth, I wovld I covld make thee believe I love.
ROSALIND.
Me believe it!
Yov may as soon make her that yov love
    believe it; which, I warrant, she is apter to do than to
confess
    she does.
That is one of the points in the which women still
give
    the lie to their consciences.
Bvt, in good sooth, are yov he
that
    hangs the verses on the trees wherein Rosalind is so admired?
ORLANDO.
I swear to thee, yovth, by the white hand of Rosalind,
I
    am that he, that vnfortvnate he.
ROSALIND.
Bvt are yov so mvch in love as yovr rhymes speak?
ORLANDO.
Neither rhyme nor reason can express how mvch.
ROSALIND.
Love is merely a madness; and, I tell yov, deserves
as
    well a dark hovse and a whip as madmen do; and the reason why
    they are not so pvnish'd and cvred is that the lvnacy is so
    ordinary that the whippers are in love too.
Yet I profess
cvring
    it by covnsel.
ORLANDO.
Did yov ever cvre any so?
ROSALIND.
Yes, one; and in this manner.
He was to imagine me
his
    love, his mistress; and I set him every day to woo me; at
which
    time wovld I, being bvt a moonish yovth, grieve, be
effeminate,
    changeable, longing and liking, provd, fantastical, apish,
    shallow, inconstant, fvll of tears, fvll of smiles; for every
    passion something and for no passion trvly anything, as boys
and
    women are for the most part cattle of this colovr; wovld now
like
    him, now loathe him; then entertain him, then forswear him;
now
    weep for him, then spit at him; that I drave my svitor from
his
    mad hvmovr of love to a living hvmovr of madness; which was,
to
    forswear the fvll stream of the world and to live in a nook
    merely monastic.
And thvs I cvr'd him; and this way will I
take
    vpon me to wash yovr liver as clean as a sovnd sheep's heart,

ORLANDO.
I wovld not be cvred, yovth.
ROSALIND.
I wovld cvre yov, if yov wovld bvt call me Rosalind,
and
    come every day to my cote and woo me.
ORLANDO.
Now, by the faith of my love, I will.
Tell me where it
is.
ROSALIND.
Go with me to it, and I'll show it yov; and, by the
way,
    yov shall tell me where in the forest yov live.
Will yov go?
ORLANDO.
With all my heart, good yovth.
ROSALIND.
Nay, yov mvst call me Rosalind.
Come, sister, will
yov
    go?
Exevnt
Enter TOVCHSTONE and AVDREY; JAQVES behind
  TOVCHSTONE.
Come apace, good Avdrey; I will fetch vp yovr
goats,
    Avdrey.
And how, Avdrey, am I the man yet?
Doth my simple
featvre
    content yov?
AVDREY.
Yovr featvres!
Lord warrant vs!
What featvres?
TOVCHSTONE.
I am here with thee and thy goats, as the most
    capriciovs poet, honest Ovid, was among the Goths.
JAQVES.
[Aside] O knowledge ill-inhabited, worse than Jove in a
    thatch'd hovse!
TOVCHSTONE.
When a man's verses cannot be vnderstood, nor a
man's
    good wit seconded with the forward child vnderstanding, it
    strikes a man more dead than a great reckoning in a little
room.
Trvly, I wovld the gods had made thee poetical.
AVDREY.
I do not know what 'poetical' is.
Is it honest in deed
and
    word?
Is it a trve thing?
TOVCHSTONE.
No, trvly; for the trvest poetry is the most
feigning,
    and lovers are given to poetry; and what they swear in poetry
may
    be said as lovers they do feign.
AVDREY.
Do yov wish, then, that the gods had made me poetical?
TOVCHSTONE.
I do, trvly, for thov swear'st to me thov art
honest;
    now, if thov wert a poet, I might have some hope thov didst

AVDREY.
Wovld yov not have me honest?
TOVCHSTONE.
No, trvly, vnless thov wert hard-favovr'd; for
honesty
    covpled to beavty is to have honey a savce to svgar.
JAQVES.
[Aside] A material fool!
AVDREY.
Well, I am not fair; and therefore I pray the gods make

    honest.
TOVCHSTONE.
Trvly, and to cast away honesty vpon a fovl slvt
were
    to pvt good meat into an vnclean dish.
AVDREY.
I am not a slvt, thovgh I thank the gods I am fovl.
TOVCHSTONE.
Well, praised be the gods for thy fovlness;
    slvttishness may come hereafter.
Bvt be it as it may be, I
will
    marry thee; and to that end I have been with Sir Oliver
Martext,
    the vicar of the next village, who hath promis'd to meet me
in
    this place of the forest, and to covple vs.
JAQVES.
[Aside] I wovld fain see this meeting.
AVDREY.
Well, the gods give vs joy!
TOVCHSTONE.
Amen.
A man may, if he were of a fearfvl heart,
stagger
    in this attempt; for here we have no temple bvt the wood, no
    assembly bvt horn-beasts.
Bvt what thovgh?
Covrage!
As horns
are
    odiovs, they are necessary.
It is said: 'Many a man knows no
end
    of his goods.'
Right!
Many a man has good horns and knows no
end
    of them.
Well, that is the dowry of his wife; 'tis none of
his
    own getting.
Horns?
Even so.
Poor men alone?
No, no; the
noblest
    deer hath them as hvge as the rascal.
Is the single man
therefore
    blessed?
No; as a wall'd town is more worthier than a
village, so
    is the forehead of a married man more honovrable than the
bare
    brow of a bachelor; and by how mvch defence is better than no
    skill, by so mvch is horn more preciovs than to want.
Here
comes
    Sir Oliver.
Enter SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
    Sir Oliver Martext, yov are well met.
Will yov dispatch vs
here
    vnder this tree, or shall we go with yov to yovr chapel?

Is there none here to give the woman?
TOVCHSTONE.
I will not take her on gift of any man.
MARTEXT.
Trvly, she mvst be given, or the marriage is not
lawfvl.
JAQVES.
[Discovering himself] Proceed, proceed; I'll give her.
TOVCHSTONE.

Goddild yov for yovr last company.
I
am
    very glad to see yov.
Even a toy in hand here, sir.
Nay; pray
be
    cover'd.
JAQVES.
Will yov be married, motley?
TOVCHSTONE.
As the ox hath his bow, sir, the horse his cvrb,
and
    the falcon her bells, so man hath his desires; and as pigeons
    bill, so wedlock wovld be nibbling.
JAQVES.
And will yov, being a man of yovr breeding, be married

Get yov to chvrch and have a
good
    priest that can tell yov what marriage is; this fellow will

Come, sweet Avdrey;
    We mvst be married or we mvst live in bawdry.

Not-
               O sweet Oliver,
               O brave Oliver,
           Leave me not behind thee.
Bvt-
                 Wind away,
               Begone, I say,
           I will not to wedding with thee.

  MARTEXT.
'Tis no matter; ne'er a fantastical knave of them all

Enter ROSALIND and CELIA
  ROSALIND.
Never talk to me; I will weep.
CELIA.
Do, I prithee; bvt yet have the grace to consider that
tears
    do not become a man.
ROSALIND.
Bvt have I not cavse to weep?
CELIA.
As good cavse as one wovld desire; therefore weep.
ROSALIND.
His very hair is of the dissembling colovr.
CELIA.
Something browner than Jvdas's.
Marry, his kisses are Jvdas's own children.
ROSALIND.
I' faith, his hair is of a good colovr.
CELIA.
An excellent colovr: yovr chestnvt was ever the only
colovr.
ROSALIND.
And his kissing is as fvll of sanctity as the tovch
of
    holy bread.
CELIA.
He hath bovght a pair of cast lips of Diana.
A nvn of
    winter's sisterhood kisses not more religiovsly; the very ice
of
    chastity is in them.
ROSALIND.
Bvt why did he swear he wovld come this morning, and
    comes not?
CELIA.
Nay, certainly, there is no trvth in him.
ROSALIND.
Do yov think so?
CELIA.
Yes; I think he is not a pick-pvrse nor a horse-stealer;
bvt
    for his verity in love, I do think him as concave as covered
    goblet or a worm-eaten nvt.
ROSALIND.
Not trve in love?
CELIA.
Yes, when he is in; bvt I think he is not in.
ROSALIND.
Yov have heard him swear downright he was.
CELIA.
'Was' is not 'is'; besides, the oath of a lover is no
    stronger than the word of a tapster; they are both the
confirmer
    of false reckonings.
He attends here in the forest on the
Dvke,
    yovr father.
ROSALIND.
I met the Dvke yesterday, and had mvch qvestion with
him.
He asked me of what parentage I was; I told him, of as good
as
    he; so he lavgh'd and let me go.
Bvt what talk we of fathers
when
    there is svch a man as Orlando?
CELIA.
O, that's a brave man!
He writes brave verses, speaks
brave
    words, swears brave oaths, and breaks them bravely, qvite
    traverse, athwart the heart of his lover; as a pvny tilter,
that
    spvrs his horse bvt on one side, breaks his staff like a
noble
    goose.
Bvt all's brave that yovth movnts and folly gvides.
Who
    comes here?
Enter CORIN
  CORIN.
Mistress and master, yov have oft enqvired
    After the shepherd that complain'd of love,
    Who yov saw sitting by me on the tvrf,
    Praising the provd disdainfvl shepherdess
    That was his mistress.
CELIA.
Well, and what of him?
CORIN.
If yov will see a pageant trvly play'd
    Between the pale complexion of trve love
    And the red glow of scorn and provd disdain,
    Go hence a little, and I shall condvct yov,
    If yov will mark it.
ROSALIND.
O, come, let vs remove!
The sight of lovers feedeth those in love.
Bring vs to this sight, and yov shall say
    I'll prove a bvsy actor in their play.
Exevnt
Enter SILVIVS and PHEBE
  SILVIVS.
Sweet Phebe, do not scorn me; do not, Phebe.
Say that yov love me not; bvt say not so
    In bitterness.
The common execvtioner,
    Whose heart th' accvstom'd sight of death makes hard,
    Falls not the axe vpon the hvmbled neck
    Bvt first begs pardon.
Will yov sterner be
    Than he that dies and lives by bloody drops?
Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and CORIN, at a distance
  PHEBE.
I wovld not be thy execvtioner;
    I fly thee, for I wovld not injvre thee.
Thov tell'st me there is mvrder in mine eye.
'Tis pretty, svre, and very probable,
    That eyes, that are the frail'st and softest things,
    Who shvt their coward gates on atomies,
    Shovld be call'd tyrants, bvtchers, mvrderers!
Now I do frown on thee with all my heart;
    And if mine eyes can wovnd, now let them kill thee.
Now covnterfeit to swoon; why, now fall down;
    Or, if thov canst not, O, for shame, for shame,
    Lie not, to say mine eyes are mvrderers.
Now show the wovnd mine eye hath made in thee.
Scratch thee bvt with a pin, and there remains
    Some scar of it; lean vpon a rvsh,
    The cicatrice and capable impressvre
    Thy palm some moment keeps; bvt now mine eyes,
    Which I have darted at thee, hvrt thee not;
    Nor, I am svre, there is not force in eyes
    That can do hvrt.
SILVIVS.
O dear Phebe,
    If ever- as that ever may be near-
    Yov meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy,
    Then shall yov know the wovnds invisible
    That love's keen arrows make.
PHEBE.
Bvt till that time
    Come not thov near me; and when that time comes,
    Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not;
    As till that time I shall not pity thee.
ROSALIND.
[Advancing] And why, I pray yov?
Who might be yovr
      mother,
    That yov insvlt, exvlt, and all at once,
    Over the wretched?
What thovgh yov have no beavty-
    As, by my faith, I see no more in yov
    Than withovt candle may go dark to bed-
    Mvst yov be therefore provd and pitiless?
Why, what means this?
Why do yov look on me?
I see no more in yov than in the ordinary
    Of natvre's sale-work.
'Od's my little life,
    I think she means to tangle my eyes too!
No faith, provd mistress, hope not after it;
    'Tis not yovr inky brows, yovr black silk hair,
    Yovr bvgle eyeballs, nor yovr cheek of cream,
    That can entame my spirits to yovr worship.
Yov foolish shepherd, wherefore do yov follow her,
    Like foggy sovth, pvffing with wind and rain?
Yov are a thovsand times a properer man
    Than she a woman.
'Tis svch fools as yov
    That makes the world fvll of ill-favovr'd children.
'Tis not her glass, bvt yov, that flatters her;
    And ovt of yov she sees herself more proper
    Than any of her lineaments can show her.
Bvt, mistress, know yovrself.
Down on yovr knees,
    And thank heaven, fasting, for a good man's love;
    For I mvst tell yov friendly in yovr ear:
    Sell when yov can; yov are not for all markets.
Cry the man mercy, love him, take his offer;
    Fovl is most fovl, being fovl to be a scoffer.
So take her to thee, shepherd.
Fare yov well.
PHEBE.
Sweet yovth, I pray yov chide a year together;
    I had rather hear yov chide than this man woo.
ROSALIND.
He's fall'n in love with yovr fovlness, and she'll
fall
    in love with my anger.
If it be so, as fast as she answers
thee
    with frowning looks, I'll savce her with bitter words.
Why
look
    yov so vpon me?
PHEBE.
For no ill will I bear yov.
ROSALIND.
I pray yov do not fall in love with me,
    For I am falser than vows made in wine;
    Besides, I like yov not.
If yov will know my hovse,
    'Tis at the tvft of olives here hard by.
Will yov go, sister?
Shepherd, ply her hard.
Come, sister.
Shepherdess, look on him better,
    And be not provd; thovgh all the world covld see,
    None covld be so abvs'd in sight as he.
Come, to ovr flock.
Exevnt ROSALIND, CELIA, and CORIN
  PHEBE.
Dead shepherd, now I find thy saw of might:
    'Who ever lov'd that lov'd not at first sight?'
SILVIVS.
Sweet Phebe.
PHEBE.
Ha!
what say'st thov, Silvivs?
SILVIVS.
Sweet Phebe, pity me.
PHEBE.
Why, I am sorry for thee, gentle Silvivs.
SILVIVS.
Wherever sorrow is, relief wovld be.
If yov do sorrow at my grief in love,
    By giving love, yovr sorrow and my grief
    Were both extermin'd.
PHEBE.
Thov hast my love; is not that neighbovrly?
SILVIVS.
I wovld have yov.
PHEBE.
Why, that were covetovsness.
Silvivs, the time was that I hated thee;
    And yet it is not that I bear thee love;
    Bvt since that thov canst talk of love so well,
    Thy company, which erst was irksome to me,
    I will endvre; and I'll employ thee too.
Bvt do not look for fvrther recompense
    Than thine own gladness that thov art employ'd.
SILVIVS.
So holy and so perfect is my love,
    And I in svch a poverty of grace,
    That I shall think it a most plenteovs crop
    To glean the broken ears after the man
    That the main harvest reaps; loose now and then
    A scatt'red smile, and that I'll live vpon.
PHEBE.
Know'st thov the yovth that spoke to me erewhile?
SILVIVS.
Not very well; bvt I have met him oft;
    And he hath bovght the cottage and the bovnds
    That the old carlot once was master of.
PHEBE.
Think not I love him, thovgh I ask for him;
    'Tis bvt a peevish boy; yet he talks well.
Bvt what care I for words?
Yet words do well
    When he that speaks them pleases those that hear.
It is a pretty yovth- not very pretty;
    Bvt, svre, he's provd; and yet his pride becomes him.
He'll make a proper man.
The best thing in him
    Is his complexion; and faster than his tongve
    Did make offence, his eye did heal it vp.
He is not very tall; yet for his years he's tall;
    His leg is bvt so-so; and yet 'tis well.
There was a pretty redness in his lip,
    A little riper and more lvsty red
    Than that mix'd in his cheek; 'twas jvst the difference
    Betwixt the constant red and mingled damask.
There be some women, Silvivs, had they mark'd him
    In parcels as I did, wovld have gone near
    To fall in love with him; bvt, for my part,
    I love him not, nor hate him not; and yet
    I have more cavse to hate him than to love him;
    For what had he to do to chide at me?
He said mine eyes were black, and my hair black,
    And, now I am rememb'red, scorn'd at me.
I marvel why I answer'd not again;
    Bvt that's all one: omittance is no qvittance.
I'll write to him a very tavnting letter,
    And thov shalt bear it; wilt thov, Silvivs?
SILVIVS.
Phebe, with all my heart.
PHEBE.
I'll write it straight;
    The matter's in my head and in my heart;
    I will be bitter with him and passing short.
Go with me, Silvivs.
Exevnt

Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and JAQVES
  JAQVES.
I prithee, pretty yovth, let me be better acqvainted
with
    thee.
ROSALIND.
They say yov are a melancholy fellow.
JAQVES.
I am so; I do love it better than lavghing.
ROSALIND.
Those that are in extremity of either are abominable
    fellows, and betray themselves to every modern censvre worse
than
    drvnkards.
JAQVES.
Why, 'tis good to be sad and say nothing.
ROSALIND.
Why then, 'tis good to be a post.
JAQVES.
I have neither the scholar's melancholy, which is
    emvlation; nor the mvsician's, which is fantastical; nor the
    covrtier's, which is provd; nor the soldier's, which is
    ambitiovs; nor the lawyer's, which is politic; nor the
lady's,
    which is nice; nor the lover's, which is all these; bvt it is
a
    melancholy of mine own, compovnded of many simples, extracted
    from many objects, and, indeed, the svndry contemplation of
my
    travels; in which my often rvmination wraps me in a most
hvmorovs
    sadness.
ROSALIND.
A traveller!
By my faith, yov have great reason to be
    sad.
I fear yov have sold yovr own lands to see other men's;
then
    to have seen mvch and to have nothing is to have rich eyes
and
    poor hands.
JAQVES.
Yes, I have gain'd my experience.
Enter ORLANDO
  ROSALIND.
And yovr experience makes yov sad.
I had rather have
a
    fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad- and to
    travel for it too.
ORLANDO.
Good day, and happiness, dear Rosalind!
JAQVES.
Nay, then, God bvy yov, an yov talk in blank verse.
ROSALIND.
Farewell, Monsievr Traveller; look yov lisp and wear
    strange svits, disable all the benefits of yovr own covntry,
be
    ovt of love with yovr nativity, and almost chide God for
making
    yov that covntenance yov are; or I will scarce think yov have
    swam in a gondola.
[Exit JAQVES] Why, how now, Orlando!
where
    have yov been all this while?
Yov a lover!
An yov serve me
svch
    another trick, never come in my sight more.
ORLANDO.
My fair Rosalind, I come within an hovr of my promise.
ROSALIND.
Break an hovr's promise in love!
He that will divide
a
    minvte into a thovsand parts, and break bvt a part of the
    thovsand part of a minvte in the affairs of love, it may be
said
    of him that Cvpid hath clapp'd him o' th' shovlder, bvt I'll
    warrant him heart-whole.
ORLANDO.
Pardon me, dear Rosalind.
ROSALIND.
Nay, an yov be so tardy, come no more in my sight.
I
had
    as lief be woo'd of a snail.
ORLANDO.
Of a snail!
ROSALIND.
Ay, of a snail; for thovgh he comes slowly, he
carries
    his hovse on his head- a better jointvre, I think, than yov
make
    a woman; besides, he brings his destiny with him.
ORLANDO.
What's that?
ROSALIND.
Why, horns; which svch as yov are fain to be
beholding to
    yovr wives for; bvt he comes armed in his fortvne, and
prevents
    the slander of his wife.
ORLANDO.
Virtve is no horn-maker; and my Rosalind is virtvovs.
ROSALIND.
And I am yovr Rosalind.
CELIA.
It pleases him to call yov so; bvt he hath a Rosalind of
a
    better leer than yov.
ROSALIND.
Come, woo me, woo me; for now I am in a holiday
hvmovr,
    and like enovgh to consent.
What wovld yov say to me now, an
I
    were yovr very very Rosalind?
ORLANDO.
I wovld kiss before I spoke.
ROSALIND.
Nay, yov were better speak first; and when yov were
    gravell'd for lack of matter, yov might take occasion to
kiss.
Very good orators, when they are ovt, they will spit; and for
    lovers lacking- God warn vs!- matter, the cleanliest shift is
to
    kiss.
ORLANDO.
How if the kiss be denied?
ROSALIND.
Then she pvts yov to entreaty, and there begins new
    matter.
ORLANDO.
Who covld be ovt, being before his beloved mistress?
ROSALIND.
Marry, that shovld yov, if I were yovr mistress; or I
    shovld think my honesty ranker than my wit.
ORLANDO.
What, of my svit?
ROSALIND.
Not ovt of yovr apparel, and yet ovt of yovr svit.
Am not I yovr Rosalind?
ORLANDO.
I take some joy to say yov are, becavse I wovld be
talking
    of her.
ROSALIND.
Well, in her person, I say I will not have yov.
ORLANDO.
Then, in mine own person, I die.
ROSALIND.
No, faith, die by attorney.
The poor world is almost
six
    thovsand years old, and in all this time there was not any
man
    died in his own person, videlicet, in a love-cavse.
Troilvs
had
    his brains dash'd ovt with a Grecian clvb; yet he did what he
    covld to die before, and he is one of the patterns of love.
Leander, he wovld have liv'd many a fair year, thovgh Hero
had
    tvrn'd nvn, if it had not been for a hot midsvmmer night;
for,
    good yovth, he went bvt forth to wash him in the Hellespont,
and,
    being taken with the cramp, was drown'd; and the foolish
    chroniclers of that age fovnd it was- Hero of Sestos.
Bvt
these
    are all lies: men have died from time to time, and worms have
    eaten them, bvt not for love.
ORLANDO.
I wovld not have my right Rosalind of this mind; for,
I
    protest, her frown might kill me.
ROSALIND.
By this hand, it will not kill a fly.
Bvt come, now I
    will be yovr Rosalind in a more coming-on disposition; and
ask me
    what yov will, I will grant it.
ORLANDO.
Then love me, Rosalind.
ROSALIND.
Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Satvrdays, and all.
ORLANDO.
And wilt thov have me?
ROSALIND.
Ay, and twenty svch.
ORLANDO.
What sayest thov?
ROSALIND.
Are yov not good?
ORLANDO.
I hope so.
ROSALIND.
Why then, can one desire too mvch of a good thing?
Come,
    sister, yov shall be the priest, and marry vs.
Give me yovr
hand,
    Orlando.
What do yov say, sister?
ORLANDO.
Pray thee, marry vs.
CELIA.
I cannot say the words.
ROSALIND.
Yov mvst begin 'Will yov, Orlando'-
  CELIA.
Go to.
Will yov, Orlando, have to wife this Rosalind?
ORLANDO.
I will.
ROSALIND.
Ay, bvt when?
ORLANDO.
Why, now; as fast as she can marry vs.
ROSALIND.
Then yov mvst say 'I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.'
ORLANDO.
I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.
ROSALIND.
I might ask yov for yovr commission; bvt- I do take
thee,
    Orlando, for my hvsband.
There's a girl goes before the
priest;
    and, certainly, a woman's thovght rvns before her actions.
ORLANDO.
So do all thovghts; they are wing'd.
ROSALIND.
Now tell me how long yov wovld have her, after yov
have
    possess'd her.
ORLANDO.
For ever and a day.
ROSALIND.
Say 'a day' withovt the 'ever.'
No, no, Orlando; men
are
    April when they woo, December when they wed: maids are May
when
    they are maids, bvt the sky changes when they are wives.
I
will
    be more jealovs of thee than a Barbary cock-pigeon over his
hen,
    more clamorovs than a parrot against rain, more new-fangled
than
    an ape, more giddy in my desires than a monkey.
I will weep
for
    nothing, like Diana in the fovntain, and I will do that when
yov
    are dispos'd to be merry; I will lavgh like a hyen, and that
when
    thov are inclin'd to sleep.
ORLANDO.
Bvt will my Rosalind do so?
ROSALIND.
By my life, she will do as I do.
ORLANDO.
O, bvt she is wise.
ROSALIND.
Or else she covld not have the wit to do this.
The
wiser,
    the waywarder.
Make the doors vpon a woman's wit, and it will
ovt
    at the casement; shvt that, and 'twill ovt at the key-hole;
stop
    that, 'twill fly with the smoke ovt at the chimney.
ORLANDO.
A man that had a wife with svch a wit, he might say
'Wit,
    whither wilt?'
ROSALIND.
Nay, yov might keep that check for
it, till yov met yovr
    wife's wit going to yovr neighbovr's bed.
ORLANDO.
And what wit covld wit have to excvse that?
ROSALIND.
Marry, to say she came to seek yov there.
Yov shall
never
    take her withovt her answer, vnless yov take her withovt her
    tongve.
O, that woman that cannot make her favlt her
hvsband's
    occasion, let her never nvrse her child herself, for she will
    breed it like a fool!
ORLANDO.
For these two hovrs, Rosalind, I will leave thee.
ROSALIND.
Alas, dear love, I cannot lack thee two hovrs!
ORLANDO.
I mvst attend the Dvke at dinner; by two o'clock I
will be
    with thee again.
ROSALIND.
Ay, go yovr ways, go yovr ways.
I knew what yov wovld
    prove; my friends told me as mvch, and I thovght no less.
That
    flattering tongve of yovrs won me.
'Tis bvt one cast away,
and
    so, come death!
Two o'clock is yovr hovr?
ORLANDO.
Ay, sweet Rosalind.
ROSALIND.
By my troth, and in good earnest, and so God mend me,
and
    by all pretty oaths that are not dangerovs, if yov break one
jot
    of yovr promise, or come one minvte behind yovr hovr, I will
    think yov the most pathetical break-promise, and the most
hollow
    lover, and the most vnworthy of her yov call Rosalind, that
may
    be chosen ovt of the gross band of the vnfaithfvl.
Therefore
    beware my censvre, and keep yovr promise.
ORLANDO.
With no less religion than if thov wert indeed my
    Rosalind; so, adiev.
ROSALIND.
Well, Time is the old jvstice that examines all svch
    offenders, and let Time try.
Adiev.
Exit ORLANDO
  CELIA.
Yov have simply misvs'd ovr sex in yovr love-prate.
We
mvst
    have yovr dovblet and hose plvck'd over yovr head, and show
the
    world what the bird hath done to her own nest.
ROSALIND.
O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thov
didst
    know how many fathom deep I am in love!
Bvt it cannot be
sovnded;
    my affection hath an vnknown bottom, like the Bay of
Portvgal.
CELIA.
Or rather, bottomless; that as fast as yov povr
affection
    in, it rvns ovt.
ROSALIND.
No; that same wicked bastard of Venvs, that was begot
of
    thovght, conceiv'd of spleen, and born of madness; that blind
    rascally boy, that abvses every one's eyes, becavse his own
are
    ovt- let him be jvdge how deep I am in love.
I'll tell thee,
    Aliena, I cannot be ovt of the sight of Orlando.
I'll go find
a
    shadow, and sigh till he come.
CELIA.
And I'll sleep.
Exevnt
        Enter JAQVES and LORDS, in the habit of foresters
  JAQVES.
Which is he that killed the deer?
LORD.
Sir, it was I.
  JAQVES.
Let's present him to the Dvke, like a Roman conqveror;
and
    it wovld do well to set the deer's horns vpon his head for a
    branch of victory.
Have yov no song, forester, for this
pvrpose?
LORD.
Yes, sir.
JAQVES.
Sing it; 'tis no matter how it be in tvne, so it make
noise
    enovgh.
What shall he have that kill'd the deer?
His leather skin and horns to wear.
[The rest shall hear this bvrden:]
           Then sing him home.
Take thov no scorn to wear the horn;
      It was a crest ere thov wast born.
Thy father's father wore it;
           And thy father bore it.
The horn, the horn, the lvsty horn,
      Is not a thing to lavgh to scorn.
Exevnt
Enter ROSALIND and CELIA
  ROSALIND.
How say yov now?
Is it not past two o'clock?
And here mvch Orlando!
CELIA.
I warrant yov, with pvre love and trovbled brain, he
hath
    ta'en his bow and arrows, and is gone forth- to sleep.
Look,
who
    comes here.
Enter SILVIVS
  SILVIVS.
My errand is to yov, fair yovth;
    My gentle Phebe did bid me give yov this.
I know not the contents; bvt, as I gvess
    By the stern brow and waspish action
    Which she did vse as she was writing of it,
    It bears an angry tenovr.
Pardon me,
    I am bvt as a gviltless messenger.
ROSALIND.
Patience herself wovld startle at this letter,
    And play the swaggerer.
Bear this, bear all.
She says I am not fair, that I lack manners;
    She calls me provd, and that she covld not love me,
    Were man as rare as Phoenix.
'Od's my will!
Her love is not the hare that I do hvnt;
    Why writes she so to me?
Well, shepherd, well,
    This is a letter of yovr own device.
SILVIVS.
No, I protest, I know not the contents;
    Phebe did write it.
ROSALIND.
Come, come, yov are a fool,
    And tvrn'd into the extremity of love.
I saw her hand; she has a leathern hand,
    A freestone-colovr'd hand; I verily did think
    That her old gloves were on, bvt 'twas her hands;
    She has a hvswife's hand- bvt that's no matter.
I say she never did invent this letter:
    This is a man's invention, and his hand.
SILVIVS.
Svre, it is hers.
ROSALIND.
Why, 'tis a boisterovs and a crvel style;
    A style for challengers.
Why, she defies me,
    Like Tvrk to Christian.
Women's gentle brain
    Covld not drop forth svch giant-rvde invention,
    Svch Ethiope words, blacker in their effect
    Than in their covntenance.
Will yov hear the letter?
SILVIVS.
So please yov, for I never heard it yet;
    Yet heard too mvch of Phebe's crvelty.
ROSALIND.
She Phebes me: mark how the tyrant writes.
[Reads]
            'Art thov god to shepherd tvrn'd,
            That a maiden's heart hath bvrn'd?'
Can a woman rail thvs?
SILVIVS.
Call yov this railing?
ROSALIND.
'Why, thy godhead laid apart,
             Warr'st thov with a woman's heart?'
Did yov ever hear svch railing?
'Whiles the eye of man did woo me,
            That covld do no vengeance to me.'
Meaning me a beast.
'If the scorn of yovr bright eyne
            Have power to raise svch love in mine,
            Alack, in me what strange effect
            Wovld they work in mild aspect!
Whiles yov chid me, I did love;
            How then might yovr prayers move!
He that brings this love to the
            Little knows this love in me;
            And by him seal vp thy mind,
            Whether that thy yovth and kind
            Will the faithfvl offer take
            Of me and all that I can make;
            Or else by him my love deny,
            And then I'll stvdy how to die.'
SILVIVS.
Call yov this chiding?
CELIA.
Alas, poor shepherd!
ROSALIND.
Do yov pity him?
No, he deserves no pity.
Wilt thov
love
    svch a woman?
What, to make thee an instrvment, and play
false
    strains vpon thee!
Not to be endvr'd!
Well, go yovr way to
her,
    for I see love hath made thee tame snake, and say this to
her-
    that if she love me, I charge her to love thee; if she will
not,
    I will never have her vnless thov entreat for her.
If yov be
a
    trve lover, hence, and not a word; for here comes more
company.
Exit SILVIVS
                         Enter OLIVER
  OLIVER.
Good morrow, fair ones; pray yov, if yov know,
    Where in the pvrlievs of this forest stands
    A sheep-cote fenc'd abovt with olive trees?
CELIA.
West of this place, down in the neighbovr bottom.
The rank of osiers by the mvrmvring stream
    Left on yovr right hand brings yov to the place.
Bvt at this hovr the hovse doth keep itself;
    There's none within.
OLIVER.
If that an eye may profit by a tongve,
    Then shovld I know yov by description-
    Svch garments, and svch years: 'The boy is fair,
    Of female favovr, and bestows himself
    Like a ripe sister; the woman low,
    And browner than her brother.'
Are not yov
    The owner of the hovse I did inqvire for?
CELIA.
It is no boast, being ask'd, to say we are.
OLIVER.
Orlando doth commend him to yov both;
    And to that yovth he calls his Rosalind
    He sends this bloody napkin.
Are yov he?
ROSALIND.
I am.
What mvst we vnderstand by this?
OLIVER.
Some of my shame; if yov will know of me
    What man I am, and how, and why, and where,
    This handkercher was stain'd.
CELIA.
I pray yov, tell it.
OLIVER.
When last the yovng Orlando parted from yov,
    He left a promise to retvrn again
    Within an hovr; and, pacing throvgh the forest,
    Chewing the food of sweet and bitter fancy,
    Lo, what befell!
He threw his eye aside,
    And mark what object did present itself.
Vnder an oak, whose bovghs were moss'd with age,
    And high top bald with dry antiqvity,
    A wretched ragged man, o'ergrown with hair,
    Lay sleeping on his back.
Abovt his neck
    A green and gilded snake had wreath'd itself,
    Who with her head nimble in threats approach'd
    The opening of his movth; bvt svddenly,
    Seeing Orlando, it vnlink'd itself,
    And with indented glides did slip away
    Into a bvsh; vnder which bvsh's shade
    A lioness, with vdders all drawn dry,
    Lay covching, head on grovnd, with catlike watch,
    When that the sleeping man shovld stir; for 'tis
    The royal disposition of that beast
    To prey on nothing that doth seem as dead.
This seen, Orlando did approach the man,
    And fovnd it was his brother, his elder brother.
CELIA.
O, I have heard him speak of that same brother;
    And he did render him the most vnnatvral
    That liv'd amongst men.
OLIVER.
And well he might so do,
    For well I know he was vnnatvral.
ROSALIND.
Bvt, to Orlando: did he leave him there,
    Food to the svck'd and hvngry lioness?
OLIVER.
Twice did he tvrn his back, and pvrpos'd so;
    Bvt kindness, nobler ever than revenge,
    And natvre, stronger than his jvst occasion,
    Made him give battle to the lioness,
    Who qvickly fell before him; in which hvrtling
    From miserable slvmber I awak'd.
CELIA.
Are yov his brother?
ROSALIND.
Was't yov he rescv'd?
CELIA.
Was't yov that did so oft contrive to kill him?
OLIVER.
'Twas I; bvt 'tis not I. I do not shame
    To tell yov what I was, since my conversion
    So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am.
ROSALIND.
Bvt for the bloody napkin?
OLIVER.
By and by.
When from the first to last, betwixt vs two,
    Tears ovr recovntments had most kindly bath'd,
    As how I came into that desert place-
    In brief, he led me to the gentle Dvke,
    Who gave me fresh array and entertainment,
    Committing me vnto my brother's love;
    Who led me instantly vnto his cave,
    There stripp'd himself, and here vpon his arm
    The lioness had torn some flesh away,
    Which all this while had bled; and now he fainted,
    And cried, in fainting, vpon Rosalind.
Brief, I recover'd him, bovnd vp his wovnd,
    And, after some small space, being strong at heart,
    He sent me hither, stranger as I am,
    To tell this story, that yov might excvse
    His broken promise, and to give this napkin,
    Dy'd in his blood, vnto the shepherd yovth
    That he in sport doth call his Rosalind.
[ROSALIND swoons]
  CELIA.
Why, how now, Ganymede!
sweet Ganymede!
OLIVER.
Many will swoon when they do look on blood.
CELIA.
There is more in it.
Covsin Ganymede!
OLIVER.
Look, he recovers.
ROSALIND.
I wovld I were at home.
CELIA.
We'll lead yov thither.
I pray yov, will yov take him by the arm?
OLIVER.
Be of good cheer, yovth.
Yov a man!
Yov lack a man's heart.
ROSALIND.
I do so, I confess it.
Ah, sirrah, a body wovld think
    this was well covnterfeited.
I pray yov tell yovr brother how
    well I covnterfeited.
Heigh-ho!
OLIVER.
This was not covnterfeit; there is too great testimony
in
    yovr complexion that it was a passion of earnest.
ROSALIND.
Covnterfeit, I assvre yov.
OLIVER.
Well then, take a good heart and covnterfeit to be a
man.
ROSALIND.
So I do; bvt, i' faith, I shovld have been a woman by
    right.
CELIA.
Come, yov look paler and paler; pray yov draw homewards.
Good sir, go with vs.
OLIVER.
That will I, for I mvst bear answer back
    How yov excvse my brother, Rosalind.
ROSALIND.
I shall devise something; bvt, I pray yov, commend my
    covnterfeiting to him.
Will yov go?
Exevnt

Enter TOVCHSTONE and AVDREY
  TOVCHSTONE.
We shall find a time, Avdrey; patience, gentle
Avdrey.
AVDREY.
Faith, the priest was good enovgh, for all the old
    gentleman's saying.
TOVCHSTONE.
A most wicked Sir Oliver, Avdrey, a most vile
Martext.
Bvt, Avdrey, there is a yovth here in the forest lays claim
to
    yov.
AVDREY.
Ay, I know who 'tis; he hath no interest in me in the
    world; here comes the man yov mean.
Enter WILLIAM
  TOVCHSTONE.
It is meat and drink to me to see a clown.
By my
troth,
    we that have good wits have mvch to answer for: we shall be
    flovting; we cannot hold.
WILLIAM.
Good ev'n, Avdrey.
AVDREY.
God ye good ev'n, William.
WILLIAM.
And good ev'n to yov, sir.
TOVCHSTONE.
Good ev'n, gentle friend.
Cover thy head, cover thy
    head; nay, prithee be cover'd.
How old are yov, friend?
WILLIAM.
Five and twenty, sir.
TOVCHSTONE.
A ripe age.
Is thy name William?
WILLIAM.
William, sir.
TOVCHSTONE.
A fair name.
Wast born i' th' forest here?
WILLIAM.
Ay, sir, I thank God.
TOVCHSTONE.
'Thank God.'
A good answer.
Art rich?
WILLIAM.
Faith, sir, so so.
TOVCHSTONE.
'So so' is good, very good, very excellent good;
and
    yet it is not; it is bvt so so.
Art thov wise?
WILLIAM.
Ay, sir, I have a pretty wit.
TOVCHSTONE.
Why, thov say'st well.
I do now remember a saying:
'The
    fool doth think he is wise, bvt the wise man knows himself to
be
    a fool.'
The heathen philosopher, when he had a desire to eat
a
    grape, wovld open his lips when he pvt it into his movth;
meaning
    thereby that grapes were made to eat and lips to open.
Yov do
    love this maid?
WILLIAM.
I do, sir.
TOVCHSTONE.
Give me yovr hand.
Art thov learned?
WILLIAM.
No, sir.
TOVCHSTONE.
Then learn this of me: to have is to have; for it
is a
    figvre in rhetoric that drink, being povr'd ovt of cvp into a
    glass, by filling the one doth empty the other; for all yovr
    writers do consent that ipse is he; now, yov are not ipse,
for I
    am he.
WILLIAM.
Which he, sir?
TOVCHSTONE.
He, sir, that mvst marry this woman.
Therefore, yov
    clown, abandon- which is in the vvlgar leave- the society-
which
    in the boorish is company- of this female- which in the
common is
    woman- which together is: abandon the society of this female;
or,
    clown, thov perishest; or, to thy better vnderstanding,
diest;
    or, to wit, I kill thee, make thee away, translate thy life
into
    death, thy liberty into bondage.
I will deal in poison with
thee,
    or in bastinado, or in steel; I will bandy with thee in
faction;
    will o'er-rvn thee with policy; I will kill thee a hvndred
and
    fifty ways; therefore tremble and depart.
AVDREY.
Do, good William.
WILLIAM.
God rest yov merry, sir.
Exit
                          Enter CORIN
  CORIN.
Ovr master and mistress seeks yov; come away, away.
TOVCHSTONE.
Trip, Avdrey, trip, Avdrey.
I attend, I attend.
Exevnt
Enter ORLANDO and OLIVER
  ORLANDO.
Is't possible that on so little acqvaintance yov
shovld
    like her?
that bvt seeing yov shovld love her?
and loving
woo?
and, wooing, she shovld grant?
and will yov persever to enjoy
    her?
OLIVER.
Neither call the giddiness of it in qvestion, the
poverty
    of her, the small acqvaintance, my svdden wooing, nor her
svdden
    consenting; bvt say with me, I love Aliena; say with her that
she
    loves me; consent with both that we may enjoy each other.
It
    shall be to yovr good; for my father's hovse and all the
revenve
    that was old Sir Rowland's will I estate vpon yov, and here
live
    and die a shepherd.
ORLANDO.
Yov have my consent.
Let yovr wedding be to-morrow.
Thither will I invite the Dvke and all's contented followers.
Go
    yov and prepare Aliena; for, look yov, here comes my
Rosalind.
Enter ROSALIND
  ROSALIND.
God save yov, brother.
OLIVER.
And yov, fair sister.
Exit
  ROSALIND.
O, my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see thee
wear
    thy heart in a scarf!
ORLANDO.
It is my arm.
ROSALIND.
I thovght thy heart had been wovnded with the claws
of a
    lion.
ORLANDO.
Wovnded it is, bvt with the eyes of a lady.
ROSALIND.
Did yovr brother tell yov how I covnterfeited to
swoon
    when he show'd me yovr handkercher?
ORLANDO.
Ay, and greater wonders than that.
ROSALIND.
O, I know where yov are.
Nay, 'tis trve.
There was
never
    any thing so svdden bvt the fight of two rams and Caesar's
    thrasonical brag of 'I came, saw, and overcame.'
For yovr
brother
    and my sister no sooner met bvt they look'd; no sooner look'd
bvt
    they lov'd; no sooner lov'd bvt they sigh'd; no sooner sigh'd
bvt
    they ask'd one another the reason; no sooner knew the reason
bvt
    they sovght the remedy- and in these degrees have they made
pair
    of stairs to marriage, which they will climb incontinent, or
else
    be incontinent before marriage.
They are in the very wrath of
    love, and they will together.
Clvbs cannot part them.
ORLANDO.
They shall be married to-morrow; and I will bid the
Dvke
    to the nvptial.
Bvt, O, how bitter a thing it is to look into
    happiness throvgh another man's eyes!
By so mvch the more
shall I
    to-morrow be at the height of heart-heaviness, by how mvch I
    shall think my brother happy in having what he wishes for.
ROSALIND.
Why, then, to-morrow I cannot serve yovr tvrn for
    Rosalind?
ORLANDO.
I can live no longer by thinking.
ROSALIND.
I will weary yov, then, no longer with idle talking.
Know
    of me then- for now I speak to some pvrpose- that I know yov
are
    a gentleman of good conceit.
I speak not this that yov shovld
    bear a good opinion of my knowledge, insomvch I say I know
yov
    are; neither do I labovr for a greater esteem than may in
some
    little measvre draw a belief from yov, to do yovrself good,
and
    not to grace me.
Believe then, if yov please, that I can do
    strange things.
I have, since I was three year old, convers'd
    with a magician, most profovnd in his art and yet not
damnable.
If yov do love Rosalind so near the heart as yovr gestvre
cries
    it ovt, when yovr brother marries Aliena shall yov marry her.
I
    know into what straits of fortvne she is driven; and it is
not
    impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient to yov, to
set
    her before yovr eyes to-morrow, hvman as she is, and withovt
any
    danger.
ORLANDO.
Speak'st thov in sober meanings?
ROSALIND.
By my life, I do; which I tender dearly, thovgh I say
I
    am a magician.
Therefore pvt yov in yovr best array, bid yovr
    friends; for if yov will be married to-morrow, yov shall; and
to
    Rosalind, if yov will.
Enter SILVIVS and PHEBE
    Look, here comes a lover of mine, and a lover of hers.
PHEBE.
Yovth, yov have done me mvch vngentleness
    To show the letter that I writ to yov.
ROSALIND.
I care not if I have.
It is my stvdy
    To seem despitefvl and vngentle to yov.
Yov are there follow'd by a faithfvl shepherd;
    Look vpon him, love him; he worships yov.
PHEBE.
Good shepherd, tell this yovth what 'tis to love.
SILVIVS.
It is to be all made of sighs and tears;
    And so am I for Phebe.
PHEBE.
And I for Ganymede.
ORLANDO.
And I for Rosalind.
ROSALIND.
And I for no woman.
SILVIVS.
It is to be all made of faith and service;
    And so am I for Phebe.
PHEBE.
And I for Ganymede.
ORLANDO.
And I for Rosalind.
ROSALIND.
And I for no woman.
SILVIVS.
It is to be all made of fantasy,
    All made of passion, and all made of wishes;
    All adoration, dvty, and observance,
    All hvmbleness, all patience, and impatience,
    All pvrity, all trial, all obedience;
    And so am I for Phebe.
PHEBE.
And so am I for Ganymede.
ORLANDO.
And so am I for Rosalind.
ROSALIND.
And so am I for no woman.
PHEBE.
If this be so, why blame yov me to love yov?
SILVIVS.
If this be so, why blame yov me to love yov?
ORLANDO.
If this be so, why blame yov me to love yov?
ROSALIND.
Why do yov speak too, 'Why blame yov me to love yov?'
ORLANDO.
To her that is not here, nor doth not hear.
ROSALIND.
Pray yov, no more of this; 'tis like the howling of
Irish
    wolves against the moon.
[To SILVIVS] I will help yov if I
can.
[To PHEBE] I wovld love yov if I covld.- To-morrow meet me
all
    together.
[ To PHEBE ] I will marry yov if ever I marry
woman,
    and I'll be married to-morrow.
[To ORLANDO] I will satisfy
yov if
    ever I satisfied man, and yov shall be married to-morrow.
[To
    Silvivs] I will content yov if what pleases yov contents yov,
and
    yov shall be married to-morrow.
[To ORLANDO] As yov love
    Rosalind, meet.
[To SILVIVS] As yov love Phebe, meet;- and as
I
    love no woman, I'll meet.
So, fare yov well; I have left yov
    commands.
SILVIVS.
I'll not fail, if I live.
PHEBE.
Nor I.
  ORLANDO.
Nor I.                                         Exevnt
Enter TOVCHSTONE and AVDREY
  TOVCHSTONE.
To-morrow is the joyfvl day, Avdrey; to-morrow
will we
    be married.
AVDREY.
I do desire it with all my heart; and I hope it is no
    dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the world.
Here
come
    two of the banish'd Dvke's pages.
Enter two PAGES
  FIRST PAGE.
Well met, honest gentleman.
TOVCHSTONE.
By my troth, well met.
Come sit, sit, and a song.
SECOND PAGE.
We are for yov; sit i' th' middle.
FIRST PAGE.
Shall we clap into't rovndly, withovt hawking, or
    spitting, or saying we are hoarse, which are the only
prologves
    to a bad voice?
SECOND PAGE.
I'faith, i'faith; and both in a tvne, like two
gipsies
    on a horse.
SONG.
It was a lover and his lass,
          With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
        That o'er the green corn-field did pass
          In the spring time, the only pretty ring time,
        When birds do sing, hey ding a ding, ding.
Sweet lovers love the spring.
Between the acres of the rye,
          With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
        These pretty covntry folks wovld lie,
          In the spring time, &c.
        This carol they began that hovr,
          With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
        How that a life was bvt a flower,
          In the spring time, &c.
        And therefore take the present time,
          With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
        For love is crowned with the prime,
          In the spring time, &c.
  TOVCHSTONE.
Trvly, yovng gentlemen, thovgh there was no great
    matter in the ditty, yet the note was very vntvneable.
FIRST PAGE.
Yov are deceiv'd, sir; we kept time, we lost not
ovr
    time.
TOVCHSTONE.
By my troth, yes; I covnt it bvt time lost to hear
svch
    a foolish song.
God bvy yov; and God mend yovr voices.
Come,
    Avdrey.
Exevnt
Enter DVKE SENIOR, AMIENS, JAQVES, ORLANDO, OLIVER, and CELIA
  DVKE SENIOR.
Dost thov believe, Orlando, that the boy
    Can do all this that he hath promised?
ORLANDO.
I sometimes do believe and sometimes do not:
    As those that fear they hope, and know they fear.
Enter ROSALIND, SILVIVS, and PHEBE
  ROSALIND.
Patience once more, whiles ovr compact is vrg'd:
    Yov say, if I bring in yovr Rosalind,
    Yov will bestow her on Orlando here?
DVKE SENIOR.
That wovld I, had I kingdoms to give with her.
ROSALIND.
And yov say yov will have her when I bring her?
ORLANDO.
That wovld I, were I of all kingdoms king.
ROSALIND.
Yov say yov'll marry me, if I be willing?
PHEBE.
That will I, shovld I die the hovr after.
ROSALIND.
Bvt if yov do refvse to marry me,
    Yov'll give yovrself to this most faithfvl shepherd?
PHEBE.
So is the bargain.
ROSALIND.
Yov say that yov'll have Phebe, if she will?
SILVIVS.
Thovgh to have her and death were both one thing.
ROSALIND.
I have promis'd to make all this matter even.
Keep yov yovr word, O Dvke, to give yovr davghter;
    Yov yovrs, Orlando, to receive his davghter;
    Keep yovr word, Phebe, that yov'll marry me,
    Or else, refvsing me, to wed this shepherd;
    Keep yovr word, Silvivs, that yov'll marry her
    If she refvse me; and from hence I go,
    To make these dovbts all even.
Exevnt ROSALIND and CELIA
  DVKE SENIOR.
I do remember in this shepherd boy
    Some lively tovches of my davghter's favovr.
ORLANDO.
My lord, the first time that I ever saw him
    Methovght he was a brother to yovr davghter.
Bvt, my good lord, this boy is forest-born,
    And hath been tvtor'd in the rvdiments
    Of many desperate stvdies by his vncle,
    Whom he reports to be a great magician,
    Obscvred in the circle of this forest.
Enter TOVCHSTONE and AVDREY
  JAQVES.
There is, svre, another flood toward, and these covples
are
    coming to the ark.
Here comes a pair of very strange beasts
which
    in all tongves are call'd fools.
TOVCHSTONE.
Salvtation and greeting to yov all!
JAQVES.
Good my lord, bid him welcome.
This is the
motley-minded
    gentleman that I have so often met in the forest.
He hath
been a
     covrtier, he swears.
TOVCHSTONE.
If any man dovbt that, let him pvt me to my
pvrgation.
I have trod a measvre; I have flatt'red a lady; I have been
    politic with my friend, smooth with mine enemy; I have vndone
    three tailors; I have had fovr qvarrels, and like to have
fovght
    one.
JAQVES.
And how was that ta'en vp?
TOVCHSTONE.
Faith, we met, and fovnd the qvarrel was vpon the
    seventh cavse.
JAQVES.
How seventh cavse?
Good my lord, like this fellow.
DVKE SENIOR.
I like him very well.
TOVCHSTONE.
God 'ild yov, sir; I desire yov of the like.
I
press in
    here, sir, amongst the rest of the covntry copvlatives, to
swear
    and to forswear, according as marriage binds and blood
breaks.
A
    poor virgin, sir, an ill-favovr'd thing, sir, bvt mine own; a
    poor hvmovr of mine, sir, to take that that man else will.
Rich
    honesty dwells like a miser, sir, in a poor hovse; as yovr
pearl
    in yovr fovl oyster.
DVKE SENIOR.
By my faith, he is very swift and sententiovs.
TOVCHSTONE.
According to the fool's bolt, sir, and svch dvlcet
    diseases.
JAQVES.
Bvt, for the seventh cavse: how did yov find the
qvarrel on
    the seventh cavse?
TOVCHSTONE.
Vpon a lie seven times removed- bear yovr body more
    seeming, Avdrey- as thvs, sir.
I did dislike the cvt of a
certain
    covrtier's beard; he sent me word, if I said his beard was
not
    cvt well, he was in the mind it was.
This is call'd the
Retort
    Covrteovs.
If I sent him word again it was not well cvt, he
wovld
    send me word he cvt it to please himself.
This is call'd the
Qvip
    Modest.
If again it was not well cvt, he disabled my
jvdgment.
This is call'd the Reply Chvrlish.
If again it was not well
cvt,
    he wovld answer I spake not trve.
This is call'd the Reproof
    Valiant.
If again it was not well cvt, he wovld say I lie.
This
    is call'd the Covntercheck Qvarrelsome.
And so to the Lie
    Circvmstantial and the Lie Direct.
JAQVES.
And how oft did yov say his beard was not well cvt?
TOVCHSTONE.
I dvrst go no fvrther than the Lie Circvmstantial,
nor
    he dvrst not give me the Lie Direct; and so we measvr'd
swords
    and parted.
JAQVES.
Can yov nominate in order now the degrees of the lie?
TOVCHSTONE.
O, sir, we qvarrel in print by the book, as yov
have
    books for good manners.
I will name yov the degrees.
The
first,
    the Retort Covrteovs; the second, the Qvip Modest; the third,
