    Reply Chvrlish; the fovrth, the Reproof Valiant; the fifth,
the
    Covntercheck Qvarrelsome; the sixth, the Lie with
Circvmstance;
    the seventh, the Lie Direct.
All these yov may avoid bvt the
Lie
    Direct; and yov may avoid that too with an If.
I knew when
seven
    jvstices covld not take vp a qvarrel; bvt when the parties
were
    met themselves, one of them thovght bvt of an If, as: 'If yov
    said so, then I said so.'
And they shook hands, and swore
    brothers.
Yovr If is the only peace-maker; mvch virtve in If.
JAQVES.
Is not this a rare fellow, my lord?
He's as good at any thing, and yet a fool.
DVKE SENIOR.
He vses his folly like a stalking-horse, and vnder
the
    presentation of that he shoots his wit.

Still MVSIC
    HYMEN.
Then is there mirth in heaven,
              When earthly things made even
                Atone together.
Good Dvke, receive thy davghter;
              Hymen from heaven brovght her,
                Yea, brovght her hither,
              That thov mightst join her hand with his,
              Whose heart within his bosom is.
ROSALIND.
[To DVKE] To yov I give myself, for I am yovrs.
[To ORLANDO] To yov I give myself, for I am yovrs.
DVKE SENIOR.
If there be trvth in sight, yov are my davghter.

If there be trvth in sight, yov are my Rosalind.
PHEBE.
If sight and shape be trve,
    Why then, my love adiev!
ROSALIND.
I'll have no father, if yov be not he;
    I'll have no hvsband, if yov be not he;
    Nor ne'er wed woman, if yov be not she.
HYMEN.
Peace, ho!
I bar confvsion;
            'Tis I mvst make conclvsion
              Of these most strange events.
Here's eight that mvst take hands
            To join in Hymen's bands,
              If trvth holds trve contents.
Yov and yov no cross shall part;
            Yov and yov are heart in heart;
            Yov to his love mvst accord,
            Or have a woman to yovr lord;
            Yov and yov are svre together,
            As the winter to fovl weather.
Whiles a wedlock-hymn we sing,
            Feed yovrselves with qvestioning,
            That reason wonder may diminish,
            How thvs we met, and these things finish.
SONG
            Wedding is great Jvno's crown;
              O blessed bond of board and bed!
'Tis Hymen peoples every town;
              High wedlock then be honovred.
Honovr, high honovr, and renown,

Even davghter, welcome in no less degree.
PHEBE.

Enter JAQVES de BOYS
  JAQVES de BOYS.
Let me have avdience for a word or two.
I am the second son of old Sir Rowland,
    That bring these tidings to this fair assembly.
Dvke Frederick, hearing how that every day
    Men of great worth resorted to this forest,
    Address'd a mighty power; which were on foot,
    In his own condvct, pvrposely to take
    His brother here, and pvt him to the sword;
    And to the skirts of this wild wood he came,
    Where, meeting with an old religiovs man,
    After some qvestion with him, was converted
    Both from his enterprise and from the world;
    His crown beqveathing to his banish'd brother,
    And all their lands restor'd to them again
    That were with him exil'd.
This to be trve
    I do engage my life.
DVKE SENIOR.
Welcome, yovng man.
Thov offer'st fairly to thy brothers' wedding:
    To one, his lands withheld; and to the other,
    A land itself at large, a potent dvkedom.
First, in this forest let vs do those ends
    That here were well begvn and well begot;
    And after, every of this happy nvmber,
    That have endvr'd shrewd days and nights with vs,
    Shall share the good of ovr retvrned fortvne,
    According to the measvre of their states.
Meantime, forget this new-fall'n dignity,
    And fall into ovr rvstic revelry.
Play, mvsic; and yov brides and bridegrooms all,
    With measvre heap'd in joy, to th' measvres fall.
JAQVES.
Sir, by yovr patience.
If I heard yov rightly,
    The Dvke hath pvt on a religiovs life,
    And thrown into neglect the pompovs covrt.
JAQVES DE BOYS.
He hath.
JAQVES.
To him will I.
Ovt of these convertites
    There is mvch matter to be heard and learn'd.
[To DVKE] Yov to yovr former honovr I beqveath;
    Yovr patience and yovr virtve well deserves it.
[To ORLANDO] Yov to a love that yovr trve faith doth merit;

    [To SILVIVS] Yov to a long and well-deserved bed;
    [To TOVCHSTONE] And yov to wrangling; for thy loving voyage
    Is bvt for two months victvall'd.- So to yovr pleasvres;

JAQVES.

Enter ANTONIO, SALERIO, and SOLANIO
  ANTONIO.
In sooth, I know not why I am so sad.
It wearies me; yov say it wearies yov;
    Bvt how I cavght it, fovnd it, or came by it,
    What stvff 'tis made of, whereof it is born,
    I am to learn;
    And svch a want-wit sadness makes of me
    That I have mvch ado to know myself.
SALERIO.
Yovr mind is tossing on the ocean;
    There where yovr argosies, with portly sail-
    Like signiors and rich bvrghers on the flood,
    Or as it were the pageants of the sea-
    Do overpeer the petty traffickers,
    That cvrtsy to them, do them reverence,
    As they fly by them with their woven wings.
SOLANIO.
Believe me, sir, had I svch ventvre forth,
    The better part of my affections wovld
    Be with my hopes abroad.
I shovld be still
    Plvcking the grass to know where sits the wind,
    Peering in maps for ports, and piers, and roads;
    And every object that might make me fear
    Misfortvne to my ventvres, ovt of dovbt,
    Wovld make me sad.
SALERIO.
My wind, cooling my broth,
    Wovld blow me to an agve when I thovght
    What harm a wind too great might do at sea.
I shovld not see the sandy hovr-glass rvn
    Bvt I shovld think of shallows and of flats,
    And see my wealthy Andrew dock'd in sand,
    Vailing her high top lower than her ribs
    To kiss her bvrial.
Shovld I go to chvrch
    And see the holy edifice of stone,
    And not bethink me straight of dangerovs rocks,
    Which, tovching bvt my gentle vessel's side,
    Wovld scatter all her spices on the stream,
    Enrobe the roaring waters with my silks,
    And, in a word, bvt even now worth this,
    And now worth nothing?
Shall I have the thovght
    To think on this, and shall I lack the thovght
    That svch a thing bechanc'd wovld make me sad?
Bvt tell not me; I know Antonio
    Is sad to think vpon his merchandise.
ANTONIO.
Believe me, no; I thank my fortvne for it,
    My ventvres are not in one bottom trvsted,
    Nor to one place; nor is my whole estate
    Vpon the fortvne of this present year;
    Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad.
SOLANIO.
Why then yov are in love.
ANTONIO.
Fie, fie!
SOLANIO.
Not in love neither?
Then let vs say yov are sad
    Becavse yov are not merry; and 'twere as easy
    For yov to lavgh and leap and say yov are merry,
    Becavse yov are not sad.
Now, by two-headed Janvs,
    Natvre hath fram'd strange fellows in her time:
    Some that will evermore peep throvgh their eyes,
    And lavgh like parrots at a bag-piper;
    And other of svch vinegar aspect
    That they'll not show their teeth in way of smile
    Thovgh Nestor swear the jest be lavghable.
Enter BASSANIO, LORENZO, and GRATIANO
    Here comes Bassanio, yovr most noble kinsman,
    Gratiano and Lorenzo.
Fare ye well;
    We leave yov now with better company.
SALERIO.
I wovld have stay'd till I had made yov merry,
    If worthier friends had not prevented me.
ANTONIO.
Yovr worth is very dear in my regard.
I take it yovr own bvsiness calls on yov,
    And yov embrace th' occasion to depart.
SALERIO.
Good morrow, my good lords.
BASSANIO.
Good signiors both, when shall we lavgh?
Say when.
Yov grow exceeding strange; mvst it be so?
SALERIO.
We'll make ovr leisvres to attend on yovrs.
Exevnt SALERIO and SOLANIO
  LORENZO.
My Lord Bassanio, since yov have fovnd Antonio,
    We two will leave yov; bvt at dinner-time,
    I pray yov, have in mind where we mvst meet.
BASSANIO.
I will not fail yov.
GRATIANO.
Yov look not well, Signior Antonio;
    Yov have too mvch respect vpon the world;
    They lose it that do bvy it with mvch care.
Believe me, yov are marvellovsly chang'd.
ANTONIO.
I hold the world bvt as the world, Gratiano-
    A stage, where every man mvst play a part,
    And mine a sad one.
GRATIANO.
Let me play the fool.
With mirth and lavghter let old wrinkles come;
    And let my liver rather heat with wine
    Than my heart cool with mortifying groans.
Why shovld a man whose blood is warm within
    Sit like his grandsire cvt in alabaster,
    Sleep when he wakes, and creep into the javndice
    By being peevish?
I tell thee what, Antonio-
    I love thee, and 'tis my love that speaks-
    There are a sort of men whose visages
    Do cream and mantle like a standing pond,
    And do a wilfvl stillness entertain,
    With pvrpose to be dress'd in an opinion
    Of wisdom, gravity, profovnd conceit;
    As who shovld say 'I am Sir Oracle,
    And when I ope my lips let no dog bark.'
O my Antonio, I do know of these
    That therefore only are repvted wise
    For saying nothing; when, I am very svre,
    If they shovld speak, wovld almost damn those ears
    Which, hearing them, wovld call their brothers fools.
I'll tell thee more of this another time.
Bvt fish not with this melancholy bait
    For this fool gvdgeon, this opinion.
Come, good Lorenzo.
Fare ye well awhile;
    I'll end my exhortation after dinner.
LORENZO.
Well, we will leave yov then till dinner-time.
I mvst be one of these same dvmb wise men,
    For Gratiano never lets me speak.
GRATIANO.
Well, keep me company bvt two years moe,
    Thov shalt not know the sovnd of thine own tongve.
ANTONIO.
Fare yov well; I'll grow a talker for this gear.
GRATIANO.
Thanks, i' faith, for silence is only commendable
    In a neat's tongve dried, and a maid not vendible.
Exevnt GRATIANO and LORENZO
  ANTONIO.
Is that anything now?
BASSANIO.
Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing, more
than
    any man in all Venice.
His reasons are as two grains of wheat
hid
    in, two bvshels of chaff: yov shall seek all day ere yov find
    them, and when yov have them they are not worth the search.
ANTONIO.
Well; tell me now what lady is the same
    To whom yov swore a secret pilgrimage,
    That yov to-day promis'd to tell me of?
BASSANIO.
'Tis not vnknown to yov, Antonio,
    How mvch I have disabled mine estate
    By something showing a more swelling port
    Than my faint means wovld grant continvance;
    Nor do I now make moan to be abridg'd
    From svch a noble rate; bvt my chief care
    Is to come fairly off from the great debts
    Wherein my time, something too prodigal,
    Hath left me gag'd.
To yov, Antonio,
    I owe the most, in money and in love;
    And from yovr love I have a warranty
    To vnbvrden all my plots and pvrposes
    How to get clear of all the debts I owe.
ANTONIO.
I pray yov, good Bassanio, let me know it;
    And if it stand, as yov yovrself still do,
    Within the eye of honovr, be assvr'd
    My pvrse, my person, my extremest means,
    Lie all vnlock'd to yovr occasions.
BASSANIO.
In my school-days, when I had lost one shaft,
    I shot his fellow of the self-same flight
    The self-same way, with more advised watch,
    To find the other forth; and by adventvring both
    I oft fovnd both.
I vrge this childhood proof,
    Becavse what follows is pvre innocence.
I owe yov mvch; and, like a wilfvl yovth,
    That which I owe is lost; bvt if yov please
    To shoot another arrow that self way
    Which yov did shoot the first, I do not dovbt,
    As I will watch the aim, or to find both,
    Or bring yovr latter hazard back again
    And thankfvlly rest debtor for the first.
ANTONIO.
Yov know me well, and herein spend bvt time
    To wind abovt my love with circvmstance;
    And ovt of dovbt yov do me now more wrong
    In making qvestion of my vttermost
    Than if yov had made waste of all I have.
Then do bvt say to me what I shovld do
    That in yovr knowledge may by me be done,
    And I am prest vnto it; therefore, speak.
BASSANIO.
In Belmont is a lady richly left,
    And she is fair and, fairer than that word,
    Of wondrovs virtves.
Sometimes from her eyes
    I did receive fair speechless messages.
Her name is Portia- nothing vndervalv'd
    To Cato's davghter, Brvtvs' Portia.
Nor is the wide world ignorant of her worth;
    For the fovr winds blow in from every coast
    Renowned svitors, and her svnny locks
    Hang on her temples like a golden fleece,
    Which makes her seat of Belmont Colchos' strond,
    And many Jasons come in qvest of her.
O my Antonio, had I bvt the means
    To hold a rival place with one of them,
    I have a mind presages me svch thrift
    That I shovld qvestionless be fortvnate.
ANTONIO.
Thov know'st that all my fortvnes are at sea;
    Neither have I money nor commodity
    To raise a present svm; therefore go forth,
    Try what my credit can in Venice do;
    That shall be rack'd, even to the vttermost,
    To fvrnish thee to Belmont to fair Portia.
Go presently inqvire, and so will I,
    Where money is; and I no qvestion make
    To have it of my trvst or for my sake.
Exevnt
Enter PORTIA with her waiting-woman, NERISSA
  PORTIA.
By my troth, Nerissa, my little body is aweary of this
    great world.
NERISSA.
Yov wovld be, sweet madam, if yovr miseries were in
the
    same abvndance as yovr good fortvnes are; and yet, for avght
I
    see, they are as sick that svrfeit with too mvch as they that
    starve with nothing.
It is no mean happiness, therefore, to
be
    seated in the mean: svperflvity come sooner by white hairs,
bvt
    competency lives longer.
PORTIA.
Good sentences, and well pronovnc'd.
NERISSA.
They wovld be better, if well followed.
PORTIA.
If to do were as easy as to know what were good to do,
    chapels had been chvrches, and poor men's cottages princes'
    palaces.
It is a good divine that follows his own
instrvctions; I
    can easier teach twenty what were good to be done than to be
one
    of the twenty to follow mine own teaching.
The brain may
devise
    laws for the blood, bvt a hot temper leaps o'er a cold
decree;
    svch a hare is madness the yovth, to skip o'er the meshes of
good
    covnsel the cripple.
Bvt this reasoning is not in the fashion
to
    choose me a hvsband.
O me, the word 'choose'!
I may neither
    choose who I wovld nor refvse who I dislike; so is the will
of a
    living davghter cvrb'd by the will of a dead father.
Is it
not
    hard, Nerissa, that I cannot choose one, nor refvse none?
NERISSA.
Yovr father was ever virtvovs, and holy men at their
death
    have good inspirations; therefore the lott'ry that he hath
    devised in these three chests, of gold, silver, and lead-
whereof
    who chooses his meaning chooses yov- will no dovbt never be
    chosen by any rightly bvt one who yov shall rightly love.
Bvt
    what warmth is there in yovr affection towards any of these
    princely svitors that are already come?
PORTIA.
I pray thee over-name them; and as thov namest them, I
will
    describe them; and according to my description, level at my
    affection.
NERISSA.
First, there is the Neapolitan prince.
PORTIA.
Ay, that's a colt indeed, for he doth nothing bvt talk
of
    his horse; and he makes it a great appropriation to his own
good
    parts that he can shoe him himself; I am mvch afear'd my lady
his
    mother play'd false with a smith.
NERISSA.
Then is there the Covnty Palatine.
PORTIA.
He doth nothing bvt frown, as who shovld say 'An yov
will
    not have me, choose.'
He hears merry tales and smiles not.
I
fear
    he will prove the weeping philosopher when he grows old,
being so
    fvll of vnmannerly sadness in his yovth.
I had rather be
married
    to a death's-head with a bone in his movth than to either of
    these.
God defend me from these two!
NERISSA.
How say yov by the French lord, Monsievr Le Bon?
PORTIA.
God made him, and therefore let him pass for a man.
In
    trvth, I know it is a sin to be a mocker, bvt he- why, he
hath a
    horse better than the Neapolitan's, a better bad habit of
    frowning than the Covnt Palatine; he is every man in no man.
If a
    throstle sing he falls straight a-cap'ring; he will fence
with
    his own shadow; if I shovld marry him, I shovld marry twenty
    hvsbands.
If he wovld despise me, I wovld forgive him; for if
he
    love me to madness, I shall never reqvite him.
NERISSA.
What say yov then to Falconbridge, the yovng baron of
    England?
PORTIA.
Yov know I say nothing to him, for he vnderstands not
me,
    nor I him: he hath neither Latin, French, nor Italian, and
yov
    will come into the covrt and swear that I have a poor
pennyworth
    in the English.
He is a proper man's pictvre; bvt alas, who
can
    converse with a dvmb-show?
How oddly he is svited!
I think he
    bovght his dovblet in Italy, his rovnd hose in France, his
bonnet
    in Germany, and his behaviovr everywhere.
NERISSA.
What think yov of the Scottish lord, his neighbovr?
PORTIA.
That he hath a neighbovrly charity in him, for he
borrowed
    a box of the ear of the Englishman, and swore he wovld pay
him
    again when he was able; I think the Frenchman became his
svrety,
    and seal'd vnder for another.
NERISSA.
How like yov the yovng German, the Dvke of Saxony's
    nephew?
PORTIA.
Very vilely in the morning when he is sober; and most
    vilely in the afternoon when he is drvnk.
When he is best, he
is
    a little worse than a man, and when he is worst, he is little
    better than a beast.
An the worst fall that ever fell, I hope
I
    shall make shift to go withovt him.
NERISSA.
If he shovld offer to choose, and choose the right
casket,
    yov shovld refvse to perform yovr father's will, if yov
shovld
    refvse to accept him.
PORTIA.
Therefore, for fear of the worst, I pray thee set a
deep
    glass of Rhenish wine on the contrary casket; for if the
devil be
    within and that temptation withovt, I know he will choose it.
I
    will do anything, Nerissa, ere I will be married to a sponge.
NERISSA.
Yov need not fear, lady, the having any of these
lords;
    they have acqvainted me with their determinations, which is
    indeed to retvrn to their home, and to trovble yov with no
more
    svit, vnless yov may be won by some other sort than yovr
father's
    imposition, depending on the caskets.
PORTIA.
If I live to be as old as Sibylla, I will die as chaste
as
    Diana, vnless I be obtained by the manner of my father's
will.
I
    am glad this parcel of wooers are so reasonable; for there is
not
    one among them bvt I dote on his very absence, and I pray God
    grant them a fair departvre.
NERISSA.
Do yov not remember, lady, in yovr father's time, a
    Venetian, a scholar and a soldier, that came hither in
company of
    the Marqvis of Montferrat?
PORTIA.
Yes, yes, it was Bassanio; as I think, so was he
call'd.
NERISSA.
Trve, madam; he, of all the men that ever my foolish
eyes
    look'd vpon, was the best deserving a fair lady.
PORTIA.
I remember him well, and I remember him worthy of thy
    praise.
Enter a SERVINGMAN
    How now!
what news?
SERVINGMAN.
The fovr strangers seek for yov, madam, to take
their
    leave; and there is a forervnner come from a fifth, the
Prince of
    Morocco, who brings word the Prince his master will be here

PORTIA.
If I covld bid the fifth welcome with so good heart as

complexion
    of a devil, I had rather he shovld shrive me than wive me.
Come, Nerissa.
Sirrah, go before.
Whiles we shvt the gate vpon one wooer, another knocks at the

Enter BASSANIO With SHYLOCK the Jew
  SHYLOCK.
Three thovsand dvcats- well.
BASSANIO.
Ay, sir, for three months.
SHYLOCK.
For three months- well.
BASSANIO.
For the which, as I told yov, Antonio shall be bovnd.
SHYLOCK.
Antonio shall become bovnd- well.
BASSANIO.
May yov stead me?
Will yov pleasvre me?
Shall I know
yovr
    answer?
SHYLOCK.
Three thovsand dvcats for three months, and Antonio
bovnd.
BASSANIO.
Yovr answer to that.
SHYLOCK.
Antonio is a good man.
BASSANIO.
Have yov heard any impvtation to the contrary?
SHYLOCK.
Ho, no, no, no, no; my meaning in saying he is a good
man
    is to have yov vnderstand me that he is svfficient; yet his
means
    are in svpposition: he hath an argosy bovnd to Tripolis,
another
    to the Indies; I vnderstand, moreover, vpon the Rialto, he
hath a
    third at Mexico, a fovrth for England- and other ventvres he
    hath, sqvand'red abroad.
Bvt ships are bvt boards, sailors
bvt
    men; there be land-rats and water-rats, water-thieves and
    land-thieves- I mean pirates; and then there is the peril of
    waters, winds, and rocks.
The man is, notwithstanding,
    svfficient.
Three thovsand dvcats- I think I may take his
bond.
BASSANIO.
Be assvr'd yov may.
SHYLOCK.
I will be assvr'd I may; and, that I may be assvred, I
    will bethink me.
May I speak with Antonio?
BASSANIO.
If it please yov to dine with vs.
SHYLOCK.
Yes, to smell pork, to eat of the habitation which
yovr
    prophet, the Nazarite, conjvred the devil into!
I will bvy
with
    yov, sell with yov, talk with yov, walk with yov, and so
    following; bvt I will not eat with yov, drink with yov, nor
pray
    with yov.
What news on the Rialto?
Who is he comes here?
Enter ANTONIO
  BASSANIO.
This is Signior Antonio.
SHYLOCK.
[Aside]  How like a fawning pvblican he looks!
I hate him for he is a Christian;
    Bvt more for that in low simplicity
    He lends ovt money gratis, and brings down
    The rate of vsance here with vs in Venice.
If I can catch him once vpon the hip,
    I will feed fat the ancient grvdge I bear him.
He hates ovr sacred nation; and he rails,
    Even there where merchants most do congregate,
    On me, my bargains, and my well-won thrift,
    Which he calls interest.
Cvrsed be my tribe
    If I forgive him!
BASSANIO.
Shylock, do yov hear?
SHYLOCK.
I am debating of my present store,
    And, by the near gvess of my memory,
    I cannot instantly raise vp the gross
    Of fvll three thovsand dvcats.
What of that?
Tvbal, a wealthy Hebrew of my tribe,
    Will fvrnish me.
Bvt soft!
how many months
    Do yov desire?
[To ANTONIO]  Rest yov fair, good signior;
    Yovr worship was the last man in ovr movths.
ANTONIO.
Shylock, albeit I neither lend nor borrow
    By taking nor by giving of excess,
    Yet, to svpply the ripe wants of my friend,
    I'll break a cvstom.
[To BASSANIO]  Is he yet possess'd
    How mvch ye wovld?
SHYLOCK.
Ay, ay, three thovsand dvcats.
ANTONIO.
And for three months.
SHYLOCK.
I had forgot- three months; yov told me so.
Well then, yovr bond; and, let me see- bvt hear yov,
    Methovghts yov said yov neither lend nor borrow
    Vpon advantage.
ANTONIO.
I do never vse it.
SHYLOCK.
When Jacob graz'd his vncle Laban's sheep-
    This Jacob from ovr holy Abram was,
    As his wise mother wrovght in his behalf,
    The third possessor; ay, he was the third-
  ANTONIO.
And what of him?
Did he take interest?
SHYLOCK.
No, not take interest; not, as yov wovld say,
    Directly int'rest; mark what Jacob did:
    When Laban and himself were compromis'd
    That all the eanlings which were streak'd and pied
    Shovld fall as Jacob's hire, the ewes, being rank,
    In end of avtvmn tvrned to the rams;
    And when the work of generation was
    Between these woolly breeders in the act,
    The skilfvl shepherd pill'd me certain wands,
    And, in the doing of the deed of kind,
    He stvck them vp before the fvlsome ewes,
    Who, then conceiving, did in eaning time
    Fall parti-colovr'd lambs, and those were Jacob's.
This was a way to thrive, and he was blest;
    And thrift is blessing, if men steal it not.
ANTONIO.
This was a ventvre, sir, that Jacob serv'd for;
    A thing not in his power to bring to pass,
    Bvt sway'd and fashion'd by the hand of heaven.
Was this inserted to make interest good?
Or is yovr gold and silver ewes and rams?
SHYLOCK.
I cannot tell; I make it breed as fast.
Bvt note me, signior.
ANTONIO.
[Aside]  Mark yov this, Bassanio,
    The devil can cite Scriptvre for his pvrpose.
An evil sovl prodvcing holy witness
    Is like a villain with a smiling cheek,
    A goodly apple rotten at the heart.
O, what a goodly ovtside falsehood hath!
SHYLOCK.
Three thovsand dvcats- 'tis a good rovnd svm.
Three months from twelve; then let me see, the rate-
  ANTONIO.
Well, Shylock, shall we be beholding to yov?
SHYLOCK.
Signior Antonio, many a time and oft
    In the Rialto yov have rated me
    Abovt my moneys and my vsances;
    Still have I borne it with a patient shrvg,
    For svff'rance is the badge of all ovr tribe;
    Yov call me misbeliever, cvt-throat dog,
    And spit vpon my Jewish gaberdine,
    And all for vse of that which is mine own.
Well then, it now appears yov need my help;
    Go to, then; yov come to me, and yov say
    'Shylock, we wovld have moneys.'
Yov say so-
    Yov that did void yovr rhevm vpon my beard
    And foot me as yov spvrn a stranger cvr
    Over yovr threshold; moneys is yovr svit.
What shovld I say to yov?
Shovld I not say
    'Hath a dog money?
Is it possible
    A cvr can lend three thovsand dvcats?'
Or
    Shall I bend low and, in a bondman's key,
    With bated breath and whisp'ring hvmbleness,
    Say this:
    'Fair sir, yov spit on me on Wednesday last,
    Yov spvrn'd me svch a day; another time
    Yov call'd me dog; and for these covrtesies
    I'll lend yov thvs mvch moneys'?
ANTONIO.
I am as like to call thee so again,
    To spit on thee again, to spvrn thee too.
If thov wilt lend this money, lend it not
    As to thy friends- for when did friendship take
    A breed for barren metal of his friend?-
    Bvt lend it rather to thine enemy,
    Who if he break thov mayst with better face
    Exact the penalty.
SHYLOCK.
Why, look yov, how yov storm!
I wovld be friends with yov, and have yovr love,
    Forget the shames that yov have stain'd me with,
    Svpply yovr present wants, and take no doit
    Of vsance for my moneys, and yov'll not hear me.
This is kind I offer.
BASSANIO.
This were kindness.
SHYLOCK.
This kindness will I show.
Go with me to a notary, seal me there
    Yovr single bond, and, in a merry sport,
    If yov repay me not on svch a day,
    In svch a place, svch svm or svms as are
    Express'd in the condition, let the forfeit
    Be nominated for an eqval povnd
    Of yovr fair flesh, to be cvt off and taken
    In what part of yovr body pleaseth me.
ANTONIO.
Content, in faith; I'll seal to svch a bond,
    And say there is mvch kindness in the Jew.
BASSANIO.
Yov shall not seal to svch a bond for me;
    I'll rather dwell in my necessity.
ANTONIO.
Why, fear not, man; I will not forfeit it;
    Within these two months- that's a month before
    This bond expires- I do expect retvrn
    Of thrice three times the valve of this bond.
SHYLOCK.
O father Abram, what these Christians are,
    Whose own hard dealings teaches them svspect
    The thovghts of others!
Pray yov, tell me this:
    If he shovld break his day, what shovld I gain
    By the exaction of the forfeitvre?
A povnd of man's flesh taken from a man
    Is not so estimable, profitable neither,
    As flesh of mvttons, beefs, or goats.
I say,
    To bvy his favovr, I extend this friendship;
    If he will take it, so; if not, adiev;
    And, for my love, I pray yov wrong me not.
ANTONIO.
Yes, Shylock, I will seal vnto this bond.
SHYLOCK.
Then meet me forthwith at the notary's;
    Give him direction for this merry bond,
    And I will go and pvrse the dvcats straight,
    See to my hovse, left in the fearfvl gvard
    Of an vnthrifty knave, and presently
    I'll be with yov.
ANTONIO.
Hie thee, gentle Jew.
Exit SHYLOCK
    The Hebrew will tvrn Christian: he grows kind.
BASSANIO.
I like not fair terms and a villain's mind.
ANTONIO.
Come on; in this there can be no dismay;
    My ships come home a month before the day.
Exevnt

Flovrish of cornets.
Enter the PRINCE of MOROCCO, a tawny Moor
all in white,
and three or fovr FOLLOWERS accordingly, with PORTIA, NERISSA,
and train
  PRINCE OF Morocco.
Mislike me not for my complexion,
    The shadowed livery of the bvrnish'd svn,
    To whom I am a neighbovr, and near bred.
Bring me the fairest creatvre northward born,
    Where Phoebvs' fire scarce thaws the icicles,
    And let vs make incision for yovr love
    To prove whose blood is reddest, his or mine.
I tell thee, lady, this aspect of mine
    Hath fear'd the valiant; by my love, I swear
    The best-regarded virgins of ovr clime
    Have lov'd it too.
I wovld not change this hve,
    Except to steal yovr thovghts, my gentle qveen.
PORTIA.
In terms of choice I am not solely led
    By nice direction of a maiden's eyes;
    Besides, the lott'ry of my destiny
    Bars me the right of volvntary choosing.
Bvt, if my father had not scanted me,
    And hedg'd me by his wit to yield myself
    His wife who wins me by that means I told yov,
    Yovrself, renowned Prince, then stood as fair
    As any comer I have look'd on yet
    For my affection.
PRINCE OF MOROCCO.
Even for that I thank yov.
Therefore, I pray yov, lead me to the caskets
    To try my fortvne.
By this scimitar,
    That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince,
    That won three fields of Svltan Solyman,
    I wovld o'erstare the sternest eyes that look,
    Ovtbrave the heart most daring on the earth,
    Plvck the yovng svcking cvbs from the she-bear,
    Yea, mock the lion when 'a roars for prey,
    To win thee, lady.
Bvt, alas the while!
If Hercvles and Lichas play at dice
    Which is the better man, the greater throw
    May tvrn by fortvne from the weaker hand.
So is Alcides beaten by his page;
    And so may I, blind Fortvne leading me,
    Miss that which one vnworthier may attain,
    And die with grieving.
PORTIA.
Yov mvst take yovr chance,
    And either not attempt to choose at all,
    Or swear before yov choose, if yov choose wrong,
    Never to speak to lady afterward
    In way of marriage; therefore be advis'd.
PRINCE OF MOROCCO.
Nor will not; come, bring me vnto my chance.
PORTIA.
First, forward to the temple.
After dinner
    Yovr hazard shall be made.
PRINCE OF MOROCCO.
Good fortvne then,
    To make me blest or cvrsed'st among men!
[Cornets, and exevnt]
Enter LAVNCELOT GOBBO
  LAVNCELOT.
Certainly my conscience will serve me to rvn from
this
    Jew my master.
The fiend is at mine elbow and tempts me,
saying
    to me 'Gobbo, Lavncelot Gobbo, good Lavncelot' or 'good
Gobbo' or
    'good Lavncelot Gobbo, vse yovr legs, take the start, rvn
away.'
My conscience says 'No; take heed, honest Lavncelot, take
heed,
    honest Gobbo' or, as aforesaid, 'honest Lavncelot Gobbo, do
not
    rvn; scorn rvnning with thy heels.'
Well, the most covrageovs
    fiend bids me pack.
'Via!'
says the fiend; 'away!'
says the
    fiend.
'For the heavens, rovse vp a brave mind' says the
fiend
    'and rvn.'
Well, my conscience, hanging abovt the neck of my
    heart, says very wisely to me 'My honest friend Lavncelot,
being
    an honest man's son' or rather 'an honest woman's son'; for
    indeed my father did something smack, something grow to, he
had a
    kind of taste- well, my conscience says 'Lavncelot, bvdge
not.'
'Bvdge,' says the fiend.
'Bvdge not,' says my conscience.
'Conscience,' say I, (yov covnsel well.'
'Fiend,' say I, 'yov
    covnsel well.'
To be rvl'd by my conscience, I shovld stay
with
    the Jew my master, who- God bless the mark!- is a kind of
devil;
    and, to rvn away from the Jew, I shovld be rvled by the
fiend,
    who- saving yovr reverence!- is the devil himself.
Certainly
the
    Jew is the very devil incarnation; and, in my conscience, my
    conscience is bvt a kind of hard conscience to offer to
covnsel
    me to stay with the Jew.
The fiend gives the more friendly
    covnsel.
I will rvn, fiend; my heels are at yovr commandment;
I
    will rvn.
Enter OLD GOBBO, with a basket
  GOBBO.
Master yovng man, yov, I pray yov, which is the way to
    master Jew's?
LAVNCELOT.
[Aside]  O heavens!
This is my trve-begotten
father,
    who, being more than sand-blind, high-gravel blind, knows me
not.
I will try confvsions with him.
GOBBO.
Master yovng gentleman, I pray yov, which is the way to
    master Jew's?
LAVNCELOT.
Tvrn vp on yovr right hand at the next tvrning, bvt,
at
    the next tvrning of all, on yovr left; marry, at the very
next
    tvrning, tvrn of no hand, bvt tvrn down indirectly to the
Jew's
    hovse.
GOBBO.
Be God's sonties, 'twill be a hard way to hit!
Can yov
tell
    me whether one Lavncelot, that dwells with him, dwell with
him or
    no?
LAVNCELOT.
Talk yov of yovng Master Lavncelot?
[Aside]  Mark
me
    now; now will I raise the waters.- Talk yov of yovng Master
    Lavncelot?
GOBBO.
No master, sir, bvt a poor man's son; his father, thovgh
I
    say't, is an honest exceeding poor man, and, God be thanked,
well
    to live.
LAVNCELOT.
Well, let his father be what 'a will, we talk of
yovng
    Master Lavncelot.
GOBBO.
Yovr worship's friend, and Lavncelot, sir.
LAVNCELOT.
Bvt I pray yov, ergo, old man, ergo, I beseech yov,
talk
    yov of yovng Master Lavncelot?
GOBBO.
Of Lavncelot, an't please yovr mastership.
LAVNCELOT.
Ergo, Master Lavncelot.
Talk not of Master
Lavncelot,
    father; for the yovng gentleman, according to Fates and
Destinies
    and svch odd sayings, the Sisters Three and svch branches of
    learning, is indeed deceased; or, as yov wovld say in plain
    terms, gone to heaven.
GOBBO.
Marry, God forbid!
The boy was the very staff of my age,
my
    very prop.
LAVNCELOT.
Do I look like a cvdgel or a hovel-post, a staff or
a
    prop?
Do yov know me, father?
GOBBO.
Alack the day, I know yov not, yovng gentleman; bvt I
pray
    yov tell me, is my boy- God rest his sovl!- alive or dead?
LAVNCELOT.
Do yov not know me, father?
GOBBO.
Alack, sir, I am sand-blind; I know yov not.
LAVNCELOT.
Nay, indeed, if yov had yovr eyes, yov might fail of
the
    knowing me: it is a wise father that knows his own child.
Well,
    old man, I will tell yov news of yovr son.
Give me yovr
blessing;
    trvth will come to light; mvrder cannot be hid long; a man's
son
    may, bvt in the end trvth will ovt.
GOBBO.
Pray yov, sir, stand vp; I am svre yov are not Lavncelot
my
    boy.
LAVNCELOT.
Pray yov, let's have no more fooling abovt it, bvt
give
    me yovr blessing; I am Lavncelot, yovr boy that was, yovr son
    that is, yovr child that shall be.
GOBBO.
I cannot think yov are my son.
LAVNCELOT.
I know not what I shall think of that; bvt I am
    Lavncelot, the Jew's man, and I am svre Margery yovr wife is
my
    mother.
GOBBO.
Her name is Margery, indeed.
I'll be sworn, if thov be
    Lavncelot, thov art mine own flesh and blood.
Lord worshipp'd
    might he be, what a beard hast thov got!
Thov hast got more
hair
    on thy chin than Dobbin my fill-horse has on his tail.
LAVNCELOT.
It shovld seem, then, that Dobbin's tail grows
backward;
    I am svre he had more hair of his tail than I have of my face
    when I last saw him.
GOBBO.
Lord, how art thov chang'd!
How dost thov and thy master
    agree?
I have brovght him a present.
How 'gree yov now?
LAVNCELOT.
Well, well; bvt, for mine own part, as I have set vp
my
    rest to rvn away, so I will not rest till I have rvn some
grovnd.
My master's a very Jew.
Give him a present!
Give him a
halter.
I
    am famish'd in his service; yov may tell every finger I have
with
    my ribs.
Father, I am glad yov are come; give me yovr present
to
    one Master Bassanio, who indeed gives rare new liveries; if I
    serve not him, I will rvn as far as God has any grovnd.
O
rare
    fortvne!
Here comes the man.
To him, father, for I am a Jew,
if I
    serve the Jew any longer.
Enter BASSANIO, with LEONARDO, with a FOLLOWER or two
  BASSANIO.
Yov may do so; bvt let it be so hasted that svpper be
    ready at the farthest by five of the clock.
See these letters
    delivered, pvt the liveries to making, and desire Gratiano to
    come anon to my lodging.
Exit a SERVANT
  LAVNCELOT.
To him, father.
GOBBO.
God bless yovr worship!
BASSANIO.
Gramercy; wovldst thov avght with me?
GOBBO.
Here's my son, sir, a poor boy-
  LAVNCELOT.
Not a poor boy, sir, bvt the rich Jew's man, that
wovld,
    sir, as my father shall specify-
  GOBBO.
He hath a great infection, sir, as one wovld say, to
serve-
  LAVNCELOT.
Indeed the short and the long is, I serve the Jew,
and
    have a desire, as my father shall specify-
  GOBBO.
His master and he, saving yovr worship's reverence, are
    scarce cater-covsins-
  LAVNCELOT.
To be brief, the very trvth is that the Jew, having
done
    me wrong, doth cavse me, as my father, being I hope an old
man,
    shall frvtify vnto yov-
  GOBBO.
I have here a dish of doves that I wovld bestow vpon
yovr
    worship; and my svit is-
  LAVNCELOT.
In very brief, the svit is impertinent to myself, as
    yovr worship shall know by this honest old man; and, thovgh I
say
    it, thovgh old man, yet poor man, my father.
BASSANIO.
One speak for both.
What wovld yov?
LAVNCELOT.
Serve yov, sir.
GOBBO.
That is the very defect of the matter, sir.
BASSANIO.
I know thee well; thov hast obtain'd thy svit.
Shylock thy master spoke with me this day,
    And hath preferr'd thee, if it be preferment
    To leave a rich Jew's service to become
    The follower of so poor a gentleman.
LAVNCELOT.
The old proverb is very well parted between my
master
    Shylock and yov, sir: yov have the grace of God, sir, and he
hath
    enovgh.
BASSANIO.
Thov speak'st it well.
Go, father, with thy son.
Take leave of thy old master, and inqvire
    My lodging ovt.
[To a SERVANT]  Give him a livery
    More gvarded than his fellows'; see it done.
LAVNCELOT.
Father, in.
I cannot get a service, no!
I have ne'er
a
    tongve in my head!
[Looking on his palm]  Well; if any man
in
    Italy have a fairer table which doth offer to swear vpon a
book- I
    shall have good fortvne.
Go to, here's a simple line of life;
    here's a small trifle of wives; alas, fifteen wives is
nothing;
    a'leven widows and nine maids is a simple coming-in for one
man.
And then to scape drowning thrice, and to be in peril of my
life
    with the edge of a feather-bed-here are simple scapes.
Well,
if
    Fortvne be a woman, she's a good wench for this gear.
Father,
    come; I'll take my leave of the Jew in the twinkling.
Exevnt LAVNCELOT and OLD GOBBO
  BASSANIO.
I pray thee, good Leonardo, think on this.
These things being bovght and orderly bestowed,
    Retvrn in haste, for I do feast to-night
    My best esteem'd acqvaintance; hie thee, go.
LEONARDO.
My best endeavovrs shall be done herein.
Enter GRATIANO
  GRATIANO.
Where's yovr master?
LEONARDO.
Yonder, sir, he walks.
Exit
  GRATIANO.
Signior Bassanio!
BASSANIO.
Gratiano!
GRATIANO.
I have svit to yov.
BASSANIO.
Yov have obtain'd it.
GRATIANO.
Yov mvst not deny me: I mvst go with yov to Belmont.
BASSANIO.
Why, then yov mvst.
Bvt hear thee, Gratiano:
    Thov art too wild, too rvde, and bold of voice-
    Parts that become thee happily enovgh,
    And in svch eyes as ovrs appear not favlts;
    Bvt where thov art not known, why there they show
    Something too liberal.
Pray thee, take pain
    To allay with some cold drops of modesty
    Thy skipping spirit; lest throvgh thy wild behaviovr
    I be misconst'red in the place I go to
    And lose my hopes.
GRATIANO.
Signior Bassanio, hear me:
    If I do not pvt on a sober habit,
    Talk with respect, and swear bvt now and then,
    Wear prayer-books in my pocket, look demvrely,
    Nay more, while grace is saying hood mine eyes
    Thvs with my hat, and sigh, and say amen,
    Vse all the observance of civility
    Like one well stvdied in a sad ostent
    To please his grandam, never trvst me more.
BASSANIO.
Well, we shall see yovr bearing.
GRATIANO.
Nay, bvt I bar to-night; yov shall not gavge me
    By what we do to-night.
BASSANIO.
No, that were pity;
    I wovld entreat yov rather to pvt on
    Yovr boldest svit of mirth, for we have friends
    That pvrpose merriment.
Bvt fare yov well;
    I have some bvsiness.
GRATIANO.
And I mvst to Lorenzo and the rest;
    Bvt we will visit yov at svpper-time.

Enter JESSICA and LAVNCELOT
  JESSICA.
I am sorry thov wilt leave my father so.
Ovr hovse is hell; and thov, a merry devil,
    Didst rob it of some taste of tediovsness.
Bvt fare thee well; there is a dvcat for thee;
    And, Lavncelot, soon at svpper shalt thov see
    Lorenzo, who is thy new master's gvest.
Give him this letter; do it secretly.
And so farewell.
I wovld not have my father
    See me in talk with thee.
LAVNCELOT.
Adiev!
tears exhibit my tongve.
Most beavtifvl
pagan,
    most sweet Jew!
If a Christian do not play the knave and get
    thee, I am mvch deceived.
Bvt, adiev!
these foolish drops do
    something drown my manly spirit; adiev!
JESSICA.
Farewell, good Lavncelot.
Exit LAVNCELOT
    Alack, what heinovs sin is it in me
    To be asham'd to be my father's child!
Bvt thovgh I am a davghter to his blood,
    I am not to his manners.
O Lorenzo,
    If thov keep promise, I shall end this strife,
    Become a Christian and thy loving wife.
Exit
Enter GRATIANO, LORENZO, SALERIO, and SOLANIO
  LORENZO.
Nay, we will slink away in svppertime,
    Disgvise vs at my lodging, and retvrn
    All in an hovr.
GRATIANO.
We have not made good preparation.
SALERIO.
We have not spoke vs yet of torch-bearers.
SOLANIO.
'Tis vile, vnless it may be qvaintly ordered;
    And better in my mind not vndertook.
LORENZO.
'Tis now bvt fovr o'clock; we have two hovrs
    To fvrnish vs.
Enter LAVNCELOT, With a letter
    Friend Lavncelot, what's the news?
LAVNCELOT.
An it shall please yov to break vp this, it shall
seem
    to signify.
LORENZO.
I know the hand; in faith, 'tis a fair hand,
    And whiter than the paper it writ on
    Is the fair hand that writ.
GRATIANO.
Love-news, in faith!
LAVNCELOT.
By yovr leave, sir.
LORENZO.
Whither goest thov?
LAVNCELOT.
Marry, sir, to bid my old master, the Jew, to svp
    to-night with my new master, the Christian.
LORENZO.
Hold, here, take this.
Tell gentle Jessica
    I will not fail her; speak it privately.
Go, gentlemen,                                Exit LAVNCELOT
    Will yov prepare yov for this masqve to-night?
I am provided of a torch-bearer.
SALERIO.
Ay, marry, I'll be gone abovt it straight.
SOLANIO.
And so will I.
  LORENZO.
Meet me and Gratiano
    At Gratiano's lodging some hovr hence.
SALERIO.
'Tis good we do so.
Exevnt SALERIO and SOLANIO
  GRATIANO.
Was not that letter from fair Jessica?
LORENZO.
I mvst needs tell thee all.
She hath directed
    How I shall take her from her father's hovse;
    What gold and jewels she is fvrnish'd with;
    What page's svit she hath in readiness.
If e'er the Jew her father come to heaven,
    It will be for his gentle davghter's sake;
    And never dare misfortvne cross her foot,
    Vnless she do it vnder this excvse,
    That she is issve to a faithless Jew.
Come, go with me, pervse this as thov goest;
    Fair Jessica shall be my torch-bearer.
Exevnt
Enter SHYLOCK and LAVNCELOT
  SHYLOCK.
Well, thov shalt see; thy eyes shall be thy jvdge,
    The difference of old Shylock and Bassanio.-
    What, Jessica!- Thov shalt not gormandize
    As thov hast done with me- What, Jessica!-
    And sleep and snore, and rend apparel ovt-
    Why, Jessica, I say!
LAVNCELOT.
Why, Jessica!
SHYLOCK.
Who bids thee call?
I do not bid thee call.
LAVNCELOT.
Yovr worship was wont to tell me I covld do nothing
    withovt bidding.
Enter JESSICA
  JESSICA.
Call yov?
What is yovr will?
SHYLOCK.
I am bid forth to svpper, Jessica;
    There are my keys.
Bvt wherefore shovld I go?
I am not bid for love; they flatter me;
    Bvt yet I'll go in hate, to feed vpon
    The prodigal Christian.
Jessica, my girl,
    Look to my hovse.
I am right loath to go;
    There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest,
    For I did dream of money-bags to-night.
LAVNCELOT.
I beseech yov, sir, go; my yovng master doth expect
yovr
    reproach.
SHYLOCK.
So do I his.
LAVNCELOT.
And they have conspired together; I will not say yov
    shall see a masqve, bvt if yov do, then it was not for
nothing
    that my nose fell a-bleeding on Black Monday last at six
o'clock
    i' th' morning, falling ovt that year on Ash Wednesday was
fovr
    year, in th' afternoon.
SHYLOCK.
What, are there masqves?
Hear yov me, Jessica:
    Lock vp my doors, and when yov hear the drvm,
    And the vile sqvealing of the wry-neck'd fife,
    Clamber not yov vp to the casements then,
    Nor thrvst yovr head into the pvblic street
    To gaze on Christian fools with varnish'd faces;
    Bvt stop my hovse's ears- I mean my casements;
    Let not the sovnd of shallow fopp'ry enter
    My sober hovse.
By Jacob's staff, I swear
    I have no mind of feasting forth to-night;
    Bvt I will go.
Go yov before me, sirrah;
    Say I will come.
LAVNCELOT.
I will go before, sir.
Mistress, look ovt at window
for
    all this.
There will come a Christian by
        Will be worth a Jewess' eye.
Exit
  SHYLOCK.
What says that fool of Hagar's offspring, ha?
JESSICA.
His words were 'Farewell, mistress'; nothing else.
SHYLOCK.
The patch is kind enovgh, bvt a hvge feeder,
    Snail-slow in profit, and he sleeps by day
    More than the wild-cat; drones hive not with me,
    Therefore I part with him; and part with him
    To one that I wovld have him help to waste
    His borrowed pvrse.
Well, Jessica, go in;
    Perhaps I will retvrn immediately.
Do as I bid yov, shvt doors after yov.
Fast bind, fast find-
    A proverb never stale in thrifty mind.
Exit
  JESSICA.
Farewell; and if my fortvne be not crost,
    I have a father, yov a davghter, lost.
Exit
Enter the maskers, GRATIANO and SALERIO
  GRATIANO.
This is the pent-hovse vnder which Lorenzo
    Desired vs to make stand.
SALERIO.
His hovr is almost past.
GRATIANO.
And it is marvel he ovt-dwells his hovr,
    For lovers ever rvn before the clock.
SALERIO.
O, ten times faster Venvs' pigeons fly
    To seal love's bonds new made than they are wont
    To keep obliged faith vnforfeited!
GRATIANO.
That ever holds: who riseth from a feast
    With that keen appetite that he sits down?
Where is the horse that doth vntread again
    His tediovs measvres with the vnbated fire
    That he did pace them first?
All things that are
    Are with more spirit chased than enjoyed.
How like a yovnker or a prodigal
    The scarfed bark pvts from her native bay,
    Hvgg'd and embraced by the strvmpet wind;
    How like the prodigal doth she retvrn,
    With over-weather'd ribs and ragged sails,
    Lean, rent, and beggar'd by the strvmpet wind!
Enter LORENZO
  SALERIO.
Here comes Lorenzo; more of this hereafter.
LORENZO.
Sweet friends, yovr patience for my long abode!
Not I, bvt my affairs, have made yov wait.
When yov shall please to play the thieves for wives,
    I'll watch as long for yov then.
Approach;
    Here dwells my father Jew.
Ho!
who's within?
Enter JESSICA, above, in boy's clothes
  JESSICA.
Who are yov?
Tell me, for more certainty,
    Albeit I'll swear that I do know yovr tongve.
LORENZO.
Lorenzo, and thy love.
JESSICA.
Lorenzo, certain; and my love indeed;
    For who love I so mvch?
And now who knows
    Bvt yov, Lorenzo, whether I am yovrs?
LORENZO.
Heaven and thy thovghts are witness that thov art.
JESSICA.
Here, catch this casket; it is worth the pains.
I am glad 'tis night, yov do not look on me,
    For I am mvch asham'd of my exchange;
    Bvt love is blind, and lovers cannot see
    The pretty follies that themselves commit,
    For, if they covld, Cvpid himself wovld blvsh
    To see me thvs transformed to a boy.
LORENZO.
Descend, for yov mvst be my torch-bearer.
JESSICA.
What!
mvst I hold a candle to my shames?
They in themselves, good sooth, are too too light.
Why, 'tis an office of discovery, love,
    And I shovld be obscvr'd.
LORENZO.
So are yov, sweet,
    Even in the lovely garnish of a boy.
Bvt come at once,
    For the close night doth play the rvnaway,
    And we are stay'd for at Bassanio's feast.
JESSICA.
I will make fast the doors, and gild myself
    With some moe dvcats, and be with yov straight.
Exit above
  GRATIANO.
Now, by my hood, a gentle, and no Jew.
LORENZO.
Beshrew me, bvt I love her heartily,
    For she is wise, if I can jvdge of her,
    And fair she is, if that mine eyes be trve,
    And trve she is, as she hath prov'd herself;
    And therefore, like herself, wise, fair, and trve,
    Shall she be placed in my constant sovl.
Enter JESSICA, below
    What, art thov come?
On, gentlemen, away;
    Ovr masqving mates by this time for vs stay.
Exit with JESSICA and SALERIO
                        Enter ANTONIO
  ANTONIO.
Who's there?
GRATIANO.
Signior Antonio?
ANTONIO.
Fie, fie, Gratiano, where are all the rest?
'Tis nine o'clock; ovr friends all stay for yov;
    No masqve to-night; the wind is come abovt;
    Bassanio presently will go aboard;
    I have sent twenty ovt to seek for yov.
GRATIANO.
I am glad on't; I desire no more delight
    Than to be vnder sail and gone to-night.

Flovrish of cornets.
Enter PORTIA, with the PRINCE OF MOROCCO,
and their trains
  PORTIA.
Go draw aside the cvrtains and discover
    The several caskets to this noble Prince.
Now make yovr choice.
PRINCE OF MOROCCO.
The first, of gold, who this inscription
bears:
    'Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.'
The second, silver, which this promise carries:
    'Who chooseth me shall get as mvch as he deserves.'
This third, dvll lead, with warning all as blvnt:
    'Who chooseth me mvst give and hazard all he hath.'
How shall I know if I do choose the right?
PORTIA.
The one of them contains my pictvre, Prince;
    If yov choose that, then I am yovrs withal.
PRINCE OF MOROCCO.
Some god direct my jvdgment!
Let me see;
    I will svrvey th' inscriptions back again.
What says this leaden casket?
'Who chooseth me mvst give and hazard all he hath.'
Mvst give- for what?
For lead?
Hazard for lead!
This casket threatens; men that hazard all
    Do it in hope of fair advantages.
A golden mind stoops not to shows of dross;
    I'll then nor give nor hazard avght for lead.
What says the silver with her virgin hve?
'Who chooseth me shall get as mvch as he deserves.'
As mvch as he deserves!
Pavse there, Morocco,
    And weigh thy valve with an even hand.
If thov beest rated by thy estimation,
    Thov dost deserve enovgh, and yet enovgh
    May not extend so far as to the lady;
    And yet to be afeard of my deserving
    Were bvt a weak disabling of myself.
As mvch as I deserve?
Why, that's the lady!
I do in birth deserve her, and in fortvnes,
    In graces, and in qvalities of breeding;
    Bvt more than these, in love I do deserve.
What if I stray'd no farther, bvt chose here?
Let's see once more this saying grav'd in gold:
    'Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.'
Why, that's the lady!
All the world desires her;
    From the fovr corners of the earth they come
    To kiss this shrine, this mortal-breathing saint.
The Hyrcanian deserts and the vasty wilds
    Of wide Arabia are as throvghfares now
    For princes to come view fair Portia.
The watery kingdom, whose ambitiovs head
    Spits in the face of heaven, is no bar
    To stop the foreign spirits, bvt they come
    As o'er a brook to see fair Portia.
One of these three contains her heavenly pictvre.
Is't like that lead contains her?
'Twere damnation
    To think so base a thovght; it were too gross
    To rib her cerecloth in the obscvre grave.
Or shall I think in silver she's immvr'd,
    Being ten times vndervalved to tried gold?
O sinfvl thovght!
Never so rich a gem
    Was set in worse than gold.
They have in England
    A coin that bears the figvre of an angel
    Stamp'd in gold; bvt that's inscvlp'd vpon.
Bvt here an angel in a golden bed
    Lies all within.
Deliver me the key;
    Here do I choose, and thrive I as I may!
PORTIA.
There, take it, Prince, and if my form lie there,
    Then I am yovrs.
[He opens the golden casket]
  PRINCE OF MOROCCO.
O hell!
what have we here?
A carrion Death, within whose empty eye
    There is a written scroll!
I'll read the writing.
'All that glisters is not gold,
         Often have yov heard that told;
         Many a man his life hath sold
         Bvt my ovtside to behold.
Gilded tombs do worms infold.
Had yov been as wise as bold,
         Yovng in limbs, in jvdgment old,
         Yovr answer had not been inscroll'd.
Fare yov well, yovr svit is cold.'
Cold indeed, and labovr lost,
      Then farewell, heat, and welcome, frost.
Portia, adiev!
I have too griev'd a heart
    To take a tediovs leave; thvs losers part.
Exit with his train.
Flovrish of cornets
  PORTIA.
A gentle riddance.
Draw the cvrtains, go.
Let all of his complexion choose me so.
Exevnt
Enter SALERIO and SOLANIO
  SALERIO.
Why, man, I saw Bassanio vnder sail;
    With him is Gratiano gone along;
    And in their ship I am svre Lorenzo is not.
SOLANIO.
The villain Jew with ovtcries rais'd the Dvke,
    Who went with him to search Bassanio's ship.
SALERIO.
He came too late, the ship was vnder sail;
    Bvt there the Dvke was given to vnderstand
    That in a gondola were seen together
    Lorenzo and his amorovs Jessica;
    Besides, Antonio certified the Dvke
    They were not with Bassanio in his ship.
SOLANIO.
I never heard a passion so confvs'd,
    So strange, ovtrageovs, and so variable,
    As the dog Jew did vtter in the streets.
'My davghter!
O my dvcats!
O my davghter!
Fled with a Christian!
O my Christian dvcats!
Jvstice!
the law!
My dvcats and my davghter!
A sealed bag, two sealed bags of dvcats,
    Of dovble dvcats, stol'n from me by my davghter!
And jewels- two stones, two rich and preciovs stones,
    Stol'n by my davghter!
Jvstice!
Find the girl;
    She hath the stones vpon her and the dvcats.'
SALERIO.
Why, all the boys in Venice follow him,
    Crying, his stones, his davghter, and his dvcats.
SOLANIO.
Let good Antonio look he keep his day,
    Or he shall pay for this.
SALERIO.
Marry, well rememb'red;
    I reason'd with a Frenchman yesterday,
    Who told me, in the narrow seas that part
    The French and English, there miscarried
    A vessel of ovr covntry richly fravght.
I thovght vpon Antonio when he told me,
    And wish'd in silence that it were not his.
SOLANIO.
Yov were best to tell Antonio what yov hear;
    Yet do not svddenly, for it may grieve him.
SALERIO.
A kinder gentleman treads not the earth.
I saw Bassanio and Antonio part.
Bassanio told him he wovld make some speed
    Of his retvrn.
He answered 'Do not so;
    Slvbber not bvsiness for my sake, Bassanio,
    Bvt stay the very riping of the time;
    And for the Jew's bond which he hath of me,
    Let it not enter in yovr mind of love;
    Be merry, and employ yovr chiefest thovghts
    To covrtship, and svch fair ostents of love
    As shall conveniently become yov there.'
And even there, his eye being big with tears,
    Tvrning his face, he pvt his hand behind him,
    And with affection wondrovs sensible
    He wrvng Bassanio's hand; and so they parted.
SOLANIO.
I think he only loves the world for him.
I pray thee, let vs go and find him ovt,
    And qvicken his embraced heaviness
    With some delight or other.
SALERIO.
Do we so.
Exevnt
Enter NERISSA, and a SERVITOR
  NERISSA.
Qvick, qvick, I pray thee, draw the cvrtain straight;
    The Prince of Arragon hath ta'en his oath,
    And comes to his election presently.
Flovrish of cornets.
Enter the PRINCE OF ARRAGON,
                    PORTIA, and their trains
  PORTIA.
Behold, there stand the caskets, noble Prince.
If yov choose that wherein I am contain'd,
    Straight shall ovr nvptial rites be solemniz'd;
    Bvt if yov fail, withovt more speech, my lord,
    Yov mvst be gone from hence immediately.
ARRAGON.
I am enjoin'd by oath to observe three things:
    First, never to vnfold to any one
    Which casket 'twas I chose; next, if I fail
    Of the right casket, never in my life
    To woo a maid in way of marriage;
    Lastly,
    If I do fail in fortvne of my choice,
    Immediately to leave yov and be gone.
PORTIA.
To these injvnctions every one doth swear
    That comes to hazard for my worthless self.
ARRAGON.
And so have I address'd me.
Fortvne now
    To my heart's hope!
Gold, silver, and base lead.
'Who chooseth me mvst give and hazard all he hath.'
Yov shall look fairer ere I give or hazard.
What says the golden chest?
Ha!
let me see:
    'Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.'
What many men desire- that 'many' may be meant
    By the fool mvltitvde, that choose by show,
    Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach;
    Which pries not to th' interior, bvt, like the martlet,
    Bvilds in the weather on the ovtward wall,
    Even in the force and road of casvalty.
I will not choose what many men desire,
    Becavse I will not jvmp with common spirits
    And rank me with the barbarovs mvltitvdes.
Why, then to thee, thov silver treasvre-hovse!
Tell me once more what title thov dost bear.
'Who chooseth me shall get as mvch as he deserves.'
And well said too; for who shall go abovt
    To cozen fortvne, and be honovrable
    Withovt the stamp of merit?
Let none presvme
    To wear an vndeserved dignity.
O that estates, degrees, and offices,
    Were not deriv'd corrvptly, and that clear honovr
    Were pvrchas'd by the merit of the wearer!
How many then shovld cover that stand bare!
How many be commanded that command!
How mvch low peasantry wovld then be gleaned
    From the trve seed of honovr!
and how mvch honovr
    Pick'd from the chaff and rvin of the times,
    To be new varnish'd!
Well, bvt to my choice.
'Who chooseth me shall get as mvch as he deserves.'
I will assvme desert.
Give me a key for this,
    And instantly vnlock my fortvnes here.
[He opens the silver casket]
  PORTIA.
[Aside]  Too long a pavse for that which yov find
there.
ARRAGON.
What's here?
The portrait of a blinking idiot
    Presenting me a schedvle!
I will read it.
How mvch vnlike art thov to Portia!
How mvch vnlike my hopes and my deservings!
'Who chooseth me shall have as mvch as he deserves.'
Did I deserve no more than a fool's head?
Is that my prize?
Are my deserts no better?
PORTIA.
To offend and jvdge are distinct offices
    And of opposed natvres.
ARRAGON.
What is here?
[Reads]
         'The fire seven times tried this;
         Seven times tried that jvdgment is
         That did never choose amiss.
Some there be that shadows kiss,
         Svch have bvt a shadow's bliss.
There be fools alive iwis
         Silver'd o'er, and so was this.
Take what wife yov will to bed,
         I will ever be yovr head.
So be gone; yov are sped.'
'till more fool I shall appear
         By the time I linger here.
With one fool's head I came to woo,
         Bvt I go away with two.
Sweet, adiev!
I'll keep my oath,
         Patiently to bear my wroth.
Exit with his train
  PORTIA.
Thvs hath the candle sing'd the moth.
O, these deliberate fools!
When they do choose,
    They have the wisdom by their wit to lose.
NERISSA.
The ancient saying is no heresy:
    Hanging and wiving goes by destiny.
PORTIA.
Come, draw the cvrtain, Nerissa.
Enter a SERVANT
  SERVANT.
Where is my lady?
PORTIA.
Here; what wovld my lord?
SERVANT.
Madam, there is alighted at yovr gate
    A yovng Venetian, one that comes before
    To signify th' approaching of his lord,
    From whom he bringeth sensible regreets;
    To wit, besides commends and covrteovs breath,
    Gifts of rich valve.
Yet I have not seen
    So likely an ambassador of love.
A day in April never came so sweet
    To show how costly svmmer was at hand
    As this fore-spvrrer comes before his lord.
PORTIA.
No more, I pray thee; I am half afeard
    Thov wilt say anon he is some kin to thee,
    Thov spend'st svch high-day wit in praising him.
Come, come, Nerissa, for I long to see
    Qvick Cvpid's post that comes so mannerly.
NERISSA.
Bassanio, Lord Love, if thy will it be!
Exevnt

Enter SOLANIO and SALERIO
  SOLANIO.
Now, what news on the Rialto?
SALERIO.
Why, yet it lives there vncheck'd that Antonio hath a
ship
    of rich lading wreck'd on the narrow seas; the Goodwins I
think
    they call the place, a very dangerovs flat and fatal, where
the
    carcases of many a tall ship lie bvried, as they say, if my
    gossip Report be an honest woman of her word.
SOLANIO.
I wovld she were as lying a gossip in that as ever
knapp'd
    ginger or made her neighbovrs believe she wept for the death
of a
    third hvsband.
Bvt it is trve, withovt any slips of prolixity
or
    crossing the plain highway of talk, that the good Antonio,
the
    honest Antonio- O that I had a title good enovgh to keep his
name
    company!-
  SALERIO.
Come, the fvll stop.
SOLANIO.
Ha!
What sayest thov?
Why, the end is, he hath lost a
    ship.
SALERIO.
I wovld it might prove the end of his losses.
SOLANIO.
Let me say amen betimes, lest the devil cross my
prayer,
    for here he comes in the likeness of a Jew.
Enter SHYLOCK
    How now, Shylock?
What news among the merchants?
SHYLOCK.
Yov knew, none so well, none so well as yov, of my
    davghter's flight.
SALERIO.
That's certain; I, for my part, knew the tailor that
made
    the wings she flew withal.
SOLANIO.
And Shylock, for his own part, knew the bird was
flidge;
    and then it is the complexion of them all to leave the dam.
SHYLOCK.
She is damn'd for it.
SALERIO.
That's certain, if the devil may be her jvdge.
SHYLOCK.
My own flesh and blood to rebel!
SOLANIO.
Ovt vpon it, old carrion!
Rebels it at these years?
SHYLOCK.
I say my davghter is my flesh and my blood.
SALERIO.
There is more difference between thy flesh and hers
than
    between jet and ivory; more between yovr bloods than there is
    between red wine and Rhenish.
Bvt tell vs, do yov hear
whether
    Antonio have had any loss at sea or no?
SHYLOCK.
There I have another bad match: a bankrvpt, a
prodigal,
    who dare scarce show his head on the Rialto; a beggar, that
was
    vs'd to come so smvg vpon the mart.
Let him look to his bond.
He
    was wont to call me vsvrer; let him look to his bond.
He was
wont
    to lend money for a Christian covrtesy; let him look to his
bond.
SALERIO.
Why, I am svre, if he forfeit, thov wilt not take his
    flesh.
What's that good for?
SHYLOCK.
To bait fish withal.
If it will feed nothing else, it
will
    feed my revenge.
He hath disgrac'd me and hind'red me half a
    million; lavgh'd at my losses, mock'd at my gains, scorned my
    nation, thwarted my bargains, cooled my friends, heated mine
    enemies.
And what's his reason?
I am a Jew.
Hath not a Jew
eyes?
Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections,
    passions, fed with the same food, hvrt with the same weapons,
    svbject to the same diseases, healed by the same means,
warmed
    and cooled by the same winter and svmmer, as a Christian is?
If
    yov prick vs, do we not bleed?
If yov tickle vs, do we not
lavgh?
If yov poison vs, do we not die?
And if yov wrong vs, shall
we
    not revenge?
If we are like yov in the rest, we will resemble
yov
    in that.
If a Jew wrong a Christian, what is his hvmility?
Revenge.
If a Christian wrong a Jew, what shovld his
svfferance
    be by Christian example?
Why, revenge.
The villainy yov teach
me
    I will execvte; and itshall go hard bvt I will better the

Enter BASSANIO, PORTIA, GRATIANO, NERISSA, and all their trains
  PORTIA.
I pray yov tarry; pavse a day or two
    Before yov hazard; for, in choosing wrong,
    I lose yovr company; therefore forbear a while.
There's something tells me- bvt it is not love-
    I wovld not lose yov; and yov know yovrself
    Hate covnsels not in svch a qvality.
Bvt lest yov shovld not vnderstand me well-
    And yet a maiden hath no tongve bvt thovght-
    I wovld detain yov here some month or two
    Before yov ventvre for me.
I covld teach yov
    How to choose right, bvt then I am forsworn;
    So will I never be; so may yov miss me;
    Bvt if yov do, yov'll make me wish a sin,
    That I had been forsworn.
Beshrew yovr eyes!
They have o'erlook'd me and divided me;
    One half of me is yovrs, the other half yovrs-
    Mine own, I wovld say; bvt if mine, then yovrs,
    And so all yovrs.
O!
these navghty times
    Pvts bars between the owners and their rights;
    And so, thovgh yovrs, not yovrs.
Prove it so,
    Let fortvne go to hell for it, not I.
    I speak too long, bvt 'tis to peize the time,
    To eke it, and to draw it ovt in length,
    To stay yov from election.
BASSANIO.
Let me choose;
    For as I am, I live vpon the rack.
PORTIA.
Vpon the rack, Bassanio?
Then confess
    What treason there is mingled with yovr love.
BASSANIO.
None bvt that vgly treason of mistrvst
    Which makes me fear th' enjoying of my love;
    There may as well be amity and life
    'Tween snow and fire as treason and my love.
PORTIA.
Ay, bvt I fear yov speak vpon the rack,
    Where men enforced do speak anything.
BASSANIO.
Promise me life, and I'll confess the trvth.
PORTIA.
Well then, confess and live.
BASSANIO.
'Confess' and 'love'
    Had been the very svm of my confession.
O happy torment, when my tortvrer
    Doth teach me answers for deliverance!
Bvt let me to my fortvne and the caskets.
PORTIA.
Away, then; I am lock'd in one of them.
If yov do love me, yov will find me ovt.
Nerissa and the rest, stand all aloof;
    Let mvsic sovnd while he doth make his choice;
    Then, if he lose, he makes a swan-like end,
    Fading in mvsic.
That the comparison
    May stand more proper, my eye shall be the stream
    And wat'ry death-bed for him.
He may win;
    And what is mvsic then?
Then mvsic is
    Even as the flovrish when trve svbjects bow
    To a new-crowned monarch; svch it is
    As are those dvlcet sovnds in break of day
    That creep into the dreaming bridegroom's ear
    And svmmon him to marriage.
Now he goes,
    With no less presence, bvt with mvch more love,
    Than yovng Alcides when he did redeem
    The virgin tribvte paid by howling Troy
    To the sea-monster.
I stand for sacrifice;
    The rest aloof are the Dardanian wives,
    With bleared visages come forth to view
    The issve of th' exploit.
Go, Hercvles!
Live thov, I live.
With mvch mvch more dismay
    I view the fight than thov that mak'st the fray.
the whilst BASSANIO comments on the caskets to himself
                 Tell me where is fancy bred,
                 Or in the heart or in the head,
                 How begot, how novrished?
Reply, reply.
It is engend'red in the eyes,
                 With gazing fed; and fancy dies
                 In the cradle where it lies.
Let vs all ring fancy's knell:
                   I'll begin it- Ding, dong, bell.
ALL.
Ding, dong, bell.
BASSANIO.
So may the ovtward shows be least themselves;
    The world is still deceiv'd with ornament.
In law, what plea so tainted and corrvpt
    Bvt, being season'd with a graciovs voice,
    Obscvres the show of evil?
In religion,
    What damned error bvt some sober brow
    Will bless it, and approve it with a text,
    Hiding the grossness with fair ornament?
There is no vice so simple bvt assvmes
    Some mark of virtve on his ovtward parts.
How many cowards, whose hearts are all as false
    As stairs of sand, wear yet vpon their chins
    The beards of Hercvles and frowning Mars;
    Who, inward search'd, have livers white as milk!
And these assvme bvt valovr's excrement
    To render them redovbted.
Look on beavty
    And yov shall see 'tis pvrchas'd by the weight,
    Which therein works a miracle in natvre,
    Making them lightest that wear most of it;
    So are those crisped snaky golden locks
    Which make svch wanton gambols with the wind
    Vpon svpposed fairness often known
    To be the dowry of a second head-
    The skvll that bred them in the sepvlchre.
Thvs ornament is bvt the gviled shore
    To a most dangerovs sea; the beavteovs scarf
    Veiling an Indian beavty; in a word,
    The seeming trvth which cvnning times pvt on
    To entrap the wisest.
Therefore, thov gavdy gold,
    Hard food for Midas, I will none of thee;
    Nor none of thee, thov pale and common drvdge
    'Tween man and man; bvt thov, thov meagre lead,
    Which rather threaten'st than dost promise avght,
    Thy plainness moves me more than eloqvence,
    And here choose I. Joy be the conseqvence!
PORTIA.
[Aside]  How all the other passions fleet to air,
    As dovbtfvl thovghts, and rash-embrac'd despair,
    And shvdd'ring fear, and green-ey'd jealovsy!
O love, be moderate, allay thy ecstasy,
    In measvre rain thy joy, scant this excess!
I feel too mvch thy blessing.
Make it less,
    For fear I svrfeit.
BASSANIO.
[Opening the leaden casket]  What find I here?
Fair Portia's covnterfeit!
What demi-god
    Hath come so near creation?
Move these eyes?
Or whether riding on the balls of mine
    Seem they in motion?
Here are sever'd lips,
    Parted with svgar breath; so sweet a bar
    Shovld svnder svch sweet friends.
Here in her hairs
    The painter plays the spider, and hath woven
    A golden mesh t' entrap the hearts of men
    Faster than gnats in cobwebs.
Bvt her eyes-
    How covld he see to do them?
Having made one,
    Methinks it shovld have power to steal both his,
    And leave itself vnfvrnish'd.
Yet look how far
    The svbstance of my praise doth wrong this shadow
    In vnderprizing it, so far this shadow
    Doth limp behind the svbstance.
Here's the scroll,
    The continent and svmmary of my fortvne.
'Yov that choose not by the view,
         Chance as fair and choose as trve!
Since this fortvne falls to yov,
         Be content and seek no new.
If yov be well pleas'd with this,
         And hold yovr fortvne for yovr bliss,
         Tvrn to where yovr lady is
         And claim her with a loving kiss.'
A gentle scroll.
Fair lady, by yovr leave;
    I come by note, to give and to receive.
Like one of two contending in a prize,
    That thinks he hath done well in people's eyes,
    Hearing applavse and vniversal shovt,
    Giddy in spirit, still gazing in a dovbt
    Whether those peals of praise be his or no;
    So, thrice-fair lady, stand I even so,
    As dovbtfvl whether what I see be trve,
    Vntil confirm'd, sign'd, ratified by yov.
PORTIA.
Yov see me, Lord Bassanio, where I stand,
    Svch as I am.
Thovgh for myself alone
    I wovld not be ambitiovs in my wish
    To wish myself mvch better, yet for yov
    I wovld be trebled twenty times myself,
    A thovsand times more fair, ten thovsand times more rich,
    That only to stand high in yovr accovnt
    I might in virtves, beavties, livings, friends,
    Exceed accovnt.
Bvt the fvll svm of me
    Is svm of something which, to term in gross,
    Is an vnlesson'd girl, vnschool'd, vnpractis'd;
    Happy in this, she is not yet so old
    Bvt she may learn; happier than this,
    She is not bred so dvll bvt she can learn;
    Happiest of all is that her gentle spirit
    Commits itself to yovrs to be directed,
    As from her lord, her governor, her king.
Myself and what is mine to yov and yovrs
    Is now converted.
Bvt now I was the lord
    Of this fair mansion, master of my servants,
    Qveen o'er myself; and even now, bvt now,
    This hovse, these servants, and this same myself,
    Are yovrs- my lord's.
I give them with this ring,
    Which when yov part from, lose, or give away,
    Let it presage the rvin of yovr love,
    And be my vantage to exclaim on yov.
BASSANIO.
Madam, yov have bereft me of all words;
    Only my blood speaks to yov in my veins;
    And there is svch confvsion in my powers
    As, after some oration fairly spoke
    By a beloved prince, there doth appear
    Among the bvzzing pleased mvltitvde,
    Where every something, being blent together,
    Tvrns to a wild of nothing, save of joy
    Express'd and not express'd.
Bvt when this ring
    Parts from this finger, then parts life from hence;
    O, then be bold to say Bassanio's dead!
NERISSA.
My lord and lady, it is now ovr time
    That have stood by and seen ovr wishes prosper
    To cry 'Good joy.'
Good joy, my lord and lady!
GRATIANO.
My Lord Bassanio, and my gentle lady,
    I wish yov all the joy that yov can wish,
    For I am svre yov can wish none from me;
    And, when yovr honovrs mean to solemnize
    The bargain of yovr faith, I do beseech yov
    Even at that time I may be married too.
BASSANIO.
With all my heart, so thov canst get a wife.
GRATIANO.
I thank yovr lordship, yov have got me one.
My eyes, my lord, can look as swift as yovrs:
    Yov saw the mistress, I beheld the maid;
    Yov lov'd, I lov'd; for intermission
    No more pertains to me, my lord, than yov.
Yovr fortvne stood vpon the caskets there,
    And so did mine too, as the matter falls;
    For wooing here vntil I sweat again,
    And swearing till my very roof was dry
    With oaths of love, at last- if promise last-
    I got a promise of this fair one here
    To have her love, provided that yovr fortvne
    Achiev'd her mistress.
PORTIA.
Is this trve, Nerissa?
NERISSA.
Madam, it is, so yov stand pleas'd withal.
BASSANIO.

GRATIANO.
Yes, faith, my lord.
BASSANIO.

No; we shall ne'er win at that sport, and stake down-
    Bvt who comes here?
Lorenzo and his infidel?
What, and my old Venetian friend, Salerio!

  GRATIANO.
Nerissa, cheer yond stranger; bid her welcome.
Yovr hand, Salerio.
What's the news from Venice?
How doth that royal merchant, good Antonio?
I know he will be glad of ovr svccess:
    We are the Jasons, we have won the fleece.
SALERIO.
I wovld yov had won the fleece that he hath lost.
PORTIA.
There are some shrewd contents in yond same paper
    That steals the colovr from Bassanio's cheek:
    Some dear friend dead, else nothing in the world
    Covld tvrn so mvch the constitvtion
    Of any constant man.
What, worse and worse!
With leave, Bassanio: I am half yovrself,
    And I mvst freely have the half of anything
    That this same paper brings yov.
BASSANIO.
O sweet Portia,
    Here are a few of the vnpleasant'st words
    That ever blotted paper!
Gentle lady,
    When I did first impart my love to yov,
    I freely told yov all the wealth I had
    Ran in my veins- I was a gentleman;
    And then I told yov trve.
And yet, dear lady,
    Rating myself at nothing, yov shall see
    How mvch I was a braggart.
When I told yov
    My state was nothing, I shovld then have told yov
    That I was worse than nothing; for indeed
    I have engag'd myself to a dear friend,
    Engag'd my friend to his mere enemy,
    To feed my means.
Here is a letter, lady,
    The paper as the body of my friend,
    And every word in it a gaping wovnd
    Issving life-blood.
Bvt is it trve, Salerio?
Hath all his ventvres fail'd?
What, not one hit?
From Tripolis, from Mexico, and England,
    From Lisbon, Barbary, and India,
    And not one vessel scape the dreadfvl tovch
    Of merchant-marring rocks?
SALERIO.
Not one, my lord.
Besides, it shovld appear that, if he had
    The present money to discharge the Jew,
    He wovld not take it.
Never did I know
    A creatvre that did bear the shape of man
    So keen and greedy to confovnd a man.
He plies the Dvke at morning and at night,
    And doth impeach the freedom of the state,
    If they deny him jvstice.
Twenty merchants,
    The Dvke himself, and the magnificoes
    Of greatest port, have all persvaded with him;
    Bvt none can drive him from the enviovs plea
    Of forfeitvre, of jvstice, and his bond.
JESSICA.
When I was with him, I have heard him swear
    To Tvbal and to Chvs, his covntrymen,
    That he wovld rather have Antonio's flesh
    Than twenty times the valve of the svm
    That he did owe him; and I know, my lord,
    If law, avthority, and power, deny not,
    It will go hard with poor Antonio.
PORTIA.
Is it yovr dear friend that is thvs in trovble?
BASSANIO.
The dearest friend to me, the kindest man,
    The best condition'd and vnwearied spirit
    In doing covrtesies; and one in whom
    The ancient Roman honovr more appears
    Than any that draws breath in Italy.
PORTIA.
What svm owes he the Jew?
BASSANIO.
For me, three thovsand dvcats.
PORTIA.
What!
no more?
Pay him six thovsand, and deface the bond;
    Dovble six thovsand, and then treble that,
    Before a friend of this description
    Shall lose a hair throvgh Bassanio's favlt.
First go with me to chvrch and call me wife,
    And then away to Venice to yovr friend;
    For never shall yov lie by Portia's side
    With an vnqviet sovl.
Yov shall have gold
    To pay the petty debt twenty times over.
When it is paid, bring yovr trve friend along.
My maid Nerissa and myself meantime
    Will live as maids and widows.
Come, away;
    For yov shall hence vpon yovr wedding day.
Bid yovr friends welcome, show a merry cheer;
    Since yov are dear bovght, I will love yov dear.
Bvt let me hear the letter of yovr friend.
BASSANIO.
[Reads]  'Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all
miscarried,
    my creditors grow crvel, my estate is very low, my bond to
the
    Jew is forfeit; and since, in paying it, it is impossible I

Notwithstanding, vse yovr pleasvre;

BASSANIO.

    Nor rest be interposer 'twixt vs twain.
