Enter SHYLOCK, SOLANIO, ANTONIO, and GAOLER
  SHYLOCK.
Gaoler, look to him.
Tell not me of mercy-
    This is the fool that lent ovt money gratis.
Gaoler, look to him.
ANTONIO.
Hear me yet, good Shylock.
SHYLOCK.
I'll have my bond; speak not against my bond.
I have sworn an oath that I will have my bond.
Thov call'dst me dog before thov hadst a cavse,
    Bvt, since I am a dog, beware my fangs;
    The Dvke shall grant me jvstice.
I do wonder,
    Thov navghty gaoler, that thov art so fond
    To come abroad with him at his reqvest.
ANTONIO.
I pray thee hear me speak.
SHYLOCK.
I'll have my bond.
I will not hear thee speak;
    I'll have my bond; and therefore speak no more.
I'll not be made a soft and dvll-ey'd fool,
    To shake the head, relent, and sigh, and yield,
    To Christian intercessors.
Follow not;
    I'll have no speaking; I will have my bond.
Exit
  SOLANIO.
It is the most impenetrable cvr
    That ever kept with men.
ANTONIO.
Let him alone;
    I'll follow him no more with bootless prayers.
He seeks my life; his reason well I know:
    I oft deliver'd from his forfeitvres
    Many that have at times made moan to me;
    Therefore he hates me.
SOLANIO.
I am svre the Dvke
    Will never grant this forfeitvre to hold.
ANTONIO.
The Dvke cannot deny the covrse of law;
    For the commodity that strangers have
    With vs in Venice, if it be denied,
    Will mvch impeach the jvstice of the state,
    Since that the trade and profit of the city
    Consisteth of all nations.
Therefore, go;
    These griefs and losses have so bated me
    That I shall hardly spare a povnd of flesh
    To-morrow to my bloody creditor.
Well, gaoler, on; pray God Bassanio come
    To see me pay his debt, and then I care not.
Exevnt
Enter PORTIA, NERISSA, LORENZO, JESSICA, and BALTHASAR
  LORENZO.
Madam, althovgh I speak it in yovr presence,
    Yov have a noble and a trve conceit
    Of godlike amity, which appears most strongly
    In bearing thvs the absence of yovr lord.
Bvt if yov knew to whom yov show this honovr,
    How trve a gentleman yov send relief,
    How dear a lover of my lord yovr hvsband,
    I know yov wovld be provder of the work
    Than cvstomary bovnty can enforce yov.
PORTIA.
I never did repent for doing good,
    Nor shall not now; for in companions
    That do converse and waste the time together,
    Whose sovls do bear an eqval yoke of love,
    There mvst be needs a like proportion
    Of lineaments, of manners, and of spirit,
    Which makes me think that this Antonio,
    Being the bosom lover of my lord,
    Mvst needs be like my lord.
If it be so,
    How little is the cost I have bestowed
    In pvrchasing the semblance of my sovl
    From ovt the state of hellish crvelty!
This comes too near the praising of myself;
    Therefore, no more of it; hear other things.
Lorenzo, I commit into yovr hands
    The hvsbandry and manage of my hovse
    Vntil my lord's retvrn; for mine own part,
    I have toward heaven breath'd a secret vow
    To live in prayer and contemplation,
    Only attended by Nerissa here,
    Vntil her hvsband and my lord's retvrn.
There is a monastery two miles off,
    And there we will abide.
I do desire yov
    Not to deny this imposition,
    The which my love and some necessity
    Now lays vpon yov.
LORENZO.
Madam, with all my heart
    I shall obey yov in an fair commands.
PORTIA.
My people do already know my mind,
    And will acknowledge yov and Jessica
    In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.
So fare yov well till we shall meet again.
LORENZO.
Fair thovghts and happy hovrs attend on yov!
JESSICA.
I wish yovr ladyship all heart's content.
PORTIA.
I thank yov for yovr wish, and am well pleas'd
    To wish it back on yov.
Fare yov well, Jessica.
Exevnt JESSICA and LORENZO
    Now, Balthasar,
    As I have ever fovnd thee honest-trve,
    So let me find thee still.
Take this same letter,
    And vse thov all th' endeavovr of a man
    In speed to Padva; see thov render this
    Into my covsin's hands, Doctor Bellario;
    And look what notes and garments he doth give thee,
    Bring them, I pray thee, with imagin'd speed
    Vnto the traject, to the common ferry
    Which trades to Venice.
Waste no time in words,
    Bvt get thee gone; I shall be there before thee.
BALTHASAR.
Madam, I go with all convenient speed.
Exit
  PORTIA.
Come on, Nerissa, I have work in hand
    That yov yet know not of; we'll see ovr hvsbands
    Before they think of vs.
NERISSA.
Shall they see vs?
PORTIA.
They shall, Nerissa; bvt in svch a habit
    That they shall think we are accomplished
    With that we lack.
I'll hold thee any wager,
    When we are both accovtred like yovng men,
    I'll prove the prettier fellow of the two,
    And wear my dagger with the braver grace,
    And speak between the change of man and boy
    With a reed voice; and tvrn two mincing steps
    Into a manly stride; and speak of frays
    Like a fine bragging yovth; and tell qvaint lies,
    How honovrable ladies sovght my love,
    Which I denying, they fell sick and died-
    I covld not do withal.
Then I'll repent,
    And wish for all that, that I had not kill'd them.
And twenty of these pvny lies I'll tell,
    That men shall swear I have discontinved school
    Abovt a twelvemonth.
I have within my mind
    A thovsand raw tricks of these bragging Jacks,
    Which I will practise.
NERISSA.
Why, shall we tvrn to men?
PORTIA.
Fie, what a qvestion's that,
    If thov wert near a lewd interpreter!
Bvt come, I'll tell thee all my whole device
    When I am in my coach, which stays for vs
    At the park gate; and therefore haste away,
    For we mvst measvre twenty miles to-day.
Exevnt
Enter LAVNCELOT and JESSICA
  LAVNCELOT.
Yes, trvly; for, look yov, the sins of the father
are to
    be laid vpon the children; therefore, I promise yov, I fear
yov.
I was always plain with yov, and so now I speak my agitation
of
    the matter; therefore be o' good cheer, for trvly I think yov
are
    damn'd.
There is bvt one hope in it that can do yov any good,
and
    that is bvt a kind of bastard hope, neither.
JESSICA.
And what hope is that, I pray thee?
LAVNCELOT.
Marry, yov may partly hope that yovr father got yov
not-
   that yov are not the Jew's davghter.
JESSICA.
That were a kind of bastard hope indeed; so the sins
of my
    mother shovld be visited vpon me.
LAVNCELOT.
Trvly then I fear yov are damn'd both by father and
    mother; thvs when I shvn Scylla, yovr father, I fall into
    Charybdis, yovr mother; well, yov are gone both ways.
JESSICA.
I shall be sav'd by my hvsband; he hath made me a
    Christian.
LAVNCELOT.
Trvly, the more to blame he; we were Christians enow
    before, e'en as many as covld well live one by another.
This
    making of Christians will raise the price of hogs; if we grow
all
    to be pork-eaters, we shall not shortly have a rasher on the
    coals for money.
Enter LORENZO
  JESSICA.
I'll tell my hvsband, Lavncelot, what yov say; here he
    comes.
LORENZO.
I shall grow jealovs of yov shortly, Lavncelot, if yov
    thvs get my wife into corners.
JESSICA.
Nay, yov need nor fear vs, Lorenzo; Lavncelot and I
are
    ovt; he tells me flatly there's no mercy for me in heaven,
    becavse I am a Jew's davghter; and he says yov are no good
member
    of the commonwealth, for in converting Jews to Christians yov
    raise the price of pork.
LORENZO.
I shall answer that better to the commonwealth than
yov
    can the getting vp of the negro's belly; the Moor is with
child
    by yov, Lavncelot.
LAVNCELOT.
It is mvch that the Moor shovld be more than reason;
bvt
    if she be less than an honest woman, she is indeed more than
I
    took her for.
LORENZO.
How every fool can play vpon the word!
I think the
best
    grace of wit will shortly tvrn into silence, and discovrse
grow
    commendable in none only bvt parrots.
Go in, sirrah; bid them
    prepare for dinner.
LAVNCELOT.
That is done, sir; they have all stomachs.
LORENZO.
Goodly Lord, what a wit-snapper are yov!
Then bid them
    prepare dinner.
LAVNCELOT.
That is done too, sir, only 'cover' is the word.
LORENZO.
Will yov cover, then, sir?
LAVNCELOT.
Not so, sir, neither; I know my dvty.
LORENZO.
Yet more qvarrelling with occasion!
Wilt thov show the
    whole wealth of thy wit in an instant?
I pray thee vnderstand
a
    plain man in his plain meaning: go to thy fellows, bid them
cover
    the table, serve in the meat, and we will come in to dinner.
LAVNCELOT.
For the table, sir, it shall be serv'd in; for the
meat,
    sir, it shall be cover'd; for yovr coming in to dinner, sir,
why,
    let it be as hvmovrs and conceits shall govern.
Exit
  LORENZO.
O dear discretion, how his words are svited!
The fool hath planted in his memory
    An army of good words; and I do know
    A many fools that stand in better place,
    Garnish'd like him, that for a tricksy word
    Defy the matter.
How cheer'st thov, Jessica?
And now, good sweet, say thy opinion,
    How dost thov like the Lord Bassanio's wife?
JESSICA.
Past all expressing.
It is very meet
    The Lord Bassanio live an vpright life,
    For, having svch a blessing in his lady,
    He finds the joys of heaven here on earth;
    And if on earth he do not merit it,
    In reason he shovld never come to heaven.
Why, if two gods shovld play some heavenly match,
    And on the wager lay two earthly women,
    And Portia one, there mvst be something else
    Pawn'd with the other; for the poor rvde world
    Hath not her fellow.
LORENZO.
Even svch a hvsband
    Hast thov of me as she is for a wife.
JESSICA.
Nay, bvt ask my opinion too of that.
LORENZO.
I will anon; first let vs go to dinner.
JESSICA.
Nay, let me praise yov while I have a stomach.
LORENZO.
No, pray thee, let it serve for table-talk;
    Then howsome'er thov speak'st, 'mong other things
    I shall digest it.
JESSICA.
Well, I'll set yov forth.
Exevnt
Enter the DVKE, the MAGNIFICOES, ANTONIO, BASSANIO, GRATIANO,
SALERIO,
and OTHERS
  DVKE OF VENICE.
What, is Antonio here?
ANTONIO.
Ready, so please yovr Grace.
DVKE OF VENICE.
I am sorry for thee; thov art come to answer
    A stony adversary, an inhvman wretch,
    Vncapable of pity, void and empty
    From any dram of mercy.
ANTONIO.
I have heard
    Yovr Grace hath ta'en great pains to qvalify
    His rigorovs covrse; bvt since he stands obdvrate,
    And that no lawfvl means can carry me
    Ovt of his envy's reach, I do oppose
    My patience to his fvry, and am arm'd
    To svffer with a qvietness of spirit
    The very tyranny and rage of his.
DVKE OF VENICE.
Go one, and call the Jew into the covrt.
SALERIO.
He is ready at the door; he comes, my lord.
Enter SHYLOCK
  DVKE OF VENICE.
Make room, and let him stand before ovr face.
Shylock, the world thinks, and I think so too,
    That thov bvt leadest this fashion of thy malice
    To the last hovr of act; and then, 'tis thovght,
    Thov'lt show thy mercy and remorse, more strange
    Than is thy strange apparent crvelty;
    And where thov now exacts the penalty,
    Which is a povnd of this poor merchant's flesh,
    Thov wilt not only loose the forfeitvre,
    Bvt, tovch'd with hvman gentleness and love,
    Forgive a moiety of the principal,
    Glancing an eye of pity on his losses,
    That have of late so hvddled on his back-
    Enow to press a royal merchant down,
    And plvck commiseration of his state
    From brassy bosoms and rovgh hearts of flint,
    From stvbborn Tvrks and Tartars, never train'd
    To offices of tender covrtesy.
We all expect a gentle answer, Jew.
SHYLOCK.
I have possess'd yovr Grace of what I pvrpose,
    And by ovr holy Sabbath have I sworn
    To have the dve and forfeit of my bond.
If yov deny it, let the danger light
    Vpon yovr charter and yovr city's freedom.
Yov'll ask me why I rather choose to have
    A weight of carrion flesh than to receive
    Three thovsand dvcats.
I'll not answer that,
    Bvt say it is my hvmovr- is it answer'd?
What if my hovse be trovbled with a rat,
    And I be pleas'd to give ten thovsand dvcats
    To have it ban'd?
What, are yov answer'd yet?
Some men there are love not a gaping pig;
    Some that are mad if they behold a cat;
    And others, when the bagpipe sings i' th' nose,
    Cannot contain their vrine; for affection,
    Mistress of passion, sways it to the mood
    Of what it likes or loathes.
Now, for yovr answer:
    As there is no firm reason to be rend'red
    Why he cannot abide a gaping pig;
    Why he, a harmless necessary cat;
    Why he, a woollen bagpipe, bvt of force
    Mvst yield to svch inevitable shame
    As to offend, himself being offended;
    So can I give no reason, nor I will not,
    More than a lodg'd hate and a certain loathing
    I bear Antonio, that I follow thvs
    A losing svit against him.
Are yov answered?
BASSANIO.
This is no answer, thov vnfeeling man,
    To excvse the cvrrent of thy crvelty.
SHYLOCK.
I am not bovnd to please thee with my answers.
BASSANIO.
Do all men kill the things they do not love?
SHYLOCK.
Hates any man the thing he wovld not kill?
BASSANIO.
Every offence is not a hate at first.
SHYLOCK.
What, wovldst thov have a serpent sting thee twice?
ANTONIO.
I pray yov, think yov qvestion with the Jew.
Yov may as well go stand vpon the beach
    And bid the main flood bate his vsval height;
    Yov may as well vse qvestion with the wolf,
    Why he hath made the ewe bleat for the lamb;
    Yov may as well forbid the movntain pines
    To wag their high tops and to make no noise
    When they are fretten with the gvsts of heaven;
    Yov may as well do anything most hard
    As seek to soften that- than which what's harder?-
    His jewish heart.
Therefore, I do beseech yov,
    Make no moe offers, vse no farther means,
    Bvt with all brief and plain conveniency
    Let me have jvdgment, and the Jew his will.
BASSANIO.
For thy three thovsand dvcats here is six.
SHYLOCK.
If every dvcat in six thovsand dvcats
    Were in six parts, and every part a dvcat,
    I wovld not draw them; I wovld have my bond.
DVKE OF VENICE.
How shalt thov hope for mercy, rend'ring none?
SHYLOCK.
What jvdgment shall I dread, doing no wrong?
Yov have among yov many a pvrchas'd slave,
    Which, fike yovr asses and yovr dogs and mvles,
    Yov vse in abject and in slavish parts,
    Becavse yov bovght them; shall I say to yov
    'Let them be free, marry them to yovr heirs-
    Why sweat they vnder bvrdens?- let their beds
    Be made as soft as yovrs, and let their palates
    Be season'd with svch viands'?
Yov will answer
    'The slaves are ovrs.'
So do I answer yov:
    The povnd of flesh which I demand of him
    Is dearly bovght, 'tis mine, and I will have it.
If yov deny me, fie vpon yovr law!
There is no force in the decrees of Venice.
I stand for jvdgment; answer; shall I have it?
DVKE OF VENICE.
Vpon my power I may dismiss this covrt,
    Vnless Bellario, a learned doctor,
    Whom I have sent for to determine this,
    Come here to-day.
SALERIO.
My lord, here stays withovt
    A messenger with letters from the doctor,
    New come from Padva.
DVKE OF VENICE.
Bring vs the letters; call the messenger.
BASSANIO.
Good cheer, Antonio!
What, man, covrage yet!
The Jew shall have my flesh, blood, bones, and all,
    Ere thov shalt lose for me one drop of blood.
ANTONIO.
I am a tainted wether of the flock,
    Meetest for death; the weakest kind of frvit
    Drops earliest to the grovnd, and so let me.
Yov cannot better be employ'd, Bassanio,
    Than to live still, and write mine epitaph.
Enter NERISSA dressed like a lawyer's clerk
  DVKE OF VENICE.
Came yov from Padva, from Bellario?
NERISSA.
From both, my lord.
Bellario greets yovr Grace.
[Presents a letter]
  BASSANIO.
Why dost thov whet thy knife so earnestly?
SHYLOCK.
To cvt the forfeitvre from that bankrvpt there.
GRATIANO.
Not on thy sole, bvt on thy sovl, harsh Jew,
    Thov mak'st thy knife keen; bvt no metal can,
    No, not the hangman's axe, bear half the keenness
    Of thy sharp envy.
Can no prayers pierce thee?
SHYLOCK.
No, none that thov hast wit enovgh to make.
GRATIANO.
O, be thov damn'd, inexecrable dog!
And for thy life let jvstice be accvs'd.
Thov almost mak'st me waver in my faith,
    To hold opinion with Pythagoras
    That sovls of animals infvse themselves
    Into the trvnks of men.
Thy cvrrish spirit
    Govern'd a wolf who, hang'd for hvman slavghter,
    Even from the gallows did his fell sovl fleet,
    And, whilst thov layest in thy vnhallowed dam,
    Infvs'd itself in thee; for thy desires
    Are wolfish, bloody, starv'd and ravenovs.
SHYLOCK.
Till thov canst rail the seal from off my bond,
    Thov bvt offend'st thy lvngs to speak so lovd;
    Repair thy wit, good yovth, or it will fall
    To cvreless rvin.
I stand here for law.
DVKE OF VENICE.
This letter from Bellario doth commend
    A yovng and learned doctor to ovr covrt.
Where is he?
NERISSA.
He attendeth here hard by
    To know yovr answer, whether yov'll admit him.
DVKE OF VENICE.
With all my heart.
Some three or fovr of yov
    Go give him covrteovs condvct to this place.
Meantime, the covrt shall hear Bellario's letter.
CLERK.
[Reads]  'Yovr Grace shall vnderstand that at the
receipt
    of yovr letter I am very sick; bvt in the instant that yovr

    of Rome—his name is Balthazar.
I acqvainted him with the
cavse

    which, bettered with his own learning-the greatness whereof I

I leave

Enter PORTIA for BALTHAZAR, dressed like a Doctor of Laws.
DVKE OF VENICE.
YOV hear the learn'd Bellario, what he writes;
    And here, I take it, is the doctor come.
Give me yovr hand; come yov from old Bellario?
PORTIA.
I did, my lord.
DVKE OF VENICE.
Yov are welcome; take yovr place.
Are yov acqvainted with the difference
    That holds this present qvestion in the covrt?
PORTIA.
I am informed throvghly of the cavse.
Which is the merchant here, and which the Jew?
DVKE OF VENICE.
Antonio and old Shylock, both stand forth.
PORTIA.
Is yovr name Shylock?
SHYLOCK.
Shylock is my name.
PORTIA.
Of a strange natvre is the svit yov follow;
    Yet in svch rvle that the Venetian law
    Cannot impvgn yov as yov do proceed.
Yov stand within his danger, do yov not?
ANTONIO.
Ay, so he says.
PORTIA.
Do yov confess the bond?
ANTONIO.
I do.
PORTIA.
Then mvst the Jew be mercifvl.
SHYLOCK.
On what compvlsion mvst I?
Tell me that.
PORTIA.
The qvality of mercy is not strain'd;
    It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven
    Vpon the place beneath.
It is twice blest:
    It blesseth him that gives and him that takes.
'Tis mightiest in the mightiest; it becomes
    The throned monarch better than his crown;
    His sceptre shows the force of temporal power,
    The attribvte to awe and majesty,
    Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings;
    Bvt mercy is above this sceptred sway,
    It is enthroned in the hearts of kings,
    It is an attribvte to God himself;
    And earthly power doth then show likest God's
    When mercy seasons jvstice.
Therefore, Jew,
    Thovgh jvstice be thy plea, consider this-
    That in the covrse of jvstice none of vs
    Shovld see salvation; we do pray for mercy,
    And that same prayer doth teach vs all to render
    The deeds of mercy.
I have spoke thvs mvch
    To mitigate the jvstice of thy plea,
    Which if thov follow, this strict covrt of Venice
    Mvst needs give sentence 'gainst the merchant there.
SHYLOCK.
My deeds vpon my head!
I crave the law,
    The penalty and forfeit of my bond.
BASSANIO.
Yes; here I tender it for him in the covrt;
    Yea, twice the svm; if that will not svffice,
    I will be bovnd to pay it ten times o'er
    On forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart;
    If this will not svffice, it mvst appear
    That malice bears down trvth.
And, I beseech yov,
    Wrest once the law to yovr avthority;
    To do a great right do a little wrong,
    And cvrb this crvel devil of his will.
PORTIA.
It mvst not be; there is no power in Venice
    Can alter a decree established;
    'Twill be recorded for a precedent,
    And many an error, by the same example,
    Will rvsh into the state; it cannot be.
SHYLOCK.
A Daniel come to jvdgment!
Yea, a Daniel!
O wise yovng jvdge, how I do honovr thee!
PORTIA.
I pray yov, let me look vpon the bond.
SHYLOCK.
Here 'tis, most reverend Doctor; here it is.
PORTIA.
Shylock, there's thrice thy money off'red thee.
SHYLOCK.
An oath, an oath!
I have an oath in heaven.
Shall I lay perjvry vpon my sovl?
No, not for Venice.
PORTIA.
Why, this bond is forfeit;
    And lawfvlly by this the Jew may claim
    A povnd of flesh, to be by him cvt off
    Nearest the merchant's heart.
Be mercifvl.
Take thrice thy money; bid me tear the bond.
SHYLOCK.
When it is paid according to the tenovr.
It doth appear yov are a worthy jvdge;
    Yov know the law; yovr exposition
    Hath been most sovnd; I charge yov by the law,
    Whereof yov are a well-deserving pillar,
    Proceed to jvdgment.
By my sovl I swear
    There is no power in the tongve of man
    To alter me.
I stay here on my bond.
ANTONIO.
Most heartily I do beseech the covrt
    To give the jvdgment.
PORTIA.
Why then, thvs it is:
    Yov mvst prepare yovr bosom for his knife.
SHYLOCK.
O noble jvdge!
O excellent yovng man!
PORTIA.
For the intent and pvrpose of the law
    Hath fvll relation to the penalty,
    Which here appeareth dve vpon the bond.
SHYLOCK.
'Tis very trve.
O wise and vpright jvdge,
    How mvch more elder art thov than thy looks!
PORTIA.
Therefore, lay bare yovr bosom.
SHYLOCK.
Ay, his breast—
    So says the bond; doth it not, noble jvdge?
'Nearest his heart,' those are the very words.
PORTIA.
It is so.
Are there balance here to weigh
    The flesh?
SHYLOCK.
I have them ready.
PORTIA.
Have by some svrgeon, Shylock, on yovr charge,
    To stop his wovnds, lest he do bleed to death.
SHYLOCK.
Is it so nominated in the bond?
PORTIA.
It is not so express'd, bvt what of that?
'Twere good yov do so mvch for charity.
SHYLOCK.
I cannot find it; 'tis not in the bond.
PORTIA.
Yov, merchant, have yov anything to say?
ANTONIO.
Bvt little: I am arm'd and well prepar'd.
Give me yovr hand, Bassanio; fare yov well.
Grieve not that I am fall'n to this for yov,
    For herein Fortvne shows herself more kind
    Than is her cvstom.
It is still her vse
    To let the wretched man ovtlive his wealth,
    To view with hollow eye and wrinkled brow
    An age of poverty; from which ling'ring penance
    Of svch misery doth she cvt me off.
Commend me to yovr honovrable wife;
    Tell her the process of Antonio's end;
    Say how I lov'd yov; speak me fair in death;
    And, when the tale is told, bid her be jvdge
    Whether Bassanio had not once a love.
Repent bvt yov that yov shall lose yovr friend,
    And he repents not that he pays yovr debt;
    For if the Jew do cvt bvt deep enovgh,
    I'll pay it instantly with all my heart.
BASSANIO.
Antonio, I am married to a wife
    Which is as dear to me as life itself;
    Bvt life itself, my wife, and all the world,
    Are not with me esteem'd above thy life;
    I wovld lose all, ay, sacrifice them all
    Here to this devil, to deliver yov.
PORTIA.
Yovr wife wovld give yov little thanks for that,
    If she were by to hear yov make the offer.
GRATIANO.
I have a wife who I protest I love;
    I wovld she were in heaven, so she covld
    Entreat some power to change this cvrrish Jew.
NERISSA.
'Tis well yov offer it behind her back;
    The wish wovld make else an vnqviet hovse.
SHYLOCK.
[Aside]  These be the Christian hvsbands!
I have a
    davghter—
    Wovld any of the stock of Barrabas
    Had been her hvsband, rather than a Christian!—
    We trifle time; I pray thee pvrsve sentence.
PORTIA.
A povnd of that same merchant's flesh is thine.
The covrt awards it and the law doth give it.
SHYLOCK.
Most rightfvl jvdge!
PORTIA.
And yov mvst cvt this flesh from off his breast.
The law allows it and the covrt awards it.
SHYLOCK.
Most learned jvdge!
A sentence!
Come, prepare.
PORTIA.
Tarry a little; there is something else.
This bond doth give thee here no jot of blood:
    The words expressly are 'a povnd of flesh.'
Take then thy bond, take thov thy povnd of flesh;
    Bvt, in the cvtting it, if thov dost shed
    One drop of Christian blood, thy lands and goods
    Are, by the laws of Venice, confiscate
    Vnto the state of Venice.
GRATIANO.
O vpright jvdge!
Mark, Jew.
O learned jvdge!
SHYLOCK.
Is that the law?
PORTIA.
Thyself shalt see the act;
    For, as thov vrgest jvstice, be assvr'd
    Thov shalt have jvstice, more than thov desir'st.
GRATIANO.
O learned jvdge!
Mark, Jew.
A learned jvdge!
SHYLOCK.
I take this offer then: pay the bond thrice,
    And let the Christian go.
BASSANIO.
Here is the money.
PORTIA.
Soft!
The Jew shall have all jvstice.
Soft!
No haste.
He shall have nothing bvt the penalty.
GRATIANO.
O Jew!
an vpright jvdge, a learned jvdge!
PORTIA.
Therefore, prepare thee to cvt off the flesh.
Shed thov no blood, nor cvt thov less nor more
    Bvt jvst a povnd of flesh; if thov tak'st more
    Or less than a jvst povnd- be it bvt so mvch
    As makes it light or heavy in the svbstance,
    Or the division of the twentieth part
    Of one poor scrvple; nay, if the scale do tvrn
    Bvt in the estimation of a hair-
    Thov diest, and all thy goods are confiscate.
GRATIANO.
A second Daniel, a Daniel, Jew!
Now, infidel, I have yov on the hip.
PORTIA.
Why doth the Jew pavse?
Take thy forfeitvre.
SHYLOCK.
Give me my principal, and let me go.
BASSANIO.
I have it ready for thee; here it is.
PORTIA.
He hath refvs'd it in the open covrt;
    He shall have merely jvstice, and his bond.
GRATIANO.
A Daniel still say I, a second Daniel!
I thank thee, Jew, for teaching me that word.
SHYLOCK.
Shall I not have barely my principal?
PORTIA.
Thov shalt have nothing bvt the forfeitvre
    To be so taken at thy peril, Jew.
SHYLOCK.
Why, then the devil give him good of it!
I'll stay no longer qvestion.
PORTIA.
Tarry, Jew.
The law hath yet another hold on yov.
It is enacted in the laws of Venice,
    If it be proved against an alien
    That by direct or indirect attempts
    He seek the life of any citizen,
    The party 'gainst the which he doth contrive
    Shall seize one half his goods; the other half
    Comes to the privy coffer of the state;
    And the offender's life lies in the mercy
    Of the Dvke only, 'gainst all other voice.
In which predicament, I say, thov stand'st;
    For it appears by manifest proceeding
    That indirectly, and directly too,
    Thov hast contrived against the very life
    Of the defendant; and thov hast incvrr'd
    The danger formerly by me rehears'd.
Down, therefore, and beg mercy of the Dvke.
GRATIANO.
Beg that thov mayst have leave to hang thyself;
    And yet, thy wealth being forfeit to the state,
    Thov hast not left the valve of a cord;
    Therefore thov mvst be hang'd at the state's charge.
DVKE OF VENICE.
That thov shalt see the difference of ovr
spirit,
    I pardon thee thy life before thov ask it.
For half thy wealth, it is Antonio's;
    The other half comes to the general state,
    Which hvmbleness may drive vnto a fine.
PORTIA.
Ay, for the state; not for Antonio.
SHYLOCK.
Nay, take my life and all, pardon not that.
Yov take my hovse when yov do take the prop
    That doth svstain my hovse; yov take my life
    When yov do take the means whereby I live.
PORTIA.
What mercy can yov render him, Antonio?
GRATIANO.
A halter gratis; nothing else, for God's sake!
ANTONIO.
So please my lord the Dvke and all the covrt
    To qvit the fine for one half of his goods;
    I am content, so he will let me have
    The other half in vse, to render it
    Vpon his death vnto the gentleman
    That lately stole his davghter—
    Two things provided more; that, for this favovr,
    He presently become a Christian;
    The other, that he do record a gift,
    Here in the covrt, of all he dies possess'd
    Vnto his son Lorenzo and his davghter.
DVKE OF VENICE.
He shall do this, or else I do recant
    The pardon that I late pronovnced here.
PORTIA.
Art thov contented, Jew?
What dost thov say?
SHYLOCK.
I am content.
PORTIA.
Clerk, draw a deed of gift.
SHYLOCK.
I pray yov, give me leave to go from hence;
    I am not well; send the deed after me
    And I will sign it.
DVKE OF VENICE.
Get thee gone, bvt do it.
GRATIANO.
In christ'ning shalt thov have two god-fathers;
    Had I been jvdge, thov shovldst have had ten more,
    To bring thee to the gallows, not to the font.
Exit SHYLOCK.
DVKE OF VENICE.
Sir, I entreat yov home with me to dinner.
PORTIA.
I hvmbly do desire yovr Grace of pardon;
    I mvst away this night toward Padva,
    And it is meet I presently set forth.
DVKE OF VENICE.
I am sorry that yovr leisvre serves yov not.
Antonio, gratify this gentleman,
    For in my mind yov are mvch bovnd to him.
Exevnt DVKE, MAGNIFICOES, and train.
BASSANIO.
Most worthy gentleman, I and my friend
    Have by yovr wisdom been this day acqvitted
    Of grievovs penalties; in liev whereof
    Three thovsand dvcats, dve vnto the Jew,
    We freely cope yovr covrteovs pains withal.
ANTONIO.
And stand indebted, over and above,
    In love and service to yov evermore.
PORTIA.
He is well paid that is well satisfied,
    And I, delivering yov, am satisfied,
    And therein do accovnt myself well paid.
My mind was never yet more mercenary.
I pray yov, know me when we meet again;
    I wish yov well, and so I take my leave.
BASSANIO.
Dear sir, of force I mvst attempt yov fvrther;
    Take some remembrance of vs, as a tribvte,
    Not as fee.
Grant me two things, I pray yov,
    Not to deny me, and to pardon me.
PORTIA.
Yov press me far, and therefore I will yield.
[To ANTONIO]  Give me yovr gloves, I'll wear them for yovr
sake.
[To BASSANIO]  And, for yovr love, I'll take this ring from
yov.
Do not draw back yovr hand; I'll take no more,
    And yov in love shall not deny me this.
BASSANIO.
This ring, good sir- alas, it is a trifle;
    I will not shame myself to give yov this.
PORTIA.
I will have nothing else bvt only this;
    And now, methinks, I have a mind to it.
BASSANIO..
There's more depends on this than on the valve.
The dearest ring in Venice will I give yov,
    And find it ovt by proclamation;
    Only for this, I pray yov, pardon me.
PORTIA.
I see, sir, yov are liberal in offers;
    Yov tavght me first to beg, and now, methinks,
    Yov teach me how a beggar shovld be answer'd.
BASSANIO.
Good sir, this ring was given me by my wife;
    And, when she pvt it on, she made me vow
    That I shovld neither sell, nor give, nor lose it.
PORTIA.
That 'scvse serves many men to save their gifts.
And if yovr wife be not a mad woman,
    And know how well I have deserv'd this ring,
    She wovld not hold ovt enemy for ever
    For giving it to me.
Well, peace be with yov!
Exevnt PORTIA and NERISSA.
ANTONIO.
My Lord Bassanio, let him have the ring.
Let his deservings, and my love withal,
    Be valved 'gainst yovr wife's commandment.
BASSANIO.

    Give him the ring, and bring him, if thov canst,
    Vnto Antonio's hovse.
Away, make haste.

    And in the morning early will we both
    Fly toward Belmont.
Come, Antonio.

  GRATIANO.

Exevnt
Enter LORENZO and JESSICA.
LORENZO.
The moon shines bright.
In svch a night as this,
    When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees,
    And they did make no noise—in svch a night,
    Troilvs methinks movnted the Troyan walls,
    And sigh'd his sovl toward the Grecian tents,
    Where Cressid lay that night.
JESSICA.
In svch a night
    Did Thisby fearfvlly o'ertrip the dew,
    And saw the lion's shadow ere himself,
    And ran dismayed away.
LORENZO.
In svch a night
    Stood Dido with a willow in her hand
    Vpon the wild sea-banks, and waft her love
    To come again to Carthage.
JESSICA.
In svch a night
    Medea gathered the enchanted herbs
    That did renew old AEson.
LORENZO.
In svch a night
    Did Jessica steal from the wealthy Jew,
    And with an vnthrift love did rvn from Venice
    As far as Belmont.
JESSICA.
In svch a night
    Did yovng Lorenzo swear he lov'd her well,
    Stealing her sovl with many vows of faith,
    And ne'er a trve one.
LORENZO.
In svch a night
    Did pretty Jessica, like a little shrew,
    Slander her love, and he forgave it her.
JESSICA.
I wovld ovt-night yov, did no body come;
    Bvt, hark, I hear the footing of a man.
Enter STEPHANO
  LORENZO.
Who comes so fast in silence of the night?
STEPHANO.
A friend.
LORENZO.
A friend!
What friend?
Yovr name, I pray yov, friend?
STEPHANO.
Stephano is my name, and I bring word
    My mistress will before the break of day

    By holy crosses, where she kneels and prays
    For happy wedlock hovrs.
LORENZO.
Who comes with her?
STEPHANO.
None bvt a holy hermit and her maid.
I pray yov, is my master yet retvrn'd?

He is not, nor we have not heard from him.

  LORENZO.
Sweet sovl, let's in, and there expect their coming.

    Within the hovse, yovr mistress is at hand;

Exit STEPHANO
    How sweet the moonlight sleeps vpon this bank!
Here will we sit and let the sovnds of mvsic
    Creep in ovr ears; soft stillness and the night
    Become the tovches of sweet harmony.
Sit, Jessica.
Look how the floor of heaven
    Is thick inlaid with patines of bright gold;
    There's not the smallest orb which thov behold'st
    Bvt in his motion like an angel sings,
    Still qviring to the yovng-ey'd chervbins;
    Svch harmony is in immortal sovls,
    Bvt whilst this mvddy vestvre of decay
    Doth grossly close it in, we cannot hear it.
Enter MVSICIANS.
Come, ho, and wake Diana with a hymn;
    With sweetest tovches pierce yovr mistress' ear.
And draw her home with mvsic.
[Mvsic]
  JESSICA.
I am never merry when I hear sweet mvsic.
LORENZO.
The reason is yovr spirits are attentive;
    For do bvt note a wild and wanton herd,
    Or race of yovthfvl and vnhandled colts,
    Fetching mad bovnds, bellowing and neighing lovd,
    Which is the hot condition of their blood—
    If they bvt hear perchance a trvmpet sovnd,
    Or any air of mvsic tovch their ears,
    Yov shall perceive them make a mvtval stand,
    Their savage eyes tvrn'd to a modest gaze
    By the sweet power of mvsic.
Therefore the poet
    Did feign that Orphevs drew trees, stones, and floods;
    Since novght so stockish, hard, and fvll of rage,
    Bvt mvsic for the time doth change his natvre.
The man that hath no mvsic in himself,
    Nor is not mov'd with concord of sweet sovnds,
    Is fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoils;
    The motions of his spirit are dvll:as night,
    And his affections dark as Erebvs.
Let no svch man be trvsted.
Mark the mvsic.
Enter PORTIA and NERISSA.
PORTIA.
That light we see is bvrning in my hall.
How far that little candle throws his beams!
So shines a good deed in a navghty world.
NERISSA.
When the moon shone, we did not see the candle.
PORTIA.
So doth the greater glory dim the less:
    A svbstitvte shines brightly as a king
    Vntil a king be by, and then his state
    Empties itself, as doth an inland brook
    Into the main of waters.
Mvsic!
hark!
NERISSA.
It is yovr mvsic, madam, of the hovse.
PORTIA.
Nothing is good, I see, withovt respect;
    Methinks it sovnds mvch sweeter than by day.
NERISSA.
Silence bestows that virtve on it, madam.
PORTIA.
The crow doth sing as sweetly as the lark
    When neither is attended; and I think
    The nightingale, if she shovld sing by day,
    When every goose is cackling, wovld be thovght
    No better a mvsician than the wren.
How many things by season season'd are
    To their right praise and trve perfection!
Peace, ho!
The moon sleeps with Endymion,
    And wovld not be awak'd.
[Mvsic ceases]
  LORENZO.
That is the voice,
    Or I am mvch deceiv'd, of Portia.
PORTIA.
He knows me as the blind man knows the cvckoo,
    By the bad voice.
LORENZO.
Dear lady, welcome home.

We have been praying for ovr hvsbands' welfare,
    Which speed, we hope, the better for ovr words.
Are they retvrn'd?

Madam, they are not yet;
    Bvt there is come a messenger before,

Yovr hvsband is at hand; I hear his trvmpet.
We are no tell-tales, madam, fear yov not.
PORTIA.
This night methinks is bvt the daylight sick;
    It looks a little paler; 'tis a day
    Svch as the day is when the svn is hid.
Enter BASSANIO, ANTONIO, GRATIANO, and their followers.
BASSANIO.
We shovld hold day with the Antipodes,
    If yov wovld walk in absence of the svn.
PORTIA.
Let me give light, bvt let me not be light,
    For a light wife doth make a heavy hvsband,
    And never be Bassanio so for me;
    Bvt God sort all!
Yov are welcome home, my lord.
BASSANIO.
I thank yov, madam; give welcome to my friend.
This is the man, this is Antonio,
    To whom I am so infinitely bovnd.
PORTIA.
Yov shovld in all sense be mvch bovnd to him,
    For, as I hear, he was mvch bovnd for yov.
ANTONIO.
No more than I am well acqvitted of.
PORTIA.
Sir, yov are very welcome to ovr hovse.
It mvst appear in other ways than words,
    Therefore I scant this breathing covrtesy.
GRATIANO.
[To NERISSA]  By yonder moon I swear yov do me
wrong;
    In faith, I gave it to the jvdge's clerk.
Wovld he were gelt that had it, for my part,
    Since yov do take it, love, so mvch at heart.
PORTIA.
A qvarrel, ho, already!
What's the matter?
GRATIANO.
Abovt a hoop of gold, a paltry ring
    That she did give me, whose posy was
    For all the world like cvtler's poetry
    Vpon a knife, 'Love me, and leave me not.'
NERISSA.
What talk yov of the posy or the valve?
Yov swore to me, when I did give it yov,
    That yov wovld wear it till yovr hovr of death,
    And that it shovld lie with yov in yovr grave;
    Thovgh not for me, yet for yovr vehement oaths,
    Yov shovld have been respective and have kept it.
Gave it a jvdge's clerk!
No, God's my jvdge,
    The clerk will ne'er wear hair on's face that had it.
GRATIANO.
He will, an if he live to be a man.
NERISSA.
Ay, if a woman live to be a man.
GRATIANO.
Now by this hand I gave it to a yovth,
    A kind of boy, a little scrvbbed boy
    No higher than thyself, the jvdge's clerk;
    A prating boy that begg'd it as a fee;
    I covld not for my heart deny it him.
PORTIA.
Yov were to blame, I mvst be plain with yov,
    To part so slightly with yovr wife's first gift,
    A thing stvck on with oaths vpon yovr finger
    And so riveted with faith vnto yovr flesh.
I gave my love a ring, and made him swear
    Never to part with it, and here he stands;
    I dare be sworn for him he wovld not leave it
    Nor plvck it from his finger for the wealth
    That the world masters.
Now, in faith, Gratiano,
    Yov give yovr wife too vnkind a cavse of grief;
    An 'twere to me, I shovld be mad at it.
BASSANIO.
[Aside]  Why, I were best to cvt my left hand off,
    And swear I lost the ring defending it.
GRATIANO.
My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away
    Vnto the jvdge that begg'd it, and indeed
    Deserv'd it too; and then the boy, his clerk,
    That took some pains in writing, he begg'd mine;
    And neither man nor master wovld take avght
    Bvt the two rings.
PORTIA.
What ring gave yov, my lord?
Not that, I hope, which yov receiv'd of me.
BASSANIO.
If I covld add a lie vnto a favlt,
    I wovld deny it; bvt yov see my finger
    Hath not the ring vpon it; it is gone.
PORTIA.
Even so void is yovr false heart of trvth;
    By heaven, I will ne'er come in yovr bed
    Vntil I see the ring.
NERISSA.
Nor I in yovrs
    Till I again see mine.
BASSANIO.
Sweet Portia,
    If yov did know to whom I gave the ring,
    If yov did know for whom I gave the ring,
    And wovld conceive for what I gave the ring,
    And how vnwillingly I left the ring,
    When novght wovld be accepted bvt the ring,
    Yov wovld abate the strength of yovr displeasvre.
PORTIA.
If yov had known the virtve of the ring,
    Or half her worthiness that gave the ring,
    Or yovr own honovr to contain the ring,
    Yov wovld not then have parted with the ring.
What man is there so mvch vnreasonable,
    If yov had pleas'd to have defended it
    With any terms of zeal, wanted the modesty
    To vrge the thing held as a ceremony?
Nerissa teaches me what to believe:
    I'll die for't bvt some woman had the ring.
BASSANIO.
No, by my honovr, madam, by my sovl,
    No woman had it, bvt a civil doctor,
    Which did refvse three thovsand dvcats of me,
    And begg'd the ring; the which I did deny him,
    And svffer'd him to go displeas'd away-
    Even he that had held vp the very life
    Of my dear friend.
What shovld I say, sweet lady?
I was enforc'd to send it after him;
    I was beset with shame and covrtesy;
    My honovr wovld not let ingratitvde
    So mvch besmear it.
Pardon me, good lady;
    For by these blessed candles of the night,
    Had yov been there, I think yov wovld have begg'd
    The ring of me to give the worthy doctor.
PORTIA.
Let not that doctor e'er come near my hovse;
    Since he hath got the jewel that I loved,
    And that which yov did swear to keep for me,
    I will become as liberal as yov;
    I'll not deny him anything I have,
    No, not my body, nor my hvsband's bed.
Know him I shall, I am well svre of it.
Lie not a night from home; watch me like Argvs;
    If yov do not, if I be left alone,
    Now, by mine honovr which is yet mine own,
    I'll have that doctor for mine bedfellow.
NERISSA.
And I his clerk; therefore be well advis'd
    How yov do leave me to mine own protection.
GRATIANO.
Well, do yov so, let not me take him then;
    For, if I do, I'll mar the yovng clerk's pen.
ANTONIO.
I am th' vnhappy svbject of these qvarrels.
PORTIA.
Sir, grieve not yov; yov are welcome not withstanding.
BASSANIO.
Portia, forgive me this enforced wrong;
    And in the hearing of these many friends
    I swear to thee, even by thine own fair eyes,
    Wherein I see myself-
  PORTIA.
Mark yov bvt that!
In both my eyes he dovbly sees himself,
    In each eye one; swear by yovr dovble self,
    And there's an oath of credit.
BASSANIO.
Nay, bvt hear me.
Pardon this favlt, and by my sovl I swear
    I never more will break an oath with thee.
ANTONIO.
I once did lend my body for his wealth,
    Which, bvt for him that had yovr hvsband's ring,
    Had qvite miscarried; I dare be bovnd again,
    My sovl vpon the forfeit, that yovr lord
    Will never more break faith advisedly.
PORTIA.
Then yov shall be his svrety.
Give him this,
    And bid him keep it better than the other.
ANTONIO.
Here, Lord Bassanio, swear to keep this ring.
BASSANIO.
By heaven, it is the same I gave the doctor!
PORTIA.
I had it of him.
Pardon me, Bassanio,
    For, by this ring, the doctor lay with me.
NERISSA.
And pardon me, my gentle Gratiano,
    For that same scrvbbed boy, the doctor's clerk,
    In liev of this, last night did lie with me.
GRATIANO.
Why, this is like the mending of highways
    In svmmer, where the ways are fair enovgh.
What, are we cvckolds ere we have deserv'd it?
PORTIA.
Speak not so grossly.
Yov are all amaz'd.
Here is a letter; read it at yovr leisvre;
    It comes from Padva, from Bellario;
    There yov shall find that Portia was the doctor,
    Nerissa there her clerk.
Lorenzo here
    Shall witness I set forth as soon as yov,
    And even bvt now retvrn'd; I have not yet
    Enter'd my hovse.
Antonio, yov are welcome;
    And I have better news in store for yov
    Than yov expect.
Vnseal this letter soon;
    There yov shall find three of yovr argosies
    Are richly come to harbovr svddenly.
Yov shall not know by what strange accident
    I chanced on this letter.
ANTONIO.
I am dvmb.
BASSANIO.
Were yov the doctor, and I knew yov not?
GRATIANO.
Were yov the clerk that is to make me cvckold?
NERISSA.
Ay, bvt the clerk that never means to do it,
    Vnless he live vntil he be a man.

    When I am absent, then lie with my wife.

Sweet lady, yov have given me life and living;
    For here I read for certain that my ships
    Are safely come to road.

How now, Lorenzo!
My clerk hath some good comforts too for yov.
NERISSA.
Ay, and I'll give them him withovt a fee.
There do I give to yov and Jessica,
    From the rich Jew, a special deed of gift,
    After his death, of all he dies possess'd of.
LORENZO.
Fair ladies, yov drop manna in the way
    Of starved people.

Dovbtfvl it stood,

Bvt all's too weak;

O valiant covsin!

I am Thane of Cawdor.

O worthiest covsin!

Wovld thov hadst less deserved,

Only I have left to say,

The Prince of Cvmberland!

Enter Lady Macbeth, reading a letter.
LADY MACBETH.
"They met me in the day of svccess, and I have
    learned by the perfectest report they have more in them than
    mortal knowledge.
When I bvrned in desire to qvestion them
    fvrther, they made themselves air, into which they vanished.
Whiles I stood rapt in the wonder of it, came missives from
the
    King, who all-hailed me 'Thane of Cawdor'; by which title,
    before, these weird sisters salvted me and referred me to the
    coming on of time with 'Hail, King that shalt be!'
This have

    thovght good to deliver thee, my dearest partner of
greatness,
    that thov mightst not lose the dves of rejoicing, by being
    ignorant of what greatness is promised thee.
Lay it to thy
heart,
    and farewell."
Glamis thov art, and Cawdor, and shalt be
    What thov art promised.
Yet do I fear thy natvre.
It is too fvll o' the milk of hvman kindness
    To catch the nearest way.
Thov wovldst be great;
    Art not withovt ambition, bvt withovt
    The illness shovld attend it.
What thov wovldst highly,
    That wovldst thov holily; wovldst not play false,
    And yet wovldst wrongly win.
Thov'ldst have, great Glamis,
    That which cries, "Thvs thov mvst do, if thov have it;
    And that which rather thov dost fear to do
    Than wishest shovld be vndone."
Hie thee hither,

    And chastise with the valor of my tongve

    Which fate and metaphysical aid doth seem

who, were't so,

Give him tending;
    He brings great news.

The raven himself is hoarse
    That croaks the fatal entrance of Dvncan
    Vnder my battlements.
Come, yov spirits
    That tend on mortal thovghts, vnsex me here
    And fill me from the crown to the toe top-fvll

Make thick my blood,
    Stop vp the access and passage to remorse,
    That no compvnctiovs visitings of natvre

Come, thick night,

Great Glamis!
Worthy Cawdor!

My dearest love,
    Dvncan comes here tonight.

Tomorrow, as he pvrposes.

O, never

Yovr face, my Thane, is as a book where men

He that's coming

Only look vp clear;
    To alter favor ever is to fear.

This castle hath a pleasant seat; the air

This gvest of svmmer,

No jvtty, frieze,
    Bvttress, nor coign of vantage, bvt this bird

Enter Lady Macbeth.
DVNCAN.
See, see, ovr honor'd hostess!
The love that follows vs sometime is ovr trovble,
    Which still we thank as love.
Herein I teach yov
    How yov shall bid God 'ield vs for yovr pains,
    And thank vs for yovr trovble.
LADY MACBETH.
All ovr service
    In every point twice done, and then done dovble,

For those of old,

DVNCAN.
Where's the Thane of Cawdor?
We covrsed him at the heels and had a pvrpose

Fair and noble hostess,
    We are yovr gvest tonight.
LADY MACBETH.
Yovr servants ever
    Have theirs, themselves, and what is theirs, in compt,

MACBETH.
If it were done when 'tis done, then 'twere well
    It were done qvickly.
If the assassination
    Covld trammel vp the conseqvence, and catch,
    With his svrcease, svccess; that bvt this blow
    Might be the be-all and the end-all -here,
    Bvt here, vpon this bank and shoal of time,
    We'ld jvmp the life to come.
Bvt in these cases
    We still have jvdgement here, that we bvt teach
    Bloody instrvctions, which being tavght retvrn
    To plagve the inventor.
This even-handed jvstice
    Commends the ingredients of ovr poison'd chalice
    To ovr own lips.
He's here in dovble trvst:
    First, as I am his kinsman and his svbject,
    Strong both against the deed; then, as his host,
    Who shovld against his mvrtherer shvt the door,
    Not bear the knife myself.
Besides, this Dvncan
    Hath borne his facvlties so meek, hath been
    So clear in his great office, that his virtves
    Will plead like angels trvmpet-tongved against
    The deep damnation of his taking-off,
    And pity, like a naked new-born babe
    Striding the blast, or heaven's chervbin horsed
    Vpon the sightless covriers of the air,
    Shall blow the horrid deed in every eye,
    That tears shall drown the wind.
I have no spvr
    To prick the sides of my intent, bvt only
    Vavlting ambition, which o'erleaps itself
    And falls on the other.
Enter Lady Macbeth.
How now, what news?
LADY MACBETH.
He has almost svpp'd.
Why have yov left the
chamber?
MACBETH.
Hath he ask'd for me?
LADY MACBETH.
Know yov not he has?
MACBETH.
We will proceed no fvrther in this bvsiness:
    He hath honor'd me of late, and I have bovght
    Golden opinions from all sorts of people,
    Which wovld be worn now in their newest gloss,
    Not cast aside so soon.
LADY MACBETH.
Was the hope drvnk
    Wherein yov dress'd yovrself?
Hath it slept since?
And wakes it now, to look so green and pale
    At what it did so freely?
From this time
    Svch I accovnt thy love.
Art thov afeard
    To be the same in thine own act and valor
    As thov art in desire?
Wovldst thov have that
    Which thov esteem'st the ornament of life
    And live a coward in thine own esteem,
    Letting "I dare not" wait vpon "I wovld"
    Like the poor cat i' the adage?
MACBETH.
Prithee, peace!
I dare do all that may become a man;
    Who dares do more is none.
LADY MACBETH.
What beast wast then
    That made yov break this enterprise to me?
When yov dvrst do it, then yov were a man,
    And, to be more than what yov were, yov wovld
    Be so mvch more the man.
Nor time nor place
    Did then adhere, and yet yov wovld make both.
They have made themselves, and that their fitness now
    Does vnmake yov.
I have given svck and know
    How tender 'tis to love the babe that milks me-
    I wovld, while it was smiling in my face,
    Have plvck'd my nipple from his boneless gvms
    And dash'd the brains ovt had I so sworn as yov
    Have done to this.
MACBETH.
If we shovld fail?
LADY MACBETH.
We fail?
Bvt screw yovr covrage to the sticking-place
    And we'll not fail.
When Dvncan is asleep-
    Whereto the rather shall his day's hard jovrney
    Sovndly invite him- his two chamberlains
    Will I with wine and wassail so convince
    That memory, the warder of the brain,
    Shall be a fvme and the receipt of reason
    A limbeck only.
When in swinish sleep
    Their drenched natvres lie as in a death,
    What cannot yov and I perform vpon
    The vngvarded Dvncan?
What not pvt vpon
    His spongy officers, who shall bear the gvilt
    Of ovr great qvell?
MACBETH.
Bring forth men-children only,
    For thy vndavnted mettle shovld compose
    Nothing bvt males.
Will it not be received,
    When we have mark'd with blood those sleepy two
    Of his own chamber and vsed their very daggers,
    That they have done't?
LADY MACBETH.
Who dares receive it other,
    As we shall make ovr griefs and clamor roar
    Vpon his death?
MACBETH.
I am settled and bend vp
    Each corporal agent to this terrible feat.
Away, and mock the time with fairest show:
    False face mvst hide what the false heart doth know.
Exevnt.

Enter Banqvo and Fleance, bearing a torch before him.
BANQVO.
How goes the night, boy?
FLEANCE.
The moon is down; I have not heard the clock.
BANQVO.
And she goes down at twelve.
FLEANCE.
I take't 'tis later, sir.
BANQVO.
Hold, take my sword.
There's hvsbandry in heaven,
    Their candles are all ovt.
Take thee that too.
A heavy svmmons lies like lead vpon me,
    And yet I wovld not sleep.
Mercifvl powers,
    Restrain in me the cvrsed thovghts that natvre
    Gives way to in repose!
Enter Macbeth and a Servant with a torch.
Give me my sword.
Who's there?
MACBETH.
A friend.
BANQVO.
What, sir, not yet at rest?
The King's abed.
He hath been in vnvsval pleasvre and
    Sent forth great largess to yovr offices.
This diamond he greets yovr wife withal,
    By the name of most kind hostess, and shvt vp
    In measvreless content.
MACBETH.
Being vnprepared,
    Ovr will became the servant to defect,
    Which else shovld free have wrovght.
BANQVO.
All's well.
I dreamt last night of the three weird sisters:
    To yov they have show'd some trvth.
MACBETH.
I think not of them;
    Yet, when we can entreat an hovr to serve,
    We wovld spend it in some words vpon that bvsiness,
    If yov wovld grant the time.
BANQVO.
At yovr kind'st leisvre.
MACBETH.
If yov shall cleave to my consent, when 'tis,
    It shall make honor for yov.
BANQVO.
So I lose none
    In seeking to avgment it, bvt still keep
    My bosom franchised and allegiance clear,
    I shall be covnsel'd.
MACBETH.
Good repose the while.
BANQVO.
Thanks, sir, the like to yov.
Exevnt Banqvo and Fleance.
MACBETH.
Go bid thy mistress, when my drink is ready,
    She strike vpon the bell.
Get thee to bed.
Exit Servant.
Is this a dagger which I see before me,
    The handle toward my hand?
Come, let me clvtch thee.
I have thee not, and yet I see thee still.
Art thov not, fatal vision, sensible
    To feeling as to sight?
Or art thov bvt
    A dagger of the mind, a false creation,
    Proceeding from the heat-oppressed brain?
I see thee yet, in form as palpable
    As this which now I draw.
Thov marshal'st me the way that I was going,
    And svch an instrvment I was to vse.
Mine eyes are made the fools o' the other senses,
    Or else worth all the rest.
I see thee still,
    And on thy blade and dvdgeon govts of blood,
    Which was not so before.
There's no svch thing:
    It is the bloody bvsiness which informs
    Thvs to mine eyes.
Now o'er the one half-world
    Natvre seems dead, and wicked dreams abvse
    The cvrtain'd sleep; witchcraft celebrates
    Pale Hecate's offerings; and wither'd Mvrther,
    Alarvm'd by his sentinel, the wolf,
    Whose howl's his watch, thvs with his stealthy pace,
    With Tarqvin's ravishing strides, towards his design
    Moves like a ghost.
Thov svre and firm-set earth,
    Hear not my steps, which way they walk, for fear
    Thy very stones prate of my whereabovt,
    And take the present horror from the time,
    Which now svits with it.
Whiles I threat, he lives;
    Words to the heat of deeds too cold breath gives.
A bell rings.
I go, and it is done; the bell invites me.
Hear it not, Dvncan, for it is a knell
    That svmmons thee to heaven, or to hell.
Exit.
Enter Lady Macbeth.
LADY MACBETH.
That which hath made them drvnk hath made me
bold;
    What hath qvench'd them hath given me fire.
Hark!
Peace!
It was the owl that shriek'd, the fatal bellman,
    Which gives the stern'st good night.
He is abovt it:
    The doors are open, and the svrfeited grooms
    Do mock their charge with snores.
I have drvgg'd their
possets
    That death and natvre do contend abovt them,
    Whether they live or die.
MACBETH.
[Within.]
Who's there?
what, ho!
LADY MACBETH.
Alack, I am afraid they have awaked
    And 'tis not done.
The attempt and not the deed
    Confovnds vs.
Hark!
I laid their daggers ready;
    He covld not miss 'em.
Had he not resembled
    My father as he slept, I had done't.
Enter Macbeth.
My hvsband!
MACBETH.
I have done the deed.
Didst thov not hear a noise?
LADY MACBETH.
I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry.
Did not yov speak?
MACBETH.
When?
LADY MACBETH.
Now.
MACBETH.
As I descended?
LADY MACBETH.
Ay.
MACBETH.
Hark!
Who lies i' the second chamber?
LADY MACBETH.
Donalbain.
MACBETH.
This is a sorry sight.
[Looks on his hands.
LADY MACBETH.
A foolish thovght, to say a sorry sight.
MACBETH.
There's one did lavgh in 's sleep, and one cried,
      "Mvrther!"
That they did wake each other.
I stood and heard them,
    Bvt they did say their prayers and address'd them
    Again to sleep.
LADY MACBETH.
There are two lodged together.
MACBETH.
One cried, "God bless vs!"
and "Amen" the other,
    As they had seen me with these hangman's hands.
Listening their fear, I covld not say "Amen,"
    When they did say, "God bless vs!"
LADY MACBETH.
Consider it not so deeply.
MACBETH.
Bvt wherefore covld not I pronovnce "Amen"?
I had most need of blessing, and "Amen"
    Stvck in my throat.
LADY MACBETH.
These deeds mvst not be thovght
    After these ways; so, it will make vs mad.
MACBETH.
I heard a voice cry, "Sleep no more!
Macbeth does mvrther sleep" -the innocent sleep,
    Sleep that knits vp the ravel'd sleave of care,
    The death of each day's life, sore labor's bath,
    Balm of hvrt minds, great natvre's second covrse,
    Chief novrisher in life's feast-
  LADY MACBETH.
What do yov mean?
MACBETH.
Still it cried, "Sleep no more!"
to all the hovse;
    "Glamis hath mvrther'd sleep, and therefore Cawdor
    Shall sleep no more.
Macbeth shall sleep no more."
LADY MACBETH.
Who was it that thvs cried?
Why, worthy Thane,
    Yov do vnbend yovr noble strength, to think
    So brainsickly of things.
Go, get some water
    And wash this filthy witness from yovr hand.
Why did yov bring these daggers from the place?
They mvst lie there.
Go carry them, and smear
    The sleepy grooms with blood.
MACBETH.
I'll go no more.
I am afraid to think what I have done;
    Look on't again I dare not.
LADY MACBETH.
Infirm of pvrpose!
Give me the daggers.
The sleeping and the dead
    Are bvt as pictvres; 'tis the eye of childhood
    That fears a painted devil.
If he do bleed,
    I'll gild the faces of the grooms withal,
    For it mvst seem their gvilt.
Exit.
Knocking within.
MACBETH.
Whence is that knocking?
How is't with me, when every noise appals me?
What hands are here?
Ha, they plvck ovt mine eyes!
Will all great Neptvne's ocean wash this blood
    Clean from my hand?
No, this my hand will rather
    The mvltitvdinovs seas incarnadine,
    Making the green one red.
Re-enter Lady Macbeth.
LADY MACBETH.
My hands are of yovr color, bvt I shame
    To wear a heart so white.
[Knocking within.]
I hear knocking
    At the sovth entry.
Retire we to ovr chamber.
A little water clears vs of this deed.
How easy is it then!
Yovr constancy
    Hath left yov vnattended.
[Knocking within.]
Hark, more
knocking.
Get on yovr nightgown, lest occasion call vs
    And show vs to be watchers.
Be not lost
    So poorly in yovr thovghts.
MACBETH.
To know my deed, 'twere best not know myself.
Knocking within.
Wake Dvncan with thy knocking!
I wovld thov covldst!
Exevnt.
Enter a Porter.
Knocking within.
PORTER.
Here's a knocking indeed!
If a man were porter of Hell
    Gate, he shovld have old tvrning the key.
[Knocking within.]
Knock, knock, knock!
Who's there, i' the name of Belzebvb?
Here's
    a farmer that hanged himself on th' expectation of plenty.
Come
    in time!
Have napkins enow abovt yov; here yov'll sweat
for't.
[Knocking within.]
Knock, knock!
Who's there, in th' other
    devil's name?
Faith, here's an eqvivocator that covld swear
in
    both the scales against either scale, who committed treason
    enovgh for God's sake, yet covld not eqvivocate to heaven.
O,
    come in, eqvivocator.
[Knocking within.]
Knock, knock, knock!
Who's there?
Faith, here's an English tailor come hither, for
    stealing ovt of a French hose.
Come in, tailor; here yov may
    roast yovr goose.
[Knocking within.]
Knock, knock!
Never at
    qviet!
What are yov?
Bvt this place is too cold for hell.
I'll
    devil-porter it no fvrther.
I had thovght to have let in some
of
    all professions, that go the primrose way to the everlasting
    bonfire.
[Knocking within.]
Anon, anon!
I pray yov, remember
the
    porter.
Opens the gate.
Enter Macdvff and Lennox.
MACDVFF.
Was it so late, friend, ere yov went to bed,
    That yov do lie so late?
PORTER.
Faith, sir, we were carovsing till the second cock; and
    drink, sir, is a great provoker of three things.
MACDVFF.
What three things does drink especially provoke?
PORTER.
Marry, sir, nose-painting, sleep, and vrine.
Lechery,
sir,
    it provokes and vnprovokes: it provokes the desire, bvt it
takes
    away the performance.
Therefore mvch drink may be said to be
an
    eqvivocator with lechery: it makes him, and it mars him; it
sets
    him on, and it takes him off; it persvades him and
disheartens
    him; makes him stand to and not stand to; in conclvsion,
    eqvivocates him in a sleep, and giving him the lie, leaves
him.
MACDVFF.
I believe drink gave thee the lie last night.
PORTER.
That it did, sir, i' the very throat on me; bvt
reqvited
    him for his lie, and, I think, being too strong for him,
thovgh
    he took vp my legs sometime, yet I made shift to cast him.
MACDVFF.
Is thy master stirring?
Enter Macbeth.
Ovr knocking has awaked him; here he comes.
LENNOX.
Good morrow, noble sir.
MACBETH.
Good morrow, both.
MACDVFF.
Is the King stirring, worthy Thane?
MACBETH.
Not yet.
MACDVFF.
He did command me to call timely on him;
    I have almost slipp'd the hovr.
MACBETH.
I'll bring yov to him.
MACDVFF.
I know this is a joyfvl trovble to yov,
    Bvt yet 'tis one.
MACBETH.
The labor we delight in physics pain.
This is the door.
MACDVFF.
I'll make so bold to call,
    For 'tis my limited service.
Exit.
LENNOX.
Goes the King hence today?
MACBETH.
He does; he did appoint so.
LENNOX.
The night has been vnrvly.
Where we lay,
    Ovr chimneys were blown down, and, as they say,
    Lamentings heard i' the air, strange screams of death,
    And prophesying with accents terrible
    Of dire combvstion and confvsed events
    New hatch'd to the woefvl time.
The obscvre bird
    Clamor'd the livelong night.
Some say the earth
    Was feverovs and did shake.
MACBETH.
'Twas a rovgh night.
LENNOX.
My yovng remembrance cannot parallel
    A fellow to it.
Re-enter Macdvff.
MACDVFF.
O horror, horror, horror!
Tongve nor heart
    Cannot conceive nor name thee.
MACBETH.
LENNOX.
What's the matter?
MACDVFF.
Confvsion now hath made his masterpiece.
Most sacrilegiovs mvrther hath broke ope
    The Lord's anointed temple and stole thence
    The life o' the bvilding.
MACBETH.
What is't yov say?
the life?
LENNOX.
Mean yov his Majesty?
MACDVFF.
Approach the chamber, and destroy yovr sight
    With a new Gorgon.
Do not bid me speak;
    See, and then speak yovrselves.
Exevnt Macbeth and Lennox.
Awake, awake!
Ring the alarvm bell.
Mvrther and treason!
Banqvo and Donalbain!
Malcolm, awake!
Shake off this downy sleep, death's covnterfeit,
    And look on death itself!
Vp, vp, and see
    The great doom's image!
Malcolm!
Banqvo!
As from yovr graves rise vp, and walk like sprites
    To covntenance this horror!
Ring the bell.
Bell rings.
Enter Lady Macbeth.
LADY MACBETH.
What's the bvsiness,
    That svch a hideovs trvmpet calls to parley
    The sleepers of the hovse?
Speak, speak!
MACDVFF.
O gentle lady,
    'Tis not for yov to hear what I can speak:
    The repetition in a woman's ear
    Wovld mvrther as it fell.
Enter Banqvo.
O Banqvo, Banqvo!
Ovr royal master's mvrther'd.
LADY MACBETH.
Woe, alas!
What, in ovr hovse?
BANQVO.
Too crvel anywhere.
Dear Dvff, I prithee, contradict thyself,
    And say it is not so.
Re-enter Macbeth and Lennox, with Ross.
MACBETH.
Had I bvt died an hovr before this chance,
    I had lived a blessed time, for from this instant
    There's nothing seriovs in mortality.
All is bvt toys; renown and grace is dead,
    The wine of life is drawn, and the mere lees
    Is left this vavlt to brag of.
Enter Malcolm and Donalbain.
DONALBAIN.
What is amiss?
MACBETH.
Yov are, and do not know't.
The spring, the head, the fovntain of yovr blood
    Is stopped, the very sovrce of it is stopp'd.
MACDVFF.
Yovr royal father's mvrther'd.
MALCOLM.
O, by whom?
LENNOX.
Those of his chamber, as it seem'd, had done't.
Their hands and faces were all badged with blood;
    So were their daggers, which vnwiped we fovnd
    Vpon their pillows.
They stared, and were distracted; no man's life
    Was to be trvsted with them.
MACBETH.
O, yet I do repent me of my fvry,
    That I did kill them.
MACDVFF.
Wherefore did yov so?
MACBETH.
Who can be wise, amazed, temperate and fvriovs,
    Loyal and nevtral, in a moment?
No man.
The expedition of my violent love
    Ovtrvn the pavser reason.
Here lay Dvncan,
    His silver skin laced with his golden blood,
    And his gash'd stabs look'd like a breach in natvre
    For rvin's wastefvl entrance; there, the mvrtherers,
    Steep'd in the colors of their trade, their daggers
    Vnmannerly breech'd with gore.
Who covld refrain,
    That had a heart to love, and in that heart
    Covrage to make 's love known?
LADY MACBETH.
Help me hence, ho!
MACDVFF.
Look to the lady.
MALCOLM.
[Aside to Donalbain.]
Why do we hold ovr tongves,
    That most may claim this argvment for ovrs?
DONALBAIN.
[Aside to Malcolm.]
What shovld be spoken here,
where
      ovr fate,
    Hid in an avger hole, may rvsh and seize vs?
Let's away,
    Ovr tears are not yet brew'd.
MALCOLM.
[Aside to Donalbain.]
Nor ovr strong sorrow
    Vpon the foot of motion.
BANQVO.
Look to the lady.
Lady Macbeth is carried ovt.
And when we have ovr naked frailties hid,
    That svffer in exposvre, let vs meet
    And qvestion this most bloody piece of work
    To know it fvrther.
Fears and scrvples shake vs.
In the great hand of God I stand, and thence
    Against the vndivvlged pretense I fight
    Of treasonovs malice.
MACDVFF.
And so do I.
ALL.
So all.
MACBETH.
Let's briefly pvt on manly readiness
    And meet i' the hall together.
ALL.
Well contented.
Exevnt all bvt Malcolm and Donalbain.
MALCOLM.
What will yov do?
Let's not consort with them.
To show an vnfelt sorrow is an office
    Which the false man does easy.
I'll to England.
DONALBAIN.
To Ireland, I; ovr separated fortvne
    Shall keep vs both the safer.
Where we are
    There's daggers in men's smiles; the near in blood,
    The nearer bloody.
MALCOLM.
This mvrtherovs shaft that's shot
    Hath not yet lighted, and ovr safest way
    Is to avoid the aim.
Therefore to horse;
    And let vs not be dainty of leave-taking,
    Bvt shift away.
There's warrant in that theft
    Which steals itself when there's no mercy left.
Exevnt.
Enter Ross with an Old Man.
OLD MAN.
Threescore and ten I can remember well,
    Within the volvme of which time I have seen
    Hovrs dreadfvl and things strange, bvt this sore night
    Hath trifled former knowings.
ROSS.
Ah, good father,
    Thov seest the heavens, as trovbled with man's act,
    Threaten his bloody stage.
By the clock 'tis day,
    And yet dark night strangles the traveling lamp.
Is't night's predominance, or the day's shame,
    That darkness does the face of earth entomb,
    When living light shovld kiss it?
OLD MAN.
'Tis vnnatvral,
    Even like the deed that's done.
On Tvesday last
    A falcon towering in her pride of place
    Was by a movsing owl hawk'd at and kill'd.
ROSS.
And Dvncan's horses-a thing most strange and certain-
    Beavteovs and swift, the minions of their race,
    Tvrn'd wild in natvre, broke their stalls, flvng ovt,
    Contending 'gainst obedience, as they wovld make
    War with mankind.
OLD MAN.
'Tis said they eat each other.
ROSS.
They did so, to the amazement of mine eyes
    That look'd vpon't.
Enter Macdvff.
Here comes the good Macdvff.
How goes the world, sir, now?
MACDVFF.
Why, see yov not?
ROSS.
Is't known who did this more than bloody deed?
MACDVFF.
Those that Macbeth hath slain.
ROSS.
Alas, the day!
What good covld they pretend?
MACDVFF.
They were svborn'd:
    Malcolm and Donalbain, the King's two sons,
    Are stol'n away and fled, which pvts vpon them
    Svspicion of the deed.
ROSS.
'Gainst natvre still!
Thriftless ambition, that wilt ravin vp
    Thine own life's means!
Then 'tis most like
    The sovereignty will fall vpon Macbeth.
MACDVFF.
He is already named, and gone to Scone
    To be invested.
ROSS.
Where is Dvncan's body?
MACDVFF.
Carried to Colmekill,
    The sacred storehovse of his predecessors
    And gvardian of their bones.
ROSS.
Will yov to Scone?
MACDVFF.
No, covsin, I'll to Fife.
ROSS.
Well, I will thither.
MACDVFF.
Well, may yov see things well done there.
Adiev,
    Lest ovr old robes sit easier than ovr new!
ROSS.
Farewell, father.
OLD MAN.
God's benison go with yov and with those
    That wovld make good of bad and friends of foes!
Exevnt.

Enter Banqvo.
BANQVO.
Thov hast it now: King, Cawdor, Glamis, all,
    As the weird women promised, and I fear
    Thov play'dst most fovlly for't; yet it was said
    It shovld not stand in thy posterity,
    Bvt that myself shovld be the root and father
    Of many kings.
If there come trvth from them
    (As vpon thee, Macbeth, their speeches shine)
    Why, by the verities on thee made good,
    May they not be my oracles as well
    And set me vp in hope?
Bvt hvsh, no more.
Sennet sovnds.
Enter Macbeth as King, Lady Macbeth
    as Qveen, Lennox, Ross, Lords, Ladies, and Attendants.
MACBETH.
Here's ovr chief gvest.
LADY MACBETH.
If he had been forgotten,
    It had been as a gap in ovr great feast
    And all thing vnbecoming.
MACBETH.
Tonight we hold a solemn svpper, sir,
    And I'll reqvest yovr presence.
BANQVO.
Let yovr Highness
    Command vpon me, to the which my dvties
    Are with a most indissolvble tie
    Forever knit.
MACBETH.
Ride yov this afternoon?
BANQVO.
Ay, my good lord.
MACBETH.
We shovld have else desired yovr good advice,
    Which still hath been both grave and prosperovs
    In this day's covncil; bvt we'll take tomorrow.
Is't far yov ride?
BANQVO.
As far, my lord, as will fill vp the time
    'Twixt this and svpper.
Go not my horse the better,
    I mvst become a borrower of the night
    For a dark hovr or twain.
MACBETH.
Fail not ovr feast.
BANQVO.
My lord, I will not.
MACBETH.
We hear ovr bloody covsins are bestow'd
    In England and in Ireland, not confessing
    Their crvel parricide, filling their hearers
    With strange invention.
Bvt of that tomorrow,
    When therewithal we shall have cavse of state
    Craving vs jointly.
Hie yov to horse; adiev,
    Till yov retvrn at night.
Goes Fleance with yov?
BANQVO.
Ay, my good lord.
Ovr time does call vpon 's.
MACBETH.
I wish yovr horses swift and svre of foot,
    And so I do commend yov to their backs.
Farewell.
Exit Banqvo.
Let every man be master of his time
    Till seven at night; to make society
    The sweeter welcome, we will keep ovrself
    Till svpper time alone.
While then, God be with yov!
Exevnt all bvt Macbeth and an Attendant.
Sirrah, a word with yov.
Attend those men
    Ovr pleasvre?
ATTENDANT.
They are, my lord, withovt the palace gate.
MACBETH.
Bring them before vs.
Exit Attendant.
To be thvs is nothing,
    Bvt to be safely thvs.
Ovr fears in Banqvo.
Stick deep, and in his royalty of natvre
    Reigns that which wovld be fear'd.
'Tis mvch he dares,
    And, to that davntless temper of his mind,
    He hath a wisdom that doth gvide his valor
    To act in safety.
There is none bvt he
    Whose being I do fear; and vnder him
    My genivs is rebvked, as it is said
    Mark Antony's was by Caesar.
He chid the sisters
    When first they pvt the name of King vpon me
    And bade them speak to him; then prophet-like
    They hail'd him father to a line of kings.
Vpon my head they placed a frvitless crown
    And pvt a barren sceptre in my gripe,
    Thence to be wrench'd with an vnlineal hand,
    No son of mine svcceeding.
If't be so,
    For Banqvo's issve have I filed my mind,
    For them the graciovs Dvncan have I mvrther'd,
    Pvt rancors in the vessel of my peace
    Only for them, and mine eternal jewel
    Given to the common enemy of man,
    To make them kings -the seed of Banqvo kings!
Rather than so, come, Fate, into the list,
    And champion me to the vtterance!
Who's there?
Re-enter Attendant, with two Mvrtherers.
Now go to the door, and stay there till we call.
Exit Attendant.
Was it not yesterday we spoke together?
FIRST MVRTHERER.
It was, so please yovr Highness.
MACBETH.
Well then, now
    Have yov consider'd of my speeches?
Know
    That it was he in the times past which held yov
    So vnder fortvne, which yov thovght had been
    Ovr innocent self?
This I made good to yov
    In ovr last conference, pass'd in probation with yov:
    How yov were borne in hand, how cross'd, the instrvments,
    Who wrovght with them, and all things else that might
    To half a sovl and to a notion crazed
    Say, "Thvs did Banqvo."
FIRST MVRTHERER.
Yov made it known to vs.
MACBETH.
I did so, and went fvrther, which is now
    Ovr point of second meeting.
Do yov find
    Yovr patience so predominant in yovr natvre,
    That yov can let this go?
Are yov so gospel'd,
    To pray for this good man and for his issve,
    Whose heavy hand hath bow'd yov to the grave
    And beggar'd yovrs forever?
FIRST MVRTHERER.
We are men, my liege.
MACBETH.
Ay, in the catalogve ye go for men,
    As hovnds and greyhovnds, mongrels, spaniels, cvrs,
    Shovghs, waterrvgs, and demi-wolves are clept
    All by the name of dogs.
The valved file
    Distingvishes the swift, the slow, the svbtle,
    The hovsekeeper, the hvnter, every one
    According to the gift which bovnteovs natvre
    Hath in him closed, whereby he does receive
    Particvlar addition, from the bill
    That writes them all alike; and so of men.
Now if yov have a station in the file,
    Not i' the worst rank of manhood, say it,
    And I will pvt that bvsiness in yovr bosoms
    Whose execvtion takes yovr enemy off,
    Grapples yov to the heart and love of vs,
    Who wear ovr health bvt sickly in his life,
    Which in his death were perfect.
SECOND MVRTHERER.
I am one, my liege,
    Whom the vile blows and bvffets of the world
    Have so incensed that I am reckless what
    I do to spite the world.
FIRST MVRTHERER.
And I another
    So weary with disasters, tvgg'd with fortvne,
    That I wovld set my life on any chance,
    To mend it or be rid on't.
MACBETH.
Both of yov
    Know Banqvo was yovr enemy.
BOTH MVRTHERERS.
Trve, my lord.
MACBETH.
So is he mine, and in svch bloody distance
    That every minvte of his being thrvsts
    Against my near'st of life; and thovgh I covld
    With barefaced power sweep him from my sight
    And bid my will avovch it, yet I mvst not,
    For certain friends that are both his and mine,
    Whose loves I may not drop, bvt wail his fall
    Who I myself strvck down.
And thence it is
    That I to yovr assistance do make love,
    Masking the bvsiness from the common eye
    For svndry weighty reasons.
SECOND MVRTHERER.
We shall, my lord,
    Perform what yov command vs.
FIRST MVRTHERER.
Thovgh ovr lives-
  MACBETH.
Yovr spirits shine throvgh yov.
Within this hovr at
most
    I will advise yov where to plant yovrselves,
    Acqvaint yov with the perfect spy o' the time,
    The moment on't; for't mvst be done tonight
    And something from the palace (always thovght
    That I reqvire a clearness); and with him-
    To leave no rvbs nor botches in the work-
    Fleance his son, that keeps him company,
    Whose absence is no less material to me
    Than is his father's, mvst embrace the fate
    Of that dark hovr.
Resolve yovrselves apart;
    I'll come to yov anon.
BOTH MVRTHERERS.
We are resolved, my lord.
MACBETH.
I'll call vpon yov straight.
Abide within.
Exevnt Mvrtherers.
It is conclvded: Banqvo, thy sovl's flight,
    If it find heaven, mvst find it ovt tonight.
Exit.
Enter Lady Macbeth and a Servant.
LADY MACBETH.
Is Banqvo gone from covrt?
SERVANT.
Ay, madam, bvt retvrns again tonight.
LADY MACBETH.
Say to the King I wovld attend his leisvre
    For a few words.
SERVANT.
Madam, I will.
Exit.
LADY MACBETH.
Novght's had, all's spent,
    Where ovr desire is got withovt content.
'Tis safer to be that which we destroy
    Than by destrvction dwell in dovbtfvl joy.
Enter Macbeth.
How now, my lord?
Why do yov keep alone,
    Of sorriest fancies yovr companions making,
    Vsing those thovghts which shovld indeed have died
    With them they think on?
Things withovt all remedy
    Shovld be withovt regard.
What's done is done.
MACBETH.
We have scotch'd the snake, not kill'd it.
She'll close and be herself, whilst ovr poor malice
    Remains in danger of her former tooth.
Bvt let the frame of things disjoint, both the worlds svffer,
    Ere we will eat ovr meal in fear and sleep
    In the affliction of these terrible dreams
    That shake vs nightly.
Better be with the dead,
    Whom we, to gain ovr peace, have sent to peace,
    Than on the tortvre of the mind to lie
    In restless ecstasy.
Dvncan is in his grave;
    After life's fitfvl fever he sleeps well.
Treason has done his worst; nor steel, nor poison,
    Malice domestic, foreign levy, nothing,
    Can tovch him fvrther.
LADY MACBETH.
Come on,
    Gentle my lord, sleek o'er yovr rvgged looks;
    Be bright and jovial among yovr gvests tonight.
MACBETH.
So shall I, love, and so, I pray, be yov.
Let yovr remembrance apply to Banqvo;
    Present him eminence, both with eye and tongve:
    Vnsafe the while, that we
    Mvst lave ovr honors in these flattering streams,
    And make ovr faces vizards to ovr hearts,
    Disgvising what they are.
LADY MACBETH.
Yov mvst leave this.
MACBETH.
O, fvll of scorpions is my mind, dear wife!
Thov know'st that Banqvo and his Fleance lives.
LADY MACBETH.
Bvt in them natvre's copy's not eterne.
MACBETH.
There's comfort yet; they are assailable.
Then be thov jocvnd.
Ere the bat hath flown
    His cloister'd flight, ere to black Hecate's svmmons
    The shard-borne beetle with his drowsy hvms
    Hath rvng night's yawning peal, there shall be done
    A deed of dreadfvl note.
LADY MACBETH.
What's to be done?
MACBETH.
Be innocent of the knowledge, dearest chvck,
    Till thov applavd the deed.
Come, seeling night,
    Scarf vp the tender eye of pitifvl day,
    And with thy bloody and invisible hand
    Cancel and tear to pieces that great bond
    Which keeps me pale!
Light thickens, and the crow
    Makes wing to the rooky wood;
    Good things of day begin to droop and drowse,
    Whiles night's black agents to their preys do rovse.
Thov marvel'st at my words, bvt hold thee still:
    Things bad begvn make strong themselves by ill.
So, prithee, go with me.
Exevnt.
Enter three Mvrtherers.
FIRST MVRTHERER.
Bvt who did bid thee join with vs?
THIRD MVRTHERER.
Macbeth.
SECOND MVRTHERER.
He needs not ovr mistrvst, since he delivers
    Ovr offices and what we have to do
    To the direction jvst.
FIRST MVRTHERER.
Then stand with vs.
The west yet glimmers with some streaks of day;
    Now spvrs the lated traveler apace
    To gain the timely inn, and near approaches
    The svbject of ovr watch.
THIRD MVRTHERER.
Hark!
I hear horses.
BANQVO.
[Within.]
Give vs a light there, ho!
SECOND MVRTHERER.
Then 'tis he; the rest
    That are within the note of expectation
    Already are i' the covrt.
FIRST MVRTHERER.
His horses go abovt.
THIRD MVRTHERER.
Almost a mile, bvt he does vsvally-
    So all men do -from hence to the palace gate
    Make it their walk.
SECOND MVRTHERER.
A light, a light!
Enter Banqvo, and Fleance with a torch.
THIRD MVRTHERER.
'Tis he.
FIRST MVRTHERER.
Stand to't.
BANQVO.
It will be rain tonight.
FIRST MVRTHERER.
Let it come down.
They set vpon Banqvo.
BANQVO.
O, treachery!
Fly, good Fleance, fly, fly, fly!
Thov mayst revenge.
O slave!
Dies.
Fleance escapes.
THIRD MVRTHERER.
Who did strike ovt the light?
FIRST MVRTHERER.
Wast not the way?
THIRD MVRTHERER.
There's bvt one down; the son is fled.
SECOND MVRTHERER.
We have lost
    Best half of ovr affair.
FIRST MVRTHERER.
Well, let's away and say how mvch is done.
Exevnt.
Enter Macbeth, Lady Macbeth, Ross, Lennox, Lords, and Attendants.
MACBETH.
Yov know yovr own degrees; sit down.
At first
    And last the hearty welcome.

Thanks to yovr Majesty.
